Jovis, 21* die Jantiarii;

Anno 30° Georgii IIIm Regis, 1790.

Message to A M E S S A G E from His Majesty, by Sir

attend His ZA Francis Molyneux, Gentleman Usher of the

Majee* XX Black Rod:

Mr. Speaker,

The King commands this Honourable House to attend His Majesty, immediately, in the House of Peers.

Accordingly Mr. Speaker, with the House, went up to attend His Majesty.

And being returned;

Writs issued Mr. Speaker acquainted the House, That, in pur-in Recess. suance of the Directions of an Act, passed in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to repeal so much of " Two Acts, made in the Tenth and Fifteenth Years " of the Reign of His present Majesty, as authorizes the Speaker of the House of Commons to " issue his Warrants to the Clerk of the Crown, for " making out Writs for the Election of Members to serve in Parliament, in the Manner therein mentioned; and for substituting other Provisions for " the like Purposes," he had issued his Warrants to the Clerk of the Crown, to make out new Writs for the Election of Members to serve in Parliament for the following Places; viz. for the Borough of Morpeth, in the County of Noin the room of Peter Delmet Esquire, deceased; for the Borough of Bodmyn, in the County of Cornwall, in the room of Thomas Hunt, Esquire, deceased; and for the City of Litchfield, in the room of George Anson, Esquire, deceased.

Members Several Members, Fetumed upon new. Writs, took take Oatbr. 'the Oaths, and made and subscribed the Declaration, and took and subscribed the Oath of Abjuration, according1 to the Laws made for those Purposes; and such of the said Members as are by Law required to deliver in to die Clerk of this House an Account of

Vol, 45.

their Qualification, and to take and subscribe the Oath of Qualification, delivered in such Account, and took and subscribed the said Oath accordingly.

A Bill for the more effectual preventing Clandestine Outlawry Outlawries, was read the First Time. Bill read.

Resoloed, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Speaker reported, That the House had at- Mr. Speaker tended His Majesty in the House of Peers; where reports the His Majesty was pleased to make a most Gracious King’s Speech from the Throne to both Houses of Parlia- sPetch' ment; of which, Mr. Speaker said, he had, to prevent Mistakes, obtained a Copy; which he read to the House; and is as followeth; viz.

My Lords, and Gentlemen,

Since I last met you in Parliament, the Continuance of the War on the Continent, and the internal. Situation of different Parts of Europe, have been productive of Events which have engaged My most serious Attention.

While I see with a just Concern the Interruption of the Tranquillity of other Countries, I have at the same time great Satisfaction in being able to acquaint you, that I receive continued Assurances of the good Disposition of all Foreign Powers towards these Kingdoms; and I am persuaded that you will entertain with Me a deep and grateful Sense of the Favour of Providence in continuing to My Subjects the increasing Advantages of Peace, and the uninterrupted Enjoyment of those invaluable Blessings which they haie so long derived from Our excellent Constitution.

Gentlemen of the House of Commons,

I have given Directions that the Estimates for the present Year should be laid before you, and I rely on your Readiness to grant such Supplies as the Circumstances of the several Branches of the Public Service may be found to require.

My Lords, and Gentlemen,

The Regulations prescribed by the Act of the last Session of Parliament relative to the Com Trade, not having

Committee appointed to draw it up.

Resolved, Nemine Contradicente,

That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, to return His Majesty the Thanks of this House, for His most Gracious Speech from the Throne:

To assure His Majesty, that we participate in the just Concern with which His Majesty observes the Interruption of the Tranquillity of other Countries: That we at the same Time learn, with great Satisfaction, that His Majesty con times to receive Assurances of the friendly Disposition of Foreign Powers: That we entertain a deep and gratefill Sense of the Fayour of Providence towards these Kingdoms, In continuing to us the increasing Advantages of Peace, and the uninterrupted Enjoyment of these invaluable Blessings which we have so long derived from our excellent Constitution, and which we so happily experience under His Majesty's mild and auspicious Government:

That we shall proceed with Cheerfulness 4o make such Provision as may appear to be requisite for the several Branches of the Public Service:

To express our Sense of His Majesty’s Paternal Regard for the Welfare of His People, manifested in His Anxiety to prevent the further Exportation of Corn, and to facilitate the Importation under the Circumstances which His Majesty has been graciously pleased to communicate <to us; and to return His Majesty our Thanks for having been pleased to direct a Copy of the Order, issued by His Majesty by the Advice of His Privy Council, to be laid before Us:

To assure His Majesty, that we shall uniformly continue to apply ourselves with unremitting Assiduity and Zeal to those Objects of Public Concern which may require our Attention, and shall be at all Times desirous of adopting every proper Measure for maintaining the Public Revenue, and encouraging the Commerce and Manufactures of the Country, as being essentially connected with the general Prosperity of His Majesty’s Dominions.

Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to draw up an Address, to be presented to His Majesty upon the said Resolution.

And a Committee was appointed of the Lord tort, Mr. Cawthortie, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer,

Mr. Secretary Grenville, the Earl of Mornington, Lord Frederick Campbell, the Master of the Rolls, Mr. Wilberforce. Colonel Phipps, the Lord Belgrave, Mr. Hopkins, Mr. Hobart, Mr. Secretary at War,*Sir Howard, Mr. Rose, Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Steele, Mr. Beaufoy, Captain Berkeley, Mr. Eliot; or any Five of them: And they are to withdraw immediately into the Speaker’s Chamber.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 22° die Januarii;

Anno go* Georgii III" Regis, 1790.

Ordered, That the Grand Committee for Grievances do sit evpry Thursday in the Afternoon, in the House.

Ordered, That the Grand Committee for Courts of Justice do sit every Saturday in the Afternoon, in the House.

Ordered, That the Grand Committee for Trade do sit every Friday in the Afternoon, in the House.

Ordered, That a Committee of Privileges be ap- Committee of pointed. Privilege*

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. Gilbert, Mr. aPPoi,t*tl-Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Master of the Rolls,

Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Solicitor General, Mr.

Goddard, Mr. Wilberfot'ce, Mr. Rolle, Mr. Hopkins, the

Earl of Courtown, Sir George Augustus William Shuck-

burgh, Mr. Medley, the Lord Arden, the Lord tort, Mr. Ellis, Mr. Ord, Sir Edward , Mr. Plamer, Six William Young, Mr. Rose, Mr. Steele, Mr. Pitt,

Mr. Frederick Montagu, Mr. Alderman Sawbridge, Mr.

Smith, Mr. Cawihome, the Lord Hood, Sir Archibald Edmonstone, Mr. Gamon; and all the Gentlemen of the Long Robe: And they are to meet upon Monday Sevennight, at Seven of the Clock in the Afternoon, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and to sit every,

Friday, and Monday, in the Afternoon; and all who come are to have Voices; and they are to take into Consideration all such Matters as shall or may come in Question, touching Privileges; and to report their Proceedings, with their Opinion thereupon, to the House, from Time to Time; and the Committee are to have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records, for their Information; and, if any Thing shall come in Question touching the Matter of Privilege

» of

Other usual Orders made.

30 Geo. III. 22° Januarii. 5

of any Member, he is to withdraw during the Time the Matter is in Debate.

Ordered, That all Persons, who will question any Returns of Members to serve in Parliament, do question the same within Fourteen Days next, and so within Fourteen Days next after any new Return shall be brought in; and that all Members, who are returned for Two or more Places, do make their Election by this Day Three Weeks for which of the Places they will serve, provided there be no Question upon the Return for that Place; and, if any Thing shall come in Question touching the Return or Election of any Member, he is to withdraw during the Time the Matter is in Debate; and that all Members, returned upon Double Returns, do withdraw till their Returns are determined.

Resolved, That no Peer of this Realm hath any Right to give his Vote in the Election of any. Member to serve in Parliament.

Resolved, That if it shall appear that any Person hath procured himself to be elected or returned a Member of this House, or endeavoured so to be, by Bribery or any other corrupt Practices, this House will proceed with the utmost Severity against such Person.

Resolved, That, if it shall appear that any Person hath been tampering with any Witness, in respect of his Evidence to be given to this House, or any Committee thereof, or directly or indirectly hath endeavoured to deter or hinder any Person from appearing, or giving Evidence, the same is declared to be a High Crime and Misdemeanor; and this House, will proceed with the utmost Severity against such Offender.

Resolved, That, if it shall appear that any Person hath given false Evidence, in any Case, before this House, or any Committee thereof, this House will proceed with the utmost Severity against such Offender.

Resolved, That it is a high Infringement of the Liberties and Privileges of the Commons of Great Britain, for any Lord of Parliament, or any Lord Lieutenant of any County, to concern themselves in the Elections of Members to serve for the Commons in Parliament.

Resolved, That, in all Cases of Controverted Elections for Counties in England and Wales, the Petitioners do, by themselves or by their Agents, within a convenient Time, to be appointed by the House, deliver to the Sitting Members, or their Agents, Lists of the Persons intended by the Petitioners to be objected to, who voted for the Sitting Members; giving, in the said Lists, the several Heads of Objection, and distinguishing the same against the Names of the Voters excepted to; and that the Sitting Members do, by themselves or by their Agents, within the same Time, deliver the like Lists, on their Part, to the Petitioners or their Agents.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House do, from Time to Time, take into his Custody any Stranger, or Strangers, that he shall see, or be informed of to be, in the House, or Gallery, while the House, or any Committee of the whole House, is sitting; and that no Person, so taken into Custody, be discharged out of Custody without the special Order of the House.

Ordered, That the Back Door of the Speaker’s Chamber be locked up every Morning at the Sitting

Vol. 45.

of the House, and the Key delivered to the Clerk, to be locked up by him; and that he do not presume to deliver the same to any Person whatsoever without Order of the House; and that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House do take Care to clear the Speaker’s Chamber every Day before the Door is locked up.

Ordered, That no* Member of this House do presume to bring any Stranger, or Strangers, into the House; or Gallery thereof, while the House is sitting.

Ordered, That the Constables, and other Officers of Middlesex and Westminstet, do take Care, that, from Eleven of the Clock in the Morning till One in the Afternoon, -and from Four till Six in the Afternoon; during the Session of Parliament, the Passages through the Streets between Temple Bar and Westminster Hall shall be kept free and open; and that no Obstructions be made, by Cars, Drays, Carts, or otherwise, to hinder the Passage of the Members to and from this House; and that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House do give Notice of this Order to the Officers aforesaid.

Ordered, That the Constables in Waiting do take Care that there be no Gaming, or other Disorders, in Westminster Hall, or the Passages leading to the House, during the Sitting of Parliament; and that there be no Annoyance by Chairmen, Footmen, or otherwise, therein or thereabouts.

Ordered, That the said Orders be sent to the High Bailiff of Westminster; and that he do see the same put in Execution.

Ordered, That no Footman be permitted to be within the Lobby of the House, or upon the Stairs leading thereto.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House do take Care that there be no Gaming, of other Disorders, in the Room appointed for the Footmen attending the Members of this House to wait in.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do take into his Custody such Footmen as shall presume to disobey the Orders of the House; and that no such Footmen be discharged out of Custody but by the special Order of the House.

Ordered, That, to prevent the intercepting or losing of Letters directed to Members of this House, the Person appointed to bring Letters from the General Post Office to this House, or some other Person to be appointed by the Post Master General, do for the future, every Day during the Session of Parliament, Sundays excepted, constantly attend, from Ten of the Clock in the Morning till One in the Afternoon, and for Two Hours at the least immediately after the Rising of the House; and also from Five of the Clock in the Afternoon till Seven, at the Place appointed for the Delivery of the said Letters; and take Care, during his Stay there, to deliver the same to the several Members to whom they shall be directed, or to their known Servant or Servants, or others bringing Notes under the Hands of the Members sending for the saline.

Ordered, That the said Officer do, upon his going away, lock up such Letters as shall remain undelivered; and that no Letter be delivered but within the Hours aforesaid;

Ordered, That the said Ordeis be sent to the Post Master General.

Ordered, That when any Letter or Packet, directed

Winchester

Debtors Petition.

A Petition of the Debtors in the Common Gaol at Winchester, in the County of Southampton, was presented to the Mouse, and read; Complaining of their Distress; and praying Relief.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Koads°r°U^ Petition of the Trustees named and appointed in Petition. anc* by virtue of an Act of Parliament, made and passed in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for repairing the Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Ken-itett, to Sheppards Shord, and from the Hare and Hounds in Beckhampton, to the Top of Hill, and from the Town of Avebury, to the Cross Way at Beckhampton, in the County of Wilts, and for carrying into Execution an Act of the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers of the before mentioned Act, and for repairing and widening the Road from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wroaghton, and from the North Side of Swindon, to the Carpenters Arms, in Blunsden, in the said County, and also of many of the principal Landholders and Inhabitants residing in or near the said Roads, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Sum of 2,000 /. has been borrowed, and is now due, on the Credit of the Tolls granted by the said Acts, and the same hath been expended in the Reparation of the said Roads; and that the said Roads cannot be effectually kept in Repair, and the Money borrowed be repaid, unless the Terms and Powers of the said several Acts are further extended and enlarged; and that a Part of the present Road, of about Two Miles in Length, from near The Catherine Wheel Inn, at Beckhampton aforesaid, to the Top of Cherrill Hill, is very steep, and Travellers hdve been much incommoded by die full Force of the Winds passing over the high Downs there, whereby Carriages have been sometimes overturned; and that a commodious Road may be made, so as to avoid the great Ascent of the said Hill, either on the North or South Side thereof, and that if another new Line of Road was made, branching from out of the aforesaid Road, on the East of a Place called 1 'SheppardsShord, across the Down, to lead into Caine

Turnpike Road, at or near a certain House, called The Labour in Vain, the same would be of great Convenience and Advantage to the Neighbourhood, but such Alterations cannot be effected without a considerable Expence, which may make it necessary to borrow a further Sum on the Credit of the Tolls granted by the' said Acts: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to enlarge the Term, and to alter the Powers, of the said Acts,*and for such ether Relief in the Premises, as the House shall think fit.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir James Tylney Long, Mr. Goddard, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Point A Petition of the Right honourable Lord Monson,

Petition* Lord of the Manor of Pointon, in the County of Lincoln, and the humble Petition of several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Proprietors of Commonable Houses and Tottsteads, and of old inclosed Lands within the Parish of Pointon aforesaid, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are/ within the said Parish, a Common Cow Pasture, and also a Common Fen, over which the Petitioners, and others, are entitled to Right of Common; and that the said Vol. 45.

Cow Pasture and Fen, in their present Situation, are incapable of any considerable Improvement, but, if the same were divided and inclosed, and specific Allotments made to the Petitioners, and all other Persons interested therein, according to their respective Rights and Interests, the said Cow Pasture and Fen might be greatly improved: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Common Cow Pasture, and Common Fen, in such Manner, and subject to such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Calvert, Sir John Thorold, and Mr. Anderson Pelham, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for carrying into Norwich and Execution an Act of Parliament, of the Tenth Year of the Reign of His preseut Majesty, for amending 11 "* the Road from Saint Stephen's Gate, in the City of Nonvich, to Block Hill, in Trorwse,at the Angld where the Road divides, to Bixley and Kirby, in the County of Norfolk, and also of several of the Persons entitled to the Money due and owing upon the Credit of the said Act, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Road, great Part of which still remains due;’ and that the Term of the said Act is near expiring, and the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid cannot be paid off, and the said Road effectually amended and kept in good Repair, unless the Term of the said Act is enlarged: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term of the said Act for such further Time as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration ot a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Henry Hobart, Sir John Wodehouse, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to Loo« the Clerk of the Crown to make out a new Writ for the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of East Looe, in the County of Cornwall, in the room of Alexander Irvine, Esquire, deceased.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to Dorehestei the Clerk of the Crown, to make out a new Writ for Writ, the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of Dorchester, in the County of Dorset, in the room of Thomas Ewer, Esquire, deceased.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to Malmesbury the Clerk of the Crown, to make out a new Writ for the Writ, electing of a Burgess to servo in this present Parliament for the Borough of Malmesbury, in the County of Wilts, in the room of the Right honourable James Maitland, commonly called Lord Viscount Maitland, now Earl of Lauderdale, a Peer of Great Britain.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to St. German* the Clerk of the Crow'ii, to make out a new Writ for Writ, the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of Saint Germans, in the County of Cornwall, in the room of John James Hamilton,

Esquire,

8 22° — 23’

Esquire, now Lord Viscount , called up to the

House of Peers.

Address The Lord Valletort reported from the Committee,

reported, and appointed Yesterday to draw up an Address to be agreed to presented to His Majesty, That the Committee had drawn up an Address accordingly, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the same in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Most Gracious Sovereign#

We, Your Majesty’s most dutiful and loyal Subjects, the Commons of Great , in Parliament assembled, beg Leave to return Your Majesty our humble Thanks for Your most Gracious Speech from the Throne.

While we participate in the just Concern with which Your Majesty observes the Interruption of the Tranquillity of other Countries, we feel, at the same Time, the greatest Satisfaction in being informed that Your Majesty continues to receive Assurances of the friendly Disposition of Foreign Powers: And we entertain a deep and grateful Sense of the Favour of Providence to wards these Kingdoms, in continuing to us the increasing Advantages of Peace, and the uninterrupted Enjoyment of those invaluable Blessings which we have so long derived from our excellent Constitution, and which we so happily experience'under Your Majesty’s mild and auspicious Government.

Your Majesty may be assured, that we shall proceed with Chearfulness to make such Provision as may appear to be requisite for the several Branches of the Public Service.

We are duly sensible of Your Majesty’s Paternal Regard for the Welfare of Your People, which has been manifested in Your Anxiety to prevent the further Exportation of Corn, and to facilitate the Importation under the Circumstances which Your Majesty has been graciously pleased to communicate to us; and we desire humbly to return our Thanks to Your Majesty, for having been pleased to direct a Copy of the Order issued by Your Majesty by the Advice of Your Privy Council, to be laid before us.

We assure Your Majesty, that wie shall uniformly continue to apply ourselves, with unremitting Assiduity and Zeal, to those Objects of Public Concern which may require our Attention; and shall be, at all Times, desirous of adopting every proper Measure for maintaining the Public Revenue, and encouraging the Commerce and Manufactures of the Country, as being essentially connected with the general Prosperity of Your Majesty’s Dominions.

The said Address being read a Second Time;

Resolved, That this House doth agree with the Committee in the said Address to be presented to His Majesty.

Resolved, That the said Address be presented to His Majesty by the whole House.

Ordered, That such Members of this House as are of His Majesty’s most Honourable Privy Council, do humbly know His Majesty’s Pleasure, when He will be attended by this House.

King’s Ordered, That His Majesty’s most Gracious Speech

Sp«e«h to be to both Houses of Parliament be taken into Consideration considered. To.morrowMorning.

Mr. Secretary Grenville presented to the House, by His Majesty’s Command,

N* i. Copy of a Notice, published in the Quebec Gazette for Thursday, 12th February 1789, relating to the Importation of Corn and Grain into the Province of Quebec: And also,

N° 2. Copy of a Letter from the Right honourable Lord Dorchester to the Right honourable Lord;

dated Quebec, 14th February 1789: And also,

N° 3. Extract of a Letter from the Right honourable Lord Dorchester to the Right honourable Lord Sydney; dated Quebec, 14th March 1789: And also,

N° 4. Copy of a Letter from the Right honourable Lord Dorchester to the Right honourable Lord Sydney; dated Quebec, 11th April 1789: And also,

N° 5. Extract of a Letter from the Right honourable Lord Dorchester to the Right honourable Lord Sydney; dated Quebec, 6th June 1789: And also,

N° 6. Copy of an Order of His Majesty in Council, allowing an additional Quantity of Grain and Flour, not exceeding 750 Quarters, to be exported, from the Port of Southampton, to the Island of Jersey, for the Use of the Inhabitants and of His Majesty’s Troops stationed there, up to the 25th of December 1789; dated 11th November 1789: And also,

N° 7. Copy of an Order of His Majesty in Council, allowing an additional Quantity of 300 Sacks of Flour to be exported, from the Port of Southampton, to the Island of Guernsey, for the Use of the Inhabitants and of His Majesty’s Troops stationed there, up to the 25th of December 1789; dated 18th November 1789: And also,

N° 8. An Account of the Average Prices of Corn and Grain in London, Counties Inland, Counties on the Coast, and North and South Wales, for Ten Weeks, ended oth January 1790; as ascertained in pursuance of the Statute of the 10th Geo. III. Ch. 39.

And the Titles of the said Papers and Account were read.

Ordered, That the said Papers and' Account be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the Laws relating to the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Papers and Account be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The said Papers and Account are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Luna, 25* die Januarii;

Anno 30° Georgii III. U Regis, 1790, Praters.

MR. Speaker reported to the House, That the House attended His Majesty on Saturday last, with their Address; to which His Majesty was pleased to give this most Gracious Answer;

Gentlemen,

I thank you for your very loyal and dutiful Address. It is with great Satisfaction that I receive the repeated Expressions of your affectionate Attachment, and the Assurances of your continued Attention to those Objects Vol. 45.

which are essentially connected with the Happiness and Prosperity of My People.

Resolved, That this House will receive no Petitions for Time limited

Private Bills after the 5th Day of March next. for receiving

A Petition of William Henry , Esquire, Mr. Camp-

was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, bell’s Petition That a small Part of the Road leading from the Town j£0^n"dp a of Sudbury, and the Parish of Shelf in the County p°ot p"thg of Suffolk, to the Parish of Foxearth, in the County of &c.

Essex, and also small Parts of the Foot Paths leading from the Parish of Melford, through the Park and Grounds of the Petitioner, to the said Parish of Fox-earth, are inconvenient in many Respects to the Petitioner, who is willing, upon Condition that the said Road and Foot Paths be shut up and discontinued, to take upon himself to make a good Road for Carriages and Horses, from a Farm House called now in the Occupation of Charles Favre, to the Entrance into a certain Field, called Adams's Ley, in the Occupation of John Adams, and likewise to make a good Foot Path from a Stile in a Field, called Three Acres, in the Occupation of Roger Moss, to the West Corner of a Field called Foxearth Meadow, the Property of the Petitioner, and to oblige himself, his Heirs and Assigns, from Time to Time, to keep the said Road and Foot Way or Path in good and sufficient Repair, which Road and Foot Path will answer all the Purposes of the Road and Path intended to be shut up, and will be also advantageous to the Petitioner, and of no Inconvenience to the Public: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations and Restrictions as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Lord Frederick. Campbell, Sir Archibald Edmonstone, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Owners of Estates, and Hackney Inhabitants, within the Parish of Hackney, in the Church I'eti-County of Middlesex, whose Names are thereunto unsubscribed, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Church belonging to the said Parish is very ancient, much out of Repair, and very inadequate in Size to the Accommodation of the Inhabitants; and that it appears, on a Survey lately taken, that no material Enlargement can be made of the said Church without taking down, and re-building the same, and that, if it should be re-built on the present Foundation, it cannot be made to accommodate more than half the Number necessary to be provided for; and that the Scite of the present Churchj from its Proximity to the Turnpike Road, occasions great Obstructions thereon, more particularly since the opening of a Communication with Essex, and the Eastern Counties, by the Bridge over the River Lea, for all which Reasons it is expedient that a new Church, in a more convenient Situation, should be built; and that the present Church Yard, from the great Increase of Inhabitants, is become so full, as to make it absolutely necessary to take in more Ground to enlarge the same: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a’ Bill for the several Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations and Restrictions, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do'

A Petition of the Commissioners for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for paving, lighting, and cleansing the City of , and its

Suburbs, for preventing Annoyances therein, and for better ordering the public Wells and Pumps there, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have caused several Streets, and other public Passages within the Limits of the said Act, to be paved, lighted, and cleansed, and have made several Improvements, for the Benefit of the Inhabitants of the said City and Suburbs, and of all Persons resorting thereto; and that there are several public Roads leading through the said City and Suburbs, along which great Numbers of Carriages daily pass, and the Streets through which the said Roads lead are in many Parts very narrow, incommodious, and unsafe for Travellers and Passengers; and there are also several other Streets and Passages which are narrow and inconvenient to the Inhabitants, and to all Persons having Occasion to pass along the same, and no Power is given by the said Act to widen the said Streets or Passages; and that the Petitioners find the said Act defective in other Respects, and it is necessary that some Amendments and Alterations should be made therein, to enable them to improve the said City and Suburbs: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for widening such Parts of the said Streets and other Places, as shall be necessary for the Safety and Accommodation of Travellers, and of the Inhabitants of the said City and Suburbs, and for making such Amendments and Alterations in the scud Act as the House shall think necessary and proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the Honse:

And it is referred to the Lord Eardley, Mr. JYilmot, &c.: And they are to meet To-motrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, and others, of the County of whose Names

are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Bridges over the River Uske, at Newport and ,in the County of Monmouth, are ancient Wooden Structures, narrow and incommodious, and so far decayed, that it is necessary to take down the same; and it would be beneficial to the Inhabitants of the said County, and of public Utility, if good and sufficient Bridges odf Stone, or other durable Materials, were to be erected at the said Places: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid., by such Ways and Means, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. M, Mr. &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Persons whose Names are there- London Peti-under signed, being Manufacturers of Tobacco and tion against Snuff in the Port of London, on Behalf of themselves the Tobac*. and others, was presented to the House, and read; Act*

Setting forth, That, by an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereof," the Petitioners are subjected to the Laws of Excise; and that the said Act exposes Mysteries in their Trade of inestimable Value, which have been received in Patrimony, purchased, or acquired by long and laborious Application and Experiment, and which have hitherto been considered exclusive Property: That as in those Articles alone which are mysterious, the fair Trader can maintain a Competition with the Smuggler, the Petitioners apprehend it will not only injure them, but eventually prove detrimental to the Revenue — That it imposes Rules and Regulations on the Manufacture of the Article, which, in some Cases, are impracticable, and which, in many, cannot be complied with, without rendering the Goods unfit for their Customers, and, in Consequence, subjects the Petitioners to heavy and inevitable Forfeitures and Penalties — That by directing the Manufacture of a Parcel to be completed before any Part thereof can be sent out or sold, the Petitioners are occasionally, for many Days, prevented supplying their Customers, though all the Time in Possession of the Goods which are wanted — That it debars Manufacturers, who are not in Ports of Importation, from disposing of such Goods as they cannot make use of in their own Manufacture, to the Manufacturers who are in Ports of Importation, and who are, perhaps, the only Persons they can sell them to, without sustaining a considerable Loss — That it obliges many Manufacturers to alter their Modes of Manufacture^ to the great additional Expence and Inconvenience of such Manufacturers, as well as imminent Danger of the Loss of their Trade — That it prohibits the Removal of some Articles in less Quantities than 20olbs. Weight, which, in most Cases, are more than the Petitioners, at one Time, can dispone of to their Customers — That, upon Exportation of the Article, it requires a Return of Papers which cannot always be obtained, and otherwise very much discourages our Foreign Commerce of the Commodity —

That it gives, Power to a malicious Officer to almost ruin the Business of any principal Manufacturer —

When executed in the most lenient Manner, occasions Delays and Interruptions quite inconsistent with the Nature of Trade, and, in Consequence, not only affords greater Latitude to the Smuggler, by enhancing the Price of the fair Dealer’s Goods, but has a Tendency to drive the Manufacture of the Article out of this Kingdom — That for these, and many other Reasons of Objection, as well as from a fall Persuasion that no Modification of the Act will, in the End, benefit the Revalue, or relieve the fair Trader firom the Competition of the Smugglers, the Petitioners therefore pray. That the said Act may be repealed; and that, by themselves and Counsel, in Proof of their Allegations, they may be hoard at the Bar of the House.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the

30 Geo. III. 25° — 26* 11

" and for repealing so much of an Act, pussed in the " Sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, as relates to the repairing the Road leading from Wool " to the said Borough," whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have made a considerable Progress in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed several large Sums of Money, which, together with the Tolls collected, have been duly applied, but the Road by the said Act directed to be repaired (except so much thereof as leads from the Parish of Warmwell,through the Parishes of

Poxicell and Osmington, to the Church in the said Parish of Osmington, the Petitioners being discharged from the Repair thereof by an Act, made in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of His present Majesty) cannot be sufficiently amended, and the Money borrowed repaid, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are further continued, and the said Act amended and rendered more effectual: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, subject to such Provisions and Regulations as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Lionel Damer, Mr. Medley, &c.: And they are to meet To morrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Right honourable James Lord Malmesbury, and the humble Petition of the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Proprietors of or Persons interested in the intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures and Waste Lands, within the Manor and Parish of Dibden, in the County of Southampton, was

presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the said intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds are, in their present Situation, inconvenient to the Proprietors thereof, and the said Common Pastures and Waste Lands are, at present, of little Value, but if the same were divided into specific Shares, and allotted amongst the several Proprietors thereof, and Persons having Right of Common, or other Rights and Interests therein, io lieu of, and in Proportion to, their respective Rights and Interests, the same would be more convenient to them, and might be considerably improved: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for' dividing and allotting the said intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Lands, containing such Clauses, and under and subject to such Regulations and Orders, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Sloane and Mr. Marshum do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of Joseph F Esquire, William Fountaine, and John Lupton, Gentlemen, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That there are, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York, several Open and Uninclosed Fields, called Low Field, Kellbotton, South Field, Langriggs, and Fore-Lands, and other small Fields, which lie intermixed and undivided, containing together about 50 Acres, and also a Stinted Pasture, Vox.. 45.

called Linton Pasture, containing by Estimation 480 Acres, or thereabouts; and that the said Joseph Fountaine, William Fountaine, and John Lupton, and several other Persons, are Owners and Proprietors of the Lands and Grounds within the said Open Fields, and also Owners of the Cattle Gates on the said Stinted Pasture; and that the Lands and Grounds of the Proprietors,1 in the said Open Fields and Stinted Pasture, lie dispersed, and intermixed with each other, and are not, in their present Situation, capable of Improvement, for which Reason it would be greatly to the Advantage of the Parties concerned, if the same were divided and inclosed: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Open Fields and Stinted Pasture, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Lord George Cavendish, Mr. Wilberforce, and Mr. do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That the Report from the Committee of the Report from whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the Committee Motion made upon Saturday last, That a Supply be granted to His Majesty, be now received. Supply.

Mr. Henry Hobart accordingly reported from the said Committee, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Supply be granted to His Majesty.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time j

Resolved, Nomine Contradicente, That this House doth agree with the Committee in the said Resolution, That a Supply be granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning Committee next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole appointed. House, to consider of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Ordered, That an Estimate of the Ordinary of the Estimates, Navy for the Year 1790, with an Estimate of the Half Ac.ordered Pay of Officers of the Navy, and such of the Officers of >^lnary of the Marines as were employed in the last War, be laid avy' before this House.

Ordered, That an Estimate of the Charge of what Extra Navy, may be necessary for the Buildings, Re-buildings, and Repairs of Ships of War, in His Majesty’s Yards, and other extra Works, over and above what are proposed to be done upon the Heads of Wear and Tear and Ordinary, for the Year 1790, be laid before this House.

Ordered, That an Estimate of the Charge for Guards, Guards and Garrisons, and other Land Forces, for the Year 1790, Garrisons, be laid before this House.

Ordered, That an Estimate of the Charge of the Ordnance. Office of Ordnance for Land Service, for the \ ear 1790, be laid before this House.

Ordered, That a List of the Regimental and Warrant Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s Land Forces, and of such of Officers, the Officers of the Marines, as were reduced before the last War, who are to be on Half Pay for the Year 1790, be laid before this House.

Ordered, That an Estimate of the Charge of Out- Chelsea Out-Pensioners of Chelsea Hospital, for the Year 1790, be Pensioners, laid before this House.

Ordered, That an Account of Services incurred, Services not and not provided for by Parliament, be laid before this provided for. House.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Disposition Account, shewing how the Monies, given for the Service of Grants, of the Year 1789, have been disposed of; distinguished under their several Heads.

Mr. Burges accordingly reported from the said Committee, That He was directed by the Committee td ihove the House, that, in order to facilitate the Progress of this Committee in the Matters referred to them, the House will be pleased to appoint a Committee for the Purpose of taking- the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade.

And Mr. Burges moved the House accordingly.

Ordered^That, in order to facilitate the Progress of the said Committee in the Matters referred to them, a Committee be appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. force, Mr. Gascoyne, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Lord Penhryn, Mr. Secretary Grenville, Mr. John Scott, Mr. Fox, Mr. Sloane, the Marquis of Graham, Mr. Mar sham, Sir William Mr. Alderman

Newnhart}, the Lord Belgrave, Mr. Alderman Saw-bridge, Mr. William Smith, Sir Grey Cooper, Sir Charles Middleton, Mr. Alderman Watson, Mr. Matthew Montagu, Mr. Bedford, Mr. Fitzpatrick, Sir Watkin Lewes, Mr. Martin, Mr. Cruger, Mr. Burke, Mr. Brickdale, Mr. Beaufoy, Mr. Blackburne, Mr. , Sir John

Trevelyan, the Earl of Mornington, Mr. Stanley, Mr. Edwards, Mr. Alderman Le Mr. Eliot, Mr.

Thornton, Mr. Deoaynes, Mr. Villiers, Mr. Gamon, Mr. Burges, Mr. Estwick, Mr. Rooke, Mr. Henniker, General Burgoyne, Mr. MolyneMr. Whitbread, Mr. Tudway, Mr. Windham, Mr. Grigby, Mr. the Lord Muncaster, Sir William Young; and all the Gen-

tlemen of the Long Robe, and Merchants in the House; and all the Members who serve for the Counties of Northumberland \Durham, York, . Nor-

folk, Suffolk, Essex, Kent, Sussex, Hants, Dorset, Devon, Cornwall, Somerset, Glamorgan, Carmarthen, Pembroke, Cardigan, Merioneth, Carnaivon, Anglesey, Flint, Denbigh, Chester, Lancaster, Westmoreland, and Cumberland: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records; and all who come to the Committee are to have Voices.

Ordered, That the said Committee do, from Time to Time, report the Minutes of such Examination to the House.

Ordered, That the several Petitions, Minutes of Evidence, Reports, Accounts, and Papers, which have been referred to the said Committee of the whole House, be transferred to the Committee now appointed.

Ordered, That Five be the Quorum of the said Committee.

Mr. Burges also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the said Committee of the whole House to move, that they may have Leave to sit

again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Sevennight, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Renfrew, Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to Glasgow, fee. the Clerk of the Crown, to make out a new Writ for Writ. the electing of a Commissioner to serve in this present Parliament for the District of Burghs of Renfrew, Glasgow, Rutherglen, and Dumbarton, in the room of the Right honourable Ilay Campbell, Lord Advocate of Scotland, who, since his Election for the said. District Vol. 45.

of Burghs, hath accepted' the Office of Lord President of the CoUrt of Session in Scotland.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

The House met, and being counted by Mr. Speaker, House adit appeared that Forty Members were not present; joumed. yet, it being Four of the Clock, Mr. Speaker took the Chair; and, having again counted the House, and it appearing that Forty Members were not present, Mr. Speaker adjourned the House, without a Question first put, till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 29* Januarii; Anno 30* Georgii III*" Regis, 1790.

Prayers.

THE Earl of Courtown reported to the House, Answer to That their Address of Wednesday last (that His Addregs- Majesty would be graciously pleased to give Directions to the proper Officers, that the Estimates, Lists, and Accounts therein mentioned, might be laid before this House) had been presented to His Majesty; and that His Majesty had commanded him to acquaint this House, that He will give Directions accordingly.

Mr. Secretary at War presented to the House, pursuant to their Address to His Majesty,

Estimate of the Charge of Guards, Garrisons, and other His Majesty’s Land Forces in Great Bi'itain, Guernsey, and Jersey, from 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 3G5 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of His Majesty’s Forces in the Plantations, including those in Garrison at Gibraltar, and a Corps of Foot in New South Wales, from 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 36 5 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of the General and General Staff Officers in Great Britain, for the Year 1790.

Mr. Secretary at War also presented to the House, by His Majesty’s Command,

Estimate of the Charge of One Regiment of Light Dragoons, and Nine Regiments of Foot, for Service in East India, for the Year 1790, being 365 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of Additional to the Regiment of Light Pragoons serving in East India, and of Nine Recruiting Companies belonging to Regiments of Foot on the like Service, from the 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of the Allowance to the Paymaster General of His Majesty’s Land Forces; to the

Secretary at War; to the Commissary General of the Musters; to the Judge Advocate General; to the Comptrollers of the Accompts of the Army; of the Amount of Exchequer Fees to be paid by the Paymaster General; and on Account of Poundage to be returned to the Infantry, for the Year 1790: And also.

Estimate of the Charge of Full Pay to Supernumerary Officers of His Majesty’s Forces, from 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both Days inclusive, being 365 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of the Difference between the British and Irish Establishments of Seven Battalions of Foot, serving in North America and the West Indies, from the 25th December 1789 to the 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay and Allowances to the Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s Land Forces and Marines, for the Year 1790: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay and Allowances to the Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s American Forces, for the Year 1790: And also,

Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay to the Reduced Officers of the late Scotch Brigade, in the Service of the States General, for the Year 1790: And also, Estimate of the Charge of a Corps of Foot for Service in New South Wales, under the Command of Major Francis Grose, from the 5th Day of June 1789 to the 24th Day of December following, both inclusive, being 203 Days: And also.

Estimate of the Charge of Recruiting His Majesty’s Land Forces, and of the Contingencies of the said Forces, for the Year 1790.

And the Titles of the said Estimates were read.

War Office,

29th January 1790.

Geo. Yonge.

Memorandum:

By the Act passed in the Year 1781, intituled, "An Act for establishing an Agreement with the United " Company of Merchants of England trading to the East Indies, &c." the East India Company are required to pay a certain Sum of Money, which is specified in the said Act, in Proportion to the Number of Troops sent or to be sent to the East Indies on the Requisition of the said Company. — This Sum the said Company claim, under the Words of the Act, a Right of paying in the East Indies only: And, as it will be necessary to provide for the Subsistence of’ the Additional recruiting for the Regiment of Light Dragoons, and of the Recruiting Companies remaining in Great Britain, there will be wanting at present for this Purpose the Sum of 11,435/. 12*. 10 \d.;which it will be necessary to vote on Account of the above Estimate.

Vol. 4

G

East India Troops.

Ordered, That the said Estimates do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The House being informed that Mr. Jennings, from the Exchequer, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

An Account of the Amount of the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising a certain " Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the

Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred " Eighty-nineAnd also,

An Account of the Amount of the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising a further Sum of Mon*y, by Loans or Exchequer Bins, for the " Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and " Eighty-nine."

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

The said Accounts are as followeth; viz.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

An ACCOUNT of the Amount of the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising a certain Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer " Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-nine."

The Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for raising a certain Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, amount to the Sum of

Three Millions Five hundred thousand Pounds.

Exchequer, the 29th Day of January 1790.

Rob' Jennings.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

An ACCOUNT of the Amount of the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising a further Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer " Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-nine.

The Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for raising a further Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, amount to the Sum of - - - - Two Millions.

Exchequer, the 29th Day of January 1790.

Rob' Jennings.

Mr. Buncombe presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields in the Township of Burton Leonard, in the County of York: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Henry Hobart and Sir John JVodehouse do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of several of the Feoffees of certain Estates and Hereditaments applicable, amongst other

several other Persons, are Owners and Proprietors of the Messuages, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments entitled to Right of Common on the said Moors, Commons, or Waste Grounds; and that the said Moors, Commons, or Waste Grounds, are not, in their present Uses, to the Repairs of the Church of the Parish of Situation, capable of Improvement, nor can be occupied

to such Advantage as they might be, if the same were divided and inclosed, and specific Parts thereof allotted to the several Persons interested therein, according to their respective Rights, and if the Tythable Lands and Tenements were exempted from the Payment of Tythes, upon Compensation being made for the same: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Moors, Commons, or Waste Grounds, in such Manner ds to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Sir James Pennyman and Mr. John Smyth do prepare.

Saint Thomas, in the City of Bristol, and also of the Vicar, Churchwardens, Vestry, and others, whose Names are thereto subscribed, Inhabitants of the said Parish, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Church belonging [to the said Parish is in a very ruinous State, and incapable of being repaired, and that, when the same shill be taken down for the Purpose of re-building it, it is probable that it will be necessary likewise to re-build the Tower which is contiguous thereto; and that, there being no Fund adequate to the Expence thereof, the same cannot be carried into Effect without the Aid of Parliament: And therefore praying, That

Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for taking down, and bring in, the same, and re-building, the said Church and Tower, or so much thereof as may be necessary, in such Manner, A Petition of the Proprietors, Owners, and Occu- Ouse Nsvi-

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they have Power to permit the Petitioners against the Abolition of the Slave Trade to appear, by their Counsel, before the said Committee, for the Purpose of examining such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the said Petitioners in support of their Petitions.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for indemnifying all Persons who have been concerned in advising, or carrying into Execution, certain Orders of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain, and also, certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in Consequence of the same, and for making further Provisions relative thereto: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Captain Berkeley presented to the House, pursuant Ordnance

Ordered, That the said Estimate do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he, was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole

30 Geo. III. 29° Januarn. — 1° Februarii. 33

whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Papers re* Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer presented to the lating to the House, by His Majesty’s Command,

Sresented* ' Export of a Committee of the General As-

presen . sembly of the Island of Barbadoes upon the several v Heads of Enquiry, &c. relative to the Slave Trade, received from John Brathwaite, Esquire, Agent for the said Island: And also,

N° 2. Letter from Mr. Burges, inclosing Translation of a Portuguese Law of the Year 1648, relative to the Treatment of Slaves, &c. received from the Honourable Robert Walpole, His Majesty’s Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to her most Faithful Majesty; and also inclosing Extract of a Letter from George Baldwin, Esquire, His Majesty’s Consul General in Egypt, transmitting a Memorial on the Subject of the Slave Trade carried on there: And also,

N° 3. Translation of the above-mentioned Portuguese Law: And also,

N* 4- Extract of the said Letter from Mr. Baldwin, inclosing a Memorial on the Subject of the Slave Trade: And also,

N° 5. Copy of the said Memorial.

Together with a List of the said Papers.

And the said List was read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Papers be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Papers be referred to the Committee who are appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade.

The said Papers are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

Westminster Hall.

Mr. Henry Hobart presented to the House, accord- nierbaum's ing to Order, a Bill for naturalizing Julius George Nilt- Bl1' Bterbaum: And the same was received; and read the Presente First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Mayor, Bailiffs, and Commonalty Petition in of the City of Coventry, was presented to the House, Favour of and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners find streets*BilI-Application hath been made to the House for Leave and for ad-’ to bring in a Bill for amending an Act, made in the ditional Pro-Third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for vision, paving, lighting, and cleansing the City of Coventry, and its Suburbs, for preventing Annoyances therein, and for better ordering the public Wells and Pumps there, and for making other Improvements in the said City and Suburbs; and Alledging, That it would be of Benefit and Safety to all Persons residing in, or resorting to, the said City and Suburbs, if effectual Provision was made for widening such of the Streets and other public Passages therein as are narrow and inconvenient, and for making proper Foot Paths in certain Parts thereof, and for paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the said Streets, and other public Passages, and removing and preventing all Obstructions, Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances in and near the same: And therefore praying, That a Bill may be permitted to be brought in for effectuating the several Purposes aforesaid, by such Ways and Means, and in such Manner, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to w hom the Petition of the Commissioners for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for paving, lighting, and cleansing the City of Coventry, and its Suburbs, for preventing Annoyances therein, and for better ordering the public Wells and Pumps there, is referred:

And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it slia.ll appear to them, to the House.

Luna 1° die Februarii; Anno 30* Georgii III'1* Regis, 1790.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Leicester thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Trustees for executing an Act passed in the e l* Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, intituled, "An Act " for repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester and WelfordTurnpike Road, in the Counties " of Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to " the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby de la Zouch, in the said County of ," was

presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have made great Progress hi repairing and widening the said Road, and have incurred a considerable Debt on the Credit of the said Act, which cannot be paid off, nor the said Road be properly amended, widened, and kept in Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are altered and enlarged:

And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations and Restrictions as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. HungeMr. Pochin, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Seamen.

1° Februarii. A, 1790.

Mr. Shane presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and allotting the intermixed or Commonable Lands ana Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Lands, within the Manor and Parish of Dibden, in the County of Southampton: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir James Pennyman presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and inclosing the several Moors, Commons, or Waste Grounds, called wick Common, Huby CommonWescoehill Common, and JVeeton Green, within the Manor and Parish of Hare-wood, in the County of York: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Morgan reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, and others, of the County of Monmouth, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 23d of May 1786, relative to Bills for erecting Bridges, had been complied with, in respect to the Notice directed to be affixed on the Door of the Sessions House of the County; but that there was not Time to call a County Meeting after it was found necessary to apply to Parliament, so as to give the Notices within the Time required, the County Meeting being held on the 18th of September, and the Notices were given in The Gloucester Journal of the 28th of September, and the 5 th and 12th of last; and

that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition; and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, a Member present informed your Committee, That the Bridges over the River Uske, at Newport and Caerleon, in the County of Monmouth,are ancient Wooden Structures,

narrow and incommodious, and so far decayed that it is necessary to take them down, and rebuild them of Stone or other durable Materials.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for re-building the Bridges over the River Uske, at Newport and Caerleon, in the County of Monmouth: And that Mr. Morgan, General Rooke, and the Marquis of Worcester, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Lord George Cavendish presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields, and a Stinted Pasture, called Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Bill for naturalizing Gotthbb Gotthelff Schuster* was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Alderman Le Mesurier, Mr. Cruger, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Twenty thousand Men be employed for the Sea Service, for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and

Ninety, including Three thousand Eight hundred and Sixty Marines.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Sum for That a Sum, not exceeding Four Pounds per Man per Scamen-Month, be allowed for maintaining the said Twenty thousand Men for Thirteen Months, including Ordnance for Sea Service.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally, put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Committee Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the and

whole House, to consider of Ways and Means for raising p0in°edap* the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for Marine Mu-the Regulation of His Majesty’s Marine Forces while tinyBiUor-on Shore: And that Mr. Stephens, Mr. Hopkins, and dered-the Lord Hood, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Thursday Mom- Duties on ing next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole ^"be^oiTT* House, to consider of the Duties payable upon Tin derej COim* exported.

Ordered, That Mr. Pye, Mr. Hawkins Browne, and Members Mr. Sumner, be added to the Committee who are ap- added f° pointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of on the Abo-such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the lition of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against Slave Trade, the Abolition of the Slave Trade.

The other Order of the Day being read, for the Committee House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole of Supply. House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty;

Ordered, That the Account of the Amount of the Accounts of Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in ®*'heiuer the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for BlUsre erre " raising a certain Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand " Seven hundred and Eighty-nine," be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Account of the Amount of the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act " for raising a further Sum of Money, by Loans or " Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One " thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-nine," be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to, His Majesty.

The House being informed that Mr. Smith, from Richmond the Commissioners of Richmond Bridge, attended at the Bridge Ca»h Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to Accounts the House, pursuant to the Directions of an Act of Presented-Parliament,

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Papers were read.

Ordered, That the said Papers do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Papers are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Corn Indem- A Bill for indemnifying all Persons who have been nity concerned in advising, or carrying into Execution, cer-

comnutted. Qr(jers of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain, and also, certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in Consequence of the same, and for making further Provisions relative thereto, was read a Second Time.
