Kensington, A Petition of the Trustees for putting in Execution Chelsea, and an Act of Parliament, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing several tition. Roads in the Parishes of Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, and other Parishes therein mentioned, in the County of Middlesex, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Road leading from Hyde Park Comer to Counter's Bridge, and several other Roads adjoining or near to the same, are, by the said Act, put under the Care and Management of the Petitioners, with Power to light and water certain Parts only of the said Roads, and to pave the Carriage Way of the High Street, in the Town of Kensington, ana Provision is made, by the same Act, for paving the Foot Paths on the Sides of the said Carriage Way, and for lighting and watching the said High Street, and certain other Parts of the said Town; and that a very considerable Sum of Money hath been borrowed, and is now due, on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads, and the said Tolls are also charged with the Payment of 1,000l. per Annum to the Commissioners for paving the Streets within the City and Liberty of Westminster, to enable them to keep in Repair Part of the Street or Road called Piccadilly, from Clarges Street to Hyde Park Comer, and from the South End of Park Lane to the North End of Hertford , which were heretofore

Vo i*. 45.

under the Management of the Petitioners; and that Robberies, and other Outrages, are frequently committed upon the said Roads in the Night Time, which the Petitioners apprehend might, in a great Measure, be prevented, if the Whole of the said several Roads were properly lighted and watched, and it would be a great Convenience to Travellers if the said Roads were properly watered; and Representing to the House, That only a small Part of the Term of the said Act is now unexpired, and that the Produce of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads is insufficient to enable the Petitioners to pay the said Annual Sum of 1,000l. and the Interest of the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid, and effectually to amend and widen the said Roads and Foot Paths, and keep the same in Repair, and to light, watch, and water the said Roads, and unless the Term of the said Act be enlarged, and some of the Tolls thereby granted increased, and some further Powers are given to the Petitioners, the several Purposes aforesaid cannot be effected; and that a small Part of a certain Lane in Kensington, called Church Lane, is not included in the said Act, and a new Road, called Sloane Street, hath been made from the Great Western Road at Knightsbridge, into the Road adjoining to the Burial Ground belonging to Chelsea Hospital, and it would be of public Benefit and Convenience if such Part of Church Lane as aforesaid, and also the said new Road, called Sloane Street, were put under the Care and Management of the Petitioners for the repairing, lighting, watching, and watering the same, and if Provision was made for repairing the several Foot Paths on the Sides of the said several Roads; and that, in order to widen certain Parts of the said Roads, it will be necessary to take down certain Houses, and other Buildings, situate between the Church Yard of Kensington and the Charity School on the North Side of the Great Western Road in Kensington, and a Public Hotise, called The Half-way House, situate between Knightsbridge and the Town of Kensington, and to take in, and add to, the said Road, such Gardens, Nurseries, Orchard, and other Grounds, as shall be necessary for that Purpose, and the Petitioners apprehend it would tend to the Preservation of the said Roads if some Restriction was laid upon erecting Buildings on new Foundations within a certain Distance thereof; and that frequent Complaints are made of the bad State and Condition of the Pavement in such Part of Piccadilly as aforesaid, and the Petitioners apprehend it would be of public Utility if some Provision was made for better repairing the same, or they were empowered to take the said Road again under their Care and Management; and that frequent Disputes have'arisen from the present Mode of collecting certain Tolls authorized to be received on the said Roads upon Sundays by the said Commissioners for paving the Streets within the pity and Liberty of Westminster, which the Petitioners apprehend might be prevented, if the Collection of such Tolls were put under their Care and Management for the future: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing’ the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of the said Act, and for making such Increase in the Tolls payable by virtue of the said Act, and effecting the several other Purposes before-mentioned, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Mainwaring, Mr. Alderman Wilkes, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition

36 2° Februarii. A. 1790.

Ro ton and A Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution Wondesford an Act of Parliament, passed in the Fifth Year of the Bridge Road Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for Petition*. enlarging the Terms and Powers of several Acts of " the Ninth and Twelfth Years of Queen , and of " the Thirteenth of King George the First, and of the " Fourteenth of his late Majesty, for repairing the Highways leading from Roy in the County of " to Wandesford Bridgein the county of,

" so far as relates to the Middle and South Divisions " of the Road comprized in the said Acts, and for amending the Road from the Town of Huntingdon to " the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town " of Somerskam, in the said County of ,"

was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees have proceeded to put the said Act in Execution, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which still remains due; and that the Term of the said Act is near expiring, and the Money borrowed cannot be repaid, and the said Road kept in good Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be further continued, and some Amendments and Alterations made therein: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of the said Act, by such Ways and Means, and in such Manner, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Yorke, Mr. Call, &c: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Terms and Powers of several Acts of the Ninth and Twelfth Years of Queen Anne, and of the Thirteenth of King George the First, and of the Fourteenth of his late Majesty, for repairing the Highways leading from Royston, in the County of Hertford, to Wandesford Bridge, in the County of Huntingdon, so far as relates to the Middle Division of the Road comprized in the said Acts, and so far as relates to the amending the Road from the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town of Somersham, in the said County of Huntingdon, was also presented to the House, and read; containing the same Allegations and Prayer as the last preceding Petition.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the last preceding Petition is referred: And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

Macclesfield A Petition of several Persons, whose Names are p0ftd thereunto subscribed, being Trustees for putting into

etition. Execution an Act of Parliament^ made in the Tenth

Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, King George the Third, intituled, "An Act for repairing, widening,

" and altering the Road from Macclesfield in the County " of Chester, to the Turnpike Road at Randle Carr " Lane Head, in Femilee, in the County of Derby,

" leading to Chapel in the Frith," was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees named in the said Act caused the Road therein mentioned to be made and repaired, and borrowed, upon the Credit of the Tolls by the said Act granted, the Sum of 4,100l., which was expended in making and repairing the said Road, and erecting several Bridges thereon, and the Sum of 4,100l. and upwards now remains owing: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to enlarge the Term ana Powers of the said Act, in such Manner, and with such Powers, and under such Terms and Restrictions, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Crewe, Mr. &c.:

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Bloxam reported from the Committee, to whom Schusler's

the Bill for naturalizing Gottlob Gotthelff , was Nat- Bill

committed; That the Committee had examined the rePorted-Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had directed him to report the Bill to the House, without any Amendment: And he delivered the Bill in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the Bill be ingrossed.

Mr. Hopkins, from the Commissioners for executing Estimate* of the Office of Lord High Admiral of Great Britain, Ordinary,

?resented to the House, pursuant to their Address to Ext*’a of lis Majesty, *25/

The Ordinary Estimate of His Majesty’s Navy, for the Year 1790: And also,

An Estimate of the Charge of what may be necessary for the Buildings, Re-buildings, and Repairs of Ships of War, in His Majesty’s and the Merchants Yards, and other Extra Works, over and above what are proposed to be done upon the Heads of Wear and Tear, and Ordinary, for the Year 1790.

And the Titles of the said Estimates were read.

The Ordinary Estimate of His Majesty’s Navy is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session; and the Abstract thereof, and the other Estimate, are as followeth; viz.

On WORKS of the Yards:

To complete the Walls of the Outer Mast Pond, and the returned Wharf on the West Side of the Mast House Slip, the Dwarf Wall in Front of the said Slip, and 210 Feet of the Wharf Wall, North Side the Inner Mast Pond -

To complete the remaining Part of the Floor of the New Laying House To complete the Building of the New Rope House -To building Two Mast Houses, with a Slip to join the New Tophouse

To carry on the Stone Wharf and South Pier to the New Dock proposed -To carry on the Works at the North Side of the Reservoir -

To too Feet running of Stone Wharf, in the Boat House Canal ——

To 360 Feet running of Dwarf Stone Wharf to the Mast House Slip -To building Two Storehouses and Cabins at the South End of the Officers Lodgings -

To complete the Dam between the Wharf at the Landing Hulk and North Side of the South Dock Towards building a New Boat Storehouse on the New Ground - -

To blowing and levelling the Rock of White House Hill and the Mast Pond.

To digging away the Rock behind the New Rigging House. ——

To digging the Rock and Rubble round the Head of the New Dock and North Part of the Yard ——

To completing the Joiner’s and House Carpenter’s Shops and Clock House ——

To completing the laying of the Mast House Slip with Purbeck Pitchers - .-

To joining and carrying on the Wharfs that front the Harbour on each Side of the New Dock -

To extending the present North Jetty Head ——

To building and completing a Jetty Head at the North Side of the New Dock ——

To carrying on the East Cross New Storehouse ——

To building a Pitch House, Store Cabin, Ocham House, &c. ——

To complete the New Rigging House ——

To digging away the Rock at the North Part of the Yard, and clearing the Ground for building the Armourers and Plumbers Shops, Engine House, &c. ——

To building a Wall, digging and blowing away the Rock, &c. between the East Side of the Mast Pond and West Rope House, for forming the Road in Front of the Plank Houses ——

To completing the New Team Stables.

2° Februarii. A. 1790.

Norwich and Watton Road Petition.

30 Geo. III. 2°

43

Ordered, That the said Estimates do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

A Petition of the Debtors in His Majesty's Gaol the Castle of York, was presented to the House, and read; Complaining of their Distress, and praying Relief.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Sum of Three Millions Five hundred thousand Pounds be granted to His Majesty, for paying off and discharging the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising a certain Sum " of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the

" Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred

and Eighty-nine," and charged upon the first Aids to be granted in the next Session of Parliament.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Sum of Two Millions be granted to His Majesty, for paying off and discharging the Exchequer Bills made out by virtue of an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising " a further Sum of Money, by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand

" Seven hundred and Eighty-nine," and charged upon the first Aids to be granted in the next Session of Parliament.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Owners and Proprietors of Lands in the Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of Polebrook, in the County of Northampton, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Lands of the Petitioners and others in the said Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, lie intermixed and dispersed in small Parcels, and are, in their present Situation, incapable of any considerable Improvement, and that, if the same were divided and inclosed, it would be very advantageous to the Parties interested therein: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations as the House shall direct

Ordered, Tlmt Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Hungerford, Sir James and Mr. Powys, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for carrying into Execution an Act of Parliament of the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the County of the City of Norwich, to the Windmill in the Town of Walton, in the County of Norfolk, and also of several of the Persons entitled to the Money due and owing upon the Credit of the said Act, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That the Trustees have caused the said Road to be amended and put into good Repair, and hare borrowed a considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Road, great

Vol 45.

Part of which still remains due; and that the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid cannot be paid off, and the said Road supported and kept in good Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be enlarged; and that the Petitioners apprehend it may be necessary to vary some of the Powers of the said Act: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term of the said Act, and making such Alterations therein as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the -House:

And it is referred to Sir John Wodehouse, Sir Edward Astley, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of Land, OuseNaviga-Merchants, Traders, and others, interested in the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Newhaven to httVen to B*ar-Barcombe Mill,in the County of Sussex, w as presented combe Mill.) to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the River Ouse is at present navigable, from Newhaven to Bar-combe Mill aforesaid, for small Barges, and that, by widening, deepening, and rendering strait the Current of the said River, the same may be made navigable for Vessels of a larger Burthen, whereby the Trade and Commerce upon the said River will be considerably increased, and the Public in general greatly benefited: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to improve the Navigation of the said River Ouse, from Newhaven to Barcombe Mill aforesaid, in such Manner, and by such Ways and Means, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the Jlouse:

And it is referred to Mr. Thomas Pelham, Mr. Kemp,

&c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons, whose Names are North thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves, and Collingham others, Owners of Estates within the Parish of North Collingham, in the County of Nottingham, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Lands and Grounds of the several Proprietors of the Open Arable Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and Waste Lands, in the said Parish, being greatly intermixed, are subject on that Account to frequent Trespasses and great Inconveniences, and cannot, in their present Situation, be improved in the Manner they might be, if divided and inclosed, or allotted in Severalty, and the Enjoyment thereof regulated, and certain Parts thereof well and sufficiently embanked against the River Trent: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Pierrepont and Lord Edward Bentinck do prepare,

and bring in, the same.

A Petition of Charles Pierrepont, Esquire, the Reve- Cotgrave rend Pierrepont Cramp, Clerk, William Morris, Thomas J}nclo3Ure Morris, ana others, Proprietors of Lands, and Persons Petltl0D-interested in the Messuages, Cottages, Old Inclosures,

Open Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and

Waste

44 2° — 3° Februarii. . 1790.

Waste Grounds, lying in the Manor and Parish of Cotgrave, in the County of Nottingham, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have appointed Commissioners who have divided, allotted, and exchanged several of the said Messuages, Cottages, Inclosures, Open Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and Waste Grounds, within the said Lordship, which will be a great Improvement to the Estates of the Petitioners and others interested therein: And therefore praying, That Leave may be

S'ven to bring in a Bill to confirm and establish the ivision, Allotments, and Inclosure of the Open Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and Waste Grounds, lying in the said Parish, and also several Exchanges of Property within the same, in such Manner as to the House may seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Gilbert and Lord Edward Bentinck do prepare, and bring in, the same.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Mercurii, 3° die Februarii Anno 30* Georgii IIP11 Regis, 1790.

Bierbaum

sworn.

Praters.

JULIUS George Bierbaum took the Oaths appointed, in order to his Naturalization.

Mr. Camp- Lord Frederick Campbell reported from the Com-btlTsl'eiitioa mitiee, to whom the Petition of William Henry Camp-reported. Esquire, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the said Petition is not within the Standing Orders of the House relative to Turnpike Bills, it being only for shutting up a Road and Foot Paths, and opening others; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Thomas Corder being examined, said, That he knows the Road and Foot Paths described in the Petition, the latter of which lead through the Park and Grounds of Mr. Campbell the Petitioner — That the said Road is in Length about 140 Rods, and the Foot Paths about 100 Rods, the Use of which as a public Road and Foot Paths is very inconvenient to Mr. Campbell, who is willing, in case the same are shut up and discontinued, to make another Road and Foot Path in the Line described in the Petition, and to keep the same in Repair, which will be more convenient to the Public than the old Road and Foot Paths — That the new Road will be about Ten Rods farther, and the Foot Path about Twenty Rods nearer; but that the said Road may be easily made a better Road than the old one, and gone over in less Time.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to empower 'William Henry Campbell, Esquire, to shut up a

Road and Foot Paths in the Parish of Liston, in the County of Essex, and to oblige him to make, and keep in Repair for the future, another Road and Foot Path in lieu thereof: And that Lord Frederick Campbell wad Sir Archibald Edmonstone do prepare, and bring In, the same.

Mr. Hungerford reported from the Committee, to Leicester and whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names re°.ai1

are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and ported. others, Trustees for executing an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, intituled, An Act for " repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester " and Trelford Turnpike Road, in the Counties of " Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to the

" Turnpike Road leading from Hinckly to Ashby de la " Zouch, in the said County of ," was re-

ferred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Robert Hubbard, being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed the Sum of 1,200/ on the Credit thereof, which cannot be paid off, nor the Road amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are altered and enlarged.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester and Welford Turnpike Road, in the Counties of Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby de la Zouch,in the said County of Leicester:

And that Mr. Hungerford and Mr. Pochin do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The Lord Eardley reported from the Committee, to Coventry whom the Petition of the Commissioners for putting Street* Pati* in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the dons report*. Third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for paving, lighting, and cleansing the City of Coventry, and its Suburbs, for preventing Annoyances therein, and for better ordering the public Wells and Pumps there; and also, the Petition of the Mayor, Bailiffs, and Commonalty of the City of Coventry, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth;

To prove the Allegations of the said Petitions, the said Act was read: And,

Edward Inge, Junior, Esquire, being examined, said. That the Commissioners appointed by the said Act have caused several Streets and other public Passages within the Limits of the said Act to be paved, lighted, and cleansed, and have made several Improvements for the Benefit of the Inhabitants of the said Cily and Suburbs — That there are several public Roads leading through the said City and Suburbs, along which great Numbers of Carriages daily pass, and that the Streets through which the said Roads lead are in many Parts very narrow, inconvenient, and unsafe — That there are several other Streets and public Passages within the Limits of the said Act, which are narrow and incommodious, and no Power is given to the Commissioners to widen the said Streets or Passages —

That, in order to the more effectual Improvement of the said City, it will be necessary to open Communications between some of the Streets, and to take

down

30 Geo. III. 3

down several Dwelling Houses and Buildings, and particularly in Saint Johns Bridge , where it will be proper that the Whole of One Side of Part of the Street should be taken down, and some Yards belonging thereto taken in — That the said City and Suburbs are subject to many Obstructions, Annoyances, and Encroachments, and the said Act is not effectual for removing the same, nor is there sufficient Power for the proper Management of the public Wells and Pumps within the said City — That it would be of Benefit and Safety to all Persons resorting to the said City, if effectual Provision was made for the above Purposes, and for making Foot Paths in certain Parts of the said Streets, and to light and watch the said Streets and other Places. — And the Witness further added, That the Purposes aforesaid would be more conveniently executed if the said Act was repealed, and new Powers granted for the above Purposes.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for the better paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the City of Coventry, and the Suburbs thereof, and removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein, and for widening and otherwise improving the Streets, and regulating the public Wells and Pumps within the said City and Suburbs: And that the Lord Eardley and Mr. Wilmot do prepare, and bring in,

the same.

Burton Leo- A Bill for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields nard Inclo- in the Township of Burton Leonard, in the County of sure Bill York, was read a Second Time.

commi e Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Dun-combe, Mr. Wilberforce,&c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Norwich and A Petition of several of the Trustees for carrying NewBucken- into Execution an Act of Parliament, of the Twelfth Petition*1 Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road froifl Berstreet Gates, in the City of Norwich, to New Buckenham, in the County of Norfolk, and also of several of the Persons entitled to the Money due and owing upon the Credit of the said Act, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Road,

feat Part of which still remains due; and that the erm of the said Act is near expiring, and the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid cannot be paid off, and the said Road effectually amended, and kept in good Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be enlarged: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term of the said Act for such further Time as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

And it is referred to Sir John Sir Edward

Astley, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

List of The House being informed that Mr. Morton, from

Offices in the the Directors of the East India Company, attended at East Indie* Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented presente to House, pursuant to the Directions of an Act of Parliament,

A List of all Offices, Places, and Employments, in the Civil and Military Establishments of the United East India Company, in the East Indies, with the Salaries, or Pay, and Emoluments belonging thereto, Vo i. 45.

u aril. 45

or allowed or paid by the said Company in respect thereof.

And then he withdrew.

And the Title of the said List was read.

Ordered, That the said List do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said List is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House Slave Trade to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, deferred-to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tomorrow Sevennight, the nth Day of this Instant February, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for Debtor* Bill the Relief of Debtors, for the more speedy and effec- ord€rcd-tual Payment of Creditors, and for the Regulation of Gaols, so far as relates to imprisoned Debtors: And that Mr. Burges and Sir William Dolbeti do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Stephens presented to the House, according to Marine Order, a Bill for the Regulation of His Majesty’s Mut:ny Bill Marine Forces while on Shore: And the same was P,esenled-received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

The House, according to Order, resolved itself into Committee a Committee of the whole House, to consider of Ways of Way* and and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Mea0*' Majesty.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions, which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to Supply de-resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, ferred. to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, pursuant to the Account* Directions of an Act of Parliament, presented —

An Account of the Total Produce of the Duties of Custom*, Customs, Excise, Stamps, and Incidents, respectively, Excise, fcc. for One Year, ended the 5th Day of January 1790; distinguishing, as far as possible, in each Branch, the Produce on every separate Article, the Duties on which have amounted to 1,000l. or more, in the Four Quarters of the said Year: And also,

the Exchequer, of the Duties of Excise; distinguishing, as far as possible, the Produce on every separate Article, the Duty on which has amounted to 1,000l. or more, between the 5th January 1789 and the 5th January 1790: And also,

An Account of the Total Net Produce, paid into the Exchequer, of the Duties arising from the Stamp Revenue that have amounted to 1,000l. or more, in the Four Quarters next preceding the 5th of January last: And also,

An Account of the Total Net Produce of the Duties under the Head of Incidents; distinguishing, as far as possible, in each Branch, the Produce on every separate Article, the Duties on which shall have amounted to 1,000l. or more, in the Four Quarters next preceding the 5th January last: And also,

An Account of all Additions which have been made to the Annual Charge of the Public Debt, by the Interest or Annuities for or on Account of any Loan which hath been made subsequent to the passing an Act of the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repealing the several Duties of Customs and Excise, and " granting other Duties in lieu thereof, and for applying the said Duties, together with the other " Duties composing the Public Revenue; for permitting the Importation of certain Goods, Wares, " and Merchandize, the Produce or Manufacture of " the European Dominions of the French King, into " this Kingdom, and for applying certain unclaimed

" Monies, remaining in the Exchequer for the Payment of Annuities on Lives, to the Reduction of the " National Debt:" And also.

An Account of the Produce of the Duties imposed for the Purpose of defraying the increased Charge, occasioned by the Loans, made in pursuance of an Act of the Twenty-ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for raising a certain " Sum of Money by Way of Annuities and of One other Act of the same Session, intituled, "An Act " for raising a certain Sum of Money by Way of " Annuities, to be attended with the Benefit of Survivorship in Classes," from the respective Days (within the Year next preceding the Date hereof) from which the Duties commenced, to the 5th of January 1790; made up pursuant to an Act of the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repealing the several Duties of Customs " and Excise, and granting other Duties in lieu " thereof, and for applying the said Duties, together " with the other Duties composing the Public Revenue; " for permitting the Importation of certain Goods, " Wares, and Merchandize, the Produce or Manufacture of the European Dominions of the French " King, into this Kingdom, and for applying certain " unclaimed Monies, remaining in the Exchequer, for " the Payment of Annuities on Lives, to the Reduction " of the National Debt"

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

The said Accounts are as followeth; viz.

An ACCOMPT of all Additions which have been made to the Annual Charge of the Public Debt by the *°

6 J Public Debt

Interest or Annuities, for or on Account of any Loan which hath been made subsequent to the passing of an Act of the 27th Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repealing the several Duties " of Customs and Excise, and granting other Duties in lien thereof, and for applying the said Duties,

" together with the other Duties composing the Public Revenue; for permitting the Importation of certain " Goods, Wares, and Merchandize, the Produce or Manufacture of the European Dominions of the French " King, into this Kingdom; and for applying certain unclaimed Monies remaining in the Exchequer for the " Payment of Annuities on Lives, to the Reduction of the National Debt."

By virtue of an Act 29 Geo. III. the Sum of 187,0001, was raised by Annuities, after the Rate' of 7 /. 9 & 9 d.per Centum per Annum, to continue for the Term of 18 Years and 3 Quarters from the 5th of April 1789, and then to cease; which Annuities are directed by the said Act to be added to, and made One Joint Stock with, certain Annuities granted by Two Acts, of the 18th and 19th Years of His present Majesty’s Reign, payable Half Yearly at the Bank of England, and charged upon the Consolidated Fund, the Annual Amount whereof is -

14,001

s. d. 2 6

By virtue of one other Act of the same Session, the Sum of 1,002,5001, was raised by Annuities' on Lives, with the Benefit of Survivorship, to be distributed into Classes, and to be paid at the Receipt of the Exchequer, and charged upon the Consolidated Fund; but the Annual Amount of these Annuities cannot be ascertained until the Classes into which the same are to be distributed are completed. The said Act directs, that the Contributors of the said 1,002,500!. shall be entitled to 4/. per Centum per Annum, from the 5th Day of July 1789 until the 10th Day of October 1790, from which Time the Annuity payable to the respective Nominees is to commence; the present Annual Charge therefore is- - -

> 40,100 -

Presented pursuant to an Act of the 27th Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, this 3d Day of February 1790, by

George Rose.

Charge of Ak ACCOMPT of the Produce of the Duties imposed for the Purpose of defraying the increased Charge Lose*. occasioned by the Loans, made in pursuance of an Act of the 29th Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled* " An Act for raising a certain Sum. of Money by Way of Annuities and of one other Act of the same Session, intituled, "An Act for raising a certain Sum of Money by Way of Annuities, " to be attended with the Benefit of Survivorship, in Classes," from the respective Days within the Year next preceding the Date hereof) from which the Duties commenced to the 5th of January 1790; made up pursuant to an Act of the 27th Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repealing the several Duties of Customs and Excise, and granting other Duties in lieu " thereof, and for applying the said Duties together with the other Duties composing the Public " Revenue; for permitting the Importation of certain Goods, Wares and Merchandize, the Produce or " Manufacture of the European Dominions of the French King, into this Kingdom; and for applying certain " unclaimed Monies remaining in the Exchequer, for the Payment of Annuities on Lives, to the Reduction " of the National Debtviz*.

Memdum.

It is necessary to observe, that this Accompt of the Stamp Duties is only of Money received at the Head Office on the several Articles; the Produce of such as have been consigned to the Country Distributors cannot yet be ascertained.

The Amount of the Annual Income to be made good in lieu of the Shop Tax was 56,000 being the Produce of that Tax in the Year preceding the Repeal of it. The Remainder of the Produce of the above Taxes is applicable to the Payment of the Charge incurred by the Annuities on Lives, in consequence of the Act of the 29th of His present Majesty.

The Act 29 Geo. III. Cap. 37. recites, that the Sum of 187,000l. is expected to be repaid by Annual Instalments, and the Sum of 4,026 /. has been paid into the Exchequer, on account of Interest in respect thereof, and was carried to the Consolidated Fund in the Quarter ended the 5th Day of January 1790.

Treasury Chambers,

3d Day of February 1790.

Presented pursuant to an Act of the 27th Year of His present Majesty's Reign, this 3d Day of February 1790, by

George Rose.

Ordered,


Committee on Cora Indemnity Bill.

Royston and Wandesford Bridge Roads Petitions reported.

Ordered, That the said Accounts do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the wfoie House, upon the Bill for indemnifying all Persons who have been concerned in advising, or carrying into Execution, certain Orders of Council respecting the Importation and'Exportation of Corn and Grain, and also certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in Consequence of the same, and for making further Provisions relative thereto.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Rose took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Rose reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Jovis, 4* die Februarii;

Anno 30* Georgii III'" Regis, 1790. Pkayers.

THE Lord Hinchingbrook reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, t; An Act for enlarging the Terms and Powers " of several Acts of the Ninth and Twelfth Years of " Queen Ame, and of the Thirteenth of King George " the First, and of the Fourteenth of his late Majesty, " for repairing the Highways leading from m

" tile County of Hertford, to in the County of Huntingdon, 90 far as relates to the " Middle and South Divisions of the Road comprized " in the said Acts, and for amending the Road from " the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near " the West End of the Town of Somersham, in the said " County of Huntingdon;" and also, the Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Terms and Powers of several Acts of the Ninth and Twelfth Years of Queen Anne, and of the Thirteenth of King George the First, and of the Fourteenth of his late Majesty, for repairing the Highways leading from in

the County of Hertford, to Wandesford Bridge, in the County of Huntingdon, so far as relates to the Middle Division of the Road comprized in the said Acts, and so far as relates to the amending the Road from the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town of , in the said

County of Huntingdon, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied tfith; and that the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petitions, the said Acts were read: And,

Vol. 45.

Mr. Thomas DaiMfy being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Acts, and that there remains a Debt due of 1,200l. upon the South Division of Roads comprized therein. —

Then,

Mr. George Maule being examined, said, That there is a Debt due of 3,000l. upon the Middle Division of Roads, and 2,925 /. upon the separate District of Roads, also comprized in the said Act — That the said several Sums of Money cannot be repaid, nor the said Road kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Acts be further continued; and some Amendments and Alterations are necessary to be made therein.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of certain Acts of Parliament, for repairing the Roads from Royston, in the County of Hertford, to Wandesford Bridge, in the County of Huntingdon, and from the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town of Somersham, in the County of Huntingdon, so far as relates to the Middle and South Divisions and separate District of the said Roads: And that the Lord Hinchingbrook, the Earl Ludlow, Mr. Yorke, and General Adeane, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Mainwaring reported from the Committee, to Kensington, whom the Petition of the Trustees for putting in Exe- Chelsea, and cation an Act of Parliament, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing tion reported, several Roads in the Parishes of Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, and other Parishes therein mentioned, in the County of Middlesex, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

William Bleamire, Esquire (one of the Trustees under the said Act) being examined, said, That the Road leading from Hyde Park Comer to Counter’s Bridge, and several other Roads adjoining or near to the same, are, by the said Act, put under the Care and Management of the Petitioners, with Power to light and watch certain Parts only of the said Roads, and to pave the Carriage Way of the High Street, in the Town of Kensington-, and Provision is made for paving the Foot Paths on the Sides of the said Carriage Way, and for lighting and watching the said High Street, and certain other Parts of the said Town.

That a very considerable Sum of Money hath been borrowed, and the Sum of 11,500l. is now due and owing upon the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads; and the said Tolls are also charged with the Payment of the Sum of 1,000l. per Annum to the Commissioners for paving the Streets within the City and Liberty of Westminster, to enable them to keep in Repair Part of the Street or Road called Piccadilly, from Clarges Street to Hyde Park Comer, and from the South End of Park Lane to the North End of Hertford Street, which were heretofore under the Management of the Trustees of the said Roads.

That great Depredations, and other Outrages, have been of late frequently committed upon the said Roads in the Night Time, which, it is apprehended, might in a great Measure be prevented, if the Whole of the said several Roads were properly lighted and watched, under the Directions of the Trustees, and it would be

a great

Mr. Campbell’s Road Bill presented.

4° Februarii. A, 1790.

a great Convenience to Travellers, if the said Roads were properly watered.

And the Witness further said, That the Produce of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads is insufficient to enable the Trustees to pay the said Annual Sum of 1,000l., and the Interest of the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid, and effectually to amend and widen the said Roads and Foot Paths, and keep the same in Repair, and to light, watch, and water the said Roads; and that unless the Term of the said Act be eularged, and some of the Tolls thereby granted increased, and some further Powers are given to the Petitioners, the several Purposes aforesaid capnot be effected.

That a small Part of a certain Lane in Kensington, called Church Lane, is not included in the said Act, and a new Road, called Sloane Street, hath been made from the Great Western Road at Knightsbridge into the Road adjoining to the Burial Ground belonging to Chelsea Hospital, and it would be of public Benefit and Convenience if such Part of Church Lane as aforesaid, and also the said new Road called Sloane Street, were put under the Care and Management of the Petitioners for the repairing, lighting, watching, and watering the same; and if Provision was made for repairing the several Foot Paths oti the Sides of the said several Roads.

That in order to widen certain Parts of the said Roads, it will be necessary to take down certain Houses, and other Buildings, situate between the Church Yard of Kensington and the Charity School on the North Side of the Great Western Road in Kensington, and a certain Public House, called The Half-way House, situate between Knightsbridge and the Town of Kensington, and to take in and add to the said Road such Gardens, Nurseries, Orchard, and other Grounds, as shall be necessary for that Purpose; and it is apprehended, that it would tend to the Preservation of the said Roads, if some Restriction was laid upon erecting Buildings on new Foundations within a certain Distance thereof.

And the Witness further informed your Committee, That frequent Complaints are made of the bad State and Condition of the Pavement in such Past of Piccadilly as aforesaid, and the Trustees are desirous of taking that Part of the Carriage and Foot Road which formerly belonged to the Trust under their own Care and Management, upon certain Terms; or else to be empowered to call upon the Commissioners for Paving to keep the same in proper Repair.

And he added, That frequent Disputes have arisen firom the present Mode of collecting of certain Tolls, authorized by an Act of the Fifth Year of His present Majesty to be received on the said Roads upon Sundays by the said Commissioners for Paving, which Disputes, it is apprehended, might be prevented, if the Collection of such Tolls were’ to be put under the Care and Management of the Petitioners.

Sir Joseph Andrews, Baronet, confirmed the Whole of the foregoing Evidence.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for more effectually repairing the Road from Hyde Park Comer to Counter's Bridge, and certain other Roads, within the Parishes of Saint George Hammer Square, Saint Margaret Westminster, Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, in the County of Middlesex, and for lighting, watching, and watering the same; and for several other Purposes therein mentioned: And that Mr. Mainwaring and Mr. Henry Hobart do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Sir Archibald Edmonstone presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to empower William Henry Campbell, Esquire, to shut up a Road and Foot Paths in the Parish of Liston, in the County of Essex, and to

oblige him to make, and keep in Repair for the future, another Road and Foot Path in lieu thereof: And the -same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Alderman Le Mesurier presented to the House, Hackney according to Order, a Bill for taking down the Church Church Bill and Tower belonging to the Parish of Hackney, in the *,resente<,‘ County of Middlesex, and for building another Church and Tower for the Use of the said Parish, and for enlarging the Cemetery, or Church Yard, belonging the reto: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Burges presented to the House, according to Debtors Bill Order, a Bill for the Relief of Debtors, for the more presented, speedy and effectual Payment of Creditors, and for the Regulation of Gaols, so far as relates to imprisoned Debtors: And the same was received; and read the First time. , .

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the said Bill be read a Second Time upon Wednesday Morning next.

Ordered, That the said Bill be printed.

An ingrossed Bill for naturalizing Gottlob Gotthelff Schuster’s Schusler, was read the Third Time. Nut. Bill

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title P"se<* be, An Act for naturalizing Gottlob Gotthelff Schusler.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Cruger reported from the Committee, to whom Bristol the Petition of several of the Feoffees of certain Estates Church P«ti-and Hereditaments applicable, amongst other Uses, tion reported, to the Repairs of the Church of the Parish of Saint Thomas, in the City of Bristol, and also of the Vicar, Churchwardens, Vestry, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Inhabitants of the said Parish, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read'; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the -said Petition, Mr.

Jeremiah Osborne being examined, said, That the Church belonging to the said Parish is in a very ruinous State, and incapable of being repaired; and that it is apprehended that it will be necessary likewise to rebuild the Tower which is contiguous thereto. — And the Witness added, That there is no Fund adequate to the Expense of re-building the said Church and Tower.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for re-building the Parish Church and Tower of Saint Thomas, within the City of Bristol: And that Mr.

Cruger and Mr. Brickdale do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Lynn Haling A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Paths Peti- thereunder written, in Behalf of themselves and of the Merchants, Traders, and others, concerned in the Navigation of the several Counties of Norfolk, Suffolk, Cambridge, Huntingdon, Bedford and Northampton, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Counties of Suffolk, Cambridge, Huntingdon, Bedford, and Northampton, and also Part of Essex, Hertfor d, Lincoln, Leicester, Warwick, and Rutland, have been supplied from Lynn, in the County of Norfolk, with Coals, and other Kinds of Merchandize; and that the Commodities are carried by a Navigation from Lynn to the said several Counties, and the Lighters and Boats employed in the said Trade are obliged to be drawn with Horses, and it has been usual to Hale with Horses on the Banks or Shores of the respective Rivers; and that the Owners of the Lighters have paid to the Proprietors of the Banks on the different Rivers Annual Sums for Haling, and the Sums so paid have, till lately, been received and taken as a sufficient Recompence for the Injury done the Banks by Haling; and that the several Proprietors of the Banks knowing, without their Permission to Hale, that the Trade cannot be carried on, have given public Notice that they will oblige the Traders to pay considerably more for Liberty of Haling than has been hitherto paid; and that the Demands of the Proprietors could not be complied with, and who, in consequence thereof, have on several Parts of the Banks affixed Stiles, Rails, and Posts, which prevent the Haling, and totally stops the Trade from Lynn to the several Counties of Suffolk, Cambridge, Huntingdon, Bedford, Northampton, and Part of Essex, Hertford, Lincoln, Norfolk, Leicester, Warwick, and Rutland, by which the greatest Inconvenience will arise to the Inhabitants of the said Counties, as well as many Thousands of Seamen, Labourers, and others, being immediately orut of Employ: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to enable the Owners of . Lighters and Boats to Hale on the several Banks erf the Rivers with Horses, from Lynn to the several Counties of Suffolk, Cambridge, Huntingdon, Bedford, and Northampton, Norfolk, Leicester, Warwick, and Rutland, and for appointing Commissioners to ascertain the Damages that will be sustained, by the Bank

Veneris, 5° die Februarii',

Anno 30* Georgii IIItM Regis, 1790. Praters.

SIR William Young reported from the Committee, appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade, and who were empowered to report the Minutes of such Examination, from Time to Time, to the House; That the Committee had made a Progress in the Matter to them referred, and had directed him to report the Minutes of the said Examination to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Leeds and Mr. Pepys:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Tuesday, the 16th Day of this Instant February, at Ten of the Clock in the Morning, in Westminster Hall.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Sloane, Mr. Gamon, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Ouse Na- Mr. Charles Robinson reported from the Committee,

Pedtion "I'01*1 the Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of

(from New- Lftnd, Merchants, Traders, and others, interested in haven to Bar- the Navigation of the River Ouse, from to

combe Mill) Barcombe Mill, in the County of Sussex, was referred; reported. That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Joseph Hodskinson, Junior (an Engineer) being examined, said, That he has surveyed the River Ouse from Newhaven to Barcombe Mill; that the said River is at present navigable for small Barges only, but that by widening, deepening, and rendering strait the Current or Course thereof, particularly in certain Parts, where the Bends are very sharp, and the Shallows more frequent, the same may be made navigable for Vessels of a much larger Burthen; whereby the Trade and Commerce upon the said River will be considerably increased, and the Public in general greatly benefited. Then,

Mr. Chatfield Turner being examined, said, That if the Navigation of the said River is amended as proposed by the Plan, it will be of great Advantage to the Town of Lewes and its Neighbourhood, and also of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for improving the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Newhaven to Barcombe Mill, in the Parish of Barcombe, in the County of Sussex: And that Mr. Charles Robinson and Mr. Gilbert do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Taunton A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Society Pad- thereunto subscribed, being the Committee of the An-ti0B' nuitant Society of the Town of Taunton, and its

Neighbourhood, on Behalf of themselves, and the rest of the Members of the said Society, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, in the Year 1765, a Society was formed at Taunton, in the County of Somerset, which, by Deed, dated the 9th Day of September, in that Year, was named " The Annuitant Society of the Town of Taunton and its Neighbourhood;" and that the Design of the said Society was to raise, by Subscription amongst themselves, a Stock in Money, and thereout to provide certain Annuities for the Widows of those who then became, or who thereafter should become, Members of the said Society; and that a considerable Sum of Money, raised by the said Subscriptions, and applicable to the above-mentioned Purpose, is vested in Government and other Public Securities, in the Names of certain Trustees, and the Petitioners are desirous that some Provision should be made for more effectually establishing and securing the said Fund, which they are advised cannot be effected in any Way so proper as by an Act of Parliament: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes above-mentioned, under such Regulations as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Alexander Popham, Mr. and Sir Benjamin

Hummel, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

02

Sir John Wodehouse reported from the Committee, Coin and to whom the Petition of the Guardians of the Poor Carlford poor within the Hundreds of Colncis and Carlford, in the poj^nre' County of Suffolk, was referred; That the Committee p had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth, viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Two Acts, passed in the Twenty-ninth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, and the Fourth Year of

His present Majesty, for the Relief and Employment of the Poor within the said Hundreds, were read; whereby it appeared, that the Petitioners were authorized to erect and fit up certain Buildings for the Reception and Employment of the Poor, and to borrow Money to defray the Expence thereof, and also to make certain Rates or Assessments for paying the Interest of the Money so borrowed, and for defraying the Expence attending the Management and Support of the said Poor; and divers other Powers were given for carrying tire Purposes of the said Acts into Execution: And,

Philip Bmces Broke, Esquire, being examined, said,

That by virtue of the Powers granted by the said Acts, several Buildings have been erected and fitted up, and a considerable Sum of Money borrowed on the Credit of the Rates or Assessments, which has been applied in defraying the Expence of erecting and fitting up the said Buildings; but the Number of the Poor within the said Hundreds having of late Years greatly increased, the said Buildings are become too small for their Reception and Employment, and the Money arising by the said Rates or Assessments is found insufficient for their present Support and Maintenance, by reason whereof a considerable Debt, over and above the Money borrowed as aforesaid, hath been incurred; which Debt now remains unpaid, and cannot be discharged, and the said Poor properly supported and maintained, unless the said Rates or Assessments are increased, and the said Acts amended and rendered more effectual.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for the better Relief and Employment of the Poor within the Hundreds of Colneis and Carlford, in the County of Suffolk: And that Sir John Wodehouse and Mr. Henry Hobart do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, according to Land Tax Order, a Bill for granting an Aid to His Majesty by Bill pre-a Land Tax, to be raised in Great Britain, for the sente(1-Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

entitled

entitled to the Money due and owing upon the Credit of the said Act, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Report Tin Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re- Du"ts-ferred to consider of the Duties payable upon 'Tin exported, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That the Duties now' payable upon the Exportation of Tin to Parts beyond the Cape of Good Hope, do cease, determine, and be no longer paid or payable.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill be brought in upon the said Resolution: And that Mr. Gilbert and the Marquis of Graham do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Norwich and Sir John IVodehouse reported from the Committee,

Petition^re- *° w^om Petition of several of the Trustees, for ported. Carrying into Execution an Act of Parliament, of the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the County of the City of Norwich, to the Windmill in the Town of in the County of

Norfolk, and also of several of the Persons entitled to the Money due and owing upon the Credit of the said Act, w’as referred: That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House of the 2,5th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Capel Bringloe being examined, said. That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit thereof, of which the Sum of 3,0.501, now remains due. — That the said Money cannot be repaid, nor the Road kept in proper Repair, unless the Term granted by the said Act be further continued, and the Powers thereof altered and enlarged.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and varying the Powers, of an Act, of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Stephen's Gate, in the County of the City of to

the Windmill in the Town of Walton, in the County of Norfolk: And that Sir John Wodehouse, Sir Edward Astley, and Mr. Henry , do prepare, and bring

in, the same.

Yo l. 45.

The House being informed that Mr. Welstead, from Account of the Commissioners of the Customs, attended at the Coals and Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to Coastwavs*1 the House, pursuant to their Order of the 17th Day of patented.3’ July, in the last Session of Parliament,

An Account of the Quantities of Coals and Culm carried Coastways in England, during the Years 1787 and 1788, with the Duties thereon, and the different Ports of Shipping and Discharge.

And then he withdrew.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Account is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

An ingrossed Bill for indemnifying all Persons who Corn Tndem-have been concerned in advising, or carrying into nity Execution, certain Orders of Council respecting the pass* ’ Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, and also, certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in consequence of the same, and for making further Provisions relative thereto, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for indemnifying all Persons who have been concerned in advising, or carrying into Execution, certain Orders of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, and also, certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in consequence of the same, and for making Further Provisions relative thereto.

Ordered, That the Marquis of Graham do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Ordered, That the Clerks of the Market of the Returns of different Cities and Market Towns throughout England Weights and and Wales, and the Town of Berxcick upon Tweed, do or'

forthwith make out, and transmit to the Sheriffs of the ere respective Counties in which the said Cities and Towns are situate, Returns of the different Weights and Measures now in Use in such Cities and Market Towns respectively, as well as Specifications and Descriptions of any particular Commodities that are bought and sold by any customary Denominations or Proportions of Weight or Measure, as far as any such have come under their Observation.

Ordered, That the said Order be sent to the Sheriffs of the several Counties in England and Wales, and be by them transmitted to the Clerks of the Markets in their respective Counties; and that the said Sheriffs do return to the Clerk of this House, to be by him laid before the House, the Returns they shall severally receive from the Clerks of the Markets,

R Ordered,

Committee of Supply.

Army and Ordnance Estimates refened.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Guards, Garrisons, and other His Majesty’s Land Forces, in Britain, Guernsey, and Jersey, from 25th December 1789

to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of His Majesty’s Forces in the Plantations, including those in Garrison at Gibraltar, and a Corps of Foot in New South TViles, from 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the General and General Staff Officers in Great Britain, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of One Regiment of Light Dragoons, and Nine Regiments Of Foot, for Service in East India, for the Year 1790, being 365 Days, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Additional to' the Regiment of Light Dragoons serving in East India, and of Nine Recruiting Companies belonging to Regiments of Foot on the like Service, from the 25th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the Allowance to the Paymaster General of His Majesty’s Land Forces; to the Secretary at War; to the Commissary General of the Musters; to the Judge Advocate General; to the Comptrollers of the Accompts of the Army; of the Amount of Exchequer Fees to be paid by the Paymaster General; and on Account of Poundage to be returned to the Infantry, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Full Pay to Supernumerary Officers of His Majesty’s Forces, from 2.5th December 1789 to 24th December 1790, both Days inclusive, being 365 Days, be referred to tire said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the Difference between the British and Irish Establishments of Seven Battalions of Foot, serving in North America and the West Indies, from the 25th December 1789 to the 24th December 1790, both inclusive, being 365 Days, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay and Allowances, to the Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s Land Forces and Marines, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay and Allowances to the Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s American Forces, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Half Pay to the Reduced Officers of the late Scotch Brigade, in the Service of the States General, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of a Corps of Foot, for Service in New South Wales, under the Command of Major Francis Grose, from the 5th Day of June 1789 to the 24th Day of December following,

both inclusive, being 203 Days, be deferred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Recruiting His Majesty’s Land Forces, and of the Contingencies of the said Forces, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the Office of Ordnance, for the Year 1790 — Land Service, be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House, resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Tuesday Morning next.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Ordered, That all Committees have Leave to sit, notwithstanding any Adjournment of the House.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Tuesday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

Mortis, 9* die Februarii;

Anno 30* Georgii III'11 Regis, 1790. Praters,
