The House being informed that Mr. Brent, from the Office for Affairs of Taxes, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Order of the 7th Day of in the last Session of Parliament,

An Account of the Total Number of Houses in England and Wales charged or chargeable with the Duties on Houses, Windows, or Lights, as also of the Total Number of Cottages exempted from Payment of the Duty, according to the last Survey; together with an Account of the Total Number of Houses throughout Scotland chargeable to the Duties on Houses and Windows.

And then he withdrew.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Account is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

A Bill for taking down the Church and Tower belonging to the Parish of Hackney, in the County of Middlesex, and for building another Church and Tower for the Use of the said Parish, and for enlarging the Cemetery or Church Yard belonging thereto, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed1 to Mr. Alderman Le Mesurier, Mr. Ryder, &c.: And they are to

meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Gentlemen and other Persons, in the County of Stafford, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterweirds delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, John Holliday, Esquire, being examined, said, That the Road leading from Fosbrook, in the Parish of Dillorn, through Dillorn, and from thence to or near to Chedleton, in the County of Stafford, is in a ruinous Condition, narrow and incommodious, and cannot be repaired and widened by the ordinary Means prescribed by Law.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for making, amending, and keeping in Repair, the Road from Fosbrook, in the Parish of Dillorn, through Dillorn, and from thence to or near to Chedleton, in the County of Stafford: And that Mr. Gilbert, the Earl Gower, and Sir Edward Littleton, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Crewe presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and altering the Road from Macclesfield, in the County of Chester, to the Turnpike Road at Randle Carr Lane Head, in Fcrnilee, in sche County of Derby, leading to Chapel in the Frith: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made and passed in

the Eighth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading to and through " the Town of Goudhurst, in the County of Kent," was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have made great Progress in repairing the said Roads, and, in order thereto, have borrowed a very considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads, which still remains due; and that the said Roads cannot be effectually amended and kept in Repair, and the Money borrowed, with the Interest thereof, be paid off, unless the Term of the said Act is enlarged, and some further Powers given to the Trustees for those Purposes: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of the said Act, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. , Mr. Gilbert,

&c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow MornmgJ at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

The Lord Hinchingbrook presented to the House,

according to Order, a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of certain Acts of Parliament, for repairing the Roads from Royston, in the County of Hertford, to Wandesford Bridge, in the County of Huntingdon, and from the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town of Somei'sham, in the County of Huntingdon, so far as relates to the Middle and South Divisions and separate District of the said Roads: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Mayor, Aldermen, Capital Burgesses, and Inhabitants, of the Borough of Truro, in the' County of Cornwall, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Streets of the said Borough are in a ruinous State, that various Encroachments are made into them, and Nuisances suffered to remain therein: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for paving, cleansing, widening, and lighting the Streets of the said Borough, for removing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Drivers of Carts and other Carriages, and Porters, within the said Borough.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Colonel Boscawen, the Lord Fielding, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow

Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Bill for re-building the Parish Church and Tower interested in the Navigation of the said River, was reported, of Saint Thomas, within the City of Bristol, was read referred; That the Committee had examined, and a Second Time. found that the Standing Orders of the House, rela-

Resotoed, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Cruger, tive to Navigation Bills, had been complied with;

Mr. Call, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, and that the Committee had examined the Matter of at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber. the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he A Petition of the Prisoners confined for Debt in read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered His Majesty’s Gaol of Newgate, in Bristol, was pre- it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; sented to the House, and read; Complaining of their and is as followeth; viz.

Distress, and praying Relief. To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the John Fisher being examined, said. That the Naviga-Table. tion of the River Ouse is in several Places much ob-

structed by Shoals, and other Impediments, and the A Bill to empower William Henry Campbell, Esquire, River is in many Places'so shallow as to render it to shut up a Road and Foot Paths in the Parish of very inconvenient for the conveying of Goods and Vojl 45. S Merchandize

Merchandise thereon; and that it would be of great public Utility to ropfore, continue, and extend the Navigation of the said River from to

Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of and to the

Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield: Theq,

Mr. Samuel Waller being examined, said. That the extending the Improvement-of the Navigation of the said River to Cuckfield will be attended with great Advantage, by lessening the Expence of bringing Chalk for the Manure of the Lands in the Neighbourhood; and also, by lessening the Expence of carrying Timber down to the Sea, ami of bringing back Merchandize up into the Country; knd will therefore be of public Utility.

Mr. Jethro Turner confirmed the foregoing Evidence.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Zeroes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex: And that Mr. Thomas Pelham, Lord George Henry Lenox, and Sir Godfrey Webster, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Committee Resolved, That this House will, immediately, resolve on Marine itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the utmy Bil. gjji for Regulation of His Majesty’s Marine Forces while on Shore.

The House accordingly resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Stephens took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Stephens reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Bedwin and A Petition of the Right honourable Thomas Bruce Preshute In- Rjyi cf Ailesbury, and the humble Petition of John Clark,

cosure «t>- William Jackman, James Whitelocke, and the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Owners or Proprietors of the Common or Open Fields, Common Meads, and Commonable and Waste Lands and Tyfoes, within the Parishes of Great Bedwin, Little Bedwin, and Preshute, in the County of Wilts, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Parishes, several Open and Common Fields and Downs, Common Meadows, and other Commons and Waste Lands and Grounds, belonging to the Petitioners and others, which, in their present State, are incapable of any considerable Improvement; and that the said Fields, Meadows, and Lands, might be greatly unproved, if the same were divided, and specific Allotments made thereof unto the Petitioners, and the several other Persons interested therein, according to their respective Rights and Interests: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and allotting the said Fields, Meadows, and Lands, in such Manner, and subject to such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that the Marquis of Graham and Colonel Manners do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Liverpool Snuff in Liverpool, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Set- -j^b^coAct. ting forth, That the Petitioners already find that the Act of the last Session of Parliament, which subjects them to the Laws of Excise, is attended with numberless Difficulties and Distresses — That the Rules and Regulations thereby imposed upon the Manufacturers are, in some Cases, impracticable, and must subject the Petitioners to heavy Forfeitures and Penalties, after having used their utmost honest Endeavours to comply with the Letter of the Law — That the several Notices, to take out of Bond and put into Operation, occasion a Delay of at least Forty-eight Hours before a Cask of Tobacco can be opened, and no Part can be disposed of, however pressing the Demand, till the whole Parcel under Process is actually completely manufactured, and many of the Petitioners are thereby obliged to deviate from their usual Manner and Process, from whence arises great additional Expence, Inconvenience, and Loss — That, after every Indulgence which the Officer can grant, Delays and Interruptions arise which are inconsistent with the Nature of the Trade, and that, from the present Slackness of Trade, there is every Reason to believe that the illicit Dealer has already found out Methods of supplying the Consumer, the Retail Trader being under* fewer Restrictions than the Manufacturer — That, upon the Exportation of Manufactured Tobacco, Security is required from the Exporter, in Three Shillings and Nine Pence, for every Pound Weight so exported, which Bond cannot be cancelled without a Certificate, from the Port, of such Tobacco being duly landed there, and such Certificates are sometimes obtained with great Difficulty, and, should they be delayed beyond the Time required by the said Law, the Parties concerned might thereby be involved in unavoidable Ruin: And therefore praying,

That they may be heard, by themselves and Counsel, for a Repeal of the said Act of the last Session of Parliament

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider futher of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Number of Land Forces, including One thousand Six hundred and Twenty Invalids, amounting to Seventeen thousand Four hundred and Forty-eight effective Men, Commission and Non-commissioned Officers included, be employed for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resoboed, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Five hundred Seventy-eight thousand Five hundred and Sixty-two Pounds Fourteen Shillings and One Penny, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of Seventeen thousand Four hundred and Forty-eight effective Men, for Guards, Garrisons, and other His Majesty’s Land Forces in Great Britain, Gue, and Jersey, including the Charge of the Pay of Commission and Noncommissioned Officers and Private Men, the Charge of Clothing of Non-commissioned Officers and Private Men, the Charge of Agency, and the Charge of Allowances to be made to Captains, Paymasters, Surgeons, Riding Masters, and for Serjeants, for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Three hundred Seventeen thousand Five hundred and Forty-nine Pounds and Sixteen Shillings, be granted to His Majesty, for maintaining Ris Majesty’s Forces and Garrisons in the Plantations, those in Garrison at Gibraltar, and a Coips of "Foot in New South including the

Charge of the Pay of the Commission Officers, Non-eonrmrasioned Officers, and Private Men, the Charge of Clothing of the Non-commissioned Officers and Private 'Men, the Charge of Agency, and the Charge of Allowances to be made to Captains, Paymasters, Svageons, and Serjeants, for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Four thousand Nine hundred and Seven Pounds and Ten Shillings, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of Allowances to several Reduced Officers of His Majesty’s British American Forces, for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Three thousand Three hundred Ninety-two Pounds Fourteen Shillings and Two Pence, be granted to His Majesty, on Account of the several Officers late in the Service of the States General, for the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Three thousand Four hundred and Eleven Pounds Fourteen Shillings and Four Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of Major Francis Grose's Corps of Foot for Service in New South Wales, for Two hundred and Three Days, from the Fifth Day of June One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-nine to the Twenty-fourth Day of December following, both inclusive; including the Charge of the Pay of Commission, Non-commissioned Officers, and Private Men, the Charge of Clothing of Non-commissioned Officers and Private Men, the Charge of Agency, and the Charge of Allowances to be made to the Captains, Surgeon, Paymaster, and Serjeants.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand Five hundred and Seventy-five Pounds Four Shillings and ThreePence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Expence of Services performed by the Office of Ordnance for Land Service, previous to the Thirty-first Day of December One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-three, and not provided for by Parliament.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Thirteen thousand Eight hundred and Sixty-mine Pounds and Six Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Expence of Services performed by the Office of Ordnance for Land Service, and not provided for by Parliament, in One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-eight.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Four hundred and Eighteen thousand Two hundred and Seven Pounds Seventeen Shillings and Five Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for the Charge of the Office of Ordnance for Land Service, for die Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Twenty-three thousand Seven hundred and Ninety-five Pounds Sixteen Shillings and Seven Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Expence of Services performed by the Office of Ordnance for Sea Service, and not provided for by Parliament, in One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-eight.

A Motion was made, and the Question being proposed, That the said Resolutions be now read a Second Time;

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for the better " Regulation of the Office of the Paymaster General " of His Majesty’s Forces* and the more regular " Payment of the Army; and to repeal an Act, made " in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for the better Regulation of the Office of Paymaster General of His Majesty’s Forces," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

The said Resolutions were severally read a Second Time; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill Mutiny Bill for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better ordered. Payment of the Army and their Quarters: And that Mr. Steele, Mr. Secretary at War, and Mr. Gilbert, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning; Ten of the Clock.

Praters.

MR. Marsham reported from the Committee, to Goudhurtt whom the Petition of several of the Trustees Roads Peti-for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made tion reporte and passed in the Eighth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading to and through the Town of Goudhurst, in the " County of Kent," was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. John Pope being examined, said, That the Trustees for the Care of the said Roads have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads; which Money now remains due, and cannot be paid off, nor the Roads kept in good Repair, unless the Term of the said Act is further continued.

And the Witness added, that some Alterations and Amendments are necessary to be made in the said Act, to enable the Trustees more effectjjflJly to carry the - Purposes thereof into Execution.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act of the Eight Year of His present Majesty, for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair several Roads, leading to and through the Town of Goudhurst, in the County of Kent: and that Mr. Marsham and Mr.

Honywood do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Cawthorne reported from the Committee, to Pointon In-whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Common closure Bill Cow Pasture and Common Fen in the Parish of Poin- rfPorled-ton, in the County of Lincoln, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Com* rnittee (except the Proprietor of One Common Right House, who, having been written to, returned no Answer; and also except the Proprietor of Two Common Right Houses and Twenty Acres of Land, who refused to sign the Bill; and that the Whole of the Lands, entitled to Right of Common on the'

Lands to be inclosed, consist of One thousand and Eighty-seven Acres and an Half, or thereabouts; and the whole Number of Common Right Houses is Forty-nine; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone

through

through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table; Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments,- be ingrossed.

Norwich and 'Sir John JVodehouse presented to the House, ac-Trowse Road cording to Order, a Bill for continuing an Act of the Bill pre- Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for seoted' amending the Road from Saint Stephen's Gate, in the City of Norwich, to Block Hill, in Trowse, at the Angle where the Road divides to and Kirby, in the County of Norfolk: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Old Bucicen- Sir John JVodehouse reported from the Committee, ham Inclo- to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Com-wre Bill mons. Fens, and Waste Lands, within the Parish of reported. Buckenham, in the County of Norfolk, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Owners of Lands having Right of Common, whose Property is assessed to the Land Tax at 65/. per Annum, who refused to sign the Bill; and also, except the Owners of Lands, whose Property is rated at 891, per Annum, who refused to sign, but made no material Objection to the Bill; and also, except the Owners of Lands, whose Property is rated at 421, per Annum, who would give no decisive Answer; and also, except the Owner of Lands, whose Property Vol. 45.

is rated at 15 I. per Annum, who is insane; and that the Whole of the Property of Persons having Right of Common upon the Lands intended to be inclosed, is rated at 1,674/. per Annum; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of several of the Justices of the Peace for Warwic -the County of Warwick, in General Quarter Sessions assembled, was presented to the House, and read; "*ltion-Setting forth, That the public Gaol of the said County, situate in the Town of Warwick, is too small, and not properly constructed for the Reception, Confinement, and Separation of the Prisoners, and the same cannot be made sufficiently large and commodious, with proper Apartments for the Separation of the Prisoners, without taking dotvn certain Houses and other Buildings of small Value, and also making Use of certain small Pieces of Garden Ground, and extending the said Gaol across two public Lanes or Ways, called Bridewell Lane and Joyce Pool Lane, and the making the said Gaol sufficiently large will be attended with a very considerable Expence; and that the Petitioners conceive some Regulations might be made for the better Management of the said Gaol, and the Security of the Prisoners confined therein, and also for the better Preservation of the Health of the Prisoners: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the said Gaol, and effecting the other Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and by such Ways and Means, as to the House shall appear proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Robert Lawley, Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

tion reported. whom the Petition of the Trustees for carrying into Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing,

widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading from Tavernspite to the Towns of Pembroke and and to Hubberston Haking, in the County of was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. John Rees Stokes being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the Act,

and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit thereof, of which the Sum of 3,975/. now remains due; which Money cannot be repaid, nor the said Roads kept in proper Repair, unless the Term granted by the said Act be further continued, and some wither Powers granted.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act of the Eleventh Year of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair several Roads leading from Tavernspite to the Towns of Pembroke and Tenby, and to Hubberston Haking, in the County of Pembroke: And that Sir JVatkin Lewes, the Lord Milford, and Mr. Barlodo prepare, and bring in, the same.

ttaverford-west Reads Petition reported.

Sir JVatkin Lewes reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, and other Inhabitants, of the County of Pembroke,was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with (except that One of the Parishes through which the Road is to lead was not described in the Notices, it not being known at that Time that any Part of the Road would lead through that Parish, and which Piece of Road is not more than Half a Mile in Length); and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. John Rees Stokes being examined, said, That the several Roads described in the Petition are in many Parts much out of Repair, narrow and incommodious for Carriages and Travellers; and that it will be of public Utility to have the said Roads effectually amended and kept in Repair.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Biff for amending, widening, ana keeping in Repair, the Roads leading from the Town of Haverfordwest, to a Place called Morris the Bailiffs, and to Great Treff-garne Bridge, and to the City of Saint Davids, and from the said City to the Harbour of Caerjai, in the Parish of Saint Davids, in the County of Pembroke: And that Sir JVatkin Lewes, the Lord Milford, and Mr. John Campbell, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Imports and Exports of Rum and Sugar into and from Great Britain, for the Year ending the 25th of December 1789, with the Duties of Customs and Excise, and Drawbacks paid thereon.

Ordered, That-the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for continuing and granting to His Majesty certain Duties upon Malt, Mum, Cyder, and Perry, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they have Power to receive a Clause of Credit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they have Power to receive a Clause, to direct that the deficiency, which shall be on the 25th Day of March 1790, of the Incomes of the Duties on Malt, granted for the Year 1788, to satisfy Principal and Interest charged thereupon, be made good out of the Supplies for the Year 1790.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for granting an Aid to His Majesty by a Land Tax, to be raised in Great Britain, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they have Power to receive a Clause of Credit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they have Power to receive a Clause, to make good the Deficiency of the Land Tax of the Year 1788, out of the Supplies granted for the Year 1790.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair. *

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

And the said Order being read accordingly; Resolved, That this House will upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Debtor* and Ordered, That the Bill for the Relief of Debtors, for Creditors Bill the more speedy and effectual Payment of Creditors, deferred. and for the Regulation of Gaols, so far as relates to imprisoned Debtors, be read a Second Time upon this Day Sevennight.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Glasgow Po- A Petition of John Campbell, Junior, Esquire, Lord lice Petition. Provost, James M‘Dawal, Esquire, James Gordon Esquire, and James M'L Esquire, Baillies, and the other Members of the Common Council of the City of Glasgow, for themselves and as representing the Community of the said City, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petite-era, some Years ago, purchased the Lands of

Meadowflat, and others lying adjacent to the said City, and the Inhabitants thereof having now greatly increased in Number, it has become necessary to feu and sell those Lands, for the Purpose of being built upon, which makes it expedient that the Royalty of the said City, and the Jurisdiction of the Petitioners, should be extended over the said Lands; and that it would also be greatly for the Benefit of the Inhabitants, and other Persons resorting to the said City, that certain new Streets and Avenues leading to and through the same were opened, that Footways and Pavements were made, that the Streets were better lighted and cleansed, that the Police and Markets were better regulated, and that certain Funds were raised, and Powers given for carrying these useful Purposes into Execution: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the above and other Purposes, in such Manner and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of aCommittee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it. is referred to Lord Frederick Campbell, Sir Archibald EdmonsUm, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Von. 45.

Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Mainwaring presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for more effectually repairing the Road f rom Hyde Park Corner to Counter's Bridge, and certain other Roads within the Parishes of Saint George Hanover Square, Saint Margaret Westminster, Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, in the County of Middlesex, and for lighting, watching, and watering the same, and for several other Purposes therein mentioned: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Minister, Churchwardens, and others, Trustees for building a new Church in the Parish of Saint James, Clerkein the County of Middlesex, and of other Inhabitants of the said Parish, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That an Act was made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act " for pulling down the Church of Saint James, at " Clerkenwell, in the County of Middlesex, and for building a new Church, and making a new Church " Yaid or Cemetery in the said Parish, with convenient Avenues and Passages theretoand that a considerable Progress hath been made in the Execution of the several Powers given by the said Act, but it is found that the good Purposes intended thereby cannot be effectually answered, unless the said Act is amended, and the Powers thereof enlarged: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Pill to amend and enlarge the Powers of, and to render more effectual, the said Act of Parliament.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Mainwaring, Mr. Jer-voise, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Cromford Canal Company was presented to ' the House, arid read; Setting forth, That an Act was passed in the last Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Cromford Bridge, in the County of iJerby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County; and, by the said Act, the Petitioners are authorized to take Water from the River,

and from several Brooks, Streams, Watercourses, and Mines, towards supplying the said Canal and collateral Cut, under certain Regulations and Restrictions for the Security of the Owners and Proprietors of certain Mills upon or near the said River; and that the Provisions contained in the said Act not being thought effectual by the Owners of some of the said Mills and Works on the River Denvent, for the Security of their Mills and Works, the Petitioners have consented that certain Alterations should be made in the said Act, for the better and more effectual Security of the said Mills; and that the Petitioners have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and find that some Alterations are necessary for the more conveniently carrying the same into Execution: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making such Alterations and Amendments in the said Act, and for giving such Security to the

Owners

A Petition of the several Persons whose names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves, and others, Owners of Estates, and Inhabitants, within the Parish of Streatham,in the County of Surrey, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the said Parish is large and populous, and the Poor thereof being very numerous, it would render the Rates for their Relief much less buthensome, and the Poor would be better maintained, if a Workhouse was provided, wherein they might be received and employed; and that it often happens that the Persons appointed Overseers of the Poor of the said Parish, do not execute the Duties of their Office themselves, but leave them to be performed by interested Deputies, by which means the Poors Rates are frequently much misapplied, and rendered more heavy than is necessary, which it is apprehended might, in a great Degree, be prevented, if a proper Person was appointed to act as additional Overseer of the Poor of the said Parish: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the above Pur-

MR. Thomas Pelham presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Levees Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

The House being informed that the Sheriffs of the City of London attended at the Door; they were called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House,

A Petition of the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons of the City of London, in Common Council assembled.

And then they withdrew.

And the said Petition was read; Setting forth, That by an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco M and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu " thereof," the Petitioners are deeply concerned to find that their Fellow Citizens, the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Snuff, have become subject to the Law's of Excise; and that, although the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue for the Exigencies of the Nation, and willing, upon all Occasion , chearfully to bear their Proportion of the Public Burthen, they cannot silently acquiesce in any Part of their Fellow Subjects being deprived of the Trial V o l. 45.

Lord George Cavendish reported from the Com- Linton In-mittee, to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing closure Bill several Open Fields, and a Stinted Pasture, called reported. Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York, was committed;

That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, Selby Bridge Merchants, Tradesmen, Manufacturers, and others, Petition, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, residing in the Towns of Selby, Smith, and Thome, in the West Riding of the County of York, and the Vicinity thereof respectively, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That there is no Communication, except by Ferries, over the River Ouse,between the Ridings

and Districts bounded by the said River, from the City of York, to the River Humber, which are upwards of Forty Miles distant from each other by Water, and near Thirty by Land; and that the Ferry over the said River at Selby aforesaid, called Selby Ferry, is nearly Central, in both these Respects, between the City of York and the Humber, much frequented by Passengers, Horses, Cattle, and Carriages, and the only way for the Inhabitants of several of the adjacent Villages to pass to and from their Market,

U which

74

12.° Februarii. A. 1790.

which is held every Monday at Selby aforesaid, an ancient, populous, and improving Town; and that the Passage over the said Ferry, and every other Ferry upon the Ouse, is, at all Times, attended with Delay, in some Seasons dangerous, and at others impassable, and, if a Bridge was erected at or near the Ferry over the River Ouse at Selby, the same would be of great public Utility, and of essential Service to the East, West, and North Ridings of the County of York, the Counties of Lincoln, Lancaster, and TV , and the Town of Kingston upon Hull: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for building a Bridge, at or near the Ferry over the River Ouse, at Selby aforesaid, and purchasing from the Person interested in the said Ferry, his Right and Interest therein, in such Manner as the House shall judge meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. D Mr. Wilberfo/xe,

&c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Trustees for putting in Execution Three Acts of Parliament, passed in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of King George the First, the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads leading from the Town of Bromsgrove to the Town of Dudley, in the County of Worcester, and from the said Town of Bromsgrove to the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, so far as the said Acts relate to the repairing of the Roads leading from the said Town of Birmingham to the said Town of Bromsgrove, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That great Progress hath been made in repairing, widening, and making commodious the said Road from Birmingham to Bromsgrove (which is the great Road from Birmingham to Worcester, Gloucester, Bath, Bristol, and all the West of England) in doing whereof a considerable Debt hath been contracted, o4 ‘

which cannot be paid off, and the Roads effectually amended, widened, and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Acts be continued, and the Powers thereof altered, amended, and enlarged, or wholly repealed, and other Powers granted; and that the said Road from Birmingham to Bromsgrove is exceedingly narrow in many Parts, which has occasioned various Accidents to Carriages, and, from the N ature and Hilly Situation of the Country through which the same passes, it will be necessary, in some I laccs, to vary and alter the Course thereof, and to purchase Land, as w ell for those Purposes, as for w idening the old Road in several Parts: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Rill for the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Robert , Sir George

Augustus William Shuckburgh,&c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Sir Robert Lawley reported from the Committee, to Warwick whom the Petition of several of the Justices of the Gaol Petition Peace for the County of Warwick, in General Quarter reP°rtei1, Sessions assembled, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition,

Charles Henry Hunt, Esquire, being examined, said, that the public Gaol of the said County, situate in the Town of Warwick,is too small, and is not properly constructed for the Reception, Confinement, and Separation of the Prisoners; and that the same cannot be made sufficiently large and commodious, with proper Apartments for the Separation of the Prisoners, without taking down certain Houses, and other Buildings (of small Value) and also making use of certain small Pieces of Garden Ground, and extending the said Gaol across two public Lancs or Ways; and that the making the said Gaol sufficiently large will be attended with a very considerable Expence.

And the Witness added. That it w ill be necessary to make some Regulations for the better Management of the said Gaol, and Security of the Prisoners confined therein, and also for the better Preservation of the Health of the Prisoners.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of Warwick: And that Sir Robert Lawley and Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

An ingrossed Bill for continuing and granting to His Majesty certain Duties upon Alait. Mum, Cyder, and Perry, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty by a Land Tax to be raised in Great Britain, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Mr. Speaker acquainted the House, That the Clerk Accounts of of this House had received several Returns to the Costs allowed Order of the House, of the 17th Day of July, in the Irie/in last Session of Parliament, " That the Sheriffs of the County " several Counties in England do, early Courts.

" in the next Session of Parliament, transmit to the " Clerk of this House correct Accounts of the Costs " allowed on Taxation in their several County Courts,

" in Actions tried therein, whether by Common Plaint,

" in Default, or by Justices ;" and that the said Returns were now upon the Table.

Ordered, That the said Returns do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Returns are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

A Petition of the Mayor, Sheriffs, Citizens, and Norwich Commonalty of the City of Norwich, in Common Waterworks Council assembled, was presented to the House, and *>etitloa' read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are Owners of certain Works within the said City, for raising Water from the River Wenson, for the Supply of the Inhabitants of the said City, and Parts adjacent, but the Petitioners have not sufficient Powers to convey a full and amply Supply of Water for the Use of the said Inhabitants; and that the Petitioners find that, in order to enable them to afford a regular and ample Supply of Water for the Use of the said Inhabitants, it will be necessary that certain new and additional Works should be made and erected, and certain Powers granted to the Petitioners: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for effecting the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Wind-ham, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning,

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Gilbert, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

of Lands and Estates, within the said Parish: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill in its present Form, and against the several Provisions thereof, and that the Powers thereof may be confined to repairing and enlarging the present Parish Church.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Bill for taking down the Church and Tower belonging to the Parish of Hackney, in the County of Middlesex, and for building another Church and Tower for the Use of the said Parish, and for enlarging the Cemetery, or Church Yard, belonging thereto, is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by their Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

A Bill for more effectually repairing the Bead from Hyde Park Corner to Counters Bridge, and certain other Roads, within the Parishes of Saint George Hanoroer Square, Saint Margaret Westminster, Kensington, Chelsea,

and Fulham, in the County of Middlesex, and for lighting, watching, and watering the same; and for several other Purposes therein mentioned, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Main-waring, Mr. Alderman Wilkes, c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

An ingrossed Bill for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields, and a Stinted Pasture, called Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass i And that the Title be, An Act for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields, and a Stinted Pasture, called Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York.

Ordered, That Lord George Cavendish do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

An ingrossed Bill for the Regulation of His Majesty’s Marine Forces while on Shore, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for the Regulation of His Majesty’s Marine Forces while on Shore.

Ordered, That Mr. Stephens do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being the Owners and Proprietors of Lands in the Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, within the Liberty or Lordship of Mickleover, in the County of Derby, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Liberty or Lordship, several Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, belonging to the Petitioners and others, which in their present Situation are incapable of any considerable Improvement, but that, if the said Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, were divided and inclosed, and allotted to the respective Owners and Proprietors, according to their respective Rights and Interests therein, the same might be greatly improved: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, in such Manner, and subject to such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Lord George Cavendish and Mr. Mundy do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves, and others, Owners of Estates and Inhabitants within the Parishes of Desford and Newbold Verdon, in the County of Leicester, was presented to the House, and read: Setting forth. That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that Application is making for a Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for

Vol. 45.

repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester and Welford Turnpike Road, in the Counties of Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby de la Zouch, in the said County of Leicester-, and that Two Pieces of Road, the one called Hunt's Lane, in the Parish of Desford, and the other Wood Lane, in the Parish of Newbold Verdon,branching out of the said Turnpike Road, are narrow, and very much out of Repair, and it would be very advantageous to the Petitioners, and all others travelling along the said Lanes, if the same were made Turnpike, and put under the Care and Management of the Trustees for executing the said Act: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for the above Purpose, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and Report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Hungerford, Mr. Pochin,

8cc.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Maldraeth, thereunto subscribed, being interested in, and entitled &c.Emlmuk* to, Allotments of the Marsh called Malldraeth and Corsddaugau, in the County of Anglesey, was presented pJStiouf to the House, and read; Setting forth, That an Act passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for dividing, inclosing, embanking, draining, and preserving the said Marsh, and for other Purposes, whereby Power was given to the Commissioners for carrying the Act into Execution, to raise Money for defraying the Expences of the said Embankment and Drainage, by certain Rates or Dues, to be collected for the Tonnage and Wharfage of Goods, Wares, and Commodities conveyed upon the Cuts or Channels to be made for draining and preserving the said Marsh, and also by a Pound Rate or Assessment upon the Owners and Proprietors of the said Marsh; and that the said Commissioners have expended a considerable Sum of Money in erecting a Bank, and other Works, to prevent the said Lands being overflowed by the Sea, but the same were washed down and destroyed by the high Tides in October last, and it appears that the making a Bank of sufficient Heighth and Strength against the Sea, and also such other Banks, Drains, and Works, as shall be necessary for draining and preserving the said Marsh, will be attended with a much greater Expence than was apprehended at the Time of passing the said Act, and that the Money authorized to be raised by the said Act will not be sufficient to defray such Expence; and that a very considerable Quantity of the inclosed Lands and Grounds, adjoining and lying near to the said Marsh, will be drained, and greatly improved, by the effectual Embankment and Drainage of the said Marsh, and the Petitioners conceive it is reasonable that the Owners and Proprietors of such inclosed Lands and Grounds should contribute towards the Expence thereof: And therefore praying, That I^ave may be given to bring in a Bill for amending the said Act, and for raising such further Sums of Money as shall be sufficient to defray the Expence of effectually embanking, draining, and preserving the said Marsh, by such Ways and Means as to the House shall appear reasonable and proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Bayly, Mr. Ord,:

X And.

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

30 Geo. III. 15° Februarii.

94 15°--16° A. 1790;

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

Committee Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to prepare an Estimate of the Charge of the Pay and Clothing of Estimate. the Militia, for the Year 1790.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. Rose, Mr.

Sleek, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Colneis and A Bill for the better Relief and Employment of the CarlfordPoor poor within the Hundreds of Colneis ana Carlford, in mitted"1' the County of Suffolk, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir John Rous, Sir John Wodehouse, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mutiny Bill Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for receiving deferred. the Report from the Committee of tire whole House, to whom the Bill for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters, was committed, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

rate District of the said Roads, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to the Lord Hinchingbrook, Mr. Yorke, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock in the Speaker’s Chamber.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Supply de. Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Way*»nd Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the fe^Jsdc' whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Mctrtis, 16° die Februarii;

Anno 30* Georgii IIP11 Regis, 1790.

Macclesfield A Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, Road Bill passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present committed. Majesty, for repairing, widening, and altering the Road from Macclesfield, in the County of Chester, to the Turnpike Road at Randle Carr Lane Head, in Fernilee, in the County of Derby, leading to Chapel in the Frith, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir Robert Salusbury Cotton, Mr. Plumer, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

House to be Ordered, That this House be called over upon this culled over, jj Fortnight, the 1st Day of March next.

Ordered, That such Members as shall not then attend, be sent for in Custody of the Serjeant at Arms attending this House.

Haverford- Sir WatkinLevees presented to the House, according

Biif R°adS *° Order, a Bill for amending, widening, and keeping set!ted!* in Repair the Roads leading from the Town of Haverfordwest to a Place called the Bailiffs, send to

Great Treffgarne Bridge, and to the City of Saint David's, and from the said Cky to the Harbtour of Caerfai, in the Parish of Saint David's, in the County of Pembroke: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Taverns pi te Hoads 13 ill presented.

Sir Watkin Lerces presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, of the Eleventh Year of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, Several Roads leading from Tavcrnspitc to the Towns of Pembroke and Tenby, and to Hubberston in

the County of Pembroke: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Seccfnd Time.

Prayers.

A BILL for naturalizing Noah Turmioe, was read Turmine's a Second Time. Nat Bl1'

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir John commU Wodehouse, Mr. Henry Hobart, Ac.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Walkington thereunto subscribed, being Owners of Messuages, pect'°^ Cottages, Lands, and Estates in the Township e 11

kingtott, in the East Riding of the County of York, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are several Open Common Fields, Meadows,

Pastures, and Uninclosed Lands, within the said Township; that the Lands of the respective Proprietors, thereof lie intermixed and dispersed in small Parcels, and, in their present Situation, are incapable of any considerable Improvement, but, if the same were divided and inclosed, it would be very advantageous to aH the Parties interested therein: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes above mentioned, under such Regulations and Restrictions as the House shall think fit.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Sir Christopher Sykes ‘and Sir James Pennyman do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Edington thereunto subscribed, Owners of Estates in the Hamlet of Edington, in the County of Somerset, was presented to the House, and read; Setting loyth, That there are certain Common Moors or Waste Grounds within the said Hamlet, whereon the Petitioners, and others Owners of ancient Tenements in Edington aforesaid called Old Austers, have Right of Common; and that the said Common Moors or Waste Grounds are in their present State of inconsiderable Value to the Persons interested therein, but may be greatly improved by being divided and inclosed: And therefore prayings That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Common Moors or Waste Grounds, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Trial of Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this NnHastiogs. House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and . Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to

sterHall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

1 And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker’s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

Ordered, That the Names of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, be now called over.

And they were called over accordingly; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into West-, minster Hall accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Graves and Mr. Eames:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An The Lords Act for indemnifying all Persons who have been con* cemed in advising or carrying into Execution certain jemnity Bill. Orders of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, and also certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in Consequence of the same, and for making further Provisions relative thereto; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this The Lords House, That their Lordships will proceed further in will proceed the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Thursday ®" ^J*"rsday Morning next, at Ten of the Clock, in Westminster Hastings's HaU. Trad.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the Re- Report port, which, upon the 2 2d Day of July, in the last respecting Session of Parliament, was made from the Committee, who were appointed to inspect the several Houses and Westminster other Buildings immediately adjoining to Westminster Hall, Arc. to Halt, and the Two Houses of Parliament, and the he printed. Offices thereto belonging; and to report to the House their Opinion, from Time to Time, in what Manner the same may be best secured from the Danger of Fire, and what Improvements it may be proper to make therein, be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The Order of the Day being read;

Prayers.

MR. Sloane reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for dividing and allotting the intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Lands, within the Manor and Parish of Dibden, in the County of Southampton, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietors whose Estates are assessed to the Land Tax at 14/. 8$. per Annum, or thereabouts; and that the whole Property, having Right of Common upon the Lands to be divided and allotted, is rated to the Land Tax at 83/. 15 s. 8 \d.per Annum, or thereabouts; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

A Clause wa3 offered to be ad<fed to the Bill, declaring that the Act shall not extend to the Pasture Land called The Purlieu.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Then several Amendments were made by the House, to the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Lor^r Frederick Campbell reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill to empower William Henry Campbell, Esquire, to shut up a Road and Foot Paths in the Parish of Liston, in the County of Essex, and to oblige him to make, and keep in Repair for the future, another Road and Foot Path in lieu thereof, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of several Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, and others, residing or having Estates in the County of Suffolk, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That it appears, by a Survey lately taken, that a commodious navigable Communication may be made from Stomipland Bridge, situate upon the River Gippen, at the Town of Stcncmarket, to the Town and Port of Ipsrvich, in the County of Suffolk, by making Part of the said River navigable from the said Bridge to Harford Bridge, and for a small

Distance below Hanford Bridge, and by making a Navigable Cut from the said River Gippen below Hanford Bridge, to communicate with the River Orwell, and by cleansing, scouring, and improving the Navigation of the said River Orwell,from the said navigable Cut to Stoke Bridge, and to the common Quay at the Town of Ipswich, and also by making several Cuts and Works on the Sides of the said River Gippen, to avoid several Mills or Obstructions in the said River; and the making and maintaining the said navigable Communication will, as the Petitioners apprehend, be of great Benefit to the County of Suffolk, and the Neighbourhood thereof, and of public Utility; and that it also appears, by the said Survey, that the said Navigation is capable of being extended from Stowupland Bridge aforesaid, towards Bury St. Edmunds, for the Distance of Six Furlongs, or thereabouts, and the Petitioners apprehend it may be of great Benefit to the Public if Powers are given to make such Extension, in case the same shall hereafter be found necessary: And therefore praying, That Leave may be. given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining the said Navigation, by such Ways and Means, and in such Manner, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Grigby, Sir John Rous,

See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, to Norwich whom the Petition of the Mayor, Sheriffs, Citizens, Waterworks and Commonalty of the City of Norxeich, in Common Petltioni Council assembled, was referred; That the Committee report* had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, William Dewing, Esquire, Chamberlain of the City of Norwich, being examined, said, That the Petitioners are Owners of certain Works within the said City, for raising Water from the River Wenson, for the Supply of the Inhabitants of the said City and Parts adjacent:

Then,

Robert Mylne, Esquire, being examined, said, That he has surveyed the Mills, Pipes, Engines, Machinery, Conduits, Cisterns, and other Works already erected and used for the Purpose of the Supply of the said City and Parts adjacent with Water, and that the same are not sufficient in Power and Extent for that Purpose, and that it will be necessary to re-construct the whole Works, and to make certain additional Provisions of Reservoirs, Engines, and other Works, in order to procure a sufficient Supply of Water for the Use of the Inhabitants of the said City and Parts adjacent.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for better supplying the City 0? Noiwich, and the Parts adjacent, with Water: And that Mr. Henry Hobart,

Mr. Windham, and Sir John Wodehouse, do prepare, and bring in, the same.
