Petitioa A Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of Estates,

arK^ the Merchants, Tradesmen, and others, inte-

CackfieM rested in the Navigation of the River Ouse between

Navigation Newhaven and Barcombe in the Parish of Bar-

Bilk combe, in the County of was presented to the

House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners and others have already obtained Leave of the House to bring in a Bill for improving the Navigation of the said River, from to Bar-

combe Mill aforesaid; and that the said first-mentioned Bill includes so much of the Plan meant to be executed by the Bill prayed for by the Petitioners, as relates to the said River Ouse between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, and purports, as the Petitioners are informed, to make the Navigation of the said River, between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, private Property, and thereby to charge all Persons navigating thereon with a perpetual Toll, for the Benefit and Emolument of the Undertakers of the said Navigation, which will be a Hardship on the Petitioners, an unnecessary Burthen on the Trade and Commerce of the Country, and of great Detriment to the Public, whereas, by the Petitioners Bill, the Toll will be shortly reduced, so as to be no Burthen or Check to Commerce: And therefore praying, That they may be heard by themselves and Counsel, against so much of the said Bill for improving the Navigation of the River Ouse from Lewes Bridge to Cuckfield, as relates to the Space between Lewes Bridge and Barcombe Mill aforesaid, and that the said Bill may not pass into a Law as it now stands, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ditto. A Petition of the Commissioners of Sewers for

Lewes and Laughton Levels, adjoining the River Ouse, and lying between Newhaven and Barcombe Mill, in the County of Sussex, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth. That the Petitioners are Commissioners of the Sewers for draining the Lewes and Laughton Levels, adjoining to the River Ouse, and extending the whole Distance from Newhaven to Barcombe Mill aforesaid, appointed by a Commission issued pursuant to the Statute of the Twenty-third of Henry the Eighth, and have, by virtue of their Powers under the said Commission, expended considerable sums of Money, which have been raised by Taxes or Scots upon the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the said Levels, and laid out the same in widening and deepening the said River at various Places, and in rendering the same more strait, and have thereby very considerably assisted the Drainage of the Lands, and at the same Time improved the Navigation of the said River from Newhaven to Lewes Bridge, and had begun to proceed with their said Improvements from Lewes to Barcombe Mill, having already widened the said River as far as Barcombe Mwhich they could have accomplished without any great Burthen to the Country, but were prevented from carrying their Works into complete Execution by the incessant Rains and consequent Floods; and that the principal Merchants, Tradesmen, and others, of the Town of Lewes, and its Neighbourhood, have entered into an Agreement with the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the said Levels to pursue the said Improvements upon Terms very advantageous to the said Commission of Sewers, the Owners and Occupiers of Land, and Persons inte-Vol. 45.

rested in the Trade and Navigation of the said River, which Agreement, by a Commission of Sewers, held by the said Commissioners foe 16th of last,

hath been ratified and confirmed; and that, by foe said Bill, it is proposed to vest the Powers of deepening and widening that Part of the said River which lies between Lewes and Barcombe Mill aforesaid in a Company of Proprietors, and thereby to take the Direction and Management of the Works to be carried on upon the same out of the Hands of the Petitioners, and eventually to annul and defeat foe good Effects of the said beneficial Agreement made between foe Parties aforesaid: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against so much of the said Bill as gives Power to the Company, thereby to be constituted, to amend the Navigation of the said River Ouse, between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, and that the said Bill may not pass into a Law as it now stands, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of William Kemp, of South Mailing, near Petition Lewes, in the County of Sussex, Serjeant at Law, was against the also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Navigation Petitioner is seised of the Manor and ancient Scite of Bill, foe Deanery of South Mailing, and occupies the Lands, Tenements, Rectory, and Hereditaments thereunto belonging, situate on both Sides the River Ouse, together with a Bridge over the same, supported by the Petitioner and his Ancestors only, and a private Road planted with Trees upon the Western Bank of the said River, along a Causeway called Dean's Causeway, leading through the Petitioner’s Ground to the Town of Lewes, and a several Right of Fishery in the said River; and that the Petitioner conceives his Rights will be enroached on, and the Value of his Estate very materially injured, by the said River being altered, or the Navigation thereof amended, under the Powers in the said Bill: And foerefore praying. That he may be heard, by himself or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect him, and that the same may not pass as it now stands, or that the Petitioner may have such other Relief in the Premises as to foe House shall seem meet.

A Petition of William Newton, of SouthoVer, near Ditto. Lewes, in the County of Sussex, Esquire, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioner is the Owner of a Farm at Ringmer, in the said County, adjoining to Part of the River Ouse, between Lewes Bridge and Barcombe Mill; and that, by the said Bill, a Company of Proprietors, thereby to be incorporated, are to be empowered to make such new Cuts, Canals,

Trenches, or Passages for Water, in, upon, or through foe Lands or Grounds adjoining to the said River, as they the said Company shall think proper, and also to take any Ground adjoining to foe said River for the Purpose of making, erecting, or building any Wharfs, Warehouses, or Erections, that they shall think proper; and that it is the declared Intention of foe Promoters of the said Bill, to make a Cut, and turn foe said River from its ancient Bed, through the Petitioner’s said Farm, by Means whereof he will be greatly injured, inasmuch as his Farm, which is now remarkably compact and eligible, will be separated and disjoined; and that the Petitioner has been informed, by competent Judges, and verily believes, that the Purposes of the said Bill may be as well answered by the said River being continued in its ancient Bed, as by its being turned through the Petitioner’s said Farm, in which Belief he is confirmed by a Proposal, some Time since made to him by the Promoters of foe said Bill, that, if the Petitioner would acquiesce in their obtaining the Command of the said River Ouse, from Barcombe Mill to Lewes, no

C c Cut

Petition against the Lewes and Cuckiield Navigation Bill.

98 17" Februarii. A. 1790.

Cut should be made through his said Farm, and that the River should be continued in its ancient Bed; and that, if any Part of the Petitioner’s said Farm should be taken from him, by virtue of the Powers intended to be given by the said Bill to the said Company of Proprietors, he will be thereby very materially injured: And therefore praying, That he may be heard, by himself or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect him, and that the same may not pass as it now stands, or that he may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition from Thomas Rickman the Elder, of the Parish of Barcombe, and Thomas Rickman the Younger, of the Parish of All Saints, in Lezves, in the County of Sussed', was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and setting forth, That the Petitioners are the Owners and Occupiers of a large and ancient Water Com Mill in the Parish of Barcombe aforesaid, situate on the River Ouse, between Lewes and Cuckfield; and that, ..by the said Bill, the Company of Proprietors of the River Ouse Navigation, intended to be thereby incorporated, are empowered to make and set up over the said River, and the Branches thereof, and over the new Cuts, Canals, Trenches, and Passages for Water, to be made by virtue thereof, or upon the Lands adjoining and near to the same, such and so many Bridges, Sluices, Locks, Weirs, Pens for Water, Stanks, Dams, Quays, Winches, and other Engines, Posts, and Stoops, Landing Places, Wharfs, Weighing Beams, Cranes, and Warehouses, as the said Company of Proprietors shall think necessary, and, by the said Bill, the said Company of Proprietors, their Successors or Assigns, are further empowered to ask, demand, recover, and receive, such Sums of Money, Rates, and Duties, for the Passage of Vessels upon the said River, as shall be ascertained and settled by the said Company.; and that the said River from Lewes to Barcombe Mills hath always been, and now is, a free River, that the Petitioners have at different Times expended very considerable Sums of their own private Property in deepening, -straitening, and improving the same, and, in consequence thereof, now enjoy a constant Navigation for the Carriage of their Goods on the said River at a very moderate Expence; and that the Petitioners have expended several Thousand Pounds in the Purchase of Lands, and in erecting Warehouses, Wharfs, and other Conveniences and! Improvements, for the Purpose of carrying on the Trade of the said Mills, and have laid out several other Sums, to a large Amount, in purchasing and building Craft and Shipping, for the Exportation of Flour manufactured at the said Mills to various Parts of the World, and if any Locks, Weirs, or other Works, should be erected on the said River between Lewes and Barcombe Mills, whereby the working of the said Mills may be at all impeded or obstructed, the Property of the Petitioners will be greatly lessened in Value, and, if any Tolls or Duties are levied on that Part of the River Ouse between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, the Petitioners will be deprived of the present free Navigation (sufficient to answer all their Purposes) and wul be burthened with a heavy and unnecessary Expence; and that the Petitioners said Mills are wholly supplied by certain Streams, which, by the said Bill, appear to be intended to be made Navigable, and which Streams are frequently, in dry Seasons, insufficient to keep the said Mills in constant Work, and they conceive that their Property and Trade will be liable to very great Injuries by the making the said Streams Navigable, because they will be thereby deprived of the usual Supplies of Water necessary for working the said Mills: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against such

Parts of the said Bill as may affect them, and that the same may not pass into a Law as it now stands, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of Joseph Mighell, of East Kennett, in the Mr. Mighell's County of Wilts, Esquire, was likewise presented to the Petition House, and read; also taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioner is seised of cer- Cuckfield tain Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, in the Navigation Parish of Hamsey, in the County of Sussex, of the Extent, on the Banks of the said River, of Three Miles and upwards, in Part of which the Petitioner, at a very considerable Expence, hath made a Cut of Half a Mile in Length for the Purpose of draining his Lands through which the said intended Navigation is to be carried, and erected a Bridge over the same; and that the Petitioner conceives his Rights will be encroached on, and the Value of his Estate very materially injured, by the said River being altered, or the Navigation thereof amended under the Powers in the said Bill: And therefore praying, That he may be heard by himself or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect him, and that the same may not pass as it now stands, or that the Petitioner may have such Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the said Bill is committed; and the Petitioners are to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee,

upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

Mr. Duncombe presented to the House, according to Selby Bridge Order, a Bill for building a Bridge at or near the Ferry over the River Ouse, from Selby, in the West Riding of the County of York, to the opposite Shore, in the Parish of Hemingborough, in the East Riding of the said County of York: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

A Petition of the Right honourable Robert Edward Lord Petre’* Lord Petre, Baron of Writtle, in the County of Essex, p^,u°rn(^Dj)« was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, Bill.

That the Petitioner is Owner and Proprietor of a certain Ferry over the River Ouse, at Selby, in the West Riding of the County of York, called Selby Ferry, and the Inhabitants of the Country on each Side of the said River, being desirous that a Bridge phould be erected

30 Geo. III. 17° -. 18

erected across the same at or near the Ferry at Selby aforesaid, and being also of Opinion that such Bridge would be of great public Utility, the Petitioner was applied to, and consented to give up his Right and Interest in the said Ferry in Consideration of an Annual Rent of 25 /. being secured to him Out of the Tolls of the said Bridge; and that the Petitioner is informed, that a Petition is, or is about to be, presented to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill for building such Bridge: And therefore praying. That such Bill may pass into a Law, and that the Petitioner may be secured the said Annual Rent of 2,51, out of the Tolls of the said intended Bridge, in such Manner as the House shall judge meet.

Ordered \That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

Cromford George Cavendish reported from the Committee,

tition Pe" to w^om the Petition of the Canal Corn-

reported. pany, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 20th of July 1789, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; but that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 2 5th of April 1774, relative to Navigation Bills, had not been complied with, it nor being intended to extend or vary the Line of the said Canal, or to raise any further Sum of Money for the Purposes of the said Canal; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth;

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to , Cromford Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join

and communicate with the Canal, at or near

Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mitt, in the said County, was read: And,

Mr. William Jessop, Engineer, being examined, said, That Application had been made to the said Company on Behalf of several Owners of Mills upon and hear the River Derwent, and also the Company of Proprietors of the Erewash Canal Navigation, alledging, that the several Clauses and Provisions contained in the before-mentioned Act did not give effectual Security and Protection to the said Mills, and requesting the said Company to apply to Parliament, to which the said Company had agreed.

And the Witness added. That there are some other Amendments and Alterations necessary to be made in the said Act for effecting the Purposes thereby intended.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to alter and amend an Act, passed in the Tast Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Cromford Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at of near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County: And that Lord George Cavendish and Mr. Mttndy do prepare, and bring in, the same.

and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s 'fable:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time. One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Mutiny Bill Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for reported-punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

The Order of the Day being read, for the Second Debtor, Bill Reading of the Bill for the Relief of Debtors, for the putofffor more speedy and effectual Payment of Creditors, and for the Regulation of Gaols, so far as relates to imprisoned Debtors;

A Motion was made, and the Question being put.

That the said Bill be now- read a Second Time;

It passed in the Negative.

Ordered, That the said Bill be read a Second Time upon this Day Three Months.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning de* next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning Ways and next, resolve 'itself into a Committee of the whole de‘ House, to consider further of Ways and Means for Ierre raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

AN ingrossed Bill to empower William Henry Camp- Mr. Camp-beli, Esquire, -to shut up a Road and Foot Paths bell’s Road in the Parish of Liston, in the County of Essex, and to passed, oblige him to make, and keep in Repair for the future, another Road and Foot Path in lieu thereof, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to empower William Henry Campbell,

Esquire, to shut up a Road. and Foot Paths in the Parish of Liston, in the County of Essex, and to oblige him to make, and keep in Repair for the future, another Road and Foot Path in lieu thereof.

Petition for Mr. Hungerford reported from the Committee, to

tieLdmter w^om Petition of the several Persons whose Names mdWeiford 8X6 thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves, and Road Bill re- others, Owners of Estates and Inhabitants within the ported. Parishes of Desford and Newbold in the County of Leicester, was referred; That the Committee had examined and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had not been complied with, it not being determined to repair and widen the Two Pieces of Road, mentioned in the Petition, at the Time the Notices were given of the intended Application to Parliament for a Bill to amend the Leicester and Welford Road Act; that both the said Pieces of Road are not One Mile in Length; and that it is not proposed to erect any Gate thereon, or take any additional Toll on the other Road in Consequence of repairing the said Two Pieces of Road; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the Honse; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Robert Hubbard being examined, said, That Two Pieces of Road, one called Hunt's Lane, in the Parish of Desford, and the other called Wood Lane, in the Parish of Newbold Verdon, branching out of the Turnpike Road leading from the Leicester and Welford Turnpike Road to the Road from Hinckley to Ashby de la are

narrow, and very much out of Repair, and that it would be advantageous to the Country if the said Lanes were put under the Care of the Trustees for repairing the said Road.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentle-% men, who are appointed to prepare, and bring in, a

Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester and We ford Turnpike Road, in the Counties of Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby de la Zouch, in the said County of Leicester, That they do make Provision in the said Bill, for repairing and widening Two Pieces of Road, called Hunts Lane and Wood Lane, in the Parishes of Desford and bol<T Verdon,branching out of the said Turnpike Road.

Expiring Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to en-Laws quire what Laws are expired, or near expiring; and Comm‘«te to report their Opinion, from Time to Time, to the Bppom ' House, which of them are fit to be revived or continued.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. Rose, Mr. Gilbert, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow

Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Trial of Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this

Mr.Haatingx. House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Westminster Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker's Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House, in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading the reto^ to attend

their Service in the Honse immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And be went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

And the Names of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Hall accordingly. ‘

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

A Petition of Joseph Ager, Esquire, and Francis Moore, Esquire, and the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Owners and Proprietors of Lands in the Common Fields; Common Meadows, and Common Grounds, in the Parish of Bowbrickhill, and in the Hamlet of Stratford,

in the County of Buckingham, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Lands and Grounds of the Petitioners, and others, in the said Fields, lie intermixed and dispersed, and, in their present Situation, are incapable of Improvement, and it would be advantageous to the Persons interested therein if the said Lands and Grounds were divided and inclosed, and specific Parts thereof allotted to the several Persons interested, in proportion to their respective Rights: And therefore praying That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Common Fields, and other Commonable Grounds, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Secretary Grenville and Mr. Bernard do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Owners of Land in the County of Fife, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Foodiesmiln, Inner-keithing, Aberdour, Kirkaldy, and Cameron

Bridge, to Crail;and the Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Durfermline, the Crossgates, and Auchtertool, to Kirkaldy, with the Branches from the same to Charlestown and Limekilns, by Crossford, Cadi, and Ladysmiln: and the Road from Dtafernmne, Westward to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of and' the Road from the Plais by Kinglassie and Auchterderran, to the Kirk of Beath; and the Road from Kirkaldy, Northward till it joins the Road from the Plaisterers to the Kirk of Beath’, and the Road from Kirkaldy, by the New Inn, Cupar, and Pitcullo, to Dundee Water-side; and the Road from the said New by

Falkland and Strathmiglo, Northward to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Perth, with a Branch to Newburgh by Shells Bridge’, and the Road from Cupar, by Kaimsford and Lcthem, through Kennoway, to Cameron Bridge, where it joins the Road first above-mentioned from Newmiln Bridge to; and the Road from Cupar, by Callinch Bridge, to Bal-cams, where it joins the said Road leading from Newmiln Bridge to Crail, with the Branch from La-thockar Bridge to Crail-, and the Road from Cupar, by Strathmiglo, Westward to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Kinross, with the Branch by Lethem and Newburgh, to the Extremity of the County

Fife Roads, &c Petition.

County of Fife, joining the County of Perth; and the Road from Saint Andrews, by Guard Bridge, till it joins the said Road from Kirkaldy to Dundee Water-side at Dronsmuir; and the Road from Dundee Water-side, by Guard Bridge and Denhead, joining the Road from Cupar to Balcarres,at Raderny; and the Road from Kirkaldy to Dysart, and from Dysart, Eastward until it joins the said Road from Gallatmvn to Cameron Bridge; all which Roads lead through the County of Fife, are generally in bad Repair, and inconvenient to Travellers, and the same cannot be effectually made and kept in Repair by the Funds arising by the Laws now in Force, which are applicable to the making and repairing of many other Roads in the said County; and that a Port of the said Line of Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Foodicsmiln, Inverkeithing, Aberdour, and

Kirkaldy, to Crail, and a Part of the said Line of Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Dunfermline, the Crossgates, and Auchtertool, to Kirkaldy, have been made under the Authority of an Act, passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of his late Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act for repairing the Road from the North Queensferry " through the Towns of Inverkeithing and Kinross, to " the Town of Perth; and also the Road from the said " Queensjerry to the Towns of Dunfermline, Torryburn,

" and Culross; and also the Road from the said " Queensferry, through Inverkeithing, to " and Kirkaldy,'’ and of another Act, passed in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to continue, and render more effectual, an Act, passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of the " Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing the Road " from the North Queensferry, through the Towns of " Inverkeithing and Kinross, to the Town of Perth " and also the Road from the said Queensferry to the " Towns of Dmfermline, Torryburn, and Culross; and

" also the Road from the said Queensferry, through " Inverkeithing, to Bruntisland and Kirkaldy," the

Terms granted by which Acts are not yet expired, and as the said Parts of the said Lines of Road do and will need farther Repair, and to be kept in Repair, it would be of Advantage to the Public, if the Care and Management of the said Parts, in common with the other Roads in the County of Fife, herein above described, were committed to the same Trustees; and that the free Passage and Communication by the Ferry, betwixt Leith and Kinghorn, is materially connected with the High Roads of the County of Fife, being not only the general Access to the said County, but also from the North of Scotland to the South, that the Regulation of the said Ferry is under the Direction of the Justices of the Peace for the Counties of Mid-Lothian and Fife, and the last mentioned County has already voluntarily expended several Hundred Pounds in erecting a Bason, for the Purpose of deepening and improving the Harbour of Kinghorn, or Pettycur; and that the said Harbour could yet be very much improved, by erecting another Bason for the above Purpose, and the Access to the said Harbour, and Shipping Places thereof, could also be greatly improved, if a sufficient Fund was provided for those Purposes, by a Tax to be levied on Passengers crossing at the said Ferry: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making, repairing, and keeping in Repair, the several Roads in the County of Fife, herein above-mentioned and described, and for erecting the said Bason, and improving the said Harbour.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Wemyss, Mr. Douglas, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; Vox,. 45.

and' have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and

Records.

Lord William Russell reported from the Committee, streatham to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Workhouse Names are thereunto subscribed, on behalf of themselves, Petition and others, Owners of Estates, and Inhabitants within reported‘ the Parish of Streatham, in the County of Surrey, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

John Reader being examined, said, That the Parish of Streatham is large and populous, and the Poor thereof being very numerous, it would render the

D d Rates

Slave Trade deferred.

Dibden Inclosure Bill passed.

The Lords have agreed to

Land Tax Bill.

Malt Bill.

102

18° — 19° j Februarii. 1790.

Bates for their Relief much less burthensotne, and the Poor might be better maintained, if a proper Work-house was provided, wherein they could be received and employed.

And the Witness further said, That many People of considerable Fortune reside within the said Parish, and it frequently happens that Persons appointed Overseers of the Poor do not execute the Duties of their Office themselves, but leave them to be performed by interested Deputies, by which Means the Poors Rates are frequently much misapplied, and rendered more heavy than is necessary; which it is apprehended might in a great Degree be prevented, if a proper Person was to be appointed to act as an additional Overseer of the Poor of the said Parish.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for providing a Workhouse for, and for the better Relief and Employment of, the Poor of the Parish of Streatham, in the County of Surrey, and for appointing an additional Overseer for the better Government of the Poor of the said Parish: And that Lord William Russell and Sir Joseph Mawbey do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The Order of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Sevennight, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 19° die Anno 30* GeorgiiTII,u Regis, 1790. Prayers.

AN ingrossed Bill for dividing and allotting the intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Lands, within the Manor and Parish of Dibden, in the County of Southampton, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for dividing and allotting the intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Lands, within the Manor and Parish of Dibden, in the County of Southampton.

Ordered, That Mr. Sloane do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Graves and Mr. Fames:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty, by a Land Tax to be raised in Great Britain, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing and granting to His Majesty certain Duties upon Malt, Mum, Cyder, and Perry, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; without any Amendment.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

The House being informed that Mr. Morton, from East India the Directors of the East India Company, attended at Accounts the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented Presented-to the House, pursuant to the Directions of an Act of Parliament,

N° 4. An Account (made up according to the latest Advices) of the Annual Produce of the Revenues of Fori Marlborough, and of the Annual Charges at the said Residency; distinguishing the same under the sevd* ral Heads thereof: And also,

Mr. Grigby reported from the Committee, to whotri

the Petition of several Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders and others, residing or having Estates in the County of Suffolk, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition; and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerks Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; .

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. William Jessop, an Engineer, being examined, said, That a commodious Navigable Communication may be made from Stoxcupl Bridge, upon the River Gippen, at the Town *of < to the

Town and Port of Ipswich, in the County of Suffolk, by making Part of the said River Navigable from the said Bridge to Handford Bridge, and for a small Distance below it, and by making a Navigable Cut from thence to communicate with the River Orwell, and by cleansing, scouring, and improving the Navigation of the said River from the said Cut to Stoke Bridge and Ipswich, and by making several Cuts and Works on the Sides of the said River to avoid

several Mills or Obstructions in the said River.

Mr. Jessop being further examined, said, That the said Navigation is capable of being extended from Stowupland Bridge, towards Bury Saint Edmunds, for the Distance of Six Furlongs or thereabouts.

Mr. Charles Baines being examined, said, That the making and maintaining the said Navigable Communication, and the giving Power to make the Extension towards Bury Saint Edmunds, if the same shall be found necessary, will be a great Benefit to the County of Suffolk, and the Neighbourhood thereof, and of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Communication between Stowmarket and Ipswich, in the County* of Suffolk* And that Mr. Grigby and Sir John Rous do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to the Clerk of the Crown, to make out a new Writ for the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of Old Sarum, in the County of Wilts,in the room of the Right honourable John

Charles Villiers, who, since his Election for the said Borough, hath accepted the Places and Offices of Warden and Chief Justice and Justice in Eyre of all His Majesty’s Forests, Chaces, Parks, and Warrens, on the North Side of the River Trent.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to the Clerk of the Crown, to make out a new Writ for the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of Tiverton, in the County of Devon, in the room of the Honourable Dudley Ryder, who, since his Election for the said Borough, hath accepted the Office of Comptroller of His Majesty’s Household.

Sir Robert Lawley presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of Warwick: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Lord George Cavendish presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to alter and amend an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Cromjord Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Canal, at or

near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the unfortunate Citizens of London, confined for Debt in the City Prison of Ludgate, was presented to the House, and read; Complaining of their Distress, and praying Relief.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, of the Eighth Year of His present Majesty, for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading to and through the Town of Goudhurst, in the County of Kent, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Marsham, Mr. Call, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Bill for the better paving, cleansing, lighting; and watching the City of Coventry, and the Suburbs thereof, and removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein, -and for widening and otherwise improving the Streets, and regulating the Public Wells and Pumps within the said City and Suburbs, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill, be committed to the Lord Eardley, Mr. Wilmot, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Sir William Dolben reported from the Committee, appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade, and who were empowered to report the Minutes of such Examination, from Time to Time, to the House; That the Committee had made a further Progress in the Matter to them referred; and had directed him to report the Minutes of the said Examination to the House; and he read the Report in his Place: And afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Wittlesford; and also, the Petition of tile several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Trustees for carrying into Execution several Acts of Parliament, passed for repairing the Road from London to

Cambridge, beginning at Foulmire, in the County of

Cambridge, and ending at the Pavement in ton Street, in the Town of Cand other Roads adjacent; and also, the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are ihereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others. Owners and Occupiers of Estates in the Neighbourhood of the Road leading from

Chesterjord Bridge, in the Parish of Great Chestcrford, in the County of Essex, through the Parishes of ton, Duxford, and Wittleford, to the End of the Town of Wittlesford, next to She ford, in the County of Cambridge, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with, in respect to the First-mentioned Petition; but that the said Orders had not been complied with, in respect to the Second and Third-mentioned Petitions (except that Notice for the Application of the Third-mentioned Petition was given at the Michaelmas Quarter Sessions) it not having been determined to apply to Parliament for the Repair of the Pieces of Road therein-mentioned, until it was too late fully to comply with the said Standing Orders, and which Road, described in the Second-mentioned Petition, is about One Mile in Length, and in the Third-mentioned Petition about Six Miles in Length; and it also appeared, that it is not intended to take any Toll upon either of the said Pieces of Road, or in Consequence of their being added to the Trust, and that the Trustees named in the First-mentioned Petition are willing to take those Pieces of Road under their Care; and that the Committee had also found, that the principal Inhabitants of the several Parishes, through which the Road described in the last mentioned Petition runs, are desirous that the same may be made Turnpike; and that the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; v

To prove the Allegations of the First-mentioned Petition, the several Acts therein mentioned were read: And,

Mr. Christopher Pemberton being examined, said, That for the Purpose oft repairing the Road from Stump Cross to Newmarket Heath and Cambridge, and from Shelford to Wittlesford,considerable Sums of

Money were borrowed upon the Credit of the Tolls; and that the Money now owing cannot be repaid, nor the said Roads effectually amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term granted by the said Acts be enlarged, and some Amendments made.

To prove the Allegations of the Second-mentioned Petition, Mr. Pemberton being examined, said, That he had attended a Meeting of the Trustees for the Repair of the said Road from to Carhbridge,

who having under their Care a larger Extent of Road than their Tolls are sufficient to repair, are desirous of being discharged from the Management of the Piece of Road mentioned in this Petition, which is about One Mile in Length;, and he also said, that the Trustees for the said Road from Stump Cross to Newmarket Heath, conceiving that their Fund is capable of bearing such an additional Expence, are willing to take on themselves the Care of the said Piece of Road, whereby the same may be effectually amended, and the Public be better accommodated.

Then, to prove the Allegations of the Third-mentioned Petition, Mr. Pemberton being further exq-

Vol. 45.

mined, said, That the Piece of Road therein mentioned, about Six Miles in Length, is much out of Repair, and it will be of public Advantage to have the same amended and kept in Repair by the Trustees of the Road from Stump Cross to Newmarket Heath aforesaid, who are willing to take the Charge thereof, without any Increase of Toll.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term of several Acts, made for repairing the Roads from Stump Cross to Newmarket Heath, and from Stump Cross aforesaid to the End of the Town of Trumpington next to Shelford, and from Shelford Pound to Wittlesford, and for making more effectual Provision for repairing the said Roads, and also One Mile of the Road between Trumpington and Cambridge, commencing at the South End of Trumpington aforesaid; and for amending the Road from Chesterjord Bridge to the End of Wittlesford, next to Shelford, all in the County of Cambridge: And that Mr. Yorke and General Adeane do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Abingdon thereunto subscribed, being Trustees for executing an so>ad Pe-Act, passed in the Eighth Year of the Reign of His tltio,u present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from The Mayor's Stone, in Abingdon, in the County of Berks, through Cumner to the ancient Horse Road at Swinford, in the said County, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That a Progress hath been made in amending the said Road, and a considerable Sum of Money hath been borrowed on the Credit of the said Act, which still remains due, with a very large Arrear of Interest; and that the said Debt cannot be paid, nor the said Road be effectually amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are enlarged, and some further Toll granted: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: and that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Pye, Mr. &c.:

And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " better regulating and ascertaining the Importation " and Exportation of Corn and Grain; and also for " better regulating the Exportation of Starch, and " the Importation of Rape Seed," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to consider of the said Act, and to report their Opinion to the House, in what Manner the Provisions of the said Act may be more effectually carried into Execution; and also, what Alterations and Amendments it may appear necessary to make in the Laws respecting

the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. Bramston, Mr. Spencer Stanhope,

Mr. Gregory,'Mr. Alderman Watson, Mr. Strutt, Mr. Whitbread, the Marquis of Graham, Mr. Plumer, Mr.

Smyth, Sir Henry Hoghton, Mr. Rolle, Sir Archibald monstone, Mr. Hungerford, Mr. Smith, Mr. Thornton, Mr.

Mr. Phelips, Mr. Scott, Mr. Marsfum, Mr. Wilberforce,

Mr. Hobart; and all the Knights for Shires, Gentlemen of the Long Robe, and Merchants in the House, and the Members who serve for North Britain: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and all who come to the Committee are to have Voices.

MR. Wemyss reported from the Committee, to whom Fifc Roads

the Petition of the Persons thereunto subscrib- &c. Petition ing, Owners of Land in the County of Fife, was re- reported, ferred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; vi

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, a Member present informed your Committee, That the Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Foodiesmiln, keithing, Aberdour, Kirkaldy, Gallatown, and Cameron Bridge, to Crail; and the Road from Newmiln Bridge, by Dunfermline, the Crossgates, and Auchtertool, to Kirkaldy, with the Branches from the same, to Charlestown and Limekilns, by Crossford, Cavil, and Ladys-miln; and the Road from Dunfermline, Westward to the

the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Perth; and the Roiad from the by Kinglassie and Auchterderran, to the Kirk of Beath;

and the Road from Kirkaldy, Northward till it joins the Road from the Plaisterers to the Kirk of and the Road from Kirkaldy, by the New Inn, Cupar, and Pitcullo, to Dundee Water-side; and the Road from the said Nezo Inn, by Falkland and Strathmiglo, Northward to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Perth, with a Branch to Newburgh, by Shells Bridge-, and the Road from Cupar, by Kaimsford and Lethem, through Kennoway, to Cameron Bridge, where it joins the Road first above-mentioned from Nczvmiln Bridge to Crail;and the Road from Cupar, by Callinch Bridge, to Balcarres, where it joins the said Road leading from Newmiln Bridge to Crail, with the Branch from Lathockar Bridge to Crail; and the Road from Cupar, by Strathmiglo, Westward to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Kinross, with the Branch by Lethem and Nezoburgh, to the Extremity of the County of Fife, joining the County of Perth-, and the Rdad from Saint Andrews, by Guai'd Bridge, till it joins the said Road from Kirkaldy to Dundee Water-side at Dronsmuir-, and the Road from Dundee Water-side, by Guard Bridge and join-

ing the Road from Cupar to Balcarres, at Rademy Ground; and the Road from Kirkaldy to Dysart, and from Dysart, Eastward until it joins the said Road from Gallatown to Cameron Bridge; all of which Roads lead through the County of Fife, are in general in bad Repair, and inconvenient to Travellers, and that the same cannot be effectually made and kept in Repair by the Funds arising by the Laws now in Force, which are applicable to the making and repairing of many other Roads in the said County.

That a Part of the said Line of Road which leads from Newmiln Bridge, by Foodiesmiln, Inverkeithing, Aberdour, and Kirkaldy, to Crail, and a Part of the said Line of Road which leads from Newmiln Bridge, by Dunfermline, the Crossgates, and Auchtertool, to Kirkaldy, have been made under the Authority of an Act, passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of his late Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act for repairing " the Road from the North Queen's ferry, through " the Towns of Inverkeithing and Kinross, to the Town " of Perth; and also the Road from the said " ferry to the Towns of Dunfermline, Torryburn, and " Culross; and also the Road from the said Queen'sferry, through Inverkeithing, to Bruntisland and " Kirkaldy;" and of another Act, passed in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to continue and render more effectual the said Act, the Terms of which Acts are not yet expired; and as the said Parts'of the said Lines x)f Road do and will need further Repair, and to be kept in Repair, he apprehends it would be of Advantage to the Public if the Care and Management of the said Parts, in common with the other Roads in the County of Fife above-mentioned, were committed to the same Trustees.

That the free Passage and Communication by the Ferry, betwixt Leith and Kingis materially con-. nected with the High Roads of the County of Fife, being not only the general Access to the said County, but also from the North of Scotland to the South, the Regulation of which Ferry is under the Direction of the Justices of His Majesty’s Peace for the Counties of Mid-Lothian and Fife; and the last mentioned County has already voluntarily expended several Hundred Pounds in erecting a Bason, for the Purpose of deepening and improving the Harbour of Kinghorn, or Pettycur — That the said Harbour would be very much improved if another Bason was erected for the above Purpose, and the Access to the said Harbour and Shipping Places thereof, would also be greatly

Vox.. 45.

improved, if a sufficient Fund was provided for these Purposes, by a Tax to be levied on Passengers crossing at the said Ferry.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for making and repairing the Road from Newmiln Bridge by Foodies Mill, Invcrkeithing, Aberdour, Kirkaldy,

Gallatown, and Cameron Bridge, to Craill, and other Roads in the County of Fife; and for improving the Harbour of Kinghorn or Pettycur, in the said County:

And that Mr. JVemyss and Sir Thomas Dundas do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Greenbill A Petition of several Trustees appointed in and by' Md Botham virtue of an Act of Parliament, made and passed in J’etition. *Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road leading from the Turnpike Road between Wheatley Rocks and Tein the County of Stafford, at or neair a Place called Greenhill, in the Parish of Cheadle, and County of Stafford, through the Parishes of Cheadle, Kingsley, and to a Place called

Botham House, situate on or near the Turnpike Road leading from Ashborne, in the County of Derby, to Leek, in the County of Stafford, and also the Road leading from Bothan House, across the said Turnpike Road, to and through the Township of Onecoat, to or near Butterton Moor End, in the said County of Stafford, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by virtue of the said Act, the Sum of 3,100l. hath been borrowed upon the Credit of the Tolls arising therefrom, which, together with the Tolls {after Payment of the Interest of the said Sum, and about 400l. e.^epted) have been laid out in

making and repairing the said Road, and in erecting sundry Bridges, Toll Houses, and Turnpike Gates thereon, and for such other Purposes as are by the said Act directed; and that the Whole of the Money so borrowed still remains due, and cannot be repaid; nor the Road kept in sufficient Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be enlarged, and the Powers thereof altered and continued, and the Qualifications of the Trustees therein reduced: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for renewing and enlarging the Term, ana altering and continuing the Powers, of the stud Act, under such Regulations and Restrictions as the House shall think

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Gilbert, the Earl Gower,

&c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records. *

An Account, shewing the Amount of the Sums Sufferers, that will be necessary for the Payment of Intrest, presented after the Rate of 3/. 10 s. per Centum per Annum, for Six Months, of the Principal Sums remaining unpaid on the several Orders made out at the Receipt of the Exchequer, pursuant to an Act of Parliament, of the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for giving Relief to " such Persons as have suffered in their Rights and " Properties during the late unhappy Dissentions in " America, in Consequence of their Loyalty to His (i Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government; and for making Compensation to such Persons as have suffered in ‘their Properties, in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East '

" Florida to the King of Spain," which will become due on the 5th Day of April 1790, together with the Sum of 61. 5 s. per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order, and also for Six Months Interest, which will become due on the 10th Day of October 1790, after the same Rate of 3/. 10 5. per Centum per Annum, on the Principal Sum then remaining unpaid, together with 61. 5 s.per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order respectively.

An ACCOUNT shewing the Amount of the Sums that will be necessary for the Payment of Interest, after the Rate of 3/. io$. per Centum per Annum, for Six Months, of the Principal Sums remaining unpaid on the several Orders made out at the Receipt of the Exchequer, pursuant to an Act of Parliament, of the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for giving Relief to such Persons as have suffered in their Rights and Properties during the late unhappy Dissentions in America, in " consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government; and for making Compensation to such Persons as have suffered in their Properties, " in consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain," which will become due on the 5th Day of April 1790, together with the Sum of 61. 5 per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order, and also for Six Months Interest, which will become due on the 10th Day of October 1790, after the same Rate of 3/. 10#. per Centum per Annum, on the Principal Sum then remaining unpaid, together with 61. 5 s.per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order respectively.

Exchequer, the 2 2d Day of February 1790.

Rob' Jenn.

Account of Whale Ship* from Scotland — and, of Tobacco in Warehouses there, presented.

Streatham Workhouse Bill presented.

Account of Tin exported, ordered.

Account of Pewter exported, ordered.

West India and Quebec Trade Acts to be considered.

Ordered','That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The House being informed that Mr. from the Commissioners of the Customs in Scotland, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to the Directions of an Act of Parliament,

An Account of what Number of Ships or Vessels, from Scotland, have been employed in the Whale Fishery to Davis's Streights and The Greenland Seas, with their respective Names and Burthens, from whence they were fitted out, and at what Port discharged, and also what Quantity of Oil, or Blubber, or Whale Fins, each Ship has imported, from the 10th of October 1788 to the 10th of October 1789.

Mr. Alcock also, from the Commissioners of the Customs in Scotland, presented to the House, pursuant to their Order of the 25th Day of June, in the last Session of Parliament,

An Account of the Number of Hogsheads of Tobacco received into the King’s Warehouses in Scotland, and delivered out for Home Consumption and Exportation, between the 5th Day of January 1788 and the 5th Day of January 1789; specifying the Weight of each Hogshead when brought in,. and also when delivered out.

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

OrderedThat the said Accounts do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Lord William Russell presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for providing a Workhouse for, and for the better Relief and Employment of, the Poor of the Parish of Streatham, in the County of Surrey, and for appointing an additional Overseer for the better Government of the Poor of the said Parish: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Quantity of Tin exported from Great Britain for the last Twenty Years, with the Duties paid thereon; distinguishing each Year, and to what Countries.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Quantity of Pewter exported from Great Britain for the last Twenty Years; distinguishing each Year, and to what Countries.

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade between " the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies and Plantations in North America and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of America, and between His Majesty’s said " Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The West Indies," might be read.

And the same was read accordingly.

The House was also moved, That an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to allow the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, from His Majesty’s " Colonies or Plantations in The West Indies, into " the Province of Quebec, without Payment of Duty, " under certain Conditions end Restrictions," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning,

resolve itself into a Committee" erf the whole House, to consider of the said Acts.

A Petition of the Right honourable Jacob Earl of Radnor, Lord of the Manor of Whychurch and Mil-borne, in the County of Wiltand the humble Petition of Susanna Earle, Widow, Lady of the Manor of Little Somerford, in the said County, and also of Thomas

Brown Caltey, Esquire, Abraham Young, John Stratton,

and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Proprietors of Beast Leazes in and upon the said Commons, or one of them, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Manor, certain Open Commons and Waste Grounds, called Milborne Common, Little Somerford Common, Wallow Marsh, and Whychurch Marsh, and also an Open Meadow, called The Lott and

that the said Commons are now fed in Common, and for the most Part over-run and incumbered with Furze, Brambles, and Rushes, and the said Meadow is in small Parcels, and for those Reasons the said Commons and Meadow cannot be cultivated and improved to the best Advantage: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring iu a Bill for dividing, allotting, draining, and inclosing the said Commons and Meadow, and making specific Allotments thereof, according to the Rights of the several Parties interested therein, and under such Regulations as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Bouverie and Mr. John Smyth do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution Two Acts of Parliament, one made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the other in the Eighteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for reputing, amending, and widening the Road from Keighley, in the West Riding of the County of York, to Kirkby in Kendal, in the County of Westmorland, so far as relate to such Part of the said Road as lies within the said County of York, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by the said Act, made in the Eighteenth Year of His present Majesty, so much of the said Road as lies within the County of York, was made a District separate and distinct from the other Parts of the Road comprised in the said first-mentioned Act, and put under the sole Care and Management of the Petitioners; and that the Petitioners have proceeded in the Execution of the said Acts, so far as relate to the said District, and have borrowed several considerable Sums of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which still remain due; and that many Parts of the Road within the said District were very steep and dangerous, and the Petitioners have been under the Necessity of turning and diverting the same, in order to avoid the hilly Parts thereof, which has been attended with a very great Expence, and that, in order to complete the said Road, and make the same commodious and safe, it will be necessary to divert several other Parts thereof, and to borrow a further Sum of Money for that Purpose; but the same cannot be done, and the Road kept in good Repair for the future, unless the Tolls now payable within the said District be increased, and the Term of the said Acts, so far as relate to the said District, be further continued, and some Alterations and Amendments made therein: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Tolls and Powers, of the said Acts, so far as relate to the said District, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered,

Whychurch, &c. Inclosure Petition.

Keighley Road Petition.

Motion respecting the Governor's House, &c. at Plymouth; Neg.

Supply

deferred.

Ways and Means deferred*

Leave given to make a Motion*

NewChappell Road Petition.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. D Mr.

Ac.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Money already expended in building the new House, Offices, &c. &c. within the Lines of Plymouth for the Residence of the Governor of that Garrison; together with an Estimate of the future Expence necessary to complete and to furnish the said House, Offices, &c. exclusive of the Labour of the Corps of Artificers on the same;

It passed in the Negative.

The Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty/

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Ordered, That Mr. Wilberforce have Leave to make a Motion, it being near Five of the Clock.

And he moved the House accordingly.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Mortis,23° die Februarii;

Anno 30° Georgii III*1 Regis, 1790. Prayers.

A PETITION of several Trustees, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, for putting in Execution an Act, made in the Tenth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Road from New Chappell, in the County of Surrey, over Copthorn, in the County of Sussex, through Landfield, to the Town of up to the Top of Ditchling Bost Hills, in the said County of Sussex, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have proceeded in the execution of the said Act, and have borrowed several large Sums of Money on the Credit thereof, which now remain unpaid, and cannot be repaid, and the said Road made, and kept in good Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are further continued and enlarged, and the Act in other Respects made more effectual: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and enlarging the Powers, of the said Act, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Thomas Pelham, Lord George Henry Lenox, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Vox.. 45.

Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Mayor, Aldermen, Clergy, Ci- Durban* tizens, and Inhabitants, of the City of Durham and ?avin8 Feth Framwclgate, and the Suburbs thereof, whose Names tw,1‘ are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the City of,

and Borough of Framwelgate are situated on the great

North Road from London to Edinburgh, and several of the Houses and Buildings within the said City and Borough, and the Suburbs and Streets thereof, and thereto adjoining, are in an inconvenient and dan-' gerous Situation for the passing of Carriages, and, on that Account, Accidents are frequently happening; insomuch that the Loss of many Lives are occasioned thereby, and others of the said Houses and Buildings are inconveniently situated for Foot Passengers; and that it will be of public Utility to render the said Streets and Lanes more convenient and commodious for the passing of Carriages, and for People on Foot, but, to effect which, it will be necessary to have the said Houses and Buildings taken down, and to have the Buildings and Erections, to be built on such Part of the Ground whereon the present Houses and Buildings stand, as may be necessary for making the said Streets and Lanes more commodious and convenient, designed, planned and set out, with a view particularly to such Convenience and Accommodation; and it will also be of public Utility, to have all Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances, within the said City and Borough, and the Suburbs and Streets thereof, and thereto adjoining, removed, and to have the Streets, Lanes, public Ways, and Market Places therein, in future, kept free from such Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances; and that it will tend much to the Benefit, Convenience, Advantage, and Safety, as well of the Inhabitants, as of all other Persons resorting to, and travelling through, the said City, to have the Streets,

Lanes, public Ways, and Market Places, in the said City, Borough, and the Suburbs and Streets thereof, and thereto adjoining, well paved, lighted, and otherwise improved, and to have an able and well-regulated Watch established therein; and it will be of considerable Advantage to have the Markets in the said City better regulated: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the better paving and cleansing, and for lighting of the Streets, Lanes, public Ways, and Passages, of the said City, and the Suburbs and Streets thereof, and thereto adjoining and for removingand preventing Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances therein, and for making the Streets,

Lanes, and other Passages there, more convenient and commodious for Carriages, and People passing oh Foot, and for regulating and improving the Markets therein.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Tempest, Mr. Pochin, &c.:

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Powers,' of an Act, of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the County of the City of Norwich, to the Windmill in the Town of Watton, in the County of Norfolk.
