An ingrossed Bill for continuing an Act of the Twelfth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road from Berstreet Gates, in the City of Norwich, to New Buckenham, in the County of Norfolk, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for continuing an Act of the Twelfth Year of his present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road from Berstreet Gates, in the City of Norwich, to New Buckenham, in the County of Norfolk.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

An ingrossed Bill for naturalizing Noah Turmine, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for naturalizing Noah Turmine.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Bill to alter and amend an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Cromford Bridge, in the County -of Derby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pins ton Mill, in the said County, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Lord George Cavendish, Mr. Gilbert, See.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Creme reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and altering the Road from Macclesfield, in the County of , to

the Turnpike Road at Randle Carr Lane Head, in Femilee, in the County of Derby, leading to Chapel in the Frith, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Bill for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of Warwick, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir Astley, Sir George Augustus William , &c.:

And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of the Proprietors and Occupiers of Lands, Tradesmen, and others, residing in and near the Town of Uckfield, in the County of Susses, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill lor improving, continuing, and extending the

Vol. 45.

Navigation of the River Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfeld, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfeld, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Susses; and Setting forth, That the River which runs from the Town of Uckfeld, through the Parishes of If eld and Little Horsted, is one of the Branches of the River Ouse mentioned in the said Bill, and is capable of being made Navigable for Barges, Lighters, and other Craft, to the Town of Uckfeld aforesaid; and that the Petitioners are desirous of making such Navigation to the said Town of Uckfeld: And, as they will be greatly injured by the said Bill now depending, therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the same.

A Petition of the Commissioners of Sewers for Petition Lewes and Laughton Levels, adjoining the River Ouse, ^8ainst th* and lying between Newhaven and Mill, in cuckfieW*1

the County of Sussex, was also presented to the House, Navigation and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; Bill, and Setting forth, That the Petitioners are Commissioners of the Sewers for draining the Lewes and Laughton Levels, adjoining to the said River Ouse, and extending the whole Distance from Newhaven to Barcombe Mill aforesaid, appointed by a Commission issued pursuant to the Statute of the Twenty-third of King Henry the Eighth, and have, by virtue of their Powers under the said Commission, expended considerable Sums of Money, which have been raised by Taxes or Scots upon the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the said Levels, and laid out the same in widening and deepening the said River at various Places, and in rendering the same more strait, and have thereby very considerably assisted the Drainage of the Lands, and at the same Time improved the Navigation of the said River from Newhaven to Lewes Bridge, and had begun to proceed with their said Improvements from Lewes to Barcombe Mill (having already widened the said River as far as Barcombe Mill) which they could have accomplished without any great Burthen to the Country, but were prevented from carrying their Works into complete Execution by the incessant Rains and consequent Floods; and that the principal Merchants, Tradesmen, and others, of the Town of Lewes, and its Neighbourhood, have entered into an Agreement with the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the said Levels to pursue the said Improvements upon Terms very advantageous to the said Commission of Sewers, the Owners apd Occupiers of Land, and all Persons interested in the Trade and Navigation of the said River, which Agreement, by a Commission of Sewers, held by the said Commissioners the 16th of January last, hath been ratified and confirmed, and the said River from Lewes to Barcombe Mills hath always been and still is a free River; and that by the said Bill it is proposed to vest the Powers of deepening and widening that Part of the said River which lies between Lewes and Barcombe Mill aforesaid in a Company of Proprietors, and thereby to take the Direction and Management of the Works, to be carried on upon the same, out of the Hands of the Petitioners, and to levy Tolls and Tonnage to the great Detriment of the Public, and eventually to annul and defeat the good Effects of the said beneficial Agreement made between the Parties aforesaid: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the said Bill may not pass into a Law, and that the Petitioners may have such. other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of William Kempe, of South Mailing, Ditto. ' near Lewes, in the County of Sussex, Serjeant at Law, was likewise presented to the House, and read; also taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That

G g the

23° Februarii.

A. 1790.

the Petitioner is seised of the Manor and ancient Scite of the Deanery of South , and the Lands,

Tenements, Rectory, and Hereditaments thereunto belonging, situate on both Sides of the River Ouse, together with a Bridge over the same, supported by himself only; and that the Petitioner has also a private Road, planted with Trees, upon the Western Bank of the said River, along a Causeway, called The Dean’s Causeway, leading through the Petitioner’s Grounds to the Town of Lewes, and has a several Right of Fishery in the said River; and that the Petitioner

Sluice, and the Port of King's Lynn in the said County, and on the West Side of the said River, from Salter's Load Sluice, in the Parish of Denver aforesaid, to a Place in the Parish of Tilney Saints, in the said County, called Tilney Gool, on behalf of themselves and others, Lahd Owners, charged and chargeable with the Repairs of the said Banks, and also of the several Merchants and Traders, whose Names are also thereunder written, on behalf of themselves and others, navigating and using the said River, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That conceives that his Rights, and the Value of his Estate the said Banks or Sea Walls are absolutely necessary enjoyed by himself and Ancestors, and the Comfort to be kept in good Repair, to preserve many Thou-of the Petitioner, may be materially affected and di- sand Acres of valuable Land against Inundations of minished by the said Bill: And therefore praying to the said River from Tides and Floods passing up and be heard, by himself or Counsel, against the same, down, and also for confining the Waters of the said and that the said Bill may not pass into a Law. Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for making, amending, and keeping in Repair, the Road from Fosbrookin the Parish of Dillom, through Dillom, and from thence to or near to ton, in the County of Stafford, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, residing in the Hundred of

f ate, in the County of Surrey, was presented to the louse, and read; Setting forth, That the Roads from Purley Corner, near Croydon, to Reigate, in Surrey, through Merstham, as also from Godstone, through Reigate, to Won ham Mill Gate and Buck land Church, are in a ruinous Condition, and, in several Places, very narrow and steep, and, at Times, frequently unsafe for Travellers, and want very much widening, and otherwise improving, so as to render the same at all Times convenient and passable; and that such Roads cannot be repaired by the ordinary Course of Law, and, if the said Roads were repaired and widened, it would be of great Advantage to the Inhabitants of the said County: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for repairing and widening the Road from Purley Comer, beyond Croydon, in the County of Surrey, through Merstham, to the Borough of Reigate, and from Godstone, in the said County, through the Borough of Reigate, to Wonham Mill Gate, and to Buckland Church, in the said County.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

The Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the Committee whole House to consider of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Ma- Trade Acts. jesty, intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade " between the Subjects of His Majesty's Colonies and " Plantations in North America, and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of America, and between His Majesty’s said " Subjects and the Foreign Islands in the West " and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to allow the Importation of Rum, or other " Spirits, from His Majesty’s Colonies or Plantations " in the West Indies, into the Province of Quebec,

" without Payment of Duty, under certain Conditions " and Restrictions."

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. John Smyth took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. John Smyth reported from the Committee,

That he was directed by the Committee to make a Motion, when the House will please to receive the same.

OrderedThat the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

The House being informed. That Captain Hall, Mr. Falconbridge, and Mr. Wilson, can give very material Information on the Subject of the Slave Trade, and that they are under the Necessity of soon leaving this Kingdom;

And a Member present having informed the House, that the Examination of such Persons, before the Committee appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade, will not be attended with any Inconvenience to the several Petitioners who are at this Time in the Course of examining their Witnesses in Support of their Petitions;

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do forthwith proceed to the Examination of the said Captain Hall, Mr Falconbridge, and Mr. Wilson; but that they do not report such Examination to the House, until they shall have taken and Vol. 4 5,

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Common Cow Pasture and Common Fen in the Parish of Pointon, in the County of Lincoln-, without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields and a Stinted Pasture, called Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York; without any Amendment And then the Messengers withdrew.

And then he withdrew.

' A Petition

Accounts of Imports, &c. of Hum and Suijar — and, of Tin and Pewter exported, presented.

Norwich Petition against the Tobacco Act

Leicester and Wei ford Hoad 1 ill committed*

Samwell’s

Name

Petition.

30 Geo. III. 24° Februarii. 119

A Petition of the Persons thereunder signed, being Manufacturers of, and Dealers in, Tobacco and Snail, in the City of Norwich, in Behalf of themselves and others, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof, is highly injurious to the Petitioners, as it exposes the Mysteries of their Trade, which they had been taught to consider as private Property, and imposes Regulations and Restrictions upon their Manufacture, with which they cannot comply without great Loss to themselves, and a Non-compliance with which exposes them to heavy Penalties; and that the Operation of the said Act, instead of benefiting, will be detrimental to the Revenue. by putting Smugglers in Possession of the Secrets of the Petitioners Trade, and by increasing the Price of their Goods, in consequence of the Delays and Interruptions which the said Act occasions in the Manufacture of them, which Operation has been already sensibly felt by the Petitioners, the Quantity of Tobacco and Snuff sold by them, since the said Act took Effect, having been considerably less than it was during any former Period, and Daily decreasing; and that the Petitioners also perceive, with extreme Regret, that the Penalties inflicted by the said Act are recoverable in a summary Manner, without the Intervention of a Jury, a Mode of Proceeding that tends to undermine an Institution which the Petitioners have been taught to consider as the Bulwark of the British Constitution: And therefore praying, That the said Act may be repealed.

Ordered, That the said Petitioa do lie upon the Table.

A Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road* from the Leicester and Welford Turnpike Road, in the Counties of Leicester and Northampton, near Fosten Lane, to the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby dela Zouch, in the said County of; and for repairing and widening Two Pieces of Road, called Hunt's Lane, and Wood Lane, in the Parishes of Des-ford and Newbold Verdon, branching out of the said Turnpike Road, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. -gerford, Mr. Pochm, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of Thomas Watson Samwell,

Esquire, heretofore called Thomas Samwell Watson, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That Sir Thomas Samwell, late of Upton, in the County of Northampton, Baronet, deceased, by his last Will and Testament, dated the First Day of November One thousand Seven hundred and Seventy-eight, gave and devised all his Real Estates unto his natural Son, Thomas Samwell, for his Life; Remainder to Trustees to preserve the contingent Remainders; Remainder to the first and other Sons of the said Thomas Samwell, successively in Tail Mail; Remainder to the Testator’s Brother, Wenman Samwell, for his Life; Remainder to the said Trustees to preserve the contingent Remainders; Remainder to the first and other Sons of the said Wenman Samwell, successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Petitioner for his Life; Remainder to the said Trustees to preserve the contingent Remainders; Remainder to the first and other Sons of the Peti-titioner successively in Tail Male;., with divers Remainders over: And that the said Testator did by his said Will declare, that the said Estates were devised and limited to the Petitioner and his first and other Sons in Tail Mail, upon the express Condition, that if, by Failure of Issue Male of the said Thomas Samwell Vol. 45.

and Wenman Samwell, the said Estates should, by virtue of the said Will, come to the Petitioner, or to his first or other Son or Sons, or to the Heirs Male of his or their respective Bodies, then they should, within One Month next after they should severally come into the actual Possession thereof, take upon him and them the Surname of Samwell, and do his and their utmost Endeavours, as soon as he or they could, to procure and obtain an Act of Parliament for that Purpose, and also to use the Arms of Samwell as far as he or they lawfully might; and that in case any of them should refuse or neglect to take the said Surname within the Space of One Month in Manner aforesaid, and should not within Two Years use his Endeavour to procure such Act of Parliament as aforesaid, the Estate therein before limited to him or them so refusing or neglecting as aforesaid should cease and be void, and that it should be lawful for the Person or Persons who by virtue of the said Will should be next in Remainder to enter into, hold, and enjoy the said Estates, taking upon him or them the Surname of Sanrwell; and that the Testator departed this Life soon after the making his said Will, and the said Thomas Samwell, his Son, is since dead, without Issue Male, and the said Wenman Samwell, late Sir W enmanSamwell, Baronet, departed this Life on the Eighteenth Day of October last past, without Issue Male, whereupon the Petitioner, by virtue of the said Will, came into the actual Possession of the said Estates, and immediately took upon himself the Surname of Samwell, in Conformity to the said Will; and the Petitioner, in further Compliance with the Conditions of the said Will, is desirous to obtain an Act of Parliament to enable him, and the Heirs Male of his Body, to take and use the Surname, and bear the Arms, of Samwell: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for enabling the Petitioner, and his first and other Sons, and the Heirs Male of his and their respective Bodies, to take and use the Surname, and bear the Arms, of Samwell, in pursuance of the said Will.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Hungerford and Mr. Pochin do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of George Bishop, of Maidstone, Distiller, was presented so the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioner hath incurred a very considerable Expence in establishing, at Maidstone, in Kent, a Manufactory for making Geneva, of a Quality and Sort similar to that which is made in Holland; and that, the Process by which the Petitioner makes his Geneva being different from that by which other British Spirits are produced, he hath been indulged by Act of Parliament, from Time to Time, with special Exemptions from the general Regulations of the Excise Laws, in order to enable him to continue to make his Geneva; and that, in order to promote the Sale of his Geneva in various Parts of Great Britain, the Petitioner hath, at a considerable Expence, formed very extensive Connections for that Purpose, by which Means the Practice of smuggling Foreign Geneva hath been, and will furthur continue to be, discouraged and prevented, to the great Increase of the Excise Revenue: And that the Petitioner conceives that the Expediency of his being permitted to carry on his Manufactory, as he hath hitherto done, has been very clearly proved, and as the Distillery and Utensils, which he hath erected and provided for the Purpose at a very great Expence, have not reimbursed him, therefore praying, That he may not continue to be compelled to carry on his Distillery under the great and manifest Discouragement of only a temporary Exemption from the general Regulations of the Excise Laws, but that Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to make the said Exemption perpetual, or that the Petitioner may have such other

Mr. Bishop’s Petition.

]Q0 24° Febru 1790.

other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of the Earl of Plymouth, and the hum- Glamorgan-ble Petition of several Gentlemen and Freeholders of *J»n;e Canal the County of Glamorgan, was presented to the House, etltion‘ and read; Setting forth. That, by a Survey lately taken, it appears that a Navigable Canal may be made from Merthyr Tidvile, in the County of Glamorgan, to, or near to, the Town of Cardiff', in the said County; and that the making and maintaining such Canal will be of great Benefit to the Petitioners, and to all other.

Persons having Lands and Estates within the said County, as it will open Communications with very extensive Iron Works and Collieries, and will be of public Utility: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining such Navigable Canal as aforesaid, by such Ways and Means, and under such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

And it is referred to Sir Herbert Mackworth, Sir William Dolben, &c. And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

The House being informed that Mr. Harrison, from Report from the Board of Land Revenue, attended at the Door; the Board he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the Land House, pursuant to the Directions of an Act of Par- Revenu<* liament,

A Sixth Report of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the State and Condition of the Woods,

Forests, and Land Revenues of the Crown, and to sell or alienate Fee Farm and other Unimproveable Rents:

A Plan of Aliceholt and Woolmer Forest, referred to in the said Report.

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Report and Plan were read.

The said Plan is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session; and the said Report is as followeth; viz.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

The Sixth Report of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the State and Condition of the Woods, Forests, and Land Revenues of the Crown, and to sell or alienate Fee Farm and other Unimproveable Rents.

The Forest of Aliceholt and Woolmer is situated in situation, the East Part of the County of , on the

Borders of the Counties of Surrey and Sussex; and is bounded on one Side by the River TVey, which becomes navigable at Godalming, about Ten Miles from

07 the

Water Carriage for Timber to Dock Yards.

Perambulation in *8 Ldw. I.

N#i.

John.

Hen. III.

9 Hen. III.

Perambulation ll Cha. L Appendix, a.

Plan of the Forest.

30 Ge.0. III. 24° Februarii. 121

the Middle of the Forest; and comnhinicates with the River Thames, affording an easy Conveyance of the Forest l imber to the Dock Yards in that River, and at a moderate Expence.

The most antient Perambulation we have found of this Forest is dated in the 28th Year of King Edward I. and is preserved among the Records in the Tower. A Copy of that Perambulation is given in the Appendix; from the latter Part of which it appears, that this was one of the Forests enlarged by the Four preceding Kings, and reduced by Edward to its more antient Limits, in consequence of the Provisions in the Charta de Forcsta, and of a Grant from the Commons, of ai Fifteenth Part of all their moveable Property.

Another Perambulation of this Forest was made in the 1J th of Charles I. of which a Copy is also inserted in the Appendix. The Boundaries in' those Two Perambulations, appear to be the same; and they have been traced and followed by the Surveyor employed by us, in making the Plan which is to be delivered with this Report.

The Whole of the Forest within those Boundaries contains about 15,493 Acres, Statute Measure; but

of that Quantity about 6,799 Acres belong to private Number of Proprietors; the Rest, being about 8,694, Acres, are Acres’ Forest Lands belonging to the Crown.

The Forest consists of Two Divisions, the one called The Forest in The Holt, or Aliceholt, and the other JVootmer. The TwoDivi-Two Parts are separated from each other by a consi- ^<’ns*c*1,ed. derable Extent of intervening private Property. Alice-holt was formerly divided into Three Bailiwicks, of Walks, called The North, The South, and The West Bailiwicks; but that Distinction is now laid aside.

Woolmer is divided into Two Walks,. called -borough Walk, and Borden Walk. The Whole, however, forms but One Forest, governed by One Set of Officers, and subject to the same Forest Courts; and the following is a Statement of the Quantities of the inclosed Lands, Open Pasture, and Wood Lands, belonging to the Crown, with the estimated Value of the Wood and Timber growing thereon, and the Annual Value of the Lands, supposing them to be disafforested, and turned into Tillage or Pasture, according to the Survey made under our Direction; viz. n« <j. ’

Some Incroachments, or rather Claims, have been made by the Lords of the adjoining Manors of Mill Land, and Oakhanger, or Chapel Manor, to Parts of the Soil of Woolmer-, but the Lands lie open to and are reputed Part of the Forest, and those Claims do not appear to be of long standing, or very well founded.

In what Manner the Lodges and inclosed Lands are now occupied, will be stated hereafter, when we come to speak of the Forest Officers, and their Emoluments. The uninclosed Lands of the Crown, in Vol. 45.

both Divisions, are subject to certain Rights of Com- Right* of mon, enjoyed by the Proprietors of Estates within or Common, adjacent to the Forest; and that Mixture of Rights has in this, as in other Forests, opened a Door to great Waste and Abuse.

In order to discover what Rights were admitted nr Right* for-enjoyed in this Forest during the last Century, when merlyenjoyed some Care was-taken to confine them within just ^r0*l^0m" Limits, and to protect the Rights of the Crown in the Royal Forests, we examined the Proceedings at a claim* at a Justice Seat held by Lord Holland, Chief Justice' in Justice Seat,

Ii Eyre, 11 Cha. I.

24* Fehrutiru,

A. 1790.

Land Revenue Report.

-Swanimote Courts in 18 Jo. I. and 11 Cha. 1.

Antient Govero-ment of this Forest

Appendix, N* 4.

Office of Lieute- 1 nant granted on Lease.

Appendix, N® 5.

Appendix, N*6.

Terms and Conditions of the Lease.

Eyre, in the tiih Charted I. preserved in the Tower, at which Court all Persons claiming Rights in the Forest preferred their Claims in Writing, specifying the Nature and Extent of those Rights. The Claims then made were Thirty in Number, of which Three only are wanting; and in all those Claims no Mention is made of any other Right than that of Common of Pasture, except in One Instance, where a Right is claimed- to cut Peat and Turf in the Division ealled Woolmer; and the Right of Pasture is claimed

only for Commonable Cattle, Levant and on the LandB of the Claimants (or, in other Words, for such Cattle as the Parties could maintain on their own Lands, during the whole Year) and for those only in Commonable Seasons, according to the Assize of the Forest.

We have also perused the Rolls of Two Courts of Swanimote, held in the i-8th of James I. and nth of Charles I. likewise preserved in the Tower; at which Courts all Offences committed to the Injury of the1 Forest were presented and tried. From those Proy ceedings it appears, that no other Rights than those mentioned in the Claims preferred at the Justice Seat were allowed. The Timber, Wood, and Underwood, were then held to be the sole Property of the Crown; and the cutting or carrying away any Branch of a Tree, or -even Bushes, was punished in the same Maimer as Injuries to the King’s Deer.

In a subsequent Part of this Report we shall , shew the Change which- has since taken Place, the new Claims which have been established, the total Neglect and Relaxation which have prevailed, on the Part of Government, and the Waste, Incroachraent, and Spoil which have been suffered during -the present -Century.

The antient Government of tins Forest, under the Forest Laws, was similar to that in Other Forests, by a Lieutenant, Ranger, or Keeper, Verderors, Woodward, Regarders, Agistors, and Foresters, or Under Keepers; and those Officers held Courts of Swanimote and Attachment, which took Cognizance of all Offences done in the Forest. An Extract from the Swanimote Roll of the nth Charles I. inserted in the Append!*, shews what Officers then belonged to this Forest, and the Towns which sen* Free Suitors to attend at the Forest Courts.

But the Office of Lieutenant or Keeper of this. Forest has, for a long Course of Time, been, granted on Lease for Lives, or Terms of Years, with the Power of appointing a Deputy, and the usual Number of Foresters, or Under Keepers, and of holding, every Six Weeks, the Court of Attachment, or Woodmote; in consequence of which Powers, the whole Care and Protection of the Forest Tame, at length, to depend on the Lieutenant alone. We have given-in the Appendix a List of those Leases, from the Reign of Queen Elizabeth to the present Time; from which it appears that at the Beginning of the present Century that Office was held by Emanuel Scroop Howe, Esquire, under a Grant from lung Wfo» 45- Yearn; and* after his Death, by Mrs. Ruperta Howe, his Widow.

It was afterwards granted to the Honourable John Mordaunt, by whom it was assigned, in 1750, to the late Right honourable Henry Bilson Legge, and has ever since continued in that Family. A Copy of the lost Lease, granted in 1780, to Trustees for Lord Sttnvell, for 31 Years from that Time, is also inserted in the Appendix. The Terms and Conditions in all those Leases are nearly the Same, and the Substance as follows:

The King grants to the Trustees for Lord StawelL,

A Fee Farm. Rent of 31 k 2. 11. out of the

Manor of Wordteham, in Hampshire: v

And the Office of Eieu tenant, os Keeper, of the Forest or Chase of Aliceholt and

To hold and receive the said Rent, without Account; but on Condition' to pay all Fees, Wages; and Salaries, of all- toe Officers of the said Forest;

And to hold the Office of Lieutenant or Keeper; with all Offices, Liberties, Privileges, Wages,

Fees, Rewards; and other Profits and Commodities thereto belonging;

With Power to appoint a Deputy or Deputies, amt so many Foresters and Keepers as heretofore wens appointed, for the safe Custody of the said Forest;

And to have all Beasts or Animals attached, or taken in the said Forest, by any of the Foresters;

And all Manner of Wood blown or thrown dbwn by the Wind, and all dead Woody and the Boughs and Branches of Trees and Wood in the said- Forest, out off or thrown down;

And Housebote and Firebote for bitnseff and the Foresters and Keepers;

And all Waifs, Estrays, Honey and Wax found there;

And separate Pasture within the King’s Lands in the said Forest, for Two Horses for himself, or his Deputies, and sufficient Pasture within the Forest for One , Horae for each Forester or Keeper;

With Liberty -of Fishing within the Kings Waters there, and to keep the Fish to his own Use;

Also Power to hold, every Six Weeks, the Court called the Wood Court, and to take.afr Fines and Amerciaments there to his own Use;

And to have the Entrails, commonly called the Humbles and Suets, of the Deer killed there;

And Liberty to take One Stag and One Buck in the Summer, and One Hmd and One Doo in the Winter, to his own Use.

To hold and exercise all the Offices; Authorities*

Liberties, and Privileges aforesaid, without any Account to be rendered to His Majesty, His Heirs or Successors, for the same.

And the Grantee covenants as follows:

To repair all the Lodges, Fences, and Inclosures at his own Expence;

To discharge His Majesty from the Payment of the Salaries, Stipends, or Wages, of the Foresters,

Keepers, and Officers of the Forest;

To preserve and keep the Deer, and other Game, and also the Woods, Timber, and other Trees, from cutting chopping, and Spoil; and, so preserved, to leave the same, at the End of the Term.

It is probable that the Object and Expectation Observations on of Government, in granting a Lease on such Condi- offiS"©?Lieuw-tions, was, that by bestowing on a Person of some nant Distinction, for a Term of \ ears, the Authority and Dignity, with the Patronage and Emoluments annexed to this desirable and respectable Office, supporting it with the Aid of the other Officers of the Forest, and with the Power of the Forest Courts, more Weight might be added to the Situation, ami the Protection of the Deer and Timber be rendered more certain and effectual, than it would have been undo* an Officer holding the Appointment during Pleasure; and that, at the same Time, the Expence to the Crown, in the Management of the Forest might be ascertained and limited: But, by tracing

the Progress and Effect of the different Conditions* separately, down to the present Time, it will appear how. iff. those Expectations have been justified by the Event.

The next Perquisite allowed by the Lease to the on the perquisites Lieutenant, on which it is necessary to make any of Windfalls, and Observation, is that of "all Manner of Wood blown Boughs A Branches " down by the Wind, and all dead Wood, and the " Boughs and Branches of Trees or Wood cut off or " thrown down."

In order to discover what Interpretation was formerly given to this Clause in the Lease, we have examined the Accounts in the Auditor’s Office, relative to Falls of Timber or Wood in this Forest;

Oidere of the Sur-tejor General.

The Warrants of the Lords Justices, and Lords of the Treasury, are given in the Appendix; and a veiy sensible Paper of Remarks on this Grant, which we found among the Papers of the Treasury, so fully explains the Purpose for which the Allowances were made, and the Necessity there was of rendering the Keepers subject to the Orders of the Surveyor General, that we shall here transcribe them, instead of making any Remarks of our own; on that Transaction.

of Trees.

..... — ’ " " 1722, the same Year in which the Warrant of the Lord Justices was issued, and those Remarks made upon the Grant to the Lieutenant which we have transcribed; when 400 dotard Oak Trees, with the Barkj Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood, were felled and sold; and the whole Produce appears to be accounted for to the Crown.

Another Sale of 405 Trees, was made in 1724; and then also the Bark, Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood, were wholly accounted for to the Crown; and no Allowance or Claim whatever appears to have been made

" is no* and haA been tliie constant Complaint, as to of any Part of the Produce of either of these Sales. Vol. 45. From

124 24° Februariu . 1790.

Land Revenue From these Documents it would seem that, in those "Port* Times, the Lieutenant was considered to be entitled

' ' only to the Boughs and Branches which are casually

cut off or thrown down from standing Trees, and not from Trees felled by Warrant; and these Examples should have the more Weight, from the Falls having been made at a Time when the Emoluments and Allowances of the Lieutenant had so recently undergone a full Consideration: But we find, from subsequent Accounts in the same Office, that, in the Year 1729, Mrs. Ruperta Hmce claimed a Right to the Boughs and Branches of all Trees felled by Warrant, or to the Value of them; and she at the same Time set up a Claim to the Bark, but on what Pretence does not appear, no Mention being made of the Bark in the Lease. Unsupported, however, as this Claim was, either by the Lease itself, or, in so far as we can discover, by former Usage, it appears to have been admitted by the then Surveyor General, and allowed in his Accounts, by the Auditor, without any Waf-rant that we can find, and perhaps without examining the Lease; for it appears, that, in the same Year, 1170 dotard and decayed Trees were sold by the Surveyor General, with the Bark, Lops, and Tops, for 980/.; and in the Account of that Sale, we find that 140/. (being One Seventh Part of the Produce) was paid to Mrs. Howe, " who (it is added) claims a Right " to the Lop, Top, and ."

This Claim having thus been once admitted, it appears, in one Shape or another, to have been made at every Sale since. In the Accounts of the’next Sales in 1732, and in 1737-8, the Price of the Trees only is accounted for to the Crown, " clear of the " Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood of the said Trees, " the same being claimed, by Mrs. Ruperta Howe, by " virtue of her Grant of the Office of Ranger of the " said Forest.1’

In the Accounts of the subsequent Sales, from that Time to 1750, the Accountants are charged only with so many Trees, cut down and sold to divers Persons, for the Sums therein mentioned: and no Notice is taken of the Lops, Tops, or Bark; but from the Vouchers of those Accounts preserved in the same Office', it appears, that the Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood, were taken by the Lieutenant in Kind.

From 1750, when Mr Legge first obtained this Office, to the Year 1756, the Price of the Trees only is accounted for, as before, without mentioning the Lops, Tops, or Bark; but there is a Memorandum in the Vouchers, " that the Lop, Top, and Offal " Wood, were granted to the Honourable Mr. Mordaunt, and his Assigns."

In the Sales from 1756 to 1760, the Price of the Trees and Bark, are accounted for, without taking any Notice of the Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood; but among the Vouchers of those Accounts, we find Certificates, signed by Kemble then Deputy Sur-

veyor, " that the Timber and Bark were sold by " Auction, for the Sums stated in the Accounts, and " that the Lops and Tops were claimed by, and " delivered to the Right Honourable Henry Bilson Legge, u as Assignee of the Honourable John Mordaunt T The Vouchers for the Account of Sales in 1760 are not to be found; but the Accounts are in the same Terms as those for the Four preceding Years.

In the Accounts of the Sales, from 1760 to 1770, the Price of the Trees, with the Bark, Tops, Lops, and Offal Wood, are accounted for to the Crown; Appendix, N° 10. but in the Year last mentioned, a Memorial was presented to the Treasury by the Countess of Hillsborough, who then held the Office of Lieutenant, representing that she was entitled, by the Grant of that Office, to One Fifth Part of the Produce of all Timber sold there, by the Surveyor General, in lieu of the Top, Lop, and Bark; and by Several Warrants from the Treasury to the Yearly Sum of 130/. for the Keepers

Salaries; that the 130/. a Year had been regularly paid up to 1761, together with One Fifth Part of the Sales for the preceding Year, after which nothing had been paid; that the Wood Sales, since 1761, amounted to 2,291/.; and that One Fifth Part, being 458/. 4 was due to the Memorialist; and praying their Lordships to order the Surveyor General to pay the same.

The Lords of the Treasury referred this Memorial to the Surveyor General of the Woods, directing him to report a true State of the Premises; and that Officer reported, on the 25th of June 1770, " That he " had considered the Memorial, and found, that " during the Years mentioned in it, the several " Quantities of Timber were sold in the Forest, and " for the Sums therein specified; and that a Proportion of One Fifth Part of the said Sums, due (0 " Lady Hillsborough, in lieu of the Tops, Lop, and " Bark of the said Timber, and also the Sum of " 130/. a Year for Keepers Salaries, had not been " paid;" and recommended that Part of the Arrear should be paid out of Monies in his Hands, and the Remainder raised at the next Fall.

In this Report the Surveyor General does not seem to have examined -whether the Lieutenant was entitled to the Allowance claimed by the Memorial: If he had looked into the Lease itself) he would have seen that the Bark was certainly not a Perquisite of the Lieutenant; and that there was not any Expression in it that warranted a Claim to One Fifth Part of the Produce of the Timber sold, in lieu of the Lop, Top, and Bark. If he had inspected the Accounts in the Auditor’s Office, he would have found no Example of, a Fifth Part having ever, before the Appointment of Mr. Legge, been claimed or allowed; and the Payment of that Proportion of the Price of the Trees sold in the Year 1760 is not stated in the Accounts of the Sales, in that Year.

On the 6th July 1770, the Lords of the Treasury, by Letter from their Secretary, directed the Surveyor General to pay the whole Sums claimed in this Memorial, both for the Fifth Part of all the Timber felled in the Forest since the Year 1760, and for the Allowance of 130/. a Year for the Keepers Salaries; and, in future, to pay the growing Salaries as they became due.

The Accounts of Sir Edmund Thomas and Mr. Pitt, the Surveyors General of the Woods, being brought under the Examination of the Auditor, he very properly declined passing them with those Allowances, which then, for the First Time, appeared in the Surveyor’s Accounts, without a Special Warrant. In consequence of this Refusal, a Memorial was presented to the Lords of the Treasury by the Surveyor General, in January 1777, stating the Substance of that presented by the Lieutenant in 1770, with his Report thereon, and the Directions given to him in consequence of it; and that he had ever since conti-uned to pay the Salaries of 130/. a Year, and the Fifth Part of the Produce of all the Timber cut in the Forest; and he prayed their Lordships to issue their Warrant, directing the Auditor to allow those Payments in his Accounts, and also, from Time to Time, the future Payments thereof. And on the 24th March 1777, the Lords of the Treasury issued a Warrant, authorizing the Auditor to make those Allowances accordingly.

The Lords of the Treasury having been induced, by the Means which have been stated, to admit the Claims made by the Lieutenant, a new Circumstance occurred, which brought the Rights of that Officer again under Examination.

Prior to the Year 1777, no Timber had been, cut in this Forest for the Use of the Navy, during the present Century, probably owing to the Trees not having, till about that Time, grown to the necessary Size. A Fall of 300 Loads was then, ordered, by Warrant from the

Appendix, N* 11.

Appendix, N* u»

Appendix, N° 13.

30 Geo. III. 24 Februar 125

the Treasury, for the Use of the Navy, and delivered ' at the usual Price allowed for Oak Timber furnished > to the Dock Yards, from other of the Royal Forests, being i/. 18$. per Load.

.Appendix, N° 14. On this Occasion, a new Memorial was presented to the Treasury by Lady , stating, as before,

" that as Lieutenant she was, by the Grant, entitled " to the Boughs and Branches ot all Trees cut within " the said Forest, which used formerly to be taken by " the Lieutenant; but that Mode was found to be so " injurious to the Sale of the Timber, that for a great " Number of Years past, long before the Memorialist, " or her late Husband Mr. Legge, had the Grant of " that Office, it had been agreed between His Majesty’s then Surveyor General, and the then Lieutenant, that the Whole of the said Timber Trees , " should be sold, and that the Lieutenant should have " One Fifth of the Amount of the Sale, in lieu of " his Right therein, which had been accordingly paid " ever since. That it had been always usual to sell " the Timber by Public Sale, until the last Year, M when the Fall of 300 Loads was ordered for the " Navy. That if that Timber had been put up to " Sale, (instead of being taken for the Use of the " Navy at 11. 18$. per Load) it would have produced "nearly 2,500l., whereas by the Account of the " Deputy Surveyor, the Gross Amount was only " L074/. io$. 9 d.,to which was to be added about " 80/. lor Stack Wood, taken away by the People " of Frensham, under a pretended Right; and out of " which was to be deducted 179/. 19$. for the " Expences of cutting, &c. charged in the Surveyor’s " Account. That if it had been sold publicly, as " usual, and had produced 2,500l., the Memorialist’s Fifth would have been 500l.; that had the Memo* " rialist taken the Offal Wood, it would, by the " Deputy Surveyor’s Account, have amounted to " 382 /., exclusive of the Eighty Pound’s Worth of " Stack Wood, taken away, which would have made " it 462/.; but that if the Memorialist was only to " have One Fifth Part of the Sale, according to the " Accounts of the Deputy Surveyor, it would amount " only to 178/.; and though the Memorialist was willing to take such Sum for her Right as their Lordships should be pleased to order, yet she prayed " that a Warrant then lately issued, for an additional " Fall of 500 Loads for the Navy, might be revoked, and that for the future all the Timber might he sold " by Public Auction, as usual.’’

This Memorial was likewise referred to the Surveyor General, who seems then to have considered the Terms of the Grant with more Attention than he had

Appendix, N° 15, done on the former Reference; and, in his Report thereon, he suggested a Doubt, whether the Clause in the Grant, as to Boughs and Branches, might not be construed to extend only to the Boughs and Branches casually cut off or thrown down, and not to the Branches of all Trees cut for the Use of His Majesty. That it was however necessary to inform their Lordships, that at the Time of his Appointment he understood that the Lieutenant was entitled to the Boughs and Branches of all Timber Trees cut down in the said Forest; and did therefore, as he found his Predecessors had done, agree that the Whole of the Timber cut there should be sold, and that the Lieutenant should be paid One-fifth of the Amount of the Whole, in lieu of the Boughs and Branches; and that all Trees cut in the said Forest to the Year 1776, had been sold by Auction, and One-fifth Part paid to the Lieutenant accordingly; that the Oak Timber lately felled for the Navy had been delivered at the usual Price allowed for the King's Timber in New Forest; and that if the Whole of that Timber had been sold, the Lieutenant would certainly have been entitled to a larger Sum than he thought himself justifiable in paying, without particular Directions from Vol. 45.

their Lordships: And he proposed that, for the fu- Land Revenue ture, the Lops, Tops, and Bark, should be sold by Report.

Auction, and that Two Third Parts of the Net Pro- v — ----- -s/ ——

duce should be paid to the Lieutenant, and the remaining Third for the Use of the Crown, that Proportion being, as nearly as could be competed, the Value of the Bark, to which the Lieutenant had no Right or Claim.

We do not find that any Order was made by the Treasury, in consequence of this Report. It appears, however, that the Lieutenant did not obtain the Allowance of a Fifth Part of the Value of the 300 Loads of Navy Timber felled in 1777, at the Market Price, or any pther Allowance on that Account, but Lord Stawell has not relinquished his Claim to it. And we know that the Warrant issued in 1778, for the Fall of 500 Loads for the Navy was not executed, though strongly recommended by the Surveyor General. '1 his Memorial and Report, which contain various other Particulars concerning the Forest, are inserted at Length in the Appendix. 'I'hey very clearly shew, j |

either that the Memorialist had been grossly misin- an >5’ formed, and that the Surveyor General had admitted the Facts alledged, without due Examination; or that some Agreement, for allowing One-fifth of the Value of the Trees, instead of the Lops and Tops, had been secretly and improperly made between some former Lieutenant and Surveyor, without the Knowledge or Authority of the Treasury; for after a careful Examination of the Books of the Treasury, and those in the Officp of the Auditor of the Land Revenue, relative to Woods and Forests, no Traces can be found of such an Agreement.

Under these Circumstances, we thought it necessary to mention to Lord Stawell our Apprehensions, that Lady Hillsborough might have been misinformed with respect to that supposed Agreement; and to request, that if such an Agreement had been made, we might be informed at what Time it took Place. In Answer to our Enquiry, we received a Letter trom Mr.

Sainsbury, Agent for Lord Staxvell, and who was also Agent for Lady Hillsborough at the Time of preferring that Memorial, in which Letter Mr. Sainsbury states, that he. had been told by a Mr. Ho, who had been Head Keeper in the Forest for upwards of 40 Yeais, that such an Agreement was made many Years before Mr. Legge purchased the Grant; but that he never saw any Agreement; and he has sent Copies of Entries in Mr. Legge's Books, in his own Hand Writing, of Sums received from the Surveyors General for Lop and Top, from 1753 to 1761; but he admits, that it does not thereby appear, that it was in the Proportion of One fifth, though he has no Doubt of its being so. Mr. Sainsburys Letter, and the Account sent

with it, are inserted in the Appendix: And upon the Appendix, N° 16. Whole of this Transaction we must observe, that it does not appear that such an Agreement was ever made, or that the Lords of the Treasury were, ever informed that such a Claim existed, prior to the before-mentioned Memorial and Report in the Year 1770, though, if such an Arrangement had been judged expedient, it was the Duty of the Surveyor General to apply to the Treasury for Permission to agree to it.

A secret Transaction of this Kind, if it had really taken Place, between Two of the Servants of the Crown, One of them entrusted with the general Care of the Timber in all the Royal Forests, and the other with the particular Management -and Protection of this Forest, should not, and we conceive could not, establish a Right for the Advantage of either of them to the Prejudice of the Crown.

But besides this Claim, of One-fifth of the Value of the Trees, another very singular Demand, or rather Request, is made in the Memorial; that in this Forest, maintained by the Public at very considerable Expence, as a Nursery of Timber for the Navy, no

K k more

126 24° Februarii. A. 1790:

Land Revenue more Timber should be cut for the Public Service, Report but that all should be sold by Auction, in order that

' ----- ----- -- the Grantee might receive a greater Advantage from

it, than he would, if it were sent to the Dock Yards at the ordinary Price.

The Execution of the Warrant for the Fall of 500 Loads remained suspended, till January 1783, when on an Application from the Navy Board, a Warrant was issued for supplying that Quantity to the Dock Yards in the following Season; which was done accordingly. Another Fall of 1,000 Loads was afterwards directed, by WTarrant dated 3d December 1783, and, on that Occasion, Lord presented a Me-

Appendix, v° 17. mortal to the Treasury, stating that the People of Frem/utm, under a pretended Right, took away not only the Stack Wood, but almost the Whole of the Tops of the Trees of the preceding Fall; and that those of the Fall then ordered would also be carried off, if the Timber were to be immediately cut; that as he conceived them to be his absolute Property, he was willing to try the Validity of that pretended Right, if the Crown did not choose to do it; and praying that the Execution of the Order might be suspended, until the Right should be determined by a Court of Justice. The Memorial also stated various Abuses, practised in executing the Warrants for former Falls, which we shall hereafter take No-tie4 of.

After a short Suspension this Warrant was carried into Execution, and the Timber delivered to the Dock Yards; and we are informed by Mr. that Lord Staxcell, in the Year 1784, commenced upwards of Forty Actions against the poor People of the adjoining Parishes, for taking away Parts of the Wood; and that they all entered Appearances, but suffered Judgment to go by Default. It appears likewise, Appendix, N° 18. from Papers in our Possession, that the same Question was tried in the Year 1741, and determined against the Claimants.

It is observable that the Warrants for these Two Falls directed that the Lops, Tops, and Bark should be sold for His Majesty’s Use; but the Accounts in the Auditor’s Office state that the Lops and Tops were delivered to Lord Staxcell, " in Lieu and Satisfaction of his Right to One-fifth Part of the Produce on the Sale of the said Timber." And Mr. Briant, the Deputy Surveyor, in his Examination says, Appendix, N° 19. that " the Lops and Tops, and all the Timber of the " last mentioned Fall, unfit for the Navy, was taken " by Lord Statcell, of which he gave Notice to the " Surveyor General."

In February 1788 another Fall of 500 Loads was ordered for the Use of the Navy; but before the Execution of that Warrant, our Enquiries concerning this Forest were begun, and we had judged it necessary to state a Case for the Opinion of the Attorney and Solicitor General upon the Construction of the Grant; we therefore thought it our Duty to propose to the Lords of the Treasury that the felling of that Timber should be suspended, until the Rights of the Grantee should be duly investigated. The Fall was accordingly for some Time delayed; and when the Warrant was afterwards ordered to be carried into Execution, the Surveyor General was directed by the Treasury to sell the Lop, Top, and Offal Wood, by Public Auction, in the Presence of the Officers of the Forest, and of an Agent on the Part of Lord Starvell; and to retain the Produce in his Hands, to await the Decision upon Lord Stawell’s Claim. The Tops of the Trees were accordingly sold, and the Produce paid to the Surveyor General; but the Offal Wood, after "having been made into Faggots, and a Day appointed for the Sale of it, was openly carried off by the People of Frensham, to the Number of 6,365 Faggots, in One Day and Night

Appendix, N° 19. The Account given of this Transaction, upon Oath,

by Mr. Briant, the Surveyor General’s Deputy, is, that he was absent from the Forest on other Business, when the Country People began carrying away the Wood; and that when he returned it was almost all gone; that he detected Two Men loading a Waggon with Part of it, and got a Warrant for apprehending them; but that the Tything Man of where the

Offenders live, has never executed it, though repeatedly pressed to do it, and offered Assistance by him; that on his applying to the Keepers, and enquiring whose Teams had been employed in taking away the Wood, they told him they knew nothing of it; and he could get no Information from them against the Offenders.

This Proceeding of the People of Frensham was the more daring, as the Right claimed by them had been so lately determined; and it is remarkable that Mr. Briant, in his Examination, says, he has observed " That no Attempt is ever made to take the Offal " Wood of Trees felled by Lord StarceU's Order, and " that hardly a Faggot is ever missing."

The Attorney and Solicitor General having given it as their Opinion, upon the Case laid before them by our Direction, " that the Grant, by Letters Patent, " of the Boughs and Branches of Trees and Wood " w'ithin the Forest, cut off ox thrown down, does not " appear to them to comprehend more than tire " Boughs and Branches which may casually be cut or thrown down, from standing Trees, and not from " Trees which have been felled; but that notwithstanding it appears to them that the Words of the " Letters Patent ought to be so construed, nevertheless if it can be shewn that for a great Length of " Time, prior to Lady Hillsborough's First Memorial, " the Boughs and Branches cut off and thrown down " from Timber felled, were taken by the Grantee, " and a Composition given for them, it might establish " the Construction contended for by Lord Staxcell; " we have thought it our Duty to make the fullest Investigation, in order to ascertain what has been the Usage with respect to the Disposal of the Lops and Tops, from the earliest Period for which any Accounts of Timber felled in this Forest can be found, down to the present Time; and to state the Result of our Exa mination thus at large for the Information of those whose Province it is to decide upon this Claim.

In case the Lieutenant should establish a Right to the Boughs and Branches of all Trees felled in the Forest, we apprehend it to be extremely necessary that it should be ascertained what Parts of a Timber Tree are comprehended under that Description: It is well known that, in Navy Timber, some of the most valuable Pieces, as Knees, Crooks, &c. are taken from the Limbs or Branches of Trees; and that other Parts of the Branches frequently contain Timber fit for Carpentry Uses. It sometimes happens also, that Trees apparently fit for the Navy prove unfit for that use, from some Defect not discoverable while they are standing; which Trees nevertheless contain good Building Timber; and large Butts of Trees and other Pieces of Timber are frequently cut off, as unfit for the Navy, but which are very useful for other Purposes: So that if the Lieutenant were allowed to take all that is not fit for the Use of the Navy, as was done on the Fall of 1,000 Loads' in 1784, he would upon every Fall made for the Navy have considerable Quantities of useful Timber, which could not be comprized under the Description of - and

Branches. It is equally necessary that this Point should be settled before any farther Wood Sales are made in this Forest, as few Persons would choose to become Purchasers subject to such a Claim, before it is determined what Parts they would be obliged to leave for the Grantee: To us it seems that the Mean-; ing of the Clause relative to Boughs and Branches could only be, to give such Boughs and Branches as might

State of the Fo- In the Reign of James the 1st, and In earlier Times, r*d at *Brmer *e* when the Courts in this Forest were regularly held, n *' and the Crown’s Rights in it duly protected, no bad

Consequence appears to have arisen from granting the Office of Lieutenant in Lease; and the Forest was then well stored with Timber. It appears by a Sur-QuantUyofTim- vey, taken in the Year 1608, that there were at that 1608^ Survey *u Time 13,031 Trees fit for the Navy growing in this 1 See Appendix to Forest, and so many dotard and decayed Trees as 5th Report, N# 31. were computed to contain 23,934 Loads. Another And in 1635. Survey was taken in the Year 1635, in which the Appendix, N#2. Number of the Trees is not specified; but the Timber and Wood were valued at 10,247/. which, considering that the Price of Timber was then only about Ten Shillings per Load, must have comprized a very considerable Quantity. The Underwood and Thorns are included in this Valuation.

The Forest wasted During the Disturbances in the succeeding Reign,

during the Usurpa- we have Reason to believe that the Timber in this U0»(EntryBookE. Forest was almost entirely destroyed*; but after the p. 221, A> i66ij Restoration, though the rigorous Execution of the in Surveyor Gene- Forest Laws was abated, the lessening the Security ral’eOffice of Crown which they afforded to the Timber was amply made _n ’ . up for, by the Attention shewn by the Servants of the

after the PR*stora- Crown in this Department, by Means of which a lion. great Stock of young Timber was speedily nursed up,

and well protected. This appears by the Privy Seal x* 7. and Warrants issued in 1704, for continuing the Allowance for the Under Keepers Salaries, and is con» firmed by the present State of the Timber in the Forest: But from the Reign of Queen Anne, when the Civil List Act had lessened the Influence which Ministers formerly derived from the Power of granting away the Estates of the Crown, and their Attention was withdrawn from this Part of the public Property. the Interest of the Crown, in this Forest has been little regarded; the thinning of the young Trees, Effects of N«j which had grown up during the preceding Forty or p e

Fifty Years, was neglected, so that few of them have had Room to grow to a great Size, and have stood too long in that State to be now capable of Benefit from thinning; the Appointment of Verderors and Re-garders, which till then had been regularly chosen, was discontinued, and none have been appointed for more than Forty Years past; the driving of the Fo- 26. rest, either for clearing it of Cattle dunng the Fence Month and Winter Haining, or preventing the surcharging of the Common, or the Admission of the Cattle of Strangers, is entirely laid aside; and no Courts of Attachment or Swarumote have been held within Memory. None of the Keepers are sworn to do their Duty; the Inhabitants of the neighbouring

Villages

30 Geo. III. 24° Februarii. 129

Villages are suffered to lop and top the Trees, and to 19. dig up the Roots of them as fast as any are felled; 33‘ and the greatest Depredations are committed with Impunity.

It appears from the Survey taken in 1635, as well as from the Claims preferred at the last Justice Seat, and the Proceedings at the Courts of Swanimote, mentioned in the former Part of this Report, that the Timber, Wood, Underwood, and Thoms or Bushes, were the sole Property of the Crown, and that the neighbouring Inhabitants were not then understood or admitted to have any Right whatever in the Forest, except that of Pasture, under the Restrictions there mentioned; but, early in the present Century, the Abuses had risen to a great Height, and in the Reign of the UKightUto^cut Queen Annt, an Information was filed by Sir Edward, Bushes. Northey, Attorney General, against one John Hammond, the Owner of a small Estate in Kingsley, within the Bounds of the Forest, for cutting and taking away Bushes to repair his Fences; and a Bill was also filed against him in the Exchequer, for the same Offence. The Defendant justified the cutting of Bushes for Repairs of his Hedges and Fences, claiming it as a Right appurtenant to his Estate; and the Cause was tried at Winchester, at the Lent Assizes in 1713, -when Hammond v 5°^ bjr obtained a Verdict on the Information, and in

eCre* mas Term following a Decree in the Exchequer, esta-/ Wishing the Right claimed, by him. We have looked

into that Decree, and the Depositions of the Witnesses; and it does not appear to us that either the Claims preferred at the Justice Seat, in which no Right to cut Bushes was pretended, or the Proceedings at the Swanimote Courts, in which the cutting of Bushes was

punished as an Offence against the Rights of the Crown, LaDd Reventf<? or the Survey in 1635, in which the Bushes were Report.

comprised, and valued as the Property of the Crown, - ——

were adverted to on that Occasion; and though a Right so acquired, and so long exercised, is now unquestionably established, we shall venture to observe, that the Proceedings in that Suit afford the strongest Reason to believe that the Practice of cutting Bushes took its Rise from the improper Indulgence allowed by former Keepers to the Occupiers of Lands adjacent to the Forest, to cut them for outside Fences, to keep out the Deer. The Witnesses on both Sides, who were questioned concerning the State of the Forest, all concurred in saying that there was a great Quantity of young Timber then growing in it, of 30, 40, and 50 Years old, which they believed could not have been raised there without the Protection of the Bushes; and that there could not have been a sufficient Quantity of Bushes left, to nurse up such a Stock of young Timber, if the Inhabitants had formerly had the Liberty of cutting them, in the Manner then claimed.

The present Condition of the Forest is a melancholy Effects of that Proof of the Truth of that Declaration, and of the Decision.

Effects which have ensued from that Decision; for the State of the Forest is now so changed in that Respect, that there are hardly any Bushes, and very few young Trees remaining.

Appendix, N° 19. the Whole to 50,399 I. 13 9 Mr. Briant, the

Woodward and Deputy Surveyor, by whom that Survey was taken, is of Opinion that the Quantity of the Timber fit for the Navy, deducting what has been felled, and allowing for the Increase in Growth since that Time, is now about 1,100 Loads less than when that Survey was taken; which reduces the Amount of his Valuation to 45,862/. 8 s. 9 d.;and both he and the Purveyor of N# *<» Portsmouth Dock Yard, who viewed the Forest at our Desire, are of Opinion that most of the Trees are The Trees all nearly-of the same Age, being from 100 to 120 Years; nearly of the same which also agrees with the Opinion of the Surveyor AKe- employed by us, and with our own Observations on

viewing the Forest, as well as with the Evidence on the Trial in 1713; and is a clear Proof that the present Stock of Timber may be almost wholly attributed to

that Care and Attention which was bestowed on it, from the Restoration to the End of the last Century, and for a few Years afterwards. The small Number of T^eb^r |lttle younS Saplings, compared with the Number of Grown Trees, 1 er ’ shews how little young Timber has been suffered to And no Prospect get up for many Years past: And it is the Opinion of of any more coming every. Person acquainted with the Forest, whom we "P* have conversed with respecting it, that unless some Regulations shall take Place, and some other Means be provided for raising young Timber,. for which the Bushes were formerly sufficient, no farther Succession of Trees can come up; and, consequently, that the present Stock of Timber is the last that the Forest can ever produce.

Among the Effects of that Inattention to the Incroachments on Rights of the Crown in this Forest which has pre- Woolmer. vailed for several Years past, may be mentioned the Incroachments or Claims made by the Lords of adjoining Manors, to Parts of the Soil of Woolmer.

The most material of these is a Claim of the Lord of the Manor of Mill Land,- to about 220 Acres of the

Note. — The Number of Loads here mentioned is little, more than One Third, of the Number stated in the Account of the Timber in this Forest, laid before the House of Commons by John Pitt, Esquire, late Surveyor General, in 1783, abstracted from the same. Survey; The Difference arises partly from the Quantities in that Account being stated in Square Measure, which gives the Number of Loads One Third more than in Girt Measure; (Two Loads of Timber Measure being equal to Three Loads Squart) but was principally occasioned by an Error of the Person employed to make that Abstract, who appears to have taken the Timber in Holt Forest twice into the Account, as is explained more fully in an Abstract taken from the original Survey, and inserted in the Appendix, No. 3t.

We have stated the Terms of the Grant of the Office of Lieutenant, and the Doubts which have arisen upon the Construction of some of the Clauses Royal Forests, are much more urgent than in other in it; Mid have explained the Liberties which have Property; for in ordinary Cases of Commons and been taken, and the Advantages now enjoyed by the Waste Lands, the Evil is confined to the Waste it-Grantee. self; but in the Royal Forests it extends much far-

It remains for us to point out what course we think,

puts it in the Power of the Crown to render the Pasture of the Forest of little or no Value to the Commoners, and subjects their Property to greater Injury, from the Incursions of the Deer, which must become' more frequent, and more detrimental, in Proportion as

under the Circumstances which we have mentioned, should ndw be taken to render this Part of the Public Property of the greatest immediate Advantage and future Value.
