The Case of Dean of other Forests. Of these the Case of Fo-

Forest analogoas to reSf js m0S{ analogous to that of Aliceholt and the present. rir , °

v Woolmer.

Commons Jour- Within the Perambulation of Dean Forest there were nals, Vol. ix. p. 45 considerable Estates which had Right of Common of *8' Pasture and Pannage, and claimed Estovers in the King’s

Waste: There were no Deer in the Forest at the Time of passing the Act; but the Crown had a Right to keep Deer, as in other Forests, without Limitation: The private Estates were subject to the Forest Laws, and to the ' Range of the Deer.

The King’s Waste contained about 23,000 Acres; and after the fullest Discussion in Parliament, the Act which we have refereed to was passed, by which the Crown was empowered to inclose it,000 Acres, being nearly One Half of the Waste of the Forest, freed from all Manner of Right, Title, or Pretence whatever; with Power to make new Inclosures in the Residue, on throwing open an equal Quantity of the Land first inclosed. All Claim to Estovers was given up; and all Trees and Wood growing, or to grow, on the whole 23,000 Acres, were declared to be the Property of the Crown: The Right to Common of Pasture, which formerly extended over all the Forest, was confined to the Part left uninclesedK and the Right of the Crown to keep Deer without Stint, was limited to Eight hundred in the open Part of the Forest; " and to the End that some Recompence might be " made to those Persons whose Right of Common, " within the Inclosures, was taken from them, for " the necessary Preservation of the Timber," their Estates within the Perambulation were freed and exonerated from the Range of the Deer, and from those Restrictions on the Use of their Property which the Forest Laws imposed.

An Act propoted The Account which we have given of the Rights for this Forest simi- of the Crown, and of the private Proprietors, and Forest! dt neighbouring Inhabitants in Aliceholt and,

will be found so similar to those in Dean Forest, the Rights in the latter were so deliberately considered, when the Act for its Improvement was passed, and the Effects which resulted from that Act were so beneficial to the Crown as well as to the Country, that we are induced humbly to propose that a similar Act should now be passed for the Improvement of this Forest; with this Difference only, that in order that a greater Proportion may be set apart for the Growth of Timber, no Deer whatever should be kept on any Part of this Forest; and as the neighbouring Inhabitants have acquired a Right to cut Bushes in the Forest, that when the Trees in the Inclosures shall be past Danger from Cattle, and it shall be judged proper to lay open a Part, on inclosing an equal Quantity of the Residue, they shall then be entitled to cut Bushes in the Parts so laid open.

In forming a Plan for the Improvement of Forest, where the Claims are so numerous and the Rights of the Crown over the different private Estates within the Perambulation so various, and where there would probably be a Necessity for the Examination of many Witnesses, to ascertain the Rights of Parties, preparatory to a Settlement with them, it appeared to us to be proper to recommend the Appointment of Commissioners for making those necessary Investigations, and to treat with the Claimants for bringing about the Settlement there proposed: But the Forest of Aliceholt and Woolmer being much less extensive, the Claims on it less numerous, and the Rights which the Crown has over the different private Estates less various; the Case of Dean Forest being also so similar and the Act for the Improvement of that Forest affording so good a Precedent, we have not supposed that the Appointment of Commissioners would be found essentially necessary in this Instance, previous to the passing of an Act, but that any farther Information that might be deemed requisite, for enabling Parliament to determine on the Propriety of the Measures to be adopted, and the exact Proportion of this Forest which should be inclosed for the Cultivation of Timber, might be obtained during the Progress of a Bill, as was done in the Two Instances of Dean and New Forests.

If, however, the Mode of Settlement by Commissioners should be thought more proper or expedient, we would, in that Case, humbly propose that Powers should be given to the Commissioners, similar to what we have recommended in our Report on New Forest; and that they should be instructed and empowered, either to make such an Arrangement and Settlement as we have proposed in this Report, or to purchase the just Claims on the Forest, giving to the Claimants the Price or Value of them, either in Money, or in an adequate Share of Land; so as to effect an entire Separation of Rights, and Division of the Soil; and such a complete Divi- Oran entireDi.l sion would be by far the most likely Means to prevent future Intrusion, or Waste, and to raise the Property, 1

whether in Wood or in Tillage, to the highest State of Improvement.

After a Settlement shall be made between the Crown Proposed Mod* and those having Rights of Common, a similar System of future Manage-of Management to that which we have proposed in our ment*

Report on New Forest should take place here, proportioning the Number of Officers to the Extent, and other Circumstances; and as the Trees, in general, at present A general Sale growing in this Forest, are found to he past Improve- of the Timber, ment, and suffer daily from the Depredations of the neighbouring Inhabitants, we are of Opinion that the Timber should be cut, and disposed of, in Annual public Sales, in such Quantities as may be brought to Market, without depressing the Price, reserving only such Trees Reaming onljj as are in the most thriving State, or may be proper to »l»riving Trees; i be left to drop their Acorns, and render the future Sue- I

cession more certain; and such likewise as should be "dbe [e7te'forP$^ left for Ornament, among which we cannot avoid par- or Ornament.: ticularly mentioning one antient and decayed Tree, called The Grindstone Oak, which being one of the largest Trees in England, measuring about 34 Feet and a Half in Circumference, at Five Feet from the Ground, and computed to contain 27 Loads of Timber, is a Proof what this Forest is capable of producing, if properly taken Care of.

The alarming Decrease of Oak Timber in this Kingdom, still confirmed to us on every Enquiry, and the grow ing Demand for private Shipping, as well as for the Navy, call for the Improvement of the Forests; and our Duty requires that we should suggest Plans and Regulations conducive to that End, though they may lessen the Advantages and Emoluments of those employed under the present System of Management: But it would, perhaps, be hard on those who may have been led, by the former Practice of Government, to consider their Residence in the Forests as permanent, and would not, in our Opinion, be consistent with the Dignity of the Crown, to strip away all Trees that are conducive only to Ornament, and reckon the Beauty of the Forests as not deserving of any Care.

Previous to the proposed Sale of Timber, the Forest propo*ed Mod should be divided into so many Parts, as that each of telling the Tin Division shall contain no more than may be sold in *>"

One Year; and each Part should be fenced in as soon as the Trees are removed, until the Whole of the Ground set apart for Inclosure shall be inclosed.

The Deputy Surveyor, and the Purveyor of Portsmouth Yard, are of Opinion, that the whole of the Timber may be sold in Eight or Ten Years, without bringing down the Price; and they think that it would be the most advantageous Way of disposing of it, to sell the Navy Timber along with the rest. In that Case, such as is fit for the Navy may be secured for the Dock Yards, by making it a Condition, at the Sale, that the Navy Board shall have the Liberty of taking it at the usual Prices given to Contractors for Naval Timber delivered at the Dock Yards under similar Circumstances:

This

Advantages of improving this Forest.

To the Public-

Appendix, N° 37.

To those having Rights of Common on the Forest.

Proposed Compensation to the Lieutenant.

30 Geo. III. . 24° Febr i35

This Mode would dot only preserve the proper Timber for the Navy, but by making the Purchaser sure of the best Price for those Kinds, prevent the Value of the rest from being depreciated, by any Suggestion of the Timber to be sold being only the Refuse of the Forest.

If either of the Plans we have suggested for the Improvement of this Forest shall take Place, we are satisfied that the whole Property will be rendered more valuable, and that the Crown and the Commoners will receive mutual Advantage from the Change.

The Public will, in the first Place, receive, probably, from Forty to Fifty thousand Pounds for the Timber growing the re; and the Part of the Forest allotted for Inclosure will, in Time, become a valuable Nursery of Timber, the Soil of Aliceholt being very fit lor the Growth of Oak, and that of for the Larch and Fir Trees, of which latter Sort there are some small Plantations, made for Ornament, about 25 Years since, which are now in a very thriving State: And the whole Expence of Carriage to the Dock Yards in the River does not exceed,) /. 8$. per Load. And we the more willingly recommend this Plan, because it would furnish an ample Fund, derived from the Forest itself, for the Improvement hot only of this Forest, but also of Dean and New Forests.

The Rights of the Commoners will also become more valuable: The Pasture for their Cattle in The Holt, which is at present of small Value, after the Feeding of the Deer (upwards of 1,900 Acres of the Lands being covered with Wood, and less than 500 Acres open Pasture) will be worth much more to them when the Deer and Timber are removed. The private Property will be freed from the Injuries to which it is now liable from the Deer, and which would be very much increased, if Government should again stock Woolmer with Red Deer, in case it snail not be disafforested; and the making of Inclosures for the Growth of Timber will be the Means of raising Bushes, of which there are hardly any at present in the Forest, and which those who have obtained the Right, will have the Liberty of cutting, for repairing their Fences, when the Inclosure shall be laid open. If the more complete Division before suggested shall take Place, the Commoners will obtain a Share of the Soil, instead of their former Rights, and will, in that Case, reap the Benefits which are commonly derived from the Inclosure and Improvement of Wastes.

We have fully stated what Rights are granted to the Lieutenant by his Lease. The Privilege which we apprehend would be chiefly affected by the Adoption of either of the Plans we have suggested, is that which relates to the Deer: By the Terms of the Grant, the Lieutenant is allowed to take One of each Kind Yearly for his own Use: The Perquisite of a Stag and a Hind ceased, of course, on the Removal of the Red Deer, about Thirty Years ago; and we should apprehend that there must be the same Right to remove the Fallow Deer from Aliceholt, as there was to remove the Red Deer from Woolmer. How far the discontinuing to serve Venison for the Use of His Majesty, or any of His Officers, may constitute an Exemption, or vest the entire Property or Disposal of the Deer in the Lieutenant, contrary to the express Terms of his Grant, is not for us to decide; but however unwise it may have been in Government to make such a Grant, the Rights and Advantages conferred by it must undoubtedly be continued to the Grantee during the Term of his present Lease, unless he shall be disposed to sell it to Government, at a fair Price; or a full Compensation must be given for such of them as he may be deprived of, by the Execution of any Plan for the Improvement of the Forest. This last may perhaps be done by renewing Vol. 45.

the Grant of the Office of Lieutenant, with the Great Lodge, and inclosed Lands round it, on beneficial T erms, but without any of the Conditions which have v-been found prejudicial to the Forest, or that may be liable to Misinterpretation; but it cannot reasonably be desired that a System of Management which is found by Experience to defeat the public Object of raising Timber for the Supply of the Navy, and which is likely to render the Property itself of no Value to the Crown, should be longer continued, if substantial Justice does not require it, and we must give it as our clear and decided Opinion, that no Renewal of the Lease should be granted on the present Conditions, and that none of those Advantages which are hurtful to the Timber, should on any Account be suffered to continue.

In the mean Time, and until the Alteration in Management shall take place, the Annuity of 130/. allowed by Government, during Pleasure, in order to be paid over to the Keepers, for their better Encouragement in protecting the Timber, should (if it shall be his Majesty’s Pleasure to continue it) be paid in such a Manner as to make them subject to the Orders of the Surveyor General of the Woods; and if they shall not be found effectually to protect the Timber, that Annuity should be paid to others, to be hired for that sole Purpose; a Regulation which we judge to be the more necessary, as we are informed that the Abuses of lopping and topping the Trees have already been increased since we viewed the Forest, and because it is probable that those accustomed to commit such Offences will become still more daring and desperate, when they hear of a Proposal to cut the Timber, by which their Profits must cease.

We cannot close this Report without observing, that though this Grant, which has had Effects so prejudicial to the Estate of the Crown, is not a Grant of the Forest, but of an Office to which Duties are annexed, as well as Emoluments, and those Duties have been neglected, while the Emoluments have been increased; yet it ought to be considered that these are the Consequences of the total Relaxation which has so long prevailed in this Department, and the Blame is less to be imputed to the Grantee, than to the System of Management, which affording no effectual Check on those entrusted with, the Care of any Forest, naturally leads to such Abuses.

Under an Office for the Management of the Landed Estates of the Crown, properly constituted, and keeping regular Entries, or Registers, of every Grant, Warrant, or Proceeding, relative to any Part of the Property, Incroachments on the Crown’s Rights would be so easily detected, that they could not long prevail. Without such Guides, it is neither an easy nor a pleasant Part of our Duty to discover what the Crown really intended to grant, or to reserve, and to trace the Steps by which Advantages have been acquired by Individuals, or the Crown deprived of any Part of its Rights.

One of the worst Effects of this Relaxation in the Government is, that the Grantees of Offices, being left so long in the undisturbed Possession of the Profits of what has been entrusted to their Care, are gradually led to look upon the Property itself as their own. To attempt a Reform in the Management, — to revive the Rights of the Crown, — and to endeavour to put a Stop to Emoluments, which, though inconsistent with the Public Interest, have been long enjoyed, may possibly now have the Appearance of Hardship; and where the Abuses have not originated, or been increased, during the Time of the immediate Possessor, perhaps it may be judged proper to give some Recompence for the Loss of Advantages, which, though at first improperly taken, have received a Kind of Sanction from the Inattention

M m or

Land Revenue Report.

____________j

134 24° Februarii. A. 1790.

Land Revenue

Report.

or Forbearance of Government: But whether there should be any such Compensation given in the present Instance, beyond what may be fairly claimed in Return for any of those Emoluments which may be given up during the Term of the subsisting Lease, or what that Compensation onght to be, is not for our Consideration, and must be left to the Wisdom of the Legislature to determine: Our Duty requires only that we should state the Circumstances distinctly, in order that the Means of judging may not be wanting; and that we should suggest such Plans of Improvement, and better Management, of this Part of the Public Property, as we think the most likely to increase the Supply of Timber, so much wanted for the Royal Navy.

If either of the Plans we have suggested for this Forest shall meet with the Approbation of the Legislature, we are of Opinion that an Act should be passed for carrying it into Execution, before the Timber should be felled, lest, by rendering the Pasture more valuable, the Commoners should become more unwilling to agree to the Arrangement proposed and as the present State of the Timber is such that the greatest Part of it must diminish in Value the kmgcr

it continues standing, and no Succession of young Trees can come up, we humbly submit, that in our Opinion the Public Interest requires that the Plan which shall be adopted for the Improvement of thie Forest should be carried into Execution as soon as the Claims of the Lieutenant shall be duly ascertained, or his Lease purchased, and such a Change shall take Place in the System of Management of the Royal Forests, as that the Officers to be employed shall receive adequate Salaries for their Services, free from Deduction, and without any Perquisite, in Lieu of the present numerous and irregular Fees, Poundages, and Emoluments, by which the Produce to the Public, of the proposed Sale of the Timber, would be much impaired.

Cha> (L. S.)

Land Revenue Office, ,(L. S.)

Scotland Yard, John Fordyce, (L. S.)

8th February 1790.

Forrest of Alice Holt and Woolmer in the County of South ton.

This xvij day of June iti the eleaventh Yeare of the reigne of our Sovereign Lord Charles by the Grace of God King of England Scotland France & Ireland Defender of the Faitlq &c. 1635.

WEE his Maj*? Officers w^in the s* Forres': of Aliceholt and Woolmer who have hereunto sett our hands and Seales by virtue of a Warr'. to vs directed from ye: Wor". Charles Harbord Esq’: his Maj,jr": Surveyor Generali Doe hereby according to the purport of the said Warr'. certifye concerning the severall Offices and names of ye: p’sent Officers and Ministers and theire Deputyes and concerning the Lodges Plekes Inclosures Proffitts and allowances casuall and certaine to them ap^taineing and concerning the Coppices Woods Underwoods and fitt places to be enclosed to supply of Tymber Trees and other the contents of the aforesd. Warr': in forme hereunder expressed viz:

ambuladon. ffirst as touching the bounders and extents of the said fforrest beginning at Amers-ford and soe to Issington Hatch and soe to Aldwicle and so as the fottpath leadeth to the topp of the Hill above Grymsham ats Grimsgrove and soe to the Old Marlepitt wcb: is in Crockensland and soe as the foot patli leadeth by the side of the said Hill to the Wood or Linch above Sturtleiriead and so to the broad Hatch at purehill ats Riverhill and thence as the foot path leadeth by the side of the Hill into Shackstreet and so directly to the Pleystowe of Whatleigh and soe by the Hedge on the East side as the said Shackstreet goeth along to the loot of the Old Marlepitt at Whatleigh and soe to the topp of Amersputt and soe above the topp of Randolsclyme to Modiesputt and so to the Ash of Southees and soe bending a little towards the North to Wolstansuall and descending directly to Cotts where sometime Cott Mill did stand and soe to Weeke and soe by the middle of the Gate of John of Linch now in the tenure of Robert Cheyney and soe descending by the middle of y*. Sixth Land Revenue Report.

REMARKS:

From the Appearance of the Timber in Aliceholt Forest, and The Straits, it must have been well protected in its early Growth by Underwood, which the Rangers then preserved with Care; but, owing to the Preservation of it being neglected, and the uninterrupted Exercise of a Right, which the Proprietors of neighbouring Estates and Cottages claim, of cutting what Quantity of the Underwood and Bushes they think proper, there is no Prospect of an Increase of Timber; and even that now standing is frequently lopped, topped, and otherwise much injured, by those who, it is conceived, unjustly claim, and put in Force the Right before-mentioned.

The Timber in Aliceholt (on a computed Valuation) I estimate at 60,000l. It would have been of much more Value, had it not been so much lopped, and a great Number of Trees entirely topped; by which it has received considerable Damage. There is a great deal of it very old, and worse for standing.

I recommend a Fall of all Timber that is fit for the Navy, of which there is a great Quantity, and some spoiling.

Those Trees that have been lopped and topped, would serve wrell for Posts and Rails, to fence in, and sub-divide by a Ditch, Four Feet at Top, Three Feet deep, and Two Feet wide at the Bottom. This should be done without Delay, if the Ground is intended for the Produce of Timber, as the Inclosure would prove an excellent Fence for the numerous young Oaks, with which the Forest abounds.

The Deer, which I believe are about Four or Five hundred in Number, do much Prejudice to the Timber.

Aliceholt chiefly consists of Clay and Gravelly Soils, each excellent in its Kind, capable of being converted into Arable, Meadow, or Pasture. The Whole contains 2,427 Acres, and I have Averaged it at ioj. Acre, which amounts to 1,224/. 7 s. 6</. per Annum.

Vo 1.. 43.

In

A. 1790

24° Februarii.

Sixth Land Revenue Report.

Total in Woolmer - - - 5,949 2 8 945 6 4

R E M A R K S.

The chief Part of Woolmer consists of a light sandy Soil, interspersed with Peat Moors, as shewn on the Plan. For Sale I average it at 3 s.per Acre. The Land is not fit for the Produce of Oak, but is well adapted for the Growth of the Weymouth Pine, or any Kind of Fir, as proved by the several ornamental Plantations set by the late Ranger, Mr. Legge.

George the Third, by the Grace of God of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith, and so forth, To all to whom these Our Letters Patent shall come, Greeting: Know ye, That We of Our Royal Grace and Favour, and in Consideration of the Covenants, Conditions, and Agreements herein contained, and also by and with the Advice of Our right trusty and well-beloved Councellors Frederick North, commonly called Lord North, Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter, First Commissioner of Our Treasury of Great Britain, and Chancellor and Under Treasurer of Our Exchequer, and of Our trusty and well-beloved Francis Conway, commonly called Loud Viscount Beauchamp, Cornwall,

Esquire, William ''Henry Lord and Henry

Temple Lord Viscount -Pnknersion, both of Our King-doni of Ireland, Commissioners of'Our said Treasury, have demised, granted, and'to Farm letten, and by these Presents, for Ourself, Our Heirs, and Successors, do demise, grant, and to Farm let, unto Our beloved Cousin and Councilor William Earl of Dartmouth, together with' Our beloved Subject Sir William Bagot, Baronet, Charles Tewnshend, and John Butter, Esquire, Trustees named in the Marriage Settlement of the Right honourable Wills Earl of Hillsborough, and Mary Countess Of Hillsborough, Lady Baroness of

'Seiherton, in the County of Somerset, his Wife, all that

Yearly Rent Of Thirty-one Pounds Two Shillings and Eleven Pence reserved by Letters Patent of Our Royal Predecessor his Majesty King Janies the First, for and out of all that the Manor or Manors of Wordleham, otherwise East Wordleham and West Wordleham, with the Rights, Members, and Appurtenances thereto belonging, situate and being in Our County of Southampton, and Parcel of the Possessions of Our Crown of England, late in the Tenure of William Viscount Wallingford, deceased, and by the said Letters Patent granted to George Shiers and John Wells; and also all that the Office of Lieutenant or Keeper of the Forest or Chace of Aliceholt and Woolmer, with the Appurtenances, in Our said County of Southand all Offices, Liberties, Wages, Fees, Commodities, and Privileges whatsoever, to the said Office of Lieutenant or Keeper of the said Forest and Chase belonging or appertaining; all and singular which said Premisses were demised by Our late Royal Grandfather, his Majesty King George the Second, by Letters Patent under the Seal of his Court of Exchequer at Westminster, bearing Date on or about the First Day of February, in the Fifteenth Year of his Reign, unto John,

nistrators, and Assigns, or their Lieutenant or Lieutenants in the said Forest, to hold the Court commonly called The Wood Court, and to take, levy, and receive,

as well by themselves, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, as by their Deputy or Deputies, for the Use of the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Bagot, Charles Toicnshend, and John Buller, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, all Fines and Amerciaments made and Forfeiture in the said Court, to Us, Our Heirs and Successors, during the said Term; and also to have and take the Entrails, commonly called the Humbles and Suets, of all Deer killed and taken within the said Forest and Liberty; to have and take, within the said Forest and Chace, or either of them, for their own proper Use, One Stag and One Buck in the Summer Season, and One Hinde and One Doe in the Winter Season; and to have, hold, exercise, and enjoy all and singular Offices, Authorities, Privileges, and Liberties aforesaid; and to take and keep all and singular Profits, Commodities, Advantages, and other the Premisses, to the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Bagot, Charles T&wnshend, and John Buller, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for and during the said Term in and by these Presents granted, without any Account to be made or rendered to Us, Our Heirs or Successors, for the said Premisses, or any Part or Parcel thereof, in as full and ample Manner and Form as William Legge, and Emanuel Scroope How, Esquires, or any other Person or Persons, heretofore had, held, and enjoyed the same, subject to the Uses and Trusts hereinbefore mentioned and declared of and concerning the same: And the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Bagot, Charles Townshend, and John , for themselves

respectively, and for their respective Heirs, Executors, and Administrators, do, and each of them doth covenant, promise, grant, and agree, to and with Us, Our Heirs and Successors, by these Presents, in Manner and Form following; (that is to say) That they the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Bagot, Charles Townshend, and John Buller, their Executors, Administrators and Assigns, shall and will, from Time to Time, during the Term hereby granted, when and as often as Need or Occasion shall be and require, at their or One of their own proper Costs and Charges, well and sufficiently repair, amend, support, uphold, and maintain all and singular the Lodges, Fences, and Inclosures of and belonging to the said Premisses hereby demised, by and with all and all Manner of needful and necessary Reparations and Amendments whatsoever; and the said Premisses, and every Part of the same, so well and sufficiently repaired and amended, at the End or other Determination of the said Term shall and will peaceably and quietly leave, surrender, and yield up to Us, Our Heirs and Successors: And also, that they the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Bagot, Charles Townshend, and John Buller, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, shall and will, from Time to Time, and at all Times hereafter, during the Term hereby granted, discharge, save harmless, and indemnify Us, Our Heirs and Successors, of and from the Payment of all and every the Salarys, Stipends, or Wages, which shall or may become due or payable to any of the Foresters, Keepers, and Officers of the said Forest and Chace, during the Term hereby granted; and also shall and will preserve and keep the Deer and other Game within the said Forest and Chace, and all the Woods, Timber Trees, and other Trees growing in and upon the said Premisses, from cutting, chopping, and Spoil, during the said Tei'm hereby granted, and, being so preserved and kept, at the End or other sooner Determination of the said Term hereby granted shall and will peaceably and quietly leave and yield Von. 45.

up to Us, Our Heirs and Successors: Provided always nevertheless, That if these Our Letters Patent, and all Assignments thereof which shall or may at any Time or Times hereafter be made of these Our Letters Patent, or of the Premisses hereby demised, or any Part thereof, shall not be inrolled before Our Auditor of Our said County of Southampton, or his Deputy or Deputies for the Time being, within the Space of Six Months next following their respective Dates, and Minutes or Docquets thereof entered in the Office of Our Surveyor General of Our Land Revenues for the Time being, within the like Space of Six Months next following their respective Dates, that then and from thenceforth, in any such Case, or on any such Default, this Our present Demise and Grant, and all and every such Assignments thereof respectively, shall and may be accounted null, void, and of no Force or Virtue, any Thing in these Presents contained to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding: In Witness whereof, We have caused these Our Letters to be made Patent. Witness Our above-named right trusty and well-beloved Commissioners of Our Treasury aforesaid, at Westminster, the Twenty-third Day of March, in the Twentieth Year of Our Reign, One thousand Seven hundred and Eighty.

By Warrant of the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury.

j

Inrolled the 4th of April 1780.

A true Copy from the Inrollment, before me,

John Hosier, Dep. AudT.

N# 7.

soutHto

Anne, by the Grace of God Queen of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &;c. To Our right trusty and well-beloved Councellor, Sidney Lord Godolphin, Our High Treasurer of England, and Treasurer of Our Exchequer, the Chancellor and Under Treasurer of Our Exchequer now being, and to the High Treasurer or Commissioners of the Treasury, Chancellor, and Under Treasurer of Our Exchequer for the Time being, Greeting: Whereas Our late Royal Brother King William the Third, by Letters under his Privy Seal, bearing Date on or about the One and Thirtieth Day of August 1701, did direct the Payment of One hundred and Fifty Pounds per Ann. out of the Receipt of Exchequer,- to Our trusty and well-beloved Emanuel Scroop Howe, Esquire, Lieutenant and Keeper of Our Forests of Alice Holt and Woolmer, in Our County of Southton. for the Wages to 5 Under Keepers in the said Forests at 25/. Ann. each for themselves, and 5/. per Annum each for a Servant; the same to commence from Michaelmas 1699, and to continue during the Pleasure of Our said late Royal Brother; which said Letters of Privy Seal became void by the Death of Our said late Royal Brother: And whereas the said Emanuel Scroop Howe hath by his Petition prayed that the said Allowances may be continued, and that the same may be paid by the Surveyor General of Our Woods on the South Side Trent, out of such Money as is or shall be in his Hands, arising by Wood Sales; which Petition being by you, OurHigh Treasurer

Q q of

Sixth Land Revenue Report.

150 24° Februarii. A. 1790.

Sixth of England, referred to our trusty and well-beloved Land Revenue Edu^1 Wilcox, Esquire, Surveyor General of Our Woods

Report. on South Side Trent, he has reported that he is of Opinion an Allowance of 20/. per Ann. each, to Two of the said Under Keepers, being Keepers of Wolmer Forest, where there is no Timber, may be a sufficient Allowance, without any Servant, for taking Care of the Deer and Game, and which is the usual Allowances to Keepers in other Our Forests; and that the other Three, being Keepers in Holt Forest, where there is a great Quantity of young thriving Timber, and lately well preserved, which hereafter may be fit for the Use of Our Navy, may deserve Encouragement by having the like Allowances granted by the said former Letters of Privy Seal continued to them, the Whole proposed by the said Surveyor General of Our Woods to be allowed, amounting to 130/. per Ann.; which We being graciously pleased to approve of, Our Will and Pleasure is, and We do hereby authorize and command, That you issue the necessary Warrants or Orders to the Surveyor General of Our Woods on the South Side Trent for the Time being, directing him, out of such Money as is or shall be in his Hands arising by Wood Sales, to pay unto the said Emanuel Scroop Howe, or the Lieutenant and Keeper of the said Forests for the Time being, as well the Sum of 292/. 10. for Two Years and a Quarter, from Lady Day 1702 to Midsummer last 1704, as of what shall for the future grow due Quarterly on the several Allowances before mentioned, amounting in the Whole to 130/. per Ann.; to wit, 20/. per Ann. for the Wages to each of the Two Keepers in Wolmer Forest, and 25/. Ann. for the Wages to each of the Three Keepers in Alice Holt Forest, and 51, per Ann. more to each of the said Three last mentioned Keepers for a Servant, the same to continue during Our Pleasure: And We do hereby further authorize you to give Directions to the Auditor of Our said County of Southton. to give Allowance to the said Surveyor General of Our Woods in his Accounts of all such Sum and Sums of Money as shall appear to Our said Auditor to have been paid in pursuance hereof: And these our Letters shall be your sufficient Warrant and Discharge in this Behalf. Given under Our Privy Seal, at Our Palace of Westminster, the 16th Day of August, in the Third Year of Our Reign.

John Tench,

Deputy to The/ Gosling, Esqr.

SOUTHTON.

After my hearty Commendations: Whereas Her Majesty, by Letters under Her Privy Seal, bearing Date the 16th Day of August Instant, hath directed Payment to be made of 130/. per Ann. out of Wood Sales to Emanuel ScroopeHoive, Esquire, Lieutenant and Keeper of the Forests of Alice Holt and Wolmer, the same to commence from Lady Day 1702, and to be applied in Manner following; that is to say, 20/. per Ann. for Wages to each of the Two Keepers in Wolmer Forest, and 25/. per Ann. for the Wages to each of the Three Keepers m Alice Holt Forest, end 51, per Ann. more to each of the said Three last mentioned Keepers for a Servant: These are, by virtue of the said Letters of Privy Seal, to authorize and require you, out of such Money as is or shall be in your Hands arising by Wood Sales, to pay unto the said Emanuel Scroop Howe, or his Assigns, as well the Sum of 292/. 10. for Two Years and a Quarter of the said Allowances, from Lady Day 1702 to Midsummer last 1704, as of what shall from Time to Time for the future grow due thereupon, pursuant to the Direction of the said Letters of Privy Seal; and this shall be, as well to you for making the said Payments as to the Auditor for allowing thereof on your Accounts, a sufficient Warrant

Treasury Chambers, 21st Aug' 1704-Godolphin.

To my very loving Friend, Edvfi Wilcox, Esqr, Surveyor General of Her Majesty’s Woods on the South Side Trent.

N8 8.

By the LORD JUSTICES.

Wm Cant. Roxburghe.

Argyll & Greenwich. Berkeley.

Holies Newcastle. Cadogan.

Whereas wee are given to understand, that the Keeper or Ranger of His Maties. Forest or Chase of Alice Holt and Woolmer, in the County of Southampton, by virtue and in pursuance of the Grant of the said Office, holds and enjoys or receives a Fee Farm Rent, belonging to the Crown, of Thirty-one Pounds Two Shillings and Eleven Pence per Annum, issuing out of the Manor of Wordelham in the said County, with Intent that the said Keeper or Ranger might pay and support Yearly all Fees, Rewards, Salaries, and Stipends, of all and singular the Foresters, Keepers, and Ministers, of the said Forest or Chase; and accordingly the Grantee has covenanted in the said Grant, That the Crown shall be discharged from the Payment of any Salaries or Wages to any Under Keepers of the said Forest or Chase: And whereas wee are further given to understand, that her late Matie. Queen Anne, notwithstanding the Covenant of the said Grantee to exonerate and discharge the Crowne as aforesaide, was pleased to order and direct, out of Money ariseing by Wood Sales, which should be and remain in the Hands of the Surveyor Generali of her Woods for the Time being, the Yearly Sume of One hundred and Thirty Pounds per Ann. to be distributed and paid over by the said Keeper or Ranger, in Manner following; that is to say, to Two Keepers in Woolmer Forest, Twenty Pounds per Ann. each, for their Wages; to Three Under Keepers in Alice Holt Forest, which was then and is now, as wee are informed, well stockt with young Timber, Twenty-five Pounds per Annum each for their Wages, and Five Pounds per Ann. more for each of the said Keepers, for a Servant: And whereas Mrs. Ruperta How, in whom the said Office of Keeper or Ranger is now legally vested, hath humbly besought His Matie. for the Encouragement of the said Keepers, and for the better Preservacon of Vert, Venison, and Timber, within the said Forest or Chase, and to the End many Disorders and Depredacons which frequently happen for Want of such Encouragement, may be hindered for the future, that the said Allowance may be continued in Manner it was directed to be paid by her said late Matie. to which Request wee, on His Majesty’s Behalfe, think reasonable to condescend and agree: These are therefore, in His Maties. Name to authorize, direct, and require you to issue your Warrant or Warrants to the Surveyor Generali of His Maties. Woods for the Time being, thereby authorizing and impowering him, out of such Monies as shall from Time to Time be and remain k» His Hands ariseing or to arise by Wood Sales, in any his Maties. Forests, Parks, or Chaces whatsoever, to pay, or cause to be paid, unto the said Ruperta How, or her Assignee, the said Yearly Sume of One hundred and Thirty Pounds from the Time it was last paid, for and during His Maties. Pleasure, to be applied and payed over by the said

Ruperta

30 Geq. III. 24° Februarii: . 151

Ruperta How in Manner following; (that is to say) to the Two Keepers in Woolmer Forest, after the Rate of Twenty Pounds per Annum each for their Wages, and to Three Keepers in Alice Holt Forest, after the Rate of Twenty-five Pounds Ann. each for their Wages, and after the Rate of Five Pounds per Ann. more to each of the said Three Keepers for a Servant; and in the said Warrant or Warrants you are to order and direct the said Surveyor to take Care that the said Yearly Sume, and the Arrears thereof, be paid over to the said Keepers accordingly, and to enjoyn and require the said Keepers to observe and follow such Rules, Orders, and Instruccons, with respect to the Preservacon of the Timber, Vert, Venison, and other His Maties. Interest in the said Forest or Chace, as you or the said Surveyor Generali of His Maties. Woods for the time being, shall in that Behalfe think fitt to direct and appoint; and for so doeing this shall be your Warrant.

Given at His Maties. Court at Whitehall, the 25th Day of September 1723, in the Tenth Year of His Maties. Reign.

By their Excellencies Command,

Walpole.

Geo. Baillie.

To the Com" R. Edgcumbe.

of His Maties;

Treasury.

After our hearty Commendacons: We doe hereby, in pursuance of their Excellencies the Lords Justices Pleasure, signified to us by the aforegoing Warrant under their Hands, authorize, direct, and require you, out of such Monies as are therein menconed, to pay, or cause to be paid, unto Mrs. Ruperta How, Chfeif Ranger or Keeper of His Matie. Forest or Chace of Alice Holt and Woolmer, or her Assigns, not only all such Sume and Sumes as are now due and in Arrear, on the Yearly Sume of One hundred and Thirty

Pounds, thereby made payable for the Keepers of the said Forest or Chase, in Proporcons as are therein menconed, but also of all such Sume and Sums as shall from Time to Time for the future Quarterly become due and payable thereupon; takeing Care that the said Arreares and growing Payments be applyed and paid over to the said Keepers in Manner as by the said Warrant is directed; and moreover, you are hereby authorized and directed to enjoyn and require the severall and respective Keepers receiveing the said Yearly Sume to observe and follow such Rules, Orders, and Instruccons, with respect to the Preservacon of the Timber, Vert, Venison, and other His Maties. Interest in the said Forest or Chase, as you shall in that Behalfe think fitt to direct and appoint, under Pain (in case of Failare, Neglect, or Contempt) of being deprived the Benefitt of the Allowances His Matie. is pleased to make them: For all which this shall be your sufficient Warrant, provided an Entry hereof be first made before His Maties. Auditor of the Land Revenues for the Countys of Southampton, or any His Majesty’s Auditor before whom you are to account for the Monies, or any Part thereof, out of which the Sums due and to be due on the said Allowance shall be satisfied and paid, as also before the Auditor of the Receipt of His Maties. Exchequer and Clerk of the Pells there.

Whitehall Treasury Chambers, 2d Oct' 1723.

R. Walpole,

R. Edgcumbe, H. Pelham.

To our very loving Friend,

Charles Wither, Esq'. Surveyor Gen11 of His Maties. Woods, and to all others herein Concerned.

Vol. 45.

Sixth Land Revenue Report.

N° 9.

EXTRACTS from the Accounts of all Wood Sales in the Forest of Aliceholtand Woolmer. from the Year 1722 (being the earliest Period for which any such Accounts can be found) to the Year 1774; taken from the original Accounts of the Surveyors General of the Woods in the Office of the Auditor of the Land Revenue, in order to shew what has been the Usage with respect to the Disposal of the Lops, Tops, and Bark felled there during that Period.

1729-

1732.

In 1722, The Accomptant is charged with 180 dotard Oak Trees, with the Bark, Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood thereof, felled in Alice Holt Forest, valued and sold for the sum of 1724. The Accomptant is charged with 405 underling unthrifty Oak Trees, together with the Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood thereof, felled in Alice Holt Forest, valued and sold for the Sum of ——

The Accomptant is charged with 1,170 dotard and decayed Oak Trees, together with the Bark, Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood thereof, felled and cut down in Holt Forest, valued and sold to Mr. John Smith, of Basingstoke, for the Sum of -The Accomptant is charged with 577 Trees, with the small Flittems, felled in Alice Holt Forest (clear of the Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood of the said Trees, the same being claimed by Mrs. Ruperta How, by virtue of her Grant of the Office of Ranger of the said Forest) sold and delivered to divers Persons, for the Sum of ——

737*8. The Accomptant is charged with 998 small Flittern Trees, and 621 dotard and decayed Trees, felled and cut down in the said Forests, in the Year 1736 (clear of the Lops, Tops, and Offal Wood of the said Trees, the same being claimed by Mrs. Ruperta How, by virtue of her Grant of the Office of Ranger of the said Forests) sold and delivered to Henry Hoult and William Hercy, for the Sum of -

To the Right honourable the Lords Comriaissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury.

The Memorial of the Right honourable

Countess of Hillsborough, Lady Baroness of Sojnerton, Lieutenant or Keeper of the Forest or Chase of Alice Holt and Woolmcr, in the County of Southampton; and of John Esquire, and Charles Esquire, Ex-

ecutors of the Right honourable Henry Bilson Legge, Esquire, deceased, who was Lieutenant or Keeper of the said Forest or Chase;

Sheweth,

That the said Henry Bilson Legge was by several Letters Patent appointed Lieutenant or Keeper of the said Forest or Chase, and by virtue thereof was entitled to One Fifth Part of the Produce of all Timber sold by the Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods in the said Forest or Chase, in lieu of the Top, Lop, «nd Bark thereof, and by several Warrants issued from his late and present Majesty’s Treasury, was also entitled to the Yearly Sum of One hundred and Thirty Pounds for the Keeper’s Salaries, which is directed to be paid by the Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Sixth

Woods: . ’ LaReRorVt!m'e

That the said Henry Bilson Legge died on the Twenty- »____

third Day of August 1764, upon whose Death the same descended on your Memorialist, the Coutltess of Hillsborough, his Widow:

That the saTd Henry Bilson Legge and Countess of Hillsborough regularly paid the Salaries to the Under Keepers of -the said Forest or Chase, but have not received the said Yearly Sum of One hundred and Thirty Pounds since the 17th of March 1761, when John Pitt,

Esquire, the then and present Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods, paid the said Henry Bilson Legge the same, together with the Fifth Part of the Sale for the preceding Year; after which nothing was paid to the said Henry Bilson Legge during. his Life Time, noi* has any thing been paid to your Memorialist since his Death:

That Sir Edmund Thomas, Baronet, succeeded the said John Pitt', as.Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods, and continued so till his Death, when the said John Pitt was again appointed Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods':

That the said John Pitt and Sir Edmund Thomas have sold Timber in the said Forest or Chase, in the Years and to the Amount following; (that is to say)

£. s. d.

" 1761 None cut ——

1762 - - - 323

1763 None cut - —

1764 ... - 352

In the Years/ 1765 - 329

1766 349

1767 None cut ——

1768 - - 661

L *769 - - - - 277 — —

2,291

One Fifth Part of which, amounting to the Sum of Four hundred and Fifty-eight Pounds and Four Shillings, is due to your Memorialists in lieu of the Top, Lop, and Bark thereof, together with the said Yearly Sum of One hundred and Thirty Pounds for the several Years above-mentioned.

Your Memorialists therefore pray your Lordships will be pleased to order the said John Pitt to pay them their respective Dues out of the Monies which have or may come to his Hands; and that your Lordships will also be pleased to order the Representatives of the said Sir Edmund Thomas to pay them their respective Dues out of the Monies which came to his Hands; or that your Lordships will be pleased to mike such other Orders for the Payment of your Memorialists as to yoilr Lordships shall seem meet:

And your Memorialists shall ever pray; &c.

Whitehall, Treasury Chambers, the 16th May 1770.

The Right honourable the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury are pleased to refer the aforegoing Memorial to John Pit Esquire, Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods, who is to consider the same, and report to their Lordships a true State of the Premises, together with an Estimate of the Expences that the therein-mentioned Works and Repairs will amount to.

Grey Cooper.

Vol. 45.

N° 11.

To the Right honourable the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury.

My Lords,

In Obedience to your Lordships Order of Reference on the Memorial of the Right honourable the Countess of Hillsborough, hereunto annexed, I have considered the same, and find that during the Years mentioned in the said Memorial the several Quantities of Timber were sold in the Forests of Alice Holt and Woolmer, and for the Sums mentioned in

the said Memorial; and I also find, that the Propor-. tion of One Fifth Part of the said Sums due to her Ladyship, in lieu of the Lops, Tops, and Bark of the said Timber, and also the Sum of 130/. per Annum for Keepers Salaries, have not been paid, but remain- in Arrear for the whole Time of Sir Edmund Thomas's holding the said Office of Surveyor.

General.

That at the Time' I last came into His Majesty’s Service, I found that there were several Works and Repairs unfinished, and absolutely necessary to be carried on, to prevent their going to Decay; and, there being no Money in Hand to be delivered over to me, I was under a Necessity of applying the Money raised by the Falls made under my Directions for the Purposes last mentioned.

That a Fall of Timber has. lately, been made, under my Directions, by the Aid of which I shall be enabled \o discharge the Money due from me to her Ladyship, which shall be done so soon as the Money is received,

That

i -J

A. 1790.

156 24° Februnrn.

That in regal’d to the several Sums which, during the Time Sir Edmund Thomas held the Office, ought to have been paid to her Ladyship, and which are in Arrear, and amount to 856 /. I humbly propose, if your Lordships approve thereof, that the same be raised at the next Fall, and paid to her Ladyship so soon as the same is received by me. *

June 25, 1770.

N* 12.

Sir,

The Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury having had under their Consideration your Report on the Memorial of the Countess of Keeper of the Forest of Alice Holt and , in the County of Southampton, their Lordships are pleased to direct you forthwith to discharge the Arrears due to her, as well on Account of the Fifth Part of the Timber felled in the said Forest, as of the Keeper’s Salaries incurred both in your Time and in that of Sir Edmund Thomas, out of the first Monies that shall come to your Hands, arising from the Sale- of Timber, and in future regularly to pay the growing Salaries as they become due.

I am, Sir,

Your most humble Servant, Treasury Chambers, Grey Cooper.

the 6th July 1770.

To John Pitt, Esq*. Surveyor _

General of His Majesty’s Woods.

N* 13.

After our hearty Commendations: Whereas John Pitt, Esqr; Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods, hath represented, that the late Right honourable Henry Bilson Legge, by virtue of his Office of Lieute-

nant or Keeper of the Forest or Chase of Alice Holt and Wolmer, in the County of , was en-

titled to One Fifth Part of the Produce of all Timber sold by the Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods in the said Forest, in lieu of the Top, Lop, and Bark thereof, and also to the Yearly Sum of One hundred and Thirty Pounds for the Keeper’s Salaries, to be paid by the said Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods; that Payments have accordingly been made by the said John Pitt, and his Predecessor Sir Edmund , of the Fifth Part of the Timber sold in the said Forest, and also of the said Salary of One hundred and Thirty Pounds; and praying that we would grant our Warrant to you, to allow in his Accounts, and in the Accounts of Sir Edmund Thomas, the Sums which have been paid on the above Service: These are to authorize and require you, in passing the Accounts of the said Sir Edmund, and of John Pitt, Esq'; the present Surveyor General of the Woods, to allow all such Sums of Money as shall appear to you to have been paid on Account of One Fifth' Part of the Produce of all Timber sold in the Forest or Chace of Alice Holt and Wolmer, and also of the Yearly Allowance of One hundred and Thirty Pounds for the Keeper’s Salaries; and that you do also allow, in the future Accounts of the said John Pitt, as Surveyor General of the Woods, such Payments on the aforesaid Service as shall appear to you to have been made; and this shall be as well to you and to all others concerned in passing the Accounts of the said Sir Edmund Thomas, and of the said John Pitt, Esqr; of the said several Payments, a sufficient Warrant.

Whitehall, Treasury Chambers, 24 Mar. 1777.

C. Townsend. Beauchamp. C.JV. Cornwall.

To our very loving Friend, Ja‘ West, Esqr. Auditor of His Majesty’s Land Revenue.

N*'i4,

To the Right honourable the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury.

The Memorial of the Right honourable Mary Countess of Hillsborough:

Sheweth,

That your Memorialist, as Lieutenant or Ranger of His Majesty’s Forest or Chace of Alice Holt and Woolmer, in the County of Southampton, lately presented a Memorial to your Lordships, praying, for the Reasons therein contained, that your Lordships would be pleased to order that no more Timber might be cut in the said Forest, until the Right therein mentioned, claimed by the People of Frensham, had been determined by a Course of Law; which Memorial your Memorialist is informed hath been referred by your Lordships to the Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods.

Your Memorialist begs leave further to state to your Lordships, that your Memorialist, by her Grant from His Majesty, is entitled to the Boughs and Branches of all Trees and Wood within the said Forest, cut or thrown down, which your Memorialist hath been informed used to be taken by the Lieutenants or Rangers of the said Forest; but it was found to be so injurious to the Sale of the Timber therein, that for a great number of Years past, long before your Memorialist, or her late Husband, the Right honourable Bilson Legge, had the Grant of the Lieutenantship thereof, it had been agreed between His Majesty’s then Surveyor General, and the then Lieutenant of the said Forest, that the whole of the said Timber Trees should be sold, and that the Lieutenant should have One Fifth of the Amount of the Sale, in lieu of his or her Right therein; which hath been accordingly paid ever since.

That it hath been always usual to sell the Timber in the said Forest by public Sale or Auction, until last Year, when your Lordships were pleased to order Three hundred Loads of Timber to be cut therein, for the Use of His Majesty’s Navy, as your Memorialist hath been informed.

That, in pursuance of the said Order, Mr. Robert Briant, the Deputy Woodward, attended by a Mr. Slade, a Purveyor, and a Mr. Mills, a Contractor, went to the said Forest, and marked upwards of Six hundred Oak Trees, which were afterwards cut.

That your Memorialist caused a great many Applications to be made to the Deputy Surveyor and Deputy Woodward, for an Account of the said Timber, that your Memorialist might know how much her Fifth Part thereof amounted to; which your Memorialist could not obtain, till after she had presented her last Memorial to your Lordships, when the said Mr. Briant, the Deputy Woodward, gave your Memorialist’s Agent an Account thereof, a Copy of which is annexed.

That your Memorialist's Agent seeing by the Account how much the Quantity therein mentioned, amounting to 364 Loads and upwards, exceeded the Quantity ordered by your Lordships to be cut, asked Mr. Briant the Cause thereof; who told him that Mr. Slade and Mr. Mills (whom he considered as his Masters) would have a great Number of Trees marked, after he had repeatedly told them enough had been marked to fulfil your Lordships Order of 300 Loads.

That your Memorialist’s Agent then asked Mr. Briant why the whole of the 364 Loads had not been served into His Majesty’s Dock Yards; and why Mr. Mills, a Contractor, was suffered to have 42 Loads and 40 Feet of it, at so low a Price as 38 a1. a Load, although the same was bond Jide worth between 3/. and 4/. a Load; to which Mr. Bnant said, that Mr.

02 Slade

30 Geo. III. C2A° Februar 157

Slade, fearing he might be blamed for exceeding the ordered Quantity so much, directed Mr. to let

Mr. Mills have the 42 Loads and 40 Feet at that low Price of 38#. a Load.

That your Memorialist is informed, if the Timber had been put up to Sale in the usual public Manner by Auction, it would have produced nearly 2,500 whereas, by Mr. Briant's Account, the gross Amount is only 1,074/. lor. 9 d.to which is to be added about 80/. for the Stack Wood taken away by the People of Frenskam, under a pretended Right; out of which is to be deducted 179/. 19#. the Expences charged in Mr. Briant's Account

That if the said Timber had been sold publickly, as usual, and bad produced 2,500 /. your Memorialist’s Fifth Part thereof would have been 5001.; that had your Memorialist taken the Offal, it would, by Mr. Briant's Account have amounted to 382/. ex-clusivl of the 80/. worth of Stack Wood taken away, which would have made it amount to 462/. but if your Memorialist is to have only a Fifth Part of the Sale, according to Mr. Brs Account, after deducting the Expences, it will amount to only 178/.; your Memorialist however, is very ready and willing to take such a Sum for her Right as your Lordships shall be pleased to order.

That your Memorialists caused several Applications to be made last Year to the Deputy Surveyor for the Keepers Salaries, amounting to 130/. a Year for the Year 1776; but he told her Agent that he had no Money in his Hands, and therefore could not pay it.

That since Mr. Briant bad given in his Account, your Memorialist hath caused Application to be made to the Deputy Surveyor for the Keepers Salaries for the Years 1776 and 1777, when he offered to pay the Salaries for the Year 1776, but said he had not Money in his Hands to pay for both Years; and your Memorialist, knowing that more than sufficient had been received, either by the Deputy Surveyor or Deputy Woodward, ordered her Agent not to receive One Year’s Salary only; and the Deputy Surveyor refusing to pay both Years Salaries, her Agent received none at all.

That your Memorialist since she delivered her last Memorial is informed, that instead of 500 Trees, therein mentioned to be applied for by the Surveyor General to be cut this Year in the said Forest; the Application is for 500 Loads, which by the Rule of cutting last Year, will require upwards of 800 Trees, which your Memorialist is informed is a greater Number of Trees than there are in the said Forest fit for His Majesty’s Navy, unless a great many very growing Trees are cut.

That since your Memorialist delivered her last Memorial, she hath been informed through the Deputy Surveyor, that your Lordships ordered the 500 Loads to be cut this Year in the said Forest, before her Memorial came before your Lordships.

Your Memorialist therefore, for the Reasons contained in her former and this Memorial, prays your Lordships will be pleased to revoke your Order for the cutting 500 Loads this Year in the said Forest, and that for the future all the Timber may be sold by public Auction as usual; and that your Lordships will also be pleased to order the Surveyor General to pay to your Memorialist the Salaries for the Years 1776 and 1777 (which she hath already paid to the Keepers) and such a Sum in lieu of her Right in the Trees cut last Year, as to your Lordships shall seem right and equitable.

And your Memorialist will pray, &c.

Sir,

su

My Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Trea-ry having resumed the Consideration of the Memo-Vol. 45.

rial of the Countess of Hillsborough, as Lieutenant or Ranger of His Majesty’s Forest or Chace, called Alice Holt and JVolmer, in the County of Southampton, stating several Abuses in cutting Timber in the said Forest last Year; and desiring that an Order for cutting 500 Loads this Year may be revoked, but that for the future all the Timber may be sold by Auction, that the Salaries of the Keepers for 1776 and 1777 may be paid; and also such a Sum in lieu of her Right in the Trees cut last Year, as to my Lords shall seem meet: I am ordered by their Lordships to refer the said Memorial to you, and to direct you to enquire into the Facts and Circumstances of the Case, and report the same to this Board.

I am,

Sir,

Your most humble Servant,

John.

Treasury Chambers, 21st July 1778.

Sixth Ip&nd Revenue Report.

John Pitt, Esquire, Surveyor of the Woods.

N* 15.

To the Right honourable the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury.

My Lords,

In Obedience to your Lordships Order of Reference, I have considered the Memorial of the Right honourable - Mary Countess of Hillsborough, hereto annexed, and beg Leave to state to your Lordships,

That by Letters Patent, bearing Date the 11th Day of March 1773, all that Yearly Rent of 31 /. 2 11 d.

reserved by Letters Patent of his late Majesty King James the First, for and out of the Manor or Manors of Wordleham, otherwise East Wordleham and West

Wordleham, with the Rights, Members, and Appurtenances, situate in the County of Southampton, and Parcel of the Possession of the Crown, and also the Office of Lieutenant or Keeper of the Forest of Alice, Holt and Woolmer, with the Appurtenances, in the said County of Southampton, and all Officers Liberties, Wages, Fees, Commodities, and Priviledges whatsoever to the said Office belonging, were demised and granted unto the Right honourable William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Baggot, Baronet, Charles Townsend, and John Buller, Esquires, Trustees named in the Marriage Settlement of the Right honourable Wills Earl of Hillsborough and the said Countess of Hillsborough, to hold and enjoy the said Annual Rent of 31/. 2 s.nd. unto the said William Earl of

mouth, Sir William Baggqt, Charles Townsend, and Buller, Trustees as aforesaid, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for and during such Term or Number of Years as would fill up and compleat the then existing. Term and Interest to the full Term of 31 Years from the said 11th Day of March, 1773; upon Condition, nevertheless, that the said William Earl of Dartmouth, Sir William Baggot, Charles Townsend, and John Buller, their Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, should pay, or cause to be paid, all and singular Fees, Wages, Salaries, and Stipends of all and singular the Forest Keepers and Officers within the said Forest or Chace: And also to have, hold, exercise, and enjoy the said Office of lieutenant or Keeper of the Forestand Chace aforesaid, with all and singular Offices, Liberties, Priviledges, Wages, Fees, Rewards, and all other Profits thereto belonging, for the like Term or Number of Years; and also to have and take all Beasts and Animals attached or taken within the said Forest or Chace by any of the Foresters

S s there,

158 24° Februarii 1790.

there, and all Manner of Wood blown or thrown Je down by the Wind, and all -dead Wood, and the; Boughs and Branches of Trees and Wood within the said Forest cut or thrown , and House Bote or Fire Bote for themselves and the Foresters and Keepers aforesaid; and several other Priviledges were also granted by the said Letters to the said Earl of

Dartmouth, Sir William Baggot, Charles and

John Bailer; and they did by the said Letters Patent covenant, promise, and agree, at their own proper Costs and Charges, well and sufficiently to repair, amend, support, uphold, and maintain all and singular the Lodges, Fences, and Inclosures of and belonging to the Premises, by and with all and all Manner of needful and necessary Reparations and Amendments whatsoever; and also covenanted that they would from Time to Time, and at all Times thereafter during the said Term thereby granted, discharge, save harmless, and indemnify His Majesty, His Heirs, and Successors, of and from the Payment of all and every the Salaries, Stipends, or Wages which should or might become due or payable to any of the Foresters, Keepers, and Officers of the said Forest or Chace, during the Term granted by the said Letters Patent; and also that they would preserve and keep the Deer and other Game within the said Forest and Chace, and all the Woods, Timber Trees, and other Trees growing in and upon the said Premises, from cutting, chopping, and Spoils, as will more fully appear by Reference to the said Letters Patent.

Upon a Search at the Auditor’s Office I find that in former Leases or Grants of the before-mentioned Offices, and particularly in one granted to John Mordaunt, Esquire, the ist of February, 15th Geo. lid. the Clause similar to that under which Lady Hillsborough founds her Claim to the Lop3 and Tops of all Timber cut down in the said Forest, is worded so as to admit of a different Construction, and is as follows; viz*. " All and all Manner of Wood thrown down " by the Wind, and all dead Wood, and the Boughs " and Branches of Trees and Woods within the said " Forest cut off or thrown down, and House Bote and " Fire Bote,"&c.

I therefore submit to your Lordships Judgment, whether the Clause in the Grant to Mr. may

or may not be construed to extend to the Boughs and Branches of Trees and Woods casually cut off or thrown down, and not to the Branches of all Timber cut for the Use of His Majesty. If your Lordships should be of Opinion that this Construction ought to be put upon that Clause, I then submit to your Consideration, whether the different wording of the Two Grants may not have escaped the Notice of the Officers of the Crown at the Time of passing the last Grant. It is however necessary to inform your Lordships, that at the Time I had the Honour to be appointed Surveyor General of His Majesty’s Woods and Forests, I understood that the Lieutenant or Keeper of the said Forest was entitled to the Boughs and Branches of all Timber Trees cut down in the said Forest; and I therefore did, for the Reasons mentioned in her Ladyship’s Mepiorial, as I found my Predecessors had done, agree that the Whole of the Timber cut down in the said Forest should be sold, and that the Lieutenant should be paid One-fifth of the Amount of the Sales of the Whole, in lieu of the Boughs and Branches; and all the Timber cut in the said Forest to the Year 1776 has been sold by Auction, and a Fifth Part paid to the Lieutenant of the said Forest accordingly.

In the said Year 1776 Application was made to your Lordships for a Fall of 300 Loads of Oak Timber for the Use of His Majesty’s Navy, which I waa of Opinion might be supplied from the said Forest; and your Lordships were pleased, in pursuance of His Majesty’s Royal Sign Manual, to issue a War-

rant, dated the 19th Day of July 1776, directing 300 Loads of Oak Timber to be cut in the said Forest,-and delivered for the Use of His Majesty’s Navy at the usual Price of Timber supplied from the New Forest; that is to say, 1/. 18#. per Load. This Warrant was issued so late in the Year 1776, that to avoid the Loss of the Profits of the Bark, the Execution thereof was deferred till the Year 1777, when 321 Loads and 30 Feet of Timber were delivered to the Purveyor of the Navy, and a Bill made out to me for the same at the Price before-mentioned.

As to the 42 Loads and 40 Feet of Timber, mentioned in the annexed Memorial to be delivered to Mr. Mills at the Price of 1/. 18*. per Load, it was done without my Knowledge, and very much contrary to my Inclinations, for which Offence I have discharged my Deputy in the said Forest. All I could then do was to oblige Mr. Mills to pay me the full Market Price, at which, if the whole Quantity of the Timber had been sold, her Ladyship would certainly have been entitled to a larger Sum than I think myself justifiable in paying without particular Directions from your Lordships.

notwithstanding the Covenant in the Letters Patent, for the Lieutenant or Keeper of the said Forest to pay and indemnify the Crown against all Keepers and Officers Salaries within the said Forest, the Lieutenants or Keepers of the said Forest have for many Years past been paid the Sum of 130/. towards defraying the Expence of Under Keepers Salaries, and that Sum is now paid by me in pursuance of a Letter for that Purpose from Your Lordships Secretary, when the same comes in a Course of Payment, and I have Money in my Hands for that Purpose; and I have been informed that Lady Hillsborough is in Possession of a Warrant directing that Sum to be Annually paid out of Wood Sales; but her Ladyship has never thought proper to bring the said Warrant to be entered in my Office.

In pursuance of His Majesty’s Royal Sign Manual, your Lordships were pleased to issue a Warrant, dated the 2d of March 1778, for the Fall of 500 Loads of Timber in the said Forest for the Use of the Navy, which, in consequence of Lady Hillsborough's Memorials, now rests suspended; and the last of these Memorials having stated to your Lordships, that that Quantity could not be spared unless a great many very growing Trees were cut, I have, in Person, examined into the State of the Timber in the said Forest, and I find that 500 Loads of Oak Timber may with great Propriety be supplied from the said Forest; and, in order to avoid for the future all Occasions of Difference with the Lieutenants or Keepers of the said Forest, and to prevent like Delays in supplying the Navy with Timber therefrom, it has been agreed (subject to your Lordships Approbation) that for the future the Timber to be cut down in the said Forest be delivered for the Use of the Navy at the same Price that Timber is delivered from the New Forest, and that the Lops, Tops, and Bark, shall be sold by Two Persons, One whereof to be named by me, and the other by the said Lieutenant or Keeper, by Public Auction, to the best Advantage; and that Two Third Parts of the Net Produce thereof be paid to the said Lieutenant or Keeper, and the remaining Third Part to me, for the Use of the Crown, the same being, as nearly as can be computed, the Value of the Bark, to which the said Lieutenant or Keeper has no Right or Claim. This Agreement I humbly submit to your Lordships; and propose, if your Lordships approve thereof, that, agreeable to the Desire of the Navy Board, the said last mentioned Warrant, directing the Fall of 500 Loads, be put in Execution so soon as the Season of the Year shall permit

All which is humbly submitted, 8gc.

Notf 24, 1778. J. Pitt.

30 Geo. III. 24° .
