N" 17.

To the Right Honourable the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury.

The Memorial of the Right Honourable Lord Stawell, Lieutenant or Keeper of the Forest or Chase of Alice Halt and ,in the County of Southampton.

Sheweth,

That your Memorialist, on the 15th Day of April 1783, presented a Memorial to the then Lords Commissioners of the Treasury, stating,

That about Five or Six Years before, an Order was issued from the Treasury, empowering the Surveyor General of His Majesty's Woods to cut Three hundred Loads of Timber in the said Forest or Chase; under Colour whereof a much greater Quantity was cut, of which about Three hundred and Twenty Loads were sent for the Use of His Majesty’s Navy, and about Forty Loads were taken by Mr. a Contractor, at a very low Price.

That, in the succeeding Year, another Order was issued, to empower the Surveyor General to cut another large Quantity of Timber in the said Forest; but your Memorialist’s late Mother, the Countess of Hillsborough, the then Lieutenant or Keeper thereof, presented Two Memorials to the then Lords Commissioners of the Treasury (to which your Memorialist begged their Lordships to refer) in consequence of which the Execution of the last Order was suspended.

That Mr. Robert Briant, the Deputy Woodward of the Forest, attended by Mr. Slade, a Purveyor, and the before-named Mr. Mills, on the 3d and 4th Days of April 1783, went into the Forest; and Mr. Briant, by virtue of an Order supposed to have been then lately obtained from the Treasury, marked Three hundred and Thirty Oak Trees, which, in his Opinion, were sufficient to make up the Quantity of Loads directed by such Order to be cut: But Mr Millssaid he must have more; and with another Hammer, be (Mills) marked about One hundred and Eighty more Oak Trees, which your Memorialist presumed he had no Right to do.

That no Satisfaction was made to your Memorialist’s late Mother for her Right in the Trees so formerly cut, nor had any since her Death been made to your Memorialist for the same, neither had any Prosecution been commenced against certain Offenders mentioned in the said Memorial.

That your Memorialist might be considerably injured, if the Three hundred and Thirty Trees, then marked by Mr. Briant, should be cut before the Offenders referred

to were tyied; and that the Public Revenue would be greatly injured, if the One hundred and Eighty Trees, so marked by Mr. Mills, were permitted to be cut, which jCfjr Memorialist was informed would be immediately done, unless the said Order should be countermanded or suspended.

And your Memorialist therefore prayed their Lordships would be pleased immediately to suspend the Execution of the Order, until their Lordships should have fully enquired into the Facts contained in that, as well as in his Mother’s Memorials.

Your Memorialist now begs Leave to state to your Lordships, that in consequence of his Memorial, the Lords of the Treasury immediately ordered a Stop to be put to the cutting of the One hundred and Eighty Trees, marked by Mr. Mills; and soon afterwards their Lordships also directed, that the Execution of the Order of the Three hundred Loads should be suspended; but before their Lordships Directions came to the Knowledge of Mr. Briant, the Deputy Woodward, almost all the Trees marked by him were cut.

That the People of Freruham, under their pretended Right, immediately took away not only the Stack Wood, but the whole of the Tops of the Trees that were cut, except a very small Part thereof, which Mr. Briant secured.

That your Memorialist, a few Days past, was informed by Mr. Briant, the Deputy Woodward, that he had an Order to cut One thousand Loads of Oak Timber in the said Forest, immediately.

That your Memorialist is informed, that the Value of the Tops of the Timber Trees now ordered to be cut, is about Six Shillings a Load; which would produce to your Memorialist about Three hundred Pounds, in case the pretended Right of the People of was

tried and set aside; but if the One thousand Loads are to be immediately cut, the Whole of the Tops will be carried away by the People of Frensham, to the great Loss of your Memorialist.

That no Magistrate will interfere to prevent their taking it away, as they claim it as a Right; and that no pecuniary Satisfaction can be recovered from them, as they are all very poor.

That your Memorialist conceives the Crown ought to try the Validity of the pretended Right of the People of Frensham; nevertheless, if the Crown does not chuse to do it, your Memorialist, rather than suffer what he conceives (during the Continuance of his Grant) to be his absolute Property to be thus taken from him without a legal Decision, oners to try the Right in the Course of this present Year, as he has no other Wish to procrastinate the cutting the Timber, than to assert his Right to the Tops thereof in a legal Manner.

Your Memorialist therefore prays your Lordships will be pleased immediately to suspend the Execution of the Order for cutting the One thousand Loads of Timber, until the pretended Rights of the People of Frensham shall be determined by a Court of Justice.

And your Memorialist shall pray, &c. January 14th, 1784.

N# 18.

CASE.

Some Time ago several Parcels of Timber were cut down in His Majesty’s Forest of Holt otherwise Alice-holt, in Hants, by Order of His Majesty’s Surveyor of the Woods; and the Wood cut therefrom was sold by Order of the Surveyor for His Majesty’s Use; but before the same was carried away by the Purchasers, several poor Persons living in the neighbouring Parishes to the Forest pretended to have a Right to the Wood, and took Part of it, and carried it away. Application was made to some Justices of the Peace, in order to have the Offenders punished; but as the Persons claimed and insisted upon their Right to the Wood, the Justices declined acting against them, till the Right was determined; whereupon an Action was brought, in the Name of the Persons who bought the Wood, against One of the Offenders, which was tried last Assizes at Winchester, when a Verdict was given for the Plaintiffs.

notwithstanding which, upon more Timber being lately cut down, and the Wood cut therefrom sold Ity the King’s Officers, several of these poor People have como again into the Forest, and brought Carts with them, and carried away the Wood which was sold and corded up.'

Q. Whether the Justices of the Peace in the County may and ought not, upon Information made before them, issue their Warrants against these Offenders, and bind them over to the Assizes, or commk them

for

30 Gec>. III.

2'4° Febru

161

for Want of Sureties, as the Right has been already tried, and a Verdict obtained; or what other will be the most expeditious Method to punish these People, and put a Stop to their Practices ? .

I think the Justices of Peace for the County may and ought, on such Information* to issue out their Warrants, and bind them over, or commit them for Want of Sureties.

Ryder.

7 June 1742*

N* 19.

The Examination of Robert Deputy to the

Surveyor General of the Woods in Aticeholt and Woolmer Forest; taken on Oath, the Thirty-first.

Day of December 1789.

This Examinant has been about Fifteen Years Deputy to the Surveyor General in the Forest of Aticeholt and Woolmcr. He was appointed by John , Esquire, late Surveyor General. His Salary is Thirty Pounds a Year, paid by the Surveyor General; and he has no Fees or other Emoluments whatever. He understands his Duty to be to endeavour to protect the Wood and Timber; to discover Offenders, and to get them punished; to superintend the Felling and Delivery of the Trees for the Navy; and to execute all Warrants from the Treasury for Wood Sales, or any other Purpose, under the Orders of the Surveyor General. That as there are no Verderors or Regarders now in this Forest, he has little Assistance in the Protection of the Forest. When he detects any Offenders, he carries them before a Justice of the Peace, and endeavours to get them punished; and there is a Man now in Prison at his Instance, for an Offence done in the Forest. That when a Warrant is issued for a Fall of Navy Timber, it is sent to him by the Surveyor General: Sometimes a Purveyor of the Navy is sent to assist him in marking the Timber, and sometimes not; and one or more of the Keepers has always attended at his Desire, on marking the Timber; and he has commonly applied to a Justice of the Peace to be present at the marking, but no one ever attended till the marking of the Trees for the Fall of .500 Loads this Year, when, at his Request, Mr. Sewell, of Headley, attended; but no Purveyor was present on that Occasion, though required by the Warrant.

There have been Four Falls of Timber for the Navy since his Appointment (viz.); One of Three hundred Loads in 1777, One of Five hundred Loads in 1783, One of a Thousand Loads in 1784, and One of Five hundred Loads in this present Year 1789. Upon the first Two Falls the Timber for the Navy was squared and conveyed to the Dock Yard by Mr. Mills, a Contractor with the Navy Board. The Felling of the Timber was paid for, and the Tops and Cast Timber, and Bark, were sold by this Examinant, and accounted for to the Surveyor General; but the Offal Wood, after being cut for Sale, was stolen by the Country People, and carried off into Abbot's Wood, where Carts and Waggons came and carried it away publicly. The Fall of One thousand Loads was Winter-felled, and upon that Occasion the Navy Board agreed with this Examinant for felling, squaring, and superintending the Delivery of it at the Dock Yard, at Three Shillings and Five Pence per Load, exclusive of the Carriage, which was paid for by the Navy Board. The Tops, Lops, and all the Timber of this Fall, unfit for the Navy, was taken by Lord of which this Examinant gave Notice to the Surveyor General, but does not know what was done in Consequence thereof. On the Three Falls above-mentioned, the Tops and Parts unfit for the Navy were rased off Vot. 45.

by this Examinarft. On the last Fall Mr. Slade, a Sixth Purveyor from Deptford Yard, attended for that Pur- Lan^ heveno* pose, and the Timber was hewed, add conveyed to the , L»

Dock Yard, under his Direction. The Tops and Cast Timber, rejected as unfit for the Navy, were sold by Auction, and the Offal Wood cut for Sale by this Examinant, by Order of the Surveyor General, and Notice given of a Day of Sale; but before that Time arrived the neighbouring Inhabitants came with their Teams, and in One Day and Night carried off the Whole, being Six thousand Three hundred and Sixty-five Faggots. This Examinant detected Two of the Offenders loading a Waggon, and warned them to desist; but they refused, saying the y would have some as well as their Neighbours. . He afterwards got a Warrant from a Magistrate for apprehending them, and delivered it to William Harding, Tything Man of Frensham, who has never executed it, though the Examinant has often pressed him to do it, and offered the Assistance of himself, and his Labourers; and nothing has been done in it since, except that he has informed the Surveyor General thereof, who told him that he should lay the Matter before the Attorney General.

This Examinant was absent from the Forest onf other Business, when the Country People began carrying away the Wood; and when he returned it was almost all carried off. On his speaking of it to the Keepers, and asking whose Teams had been employed in taking it away, they declared they knew nothing of it, and he could get no Information from them against the Offenders: But this Examinant has observed that when any Timber is felled by Lord Order, no

Attempt is made by the Country People to steal the Offal Wood, and that hardly a Faggot is ever missing.

There was a much greater Quantity of Timber growing in the Forest when he first knew it, about Forty Years ago, than there is now: The Trees were not then near so much lopped as they now are; there were k great Number of Bushes, and a great many young Trees nursed up and protected by them. It has been falling off every Year since. There are now few Bushes remaining, and hardly any young Trees are suffered to get up. The Bushes which the Inhabitants used to take for Fuel being gone, they now lop the Trees,

.by which many have of late suffered; and they dig up the Roots of the Trees cut, which effectually prevents any young Growth. He believes there have been no Verderors or Regarders chosen for this Forest since he was appointed, and no Courts have been held. A great deal of Timber has been cut for the Use of the Lieutenant, without View or Warrant, under Pretence of Fuel and Repairs; and in One Year a large Opening was made in the Wood, opposite to the Front of the Great Lodge, quite through the Forest, to the North, to give a View of the Country, and the Timber felled to make that Opening was taken by the Lieutenant to his own Use; and this Examinant saw a great Pile of that Timber in the Yard of a Carpenter at Famham, who then did the Work at the Great Lodge.

Of this he also gave Notice at that Time to the Surveyor , Genera], but no Notice was taken of it, that he knows of.

By far the greatest Past of the Timber in this Forest appears to the Examinant to be nearly of the same Age, and of not less than One hundred Years Growth.

The chief Part of that Timber is past improving and a great deal of it in a decaying State. A great many Trees, he thinks about Twenty thousand, were lately marked by him, by cutting off a Square Piece of the Bark, and marking the Number of the Tree,' the Name of the Forest, and the Figure of a Crown on the Timber, with Iron Stamps. This he did in Obedience to Orders, after stating his Objections to the Mode. Another Method of marking was afterwards adopted, by shaving off the Rough Surface only of the Bark, and stamping Marks ana Numbers1

T t on

24° Febru*

1790.

Sixth on it with the same Irons. But he admits, that he Lan<i Revenue would prefer the marking with Paint to either of those . KeP°rn „ Methods; being, in his Opinion, safer than the first, and more durable than the last mentioned. But the Object of marking and registering the Trees in this Forest is defeated by the Steps taken by Lord who felled last Year, for his own Use, more than Two hundred Beech Trees for Foel, and since, more than Fifty Oak Trees, of those which had been marked and registered by the Direction of the Surveyor General, without the View or Assignment of this Examinant, or of any other Person on Behalf of the Crown.

If any Inclosures are to be made in the Forest for the Growth of Timber, he thinks that the Pruts to be inclosed should, in the first Place, be almost entirely cleared of the Trees now growing the re, leaving only a few, Ten or Twelve, of the young and most thriving on every Acre; he would then recommend ploughing the Ground before sowing the Aoorns, and along with the Acorns be would sow Hips, Haws, and Holly Berries, which would grow up and protect the young Oaks. In selling the Trees now growing, he thinks it would be right to sell those fit for the Navy, as well as the rest: There will, in consequence of that, be more Bidders, and the Navy Board may buy such of the Timber as is fit for the Use of the Navy again from the Merchant He thinks that Two thousand Loads might be sold Annually, without overloading the Demand, or depressing the Price: And, referring to his Survey of the Timber in this Forest, in 1783, he is of Opinion, that the Trees there stated as of a Size fit for the Navy, would probably sell for about Four Pounds Two Shillings and Six Pence per Load; those front Five to Thirty Feet Metings at Two Pounds and Ten Shillings Load; the S for era and Saplings at about One Pound and Ten Shillings per Lend; and the scrubbed and dotard Trees also at about One Pound and Tea Shitting; per Load. The Beech he thinks worth about One Pound and Five ShiUiogs per Load; the Ash, One Pound and Ton Shillings; the EJm, Two Pounds One Shilling and Four Pence; nod the Fir, about One Pound ana Five $hidingg per Load, all Girt Measure: But he Blinks, that owing to the Falls made since 1783, for the Navy, being Fifteen hundred Loads, Girt Measure, «pd at least Three hundred Loads for Lord the Damage done to the Forest by lopping, and the little Improvement which the growing Trees have made, the Quantity first-mentioned, as of a Size for the Navy, is considerably decreased, and that there is now, of Trees of that Size, about Eleven hundred Loads less than the Quantity stated in that Survey. Ho thinks the Soil of the uninclosed Part of A lice holt, if the Trees were removed, would be worth about Ten Shillings' per Acre; the Inclosures near the Great Madge worth about Fifteen Shdfings per Acre, besides the Garden; the Inclosures of Old Close Lodge, about Fiftem Shillings also per Acre; those at Goose Green Ledge worth Thirty Shillings per Acre. The Soil in the Part of the Forest called he thinks worth

Foar Shillings per Acre; and he thinks that a considerable Part, perhaps a Thousand Acres, of would produce good Oak Timber, as he observes that there is Oak Timber growing on the Estates round it, on Soils which appear to be of the same Nature; and that the Soil of Oak Hill, and of the Land about

borough Lodge, in fVoalner Forest, where there is some good Oak Timber now growing, appears to be very poor Laud on the Surface; from which he concludes, that there must be a better Soil below it to nourish the Oaks. And he thinks that the greatest Part of the r#st of Woolmer, except the Bogs or Mosses, would produce good Firs. The inclosed Land at Bourn Lodge he thinks worth about Seven Shillings per Acre; hut be is not so well acquainted with the Nature of the Soil nt Linchborough Lodge as to be able to set a

Value upon it He thinks the new Inclosures should be fenced with a good Bank, and Post and Rail, which might be done at little Expence, from the Refuse of the Timber. The medium Distance from Alice Holt to Godalming, where the Timber is shipped, is about Ten Miles; and from fVoolmer to Godalming, about Eleven Miles. The Expence of Land Carriage from Alice Holt is at present Thirteen Shillings per Load: But a Canal is now cutting from Basingstoke to the River Wye, which may, perhaps, come within a less Distance of the Forest than Ten Miles.

(Signed) Rob, Briant.

N* 20.

The Examination of John Adams, of Headley, in the County of Southampton, heretofore One of the Keepers of fVoolmer Forest; taken on Oath, this Seventh Day of January 1790.

This Examinant saith, That he is now of the Age of 76 Years or thereabouts, was born at Linchborough Lodge, in fVoolmer Forest, his Father, who was also bora there, being then Keeper of Linchborough Walk, as his Grandfather and Great Grandfather also were. That upon his Father’s Death, about 46 Years ago, he was appointed Keeper of the said Walk, by the Honourable Ruperta How, then Ranger of the said Forest, but was removed about Five or Six Years afterwards by

..... Mordaunt, Esquire, then Ranger: That he

was afterwards appointed Keeper of Borden Lodge in Woolmer Forest, by Henry Legge, Esquire, who succeeded Mr. Mordaunt as Ranger, and continued Keeper of that Lodge about Four Years, when he was again removed, at the Instance, as he believes, of one Henry Hoult, then Head Keeper and Steward to Mr. Legge, to make Room for his Son-in-Law Henry,

the present Keeper there. That himself and his Father were allowed by Lady How, a Salary of 30/. a Year, and they had the Occupation of the Lodge and inclosed Lands about it, then worth about Five or Six Pounds a Year, and now in his Opinion worth about 20/. a Year, having been improved by his Father and himself; that they received Fees for such Deer as were then killed in Woolmer Forest, which were about a Brace or a Brace and a Half of Stags, one Year with another; they also received One Shilling a Thousand for Peat, besides Eighteen Pence a Load for cutting; and Eighteen Pence a Thousand for Turves, and Eighteen Pence for cutting; and Five Shillings a Kiln (containing about. Five or Six Loads) for Heath, or One Shilling per Load by the single Load: That the said Salary of 30/. a Year was first discontinued by Mr. Mordaunt, who allowed the Keepers of Woolmer oDly what they could make out of the Forest, by the Sale of Peat, Turf, and Heath; but no Persons living out of the Perambulation of the Forest were allowed to purchase any Peat, Turf, or Heath, the Regarders not suffering the Keepers to dispose of any, except to those who had Right of Common. That at the Time this Examinant was appointed Keeper, there were about 50 Head of Red Deer, and no Fallow Deer in Woolmer; that between the Time of his Removal from Linchborough Lodge, and Appointment to Borden Lodge, the King’s Hounds were brought into the Forest to hunt the Red Deer, and such as. were caught alive were carried to Windsor, many were driven out into the Country and destroyed, and the Remainder of the Stock, being about Two or Three Brace, were

given by Mr. Legg to.....Bonham, Esquire, of

Fetersfield.

That this Examinant has heard his Father say, that in his Time a Swanimote Court was held Once a Year for the said Forest, and other Courts more frequently, and that there were Verderors and Regarders regularly

chosen;

24° Februariu

163

chosen; and this Examinant himself remembers at one Time Four Regard ers, namely, Mr. Jeffery of Bonham, near Binsted, and his Brother, Mr. Jeffery of

Issington Mill, Mr. Lee of Headley , and Mr.* Ed-

xpaker of Neatham, all of whom used to attend with the Keepers when any 'limber was assigned to be cut for Repairs, or Wood for Fuel; and this Examinant has often been with them on such Occasions. That the Quantity of Fuel Wood then allowed was, as he believes, ao Cords Yearly for the Great Lodge, and to Cords for each of the other Lodges; and that when any Repairs were to be done, a Survey was firet made by the King’s Officers, to know what Quantity was wanted, before; the Timber was assigned.

That be has often heard his Father say that the Commoners used to give an Account to the Keepers of the Cattle they turned into the Forest; and that each Man’s Cattle used to be marked with an Ear Mark, and the Whole with a general Brand Mark, called The Forest Brand, to distinguish them from the Cattle of Strangers; and that the Forest used to be driven at that Time, to clear it of Cattle during the Fence Monti); and he has in his Possession a Paper, dated the 2d June 1727, being a Notice from George Vernon, Senior, Esquire, and C Vernon, Knt. appointing Monday the 5th of the same Month to drive the Forest, and requiring the Regarders, Keepers, Reeves, and other Officers of the said Forest, to give their Assistance therein; which Paper came to this Examinant among various other Papers belonging to his Father (then Keeper as aforesaid:) — Which Paper is produced by him at the Time of his Examination, and left with the Commissioners of the Land Revenue.

That this Examinant also remembers the Forest being driven in the Fence Month Once white be was Keeper, at which Time all the Cattle ware impounded in the Forest Pound in Woelmer. That one Counsellor Guidot., who, as he believe*, was then Steward of the Forest Courts, attended at the said Driving, together with an Attorney from Alton, to swear the Claimants to their own Cattle; and that such Cattle as belonged to Commoners were let out of the Pound, an paying ^d.a Head, called a Fee for the Pound Lock; and such Owners as had not Right of Common in the Forest were fined, some 5 and 6ome fit. fid. a Head each lor their Cattle then found treepassing in the Forest; but some refused to pay any Thing, or to redeem their Cattle, and suffered them to remain in the Pound until they broke out, or were let out, without any Thing being paid for them; and the Forest has not been driven, a6 he believes, for Horned Cattle, since that Time, but Sheep have been pounded many Times since.

That the Owners of several Estates near the Forest used formerly to pay Rents, in Money and in Com, to the Ranger of the Forest. He cannot specify the particular Estates, or the Quantities of Com; but he has in his Possession a Receipt, signed Wm Legge, dated 7th N<nf 1675, for 12 Bushels of Oats, expressed to be for Six Years, at Two Bnshete a Year, payable by his Grandfather John Adame, then Keeper of Linobbo-rough Walk, for Land in Kingsley, then belonging to

him. That he remembers, when a Boy, hie Father collecting several Bushels of Rent Oats, and currying them to the Great Lodge’, but that no such Com Rents have been paid, as he believes, for many Years past.

That this Examinant well remembers, when the Quantity of Bushes, Underwood, and Fern, was so great in almost every Part of The Holt, that it was impossible to ride through them. That he has often assisted the Keepers of The in looking for owt-lying Deer which they wanted to kill, and which Deer, after being driven back to The Holt, have lain concealed in the thick Covers there;- and that this Exwnmafrt has . Vol. 45.

sometimes sought for them, and beat thp Covers Four Sixth or Five Days together before they could be found. Land itevaouS That the Bushes in general were very high and strong; . RePort- „ and he remembers that, when one Thomas Grover was once employed by his Father, to cut a Load of Bushes to repair the Fences of the Ground about Lodge, the said Grover cut off a Cord of Wood from the Bottoms of the Bushes for his own Usfe; and that what remained afterwards were as long as the whole Length of the Waggon. That there were at that Time a great many young Trees nursed up and protected by the Bushes and Underwood; and that very few Bushes were then cut in the and none

whatever in The Holt, without Leave erf the Keepers; and he has heard, that the People used to pay the Keepers One Shilling a Load, until a Dispute happened between One of the Keepers of The Holt and one Mr. Hammond of Kingsley, who, as he has heard, refused to pay the Keeper’s Demand of One Shilling a Load for Bushes cut in the Straytes; which Dispute was followed by a Trial at Law, in which Mr. Ham* mond prevailed against the Keeper. That he well remembers hearing of the said Trial while he lived at Linehborough Lodge, but cannot tell exactly how many Years ago. That after the said Trial, the Bushes in the Straytes were cut more frequently, and in greater*

Quantities than before; and at length came to be cut by all the Country People thereabouts, without any Interruption from the Keepers, and without paying any Thing for the same; but no Bushes were cut in The Halt until those in the Straytes were almost all destroyed, when the Bushes iu The Holt were suffered to be cut in like Manner, in consequence of which there are now ao few Bushes, and what remain stand so thin, that they do not afford the least Shelter or Protection to the young Shoots, nor have done for many Years past, and there is now little or no young Timber growing the re.

That there are Three Tracts of Waste Ground lying on the Borders of Woolmer, adjoining to the Manors of Mill Land, Southay, and Oakhanger, otherwise Chapel Manor, and claimed as belonging to those Manors.

As to the First, this Examinant says, that the Bounds Of the Forest next Mill Land Manor were always reputed to be as they are described in the old Perambulation of the Forest, made in the Year 1635; vix. from the Highway leading to Medhurst along by the Fen Path to Old Thorn, and so to ford. That the Bounds were trodden publicly, acJ cording to the said Perambulation, by this Examinant as Keeper, and by many of the neighbouring Inhabitants, by Order of Mr. Legge, then Ranger, after a Week’s previous Notice given to Sir Thomas Ridge, then Lord of the said Manor. That this Examinant; diming all die Time that he was Keeper there, and his Father also, as he well remembers, cut Turf and Heath on the Land so claimed for the Use of the Commoners, and dug Stones there, and sold the same to various Persons, particularly some to Sir Thomas Ridge, then Lord of Mill Land Manor, and to Mr.

Jottiffe of Peter afield, and was paid for them at the same Rates as for Turf and Stones in other Parts of the Forest. That several Years after the Death of Mr. Legge, and after this Examinant was removed from the Office of Keeper, Mr. Richardson, then Lord of Mill Land Manor, cut the greatest Part of the Timber growing on that Land, and sold the same, and since that Time the Lords of Mill Land Manor have claimed an exclusive Right to that Land, mid the Keeper from that Time ceased to cut Turf or dig Stones there,' as before.

As to the Waste Land claimed as lying within Southay Manor, this Examinant says, That when he was first appointed Keeper, and long before, one Mr.

Heroey was Lord of that Minor; that Mr. Legge

purchased

24° Februarii.

A. 1790.

Sixth purchased the Same sbrfte Years before his Death; and That this Examinartt well knows the Wood called Land Revenue that Lord Stawell is the present Lord of that Manor. in the Parish of within the

"V RePort‘ That this Examinant's Father, as Keeper of Linc Perambulation of the Forest, and remembers going with borough Walk, as far back as this Examinant can re- his Father, and afterwards when himself was Keeper, member, and himself also during all the Time that during the Fence Month, to look after the Hinds, he was Keeper, always cut Peat and Turf on that which used frequently to Calve there, the Wood be-Land for the Use of the Commoners at the usual ' "

Prices, quite up to the Hedge of Blackmore Estate,

which Hedge is the Boundary of that Part of the Forest, and that no Person ever interrupted them, or ever attempted to take any without paying the Keep-

ing then very full of Timber and Btrong Underwood, affording Shelter and Protection to the Deer and their Young. That at that Time the Wood lay open for the Deer, and for all Cattle commoning on the Forest, to depasture there, and so continued during

ers for the same, during the Life-Time of Mr. Hervey, all his Remembrance, until about Twenty Years ago, or Mr. Legge, the former Lords, nor until after the when Sir Simeon Stuart ordered Gates to be set up in Death of Mr. George Wakeford, late Owner of Black- the Lanes leading into Bins Wood from Short Heath moor Estate, near 20 Years ago, when Mr. Wm Wake- Common on the East Side, and from Green Street on ford, the present Possessor of Blackmoor, and other the North Side, and excluded the Forest Cattle and Owners and Tenants of Estates within Southay Manor, all others, except those belonging to the Inhabitants took upon themselves to cut Peat and Turf there of Wordleham Parish. That Sir Simeon Stuart's Estate without paying for the same, and to prevent the Keeper from so doing; and upon treading the Bounds of Southay Manor have included that Part of the Forest as within the said Manor, to the Amount of about 160 Acres, without any Interruption from the Keeper.

As to the Part of the Forest claimed as belonging to Oaklianger or Chapel Manor, containing about Two hundred Acres, this Examinant says, That the true Boundary between the said Manor and the Forest is a small Stream of Water rising near the Corner of some new inclosed Lands belonging to Thomas Butler,

Esquire, in Temple Manor, and running down through the Peat Moor there into a Pond called Bins Pond, and through the Middle of that Pond, in which, as this

Examinant well remembers, there were formerly Two Term of Thirty-one Years. I receive a Rent of

there has lately been sold, and that this Examinant has heard that Lord Stawell is the Purchaser thereof.

(Signed) John Adams.

N* 21.

The Answer of Henry Lord Stawell, Lieutenant or Keeper of the Forest of Aliceholt and Woolmer, to the Precept of the Commissioners of the Land Revenue.

I hold the Office of Lieutenant or Keeper by Lease from the Crown, for the Remainder of a

Sluices, one of which, with One Half of the Pond, belonged to the Forest, and the other to the said Manor; and this Examinant remembers when he was a Boy going the Bounds of the said Manor, according to the Course above described, with the

Steward and Tenants of.....Wilcox, Esquire, then

Lord of that Manor, and Doctor Holmes, then Rector of Headley, who, it was reported, was about purchasing the said Manor, or taking a Mortgage thereof. That' when this Examinant was Keeper of Borden

31/. 2 11 issuing out of the Manors of East and

West Wordleham, in Hants, and 60/. for the Rent of Old Close Lodge, without Account, and no other Rent.

I appoint Five Keepers in Aliceholt and Woolmer, and pay all Wages and Salaries to the Keepers, and for punishing Offenders, and all Expences of repairing the Lodges. No Salary is granted by the Lease, but 130/. a Year by the King’s Warrant, paid by the Surveyor of His Majesty’s Woods. The casual Fees or Emoluments of my Office are Windfalls, Dead Lodge he used to cut Peat on that Land, and dispose Wood, Fire Boot, Lop and Top, Liberty of Fishing, of the same to the Commoners at the usual Prices, and Property of the Fish; the Average Yearly Value until the Tenants of the said Manor claimed a Right of which has been about Ninety or a Hundred Pounds to cut Peat there without paying for it, and prevented a Year, exclusive of the Lop and Top, which I have this Examinant from cutting any more there. That had but once, and then a great Part of it was taken this Examinant remembers hearing Mr. Legge say away by the People of the adjoining Parishes, as a (when the Inhabitants of Kingsley complained to him pretended Right. The Messuages and Lands in my of being prevented by his Tenants in Oakhanger from Possession are the Great Lodge House and Land, within having Peat from that Common where they had the Pale or Rail, containing about 142 Acres, oc-usually been supplied) that he had examined his Writ- cupied by myself, now of the Yearly Value of 100l.; ings, and did not find that ito belonged to his Manor, but about 11 o Acres, Part of it, were only Heath, till That for several Years past the Tenants of Oakhanger divided and improved by my late Father: Goose Green or Chapel Manor have discontinued cutting Peat on Lodge House, occupied by Keepers, and the Land that Moor, and none is now cut there, except for the within the Pale or Rail, containing about 43 Acres, Use of Lord Stawell'& Hot House at the Great Lodge, occupied by myself, of the Yearly Value of 50/.; But the Keeper of Borden Lodge cuts Turf there for Old Close Lodge House, re-built at my own Expence, Sale as in other Parts of his Walk, as this Examinant and the Land within the Pale or Rail, containing

used to do when he was first appointed Keeper of that Walk.

That there is another Piece of Waste Land, Part of the Forest, containing about 30 Acres, near a Place called Rackrcell, adjoining to the Manor of Lysse, and now claimed by the Lord of that Manor. That this Examinant and his Father, while Keepers, used to cut Turf on that Land for Sale, without Interruption

about 95 Acres, in the Occupation of the Widow of the late Thomas Bennett, at the Yearly Rent of 60/. No regular Quantity of Timber is cut in the Forest for the Navy or for Wood Sales, but from about too to 140 Cords of Beech Wood for Fuel for the Great Lodge, about 16 Cords for Goose Green Lodge, and about 16 Cords for Old Close Lodge, and a small Quantity of Oak Timber for Cart Boot; of which, and of Timber

from any Person, and he never heard of its being for Repairs, the Ranger takes what he wants at his claimed as belonging to Lysse Manor until after the own Discretion. No Venison Warrants are served, Death of Charles Cole, Esquire, late Lord of that because there were scarce any Deer in the Forest when Manor, about Seven or Eight Years ago, when the my Father purchased it. He bought a great many Tenants of Lysse going their Bounds included that Head of Deer, and stocked it. The Number killed. Piece of Land within their Circuit, as belonging to on an Average of the last Ten Years, is Nine Brace Lysse Manor. of Bucks, and Five Brace and a Half of Does. No

v Hay

Hay or Com is purchased for the Deer. Several small Encroachments have been made, and much Spoil by the People adjoining, Notice of some of which has been sent to the Surveyor General’s Deputies.

No Verderors, Regarders, or Steward, have been appointed, or Courts held for this Forest in my Memory. No Court Rolls, or Records of Proceedings of Courts held for the Forest at any Time past, are in my Custody. The People of particular Parishes claim, and, I believe, have a Right of cutting Bushes in the Forest. The Parishes or Places which have Right of Common are Bramshot, Liss, Greatham, Part of Selbome, Part of Headley, Dockenfield, Binsted, and Kingsley in Hants. There are no Fences against Farnham Common, so that the Commons are intermixed. All Kinds of Cattle are admitted but Sheep; at all Times there is a Howherd, but not sworn. Pigs found not ringed are pounded. The Forest has never been cleared of Cattle in the Fence Month or Winter Haining, or driven, in my Memory. The Deer and Commonable Cattle depasture on the Commons of Dockenfield and Farnham Manors, adjoining the Holt Forest, and on the Commons of Passfield, Stanford, Mill Land, Oakhanger, Blackmore, Broxhead, Linford Chace, Mill Chace, Priors Luce, Greatham, and Kingsley, adjoining to Woolmer. The Deer do not depasture on the inclosed Lands within the Perambulation. There are no Purlieus belonging to the Forest. None of the Crown Lands in the Forest are extra-parochial. The Lodges in The Holt pay Land Tax and all Parochial Dues to Binsted Parish, but those in Woolmer pay no Taxes. The Forest not being driven, it is probable that Cattle belonging to Persons not having Right of Common depasture in the Forest No Payments are made to me, or the Keepers in The Holt, for feeding of Cattle or Swine, or cutting Peat or Turf in the Forest ;but Payments are made to the Keepers of Woolmer, of which Accounts are sent herewith. There have not been any Lands inclosed from the Forest, for the Use of the Lieutenant or Keepers, since the Appointment of any of the present Keepers; nor any Licences granted for inclosing Waste Lands belonging to the Forest; nor any Fines, Rents, or other Payments received for any such Inclosures, within Ten Years last past. I keep no Cattle in the Forest in Right of my Office, but I occasionally do turn out Cattle in Right of Freehold Lands in my own Occupation, which have a Right of Common. The Keepers in The Holt do not turn out any. The Keepers in Woolmer have Horses and Cows that they keep in the inclosed Lands, and occasionally in the Forest. Arnett has,' on an Average, Two Mares and Two Colts; and White, Four Cows, Three Horses, and Four Colts.

Stawell.

Jan. 7, 1790.

The Examination of William Moore, Keeper of Browse for the Deer, and the Wood after browsing is Alice Holt Forest; taken on Oath, the First Day cut up for Fuel, and sold for the benefit of the Keeper, of February 1790. as before-mentioned. There have not been any Courts

held, or Verderors or Reorders chosen for this Forest,

This Examinant has been employed in Alice Holt since he has known it. No Inclosures have been made Forest about 31 Years. He was first appointed Ser- there for raising Timber, nor has he ever heard that vant to Mr. Carter, the late Keeper, and so continued there were any. his Pleasure. Year, and he keeps One Horse (on Land rented by him but that this Prohibition was not strictly enforced, out of the Forest) and about Two Couple of Hounds Says, that the Forest is frequently driven in Pannage at his own Expence, which together cost him on an Time, to see that the Hogs are duly ringed, and if any Average about Twenty-four Pounds a Year. In regard are found unringed, the Howherd rings them, and takes to the Stock of Deer in the Forest, he has heard, that Four Pence each from the Owners for all that are un-when the late Mr. Legge first became Lieutenant, there ringed. Sheep are also impounded when any are found were not more than Seven 'or Eight Deer there in the in the Forest, which seldom happens, and a Penalty of Whole; and that he bought a great many Deer, and Four Pence a Head imposed on the Owners, which is increased the Stock so much, that there were at One received by the Howherd for his own Use. He does Time near Fifteen hundred Head. The Number of not remember the Forest being driven for Horned Deer has been as low as about Three hundred since Cattle, but about Fifteen Years ago the People of this Examinant has been in the Forest, but is now about Binsted and the Keepers drove the Forest for Horses;

Eight hundred in the Whole. Lieutenant or Keepers since he has known it, nor any Licences or Permissions given by them, that he has heard of, to inclose Lands there, or Fines or Rents paid to them for Encroachments on the- Forest and as to such Encroachments as have been made there since he has known the Forest, be has given the best Account he can of them in a Paper signed by him, and hereto annexed.

ACCOUNT of Encroachments on the Forest of Alieeholt, referred to in the Examination of Head Keeper of the said Forest;, taken on Oath die First Day of February 1790.

John Falkner, at Holt Pound -

James Collins, at Row ledge Bask

the other m a Field near it, next the Bounds of the County of Surrey, taken hr about Seven or Eight Years,

N# 27.

The Examination of Hairy Him, one of the Keepers of Abedhalt Foresttaken, on Oath, the 15th Day of January 1790.

This Examinant was appointed Keeper of Old Close Walk,in Aliccholt Forest, about Two Years ago, by the Right honourable Lord during his Plea-

sure. His Salary is Twenty Pounds a Year, and he receives no Fees or Perquisites of any Kind, besides his Salary. He occupies Part of the House called Goose Green ledge, with a small Garden, but no other Lands, and he keeps no Cattle on the Forest The other Part of Goose Green Lodge is occupied by Richard Whorsrd, Game Keeper of Lord s Manors

near the Forest. The inclosed Lands adjoining to that Lodge are in Lord Stawe own Hands; and the Lodge called Old Close Lodge, and the Lands belonging to it are rented as a Farm by William Bennett. He considers it his Duty to take Care of the Deer, and of the Wood and Timber iu that Part of the Forest. When he detects any Persons cutting or lopping Trees in the Forest be endeavours to prevent them, and to take away their Hatchets; and gives Information thereof, and of the Names of the Offenders, to William Moore, Head Keeper of the Forest, that he may acquaint Mr. Briant, the Deputy Surveyor, therewith; and he sometimes acquaints Mr. Briant himself, when he has an Opportunity. The Quantity of Wood cut for Fuel for Goose Green Lodge is about Fifteen Cords for himself, and the said Richard Whorard. He does not know what Timber or Wood is cut in the Forest for any other Purpose. He cannot tell the exact Number of Deer in the Forest, but believes there may be about Five or Six hundred of all Sorts. He does not know how many are killed Annually, having no Concern with the killing of the Deer, which is entirely under the Management of the Head Keeper. There is not any Hay or Com given to the Deer, but sometimes some Ash and Maple Boughs are ent for Browse for the Deer, in very severe Seasons, but this has happened only Once since his Appointment. There has not been any Encroachment made in Old Close Walk since be was appointed, except One, of a few Rods of Ground, by one Thomas Grocer, which was thrown out again by this Examinant.

(Signed) Henry How.

N* 38.

Hie Examination of Henry White, One of the Keepers in Woolmer taken on Oath,

this Thirteenth Day of December 1789.

This Examinant has been One of the Keepers in Woolmer Forest about Thirty-five Years. He was first appointed by the late Mr. Legge, Father of Lord Stawell, and has always resided in Bourn or Borden Lodge. — He understands that there is a Salary from Government intended for his Office, amounting to Three Pounds and Ten Pence a Year, but no Salary has ever been paid to this Examinant, nor has he any certain Fees, but is allowed to take whatever he can make of the Forest by the Disposal of Peat, Turf, Heath, or Fern cut within his Walk.- — That he is not restrained to any Quantity, nor confined to any particular Parts of the Walk, but may cut as much as be can dispose of in any Part of his Walk, and sell it to any Person whatever, without Distinction, whether living within or without the Perambulation, and without Regard to the Palish in which the Purchaser has his Residanoe. No Persons cut Peat, Vol. 45.

Turf, or Heath, but such as are employed by this Examinant, and the Buyer pays for Peat Twq Shillings per Load to the Labourer for cutting and drying it, and One Shilling per Load to the Keeper. The Load contains, he believes, more than a Thousand Peats, but they are not commonly numbered. For the Turf the Buyer pays One Shilling and Six Pence per Thousand to the Cutter or Labourer, and One Shilling to this Examinant, and the Labourer is paid Six Pence per Thousand more if lie sets up the Turves and dries them; and for Heath, the Labourer is paid Three Shillings per Load for cutting, and the Examinant receives One Shilling. — The Heath is commonly used in burning Lime; Six Loads burn a Kiln, and when he is paid by the Kilo, and not by the Load, he receives only Five Shillings for the Kiln. For the Fern he gets such Price as he can obtain from the Buyers, setting out a certain Quantity of Ground on which the Farmer or Buyer is allowed to cut the Fern, according to the Price agreed on. The Fern is used for littering Horses or Cattle, and the Peat and Turves for Fuel. No Coal is burnt except in Gentlemen’s Houses, and Wood is become scarce and dear, so that the Turf and Peat are the most common Fuel. There are other Parts in the Neighbourhood in which Turves are got, but they are not so good as those in Woolmer, the Soil being inferior, and more sandy. His Profit from the Disposal of all those Articles, Peat, Turf, Heath, and Fern, is, one Year with another, to the best of his Belief, about Forty Pounds a Year. In the Mosses, Roots and Stems of Trees are often dug up, some of which are Oak, and others Fir, but none of great Size. The Soil on the Hills in the Forest is generally sandy, some white, some black, and some red, all poor, but he thinks the red is the best, and the black the woret A Plantation of Scotch Fir was made by Mr. Legge about Twenty or Five-and-Twenty Years ago, of about Two or Three Acres. Some of the Soil is of the red and some of the black Kind, and the Trees on the red thrive much better than the rest Some of those Firs are now about One Foot diameter, and very thriving. The low Grounds are generally mossy, producing Heath and coarse Grass; Peat is got in the greatest Part There were formerly some Red Deer in Woolmer Forest, but there are none now; formerly, as he has been told, Cattle were turned out of the Forest, particularly Milch Cows and Shoed Horses, during the Fence Month, and the Forest was then driven, but no Attention has been paid to that within his Time. All Kinds of Cattle are now admitted, Sheep only excepted, and at every Season; the Forest is never driven. Formerly Cattle put into the Forest by those who had no Right of Common were pounded; but that has also been discontinued, and the Cattle of Strangers are admitted without Challenge. No Fine or Fee is paid for depasturing Catde. Some Rents in Oats, as he has been informed by his Wife’s Father, Henry Holt, who was Keeper in Holt Forest in Lady H<m'% Time, were formerly paid, hut he has never received any Oats, nor any Rent of any Kind; but there are Three Persons, Edward Al-berry, James Farr, and John Chuarlon, who possess Cottages, with small Pieces of Land adjoining to their Houses, and within the Forest, who pay small Quit Rents to Lord Stawell — the First a Pepper Com, the Second Four Pence, and the last he does not exactly know the Rent The Land, in all of these Parts together, may be about Thirteen Acres, and they are said to hove been granted to them for assisting the Keepers when there were Deer in the Forest. The Examinant possesses a House, called Borden Lodge, with about Ten Acres of Land within the Rails, worth together about Four Pounds a Year, the Land being of a poor Quality. He keeps generally Seven Horses, Four of winch are Foresters, which go" always in the

Forest;

Sixth Land Revenue? Report.

V"’ " ">r

172 24° FebruariuA. 1790.

Sixth Forest; Three Cows, which go in the Forest all Day, Land Revenue and are put into the House at Night; and generally Report. Two pjg9 or Swine. There have been no Encroach-' ments in his Walk since he has been Keeper, except that Alberry above-mentioned, in making his Hedge straight, took in a few Rods. No Courts of Attachment or Swanimote have been held, nor are there now any Verderors or Regarders, though he remembers, when he was first appointed, there were Two Regarders, the one Mr. and the other Mr.

Jefferey, of Bonham; and he remembers to have been sent by his Father-in-Law to call upon them, to attend in Holt Forest, in order to mark Beech Wood for Fuel for the Great Lodge; and has heard, that they always did attend when any Wood was to be marked for that Purpose. Believes that the Places which have Right of Common in Forest are the

Parish of Kingsley, and Oakhanger, which is Part of the Parish of Selbourtie, and Farm, belonging to

John Baker of Hadley, which is in the Tything either of Kingsley or Oakhanger, and is a Purlieu; he knows no other Purlieu. Stream Farm has also Right of Common, and Moor House Farm and Hopperie, and a small Farm called Haine's and Becil's Farm, all in the Tything of Kingsley; he knows of no other out of the Perambulation which have Right of Common; but on all Open Grounds within the Forest the Deer and Commoners Cattle of the Forest are admitted, and all Estates within the Perambulation have Right of Common in the Forest, which is called Intercommoning. There are very few Oak Trees now in his Walk; one grows at a Place called Dead Water, and is called Grover's Oak, where a Forest Court is said formerly to have been held. There is a Part of the Common near Bins Pond, on the West Side of his Walk, claimed as belonging to Chapel Manor, which Manor, when he was first appointed Keeper, belonged to the late Mr. Legge, who had bought it about Three or Four Years before of one Mr. Chaffinch, a» he believes; and he remembers hearing Mr. Legge say' to a Tenant of his, one John Lee of Chapel Farm, who desired to have that Land for a Sheep Common, that he should not have it, as he could not find by his Writings that it belonged to Chapel Manor; and added, that , he should certainly have been glad to find that it belonged to him, as he would rather have it for his own than be Ranger over it. This Examinant has heard that Bins Pond was the ancient Boundary between the Forest and Chapel Manor, and that there were formerly Two Sluices in that Pond, one of which was managed by the Forest Officers, and the other by the Owner of Chapel Manor; but this Examinant does not remember more than One Sluice there since he has been Keeper, which Sluice is wholly managed by the Lord or Tenants of Chapel Manor. Says, that Lord Slawell cuts Peat in that disputed Part for his own Use at the Great Lodge, but not for any other Use; and that this Examinant cuts Turf there for Sale, as in other Parts of the Forest, but not Peat; but he has been informed by one John Adams, who was Keeper of the same Walk before him, that in Mr. Mordaunt's Time (Mr. Legge's Predecessor) the Keepers cut Peat there for Sale, as well as Turf.

(Signed) Henry White.

N* 29.

The Examination of Darnel Arnett, One of the Keepers of Woolmer Forest', taken on Oath,the Thirtieth Day of December 1789.

This Examinant is Keeper of Linsberry, otherwise Lynchborough Lodge, in Woolmer Forest. He was appointed by Lord Starcell in February last, of the Death of his Father Darnel Arnett, who was Keeper , of the 07

same Lodge upwards of Twenty-two Years, during all which Time this Examinant lived with his Father at the Lodge, and for the greatest Part of it acted aa a Servant under him. He occupies the Lodge House, with about Eight Acres of Arable Land, Seven Acres of Meadow-, and about One hundred and Ten Acres of rough Forest Ground, all of a poor Soil,*and not worth more than Nine or Ten Pounds a Year. He usually keeps about Four Cow’s, and Two nr Three Pigs, for the Use of his Family, and a Mare and Colt upon the Forest, and no more. He receives no Salary, nor any Rents or other fixed Payments; and his only Profits arise from Peat, Turf, Heath, Fern, and Stones, of which he has the Liberty of selling as much as he can. The Average Amount of these Profits he believes to be about Fifty Pounds a Year at the most, out of which he pays Five Pounds a Year to an Assistant (one William who

lives in a small House called Woolmer Pond House, and for the Wages and Board of a Boy who lives with him about Thirteen or Fourteen Pounds a Year, and he keeps One Horse, which costs him abont Nine or Ten Pounds a Year. There are no Deer in Woolmer Forest, nor have been since he has known it; but there are several People in the Neighbourhood who remember when there was a considerable Number of Red Deer there. There have not been any Courts held for the Forest, nor Verderors or Regarders appointed, since he has been employed there. There is some Oak Timber growing on a Tract of Ground of about Fifty Acres, called Oak Hills (or Holly Hills) near his Lodge, and in the Fences of his inclosed Grounds, in Number about One hundred and Eifty or Two hundred Trees, whereof about Twelve or Fourteen are good Trees, meting at about a Load each, and in his Judgment are fit for the Use of the Navy. The rest are young Trees, and were in a thriving State, but have been very much hurt by cutting Pieces of Bark from the Sides, and stamping Marks and Numbers on the Bodies of the Trees, which was done by this Examinant, by Order of Mr. Briant, the Deputy Surveyor. There is no Timber or Wood on any other Part of his Walk, except some Hollies in a Place called Sheer and some Alders and Willows in a Place called Liss Moor, and a small Alder Bed near the Lodge, which the Keeper cuts for Firing and for making Fences; the rest of Woolmer Forest is a barren sandy Soil covered with Heath, Part of it consisting of a reddish Sand, Part a white Sand, and the rest a Kind of black Rock. The best of these, he thinks, is the red Sand, which may be about One Tenth Part of the Whole. There are some Plantations of Firs in Henry White's Walk, made by the late Mr. Legge in that Sort of Soil, which seem to thrive very well; but some Firs, which were planted in the white Sand, died very soon. About One Half of Woolmer Forest is of this latter Kind. The black rocky Soil is deemed the worst, and will bear nothing besides a little Heath, on the Surface. There have not been any Encroachments made on the Forest since his Father was appointed Keeper, nor any Lands inclosed from thence for the Benefit of the Keepers, or otherwise; but the Lord of the Manor of Mill Land claims a Part of Oak Hill as within his Manor, and has cut Timber, and Wood there; and since the Trees now growing the re were marked by Mr. Briant's Order, as before;mentioned, Mr. Hutterson, the present Lord of that Manor, has had his Mark put upon them, and threatened to prosecute this Examinant for marking them as directed by Mr. Briant. Says, that the Parishes of Bramshot, Headley, Liss, Greatham, Amshot, Selbume, Kingsley, Binsted, and Bentley, claim a Right of Common of Pasture and Turbary, paying to the Keeper One Shilling per Waggon Load for Peat, which contains from 1,000 to 1,200 in Number, and for Turf One Shilling

and

173

and Six Pence per Thousand, besides One Shilling and Six Pence a Thousand for cutting the Turf, and Two Shillings a Load for cutting and drying the Peat. He has heard that the Price of Turf was formerly One Shilling a Load, but raised by one John Adams, a former Keeper, to One Shilling and Six Pence per Load, on being threatened by the Parishioners of Bramshot to be assessed to the Parish Rates, which however was not effected. These Prices are paid by the Commoners, but Strangers are charged Six Pence per Load more for Peat, and are not allowed to have any Turf. Heath is cut for burning Bricks and Lime, and is usually sold by the Kiln, at Five Shillings per Kiln to the Keeper, and Eighteen Shillings a Kiln for cutting; but if sold by the Load, the Price is One Shilling per Load, and is cut by the Buyers, or at their Expence, for which they pay Three Shillings a Load. Fern is cut for Litter for Cattle, and is sold at Two Shillings and Sixpence a Waggon Load, if cut by the Keeper, or One Shilling, if cut by the Buyers; and Stones at Six Pence per Load, and One Shilling and Six Pence for digging. It frequently happens that Stems of Fir Trees are found in the Peat Bogs, some as large as a Man’s Body. He has heard that Oak Trees have been

found in some of the Bogs in Woolmer, but never saw any other than Fir. No Payments are made for Herbage, except an optional Gratuity of One Shilling or One Shilling and Sixpence each, formerly given to the Keeper at Easier, by many of the Commoners, but now by very few. All Kinds of Cattle are admitted, except Sheep* which are not allowed to be turned into the Forest, but sometimes stray in from the adjoining Commons, the Forest being open on almost every Side. The Forest has not been driven within his Remembrance, but when any Cattle are seen in the Forest not belonging to Commoners, the Keeper endeavours to find out the Owners, gives Notice to them to take away their Cattle, and threatens to pound them if not taken out of the Forest. Has never pounded any Horned Cattle there, but frequently Horses, the Owners of which, on taking them out of the Pound, pay Two Shillings and Six Pence each for catching them, and the Expence of keeping them while there, and if not owned, they become the Property of Lord Sterwell; but he remembers only Three or Four Instances of Horses not owned, which were given by Lord Stawell to his Father for his Trouble.

(Signed) Daniel.

Sixth Land Revenue Report.

Memorandum. — It appears on comparing the above Abstract, taken from the Original Survey, with the Account presented to the House of Commons in 1783, abstracted from the same Survey, that the Sixth Liue.

being the Total in Holt Forest, was by Mistake added as a separate Article; and that the Number of Loads in the Survey being given in Girt Measure, an Addition of One Half of that Number was afterwards made, in order to state the Quantities in Square Measure (Two Loads Girt Measure being equal to Three Loads Square) by means of which Error, the Quantity of Timber WHS represented to be nearly Twice the real Amount, according to the Original Survey (viz*J

24° Februarn. A. 1790.

Famham, 31st of December, 1789.

Gentlemen,

In Obedience to your Directions of the 21st Instant,

I have attentively looked over the Forests of Aliceholt and Woolmer, and have considered the Nature of the Soil; and am of Opinion, That every Part of Aliceholt would produce Oak Trees of a Size and Quality fit for Naval Purposes, if properly managed. — The Trees now standing thereon are mostly Oak, some Beech, and a few Ash; and I judge to be nearly all of the same Age, and the greatest Part arrived at Maturity, and of course will not improve by standing longer.

From the present Appearance of this Forest, I am inclinable to believe, that the greatest Part of the Trees now standing thereon were originally raised by one general Inclosure of the whole Forest, as most of them appear to be of the same standing, which I suppose to be about 115 or 120 Years; and I cannot discover the Traces of either Banks or Ditches in the interior Parts, or any Appearances whatever of separate Inclosures, or if there were originally no Inclosure, the Bushes and Underwood must have been carefully preserved. The Trees were brought up very close together, and not being thinned from Time to Time, as they ought to have been, is the Reason why they are generally no larger at present.

There are not now any Inclosures in this Forest for raising of Timber, or very little Timber in Succession, nor is it possible there should, as the Bushes and Underwood of all Kinds, which are the Nurses and

Protectors of Timber, are destroyed by the adjacent Inhabitants as soon as they come up.

Though there are vast Numbers of Oak Trees standing in this Forest arrived at their full Growth, by far the greatest Part is not of a Size or fit for the Navy, owing to the Causes before observed; and a great Number of them are much injured by lopping, particularly on the South East, South, South West, and West Parts of the Forest, adjoining to the Parishes of Kingsley, Binstead, Famham, and 'Bently.

From the Account of the Survey taken of the Timber in this Forest in the Year 1783, and considering what has been felled since that Time for the Navy, together with the present Appearance of the Timber,

I am of Opinion, that about Two hundred Loads may be supplied from thence Annually for the Use of the Navy, for a few Years, exclusive of what Planking Timber may arise, which I suppose would be very considerable; and I would recommend that Six or Seven hundred Trees be felled Annually for Sale, reserving all such as should be found fit to make or 3 Inch Plank for the Navy, and to be converted in the Forest, in order to lessen the Expence of Carriage; and to send none to the King’s Yards but such as was good and fit for the Service. — In making such Annual Falls 1 would propose to begin, and so go on, in those Places where the Trees are most given out, or quite done growing, or most abused by lopping, and entirely clear the Ground as I went on, reserving all such Trees as should be found fit for the Navy to go towards making Part of the Two hundred Loads to be supplied Annually, besides all such as were fit to be cut for Plank; and I would recom-

04 mend

30CrEO.HI. 24° Fe'brtiarii.

177

rmdnd the'making of Inclosures as the Land became Vacant, and in such Parts as are already so, and that they should be well attended to; without which (or a Toted Stop put to the cutting of the Bushes) a few Years must put a' Period to this Forest as a Nursery of Timber for the Navy; yet if a Stop could be put to the Abuses, and voting Timber; propetly cultivated and well managed, this ^Forest may beiinade of great Benefit to the Country, by yielding a lasting ‘Supply of Naval Timber, probably a Thousand Loads a Year.

The Average Distance of this Forest to the nearest Wharf (which is Godalming) is Ten Miles, and the Timber' carried thither at 13 Shillings per Load, and from thence to Deptford at 14 Shillings per Load more, the Hewing 1 s. 6d.per Load; the whole Expence, from the Felling to the Delivery, 1 /. 8$. 6d.

The most glaring Abuses now prevailing in this Forest, are the neighbouring Inhabitants going into the Woods, and constantly destroying the Bushes and Underwood of all Kinds as fast as they come up, so that there are none to be seen in any Part of it; the lopping and topping the Trees in a most shameful Manner, particularly in those Places mentioned before; they also claim a Right to the Roots of all Trees, and constantly grub them up as soon as the Trees are felled; also the stealing of Trees is not the least evil Practice in this Forest; and I presume that the Practice of Lord Stawell's People cutting Trees without Limita-

tion, View or Assignment, or giving any Account of what they do cut, or for what Purpose, must be considered also as an Abuse. As I was looking over the Forest, I saw 37 Oak Trees just felled by his Lordship’s People, with the Rind on, that would square about 30 Feet a Tree one with another. There are a few Encroachments in this Forest, which I suppose are pointed out in the Plan that has been taken. — I beg to remark, that if all this Forest was at some Time or other inclosed for the raising of Timber, which its present Appearance strongly indicates, there could be then no Claims upon it, or they must have been for a Time suspended; and if the Trees were1 brought up Without being inclosed (which is not likely) the Bushes alnd Underwood must have been preserved, otherwise it was impossible the Trees could have got up in the Manner they have; in this Case the Inhabitants must have been restrained from cutting them, and consequently had no Right to do so.

There are but a very few Oak Trees in Woolmer Forest; most of the Land is quite barren, being a sandy Soil, though there are some Parts of it that would produce Oak Trees, and Inclosures for that Purpose may be made with Advantage; and it is to be observed, that Fir Trees will grow in all Parts of it; some few, that were planted about 25 Years ago, by Government, are now in a very thriving State. The Average Distance of this Forest to the nearest Wharf (which is is

about Eleven Miles.

As I think it my Duty to endeavour to give every Information on this Subject in my Power, I shall be ready to answer any Questions you may be pleased to ask me.

And am,

Gentlemen,

with milch Respect, your most humble Servant,

The Commissioners Th<? Nichols.

bf the Land Revenue.

N*34-

Bedbridge, 17th of January 1790.

Gentlemen,

In Obedienee-to your Directions of the 1 ith Instant, I have considered of what Mr. Briant has proposed, relative to the selling of the Timber in Aliceholt Forest.

As most of the Timber in that Forest is at full Maturity, and will not improve by standing, but on the contrary get worse, and but a small Part of it fit for the Navy, nor ever will be; and considering the constant and many Depredations that are committed, and the very small Income it now brings to the Crown, owing to the extreme bad Mode of Management;

I am clearly of Opinion, that if all the Timber in this Forest was divided as near as could be into Ten Parts, and One of those Parts sold to the Merchants Yearly, and so on till the Whole was cleared away, leaving only a few Trees standing to spread Seed, at the same Time taking Care to make Inclosures for raising more in its Stead, that it would be the most advantageous Way of disposing of it, for the Benefit of the Public, and what, I believe, every Individual would do, was it his own Property.

That Part of the Timber which is fit for the Navy would most likely be sold again to the Navy Board, and at a Price on the Whole not much above w’hat is now given for it. — If not, the India Company would have it, who are now become Competitors with Government for large 'limber, and whose Market will be supplied, so long as there is any to be got in the Kingdom on private Estates, and Things remain on the Footing as at present.

Should the Mode of selling the Timber in this Forest to the Merchants, as proposed, be approved of, I would humbly recommend that after fixing on die Part where the first Fall is intended to be made, that the Trees should be numbered progressively till the Number was marked as intended to be felled for the first Part; and an Account taken, and put in different Classes, according to the Sizes and Quality of the Trees, with the estimated Content of each Tree, put against the Numbers, and the Value Load set against each Class; by this the Value of the whole Lot would be obtained, and the Numbers would be a Check against Abuses; but before felled each Tree should be marked on the Claw with the broad Arrow Hammer. The Lot to be put up to Auction to be sold standing; and should not the Value of it be offered, it may be afterwards sold privately, or left standing till the Value was offered, which I presume would soon be.

In all Cases were Goods are intended to be sold by Auction, or privately, the real Value of them should be first obtained, in order to guard against any Combinations in the Bidders.

I am,

Gentlemen,

with much Respect, your most humble Servant,

Thot Nichols.

The Commissioners of the Land Revenue.

Sixth Land Revenue Report.

N° 37-

Gentlemen, Navy-Office, 22d December, 1789.

Id Answer to your Letter of the 16th Instant, we acquaint you, that the Navy Timber from Alice Holt Forest has usually been delivered into His Majesty's Dock Yard at Deptford, conveyed from the Forest by Land to Godalming, in Surrey (the Distance about 15 Miles) and from thence by Water to Deptford Yard. — The Expence by Land is 13 s.6d. per Load, by Water 145. 6d. per Load; making the whole Expence by Land and Water 1/. 8 s. per Load.

We are.

Gentlemen,

Comm" Land Revenue.

Land Revenue Office, Scotland Yard, February 8th, 1790.

Bishop* A Petition of several Noblemen, and the humble

Stortford Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Traders, and

n d itMion" ot^ers, Inhabitants of the Counties *01 Herts,

Petition. Cambridge, Isle of Ely, and Suffolk, on

Behalf of themselves and others, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That a Navigation is already completed from the City of London to the Town of Bishops Stortford, in the County of Herts, and, by a Survey which has been taken, it appears that the same may be extended by proceeding to a Place called Palmer's Water, in the said County, and from thence to the Parish of Elsenham, and through the North Parts of the County of Essex to the Town of Saffron Walden, and from the last mentioned Place, through the Counties of Cambridge and Suffolk, to join the Brandon River, whereby Communication will be opened to the County of Norfolk; and that a Branch may be made from such extended Line by a Cut therefrom in the Parishes of Great and Little Abingdon and Baberham, to join and communicate with the Town of Cambridge, and that another Branch may be made by a Cut to fall into the Burwell Lode, already navigable to the Cambridge River, whereby convenient Communication will be opened with the Isle of Ely, and the Counties of Huntingdon and Bedford; and that, if such Navigation, with the Branches aforesaid, are made, the same will be productive of great Utility and Benefit to the Inhabitants of the said Counties, and the Public in general, by rendering the Carriage of Corn, and all Kinds of Merchandize which pass between the Metropolis and the Counties aforementioned, and also the several Towns and Places lying within the said Counties, cheaper and easier than at present: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining the said Navigation and Cuts, in such Manner, and

Your most obedient,

Humble Servants,

J.

. Geo. Marsh.

Cha* Middletokt, . In* Call,

John Fordyce.

Mr. John Smyth, according to Order, reported from Report on the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was West India referred to consider of an Act; made in the Twenty- and Quebec eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, Acts, intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade between " the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies and Plantations in North America, and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of America, and between His Majesty’s said " Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The West ;" and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act " to allow the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits,

Royal Assent A M E S S A G E by Sir Francis Gen-

to Bill*. Jr\ tleman Usher of the Black Rod:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords, authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission for declaring His Royal Assent to several Acts agreed upon by both Houses, do desire the immediate Attendance of this Honourable House in the House of Peers, to hear the Commission read.

Accordingly Mr. Speaker, with the House, went up to the House of Peers.

And being returned;

Mr. Speaker reported, That the House, at the Desire of the Lords authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission afore-mentioned, had been at the House of Peers, where a Commission, under the Great Seal, was read, giving, declaring, and notifying the Royal Assent to the several Public and Private Bills therein mentioned; and also impowering His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, His Royal Highness the Duke of York, His Royal Highness the Duke of Clarence, His Royal Highness the Duke of Gloucester, His Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland, the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and several other Lords, to declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills; and that the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and the Duke of Leeds, named also in the said Commission, did accordingly declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills: Which Bills are as followeth; viz.

An Act for continuing and granting to His Majesty certain Duties upon Malt, Mum, Cyder, and Perry, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety:

An Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty, by a Land Tax to be raised in Great Britain, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety:

An Act for indemnifying all Persons who have been concerned in advising or carrying into Execution certain Orders of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain, and also certain Orders issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits

Vol. 45.

in Consequence of the same, and for making further provisions relative thereto:

An Act for the Regulation of His Majesty’s Marine Forces while on Shore:

An Act for punishing Mutiny and Desertion, and for the better Payment of the Army and their Quarters:

An Act for dividing and inclosing the Common Crown Pasture and Common Fen in the Parish of tqn, in the County of Lincoln:

An Act for dividing and inclosing several Open Fields, and a Stinted Pasture, called Linton Pasture, within the Township of Linton, in the West Riding of the County of York:

An Act for naturalizing Gottlob Gotthelff Schusler.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Owners and Occupiers of the several and respective ancient Commonable Messuages in Waterbeach, in the County of Cambridge, on Behalf of themselves and others, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That an Act was passed in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for the effectual Draining and Preservation of Waterbeach Level, in the County of Cambridge, and to establish an Agreement made between the Lord of the Manor of Waterbeach cum Denny and the Commoners within the said Manor; and that it is necessary, for the better and more effectually regulating and stinting the Right of Common in the several Commonable Waste and Fen Grounds in Waterbeach aforesaid, that some Alterations and Amendments should be made in the said Act: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to alter and amend the said Act, under such Regulations and Restrictions as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Charles Gould, Mr. Yorke, Scc.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Wemyss presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for making and repairing the Road from Newmiln Bridge by Foodies Mill, dour, Kirkcaldy, G alia town, and Cameron Bridge, to Craill, and other Roads in the County of Fife; and for improving the Harbour’of Kinghorn or Pettycur, in the said County: And the same was received, and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Yorke presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for enlarging the Term of several Acts made for repairing the Roads from Slump Cross to Newmarket Heath, and from Stump Cross aforesaid to the End of the Town of Trumpington next to and from Shelford Pound to and for making

more effectual Provision for repairing the said Roads, and also One Mile of the Road between Trumpington and Cambridge, commencing at the South End of Ti'umpington aforesaid, and for amending the Road from Chesterjord Bridge to the End of Wittlesford next to Shelford, all in the County of Cambridge: And the same was received; and read the First Time,

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.
