Mr. Hmgerford presented to the House, according 'to Order, a Bill to enable Thomas Watson Sam-

well, Esquire (lately called Thomas Samweil )

and his Heirs Male, to take the Surname, and use the Arms, of Samweil, pursuant to the Will of Sir Thomas Samweil, Baronet, deceased: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Thomas Belham reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Trustees, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, for putting in Execution an Act made in the Tenth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Road from New Chappell, in the County of Surrey, over Copthorn, in the County of Sussex, through Lindfield, to the Town of Ditchling, up to the Top of Ditchling Bost Hills, in the said County of Sussex, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Samuel Waller, the Clerk to the Trustees, being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed several considerable Sums of Money upon the Credit thereof, of which the Sum of 3,7551, now remains due; which Money cannot be repaid, nor the Roads kept in proper Repair, unless the Term of the said Act is further continued, and the Powers thereof altered and enlarged. And the Witness added, That it will be necessary to vary and alter some of the Tolls by the said Act granted.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for continuing die Term, and enlarging the Powers, of an Act, made in the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Road from New Chappell, in the County of Surrey, over Copthorn, in the County of Sussex, through Lindfield, to the Town of Ditchling, up to the Top of Ditchling Bost Hills, in the said Coanty of And that Mr. Thomas Belham, Lord George Henry Lenox, and Mr. Kempe, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Westminster Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and dear the Lobby, and the Speaker’s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

And the Names of the Members appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into Wt°M-minster Hall accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

A Petition of the Commissioners for putting in Exe- Petition cution the several Acts of Parliament for paving, aSainst the cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, chelaea^au’d and other Places, within the City and Liberty of West- Fulham’ mitister, and other Places therein mentioned, was pre- Roads Bill, sented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for more effectually repairing the Road from Hyde Park Comer to Counters Bridge, and certain other Roads within the Parishes of Saint George Hanover Square, Saint Margaret Westminster, Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, in the Coanty of Middlesex, and for lighting, watching, and watering the same, and for several other Purposes therein mentioned; and Setting forth, That by an Act, made in the Fifth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, the Commissioners for paving Westminster were empowered to collect certain Tolls on Sundays at the several Avenues to the City of Westminster in the said Act particularly mentioned, one of which is a Turnpike at Kensington, near the Entrance into Hyde Park, the Term of which Act was continued by an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act " for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act,

" passed in the Fifth Year of His present Majesty’s " Reign, for impowering the Commissioners for putting in Execution the several Acts passed for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets,

" and Lanes, within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, to collect certain Tolls on " Sundays upon the several Roads therein mentioned,

" and apply the same for the Purposes of the said " Acts;" and that by an Act, made in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Road from Clarges Street to Hyde Parke Comer, and from the South End of Park Lane to The North Side of Hertford Street, in the Parish of Saint George Hanover Square, in the County of Middlesex, then under the Direction of the Act for repairing the Roads in the Parishes of Kensington, Chelsea, Futham, and Saint George Hanover Square, was put under the Management of the Commissioners for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Placesin

and.

30 Geo. III. 25° Februarii. 183

and, in order to enable the said Commissioners effectually to pave, cleanse, light, keep in Repair, and regulate the said Roads, leading from the End of Charges Street to the Turnpike near Hyde Park Corner, and frdna the South End of Park Lane to the North Side of Hertford Street, in the said Parish of Saint George Hanover Square, the Trustees for the Time being, under the Acts tnen in Force, and under any future Act or Acts of Parliament, for repairing the several Roads in the Parishes of Kensington, Chelsea, and Fulham, in the County of Middlesex, which Roads are now comprized in the Act meant to be amended by the said Bill, were directed to pay to the Commissioners for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, add other Places in /Westminster, the Sum of 1,000l. per Annum, which Sum was, by the said Act, directed to be applied, by the said paving Commissioners, in paving, cleansing, lighting, repairing, and -regulating the said Roads, leading from the End of ‘ Charges Street to the Turnpike Gate near Hyde Park Comer, and from the South End of Park Street to the North Side of Hertford Street, in the said Parish of Sami George Hanover Square, and the several other Squares, Streets, Lanes and Places, under the Cane ’ and Management of the said Commissioners, and that, pursuant to the Direction of the said Act, the said ‘Street and Road have been paved, cleansed, lighted, repaired, and regulated by the said Commissioners; and that, by virtue of the Powers and Authorities given to the Paving Commissioners, the Sum of 35,0001, has been borrowed on the Credit of the Sunday Tolls granted by the said Act of the Fifth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, and the Sum of 20,00 has been borrowed on the Credit of the said Annual Payment directed to be made by the said Act of the Sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign; the Whole of which Sums now remain due and owing on their respective Securities, and the said Annual Payment of 1,000l. proving insufficient to defray the Expence of executing the several Works, for the performing of which it was granted, the Deficiency of that Fund was, by the said Act passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, directed to be made good out of the Surplus of the Sunday Tolls granted by the said Act of the Fifth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, which has been done accordingly, to the Amount of about 170 /. per Annum; and that the said Bill contains divers Powers and Regulations, which, if carried into effect, would interfere very materially with, if not annihilate, the Powers and Authorities granted by Parliament to the Commissioners for paving Westminster, and would, as the Petitioners conceive, prove highly injurious to the numerous Creditors on the said Sunday Tells and Annual Payment, and prejudicial to the Public: And therefore praying, That they may be heard by themselves or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect them, and that the same may not pass, as it now stands, or that they may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, m Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

A Petition of the several Persons who have there- Peterborough unto subscribed their Names, on Behalf of themselves Paving and others, Owners and Inhabitants of Houses in the Pet,tion* Parish of Saint John Baptist, in the City of Peterborough, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the several Streets, Lanes, Passages,

Causeways, and other Roads and public Places, within the said Parish and City, are very ill paved, and badly repaired, and not sufficiently cleansed, lighted, and watched, and are much incommoded by Nuisances, Annoyances and Encroachments; and that it would tend greatly to the Safety, Accommodation, and Convenience of the Inhabitants of the said City, and of all Travellers and other Persons resorting thereto, if the said Streets, Lanes, Passages, Causeways, Roads, and public Places, were properly paved, repaired, eleanstti, lighted, watched, and regulated: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the several Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Benyon, Mr. Lionel Hamer, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Dudley Canal A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the

Navigation Dudley Canal Navigation was presented to the House, etition. an{j rea(j. §etting forth, That by an Act, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners were authorized to make and maintain a Navigable Canal within and from certain Lands belonging to Thomas Talbot Foley, Esquire, in the Parish of Dudley, in the County of Worcester, to join and communicate with the Stourbridge Navigation, at a Place called Black Delph, upon Pensnett Chace, in the Parish of , in the County of Stafford, and, in pursuance thereof, they have fully completed the said Canal, and the same is now navigable; and that by an Act, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners were empowered to extend the said Dudley Canal from the Termination thereof, in the Lands of the said Thomas Talbot to join the Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Navigations, at or near Tipton Green, in the County of Stafford, and they were thereby enabled to raise the Sum of 22,0001. for the purpose of carrying the said Undertaking into Execution, and, in case the said Sum should be found insufficient for that Purpose, the Petitioners were thereby also enabled to raise any further Sum, not exceeding 5,000l. for completing and perfecting the Extension of the said Navigation; and that, in pursuance of the Powers in the said Acts, the Pe-tioners have proceeded to extend the said Dudley Canal from the Lands of the said Thomas Talbot Foley, to join the said Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canals at Tipton Green aforesaid, and have made great Progress therein, and expended, in doing thereof, the Sum of 27,000l. being the Money they were enabled to raise for that Purpose by the said Act of the Twenty-fifth Year of His present Majesty, but some Part thereof still remains undone, unfinished, and incomplete; and that the Petitioners are informed that it will be necessary to expend the farther Sum of 10,000l. and upwards, to make, finish, and complete the Extension of the said Dudley Canal, in Manner as is directed by the said Act of the Twenty-fifth Year of His present Majesty, but which they have no Power to raise without the Authority of Parliament; and that, if the said Acts were, in some Respects, repealed, enlarged, altered, and amended, it would be of great Benefit and Advantage to the Petitioners: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to authorize and enable them to raise and contribute the Sum of 10,100l. for the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and by such Ways and Means, as the House shall think proper, and also to repeal, enlarge, alter, and amend the said Acts, in such Respects as to the House shall appear requisite and necessary.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Lygon, Mr. Foley, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records,

A Petition of Thomas Dudley, of Shutt End, in the Donnstonw Parish of Kingswinford, in the County, of Stafford,

Esquire, and the Reverend John Dudley, of Himley, in the said County of Stafford, Clerk (Trustees named and appointed in and by the last Will and Testament of John Keelinge, late of the Parish of Kingswinford aforesaid, Esquire, deceased) Lords of the Manor of Dormstone, in the County of Worcester, and of Henry Cecil, Esquire, Impropriator of the Great and Small Tythes arising and reserving within the said Manor and Parish of Dormstone, and of the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Owners and Proprietors of Lands and Tenements within the said Manor and Parish of Dormstone, on Behalf of themselves, and the rest of the Owners and Proprietors of Lands and Tenements within the same Manor and Parish, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Manor and Parish of Dormstone, several Open Common Fields, wherein the Lands belonging to the Petitioners and others lie intermixed and dispersed in small Parcels, and are, in their present Situation, inconveniently situated, and incapable of Improvement; and that there is also, within the paid Manor and Parish, a certain Common and Waste Ground, containing by Estimation Thirty Acres, or thereabouts, upon which the Petitioners, and the rest of the said Proprietors, have, or respectively claim, a Right of Common, and the said Common and Waste, in their present Situation, yield very little Profit to the Petitioners, and the rest of the Proprietors aforesaid; and that, if the said Open Common Fields, and also the said Common and Waste Ground, were divided and allotted amongst the Petitioners, and all other Persons interested therein, according to their respective Interests, the same might be inclosed, and thereby greatly improved, and become profitable to the Petitioners, and the rest of the said Proprietors, as well as of public Advantage: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Open Common Fields, and Common and Waste Ground, in such Manner, and under such Regulations and Restrictions, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr.

Lygon and Mr. Foley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

MR. Marsham reported from the Committee, to

whom the Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, oif the Eighth Year of His present Majesty, for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading to and through the Town of Goudhurst, in the County of Kent, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of the several principal Inhabitants of the Hamlets of Deretend and Bordesley, in the Parish of Aston, near Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and the other Inhabitants of the said Hamlets, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Great Road, leading from Birmingham towards London extends through the High Streets of the said Hamlets; that the Trade and Popularity of the said Hamlets are greatly increased, and several new Streets have been lately laid open and erected therein, by Reason whereof a greater Number of Carts and Carriages are now used there than formerly in conveying Goods and Merchandize; and that the Streets, Lanes, aind Passages within the said Hamlets are not properly cleansed, lighted, or watched, and are subject to various Irregularities, Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments, and it would be greatly to the Benefit and Convenience of the Petitioners, and the rest of the Inhabitants of the said Hamlets, and others resorting thereto, if the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and Passages thereof, were properly cleansed, lighted, and 'watched, and the Surfaces of the Streets kept upon a proper Level, and all Nuisances, Irregularities, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments therein, removed, and prevented in future, and if Carts and Carriages used in the said Hamlets for carrying Goods, Wares, and Merchandize, were Voii. 45.

r - # % put under proper Regulations, and the Behaviour of the Owners and Drivers thereof properly restricted

And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to

bring in a Bill for effecting the several Purposes before

mentioned, in such Manner, and by such Ways and

Means, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Robert Laxvley, Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, &c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, . in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons; Papers, and Records.

Sir Joseph Mawbey reported from the Committee, to

whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, residing in the Hundred of Reigate in the County of Surrey, was referred; That the

Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followed), viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. John Midleton being examined, said, That he knows the Road from Purley Comernear , to Reigate

through Merstham, to be in several Places very narrow, and inconvenient, and at Times unsafe for Persons to pass and repass.

That the Road from Godstonthrough Reigate, to WonhamMUl Gate and Buckland Church, is very steep, narrow, and dangerous; that the Witness apprehends the said Roads cannot be sufficiently repaired and widened by the ordinary Course of Law; and that the amending, widening, and repairing the said Roads would be very advantageous to the Inhabitants of the said County.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for repairing and widening the Road from Purley beyond Croydon, in the County of Surrey, through Merstham, to the Borough of Reigate, and from God-stone by Redstone House, in the said County, through the Borough of Reigate, to Wonham Mill Gate, and to Buckland Church, in the said County: And that Sir Joseph Mawbey and Lord William Russell do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Pierrepont presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing, allotting, inclosing and regulating the Open Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Moors, Commons, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of North Collingham, in the County of Nottingham: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of Estates, and of the Merchants, Tradesmen, and others, interested in the Navigation of the River Ouse, between Newhacen and Barcombe Mill, in the Parish of combe, in the County of Sussex, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the Rive Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners and others have already obtained Leave of the House to bring in a Bill for improving the Navigation of the said 'River, from to Barcombe

Mill aforesaid; and that the said first-mentioned Bill includes so much of the Plan meant to be executed by the Bill prayed for by the Petitioners, as relates to the said River Ouse, between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, and purports, as the Petitioners are informed, to make the Navigation of the said River, between Lewes and Barcombe Mill, private Property, and thereby to charge all Persons navigating thereon with a perpetual Toll, for the Benefit and Emolument of the Undertakers of the said Navigation, which will be a Hardship on the Petitioners, an unnecessary Burthen on the Trade and Commerce of the Country, and of great Detriment to the Public, whereas, by the Petitioners Bill, the Toll will be shortly reduced, so as to be no Burthen or Check to Commerce: And therefore praying, That

they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the said Bill may not pass in to a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Report be received from the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at ^he same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, to whom Gre«nhU! the Petition of several Trustees appointed in and by virtue of an Act of Parliament, made and passed in petition «-the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty ported.

King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road leading from the Turnpike Road between Wheatley Roclcs and Tean, in the County of Stafford, at or near a Place called - Greenhill, in the Parish of Cheadle, and County of Stafford, through the Parishes of Cheadle, Kingsley, and Ipstones, to a Place called Botham House, situate on or near the Turnpike Road leading from Ashborne, in the County of Derby, to Leek, in the County of Stafford, and also the Road leading from Botham House, across the said Turnpike Road, to and through the Township of Onecoat, to or near Butterton Moor End, in the said County of Stafford, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followed); viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And

Mr. John Child being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the'Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed the Sum of 3,100l. upon the Credit of the Tolls and Duties thereby granted, which Sum hath been duly applied in making and repairing the said Road, and in erecting sundry Bridges,

Toll Houses and Turnpike Gates thereon, and for such other Purposes as are by the said Act directed — That the Whole of the Money so borrowed still remains due, and cannot be repaid, nor the Road kept in sufficient Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be continued, and the Powers thereof altered and enlarged.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue the Term, and alter and enlarge the Powers, of an Act, passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the.

Road from Cheadle to Botham House, and from thence to Buttertoti Moor End, in the County of Stafford: And that Mr. Gilbert and the Earl Gower do prepare, and bring in, the same.

" without Payment of Duty, under certain Conditions " and Restrictions:" And the same was received; and read the First Time.

The Lords A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Montagu and have agreed Mr. Leeds:

Mr. Speaker,

Norwich and The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Trowse Act for continuing an Act of the Tenth Year of Road Bill, die Reign of His present Majesty, for amending the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the City of Norwich, to Block Hill, in Trowse, at the Angle where the Road divides to Bixley and Kirby, in the County of Norfolk; without any Amendment: And also,

Norwich and The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Caister Act for continuing an Act of the Ninth Year of Roacf Bdl the ^e'8n His present Majesty, for amending the

a 1 ' Road from Bishopsgate Bridge, in the City of Norwich, to a Stoue, formerly called The Two Stone, where the Norwich Road joins the Caister Causeway, Two Miles and a Half short of the Town of Great without any Amendment: And also,

Norwich and The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An NewBucken- Act for continuing an Act of the Twelfth Year of, ham Road jjs present Majesty, for repairing and amending the 1 ‘ Road from Berstreet Gates, in the City of Norwich, to

New Buckenham, in the County of without any Amendment: And also,

Bristol The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An

New Chappell Mr- Thomas Pelham presented to the House, accord-Road Bill ing to Order, a Bill for continuing the Term, and

Ordered, That the Committee to whom the Bill for Commit improving, continuing, and extending the Naviga- onLew« tion of the River Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of forpere Cuckfeld, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Papero, Cuckfeld, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex, is committed, have Pow'er to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are R0wdei thereunto subscribed. Gentlemen, Clergy, and Free- and Red holders of the County of Wilts, was presented to the Road House, and read; Setting forth, That the Road lead- tItion‘ ing from Rowde Ford, in the County of Wilts, through Bromham, Chittoe, Caine, Chippenham, and Pewsham, to Red Hill, in the said County, to join the Turnpike Road there, is the common Highway from Devizes, and.other Places, to Chippenham, both of which are considerable Market Towns, and is also the direct and nearest Road from Devizes, and other Places, through Chippenham, into Gloucestershire, and, if kept in Repair, would open a very considerable Communication between divers large Towns and Places in the Counties of Wilts and Gloucester, but the said Highway is in many Parts founderous, narrow, incommodious, and dangerous to Travellers; and that a certain other Road branching out of the said first-mentioned Road, at or near the West Corner of a Close, called The Land of Nod, in Chittoe Heath, and extending from thence through Whetham to Caine, in the said County, is also in a ruinous Condition, and, in most Parts, narrow and incommodious, and the said Roads cannot be effectually amended, widened, and kept in Repair, by the ordinary Course of Law; and that a small Part of the said first-mentioned Road, about One hundred Poles in Length, is Part of the Road comprized in, and intended to be repaired by Two Acts, made in the Second and Twenty-fifth Years of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for repairing the Highways between Sheppard's Shard and Horsley Upright Gate, leading down Bagdovm Hill, in the County of Wilts, and other ruinous Parts of the Highways thereunto adjacent, and also an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of the said Two before-mentioned Acts, and the Tolls collected under the said Acts have arisen almost wholly from Carriages and Horses passing and re-passing over that small Distance of the said Road lying between the Towns of Devizes and Chippenham, and no Part thereof is collected on the other Branch of the said Turnpike Road; and that the Tolls collected on the said Roads have been, from Time to Time, applied in Discharge of the Money due upon the Credit of the Tolls granted by the said Acts, and, under the Powers given to the Trustees by the said Act, passed in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the said Trustees have compounded with the several Mortgagees, and other Creditors upon the said Road, for their respective Debts, and they have accordingly been satisfied, and no Debt whatever remains due upon the said Road; and that the said Road, comprized in the said Acts, was formerly Part of the Great Road between London and Bath, but other Roads more convenient to Travellers have been since made, and in consequence thereof the Road intended to be repaired by the said Acts (except only that small Part thereof which lies in, and composes a Part of, the said Highway, from Rowde, Ford to Red Hill aforesaid) is become almost wholly useless,

Petition in fovoar of Rowde Ford and Red Hill Road Bill.

and will not, as the Petitioners apprehend, require any further Aid for repairing the same than is given by. the ordinary Course of Law; and that it would be a peculiar Convenience to the Inhabitants of the said Towns of Devizes, Chippenham, and Caine, and the Villages adjacent, as well as of general public Utility, if Pow ers were given to Trustees to repair and improve the Whole of the said Road from Rowde Ford to Red Hill aforesaid, including the said small Part thereof so comprized in the said recited Acts, and also to repair and widen the said other Road from Chittoe Heath to the Town of Caine aforesaid, and for that Purpose it will be expedient to repeal the said several recited Acts: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for repairing and improving the said last mentioned Roads, and for repealing the said several recited Acts, in such Manner as to the House shall appear meet and expedient.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Joshua Smith, Mr. Rye, &c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Trustees named and appointed for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made and passed in the Tw’enty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for continuing " the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of " Two Acts, made in the Second and Twenty-fifth " Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing " the Highways between Sheppard's Shord and Horsley Upright Gate, leading down Bagdown Hill, in the " County of Wilts, and other ruinous Parts of the " Highways thereunto adjacent," was presented to the House, and read; taking Notice of the last preceding Petition; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners being desirous to co-operate in the Measures necessary to be taken for obtaining such Bill, and for repealing the said Acts, beg Leave to represent to the House, that a very inconsiderable Portion of the Highway between R&wde Ford and Red Hill, not more than One hundred Poles in Length, constitutes a Part of the Turnpike Road mentioned and described in the said Acts, and the Tolls received under the same Acts have principally arisen from Persons travelling upon such Portion of the Road, so lying between Rowde Ford and Red Hill, and no Part of such Tolls is collected on the other Branch of the said Turnpike Road; and that the said Tolls have been principally applied in Discharge of the Money due upon the Credit thereof, and that, under the Powers given to the Petitioners by the said Act, passed in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, they have compounded with the several Mortgagees, and other Creditors, upon the said Road, for their respective Debts, and the said Mortgagees, and other Creditors, have accordingly been satisfied, and no Debt whatever now remains due upon the said Road;’and that the Road mentioned in the said Acts heretofore constituted a Part of the Great Road leading from London to Bath, but more convenient Roads have been Jong since formed, and by Reason thereof the Road intended to be repaired under the said Acts (except that small Portion lying between Rowde Ford and Red Hill aforesaid) is become neglected and disused, and will not, as the Petitioners conceive, require any further Aid for repairing the same than is given by the ordinary Course of Law; and that the Petitioners are satisfied that it would be of great Utility to the Public at large, if Powers were given to Trustees to repair and improve the Highway between Rowde Ford and Red Hill, so as to include the said Portion of Road comprized in the said Acts, and also to repair the said Road from Chittoe Heath to Caine, and to that End it will be expedient to

Vol. 45.

repeal the said several Acts: And therefore the Petitioners beg Leave to signify to the House their full Consent to the Repeal of the said Acts, and pray, That Leave may accordingly be given to bring in a Bill for repairing and improving the Roads between Rowde Ford and Red Hill, and between Chittoe Heath and Caine aforesaid, and for repealing the said several recited Acts, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the last preceding Petition is referred: And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That this House will, immediately, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of permitting the Removal of Sheep from the Ports of Southampton and Portsmouth to Cowes, and of permitting the Removal of Sheep and Lambs, and all Goods (not liable to Duty on Exportation, or prohibited to be exported) between the said Ports reciprocally without Cocket or Bond, under certain Regulations and Restrictions;

The House divided.

The Yeas were directed to go forth.

{Mr. Rushworth, 1

Mr. Alderman ! None. Newnham: J

Tellers for the Noes, Mr. Grap/Acrwc:/

So it passed in the Negative.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for appointing Commissioners to put in Execution an Act of this Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " granting an Aid to His Majesty, by a Land Tax to " be raised in Great Britain, for the Service of the " Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety," together with those named in Two former Acts for appointing Commissioners of the Land Tax: And that Mr. Rose and Mr. Gilbert do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The House, according to Order, resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for taking off the Duties upon unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good . Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Edinburgh thereto subscribed, being Trustees named and appointed and Stirling by, and in virtue of, Two several Acts, passed in the Roads Pe-Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of his late Majesty’s tition-Reign, herein after more particularly mentioned, and others, Land Owners within the County of Stirling, was presented to the House, and read: Setting forth.

That by an Act, passed in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for repairing the Post Road from the City of Edinburgh, through the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, from the Boathouse Ford on Almond Water, and from thence to the Town of Linlithgow, and from the said Town to Falkirk, and from thence to Stirling, and from Falkirk to Kilsyth, and to Inch-bellie Bridge, on the Post Road to the City of Glasgow, several Tolls, Duties, and Powers, were granted to certain Trustees for repairing the said Roads, and for other Purposes in the said Act mentioned, which were to have Continuance from the 1st Day of June 1752, for the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament; and that by another Act, passed in the Thirty-first Year of the Reign of his said late Majesty, the above-mentioned Act w<as continued for the further Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, subject to the Alterations and Amend-

3 D ments

194 1° Martii. A. 1790.

merits in the said Second Act contained; and that the Trustees named in the said Acts have borrowed several considerable Sums of Money, and repaired the said Roads, but the Money borrowed, and the Interest thereof, cannot be paid, nor the said Roads kept in sufficient Repair, unless the Terms and Powers granted by the said Acts are further continued and enlarged; and that it is thought expedient, by the Trustees in the said Acts named, that the Turnpike Roads and Tolls of the said Two Counties of Stirling and Linlithgow, which were included and comprehended in the said Acts, and under the Directions of the same Trustees, should now be separated, and put under the separate Management of the Trustees of the respective Counties in which such Roads lie; and that the Road from Loanhcad to Saint Ninians, through the Parishes of Denny, Dunipace, and Saint Ninians, is in a ruinous Condition, and, during bad Weather, in many Parts impassable for Carriages, and cannot be sufficiently repaired, amended, and kept in Repair, by the Laws now in Force: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, and that the Petitioners may have such other and further Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Thomas Dundas, Sir John Sinclair, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Biggleswade A Petition of several of the Trustees for putting in

Roa^Uj*e-n Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Tenth

titi<m. " Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repair-

ing and amending the Road from Biggleswade, in the County of Bedford, through and to

the Top of Alconbury Hill, and from Bugden to Huntingdon, and from Cross Hall to Great Stoughton Common in the County of Huntingdon, and for repairing, widening, turning, and altering the Road, leading out of the aforesaid Road at or near The Ferry House, in the Parish of Tempsford, to and through Little Barford, Eynesbury, and Saint Neot’s, to the Turnpike Road at the End of Cross Hall Lane, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That a considerable Sum of Money is now due on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be collected upon the said Roads, and it hath been found necessary that a small Increase should be made in some of the Tolls, in order to enable the Petitioners to keep the said Roads, and the several 1 Bridges thereon erected, or which have been ordered to be erected, in Repair, and for altering and widening such of the old Bridges as are now ordered to be widened and repaired, and to pay the Interest of the Money borrowed and due as aforesaid; and that the Term of the said Act is near expiring, and, in order to keep the said Roads in good Repair, it is necessary that the same should be further continued, and some other Alterations and Amendments made in the said Act; and that a small Piece of Road (being about Half a Mile in Length) leading out of the present Turnpike Road, in the Parish of Eaton Socon, in the said County of Bedford, and through Eaton Ford to another Part of the same Turnpike Road near Saint Neot’s Bridge, is sometimes overflowed, and rendered inconvenient for Travellers, and it would be a great Benefit to Persons making Use of the same, if the said Road was properly raised and amended: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of the said Act, and for raising

and repairing the said Piece of Road, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof: and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to the Lord Mr.

Gilbert, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Churchwardens, Overseers of the Manchester Poor, and principal Inhabitants of the Town of Man- Poor-Petition. Chester, in the County of Lancaster, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, from the present great Populousness of the Town of Manchester, and the daily Increase of the Poor belonging to that Township, the Workhouse now used there is found much too small, and in all Respects unfit for the due Accommodation of the Poor; and that a new Work-house is necessary, and further Regulations are wanting for the better Government of the Poor within the said Township: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes above-mentioned.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Blackbume, Mr. Hunger-ford, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers; and Records.

A Petition of the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Manchester Snuff in Manchester, in the County of Lancaster, was £etlUon presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, Tobacco Act! That the Petitioners finding that the Tobacco Manufacturers in some of the Sea Port Towns are exerting their Endeavours to procure a Repeal of the Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," beg Permission to express to the House their Approbation of the general Principles of the Act, having from Experience found, during the short Interval of Time since it passed into a Law, very essential Advantages from its salutary Regulations; that the Petitioners find however an Inconvenience laid upon them by the 119th Section of the said Act, which restrains them from the Removal of their Tobacco Stalks to any of the Ports therein mentioned, whereby they are deprived of the only Means of disposing of their Stalks, except the small Portion thereof which they can use in the making of Snuff and Spanish, and are laid under a manifest Disadvantage in Comparison to the Manufacturers resident at the Sea Port Towns: And that the Petitioners, conceiving that, under the general Principles of the Act, the Revenue upon Tobacco is better secured, and more equally collected, and that Protection is thereby afforded to the fair Trader, therefore pray,

That the Act may not be repealed, but that it may be continued in Force under such Alterations and additional Regulations as the Legislature shall think proper to adopt.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of the several Persons and others whose Bleatam Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to Inclosure the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Peti- Petition, tioners, as Proprietors of Houses, Lands, and Tenements, within the Manor of Bleatam, in the Parish of

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and principal Inhabitants, of the Town of Bromsgrove, in the County of Worcester, and the County adjacent, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that Application is made for Leave to bring in a Bill for enabling the Commissioners of the Turnpike Road leading from Birmingham to Bromsgrove (and which Road leads immediately to all the principal Places in the West of England) to repair, widen, and amend the same; and that the said Road is in several Parts very narrow, and particularly in that Part which lies within the Parish of Northfield, and, in the direct Line from Birmingham to Bromsgrove is so hilly and narrow, that it seems not only absolutely necessary to have the same widened, but the Course thereof changed, to bring the same to a proper Level; and that, by reason of the narrow hollow Ways within the Parish before mentioned, many Accidents have happened, and Travelling on the said Road is become exceedingly dangerous: And therefore praying, That the House wili take the Line of Road into their Considera-tieon, and alter the present Course thereof, so as to make the Hills more easy of Ascent, and grant the Petitioners such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the

Table.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for carrying into Execution an Act of Parliament, of the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from the Town of Denbigh, to the Turnpike Road between Northop and Holywell, and from Afon Wen to the Town of Mold, in the Counties of Denbigh and Flint, w as presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby authorized to be collected, which still remains due, and cannot be paid off, and the said Roads effectually amended and kept in good Repair, unless, the said Act be further continued, and some Alterations and Amendments made therein; and that a certain Road branching out of the above-mentioned Turnpike Road near a Public House called The Blue Hand, opposite Lleweney Park, and extending from thence across Part of a certain Common called Denbigh Green, to a Turnpike Gate called Pen jf Paliment Gate, erected across the Road leading from the Town of Denbigh, in the County of Denbigh, to the Town of Saint Asaph, in the County of Flint, is in a ruinous Condition, and in many Parts, narrow and incommodious for Carriages, and cannot be effectually amended, widened, and kept in Repair, by the ordinary Course of Law: And therefore praying, That Vol. 45.

Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering' and enlarging the Powers, of the above-mentioned Act, and for including therein the said Road leading from The Blue Hand to Pen j Palmant Gate, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet. m

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Williams, Mr. Wynn, &c.:

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Gilbert presented to the House, according to LaanTax Order, a Bill for appointing Commissioners to put in Commission Execution an Act of this Session of Parliament, inti- ers Bi® tuled, " An Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty, presented'

" by a Land Tax, to be raised in Great Britain, for " the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety," together with those named in Two former Acts for appointing Commissioners of the Land Tax: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Ordinary Estimate of His Majesty’s Navy, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of what may be necessary for the Buildings, Re-buildings, and Repairs of Ships of War, in his Majesty’s and the Merchants Yards, and other Extra Works, over and above what are proposed to be done upon the Heads of Wear and Tear and Ordinary, for the Year 179P, be referred to the said Committee.

A Motion being made, That the Report which was made from the Committee, who were appointed to prepare an Estimate of the Charge of the Pay and Clothing of the Militia, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, by His Majesty’s Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty recommends it to the House, to make such Provision for defraying the Charges of the Pay and Clothing of the Militia, for the Year 1790, as they shall think necessary.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert alsq acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

MaUdraeth, &c. Embanking and Drainage Petition reported.

196 1° — 2° MartS. . 1790.

The Order of the Day for the Call of the House being read;

Ordered, That the House be now called over.

The House was accordingly called over, and several of the Members appeared; and the Names of such Members as made Default to appear were taken down.

And the Names of the Defaulters being called over, several of them appeared, and several of them were excused, some upon Account of their own Illness, or of the Illness or Death of near Relations, or as being in Parts beyond the Seas, or employed Abroad on the Public Service.

Ordered, That the Names of such Members as have made Default to appear, and have not been excused, be again called over upon this Day Sevennight.

Mr. Bayly reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being interested in and entitled to Allotments of the Marsh called MaUdraeth and Corsddaugau, in the County of , was referred;

That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of 1774, relative to Bills of Drainage, had not been complied with, the Necessity of applying to Parliament, occasioned by the breaking and destroying of the Banks and other Works by the Sea, having happened late in the Month of October last, but that the Notices required by the said Standing Orders were given in the Months of November and December last; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as follorweth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for dividing, inclosing, embanking, draining, and preserving the said Marsh, and for other Purposes, was read, whereby it appeared that the Commissioners appointed for carrying the said Act into Execution were authorized to raise Money for defraying the Expences of the said Embankment and Drainage, by certain Rates or Dues to be collected for the Tonnage and Wharfage of Goods, Wares, and Commodities, conveyed upon the Cuts or Canals to be made for draining and preserving the said Marsh, and also by a Pound Rate or Assessment upon the Owners and Proprietors of the said Marsh: Then,

Thomas Williams, Esquire, being examined, said,

That the said Commissioners have expended the Sum of 6,000l. or thereabouts, in erecting a Bank, and other Works to prevent the said Lands being Overflowed by the Sea, but the same were washed down and destroyed by the High Tides, accompanied by uncommon High Winds, in October last — That the making a Bank of sufficient Height and Strength against the Sea, and such other Banks, Drains, and Works, as shall be necessary for the Preservation of the said Marsh, will be attended with a much greater Expence than was apprehended at the Time of passing the said Act, and that the Money authorized to be raised thereby will not be sufficient to defray such Expence — And the Witness added, That a considerable Quantity of the inclosed Lands and Grounds adjoining the said Marsh will be greatly improved by the effectual Embankment and Drainage of the said Marsh, and therefore it is thought reasonable that the Owners and Proprietors of such inclosed Lands and Grounds should contribute towards the Expence thereof.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for more effectually embanking the Marsh called MaUdraeth and Corsddaugau, in the County of and drain-

ing and preserving the same, and the inclosed low Lands

k

contiguous thereto: And that Mr. B*ykf and Mr. Gould do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Ordered, That the Bill to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating the " Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies " and Plantations in North America, and in the West " India Islands, and the Countries belonging to the " United States of America, and between His Majesty’s " said Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The " Indies and the other intituled, "An Act to allow " the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, from His Majesty’s Colonies, or Plantations in The West , " into the Province of Quebec,without Payment of Duty,

" under certain Conditions and Restrictions," be read a Second Time Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for taking off the Duties upon Unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good Hope, was committed, be received Tomorrow Morning.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

AP E TITIO N of the Lord Provost, Magistrates, and Council of the City of Edinburgh, for themselves, and on Behalf of the Community of the said City, and of the Proprietors and Inhabitants of the respective Counties of Edinburgh, Haddington, Linlithgow, Peebles, Fife, Stirling, and Clackmanon, thereunto subscribing, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That it is necessary to build a new Prison within or adjacent to the City of Edinburgh, for confining Criminals, and also a Prison for Debtors, and Persons guilty of petty Offences, and it is also become absolutely necessary to build a Bridewell, or House of Correction, within or adjacent to the said City, for the Punishment of idle, refractory, and profligate Persons within the said City, or within any of the aforesaid Seven Counties; and that a considerable Sum of Money will ’be necessary to be raised by Assessments for erecting those Buildings, as well as for a proper Establishment, and keeping them in Repair after they are built, and, in so far as concerns the said House of Correction, or Bridewell, and appointing Persons to be confined there, and transmitting them for that Purpose, it will be necessary to give additional Powers to the Sheriffs, Justices of the Peace, and Magistrates, within the aforesaid Counties: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for effecting the several Purposes before mentioned, in such Manner and under such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof, and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

And it is referred to Mr. Wetnyss, the Marquis of

A Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open and Common Fields, Meadows, Heath, and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Bowbrickhill and Hamlet of Fenny Stratford, in the County of Buckingham, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Bernard, Mr. Secretary Grenville, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Lionel Darner reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Trustees appointed to put in Execution an Act, made in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act " for amending, widening, altering, clearing, and " keeping in Repair, several Roads leading from the " Borough of Dorchester in the County of Dorset, and " for repealing so much of an Act, passed in the Sixth " Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, as relates to " the repairing the Road leading from Wool to the said " Borough," whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and thpt the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s T^ble: Where the same was read; and is as followeth;

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. John Templeman being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have borrowed the Sum of 1,750/., which, together with the Tolls collected, have been duly applied, but the Road by the said Act directed to be repaired .(except so much thereof as leads from the Parish of Warmwell, through the Parishes of and Osmngton, to the Church of Osmington, the Trus-

tees being discharged from the Repair thereof by an Act, made in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of His present Majesty,) cannot be sufficiently amended, and the Money borrowed re-paid, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act be further continued, and the said Act amended, and rendered more effectual.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of so much of an Act, made in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, as relates to the amending, widening, altering, clearing, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading from the Borough of Dorchester, in the County of Dorset: And that Mr. Lionel Darner and Mr. Ashley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Freeholders, and Manufacturers of the County and City of Worcester, and of several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; setting forth, That it appears by Levels and Surveys already taken, that a Navigable Cut or Canal for Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, may be 'made from or near to the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to join and communicate with the River Severn at or near a Place called Diglis, in or near to the City of Worcester; and that, by Means of such Cut or Canal, a better and more certain Communication than there is at present would be opened for the Conveyance of Goods and Merchandize between the Ports of Bristol and Hull, and also between Vol. 45.

the Town of Birmingham,the large Manufactories in the

Neighbourhood thereof, and the Cities of Worcester, Gloucester and Bristol, and the several other intermediate Parts; and the several Counties of Worcester, Gloucester, and Hereford, and other Counties and Places, would be supplied with Coals from the large and extensive Coal Mines, lying upon or near the Line of the said intended Canal, at an easier Expence, and in a more constant and regular Manner, than at present, and many other Benefits would result to the Public therefrom: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from or near to Birmingham aforesaid, to join and communicate with the said River Severn at or near Diglis aforesaid, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Lygon, Sir Robert Lawley, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of Thomas Lacy Dickonson, Esquire, Lord of the Manor of Clayworth, in the County of Nottingham, the Reverend Sir Richard Kaye, Baronet, Dean of Lincoln, Patron of the Rectory of Clayworth aforesaid, the Reverend William Dawson, Rector of the Parish and Parish Church of Clayworth aforesaid, and of Jonathan Acklom, Anthony Hartshome, and John Gylby, Esquires, Thomas Colton, Francis Otter, and John Otter, Gentlemen, and of the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Proprietors of Lands and Tenements within the Township and Parish of Clayworth aforesaid, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Township and Parish, several Open Arable Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and Waste Grounds, containing by Estimation Two thousand Acres, or thereabouts, which, in their present Situation, cannot be properly improved, but, if inclosed, regulated, and divided into specific Allotments, would be of much greater Advantage to the several Persons interested therein, as well as to the Public: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for those Purposes, under such Regulations as to the House shall seem requisite.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Pierrepont and Lord Edward Bentinck do prepare,

and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Merchants, Traders, and others, resident in and near the City of York, on Behalf of themselves and other Inhabitants of the said City and Neighbourhood, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for building a Bridge at or near the Ferry over the River Ousej from Selby, in the West Riding of the County of York, to the opposite Shore, in the Parish of Hemingborough, in the East Riding of the said County of York; and Setting forth, That York is a very ancient City, and the Number of Inhabitants resident therein, and in the Neighbourhood thereof, very considerable; and that the River Ouse has always been Navigable from the River Humber to the said City, and such Navigation has been improved, under the Authority of Parliament, at a great Expence, ever since, and probably before, the Reign of King Henry the Eighth, so as to render it safe and commodious for Vessels of considerable Burthen, by Means whereof the Petitioners can have their Merchandize and Commdities in the same.

3 E Bottoms

Clayworth

Inclosure

Petition.

Petition from York against Selby bridge Bil

198 2? Martii. A. 1T90.

Bottom* from London and every Part of the Coasts of Great Britain, and from most Foreign Port*; and that a Set of Vessels, from 100 to 140 Tons Burthen each, have been purposely built,' and have beeo for several Years past, and are now constantly employed in the Trade between London and York, and several other Vessels of as large Burthen are constantly employed in conveying Oak Timber from the said City of York, and other Places above Selby, to the City of London, to several of His Majesty’s Dock Yards, and to many other Ports and Places on the Sea Coasts of this Kingdom, and the said City of York, and a great Extent of Country for many Miles above the said City, are supplied with Coals, and chiefly with Lime, and all Sorts of Goods brought up the said River; and that the Petitioners apprehend the Navigation of the said River Ouse, and the Trade of the City of York, and all Places above Selby, will be materially injured by the Erection of any Bridge across the said River there, the Situation for which is very improper, the Course of the said River, above and near the said Town of Selby, being very crooked, the Current of Water rapid, and the Tide rising a considerable Heighth; and that several Vessels can now pass and re-pass, there at the same Time, whereas, if a Bridge is erected with One, or even Two Apertures, the Navigation will be greatly impeded, and rendered extremely dangerous for all Vessels navigating above Selby, which may frequently oblige the Traders of the City of York to change Bottoms, and have theiF Goods lightered up lor the Space of about Twenty-five Miles, the Distance between the City of York and Selby, by Water; that the Number of Vessels, constantly lost by the Erection of Bridges across Rivers-where the Tide runs so high and rapidly as at Selby, is considerable, and the Danger and Delay great, and in case of any Damage to their Goods the Traders of York would have great Difficulty to ascertain, with Precision, from whom to recover a Compensation for such Damage, which would not be the Case if their Goods were conveyed in One Bottom only, as at present; and that, at a General Meeting of Gentlemen, Land Owners, Merchants, Owners of Vessels, Tradesmen, Manufacturers, and others, held at Selby, in January >787, when an Application was intended to be made to Parliament for Power to build a Bridge over the River Ouse at Langrich, about Five Miles below Selby, it was resolved unanimously, " That it was the Opinion of " that Meeting, that such Bridge would not only bo " attended with the greatest Danger and Delay to the " Navigation of the said River, but would also be very " detrimental to the Trade of all other Navigations,

" frilling into, or connected therewith, and consequently to the Conveyance of Goods to and' from " London, Hull, and other Places, belonging to Merchants, Tradesmen, Manufacturers, and ethers, of the many great Trading Towns in the Counties of " York, Lancaster, and Westmoreland? and it was also resolved unanimously, " That it was the Opinion of " that Meeting, that the most effectual Measures " should be adopted for opposing such intended " Bridge;" and that most of the Persons, who now solicit Authority to build a Bridge at Selby, promoted and entered into the said Resolutions, but notwithstanding the Objections therein stated, which apply with equal, if not greater, Force to the Erection of a Bridge at Selby, the same Persona appear now to be desirous of erecting a Bridge at that Place, because the Inconvenience wiu be thereby removed' from- them, and thrown upon the Petitioners, with a View, no Doubt, to fix- the Trade at Selby below the said1 Bridge; although, jf any Bridge ought to be erected across the said River, it would' be likely to be of more Advantage to the Public at Langrich, than at Selby: And therefore praying; That they may- be beard1, by themselves or their Counsel1, against the said Bill, and that the

w

same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of the principal Inhabitants, Grocers, and Petition from Shopkeepers, in the Borough of Thirslc, was also pre- Thirsk seated to the House, and read; Likewise taking Notice of the said Bill: And praying, That the same may not pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and the first-mentioned Petitioners are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained- of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

A Petition of William Peachey, Esquire, Lord of ShiPton In-the Manor of Shipton Sollers, in the County of Glou- ®ure PetI" cester, and Jane West, Mother and Guardian of William Postumus Chapeau, a Minor, Lord of the Manor of Shipion Oliffe,in the same County, and Patrons of the United Rectories of Shipion and

Oliffe aforesaid, and Proprietors of the greatest Part of the Lands within the said Parishes, the Reverend John Chapeau, Rector of the said United Rectories, the Reverend John Hayward, Rector of the Parish of Withington, Thomas Barnjitld, John Wood, and others,

likewise Owners and Proprietors of Estates within the said Parishes of Shipton Sollers and Shipion Oliffe aforesaid, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said respective Manors and Parishes, several Common Fields, Meadows, Pastures, and Commons, which lie contiguously, containing about Two thousand Acres; and that the several Properties lie intermixed, and in their present State are incapable of any considerable Improvement, and it will be very advantageous to the several Proprietors to have the said Lands divided, exchanged, and inclosed: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a BHI for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Rules and Regulations as the House shall think proper.

Bristol- Gaol A Petition of the Mayor, Burgesses* and Competition. monalty, of the City of Bristol, under their Common Seal* was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth* That the public Gaol of the City of Bristol, and! County of the same City,- is too small, and not properly constructed for the Reception, Confinement, and Separation of the Prisoners, and it will be necessary to build a Gaol within the said City; and that the purchasing Ground necessary for erecting1 such Gaol, and building the same upon a Scale sufficiently large and commodious, will be attended with very considerable Ezpence, which cannot be provided for, nor can proper Regulations for the doe Management) of the' same, and for the Security and Preservation of the* Health of the Prisoners* be established and enforced, without the Authority of Parliament?: And therefore preying, That Leave nuy be given to bring in Bill for purchasing the necessary Ground for erecting the mid Gaol, for Yol. 45.

201

King George the Second, granting a Duty of Two Pennies on the Scots Pint of Ale brewed or consumed within the Liberties of the said Burgh, for the Purposes of building and keeping in Repair the said Harbour, which Duty was put under the Management of the Petitioners, as Trustees specially appointed for that Purpose, and of certain Persons as Overseers for inspecting their Accounts, and seeing the Money applied for the Purposes of the Act, which was renewed by another Act, passed in the Eighth Year of His present Majesty, continuing the said Duty for Twenty-live Years longer; and that those Funds for defraying the Expence of keeping up and repairing, &c. are defective and insufficient, and the said Harbour, of so great public Utility, cannot be maintained and preserved, and those useful and salutary Purposes accomplished, for Want of proper Powers and a sufficient Fund: And therefore praying for Leave to bring in a Bill for the Purposes before mentioned.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Henry Dundas, the Marquis of Graham, See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Balance of Cash which remained in the Treasury of the East India Company on the i st Day of March 1789, and of their Receipts and Payments in England from the 1st Day of March 1789 to the 1st Day of March 1790; together with an Estimate of the Receipts and Payments from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Sales of Good? from the East Indies, between the 1st Day of March 1789 and the 1st Day of March 1790, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize paid, or to be paid, thereout; together with an Estimate of the expected Sales of East India Goods, from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791, and the Amount of Customs, Freight; and Charges of Merchandize, to be paid thereout.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Sales of the Goods from China, between the 1st Day of March 1789 and the 1st Day of March 1790, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize paid, or to be paid, thereout; together with an Estimate of the expected Sales of China Goods, from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize, to be paid thereout.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, the Amount of the Bond and other Debts of the East India Company in Great Britain, as the same stood upon the

1st Day of March 1790.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House,' a Statement of the Debts of the East India Company (exclusive of the Debts transferred from ,agreeable to the Orders of the 15th of September 1785, and the 31st July 1787) and a Statement of the Effects of the Company in England, and a-float Outward, as they stood on the 1st Day of 1790; together

with an Account of the Balance of Quick Stock in China, according to the latest Advices.
