Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Report Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re- Supply, ferred to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Ordinary of That a Sum, not exceeding Seven hundred and Three thousand Two hundred and Seventy-six Pounds Seventeen Shillings and Eleven-pence, be granted to His Majesty, for the Ordinary of the "Navy, including Half Pay to Sea and Marine Officers, for the Year ,79°-

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Extra Navy, That a Sum, not exceeding Four hundred and Ninety thousand Three hundred and Sixty Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, towards the Buildings, Re-buildings, and Repairs of the Ships of War, in His Majesty’s Yards, and other Extra Works, over and above what are proposed to be done upon the Heads of Wear and Tear, and Ordinary, for the Year 1790.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, provision for That Provision be made for the Pay and Cloathing of Militia, the Militia for the Year 1790.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

A Bill for appointing Commissioners to put in Exe- Land Tax cution an Act of this Session of Parliament, intituled, Con""lS8,on* " An Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty, by a *Ued com* " Land Tax, to be raised in Great Britain, for the " Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety," together with those named in Two former Acts for appointing Commissioners of the Land Tax, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Fortnight, the 16th Day of this Instant March, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

Ordered, That the Knights of the Shires, and other Member* to Members of this House, do prepare Lists, fairly prepare Lists written, of the Names of additional Commissioners commission-for executing the said Act, for the respective Counties, ers Names. Cities, and Places, for which there have been used to be Commissioners; and that the Christian and Surnames of the said Commissioners be written at Length.

The House was moved. That the Resolutions of Resolutions the House, of the 31st Day of May 1786, relative to relative tode-delivering in Lists of Commissioners for executing any byeringinthe Land Tax Act, might be read. Lists, read.

And the same were read accordingly; and are as followeth; viz.

" Resolved, That, for the future, every List of " Commissioners for executing any Land Tax Act " shall be delivered in signed by the Member delivering in the same, that the said List be carefully " kept by the Officer td whom the same shall be intrusted, and that no Person whatever do presume " to make any Alteration in such List, without the " Order of this House, or of a Committee thereof."

" Resolved, That every Member delivering in such " List, shall, at the Time of the Delivery thereof,

" sign and deliver a Duplicate thereof, which Duplicate shall be kept upon a File, open to the Inspection of any Member of this House."

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Tin Bill

Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for reported.

A. 1790.

taking off the Duties, upon Uawrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good Hope, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Tlace; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were, with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Sir George Howard presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for naturalizing Franfoise Antoinette De Luc: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Message from the Lords by Mr. Pepys and Walker:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled,

Act for naturalizing Noah Turmine; without Amendment: And also.

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled,

Act for dividing and allotting the intermixed or Commonable Lands and Grounds, and Common Pastures or Waste Grounds, within the Manor and Parish of Dib-den, in the County of Southampton; with an Amendment; to which Amendment the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Petition from Hull re-

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereto subscribed, being the Principal Owners of Confiscation Ships and Vessels belonging to the Port of Kingston of Ship*. upon Hull, on Behalf of themselves, and all others concerned in Ships and Vessels employed in the Foreign Mercantile Trade from and to the said Port, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That most of the Acts, which have of late passed for the Suppression of Smuggling, expose the Ships of the fair and open Mercantile Trader to Forfeiture on there being found therein any inconsiderable Quantities of Foreign Spirituous Liquors, Tea, Coffee, or other Goods, above the Quantity allowed by Law, notwithstanding such Goods are clandestinely brought on Board by the Seamen belonging to such Ships, contrary to the express Directions of the Owners and Masters thereof, and though there has not been in any Degree a Want of due Care and Diligence in such Owners or Masters to prevent every illicit Practice; and, by an Act of the Twenty-sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, Ships of every Description, and be their Burthen or Value ever so great,

wherein is imported any Foreign Spirituous Liquors (British Plantation Ruin and Arrack excepted) in any Cask containing less than One hundred Gallons, except Two Gallons for each Seaman, with all their Stores and Furniture, are declared to be forfeited; and that neither the Act of the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty for securing the Property of the Owners in such Ships or Vessels as are liable to Forfeiture for importing Spirits, or other Goods, by the Misconduct of the Masters, Mates, and Seamen, the Second Section of the Act of the Twenty-fourth Year of His present Majesty, admitting Evidence to be given in Extenuation of the Charge of Smuggling, nor the Power of Mitigation, said to be entrusted with the Commissioners of the Customs and Excise, afford either effectual Security, or adequate Indemnity, to the unoffending Ship Owner, for though the Ships of the fair Trader are not in every Instance prosecuted to Condemnation, they are seized for having the most trivial Quantities of Contraband Goods on Board, and are frequently for a long Time withheld from the innocent Owners, who, beside losing the Use of their valuable Property, and, as it often happens, their only Means of Support, are put to very heavy and disproportioned Fines, Fees, and Impositions, and suffer other Loss, Expence, and Trouble, in obtaining the Release of such Ships, and are left without being able to obtain any Remedy over against the Persons guilty, Owners not daring, from the Hazard such a Prosecution would involve them in, to proceed for the Recovery of the Penalty imposed on the Master, Mate, and Seamen, by the former of the last mentioned Acts; and that the Petitioners, fully sensible of the Necessity of preventing Smuggling, and of enforcing the Laws for raising Revenues for the Exigencies of the State, are willing not only to suffer the utmost Rigour of those Laws in case of they themselves directly or indirectly conniving at any illicit Trade, but are ready, even though innocent of any Offence, where the Offender cannot be immediately discovered, to be answerable for such a Forfeiture as may be proportioned to the Quantity of the Goods seized, they having Authority to reimburse themselves, as far as may be, out of the Wages due from the Owners to the Persons most likely to be guilty. — As such, and understanding it has been ever held incompatible with the Spirit of the British Constitution and Laws to punish one Person, and that too in the most summary Way, for the Offence of another, who, as in the present Instance, it is not in his Power effectually to prevent offending, the Petitioners cannot but feel themselves as labouring under more cruel Oppressions and Hardships than any other Branch of Trade whatever, and' they conceive the Severity of the Laws alluded to must soon have the roost prejudicial Effect: on the Trade and Commerce of this Country: And therefore praying, That the House will take the aforesaid Laws, and the Hardships they impose upon the Petitioners, into Consideration, and that Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to repeal so much or such Clauses of the before mentioned Acts, of Parliament as expose Ships employed in an open and fair Mercantile Trade to Confiscation, or to grant the Petitioners such other Relief as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

The other Order of the Day being read;

The Bill to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign: of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s; Colonies and " Plantations in North America, and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of America, and between His Majesty’s said

" Subjects

Ordered, That Mr. Fox have Leave to make a Motion, it being Half an Hour after Four of the Clock.

And he moved the House accordingly: And,

An Act, made in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of King Charles the Second, intituled, "An Act for " the well-governing and regulating of Corporations and also, an Act, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of King Charles the Second, intituled, "An Act for preventing Dangers which may happen from " Popish llecusants," were read.

And a Motion being made, and the Question being put. That this House will resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of so much of the said Acts as requires Persons, before they are admitted into any Office or Place in Corporations, or having accepted any Office, Civil or Military, or any Place of Trust under the Crown, to receive the Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the Rites of the Church of England;

The House divided.

SI R Thomas Dundas reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereto subscribed," all Freeholders and Land Owners in the Counties of Stirling and Dumbarton, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, a Member present informed your Committee, That the Road from Kirkintilloch to Springfield , and from thence, by or near Balwarridge House, to Muckroft Vol. 45.

Bridge, over the Rivulet Gldssert, and from thence, by the present Line of Road through the Village of New Barbrestoun to the Foot of the Craw Road, from thence, by Fintry, to the Military Road at or near the Town

of Kippen, through the Parishes of Campsie, Fintry,

Balfrone, and Kippen, in the County of Stirling; and from the said Military Road between Balwell and Balfunning, to Killearn, and from thence to -

blane, by or near the Church of Strathblane, and to Milngavie and Garscube Bridge, and from thence to New Kilpatrick and Drymen Bridge, through the Parishes of New Kilpatrick (Part thereof in the County of Dumbarton)Raider nodi, Strathblane, Killearn,

Balfrone, and Drymen, in the County of Stirling, and Kilmaronock, in the County of Dumbarton, with the Bridges of the said Roads, are at present in a ruinous Condition, and during bad Weather, are in many Parts impassable for Wheel Carriages; and the Lines of Direction of the same, in several Places, require to be altered, which cannot be done, nor can the said Roads be repaired, amended, and kept in Repair, by the Laws now in Force.

Ordered, That Leave be given to' bring in a Bill for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Stirling and Dumbarton: And that Sir Thomas Dundas, the Marquis of Graham, Sir Archibald Edmonstone, and Colonel Dundas, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Sir Thomas Dundas reported from the Committee, Edinburgh to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose and Stirling Names are thereto subscribed, being Trustees named ,<oads Pe|'* and appointed by and in virtue of Two several Acts, ,onr P° passed in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of his late Majesty’s Reign, thereinafter more particularly mentioned, and others, Land Owners within the County of Stirling, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in1 his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act, passed in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing the Post Road from the City of Edinburgh, through the Counties of Lin-Uthgow and Stirling, from the Boathouse Ford on Almond Water, and from thence to the Town of Linlithgow, and from the said Town to Falkirk, and also from Falkirk to Kilsyth and to Inch-bellie Bridge, on the Post Road to the City of Glasgow; and also an Act, passed in the Thirty-first Year of the Reign of his said late Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers of the said Act, were read: And,

A Member present informed your Committee, That the Trustees named in the said Acts have borrowed several considerable Sums, of Money, which have been laid out in the Repair of the said Roads, which Money cannot be, repaid, nor the Roads kept in sufficient Repair, unless the Terms and Powers granted by the said Two Acts are further continued and enlarged- —

And he added; That it is thought expedient by the Trustees, that the Turnpike ! Roads and Tolls of the said Two Countieji of Stirling and Ihdilhgow, which were included and comprehended hi both the said Acts, and under, thie Directions of jthe same Trustees, should be separated and disjoined* and put under the separate Management of the Trustees of the respective Counties in attach < such Roads lie and are’ situated.

A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Forth and Clyde Navigation, and the Company of Proprietors of the Monkland Navigation, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act, made in the Eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for making and

" maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from the " Frith or River of forth, at or near the River of " Carron, in the County of , to the Frith or

" River of Clyde, at or near a Place called Dalmuir " Bumfoot,in the County of Dumbarton, and also a

" Collateral Cut from the same to the City of " gow, and for making a Navigable Cut or Canal

" of Communication from the Port or Harbour of " Barrmstounness, to join the said Canal, at or near " the Place where it will fall into the Frith of Forth," the Company , of Proprietors of the Forth and Clyde Navigation were incorporated for the Purpose of making, completing, and maintaining a Cut or Canal from the Frith or River of Forth, to the Frith or River of Clyde, with sundry Powers, and under certain Orders and Regulations therein particularly mentioned, which Act was further explained, enlarged, and amended by several subsequent Acts, passed in the Eleventh, Thirteenth, Twenty-fourth, and Twenty-seventh Years of His present Majesty’s Reign, and, under the Powers thereby given, the main Line of the Forth and Clyde Navigation is now nearly finished, and a Collateral Cut is made from the same to a Place called Hamilton Hill, within about a Mile of the City of Glasgow’, and that by another Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for making and maintaining a Navi-M gable Cut or Canal, and Waggon Way from the " Collieries in the Parishes of Old and New Monkland,

" to the City of Glasgow,"the Petitioners the Company of Proprietors of the Monkland Navigation were also incorporated for the Purpose of making and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal, of the Dimensions therein specified, from a Place called The Sheepford, in the Parish of Old Monkland, and County of Lanerk, to or near the City of Glasgow, in which Work great Progress has also been made; and that the Petitioners are now desirous to have a Junction formed between the Two Canals, and it would be highly beneficial to the Public at large if the Company of Proprietors of the Forth and Clyde Navigation were empowered to carry on their Collateral Cut from Hamilton Hill to the West End of the Monkland Canal, at or near the Townhead of the City of Glasgow, to purchase Lands for making a Harbour and Bason at or near a Place called Hundred Acre Hill, and for building Houses and Warehouses for the Accommodation of Merchants, and others resorting thereto, and to open Roads, Lanes, and Passages leading from the same to the City of Glasgow; and that, in order to supply both

Navigations with Water, and for completing the same, it is become necessary that the Monkland Canal should be extended from the Sheepford to the River Gaidar, that the before-recited Acts relative to both

Companies should be further explained, amended, enlarged, extended, and rendered more effectual, and more ample, and other Powers given to the Petitioners respectively, to finish the Works in which they are engaged: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the above and other Purposes, under such Rules and Regulations as to the/ House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do' examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir T Dundas, Sir Archibald Edmonstone, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Sir William Cunynghame reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several of the Trustees, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, appointed by virtue of Two Acts of Parliament, passed in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for repairing sundry Roads therein mentioned, passing through the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 2^th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act, passed in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing the Post Road from the City of Edinburgh through the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, from the Boathouse Ford on Almond Water, and from thence to the Town of Linlithgow; and from the said Town to Falkirk; and also from Falkirk to Kilsyth, and to Inch-bellie Bridge, on the Post Road to the City of Glasgow, and also an Act passed in the Thirty-first Year of the Reign of his said late Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers of the said Act, were read: And,

A Member present informed your Committee, That it is judged expedient, and would more effectually promote the repairing, and keeping in Repair, the Roads in the aforesaid Two Acts mentioned, if the said Trust was separated and divided, and that the Tolls levied on such Parts of the aforesaid Roads as lie within the County of Linlithgow be applied to the making, repairing, and widening the same, and be put under the sole and separate Direction and Management of the Trustees connected with the said County of Linlithgowj and that the Tolls levied on such Parts of the said Roads as lie within the County of Stirling should be applied to the making, repairing, and widening the same, and be put under the sole and separate Direction and Management of the Trustees connected with the said County of Stirling. — That the Road extending from Carlourie Bridge, formerly the Boathouse Ford, on Almond Water, to the Burgh of Linlithgow, and from thence to Linlithgow Bridge, upon the Water of Avon (being Part of the Roads comprehended in the said Two former Acts) lie within the County of Linlithgow» and the making, repairing, and widening thereof, and the Tolls to be levied thereon, ought to be put under the sole and separate Direction and Management of Trustees, Landholders in, or otherwise connected: with, the said County of Linlithgow.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the

Vol. 45.

County of Linlithgow: And that Sir William Cunynghame and Major Moore do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Inhabitants of the Town and Bo- Lewes Mar-rough of Lewes, in the County of Sussex, was presented kets *et't'0D‘ to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners at present enjoy, by Prescription, a Market for Provisions within the said Town and Borough, but the same is too small for their Accommodation, and the Powers thereof too contracted, and the Place where the same is now held is so situated as not to admit of any Enlargement; and that they labour under very

treat Inconveniences in not having a Market for Live tock within the said Borough, which, if instituted, would tend greatly to their Benefit and Advantage: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging and extending the Powers of the present prescriptive Market within the said Town and Borough, and removing the same to another convenient Place within the said Town and Borough of Lewes, or within the Precinct of the Castle of Lewes aforesaid, and also for holding a Market within the Districts aforesaid, for Live Cattle.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

And it is referred to Mr. Kempe, 'Mr. Pelham, &c.:

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of Henry Weston, of Fletching, in the Mr. Weston’s County of Sussex, Miller, was presented to the House, Petition and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the River cuckfield Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, Navigation to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to Bill-the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and the several Branches of the said River, all in the County of Sussex; and Setting forth, That the Petitioner is the Owner and Occupier of a Water Corn Mill, in the Parish of Fletching, in the County of Sussex, situate on the River Ouse, between Lewes and Cuckfield, and hath laid out at different Times, considerable Sums of Money in respect of the said Mill, and in procuring a proper Supply of Water for the Working thereof, and the same is wholly supplied by certain Streams, which, by the said Bill, appear to be intended to be made Navigable, and which Streams are frequently, in dry Seasons, insufficient to keep the said Mill in constant Work; and that the Petitioner hath been informed it is the Intention to erect new Locks across the said Streams, for letting Boats, Barges, Lighters, and other Craft, up and down the said River, by which, and by the said Navigation, the Petitioner is likely to be injured in his Property and Trade: And therefore praying, That he may be heard, by himself or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect his Property and Trade; and that the Petitioner may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall appear just and reasonable.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioner be heard, by himself or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon his Petition, if he thinks fit

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Bath Streets Petition.

Road and Langham Inclosure Petition.

206 4 M A. 1790.

was presented to (be House, and read; Setting forth, That, in the Year 1785, the Steeple of the Church of the said Parish suddenly gave way, and falling upon the Body of the Church, entirely demolished the same, so that no Divine Worship has since been performed therein^ and that the Inhabitants of the said Parish have exerted their utmost Endeavours to rebuild the said Church, but find they cannot raise Money sufficient to effectuate the Purpose without the Authority of Parliament: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill in order to enable them to raise a Rate among themselves, for the Purpose of re-building the said Church.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Medley, Lord George Henry Lenox, See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of several of the Commissioners for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, and other Places, in the City of Bath, and the Liberties thereof, and for removing and preventing Nuisances and Obstructions therein, and of the several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Inhabitants of the said City and Liberties, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for removing and regulating the public Markets in the City of Bath, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, certain Provisions were made, and Powers and Authorities given, for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, Passages, and other Places, within the said City, and the Liberties and Precincts thereof, and removing and preventing Nuisances and Obstructions therein, which Provisions, Powers, and Authorities, have been found in many Respects defective, and insufficient to answer the Purposes thereby intended; and that it is necessary, for the Safety and Accommodation of the Inhabitants of the said City, Liberties, and Precincts, and of Persons resorting thereto, that the said Provisions, Powers, and Authorities, should be explained, amended, and rendered more effectual, and extended to certain new Streets, and other Places, made, and to be made, and laid out, in the said City and Liberties, and the Vicinity thereof, or else that the same should be wholly repealed, and other Powers and Provisions granted in Lieu thereof, and extended to the said new and intended new Streets, and other Places aforesaid: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to explain, amend, extend, and render more effectual, the said Powers of the said Act, or to repeal the same, and grant others in Lieu thereof, in such Manner, and under such Restrictions and Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same* as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. P the Lord Bayham, See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Narttos are thereunto subscribed, who claim to be entitled to Rights of Common, and other Rights and Interests, on Part of a certain Common, or Waste Land, lying within the Manor of Road and Langham, in the

Counties of Somerset and Wilts, was presented to the House,’and readSettling forth, That there is Part of a certain Common, or Waste Land, called Rood mon, lying within, and Part Of, the Manor of Road and

Langham,in the Parishes of Road and North Bradley, in the Counties of Somerset and Wilts, or One of them, containing, by Estimation, about 500 Acres; and that it will not only be of great Benefit and Advantage to the Petitioners, and all Persons interested in the said Part of the said Common or Waste Land (which is now wholly uncultivated, and subject to Trespasses) but to the Public at large, if the same was properly divided and inclosed: And therefore praying,

That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the same, and for allotting specific Parts and Shares thereof to the Petitioners, and the other Persons interested therein, in Proportion to their several Rights and Interests of and in the said Part of the said Common, or Waste Land, in such Manner, and with such Restrictions, as to the House shall seem meet and right.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr.

Phelips, and Sir John Trevelyan do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Proprietors of certain Works Bradford and made for the supplying the Towns of Bradford and Hortou \v». Horton, in the County of York, with Water, was pre- £rw0lks sen ted to the House, and read; Setting forth, That retltl0D the Petitioners are Proprietors of certain Works which have been, at a great Expence, made for supplying the said Towns with Spring Water; and that the said Works have been and now are, of great Use and Benefit to the Inhabitants of the said Towns; that they are often injured, and the Water conducted thereby is much wasted, to the great Inconvenience of some Part of the said Inhabitants, and Loss to the said Proprietors; and the said Proprietors are frequently deprived of the Rents (which are in general very small) agreed to be paid for such Water; and that the said Works, under proper Regulations and Powers, might be very much improved, and the Water conveyed thereby preserved pure and clear: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for preserving and protecting the said Water WorkB, and regulating the same, and for the better securing the Payment of the Rents thereof, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Duncottobe, Mr.

force, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers* and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names Petition (mm are thereunto Subscribed, Owners of Lands in, and Barlby, Inhabitants of, the several Towns of Barlby, Osgodby,

Lund, Cliff, North Dttffield, South Duffidd, and Riccall,

near Selby, in the County of York, wa6 presented to the House, and read j Taking Notice of the Bill for building a Bridge at or near the Ferry over the River Ouse, from Selby, in the West Riding of the County of York, to the opposite Shore, in the Parish of Hemingborough, in the East Riding of the said County of York; and Setting forth, That the Inhabitants of the several Places above-mentioned are entitled to pass and re-pass over the Ferry at or near Selby for small Payments or Acknowledgments Yearly, and such Ferry is safe and commodious, and very sufficient to answer all the Purposes of Communication in that Part of the Country; and that, if i Bridge should be S " erected

erected over the RiVer Ouse there, find the Petitioners shade subject to 'the Payment of Toll every Day on tohdch they may have Occasion to pass over the same, it will affect and materially injure their Rights, and be an unnecessary and expensive Burthen upon them, and they are informed it is also proposed to subject them to other Restraints in the Use of the said River, contiguous to their respective Estates; and that no Communication towards HuU or any principal Town in the East Riding of Yorkshire, in any respect likely to be of general Use, or public Utility, can be effected by any such Bridge, because there are no direct Roads from Selby to those Places, nor any Materials to be procured to make Roads, or repair those already made, except at a great Distance and very considerable Expence, and it would also be requisite to build another Bridge over the River Derwent, in the Tideway of that River, and, if it were the Intention of the Promoters of a Bridge at Selby to procure any such proposed Advantage to the Public, the Petitioners apprehend it is incumbent upon them to bring forward a Plan for effecting every Thing requisite to attain that End at the same Time, in order that the whole Extent of the supposed Benefit on the one Hand, and the inevitable Expence and Mischief on the other, may be compared and considered together: And. therefore praying, That the said Ferry may remain in its present State, that the Right of the Petitioners to pass over the same may not be varied or affected, that the said Bill may not pass into a Law, or that they may have such other Relief in the Premises, as to the House shall seem meet.

Petition A Petition of several Persons whose Names are

against Selby thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and Bridge Bill. others, Owners and Proprietors of Lands and Tenements adjoining on, or lying contiguous to, each Side of the River Ouse, between the Town of Selby, in the County of York, and the City of York, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners are Owners and Proprietors of large Tracts of Land, adjoining upon, or near to, the Banks on each Side of the said River, between the Town of Selby and the said City of York, which, in the Winter Season, are constantly much damaged by being overflowed with Water from the said River, and the Banks against the same, which are composed of Earth only, and in many Places very high, and supported at a great annual Expence, are often injured and broken down by the Overflowing of the said River; and that the Petitioners conceive that, if such Bridge be erected, it will constantly be the Cause of greatly interrupting the free Course of the Current of Water in the said River, and more particularly on the breaking up of Frosts, when there are large Sheets of Ice, whereby the Embankments on such River will be materially injured, and much more liable to be overflowed, and in greater Danger of being broken down than at present, to the great Injury and Prejudice of the respective Estates, of the Petitioners and others, by Reason of such Estates (which contain many thousand Acres of cultivated Land) being Overflowed, and by the enormous Expence that the Petitioners and others would unavoidably be put to in the necessary Repairs of the said Banks: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves Of their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such Relief in the Premises as to the Hbuse shall seem meet.

Petition from A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Matters of thereunto Subscribed, Owners or Masters of Ships Ship* apart and Vessels used and employed on the Navigation of 1 ‘ the River Ouse, in the County of York, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking. Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Naviga-Vot. 45.

tion of the said River hath been improved, at a considerable Expence, by the Trustees thereof, and is rendered Safe and Commodious, and sufficient to admit Vessels of 120 Tons, and upwards, to the City of York, and such Vessels may be safely navigated to all Parti of the Kingdom, and to Foreign Ports; and that the said Navigation hath been for Time immemorial, and now is, open and free to all Persons, and the Tonnage Dues are extremely low, and the City of York, and the Towns of Tadcaster, Wetherby,

Knaresborough, Ripon, Masham, Richmond, Bedale,

Thirsk, Easingwould, Helmsley, Blackmoor, Kirby-moorside, and a very large Extent of the adjacent Country (which is well cultivated and populous) are supplied with Goods and Merchandize by Means of the said Navigation, and the City of York, and its extensive Neighbourhood, and many other Places, are also thereby wholly supplied with Coals, Lime, and many other Articles, from the West Riding of Yorkshire; and that the Quantity of Lime and Coals, constantly carried up the said Navigation, to be used in and near the above Places, is very considerable, and the Value of the Timber, Lead, Butter, Bacon, and other Articles taken in Return, amounts to a great Sum Annually; and that many of the Petitioners have expended considerable Sums, and others their whole Property, in purchasing Vessels and fitting up the same, to navigate on the said River, and the Maintenance of themselves and Families greatly depends upon the Safety and Success of their Employment therein; and the Petitioners being fully convinced that such Bridge will obstruct and materially prejudice the Navigation of the said River, are alarmed for the Consequences, as it will certainly occasion great Delay, and be very dangerous, to all Vessels passing the said Bridge, particularly those which are deeply loaded, and not in the best Condition, many of which are employed in the Coal Trade, and, should any of them run against the Bridge, which must sometimes unavoidably happen, the Petitioners Vessels, and their Cargoes, will be in the utmost Danger of being totally lost, and by any such Loss the Navigation will be liable to be entirely obstructed for a considerable Time, because the Bridge will confine the Passage of Vessels to one Aperture only, and it is found, by fatal Experience, that Numbers of Vessels are constantly lost wherever Bridges have been erected across Rivers in the Tideways; besides, the Petitioners are informed, it is intended to subject them to expensive Suits, by an opulent Body of Proprietors, for Damages done to the Bridge by the Carelessness or Negligence of their Servants, when the Fact may be so doubtful as not to be determined but by the Verdict of a Jury, and therefore the Petitioners must either submit in the First Instance, or risque the Expence of a Trial; and that, besides the Hazard and Mischief above specified, the River at Selby is crooked and narrow, the Banks dangerous, the Anchorage bad, and the Tide rises high, and runs rapidly, all which render it difficult to'bring Vessels up, either by running them aground, anchoring, or getting Ropes on Shore, and in Spring Tides, particularly, every Vessel ought to bring up and approach the Bridge Stem foremost, to pass with the least Degree of Safety: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of the Merchants, Traders, Shopkeepers, Petition from and other Inhabitants of the Town of Tadcaster, as Tad.ca®t£r,lk well within the West Riding of the County of York, 5fr"d"ge jjhi/ as within the County of the City of York, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth. That the Town of Tadcaster is situate on the Banks of the River

fVharfe,

JVharfe, which communicates with the River Ouse, about Six Miles above Selby, and is Navigable, from its Junction with the River Ouse, to the Town of Tadcasteraforesaid; and that the Petitioners have their Goods Water-borne on the said Rivers to a very

f eat Amount, and derive great Benefit by their rade on such Rivers, and are greatly alarmed at the inevitable Delay and Danger the Navigation of the River Ouse must receive from so great an Impediment as the Erection of a Bridge in the Tideway thereof at Selby, where the Foreshores and Anchorage are bad, and at the Injury they must consequently suffer in their Trade: And therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, but that the Navigation of the said River Ouse may be preserved in its present State, free and uninterrupted, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief as to the House shall seem meet

Petition A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are

against Selby thereunto subscribed, Trustees for improving the Na- Bridge Bill, vigation of the River Ouse, an the County of York, on Behalf of themselves and the other Trustees of the said Navigation, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That by virtue of Two Acts, passed in the Thirteenth Year of King George the First, and the Fifth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, the said Trustees were authorized to make the said River Ouse more Navigable for Ships and other Vessels, and to remove all Gravel Beds, and other Impediments whatsoever, which may hinder the Navigation, either in sailing, or hauling Ships or Vessels upon the said River, and are entitled to receive divers Tolls for Goods and Merchandize conveyed upon the said River above a Place called Mouth; and that the said Navigation hath been improved at a very considerable Expence, and particularly by the Erection of a very expensive Lock and Dam, at the Distance of about Five Miles by Water from the said City, in order to raise the Water in that Part of the River above the said Lock and Dam, and the Tide flows up to the said Dam, so that Vessels of considerable Burthen can safely navigate from the Sea to the said City; apd that many Parts of the said River, below the said Lock and Dam, are so shallow, that any Interruption to the free Course of the Tide would materially prejudice the said Navigation, and occasion great Expence in deepening the same; and that about 1,900 Vessels pass through the said Lock to York Annually, and return through the same, and the Petitioners apprehend the Erection of any Bridge at or near Selby would not only materially interrupt and stop the free Course of the Tide, but would also be very dangerous and occasion great Delay to all Ships and Vessels having Occasion to pass through the same, and would materially affect the Trade upon the said River above Selby, and greatly decrease the Tolls,

- which the Petitioners are authorized to take, as Trustees of the said Navigation: And therefore praying, That the Rights and Interests of the Petitioners may be preserved, that they may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Petition A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are

against D* thereto subscribed. Commissioners for making navi-Bl ' gable and improving the River Ouse, from below

JViddington Ings, at or near Linton, to the Junction of the Rivers Szvale and Ure, in the North Riding of the County of York, on Behalf of themselves, and the other Commissioners of the said Navigation, and also on Behalf of the several Proprietors of the said Navigation, was likewise presented to the House, and read; also taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth. That, by virtue of an Act, passed in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners were authorized to make the River Ouse, from below Widdington Ings aforesaid, to the Junction of the River Swale and Ure, more navigable, and to remove all Gravel Beds, and other Impediments whatsoever, which may hinder the said Navigation, either in Sailing, Haling, or Towing of Keels or Vessels upon the said River, and are entitled to receive divers Tolls for Goods and Merchandize conveyed upon the said River from below JViddington Ings, and the said Navigation hath been greatly improved, particularly by the Erection of a Lock and Dam near Linton, in the Coupty of York, and in such Improvements very large Sums of Money have been expended; and that about 900 Vessels pass through the said Lock from York Annually, and return through the same, and the Petitioners apprehend the Erection of any Bridge at or near Selby would not only materially interrupt the free

Passage of the said River, but would also occasion great Delay and imminent Danger to all Vessels navigating upon the River above Selby, and would materially affect the Trade upon that Part of the said River which is under the Management and Direction of the Petitioners, and greatly decrease the Tolls which they are authorized to take by the said Act: And therefore praying, That the Rights and Interests of the Petitioners may be preserved, that they may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and such of the Petitioners as desire to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, are to be then heard by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

A Petition of the Mayor, Aldermen, Bridgemen, and Henley upon Burgesses, of the Town of Henley upon Thames, in Than»e*Poor, the County of Oxford, and of the Churchwardens and &c. Petition. Overseers of the Poor, and other Inhabitants, of the same Town and Parish of Henley upon Thames, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Poor of the said Town and Parish are very numerous, and are supported at a great Expence, and the House appointed for their Reception is much too small and inconvenient, from its confined State in the Centre of the Town, and is rented at a very considerable Expence, besides which, many Cottages are obliged to be rented for the Reception of such Poor; and that the granting proper Powers for governing, maintaining, and regulating the said Poor, and providing a proper Place for their Reception, will tend to the more effectual Relief of such as, by Age and Infirmities, are rendered incapable of supporting themselves by their Labour, to the better Employment of the Able and Industrious, to the proper Correction and Punishment of the Profligate and Idle, and to the Education of Poor Children in Religion and Industry, whereby the said Poor, instead of being wholly supported by the Inhabitants of the said Town and Parish, and being suffered to live in Idleness and Debauchery, may be brought to contribute to the Support and Relief mutually of each other, and be of some Advantage and Credit to the Community; and that the Corporation of the said Town, for the Time being, are seised, in Trust for the Poor of the said Town and Parish, of the Fee Simple and Inheritance of a Piece of Ground, called The Poor's Land, containing, by Estimation, about Three Acres, situate on the North Side of a certain Street in the said Town,

in the County of Lancaster, together with the Trustees of several lands appropriated to the Use of the Poor within the said Township, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That from the present great Populousness of the Town of Salford, and the Daily Increase of the Poor belonging to that Township, the Poor House now used there is found much too small, and in all Respects unfit for the due Accommodation of the Poor; and that a new Poor House, or House of Industry, is necessary, and further Regulations are wanting for the better Government of the Poor within the said Township: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes above-mentioned.

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and principal Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, on Behalf of themselves, and others, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Great Western Road from London, and from Portsmouth to Exeter and Plymouth, and to Falmouth, and other Parts of Cornwall, is through the Town of Honiton, and there are now standing, in the Middle of the High Street of the said Town, a large old Building, called The Shambles, and certain Dwelling Houses contiguous thereto; and that the Entrance into, and Passage through the said Town, are very inconvenient, and the Streets of the said Town are badly paved, not kept cleaned, and are not lighted in the Night, and there are many Nuisances, Annoyances, and Encroachments in the said Streets, by all which a very great Inconvenience arises to the said Inhabitants, and the Passage through the said Town is greatly obstructed, and rendered very incom-.modious and dangerous to Travelling, and the remedying those Evils will be of great Service to the Inhabitants of the said Town, and to all other Persons resorting the reto: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making the Entrance into, and Passage through, the said Town more convenient, to take down the said Buildings, to clean, pave, and light the said Streets, and to remove such Nuisances, Annoyances, and Encroachments, and to enable them to raise Monies for defraying the Expences attending the same, and for indemnifying and making an adequate Satisfaction to any Person or Persons whose Property may be thereby effected, and for such other Relief in the Premises as the House shall think expedient.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the Hbuse:

And it is referred to Mr. Secretary at War, Mr. Rolle, Scc.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of several Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the Justices, Gentlemen, Clergy, and Freeholders, of the County of Warwick, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Town of Birmingham, in the said County, is become very large and populous, and from the great Number of

Felonies, and other Offences, committed within the said Town, the Maintenance and Prosecution of the Prisoners sent from thence to the County Gaol has very considerably increased the County Rate, which is become a heavy Burthen upon the other Parts of the said County, and by Reason of the great Number of Prisoners sent to the Gaol of the said County, for Offences committed within the said Town, it is found necessary forthwith to enlarge the said Gaol, which will be attended with a very considerable Expence to the County at large; and that the stud Town is rateable only in the same Manner it has heretofore been, which is greatly below its fair and equal Proportion: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for relieving the County, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, Sir Robert Lawley, c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Mayor, Jurats, and Commonalty, Deal Paving and other Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Petition. Deal, in the County of Kent, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, that the Highways,

Streets, and Lanes, within the said Town, are not properly repaired, paved, and cleansed, and, on account of various Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances, the same are rendered very unsafe, dangerous, and incommodious; and that it would conduce very much to the Benefit, Convenience, and Safety, of the Petitioners, and all Persons resorting to the said Town, if the said Highways,

Streets, and Lanes, were properly repaired, paved, and cleansed: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, with such Powers and Authorities, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Charles Robinson, Mr.

Brett, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Lygon reported from the Committee, to whom Birmingham the Petition of the several Noblemen, and the humble and Wor* Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Free-holders, and Manufacturers, of the County and City reported, of Worcester, and of several other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

John Snape,an Engineer and Surveyor, being examined, said, That he hath taken Levels and Surveys, whereby it appears, That a Navigable Cut or Canal for Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, may be made

from

from or near the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to join and communicate with the River Severn at or near a Place called Diglis, in or near the City of Worcester; and that by Means of such Cut or Canal, a better and more certain Communication will be opened for the Conveyance of Goods and Merchandize between the Ports of and Hull, and

also between the Town of Birmingham, the large Manufactories in the Neighbourhood thereof, and the Cities of Worcester, Gloucester, and Bristol, and the several other intermediate Parts — That the several Counties of Worcester, Gloucester, and Hereford, and other Counties and Places, will be supplied with Coals from the large and extensive Coal Mines lying upon or near the Line of the said intended Canal, at an easier Expence, and in a more constant and regular Manner, than at present, and many other Benefits will result to the Public therefrom.

And being asked, Whether there is any Water Carriage on the whole Line of this Canal, between Birmingham and Worcester? he said, There is not.

And being asked, Whether he thinks there will be a better Corntnunication by Means of this Canal ? he said, There will; and that it will be a nearer Way than the other Water Carriage between Birmingham and Worcester, whereby Worcester will be better supplied with Coals — That there are no Coal Mines on the intended Line of this Canal, or nearer than Oldbury, at which Place there are now some Pits opening.

And being asked, What Part of this Canal he calls the Summit, and what the Extent of the Summit ? he replied. The Part between Tardebigg, being in Length about Sixteen Miles and an Hair — That this Canal does not communicate with the Birmingham Canal — That there will be Four Pounds, or Summits, on this Canal; the Locks are to be about Sixty-six Feet by Sixteen in the Chamber, and the Falls Six Feet — That the Canal is to be supplied with Water from various Springs which are found in the Bed of the Canal in digging; and Steam Engines are to be erected to raise more Water, so as to form a general Supply.

And being asked. How the Summit Level is to be supplied ? he answered. By such Springs as are found in it, and by Steam Engines, which have Power enough to supply Ten such Canals as the one intended.

And being asked, Whether he was ever concerned in the Execution of any Canals ? he replied. Not in the executive Parts; but that Canals have been executed from his Plans.

And being asked, Whether he has not good Reason to believe that the proposed Canal will, from all Appearances, according to his Judgment, be as well furnished in a natural Way with an ample Supply of Water, as those Canals which have been executed under his Plans ? he said, It will — That he alluded to the Birmingham, and Birmingham and Canals,

as having been executed on the Plan of the intended Canal.

And being asked. Whether those Canals depended entirely upon Water which was to be discovered in digging of the Canal? he said, No.

And being asked, Whether it is meant to raise Water by Engines to supply the Summit of the intended Canal from the River Severn ? he answered, What is not found in digging is to be supplied by Engines from that River; the Distance of this Summit from the River Severn is Fifteen Miles, and the Fall from the Summit is 448 Feet — That the Birmingham Canal is amply supplied with Water by Engines; the Locks of the said Canal are about 74 Feet long, and Eight Feet wide.

And being asked. What other Supplies the Birmingham Canal has besides the Water raised by Engines ? he said, The Summit of that Canal was heretofore Vox- 4£.

about One thousand Yards long, but was found inadequate to the great Trade carried on the Canal; and, in order to obviate that, they are now cutting down the Summit Eighteen Feet deeper, which will lengthen the Summit about Fifteen Miles — That the Birmingham Canal is at present in Part supplied by Reservoirs, but the greater Quantity of Water is supplied by Steam Engines; one Reservoir is about Two Miles, and the other not more than Half a Mile from the Canal.

And being asked, Whether, in dry Seasons, even with these Reservoirs, there is not a great Want of Water? he replied, No; it was just the Reverse — That before Steam Engines were introduced, there was a great Want of Water, which was a Reason for building of Steam Engines, which are supplied with Water from Old Coal Pit Hollows, and by Steam Engines from the Working Pits.

And being asked, Whether there can be any such Supplies from Steam Engines upon the Course of the intended Canal? he said. There are no Coal Mines upon the Canal.

And being asked, Whether the Birmingham Canal would not be amply supplied with Water at all Seasons, by Means of the Steam Engines only? he answered, Yes, very abundantly; and there would be a great deal of Water to spare — That he does not know whether it is intended to take any Water from the Birmingham Canal to supply the intended Canal — That Part of the present Waste Water from the Birmingham Canal runs into the Fazeley Canal, and a Part into the River Rea.

And being asked, Whether, notwithstanding the Fall of the Locks, and the Breadth of the intended Canal, and the Distance from the Summit to the vern, he does not think that the said Canal may be abundantly supplied with Water with Steam Engines, in the same Manner as the Birmingham Canal is from the River Severn ? he replied, It may.

And being asked, Whether the Upper Pound of the intended Canal is on a Level with the Birmingham Canal? he said, It is on a Level with that Part of the Old Canal next to the Town of Birmingham, but not so high as the long Summit by Eighteen Feet.

And being asked. Whether the Water raised by the Steam Engines upon the Birmingham Canal would not supply this Canal, if wanted ? he said, He apprehended it would.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn,

near to the City of Worcester: And that Mr. Lygon, Mr. Foley, Mr. Samuel Smith, Mr. Wigley, Sir Robert Lawley, and Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The Lord Hinchingbrook reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several of the Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road from Biggleswade, in the County of Bedford, through Bugden and Alconbury, to the Top of Hill, and from

directed him to report the same, as it appeared to then, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as tol-loweth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Robert Godby (Treasurer for the said Roads) being examined, said, That the Trustees have pro* ceeded in the Execution of the said Act, for which Purpose a considerable Sum of Money has been borrowed upon the Credit of the Tolls, which now remains due, and cannot be paid off, nor the Roads effectually repaired, unless the Term of the said Act be enlarged, and some Amendments made thereto; and that it will also be necessary that a small Increase should be made in some of the Tolls authorized to be collected thereby: Then,

Mr. John Smith (a Surveyor) being examined, said, That the Road leading out of the present Turnpike Road, in the Parish of Eaton Socon, in the County of Bedford, and through Eaton Ford to another Part of the said Turnpike Road, near Neat's Bridge (being about Half a Mile in Length) is sometimes overflowed, and rendered inconvenient for Travellers; and that it would be of great Benefit to Persons making Use of the same, if the said Piece of Road was properly raised and amended: And,

Mr. Godby being further examined, said, That no additional Toll is intended to be taken in, consequence of repairing the said Piece of Road, nor any Money borrowed.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue the Term, and alter and enlarge the Powers, of an Act of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Biggleswade, in the County of Bedford, through Bugden and Alconbury, to the Top of Alconbury Hill, and from Bugden to Huntingdon, and from Cross Hall to Great Stoughton Common, in the County of Huntingdon, and also the Road leading out of the aforesaid Road, at or near the Ferry House in the Parish of Tempsford, to and through Little Barford, Eynesbury, and Saint s, to the Turnpike Road at the End of Cross Hall Lane: And that the Lord Hinckingbrook and the Earl Ludlow do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from Tunstall, in the County of Stafford, to Bosley, in the County of Chester, and from Great Chell to Shelton, in the said County of Stafford, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by the said Act, the said Roads are made Two separate Districts, with separate Trustees for the Care of each District, and all the Tolls collected are directed to be applied towards repairing the Road within the District in which they are collected, and not otherwise; and that the Trustees have borrowed several Sums of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls arising within their respective Districts, which still remain due; and that the Term of the said Act is near expiring, and, unless the same is further continued, the Money borrowed cannot be repaid, and the Roads kept in good Repair: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the said Act for such further Term as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Gilbert, the Earl Gower, &c: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at

Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.
