A Petition

Leeds and Liverpool Navigation Petition.

213

A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool, was presented to the House, and read; setting forth, That an Act passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from Leeds Bridge, in the County of York, to The North Lady’s Walk, in Liverpool, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, and from thence to the River Mersey; whereby the Petitioners were united into a Company, and authorized to make and complete a Cut or Canal, Navigable for Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, from or near Leeds Bridge, in the Town of Leeds, through the several Townships, Parishes, and Hamlets, in the said Act particularly mentioned, to or near a Place, called The North Lady’s Walk, in Liverpool, and from thence to communicate with the River Mersey; and, to the End the Petitioners might be enabled to carry on so useful an Undertaking, they were thereby empowered to raise among themselves a competent Sum of Money, not exceeding 260,000l. in the Whole, unless the said Sum should be found insufficient for the Purposes aforesaid, when they were empowered to raise any further Sum, not exceeding 60,000 /.; and that the Petitioners have raised among themselves the Sum of 300,000l., and upwards, which hath been expended in making and completing such Part of the said Cut or Canal as lies between the said Leeds Bridge and a certain other Bridge called Holm Bridge, in the said County of York, and in making and completing such Part of the said Cut or Canal as lies between the said Port of Liverpool and the Township of Parbold,in the said County of Lancaster, and in the purchasing and improving the Navigable River Douglas, alias Asland, in the said County of Lancaster, which is now consolidated and incorporated with the said Canal Navigation, by virtue of an Act passed in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, and in other Purposes directed by the said Acts; and that about Fifty-six Miles of the said intended Canal remain uncut, by Reason whereof all the interior Parts of the said Counties in particular, and the Public in general, are deprived of the Advantages which would be obtained by finishing the said Canal, and opening a short, easy, and commodious Communication between the said Ports of Hull and Liverpool, and the beneficial Intentions of the said Acts are thereby greatly prevented; and that the Petitioners are desirous of completing and finishing the said Cut or Canal with all Expedition, and for that Purpose have caused the Country, lying intermediate and between the said completed Parts thereof, to be re-surveyed, whereby it appears, that great Difficulties might be avoided, or very much diminished, and much Expence saved, by varying a Part of the said original intended Line of the said Cut or Canal, and by making the same Navigable for Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, from or near a Place called Reediford, in the Township of Great Marsden, in the said County of Lancaster, through Great Marsden, Little Marsden, Pendle Forest, Ightenhill Park, otherwise

Gawthorp, Padiham, Hapton, Altham, Clayton, and Harwood,otherwise Great Harwood, in the said County of Lancaster, to and through a Place called Nab Wood, in Great Harwood aforesaid; and that, in order to complete and finish the said intermediate Parts of the said intended Cut or Canal, it will be necessary to borrow a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit of the said incorporated Navigations: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to enable the Petitioners to borrow Money for making and completing the said Cut or Canal, and to make such Variations therein, as aforesaid, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do exa-

Vol. 45.

mine, the Matter thereof; and Report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Thomas Stanley, Mr.

Duncombe, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the Inhabitants of the Town and Manchester Neighbourhood of Manchester, whose Names are there-under signed, was presented to the House, and read; ^acco Act. Setting forth, That the Petitioners cannot but observe, with deep Concern, the gradual Progress of the Excise Laws amongst the Manufactures of Great Britain, and the late alarming Step towards the general Establishment of that destructive System of Taxation, by an Excise upon the Manufacture of Tobacco and that the Petitioners are convinced, from Experience, that; although the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, their ultimate and certain Tendency is to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced; and that the whole System of Excise is arbitrary itr its Principle, and oppressive in its Execution, that it subjects the Manufacturer to Delays and Restrictions vexatious and unnecessary, invades the Security of private Dwellings, is peculiarly fitted to become the secret Instrument of iniquitous Oppression, or unjust Preference to particular Persons, and occasions the arbitrary Inflictions of Fines and Forfeitures in many Cases which no Foresight can prevent; and that the Trial by Jury is the unalienable Right of every English-, man in all Cases where his Person or Property is to be decided on, a Right of which every Subject of this Realm is unjustly deprived, who is liable to the Operation of the Excise Laws; and that the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and will chearfully submit to every Constitutional Claim for their Share of the Common Burthen, but they cannot, on any Consideration whatever, silently acquiesce in the Annihilation of their dearest Rights and Privileges, to which, as Englishmen, they are justly entitled:

And therefore praying, That the Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the " Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Rights and Privileges of Individuals, and to the Injury of the Commerce and Prosperity of this Country.

A Petition of the Persons whose Names are there- Bristol Peti-unto subscribed, Manufacturers of Tobacco and Snuff don against in the City of Bristol, in Behalf of themselves and D#Act-others, was also presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That, by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the " Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in lieu thereof," the Petitioners are subjected to the Laws of Excise 5 and that, while the said Act was pending in the House, Evidence was given at the Bar, to prove that the System of Excise was inapplicable to those Manufactures, that given Rules could not be made to apply without Injury to the Trade, and Danger to the Revenue, on account of the Complexity and Variety of the Operations, the Uncertainty of the Produce of such Operations, and withal the exposing the Mysteries of every Individual Manufacturer of Snuff to the probable Knowledge' of the Smugglers; and that Experience under the Operation of the said Act hath proved the Truth of the Evidence, the Act (though hitherto executed with Lenity) is injurious to the Trade, dangerous

3 I to

to the Revenue, and in many Cases impracticable, and the Petitioners are fully persuaded that no Modification of the said Act will either ultimately benefit the Revenue, or relieve the fair Trader from the Competition of the Smuggler: And therefore praying, That the said Act may be repealed.

Petition ' A Petition of the Manufacturers of, and Dealers in, wainet the Tobacco and Snuff, in the City of in Be-

obacco Act jjajf of themselves, and others, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act " for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, ,c and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," the Petitioners are subjected to the Laws of Excise, and by the said Act the Mysteries of the Trade, of inestimable Value, purchased or received in Patrimony, and hitherto considered as exclusive Property, are exposed — That, by exposing Mysteries, it will enable the Smuggler to supplant the fair Trader in those Articles which are mysterious, and thereby very materially injure, rather than improve, the present Revenues, as in those Articles alone the fair Trader can maintain a Competition with the Smuggler — That it imposes Rules and Regulations on the Manufacturer, which, in some Cases, are impracticable, and in many cannot be conformed to, without rendering the Goods unfit for his Customer, and in consequence subjects him to heavy Forfeitures and Penalties — That it prevents the Manufacturer supplying his Customers for Ten Days or a Fortnight, or sometimes longer, though all the Time in the Possession of the Goods which are wanted, the Manufacturer being under the Necessity of finishing the Manufacture of the whole Parcel before he can make Use of any Part of it — That it debars Manufacturers not in Ports of Importation, from disposing of such Parts of their Tobacco as they cannot vend amongst their own Customers, to the Manufacturers in the Ports of Importation, who are perhaps the only Persons they can sell them to without sustaining a considerable Loss — That it obliges many Manufacturers to alter their Mode of Manufacture, to the great additional Expence and Inconvenience of the Manufacturers, as well as imminent Danger of the Loss of their Customers — That it prohibits the Removal, either with or without Permit, of some Articles in less Quantities than 200 Pounds Weight, which, Nine Times out of Ten, are more than can be sent or sold — That, when executed in the most lenient Manner, it occasions Delays and Interruptions quite inconvenient with the Nature of the Trade, and which, as such, must in the End drive the Manufacture of the Article out of the Country, and give a Power to a malicious Officer to ruin the Business of any principal Manufacturer: And, that for these and many other Reasons, as well as from a full Persuasion that no Modification of the said Act will either ultimately benefit the Revenue, or relieve the fair Trader from the Competition of the Smuggler, therefore praying. That the said Act may be repealed.

Ditto. A Petition of the Tavemkeepers, Innkeepers, Coffeehouse-keepers, and Publicans, of the Cities of - don and Westminster, and [Parts adjacent, within the Limits of the Chief Office of Excise in , was

likewise presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act made in the Twenty-ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof, it is enacted, " That all and every Person or Persons, who shall " manufacture Tobacco or Snuff, or deal in Tobacco or Snuff, shall, before he, she, or they shall manufacture Tobacco or Snuff, or deal in Tobacco 0 or Snuff, take out such licence and Licences as therein-after mentioned;" and that the Petitioners do not conceive that the Legislature, in passing the said Act, meant that the Petitioners should be Objects of Taxation, or that they should be liable to take out such Licence under the said Act, and they do not conceive themselves to be " Dealers in Tobacco," within the true Intent and Meaning of the said Act, but the Petitioners have notwithstanding been compelled to take out Licences as Dealers in Tobacco, under a Construction of the said Act, that the Tobacco consumed in their Houses constitutes them to be " Dealers in Tobacco;" and that the Petitioners have always cheerfully contributed to the Exigencies of the State, and have and do support very heavy and large Burthens by the many Imposts exclusively laid upon them; viz. £ s d

For every Beer Licence, the Sum of - 118 —

For every Wine Licence - - - 2 4 1

For Spirit Licences - - - - 2 6 —

For every Six Weeks Licence, about Two Shillings in the Pound on the Annual House Rent, (being an Additional Duty on Brandy) so that; if the Rent amounts to Fifty Pounds per Annum, the Licences are - > - - - 4 16 —

£ ti 4

and that none of the Licences above-mentioned are transferrable (except the Beer Licence) so that, as often as the Petitioners remove their Places of Dwelling, not only the Persons taking their Houses, but also the Petitioners, if they continue in the same Trade, are obliged to take out new Licences; and that the Petitioners are put to much Trouble and great Inconvenience by the Number of Attendances at the Excise Office, and the great Delays in procuring their Licences, and the Petitioners in the Out Parts feel themselves very much aggrieved by Soldiers being constantly Quartered on them, for, notwithstanding the re are upwards of Ten thousand Public Houses within the Bills of Mortality, and though the Guards do not consist, as the Petitioners are advised, of more than Three thousand Men (many. of whom are Quartered at the Savoy Prisons and the Tower) yet each Public House is Quartered with a Soldier, which is done by Means of most of the Landlords paying the Soldiers to provide for themselves, instead of entertaining them in their Houses: And therefore praying, That the House will take their Case into Consideration, and grant them such Relief as may seem meet.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table.

A Petition of John Courtney, Christopher Keld, Wil- Tickton liam Squire, and others, whose Hands are thereunto Inclosure set or subscribed, having certain Rights or Interests Petition, in the Carr or Common herein after mentioned, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there is, within the Township of in the Parish

of Saint John of Beverley, in the East Riding of the County of York, a certain Carr or Common, called Tickton Carr, computed to contain Two hundred and Forty-nine Acres, or thereabouts; and that it would be a Benefit to all Persons interested in the said Carr or Common, in case a Division and IncLosure was made thereof, and specific Parts and Shares allotted to the Parties, according to their different Rights and Interests:

Arid therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Carr or Common, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Robert Burton and Mr. Anderson Pelham do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Petition.

Birmingham A Petition of several of the Inhabitants of the Police Town of Birmingham, and of the other Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Commissioners for putting in Execution Two several Acts of Parliament, the one passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third* intituled, An Act for laying open and widening certain Ways " and Passages within the Town of and for cleansing and lighting the Streets, Lanes, Ways, " and Passages there, and for removing and preventing " Nuisances and Obstructions therein, and the other passed in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of His said Majesty, to amend and explain the said former Act, and for widening certain other Streets and Places, for establishing a Nightly Watch, and for regulating Carts and Carmen employed in the said Town, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Commissioners for carrying into Execution the Powers contained in the said Acts, find that the same are in many Respects defective, and insufficient for the necessary Regulations of the said Town; and that it will also tend greatly to the Advantage and Ornament of the Town, and to the safe passing and re-passing of the Inhabitants, and the Public at large, if several Buildings, standing in and about the Market Place, and in different Streets, Passages, and Places, in the said Town, were removed, and if certain Ways, Places, and Passages, in the said Town, were said open and widened, and if further Power was given to pave with Flag, and other Stones, many of the Streets in the said Town, and to remove and prevent Nuisances and Obstructions therein; and that the Powers given, and the Regulations made, by the said Acts, for the Establishment of a Nightly Watch in the said Town, have proved insufficient, and cannot be rendered effectual, without the further Aid of Parliament: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for effecting the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition' be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Robert Lawley, Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Owners and Proprietors of, and otherwise interested in, the Open and Common Fields, and other Commonable Lands and Grounds, within the Parish and Liberties of Fritwell, in the County of Oxford, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Lands of the Petitioners, in the said Fields, are intermixed and dispersed in small Parcels, and in their present State are incapable of any considerable Improvement, and it would be very advantageous to the several Persons interested therein if the said Fields, Lands, and Grounds, were divided and inclosed, and specific Parts thereof allotted to the several Proprietors, according to their respective Rights and Interests: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Open and Common Fields, and other Commonable Lands and Grounds, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Lord Charles Spencer and Mr. Jerooise do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Oxford, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Parish Church of Banbury, and the Tower thereof, are in a very ruinous and decayed State, so that Divine Service cannot with Safety be performed therein, and it is necessary that the said Church and Tower should be taken down, and re-built; and that the Expences of taking down, and re-building, the said Parish Church and Tower, will be very considerable, and cannot be raised without the Aid of Parliament: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for taking down, and re-building, the said Church and Tower, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, and with such Powers and Provisions, as to the House shall seem meet.

Mr. Barlow reported from the Committee, to whom Tavernspite the Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Roads Bill Act, of the Eleventh Year of His present Majesty, rePorted-for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading from Tavernspite to the Towns of Pembroke and Tenby, and to Hubberston Haking, in the County of Pembroke, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of the Most Honourable Thomas Marquis Deverill of Bath, Lord of the Manor of Deverill jjwlosure

Hussey Deverill, and Monkton Deverill, in the County Petition* of Wilts, and the humble Petition of several other

Persons, Owners and Occupiers of Lands and Estates within the Manor aforesaid, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are within the said Manor, several Open Fields, Open Downs, Commons, and Commonable Lands, which are, at present, intermixed and dispersed, and incapable of any considerable Improvement, and it would be very advantageous to the several Proprietors, and other Persons interested in the said Lands, if the same were divided, and specific Shares thereof allotted to them in Proportion to their several Rights and Interests:

And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Mr. Goddard and Sir James Tylney Long do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Bedford thereunto subscribed, being Burgesses, Freemen, and charity principal Inhabitants of the Town of Be ford, was Pebtian. presented to the House, and read; Setting forth.

That King Edward the Sixth, by Letters Patent, dated the 15th Day of August, in the Sixth Year of his

Bedford

Charity

Petition.

216 4° Martii. A. 1790.

his Reign, granted to the Mayor, Bailiiis, Burgesses, and Commonalty of the Town of Bedford, Licence to erect and establish a Free and perpetual School in the said Town, for the Education, Institution, and Instruction of Children and Youth in Grammar and good Manners, and the same School to be of One Master and One Usher for ever; and the Wardens and Fellows of New College, in Oxford, were thereby constituted Visitors of the same School, and Nominators and Admittors of its Master and Usher, with Power to remove them for just Cause, and to appoint others to act in their Stations; and his said Majesty granted the Patentees Licence to have, enjoy, ana purchase Manors, Lands, and Hereditaments, to the Yearly Value of 40/. and to have and to hold the same in and to the Sustentation of the said Master and Usher, and for the Continuance of the said School for ever, for the Marriage of Poor Maids of the said Town, and for Poor Children there to be nourished and informed, and also of the Surplusage coming or remaining of the Premisses, to distribute in Alms to the Poor of the said Town for the Time being; and that by Indenture, dated the 2 2d Day of in the

Eighth Year of the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and made between the Mayor, Bailiffs, Burgesses, and Commonalty of the said Town, of the one Part, and Sir William Harpur, Knight, and Dame Alice his Wife, of the other Part, the same Mayor, Bailiffs, Burgesses, and Commonalty, did, in pursuance of the said Letters Patent, erect, make, found, and establish, a Free and perpetual School within the said Town of Bedford, in a Messuage there, called The Free School House, which the said Sir William Harpur of late built, and the said Sir William and Dame Alice Harpur thereby conveyed, unto the said Mayor, Bailiffs, Burgesses, and Commonalty, and their Successors, the said Messuage, called The School House, with the 'Gardens and Appurtenances thereto belonging, in the said Town of Bedford, and also Thirteen Acres and One Rood of Meadow, with their Appurtenances, lying in divers Parcels, in or near the Parish of Saint Andrew, Holborn, in the County of Middlesex, upon the same Trusts, and for the same Purposes, as are declared in the said Letters Patent, concerning the Lands thereby authorized to be purchased; and that previous to the Year 1764, a great Number of Houses and Buildings were erected on the said Ground in the County of Middlesex, and several new Streets were formed, designed, and made, out of Part of the said Premisses, for the Use of the Public, and by means thereof the Yearly Rents and Profits of the same Trust Premises being then increased to the Amount of 2,609/. 17^- per Annum, or thereabouts, an Act was passed in the Fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty for enlarging the Charitable Uses, extending the Objects, and regulating the Application of the Rents and Profits of the Estates so given by the said Sir William Harpur and Dame Alice his Wife, as aforesaid; and thereby the Mayor, Recorder, Aldermen, Thirteen Common Council, Two Bailiffs, and Two Chamberlains, of the Borough of Bedford for the Time being, the Ministers of the several Parishes of Paul, Saint Mary, Saint John, Saint Peter, and Saint Cuthbert, in the said Town of Bedford, for the Time being, and Five Persons, Inhabitants of the said Parish of Saint Paul, Three Persons, Inhabitants of the said Parish of Saint Mary, One Person an Inhabitant of the said Parish of Saint John, Two Persons, Inhabitants of the said Parish of Saint Peter, and One Person, an Inhabitant of the said Parish of Saint Cuthbert, who shall be resident in the said Borough, and shall have served the Office of Churchwardens or Overseers of the Pooi* of such Parishes respectively, to be elected in Manner, and for the Term after directed, were declared to be Trustees for the setting, letting, and leasing, regulating, disposing, ordering, and managing of the said Charity Estate and Charity, and of the Yearly and other Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof, and for carrying into Execution the Rules, Orders, and 'Directions, set forth in the Schedule thereto annexed, and for other the Purposes in the said Act mentioned; and by the said Rules, Orders, and Directions, there was to be allowed to the Master of the said School the Yearly Sum of 200l. to the Usher the Yearly Sum of 100l. and to the Writing Master the Yearly Sum of 60/.; and there was to be applied and distributed Yearly 800l. for the Marriage of Forty Poor Maids of the said Town of Bedford, of good Fame and Reputation, being Daughters either of Freemen of the said Town, who shall have been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses within the said Town, for the Space of Three successive Years, or of such Inhabitants who shall have been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses within the said Town, not being Certificate Persons from Parishes without the said Town of Bedford, for the Space of Five successive Years, and being of the Age of Sixteen Years, and under the Age of Fifty; and, if there should be any Residue of the said Yearly Sum of 800l. not applied as above, such Residue was to be applied Yearly in equal Proportions among such Maid Servants, not being of bad Fame and Reputation, who should have lived with any of the Inhabitants of the said Parishes in the Town of Bedford for Five successive Years, and should have been married within One Year before such Distribution, and should produce Certificates from their respective Masters and Mistresses of their Service and good Behaviour; and a Sum not exceeding 200l. a Year was to be applied, according to the Directions of the Trustees, in maintaining, cloathing, and employing of Poor Boys and Girls, born and resident in the said Town of Bedford, until they should be of proper Age to be placed or put out to School, Trade, Agriculture, or other Business; and the Yearly Sum of 600l. was to be applied in placing out Apprentice Forty Poor Children, not under the Age of Twelve, nor above the Age of Fifteen Years, being Sons or Daughters, either of Freemen of the said Town of Bedford, who shall have been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses, within the said Town, for the space of Three successive Years, or of Inhabitants who shall have been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses, within the said Town, not being Certificate Persons from Parishes without the said Town of Bedford, for the Space of Five successive Years; and each Boy or Girl was, after the Expiration of his or her Apprenticeship, to be entitled, upon producing a Certificate from his or her Master or Mistress, and the Minister and Churchwardens of the Parish where such Apprentice shall have lived, testifying the good Morals and Behaviour of such Apprentice, and that he or she then continues unmarried, to such Sum, not exceeding 20/. nor less than 10/. as the Trustees, or the major Part of them, should think proper; and upon the last Monday in November in every Year, the Surplusage of the Rents and Profits of the Charity Estates unapplied, and coming or remaining of the Year ending at the Michaelmas preceding, was to be applied, by the Trustees, or the major Part of them, for the Relief and Support of Poor decayed. Housekeepers, and other proper Objects, who should have lived and resided within the said Town Five Years at least before they should be admitted to partake thereof; and further, that the Trustees might, firom Time to Time, appoint a Receiver, with a Salary of 250/. per Annum, and also might appoint a Surveyor or Surveyors of the said Charity Estates, and also a Clerk to the said Trustees, in such Manner, and with such Allowances for their Trouble and Care therein, as to the said Trustees, or the major

Part

Pail of them, should seam proper; and.that by Means of the said Estates, in and near the Parish of Saint Andi'av, Holborn,being let upon Building and Re-

pairing Leases, as the former Leases have fallen in and expired, the reserved Rents thereof have been greatly increased since the passing of the said Act, and also now amount to 2,917 17 Annum,

and it is estimated, that, in as much as Fifty of the present Leases on the same Estate will expire at Midsummer 1793, and Nineteen more in the Year following, the Rents of the Estates in the same Leases, upon being new let on Building and Repairing Leases, will be increased by the Yearly Sum of 1,000l. or thereabouts, and the remaining Part of the Estates will be also capable of considerable Increase in its Yearly Value upon the Determination of the Leases now in being, some of which have but a few Years te run; and that, in as much as the Revenues of the said Charity are very considerably increased, and are in a short lime likely to be still further increased, the Petitioners conceive it may be expedient again to enlarge the Charitable Uses thereof, and they also conceive that divers Regulations are wanting for the better governing and managing of the said Charity, and to prevent Abuses and Irregularities in the Disposition of its Revenues; and that it would tend greatly to the Correction of such Abuses and Irregularities, and to the general Benefit and Advantage of the said Charity, and greatly promote the good Management thereof, if the following Regulations were to take Place, via. That the Number of Trustees shall be enlarged, by admitting to that Office, in Addition to those appointed by the aforesaid Act, all Inhabitants of the said Town of Bedford paying Scotland Lot, who shall have been actually resident there for Three Years, and be likewise possessed of, or entitled to, a Freehold-Estate within the Town or County of Bedford, of the Yearly Value of 2 oLclear of all Reprizes, but that such additional Trustees shall not be entitled to act any longer than while they^hall so reside, and continue possessed or entitled, and that no Person shall be capable of acting as a Trustee who shall be Partaker of the said Chanty, or who shall be appointed by the Trustees to any Place or Office of Profit under the said Charity; but no Person to be incapacitated from being & Trustee merely on Account of having any Child or Children educated in the School, or sent from thence to either University, with the Exhibitions after-mentioned; — That the Warden and Fellows of the Niott College, in Oxford, who are appointed Visitors of the Free Grammar School by the aforesaid Letters Patent, may be authorized and directed to send Two sufficient Visitors Yearly to the same School, who, upon every 16th Day of shall, in a public Maimer, examine the Boys in their Learning, and shall, as Visitors^ examine into the Conduct of the Master and Usher, and also into all Faults and Neglects respecting the same School, and make a Report thereof to the Wardens and Fellows of New College; and that each Visitor be allowed Fifteen Guineas for his Trouble; and that the said Wardens and Fellows shall always have the Power of removing the Master and Usher for just Causes, and of appointing others in their Stead; — That the Trustees shall grant Exhibitions, not exceeding 30 per Annum each, to such Scholars, going to either of the Universities of Oxford or Cambridge, as the Visitors shall from Time to Time recommend, and as the Trustees shall deem most worthy of Preference, hot so as there shall not be more than Six Scholars recasting Exhibitions at any one Time; and that no Scholar shall hold hie Exhibition alter Twenty-four Years of Age; — That in future no Girls shall be put out Apprentice, it haviqg generally happened that no Persons have been found to take them but their own Parents, who, being for the most Part in wry low and indiwafe Circam-Vox 45. '

stances, and following no Trade; have suffered the Bedford Girls to live in a State of Idleness and Neglect; — Chanty That Twenty Boys shall be Apprenticed every Half Pet*tion. Year, not being under Thirteen, nor above Fifteen Years of Age, and that they may be bound at any Time within Six Calendar Months from the Time of their drawing Lots, instead of within Two Months, according to the present Regulations; and that they shall be placed out to Masters of good Character and Responsibility, to be approved of by the Trustees, and that no Boys shall be Apprenticed, unless their Fathers shall have actually been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses in the Town for Ten Years next preceding the Apprenticing, or shall have been born in the Town, and been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses therein for Three Years next preceding the Apprenticing, it having been found that the Hope of obtaining this Part of the Charity has occasioned a great Influx of Paupers into the Town from neighbouring Parishes, who have soon become chargeable to the Parishes within the Town, and thereby occasioned a very burthensome Increase of Poor Rates, which are now, upon an Average, Six Shillings in the Pound; whereas, before the enlarging of the Uses of the Charity under the aforesaid Act, the Pour Rates were only from Two to Three Shillings in the Pound; and such Increase of Poor Rates appears to the Petitioners a great Grievance to the Natives or Old Inhabitants of the Town, for whose Benefit the Charity was designed; — That nd Sum shall be paid, as the Portion of any Poor Maidens, who shall marry Vagrants, or others of bad Fame or Reputation; and that no Poor Maidens shall be entitled to such Portions, unless- their Fathers shall have been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses in the Town of Bedford for Ten Years next preceding their claiming to draw Lots, or shall have been born in the Town, and been Occupiers of One or more House or Houses therein for Three Years next preceding their claiming to draw Lots; it being found that the Distribution of this Part of the Charity tu Poor Maidens of the Description in the present Regulation, has also tended greatly to causing an Influx of Paupers into the said Town, and consequently an Increase of the Poor Rates; — That in future no Sum shall be paid as the Portion of Poor Maid Servants (except to Maid Servants who shall, upon the 1st Day of June 1790, have been Two Years in Service in the said Town) the Distribution of this Part of the Charity having also been found a considerable Cause of the Grievance mentioned in the last Article; —

That no Persons shall be Partakers of the Surplusage of the Rents and Profits of the Charity Estate distributed in the Month of November Annually, unless they shall have previously lived and resided Ten Years within the said Town of Bedford, instead of Five Years, according to the present Regulations; and that the Petitioners conceive that forther Regulations may be wanted for the well managing and governing of the said Charity, and the disposing of the Revenues thereof and particularly for extending the Uses and Ob-jecta of the said Charity with respect to the Surplus of tho Annual Income: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring ia a Bill for regulating the said Charity in the Points aboYoenentioned, or ia such other Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

That the erecting of ^eotion‘ a Bridge across the River South Esk, at or near Mon-twee, would be attended with §peat publie Utility, and would complete the Communication by Bridges

£18 4? Mart A. 1790.

upon the Great Road along the North East Coast of Scotland, from whence the most solid Advantages would arise: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring- in a Bill for the above Purpose.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Douglas, the Marquis of Graham, 8cc: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Goldsmiths A Petition of the Wardens of the Mystery of Gold-

Petition. smiths of the City of London, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by an Act, made in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for preventing Frauds and Abuses in Gold and Silver Wares, there is contained a Proviso, whereby it is declared, that nothing in that Act contained should extend to oblige any or the following Wares of Gold or Silver to be stamped or marked by the respective Companies of Goldsmiths in the said Act mentioned, or any of them, viz. Rings, Collets for Rings, or other Jewels, Chains, Necklace Beads, Lockets, Hollow or Raised Buttons, Sleeve Buttons, Thimbles, Coral Sockets and Bells, Ferrils, Pipe Lighters, Cranes for Bottles, very small Book Clasps, any Stock or Garter Clasps jointed, very small Nutmeg Graters, Rims of Snuff Boxes whereof Tops or Bottoms are made of Shell or Stone, Sliding Pencils, Toothpick Cases, Tweezer Cases, Pencil Cases, Needle Cases, any Philligree Work, any Sorts of Tippings or Swages on Stone or Ivory Cases, any Mounts, Screws, or Stoppers to Stone or Glass Bottles or Phials, any small or slight Ornaments put to Amber, or other Eggs or Urns, any Wrought Seals, or Seals with Cornelian or other Stones set therein, or any Gold or Silver Vessel, Plate, or Manufacture of Gold or Silver, so richly engraved, carved, or-chased, or set with Jewels or other Stones, as not to admit of an Assay to be taken of, or a Mark to be struck thereon, without damaging, prejudicing, or defacing the same, or such other Things as, by reason of the Smallness or Thinness thereof, are not capable of receiving the Marks, in the said Act before-mentioned, or any of them, and not weighing Ten Penny Weight of Gold or Silver each; and that by another Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for granting certain Duties on all Gold and Silver Plate imported, and also certain Duties on all Gold and Silver Wrought Plate made in Great Britain, there is contained a Proviso, whereby it is declared, that nothing in the said last mentioned Act shall extend to compel any of the Wares of Gold or Silver to be stamped, or marked with the Stamp or Mark directed by the said last mentioned Act, which are particularly excepted in the said recited Act, made in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of his said late Majesty; and that Doubts have arisen, as to the true Construction and Meaning of the said Proviso contained in the aforesaid Act, made in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, and also as to what Silver Wares are intended by the said last mentioned Act, and by the aforesaid Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to be excepted from being stamped or marked with the Stamps or Marks directed by the said Acts, or either of them, and divers Silversmiths and other Persons, making or dealing in Silver Wares, have inadvertently, and without meaning to offend against the said Acts, sold, exchanged, and exposed to Sale, divers small Articles and Wares made of Silver, being of the Standard directed by Law, and not stamped or marked with the Stamps or Marks in the said Acts mentioned, whereby divers Penalties, Forfeitures, and Punishments may have been innocently incurred by such Persons, from which it is conceived they should be released and indemnified; and it is expedient that the said Provisoes in the said Acts contained, so far as the same concern Wares of Silver, should cease and determine, and that the said Acts should be amended in several Respects, and other Regulations and Declarations made as to Silver Wares:

And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Samuel Smith, Mr. Alderman Watson, &c: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names Petition for are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves additional and others, Owners and Inhabitants of Houses in the Peterborough Parish of Saint John Baptist,in the City of paving Bill,

was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth,

That a Petition hath been presented to the House, . for Leave to bring in a Bill for paving, repairing, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the several Streets, Lanes, Passages, Causeways, and other Roads and public Places, within the said Parish and City; and that the Street within the said City, called Cowgate, is at present under the Management of the Trustees for repairing the Turnpike Road leading from Wansford to Peterborough, and it is necessary that the said Street should be paved, and also that the other Roads within the Township of Peterborough, and adjoining to the said City, should be included in -the intended Bill; and that, in Aid of the Rates to be made upon the Inhabitants, it may be found necessary to lay a small Toll upon Horses, Cattle, and Carriages, passing to and from the said City, and, in order to secure the Collection of such Toll, it will be proper to erect Turnpikes near the Avenues, and at a small Distance from the Limits of the said City: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for the several Purposes aforesaid, in such Manner, and subject to such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration’ of the Committee to whom the Petition of the several Persons who have thereunto subscribed their Names, on Behalf of themselves and others,

Owners and Inhabitants of Houses in the Parish of Saint John Baptist, in the City of Pis referred: And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

A Petition of several of the Freemen of the Cor- Hallamshire poration of Cutlers, in the Lordship and Liberty of Cutlers Hallamshire, in the West Riding of the County of l*et'tion.

York, established by an Act of the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the First, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That the Petitioners, and the rest of the Freemen of the said Corporation, are greatly injured in their lawful Interests by several Practices, which have for a long Time been made Use of, and the Reputation of the Wares and Manufactures made within the Limits of the said Corporation greatly prejudiced, and the Benefits intended by the said Act to the Trade of the said Liberty, and to the Public, in a great Degree lost and defeated, and, it being generally apprehended by the Members of the said Corporation, as well as by the Petitioners, that those. Evils are occasioned by the

the Usage under the said Act in several Sets of the Public Officers of the Company being allowed to appoint their Successors, by which Means the Persons who have the Charge of the common Property of the Corporation, and of the Management of all its public Concerns, form a separate and distinct Interest, always independent of the whole Body for whom they act, and frequently adopting and countenancing Measures for their own Advantage, at the Expence of the Freemen at large, and which hath occasioned large Sums . to be spent by the Freemen in procuring Redress against the Evils complained of at the Hands of their Corporate Officers: In order to prevent the same for the future, and to procure to the Petitioners, and to all the Members of the said Corporation, and to the Public, the Advantages intended by the said Act, and the just, necessary, and useful Provisions made by the same, for the good making of all the Wares manufactured within the Limits of the said Corporation, therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to amend so much of the said Act as relates to the Appointment of the Officers of the Corporation, and to declare to the Freemen of the said Body Corporate for the Time being, the Right of choosing the Officers and Managers of the said Corporation, and also to amend such Part of the said Act as relates to binding Apprentices, and to give to all the Freemen, as well Journeymen as Masters, an equal Right to take and bind Apprentices, to be brought up and instructed in the several Branches of the said Corporation, and to expressly declare the Filesmiths within the said Liberty to be a Part of, and entitled to all the Privileges of, the said Body Corporate, and for such other Purposes as shall appear to the House to be necessary for the ordering and good Government of the said Corporation.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Duncombe, Mr. Wilberforce, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Smith'* A Petition of Henry Smith, Lieutenant in the Royal Petition re- Navy, was presented to the House, and read; Setting pecting Sea forth, That, in the Year 1781, the Petitioner served CorawaU 03 Lieutenant in His Majesty’s Ship The Squirrel,

stationed on the Cornish Coast, and, during the Time of his remaining on that Station, he frequently fell in with, and the Ship was in Danger from, certain Rocks on that Coast, called The Wolf Rock, and The Rundle Stone, both of which are liable to be overflowed at certain Times of the Tide; and that the affixing and providing of certain Mark$ and Signals on the said Rocks would be the Means of guarding Ships and Vessels, navigating on the Coast of Cornwall, from the Danger of falling in with the said Rocks, and thereby tend to the saving of the Lives of Seamen, and preventing the Loss of very considerable Property; and that the Petitioner hath invented certain Marks and Signals proper for the above-mentioned Purpose, arid is willing to affix, provide, and maintain the same at his own Risque and Expence, provided he may be allowed such an Indemnification, by Way of a Rate or Tonnage on Shipping'receiving Benefit from such Marks and Signals, as may be thought adequate and reasonable: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to enable him to erect and provide Marks and Signals on the said Rocks, in such Manner, on such Conditions, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Vol. 45.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table." '

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Heanor and thereunto Subscribed, being Owners and Proprietors Codnorln-of Lands and Hereditaments within the Liberties or PetH

Townships of Heanor and Codnor, in the Parish of Heanor, in the County of Derby, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That there are, within the said Liberties or Townships, several Commons and Waste Lands, belonging to the Petitioners, and the several other Owners or Proprietors of Lands and Hereditaments within the said respective Liberties or Townships, which, in their present Situation, are incapable of any considerable Improvement, but if the same were divided and inclosed, and specific Parts' thereof allotted to the respective Owners *and Proprietors, according to their several Rights and Interests therein, the said Commons and Waste Lands might be greatly improved: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing and inclosing the said Commons and Waste Lands, in such Manner, and subject to such Regulations, as the House shall think fit.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Lord George Cavendish and Mr. Mundy do prepare, and bring in, the same,

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Alfreton thereunto subscribed, being Trustees appointed by or R°ads in pursuance of an Act, passed in the Fourth Year of Peut,on* the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act " for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the " High Roads leading from Alfreton, in the County of " Derby, through Carter Lane, to a certain Place,

" in the Town of Mansfield, called Stockwell, and from " the Bridlegate at the Division of the Liberties of " Blackrvell and Hucknall, through the Town of Sutton " in Ashfield, to the Mansfield and Newark Turnpike,

" at or near Python Hill, in the Forest of Sherwood,

" in the County of Nottinghamwas presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees have made great Progress in repairing the said Roads, and have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money on the Credit of the Tolls by the said Act granted, but the said Roads cannot be completely amended, and kept in Repair, nor the Money borrowed repaid, unless the Term of the said Act be continued, and the Powers thereof' amended, enlarged, and rendered more effectual: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Lord George Cavendish,

Mr. Brett, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Bishop’s Traders, and other Inhabitants, of the Counties of Stortford and Herts, Essex, Cambridge, Isle of Ely, Huntingdon, and Brandon Suffolk, on Behalf of themselves and others, was pre- ?aT*8®t,on serited to the House, and read; Setting forth. That *110 a Navigation is already completed from the City of London to the Town of Bishop's Stortford, in the County of Herts, and, by a Survey which has been taken, it appears the same may be extended, by proceeding to a Place called Palmer's Water, in the said County, and from thence to the Parish of

220 4f J£Mh. 1790.

raid through die North Partd of the County of Essex, to the Town of Saffron and from the last mentioned Place, through the Counties of Cambridge a«d Suffolk, to join the Brandon River, whereby Communication will be opened to the County of Norfolk; and that a Branch may be made from such extended Line, by a Cut therefrom in the Parishes of Great and Little Abingdon, and Baberham, to join and commonicate with the Town Of , and that another

Branch may be made by a Cat to fall into the Bterwtt Lode, already Navigable to the Cambridge River, whereby convenient Communication will be opened with the Isle of Ely, and the Counties of Huntingdon and Bedford', and that if such Navigation, with the Branches aforesaid, are made, the same will be productive of great Utility and Benefit to the Inhabitants of the said Counties, and the Public in general, by rendering the Carnage of Com, and all Kinds of Merchandize, which pass between the Metropolis and the Counties afore-mentioned, and also the several Towns and Places lying within the said Counties, cheaper and easier than at present: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining the said Navigation and Cuts, in such Manner, and under such Regulations, as to the House shall seem meet

Inhabitants of the Counties of Herts, Cambridge, Isle of Ely, Huntingdon, and Suffolk, on Behalf of themselves and others, is referred: And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

Kl learnt re . a Petition of several of the Inhabitants of the Pa-

Petition UM rish of Ellesmere, in the County of Salop, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Poor of the said Parish are become very burthensome to the Inhabitants, and the Lewns have of late much increased, and to redress the same, and provide for the said Poor in a more effectual and better Manner than heretofore, the Petitioners have thought it ean-not be done effectually, without providing a House, or Houses, for the general Reception of the Poor of the said Parish, and also to take in the Poor of any other, or others, of the adjoining Parish or Parishes, that may think proper to unite with the said Parish of;

but the same cannot be done without the Aid of Parliament, to enable the said Parishioners to borrow Money, in order to carry the same into Execution, and also to unite and incorporate any other Parish or Parishes with the said Parish, that may hereafter be thought expedient: And therefore praying. That Leave may be

?'ven to bring in a Bill for effecting the said several urposes, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Mr. Crewe,

Distillers A Petition of the Rectifying Distillers of the Cities Petition. of London and Westminster, Borough of Southteerk, and Parts adjacent, was presented to the House, and read Setting forth, That the Petitioners find themselves much oppressed by the various Regulations which have, for some Time past, been enacted for taking their Stocks of British Spirits, and the Petitioners,

since those Regulations have paved, have been further aggrieved, by having tfacir Gdods rendered liable to Seawre for making them of a Saleable Strength, though they have bona fide paid the Duty to Government, and several of the Petitioners have already sustained great Lose from being in this Situation, and there is no Instance, within the Knowledge of the Petitioners, of any ether Trade being restrained from vending Goods agreeable to the Orders of their Customers; that upon an Advance of Malt Spirits to the Petitioners, they have no other Alternative bat reducing the Strength of their Goods in Proportion to such Rise, as the Prices of Compounds to the Consumer are continued with the same Uniformity as the Price of Beer; and that, since those Regulations were first enacted, the Price of Spirits has varied more than Twenty-seven per Cent.; that when the last Regulation took Place, and the Price of Spirits was 60 /. per Ton, the Petitioners found from Experience that such Allowance was even insufficient to carry on their Business to Advantage, and keep within the Limits of the Law, and it is therefore impossible at the present advanced Price of 661, per Ton; and that the Reasons which have been given in Support of those Regulations are, to increase the Revenue, and prevent Smuggling, and the Petitioners have every Reason to believe that the Reduction of Duty has suppressed the Smuggling of British Spirits, and renders it unnecessary to oppress the fair Traders; and that the Complaints of the Petitioners are aggravated by Dealers reducing their Goods again in the Presence of an Excise Officer, to the great Injury of the Petitioners, who are thereby undersold with their own Articles, and they apprehend, if smuggling of British Spirits can exist under the present Duty, that such Permission to the Dealer may be the Means of encouraging it, as has been heretofore experienced; that the Petitioners also suffer the same Hardships by Retailers reducing their Compounds after the same have been received say them into their Stocks, contrary to Act of Parliament, and the Petitioners conceive that, as Restrictions have been enacted for the Benefit of the Revenue, the Object of Government would be more effectually answered, if the Redaction of Compounds was confined to the Manufacturer only, with a sufficient Allowance to make his Goods fit for universal Consumption; and that the Petitioners, in their present Situation, to avoid having their Goods seized by the Regulations under the Act, are compelled either to sell them at a great Disadvantage, or to submit their Property to great Risque, that their Stocks may appear within the Limitation of the Law, and do Increase be stated upon the Excise Accounts, and the Petitioners are unwilling to pursue their Business under Restrictions which subject them to Loss, or Seizure and Penalty, and aTe anxious to participate in the common Advantages of other Traders in this Kingdom: And therefore praying to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, if n eedful, in Support of this Petition, imploring the Protection of the House for that Purpose, and for such Relief in the Matters complained of, as the House shall think most fit.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of the Owners of Ships at the Port of Leith, in that Part of Great Britain called whose Names are thereunto subscribing, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by several Acs for the Suppression of Smuggling, not only the Vessels of the notorious and flagrant Smuggler, but the Ships of the fair and open Trader, are exposed to Confiscation, and, if those Acts make any Distinction between them, the Petitioners beg Leave to suggest that the Distinction appears to be in favour of the Smuggler. The Act of the Twenty-fourth of His present Majesty, which applies principally to Vessels hovering on the Coast, and as such indisputably Smug-

flers and Objects of exemplary Punishment, has a Clause enabling the Owner or Master thereof, as well as those of the fair and open Trader, on giving Evidence of the smallness of the Quantity of Goods found on Board, and other extenuating Circumstances, to assert his Innocence, and preserve his Vessel from Forfeiture, but, by the Act of the Twenty-second of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for the " further securing the Property of the Owners in such " Ships or Vessels as are liable to Forfeiture, for " importing Spirits or other Goods by the Misconduct of the Master, Mate, and Seamen," after admitting the Hardship that Ship Owners labour under, and the Reasonableness of their being secured in their Property, only gives to the innocent Owners Penalties from the guilty Seamen, which the Owners find impossible to recover; and the Fifty-ninth Section of the Act of the Twenty-sixth of His present Majesty, enacts, " That every Ship importing any Foreign Spirituous " Liquors (British Plantation Rum and Arrack ex-t cepted) in any Cask containing less than One hundred Gallons, except Two Gallons for each Seaman, " with all her Stores and Furniture, be the Burthen " and Value thereof what they may, shall be forfeited " without any Limitation or Qualification whatsoeverand that, in consequence of those Acts, several of the Ships at the Port of Leith, employed in an open and fair Trade, have of late, on their Arrival from Abroad, been seized and detained by the Officers of the Customs, and the Owners put to great Incon-Vol. 45.

venience, Trouble, and Charges, by the Detention of their Shipping for many Months at a Time, by Application for their Release, by satisfying the seizing Officer, and by Fees, &c. notwithstanding the Liquor or other Goods above the Quantity allowed by Law, found on Board, have been trivial and inconsiderable both as to Quantity and Value, and notwithstanding the Owners and Masters of the Ships were not any way concerned in, or privy to, the Loading or having on Board the same; and that the Ships are seldom carried to Condemnation, yet the Owners, besides sustaining the aforesaid heavy and disproportioned Injury and Expences,. fire liable by the aforesaid Acts to be reduced to a State of Indigence and Beggary by having their valuable Property intirely wrested from them without any Offence whatever being committed by them, and without being able either to prevent the Offence in their Seamen, or having it in their Power to obtain any Recompenco or Satisfaction from the Aggressors, who often cannot be prevented in this unlawful Practice, and are poor in their Circumstances; and that the Ship Owners at Leith, having held a General Meeting, it was unanimously resolved to lay their hard Case before the House, to express their utter Aversion to, and Abhorrence of, all Smuggling whatever, and to submit to the Consideration of the House, whether if some Regulations similar to the following would not tend more to secure His Majesty’s Revenue, than the present Laws, which punish Persons not concerned in an illicit Trade, for the Crimes of those who at present pass with Impunity; viz. If a Law was made inflicting a heavy Penalty on the Persons actually guilty of Smuggling, and Imprisonment till paid, and enacting that where any Liquor or other Goods above the Quantity allowed by Law for the Ship’s Use, are found concealed, and the Aggressor cannot immediately, or before the Ship is cleared of her Cargo, be discovered, that the Owners are to forfeit Treble the Value of all the Goods so found, and the Ship detained until paid, such Owners being authorized to deduct the said Forfeiture out of the Wages due to the Master, Mate, and Seamen; and, if the Offender shall afterwards be discovered, the seizing Officer to cause him to be prosecuted for the said Penalty, and thereupon the Forfeiture of Treble the Value of the Goods seized, so paid by the Owners, to be repaid to him for the Use of the Persons from whom he may have deducted the same, except the Persons convicted, and their Shares to go to the Informer or Prosecutor, but the Ships to be in no Case liable to be seized or detained, unless for the aforesaid Forfeiture, nor liable to Confiscation, unless Proof is obtained that the Owners are concerned in, or privy to, the carrying on the illicit Trade; and that the Shipping at Leith is at present considerable, and breeds many Seamen for His Majesty’s Navy, as will appear from the Navy Books, where it will be found that more Seamen entered, or were impressed, for His Majesty’s Service last War than at any Port of its Size in the Kingdom, and the Port yields a considerable Revenue to Government; and that the Petitioners can-net continue to carry on the Business of Ship Owners, unless some Alteration is made in the present Penal Laws against them: And therefore they hope that Directions will be given for such a public Bill to be introduced as will repeal those Laws which subject Ships to Confiscation, where no Evidence can be adduced against the Owners of apy Connivance in, or Knowledge of, Contraband Goods being on Board, and fixing the Crime of Smuggling on board Ships employed in the open and fair Trade upon the Persons who must from the Nature of the Business be guilty, and thereby afford the Petitioners that Protection and Security which, as Persons whose Property is embarked in a Trade as fair and open in itself as productive to

3 L the

222 4° Ma. A. 1790.

the Revenue, and as advantageous to the State as arty Trade whatsoever may appear to merit, and as tb the House shall appear just.

A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by virtue of an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty, the Petitioners have made and completed a Navigable Canal, from the Trent and Mersey Navigation at Great Haywood, in the County of Stafford, to the River Severn at Stourport, in the County of Worcester, which has been productive of great public Renefit; and that the Navigation of the River Severn has never in any Respect been improved, but remains in its natural State, and is in many Places Effected by Shoals, and Beds of Rock, Sand, or Gravel, which in dry Seasons impede the Passage of Vessels, with heavy Burthens, upon it; and that the Petitioners, with a View to improve the said Navigation, iately began to remove some of the said Shoals between the Termination of the Petitioners Canal at Stourport aforesaid, and Digits, near Worcester, a Distance of about Thirteen Miles, and therein expended a considerable Sum of Money, but were prevented from effecting their Design for Wahtof Parliamentary Powers; and that the Petitioners are fully sensible, that the Removal of the said Obstructions would increase the general Advantages of their Canal, and greatly tend to the Public Benefit, aUd the Petitioners are desirous, at their own Expence, and without charging the Public with any Toll or Duty whatever, to effect the Purposes aforesaid: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a BiH to enable the Petitioners to scour, cleanse, and deepeny the Bed, or Channel, of the River Severn, from Stourport, in the County of Worcester, to Digits, near Worcester, and to remove and prevent all Obstructions therein, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of aCommittee: Ahd that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the Hous6:

And it is referred to Mr. Mr. , &c.:

And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of ffie Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Gentlemen, Freeholders, Bromham and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed. Road* Pui-being severally Owners of Estates, and Inhabitants, tion-within the several Counties of Bedford and Bucks, near the Roads herein after described, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Road leading from Bromham Bridge, by Bromham Grange, in the Parish of Bromham, in the County of Bedford, and through the Parish of Stiverton, to Tutvey, in the same County, and from Purvey, through the several Parishes of Brayfeld, Lavendon, Warrington, and Olney, in the County of Bucks, to the Turnpike Road, leading froth Wellingborough, in the same County, to Olney aforesaid, and also the Road leading from the said Turnpike Road at or near the South End of the Town of Olney, up a Lane called Dagg Lane, to Weston Underwood, in the said County of Bucks, and from Weston Underwood, through Parts of the Parishes of Raven-stone and Stoke Goldington, in the said County, to the Turnpike Road leading from the Town of Northampton to Newport Pagnell, in the said County of Bucks, are in many Parts much out of Repair, narrow and incommodious, and cannot be effectually amended, widened, and rendered safe and commodious, by the ordinary Course of Law; and that if the said Roads were properly repaired and widened, it would be of great Advantage to the Petitioners, and the rest of the Inhabitants, residing upon or near to the said Roads, and be of general Public Utility, by facilitating the Communication between the several Parishes and Places before described, with the Turnpike Road, leading from Wellingborough to Olney aforesaid, and the great Turnpike Road, leading from the Tofam of Northampton, through Newport Pagnell aforesaid, to the City of London, and making the Carriage of Com and Coals, and other Produce of Lands, and the Manufactures of those Parts of the Counties of Bedford and Bucks, adjacent to the said Roads, more easy and practicable: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for amending, widening, and keeping the said Roads in Repair, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.
