A Petition of the most Noble John Duke of Atholl, being offered to be presented to the House;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, by His Majesty's Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty, having been informed of the Contents of the said Petition, gives His Consent that the House may do therein as they shall think proper, and recommends the said Petition to the Consideration of the House.

Then the said Petition was brought up and read; Setting forth, That the Isle of Mann was, in the-Seventh Year of the Reign of Henry the Fourth, granted to Sir John Stanley, " cum omni Dominio et Justitia " Regali," under which Grant it was held and enjoyed,

until, in Order to determine some Family Disputes, and for a pecuniary Consideration paid by William Earl of Derby, King James the First, in the Seventh Year of his Reign, re-granted the Isle of Mann to that Earl, and in the same Year an Act of Parliament was passed, assuring and establishing the said Isle, unalienably in the Heirs General of James Lord Stanley, under which Parliamentary Entail, the Petitioner’s Grandfather, James Duke of Atholl, succeeded to and took Possession of the said Isle of Mann, on whose Decease, in 1764, the Succession devolved on John Duke of Atholl and Charlotte Dutchess of Atholl and Baroness Strange, his Wife, the Petitioner’s Father and Mother, and the Petitioner became entitled to the immediate Possession of the Isle of Mann, soon after the Demise of the said John Duke of Atholl, in 1774, by virtue of a Deed executed by Charlotte Dutchess of Atholl and Baroness Strange, his Mother, for Reasons therein recited; and that great Frauds and Abuses having been practised upon His Majesty’s Revenues of Customs, as well in Great Britain as in Ireland, by the illicit and clandestine Trade carried on by British and Irish Subjects between the Two Kingdoms and the Isle of Mann, and those evil Practices having grown to so unparalleled an Extent as to be productive of a Loss to the Public, which was computed at no less than at 350,000l. Annually to the Revenue* of Great Britain alone, and it being conceived that to annihilate this Evil altogether, no other Means would be effectual than that of laying heavy Prohibitions and Restrictions on Imports and Exports to and from the Island, and placing Officers of Revenue, and armed Vessels, in the Ports and Harbours thereof with Power to enforce the same, for which Purpose, and to avoid interfering with the acknowledged Rights of the Lords of Mann, and at the same Time to avdid the heavy Expence which the Public must otherwise have sustained by Coasters and other Vessels, it was thought expedient that the Sovereignty of the Island, and the Revenues of the Customs thereof, with some of the Rights of Property therein, should be re-vested in His Majesty upon a fair Compensation to "be made by the Public to the Proprietors, an Act was passed in the -JFifth Year of His Majesty’s Reign, whereby

the said Island, and the Sovereignty of the same, were vested in the Crown, reserving only to the Proprietors thereof their Landed Property and Manorial Rights by Words of Exception contained in the said Act, and the Sum of 70,000 /. was thereby directed to be paid by the Public, and to be vested in Lands for the Uses in the said Act mentioned, as a Compensation for the Sovereignty and Rights of Property so vested in the Crown, and to which it is proper the Petitioner should add, for the Information of the House, His Majesty was pleased subsequently to grant to the said Duke and Dutchess of Atholl, the Petitioner’s Father and Mother, for their Lives, and the Life of the Survivor of them, an Annuity of 2,000l. per Annum, on the Irish Establishment, in Consideration, as it is expressed in the Grant, that the Revenues of Ireland, as well as those of Great Britain, would be greatly improved by the Surrender of the Island; and that the said re-vesting Act was made under the Pressure of the Moment, when the Urgency of the Mischief called for an immediate and effectual Remedy, and when, from the recent Possession of the Petitioner’s Father and Mother, they could form no accurate Idea of the Extent or Value of the Rights and Interests which were necessary to be ceded, and the Act was passed without any Evidence produced to prove what Rights of Property in particular were necessary to be vested in the Crown for the Security of the Public Revenue (the sole Object of the Act) from future Frauds and Evasions; and for want of those Lights and proper Precautions, the Proprietors were under the general Transfer, and Re-vestment of the Island, and its Sovereignty, divested of sundry valuable Privileges and Rights of Property, not only unnecessary to have been transferred for the Protection and Security of the Public Revenue, but from their Nature wholly unconnected with it, and which, though they afford little Benefit to the Public, were of material Importance to the Petitioner and his Family; and that in the Hurry of the Transaction of 1765, arising from the Urgency already stated, the Titles of the Petitioner’s Family appear not to have been perfectly understood, insomuch that Words of great legal Import, contained in the Act of the Seventh of King James the First, for the Settlement and Entail of the said Island unalienably, were omitted to be inserted in the Preamble of the said Bill of 1765, and which, as the Petitioner is advised, militate against the Power of James Duke of Atholl, to new model the Succession by the Deed of Trust of 1756, recited in the said Preamble, but to the Uses of which Settlement the said 70,000l. has been actually applied by the Trustees thereof, under the Sanction given to the new Entail by that Agreement, made between the Crown and the said Trustees, and under the Power also given to the Trustees of the same Entail by the Provisions of the said Act for vesting Mann in the Crown; and that, as the Petitioner does not contest the Proposition that private Advantage should give way to public Expediency, so also he hopes that it will not be denied that a full and fair Compensation should be allowed to any Individual for such Rights of his as may be deemed necessary for the public Service; and the Petitioner is confident that upon a minute Investigation, it will be found that the Sum of 70,000l. and the said Annuity granted to his Family in 1765, were by no Means an adequate Compensation for the said Transfer, and that this Inadequacy might have proceeded from the probable Reasoning at the Time of the contingent Nature of the Revenue of the Isle of Mann, and which it might have been supposed would be considerably reduced by the Annihilation of the Contraband Trade, carried on by British Subjects to England, Scotland, and Ireland; that it appears by the Schedule annexed to the Act of 1765, the Revenues of the Isle of Mann

amounted,

amounted, for Five Years, to about 6,500l. Annually, and although from the Circumstance of the Merchants having an extraordinary Quantity of Goods on Hand, which, by Prohibitions laid on in 1765, were of Necessity kept for the sole Consumption of the Inhabitants, and by the Duties even on those having been, in a great Measure, evaded, the Revenues of Customs were considerably less productive than they would otherwise have been for a Course of Years after the Re-vestment, yet it will be found, on Enquiry, that exclusive of the Harbour Dues, and the Produce of the Herring and Salmon Fisheries, they have amounted, on an Average, for the whole Period since 1765 to about 3,000l. and

that they have been progressively improving, insomuch, that for some Years past they have amounted to nearly 5,000l. Annually, and that, with proper Management and Attention, no Doubt can be entertained of their future Increase; that he 'is confident it cannot be with reason contended that the Sums above stated were an adequate Compensation for such a Revenue, and for those Sovereign Rights and Prerogatives, and the Property of those Castles and Harbours which became vested in the Crown; that the Petitioner trusts it will appear, that in affording him that Redress which is the Ground of his Petition, and by restoring to his Family those specific Rights which do not bear upon or connect themselves in any Degree with the pernicious Practices for the Prevention of which the Act of 1765 was passed, the primary Object of the Legislature will be perfectly attained, and every Clause of the Act of 1765, and of every other posterior Act, which secures and guards the Revenues of the Public from Abuse or Evasion, continue in full Force and in full Effect; and that the Petitioner has no Wish to interfere in any Instance, or in any Manner, with the Sovereignty of the Crown, or with any of the Powers given by the Act of 1765, which are necessary for public Purposes, that he only desires that Parliament may restore to him such Rights as are consistent with the Safety of the Revenue, and enable him to avail himself of such Rights, and receive the Benefit of such Branches of his Property, as have been lost to him, and have not been productive to the Public, and that by a permanent Arrangement and Settlement of those Circumstances which the Petitioner has laid before Parliament in his Petition, the private Interest of his Family in the Isle of Mann, he trusts, will appear to be in no Degree incompatible with the Public Advantage: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for appointing Commissioners to enquire what Rights and Species of Property are necessary or expedient to remain vested in the Crown for the Protection and Security of the Public Revenues, and what are the Value thereof, and also how far, and to what Extent or Value, the Petitioners -remaining Rights and Interests in the said Island have been, or will, by the Dismemberment thereof, be impaired or diminished, or that the House will afford such other Relief to the Petitioner as they shall think fit.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Mr. Selby’s A Petition of Thomas Selby, Esquire, and Catherine

Petition.y his Wife, and William Commyns, Esquire, on Behalf of themselves, and of Patrick Power, Esquire, William Carr, Esquire, and Henrietta his Wife, Barbara White, Widow of Nicholas White, Esquire, deceased, Charlotte Strickland, Spinster, and Sir John Lawson, Baronet, which said Catherine Selby, William Commyns, Patrick Power, Henrietta Carr, Barbara White, and Charlotte Strickland, are the Heirs at Law of Sir Roger Strickland, late of Cattcrick, in the County of York, Baronet, deceased, being offered to be presented to the House;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, by His Majesty’s Vol. /45.

Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty, having been informed of the Contents of the said Petition, recommends it to the Consideration of the House.

Then the said Petition was brought up, and read;

Setting forth, That the said Sir Roger Strickland being seised as Tenant in Tail Male of the Manor of Catterick, and of several Messuages, Lands, and Hereditaments, in the Parish of Catterick aforesaid, with Remainder to Robert Strickland, his younger Brother, for Life, with Remainder to the First and other Son and Sons of the said Robert Strickland successively in Tail Male, with Remainder to the said Sir Roger Strickland and his Heirs, was in the Year 1689 attainted of High Treason, and thereby forfeited to the Crown all the Estates of which he was then seised, in Possession or in Reversion, and the Crown accordingly seized and held the said Manor and Hereditaments until the Death of Sir Roger Strickland, which happened in or about the Year 1717, without his leaving any Issue; and that the said Robert Strickland having died in the Life Time of the said Sir Roger Strickland his Brother, leaving Issue Three Sons, the Eldest of whom did, upon the Death of the said Sir Roger Strickland, claim to be entitled to the said Manor and Hereditaments as Tenant in Tail Male, by reason that the said Forfeiture was, by the Death of the said Sir Roger Strickland without Issue, suspended as long as there should be Issue Male of his Father, the said Robert Strickland, existing, and his Claim being allowed, he was accordingly let into Possession of the said Manor and Hereditaments, the Reversion in Fee thereof still remaining vested in the Crown; and that, by virtue of divers Conveyances, Assurances, and Acts, in Law, the said Thomas Selby, and Catherine his Wife, in Right of the said Catherine, the said William Commyns, the said Patrick Pozcer, the said William Carr and Henrietta his Wife, in Right of the said Henrietta, the said Nicholas White and Barbara his Wife, in Right of the said Barbara, and the said Charlotte Strickland, became and are now in the actual Seisin or Possession of the said Estates as Tenants in Common, except a small Part thereof, which hath been lately purchased by the said Sir John Lawson, but Doubts have arisen whether the Reversion of and in the said Estates, which by virtue of the said Attainder became vested in the Crown as aforesaid, has ever been barred, by Reason whereof no Person may chuse to become a Purchaser of the said Estates at a full and valuable Consideration: And therefore praying. That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for divesting the Crown of the Reversion of the said Estates, and vesting the same in the several Persons who are now in the Seisin or Possession thereof.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morn- Supply de-ing, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole ferred. House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, ways and resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to Means de-consider further of Ways and Means for raising the fen-ed-Supply granted to His Majesty.

An ingrossed Bill for taking off the Dufies upon Tin Bill Unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries passed, beyond the Cape of Good Hope, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for taking off the Duties upon Unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good Hope.

Ordered, That the Marquis of Graham do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

The Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Seven-night, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of die Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating " the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s " Colonies and Plantations in North America, and in the West India Islands, and the Countries belonging " to the United States of America, and between His Majesty’s said Subjects and the Foreign Islands in " The West Indies'," and the other intituled, "An Act " to allow the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, " from His Majesty’s Colonies or Plantations in The " West Indies into the Province of Quebec, without " Payment of Duty, under certain Conditions and " Restrictions."

Ordered, That Mr. Flood have Leave to make a Motion, it being after Five of the Clock.

And he moved the House accordingly;

And the Question being proposed, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for amending the Representation of the People in Parliament;

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That the House do now adjourn;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

And the House accordingly adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Dudley Road Petition.

find Application hath been made to the House, by the Commissioners for paving, cleansing, and lighting several Streets and other Places within the said City and Liberty, and Parts adjacent, for Leave to bring in a Bill to enable them to enforce the Payment of the Rates authorized to be made within the said Optional Streets, and for other Purposes; and Representing to the House, That by an Act, made in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Power of paving the several Streets within the said United Parishes, which were then under the Management of the said Commissioners (except the said Optional Streets) were taken out of the Hands of the Commissioners, and put under the Management of a certain Number of the Parishioners, to be Annually chosen Committee Men by the Vestry of the said United Parishes, subject in some Respects to the COntroul of the said Commissioners, but the said Optional Streets still continue and are now under the sole Direction and Management of the said Commissioners; and that the Inhabitants of the said Optional Streets have been and now are charged with much higher Rates, for the several Purposes aforesaid, than the Inhabitants of the other Streets within the said United Parishes for the same Purposes, and they apprehend, if the said Optional Streets were put under the Management of the said Committee Men in like Manner as the other Streets and Places within the said United Parishes, the Works within the said Optional Streets would be properly done, and at a much less Expence to the Inhabitants than they are now charged with for the same: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for putting the said Optional Streets under the Management of the said Committee Men for the future, or that a Bill may be brought in for giving the said Committee Men the like P ower over the said Optional Streets, as they have over the other Streets and Places within the said United Parishes.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the Petition of the Commissioners for putting in Execution the several Acts of Parliament for paving, cleansing, and fighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and other Parts therein mentioned, is referred; and that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

A Petition of the Right honourable William Lord Viscount Dudley and Ward, and the humble Petition of several Gentlemen, Merchants, Manufacturers, and others, of the Counties of Worcester, Stafford, and Salop, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Road leading from Cuddick’s Ena, in the Parish of Dudley, in the County of Worcester, to a House called The New Inn, in the Parish of Pattingham, in the County of Salop, is in a ruinous Condition, and in several Parts narrow, and at some Times almost impassable for Carriages, and there are some very considerable Windings in the Course of the said Road; and that, if the said Road was properly amended and widened, and the Course thereof altered, in the Parishes of Dudley and Sedgley, and in such other Places as shall be judged necessary, so as to make the said Road shorter, and more safe and commodious, and in a more direct Line than at present, Vojl, 45.

the same would be a great Benefit to Travellers and other Persons having Occasion to pass upon the said Road, and, by opening a regular Communication with several considerable Collieries and Lime Works, and also with several extensive Manufactories, would be of great public Benefit: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for amending, widening, altering, and keeping in Repair, the said Road, by such Ways and Means, and in such Manner, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Lygon, Mr. Foley, &c.:

And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Drainage thereunto subscribed, being Owners or Proprietors, or Agents for Owners or Proprietors, of Lands and Tenements in the several Townships of Croston, Mcrwdesley, Rufford, Latham, Bispham, and Ulnes-Walton, all in the County of Lancaster, or some or One of them, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That there are, in the several Townships above-mentioned, a considerable Extent of Low Lands, which are subject to be overflowed, and thereby much damaged, and, in their present Situation, incapable of any considerable Improvement, but, if the said Lands were drained, it would be of great Advantage to the Owners and Proprietors thereof, and of public Utility: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for draining the said Lands, in such Manner, and under such Regulations and Restrictions, as to the House shall seem meet.

Bowes Road

Petition

reported.

Admiral Leoeson reported from the Committee, to

whom the Petition of several Trustees appointed to put in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for repairing " and widening the Road from Bowes, in the County " of York, to Brough under in the County of Westmorlandand also an Act of Parliament,

made and passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, intituled, "An Act for continuing and rendering more effectual " an Act for repairing the Road from Bowes, in the " County of York, to Brough under in the County of Westmorland, and for repairing and " widening the Road from Maiden Castle to " Cross, and also the Road from Maiden Castle to the " Coal Works at Taylor Rigg, and to Tan Hill and " King's Pitts, and also the Road from Barrow Brow " to Middle Fell Dyke Nook, in the said Counties, also " from Tan Hill and King's Pitts, to Beck Crooks and " Punchatt Pasture West Gate, to Whaw Lane Head, " and by Lilly Jocks to and several other

Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had

been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Aets were read: And,

Edward Heelis being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded to put the said Acts in Execution, and have borrowed several considerable Sums of Money, of which the Sum of 1,649/. now remains due —

That the said Roads cannot be kept in Repair, nor the said Money be repaid, unless the Terms granted by the said Acts be further continued, and the Powers thereof altered and enlarged — That the Road leading from the said Road, between Maiden Castle and Kaber Cross aforesaid, near a Place called Buckles Stoop, over Buskay Moor, to Church Brough, and also the Road leading from the said Road, between Maiden Castle, by Tan Hill and King’s Pitts, to Reeth aforesaid, to the Collieries now open at Kettlepot, are in a ruinous Condition, and that the making and repairing the same will be of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of Two Acts, of the Sixteenth Year of King George the Second, and the Ninth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Bowes, in the County of York, to Brough under Stainmore, in the County of Westmorland, and from Maiden Castle to Kaber Cross, and to the Coal Works at Taylor Riggy and to Tan Hill and King’s Pitts, and from Barrow Brow to Middle Fell Dyke Nook, and from Tan Hill and King’s Pitts to Beck Crooks and Punchatt Pasture West Gate, to JVhcew Lane Head, and by Jocks

to Reeth, in the said Counties; and for repairing and widening the Road from Buckles Stoop to Church Brough, and from the said Maiden Castle and Taylor Rigg Road to the Colliery at Kettlepot, in the County of Westmorland: And that Admiral Leoeson and Sir Michael Le Fleming do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Owners, Proprietors, and Workers Petition of Lead Mines, in the County of York, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on the Behalf of themselves n 1 and the other Owners and Proprietors, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for building a Bridge at or near the Ferry over the River Ouse, from Selby, in the West Riding of the County of York, to the opposite Shore, in the Parish of Hemingborough, in the East Riding of the said

County of York;and Setting forth, That the Petitioners convey a great Part of the Produce of their Mines to the River Ouse, and Canals communicating the rewith, and the same is conveyed down the said River to York, and into the River Humber, and the Petitioners hoped that the free Navigation of the said River, which is of such material Consequence to them, would not have been interrupted or rendered dangerous by any Bridge to be erected in the Tidesway upon the said River; and that the Petitioners are thoroughly convinced, that a Bridge to be erected at Selby, where the Current is rapid, the Tide flowing high, and the River narrow, will render the Navigation of the said River extremely dangerous, greatly impede and delay the free Course of Trade along the said River, and be extremely prejudicial to the Petitioners: And therefore praying. That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, but the Course and Navigation of the said River remain as it is at present, that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves and their Counsel, against the said Bill, or have other Relief in the Premises.

A Petition of the Inhabitants of the Town of Petition from Hemingbrough, in the County of York, was also pre- Heming-sented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice brough of the said Bill; and Setting forth. That according jjSjJIMt dltto to the Custom of England, the Men and Tenants of the ancient Demesne of the Crown of England are freed, and so ought to be, from all Pannage,

Morage, and Passage, in and throughout the whole Realm of Englandtand are entitled to divers other

A Petition of the Land Owners and Lime Burners Petition in the Town arid Neighbourhood of , in the agaiustSelby

County of York, was likewise presented to the House, n ge 1 ' arid read; also taking Notice of the said Bill; arid Setting forth, That the Petitioners Lime, arid other Goods are conVeyed on the River Ouse to the City of York, and other Plaees above Selby, in the Petitioner^ Vessels, and they derive great Benefit from such Trade, the River Ouse being now safe fop the Passage of Vessels; and that the Petitioners) well know that the building any Bridge in the Tidesway of a navigable River, is extremely prejudicial to the Navigation thereof, and they have reason to apprehend the worst Consequences froin the Erection of one at Selby, in a narrow part of the River where the Tides flow very high, and the Current is rapid, and, as the Navigation of thfe said River will be thereby rendered, in an eminent Degree, dangerous, the Erection of such Bridge will, of Course, be extreitiely detri-iriental to the Interests of the Petitioners: Ana therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may be indemnified against the Loss and Damage of their Vessels at such Bridge in such Mariner as to the House shall seem meet.

Otdered, That the said Bill be read a Second Time upon Tuesday Sevennight, the Sixteenth Day of this Instant March.

A Petition of Richard Harvey, Clerk, Vicar of the Ramsgate Church of Saint Laurence, in the Isle of in Chapel Peti-

the County of Kdnt, arid of divers ' Inhabitants of tion' the Parish of Saint Laurence aforesaid, was presented to the HousC, and read; Setting forth, That the Towri Or Vifl of Ramsgate, within the Parish of Sdiht Ldurtnte, in the Isle of Thanet, in the County of Rent, hath of late Years considerably increased, and is still likely to increase, iri Extent' of Buildings, and Nuiriber Of Inhabitants; and that the Church of the said'

Parish of Saint Laurence is a Mile distant from a great Part Of the said Town of Vill of Ramsgate, and besides^ is nOt’ found sufficient for the Accommodation of all the Inhabitants of the said Parish, and it would be a very great Convenience to the Inhabitants of Ramsgate, to have a Place for Divine Worship within the' said Town or Vill; and that the Church of the said1 Parish of Saint Laurence is a Rectory Impro-

3 N priate

priate within the Diocese of Canterbury, and the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, in Right of his See, is seised of the Rectory Impropriate of the said Church, and, as Rector of the said Church, is entitled to collate to the Vicarage thereof; and that the said Archbishop of Canterbury, upon Application from the said Richard Harvey, the present Vicar of the said Parish of Saint Laurence, and from various Inhabitants of Ramsgate, and others, have approved of having a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the said Parish of Saint Laurence, erected and established within the said Town or Vill, for the Accommodation of the Inhabitants thereof, and John Fagg, of Ramsgate, Gentleman, being seised in Fee Simple of a certain Piece of Freehold Ground in the said Town or Vill, hath lately consented to make a Donation of the said Piece of Ground, for the Purpose of having the same appropriated to the building of a Chapel of Ease thereon to the Church of the stud Parish of Saint Laurence', and that the said John Fagg,the said Richard Harvey, Joseph Norwood, of Canterbury, Esquire, John Holman, and John Horn, of Ramsgate, Gentleman, have, at their own Expence, caused to be erected upon the said Piece of Ground a Building intended for a Place of Divine Worship, ‘and to be a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the said Parish of Saint Laurence, and the same is already completed and furnished: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Laurence in the Isle of in the County of Kent, as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the same Place.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Stephens, Mr. Brett, &c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Petition A Petition of the Manufacturers of Tobacco and

-against the Snuff in the Town of Paisley, North Britain, was obacco Act presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, the Petitioners were subjected to the Laws of Excise, and by the said Act the Manufacturers are subjected to a new and arbitrary Mode of Manufacture, to the great additional Expence and Inconvenience of the/ Manufacturers, as well as imminent Danger of the Loss of their Customers — That it imposes Rules and Regulations on the Manufacturer, which in many Cases cannot be conformed to, without rendering the Goods unfit for his Customer, and subjects' the Manufacturer to Pains and Penalties which he can neither foresee nor prevent — That it puts a total Stop to every Improvement in the Manufacture; as it restricts the Manufacturer in his Returns to certain per Cents. which cannot be complied with but at the Risque of spoiling the Whole, and with as much (or indeed more) Propriety might the Legislature enact that every Farmer in Great Britain should be compelled to produce a certain specified Quantity of Flour or Meal, and no more, from the same Quantity of Corn, of whatever Quality it might" be of, it being a well known Fact, that there are as many or more different Qualities of Tobacco than there are of Corn, and consequently their Retuns as different — That it prevents the Manufacturer supplying his Customer for Ten or Fourteen Days, or often longer, though all the Time in Possession of the Goods wanted, the Manufacturer being obliged to finish the Manufacture of the whole Parcel before he dare use any Part of it — That it occasions Delays and Interruptions quite inconsistent with the Nature of Trade, and which must

soon drive the Manufacture of that Article out of the Country — That it exposes the Mysteries of the Trade to the Officers and to the Smugglers, and gives a.

Power to the Officer to ruin the Business of any Manufacturer; and that it is the Opinion of the Petitioners, an Excise Law is totally inapplicable to the.

Manufacture of Tobacco, an Article which undergoes; such a Variety of Alterations in the Process of Manufacture, and it is also their Opinion, no Law consistent with the British Constitution can ever be effectual in, raising a Revenue on Tobacco, while the Duties continue so high, and they see nothing before them but the Ruin of their Manufacture, and the Triumph of the Smuggler, unless the Duties are considerably reduced:

And therefore praying, That the said Act may be repealed, and the Duties on Tobacco reduced, so that the Revenue may be benefited, and the Fair Trader »

relieved.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of several Journeymen Silk Weavers, Coventry Silk residing in the City of Coventry, and in several Towns petition* and Places in the County of Warwi, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That the.

Journeymen Silk Weavers in the said City, and.

Towns and Places aforesaid, have for many Years past laboured under great Hardships, on Account of the Abatements frequently made in their Wages, and also from the Master Weavers being allowed to take and have in their Service at the same Time any Number of Apprentices they think proper; and that it would be a great Relief to the Petitioners, and to all the other Journeymen employed in the Silk Manufacture, within the City of Coventry, and County of Warwick, and would, in the Opinion of the Petitioners, tend to encourage the Silk Manufacture carried on therein, if the like Provision was made with respect to all Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in the said City and County of Warwick, as 'is made by an Act of the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, with respect to the Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in the Cities of London and Westminster, and County of Middlesex, and the Liberty of the Tower of London: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief as the House shall think, just and reasonable.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Wilmot, the Lord Eardley,

&c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh presented Bromsgrove to the House, according to Order, a Bill to enlarge f"*1 the Terms and Powers of Three several Acts, made in j^ented. the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of King George the.

First, the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King George the Second, and the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Bromsgrove, in the County, of Worcester, to the Town of Birmingin the County of Warwick: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the principal Inhabitants, and Manu- petition facturers, of the Town of Birmingham, in the County against the of Warwick, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed, an r CanaT*"

Applica- Bill.

Petition against the Birmingham and Worces* ter Canal Bill.

231

Application is making to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill for making a new Canal Navigation, from the Town of Birmingham to the River Secern, at Digits, near Worcester;and that there has been already made and completed, at a very large Expence, one Communication by Water, from the Town of Birmingham, to Worcester, by Means of the present Birmingham, and the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canals, which falls into the River Severn at Stourport, and another Communication is now making, under the Sanction of Parliament, and nearly finished, between those Places and the Collieries on the Upper Line of the said Birmingham Canal, by Means of the Junction of the Dudley and Birmingham Canals at Tipton, which will be fully sufficient to answer every good and useful Purpose of Water Conveyance between the Town of Birmingham and Worcester, and the City of Worcester, and other Places down the Secern, may be thereby supplied with Coals from the Mines lying at a Distance from Birmingham, instead of taking them from that Manufacturing Town, and upon as cheap Terms as by the proposed Canal; and that no Public Meeting has been called to consider of the Expediency or Utility of making such new Canal, and the Petitioners conceive the same calculated to answer the private Views of the Schemers thereof, and not founded on Principles either of Necessity, or real Public Utility-; and that Birmingham is a large and populous Town, in which various Manufactories in Iron, and other Metals, are carried on, and such Manufactures greatly depend upon, and cannot be advantageously prosecuted without, a regular Supply of Coals at a moderate Price; and that Coals have been for some Time past, and now are sold at a considerable advanced Price at the said Town, and the Petitioners are fully satisfied that the proposed Canal, if made, will increase the Price of Coals, and prove highly injurious to the Trade and Manufactures of the said Town: And therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, and that the Petitioners may be heard by Counsel against the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed. Owners and Occupiers of Water Mills and other Works, upon the several Rivers, Brooks, Streams, and Rivulets, lying between the Town of Birmingham and the City of Worcester, and the Neighbourhood thereof, was also presented to the House, and read; taking Notice of the Application mentioned in the last preceding Petition; and Setting forth, That, below the Line of such intended Canal, there are many Mills worked by Water flowing from various Springs and Brooks arising in and above the Line of such intended Canal, at which Mills very extensive Trades and Manufactures are carried on, and very large Sums of Money have been expended in planting and establishing such Works and Manufactures, and the Support and Maintenance of a large Body of Manufacturers and Labourers, their Wives and Children, depend on such Works; and that the present Supply of Water is not fully sufficient for the necessary Uses of the said Mills and Works, and, in' case the said intended Canal should take place, the same must unavoidably intercept and take away great Part of the Resources of Water which now feed and support the Brooks and Streams from whence the said Mills are supplied with Water, and thereby such Mills and Works will be very considerably injured, if not wholly ruined, and the Trade lost; and that the Petitioners hope their Manufactories will be deemed of Public Utility and Importance, and on that Account entitled to Encouragement and Protection, and they apprehend no Advantage is likely to be derived to the Public from the said intended Canal adequate to the Injury which the Petitioners and others will unavoidably sustain by it: And therefore praying. That such Bill may not pass into a Law,

Vol, 45.

and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the same.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Secern, near to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and the Petitioners are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

A Petition of Richard Benyon, Esquire, and the Re- Petition verend Peter Beauvoir (Rector of the Parish of Saint ®pin»t John, Hackney, in the County of Middlesex) Lords of church^ill the Manor, and Patrons of the Rectory, of Hackney aforesaid, as Trustees and Devisees in Fee under the v Will of Francis John Tyssen Esquire, deceased, and of several Owners of Lands and Estates and principal Inhabitants within the said Parish, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That a Bill is depending in the House, to enable Trustees to purchase Land in such Part of the said Parish as they shall think fit, and to build a new Parish Church, with other Buildings thereon, and likewise to set out Part of such Land for a Cemetery or Burial Ground, for the Inhabitants of the said Parish; and that the Petitioners are informed and believe that the present Church and Tower, or such Part thereof as shall be found necessary, might be taken down, and re-built upon the present Foundation, or sufficiently enlarged on the present Scite, and made commodious for the Inhabitants, at a very moderate Expence, and the Owner of a certain Piece of Ground contiguous thereto is willing to accommodate the Parish with such a Quantity of Ground as shall be thought necessary to be made use of for enlarging the said Burial Ground; and that the purchasing Land, and erecting and fitting up a new Parish Church and other Buildings, as proposed by the said Bill, which must be attended with a very considerable Expence, will create a great and unnecessary Burthen upon the Petitioners, and the several other Inhabitants and Owners of Lands and Estates within the said Parish: And therefore praying,

That they may be beard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill in its present Form, and against the several Provisions thereof, and that the Powers thereof may be confined to taking down and re-building upon the same Foundation the present Church and Tower, or such Part thereof as shall be found necessary, or to re-build and enlarge the same on the present Scite, and for enlarging the present Church Yard, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Bill for taking down the Church and Tower belonging to the Parish of Hackney, in the County of Middlesex, and for building another Church and Tower for the Use of the said Parish, and for enlarging the Cemetery, or Church Yard, belonging thereto, is committed: And that the Petitioners be heard, by their Coupsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition,

Petition from A Petition of the Merchants and Owners of Ships Liverpool in the Port of Liverpool, whose Names are thereunto the*Confis- subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; cation of Setting forth, That the numerous and important Ad-

Ship*. vantages arising to every Maritime Power from em-

ploying the greatest possible Number of Ships in the Carrying Trade, are Facts too well known, and too firmly established, to require fresh Proofs, or further Notice, to any Member of the Legislature; and that other Nations, who wish now to acquire, or aim at increasing their already acquired, Maritime Strength, are using every Art, and exerting their utmost Efforts,

- to gain as large a Share as possible in that advantageous Employment, and, whilst other States are holding out particular and considerable Encouragements for this special Purpose, many and most depressing Clauses in our own Laws are permitted to remain unrepealed, and almost unnoticed: That, by an Act of the Nineteenth Year of His present Majesty, Owners of Ships are made answerable for all Spirituous Liquors, Tea, or Coffee, found on Board their Ships, on Arrival in Great Britain, from any Foreign Ports in Europe, in small Packages, exceeding a certain Allowance for each Man on Board, as specified in the said Act, and the Punishment for such Delinquency, though committed without the Knowledge of the Owners, and in express Breach of their positive Orders, is no less than the Confiscation of the Ship, with her Tackle and Furniture; and that the Value of such Ship is usually from One to Three thousand Pounds or upwards, and the Purchase of the Liquors, Coffee, or Tea, for which this heavy Penalty is incurred, will seldom amount to Thirty Pounds, and not often to a Third Part of that Sum, and such a Disproportion between the Crime and the Punishment, and the Infliction of that Punishment upon those who are not only clear of all Offence, actual or intentional, but have it not by any possible Means within their Power to prevent the Commission of the Crime, is certainly a Hardship which calls loudly for Redress; and that the said Law, as it now stands, is a great Discouragement to Persons of Property and Character from becoming Owners of Ships in the Carrying Trade, and without proper Modifications must tend eventually to injure much, if not totally destroy, that excellent Nursery for Seamen; and that, if the absolute Confiscation of the Spirits, Tea, and Coffee, and an additional pecuniary Penalty, payable by the Defaulter, bearing some Proportion to the Duty upon the Articles so seized, were imposed, and rigorously exacted, the Punishment would become an Act. of Justice, and the Crime be no less an Object of Vol. 45.

.Detestation: And therefore praying, That such Relief ,uu\y be granted the Petitioners as the House shall judge needful.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of the Right honourable George Earl of Tamer Ferry Mount Edgcumbe, and the humble Petition of Reginald Petitio". Pole Carew, of East Antony, in the County of Cornwall, Esquire, being offered to be presented to the House;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, by His Majesty’s Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty, having been informed of the Contents of the said Petition, recommends it to the Consideration of the House.

Then the said Petition was brought up, and read;

Setting forth, That the Parishes of Stoke Damarel, in the County of Devon, and Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall, are situate nearly opposite to each other, upon the Great navigable River, called The Tamer, and contain several Towns, Villages, or Hamlets (particularly Plymouth Dock, in the said County of Devon, ana Torpoint, in the said County of Cornwall) which are become very populous, and Places of considerable Resort, whereby a constant Intercouse is occasioned between the Inhabitants of the said Parishes, and the establishing and maintaining of a Ferry for the Conveyance of Persons, Cattle, Carriages, Goods, and Merchandize, between the said several Parishes, across the said River, will not only be of great and permanent Utility and Convenience to the Inhabitants of both Parishes, as well as to those of other Parts of the stud several Counties, but of public Benefit; and that the Petitioners are willing, at their own Charges, to provide, maintain, and keep, a competent Number of substantial and convenient Boats for the Use of the said Ferry, with a sufficient Number of able and experienced Ferrymen, and to erect Dwelling Houses and other necessary and convenient Buildings for the Purposes thereof, on being authorized to demand and receive reasonable Rates for Passage and Conveyance; and that the Ground requisite for the Purpose of such Ferry, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel aforesaid, is vested in the most Noble George Marquis Townshend, the Right honourable Jeffery Lord Amherst, and the Right honourable Charles Lord Somers, in Trust for His Majesty, and the Ground requisite for that Purpose in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacojb, otherwise Antony in the East aforesaid, is the Inheritance or Freehold of the Petitioner, Reginald Pole Carew: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for authorizing and enabling the Petitioners to establish and maintain a common Ferry over and across the River Tamer, between Plymouth Dock, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel, in the County of Devon, and Torpoint, in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall, to contain such Clauses, Provisions, Authorities, Regulations, and Restrictions, as. the Nature of the Case may require, and to the House shall seem meet

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Bastard, Mr. Aldridge, See.:

And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

3 O " Parish

" Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the " several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping " the said Road in Repair for the future;" and also another Act of Parliament, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers granted by the said Act, and for repairing several other Roads adjoining to the said Road, whose Names are thereunto subscribed) was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Trustees for putting the said Acts in Execution have opened and made a new Road, pursuant to the Directions of the said first-mentioned Act, and upon the Credit thereof have borrowed a considerable Sum of Money, which, together with the Tolls collected, have been expended in making the said Road, and keeping the same, and the several other Roads mentioned in the said last mentioned Act, in Repair; nevertheless, the said Roads cannot be kept effectually in Repair, and amended according to the true Intent and Meaning of the said Acts, and the Monies advanced On the Credit thereof be repaid, unless the Term thereby granted be enlarged, and the said Acts made more effectual; and that the Part of the said Road, leading through Part of a certain Street, called The Folly, in the Parish of Bermondsey, in Surrey, is very narrow, whereby the Passage thereof is greatly impeded, to the Inconvenience of the Public, and the Inhabitants, and the same cannot be widened without a great Expence, whereas a safe and commodious Road might be made to avoid the said Street, to lead from Dockhead, in the said Parish, on the South Side of the said Street,. called The to Lilliput Hall

Bridge, being Fifty Rods in Length, and it will be of much Advantage to the Public, to make a new Road, to lead from the South East End of Free School Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, through Three Oak Lane, to join the said Turnpike Road at Dockhead aforesaid, being Thirty Rods in Length, and also a new Road, from the said Turnpike Road at the East End of Mill Pond Street, in the Parish of Bermondsey aforesaid, through certain Grounds, to the West End of Paradise Row, in the Parish of Rotherhith, in the County of Surrey, being Eighty-eight Rods in Length: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term granted by the said last mentioned Act, and for explaining, amending, and making more effectual the same, and for making and keeping in Repair the several Roads to and from the several Places herein-before last described, in such Manner and Method as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is refered to Sir Joseph Lord

William Russell, &c.: And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mumby, A Petition of several of the Owners and Proprietors Hogsthorpe, of, or Persons otherwise interested in, the Open Fields, and Anderby Lands, and Grounds herein after mentioned, was pre-Petitfon? sented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That there are, within the Parishes of , Hogsthorpe,

and Anderby, in the County of Lincoln, certain Open and Uninclosed Arable Fields, Common Pastures, and other Common and Waste Grounds, computed to contain in the Whole about 2,700 Acres, which, in their present Situation, are capable of very little Improvement, but, if the same were inclosed, and specific Shares thereof allotted to the several Proprietors, a considerable Benefit would accrue to all the Parties interested therein, and to the Public in general: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring

in a Bill for effecting the Purposes above-mentioned, subject to such Regulations as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are PetitioR thereunder written, Dealers by Retail in Spirituous against the Liquors, and Householders, residing in the City and Spirituous Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, was pre- Licence Act. sented to the' House, and read; Setting forth. That by an Act, made in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty’s for laying additional Duties upon Licences, to be taken out by Persons dealing by Retail in Spirituous Liquors, the Petitioners are required to take out an additional Licence Annually, and the Sums paid for such Licences are regulated by the Rates of the Houses occupied by the Petitioners, and, by the said Act, they are required to attend at the Chief Office of Excise in London, Eight Times in each Year, to pay by Instalments the Sums directed by the said Act, and all Houses rated under 15/. per Annum, occupied by Retailers of Spirituous Liquors, pay 2/. 1 os. per Annum for such Licence, which Payment increases according to the Sums at which the Houses are rated; and that, prior to the said Act, the Legislature, in Tenderness to the fair Trader, reduced the Duties upon Spirituous Liquor's so low, as to enable the Petitioners to purchase Brandy, of the first Quality, at Seven Shillings and Six Pence per Gallon upon the Average, but which, at this Time, cannot be bought for less than Eleven Shillings, and the Prices of Rum, and other Spirits, have advanced in Proportion; and that the Petitioners conceive the said additional Licence was directed by the House in Consequence of the then reduced Price of Spirituous Liquors, and upon the Ground of the Petitioners not being liable to the then existing Tax on Shops; and that the Petitioners are at all Times willing to contribute to the Exigencies of their Country, in common with their Fellow Citizens, but feel themselves partially aggrieved by the Continuance of the said additional Licence, as the Payment of the Instalments is attended with great Trouble, Spirituous Liquors are nearly as dear as ever, and as the Shopkeepers have experienced the Liberality of the House by a Repeal of the Shop Tax, the Petitioners crave Leave to submit their Case to the Consideration of the House: And therefore praying, That the said Act of the Twenty-seventh of His present' Majesty may be repealed, and that they may be heard, by themselves and Counsel, in Support of this their Petition.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the -Table.

A Petition of Samuel Phipps, Esquire, Lord of the Manor of BuckneU, in the County of Salop, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That there are within the said Manor certain Woods and Wood Lands, the Property of the Petitioner, in which the Owners and Proprietors of certain ancient Messuages or Tenements within the said Manor are entitled to a Right of Estovers; and there are also within the said Manor certain Common Fields, the Property of the Petitioner and others, and certain Open Commons and WTaste Grounds, the Property of the Petitioner, subject to a Right of Common in the Owners and Proprietors of certain Hereditaments and Tenements within the said Manor, which said Woods, Wood Lands, Common Fields, Commons and Waste Grounds, in their present State, are not capable of any considerable Improvement; but if the same were inclosed, and specific Allotments made to the Petitioner, and to the other Persons interested therein, to be held in Severalty, it would be a great Improvement to their Estates: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for dividing, inclosing, and allotting the said Woods, Wood Lands, Common Fields, Commons and Waste Grounds, by such Ways and Means, and subject to such Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition: And that Sir Richard Hill and Mr. Alexander Popham, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Luna, 8* die Martii;

Prayers.

A PETITION of the several Persons whose petition Names are thereunder subscribed, Manufacturers against the and Traders in Tobacco and Snuff, and Inhabitants Tobacco Act. of the Borough of Berwick upon Tweed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners, the Manufacturers and Traders in Tobacco and Snuff, are subjected to the Excise Laws by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, which they feel is not only attended with many Inconveniences and great Hazard to themselves and others of the same Trade, but also with the most dangerous Consequences to the Trade and Commerce of this Kingdom,

and

and therefore beg Leave to state to the House the particular Difficulties imposed upon them by the said Act, and their Apprehensions of its fatal Operation upon their Branch of Trade — That the said Act is extremely complex, in many Respects appears contradictory, and impossible to be strictly, in all Instances, complied with, particularly in making Roll Tobacco, which is the principal Trade in the Neighbourhood of the said Borough, whereby Manufacturers frequently have their Goods spoiled and rendered unfit for Sale, and, notwithstanding their utmost Care and Attention, while they are fairly endeavouring to prosecute their Business without Fraud, are exposed to the Hazard of severe Penalties, in no wise proportioned to the Nature of the Offence — That sundry Regulations are prescribed relative to the Mode of manufacturing Tobacco and Snuff, which are found to be inconsistent with Fact, prejudicial to Trade, and contradictory to Experience, particularly in allowing an' Increase of only Fifteen Pounds upon every One hundred Pounds manufactured into Roll Tobacco, whereas, according to the Manner of making Roll Tobacco as practised by the Petitioners, and every Manufacturer in their Part of the Country, they generally would require an Allowance of from Twenty to Twenty-five Pounds Increase for every One hundred Pounds, an Object of very serious Concern to the Petitioners, being an evident Loss to them of from Eight to Ten per Cent. — That the said Act imposes Rules for the laying down Tobacco Leaf and Tobacco Stalks to be prepared for Snuff, which, according to the Mode of manufacturing Snuff in the Neighbourhood of the said Borough, are altogether impracticable, without the Manufacturer endangering the Loss of his Commodity, or incurring Forfeitures — That the Restrictions of the said Act, which prevent Manufacturers from taking any Roll from the Press until the whole Quantity in Process is completed, is extremely prejudicial to the Trade and Interest of the Petitioners, and all other small Traders, as they are thereby prevented from answering the Orders of their Country Customers and Retail Dealers — That it prevents certain Articles from being removed but in certain Quantities, which is a further Hardship upon the Petitioners and others not in a Port of Importation, as they are thereby necessitated to keep a Stock in Hand beyond what their Credit and Capital may enable them, are prevented from disposing of what they cannot use in their own Line of Manufacturing, and from making speedy Returns, a Thing of the most beneficial Advantages in Trade; and, that the Rules and Regulations to which Manufacturers must conform according to the said Act are found to be attended with many Inconveniences and great Delays, which must necessarily enhance the Price of the Commodity to every fair Dealer, give the Smug-

fler the greater Advantage, and tend to the further encouragement of their illicit Trade; and that a great Number of People are constantly employed in travelling round the Northern Parts of England and Southern Parts of Scotland collecting Eggs, which they bring to the said Town for Sale, and in Return used to take very considerable Quantities of Manufactured Tobacco and Snuff and Grocery Goods, with which they supplied a vast Extent of Country, but those People who traverse the Country without Controul or Molestation, are now supplied with Manufactured Tobacco from abroad, which the Petitioners know and are well assured has of late been smuggled into this Country, and, if the present troublesome and hazardous System of Regulations are' continued, must and will, very considerably increase,* to the great Detriment of the Petitioners, and to the Prejudice of the Trade and Revenue of this Country; and that the operative Mechanic and Manufacturer being left to

the Exertions of their own Genius has been a principal Means of raising the Manufactures and Commerce of this Country to their present Degree of Perfection, but shackling them with restrictive Laws has always been attended with, and followed by, a Decay of Trade, and the Ruin of many Individuals, and if the Petitioners must be governed in Business by a given Set of Rules and Regulations (however well calculated) it will totally check and prevent them from making Exertions, or trying Experiments for the Improvement of their Manufactories, which must shortly yield the Competition to Foreigners, who are engaging Workmen to carry on the same, and industriously forming Connections to supply the Consumption of this Country, and to drive us out of our own Markets:

That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue for the Exigencies of the Nation, and will chearfully contribute on all Occasions to the Public Burthens, but they are so fully convinced of the dangerous Tendency and Consequences of introducing the Severity of the Excise Laws into the Manufactures of this Kingdom, whereby the Constitution and Liberty of the Subject are infringed upon, the Trader subjected to unnecessary Restrictions and Delay, and in many Cases to the Infliction of severe Fines and Forfeitures, whereby the Trade and Commerce of the Country are endangered, and, though they apprehend Taxation is the Object in view, the Revenue must ultimately be materially injured; that they cannot silently acquiesce to the Continuance of a Law fraught with such dangerous Consequences, not only to the Petitioners, but to the Trade and Commerce of this Country in general, and hope that the Wisdom of Parliament may devise Methods more congenial to the Constitution to protect the Revenue without endangering the Trade and Commerce of the Country, or fettering the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Snuff with so many tedious and impracticable Regulations: And therefore praying, That the House will take the Premises into Consideration, and grant them Relief, by repealing an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled,

" An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco " and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu " thereof."

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Mr. Sloane reported from the Committee, to whom Sloane Street the Petition of the Right honourable Charles 'Sloane &c* Lord Cadogan, and the humble Petition of the Right rt!j>nre’ honourable Welbore Ellis, and Christopher

Esquires, Owners of a certain Piece of Land in the Parish of Saint Luke, Chelsea, in the County of Middlesex, containing about Ninety Acres, now in Lease to Henry Holland, Esquire, for a long Term of Years, and of the said Henry Holland, and several Owners and Proprietors of Houses erected upon the said Land, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

James Phtnrridge being examined, said, That a public Street or Way, called Sloane Street, leading from Knighlsbridge to Chelsea, and several other public Ways and Passages, have been set out and opened, and several Houses, and other Buildings, and Improve- . merits, have been erected and made, and are intended to be erected and made, upon the before-mentioned Piece of Land — That the forming the Carriage Way of the said Street, and other public Ways and Passages, already set out and made, and of such Streets,

Ways, and Passages, as shall hereafter be set out and made upon the said Land, and making convenient Footways therein, and paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the said Street, and other public Ways, and removing and preventing all Annoyances and Nuisances therein, will be a considerable Improvement of the Estate and Property of the Persons interested therein, and will-also be a great Convenience and Security to the Inhabitants thereof, and to all Persons passing along the same, and of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for paving, repairing, cleansing, lighting, watching, and watering Sloane Street, and certain others Streets and Places within the Parish of Saint Luke, Chelsea, in the County of Middlesex: And that Mr. Sloane and Mr. Mavmvaring do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Sir Edward Astley reported from the Committee, to Terrington whom the Petition of William Bentinok, Esquire, Lord Embanking of the Manor of Terrington, in Terrington, in the County of Norfolk, and the several Persons whose portecl. To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

John Evans being examined, said, That there are, within the said Parishes, certain Commons or Waste Grounds, of considerable Extent, Part whereof consists of a certain Tract of Land, called The Salt Marsh, extending from the Old Sea Bank to Low Water Mark towards the North, and abutting towards the West upon the Boundary Creek next the Salt Marsh belonging to Henry Hare Townsend, in the Township of Wilberforce, do prepare, and bring in, the same. in the said Parishes, are entitled to Right of Common and Feed upon the said Common Salt Marsh, and other Commons or Waste Grounds — That the said Common Salt Marsh, or the greatest Part thereof, is frequently overflowed, whereby the Feed of

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition thereunder written, being Inhabitants of Stourport, in the County of Worcester, at which Place the Stafford- and Worw shire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation communi- ter Canal cates with the River Severn, was presented to the Bill. House, and read; Setting forth. That the Petitioners are informed, an Application is made to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill for making a Navigable Canal from the Town of Birmingham to the River Severn, at Diglis, near Worcester', and that the Petitioners conceiving Stourport, from its Situation at the

such Land is greatly injured, and the Cattle feeding Junction of the said Staffordshire and Worcestershire

Account res< pecting new Offices at Somerset House presented.

Earl Cornwallis’s Letter to the Court of Directors, presented.

Canal with the said River Severn, to be a Place well calculated for Trade, have been induced to go and great Benefit to all Parties interested, and ot public reside there,- in Hopes of acquiring a competent Utility, if the said Salt Marsh, and the other Com- Livelihood for themselves and Families, and with such View have expended large Sums of Money in erecting Dwelling Houses, Warehouses, and other Buildings, for their Habitations,' and the Exercise of their several Trades and Employments, and in so doing many of the Petitioners have expended the Whole of their Fortunes; and that, if the said intended Canal to Worcester should be carried into Execution, the Petitioners are very apprehensive the same will take away from Stourport a great Pai^ of the Trade and Business now brought to, and carried on at, that Place, which will be injurious to the Petitioners in the highest Degree, as the Loss of such Trade will not only render the Houses and Buildings erected by them of little or no Value, but will be the Means of bringing utter Ruin to many of the Petitioners, who now wholly depend upon that Trade and Business for the Support and Maintenance of themselves and Families; and that the Petitioners conceive the said intended Canal is projected to answer the private Views of Individuals, and that no public Advantage can possibly be derived therefrom, adequate to the Injury it will occasion to the Petitioners, and to the private Properties of other Persons: And therefore praying, That the House will take the Premises into Consideration, and not permit the said Bill to pass into a Law, and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves, their Counsel, or Agents, against the same.

A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Ditto. Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation, was The House being informed that Mr. Morton, from also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth,

And the Witness further said, That it would be of reat Benefit to all Parties interested, and of public Itility, if the said Salt Marsh, and the other Commons and Waste Grounds, were embanked, inclosed, and divided, and specific Shares thereof allotted to the several Persons interested therein.

The House being informed that' Sir William Chambers attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Order,

An Account, specifying what Parts of the General Plan of the new Offices erecting on the Site of Somerset House remained to be completed on the 26th Day of May 1788, as specified in the said Plan presented by him to this House on the 27th Day of May 1788.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Account is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Go<

and better Communication between Birmingham and the River Secern, and for more effectually supplying Worcester and the other Towns near the Severn with Coals, Acts have since passed for making Canals from the Birmingham Canal at Tipton, by Dudley and Stourbridge, to fall into the Petitioners said Canal at ton, which is Fifteen Miles nearer from Birmingham to the River Severn and Worcester, than by the Way of Autherley; and that, in a former Session of the present Parliament, a Bill was brought in for making another Canal to the River Severn, at Diglis, near Worcester, which was rejected, on full Hearing and Consideration, as being inexpedient and unnecessary; and that the chief Ground of Application for the said Bill being, as was then alleged, the imperfect State of the Navigation of the River Severn, between the Petitioners Canal at Stourport and Diglis aforesaid, a Distance of Thirteen Miles, the Petitioners, to remove every Cause of Complaint on that Head, did offer and engage, by their Counsel, at their own Costs and Charges, to improve and make perfect the said River Navigation, without burthening the Public with any Expence, Toll, or Duty whatever, and the Petitioners did, in pursuance of such Engagement, begin to improve the said Navigation, and expended therein a large Sum of Money, but were prevented from effecting their Designs by a Body of Men, actuated, as tho Petitioners believe, by Persons who, from private Views, were adverse to such Improvement, and the Petitioners were thereby compelled to desist from further proceeding; and that the Petitioners have ever since been, and still are, ready and willing to fulfil their Engagements to Parliament, if they can be invested with Powers to do so, and to that End they have lately presented their Petition to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill to authorize them to make the necessary Improvements in the said River, by removing the Shoals, and by cleansing and deepening the Channel thereof, and it is with Surprize and Concern the Petitioners observe, that the Scheme of another Canal to Diglis is again brought forward, and that an Application has been made to the House, for a Bill to make such Canal, which, though not in the same Course, will be similar to the former in its Effects and Consequences to the Petitioners; and that the present Design, as the Petitioners understand, is, like the former, founded on the Circumstance of the River Severn being in dry Seasons an imperfect Navigation, and upon the Idea that the nearest Course between Birmingham and Wyrcester is through the Canal

of the Petitioners by Autherley, whereas in Fact (by the Junction of the Dudley Canal with the Birmingham) a nearer Course will be opened by Fifteen Miles than that which the Petitioners for the Bill have chosen to represent, and which will alsp open a nearer Communication by upwards of Eight Miles, between the Tipton and the several other principal Coal Mines and Worcester, than by the Canal proposed; and that the Petitioners doubt not but they shall be able to prove, that when the Dudley Canal is joined to the Birmingham, and they Improvements are made in the River Severn, as proposed and engaged to be done by the Petitioners, a certain, complete, and perfect Navigation will be found abundantly sufficient for all the Purposes of Trade and Commerce, and that the proposed Canal will not be necessary, or publicly useful, as it will not communicate, or open Commercial Intercourses, with any other Places than those which are already connected by Means of the present Navigations, nor will it open a Communication with any new Coal Mines; and the Petitioners submit that, in all hazardous and expensive Works executed for public Purposes under the Authority of the Legislature, the Undertakers thereof have jhst and reasonable Grounds of Reliance on Parliament for the Enjoyment of their Property acquired by such. Undertak-Vo htS»

ings, and in this Respect the Petitioners beg Leave to claim the Protection of the House; and that although the Introduction of Navigable Canals into this Kingdom has undoubtedly been, and will continue to be, of great public Benefit, yet, if suffered to be made indiscriminately, and, in the Event of some happening to succeed, others should be allowed to be made to supersede them, the Procedure would not only operate as a Discouragement, but would strike at the very Root of those National Irri^rovem^nts, and be productive of much public and private Mischief, and the Petitioners conceive such will be the Effect of the Design in Question, if suffered to be carried into Execution, in regard to the Canal of the Petitioners, and to several others lately completed, without affording the Public any material Benefit or Accommodation: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill for making a Canal from Birmingham to Diglis and that the same may not pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near, to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and the Petitioners are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from West India the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth reputed. Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade between " the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies and Plantatione in North America, and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of America, and between His Majesty's said " Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The West " Indies and the other intituled, "An Act to allow

" the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, from His Majesty's Colonies or Plantations in The West Indies,

" into the Province of Quebec, without Payment of " Duty, under certain Conditions and Restrictions," was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the ’

Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by ' the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Morn-

ing next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Ordered,'That the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, :passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties " in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered, be referred to the Consideration of a Committee of the whole House, and that such of the Petitioners as desire to be heard by Counsel, be permitted to be heard, by their Counsel, in Support of their said Petitions.
