The House being informed that Mr. Longlands, Agent for the Royal Boroughs of Scotland, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders of the 2pd Day of July, in the last Session of Parliament,

Several Accounts respecting the Royal Burghs

in Scotland-, viz.

Edinburgh — ist, Account of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, levied within the City of Edinburgh, for the Years 1779 to 1789 inclusive.

2d, Account of all Salaries, or Sums of Money, which have been paid to the Collector of the Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, for the Space of Ten Years, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue of that Burgh, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of Lands, or other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, with the Price got for the same, and the Rent received for the last Year previous to the said Sale or Feu.

Perth — 1st, Account of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, levied for the Space of Ten Years.

2d, Account of Salaries paid to the Collector of the Cess, &c. for Ten Years, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of all Lands, and other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, with the Price for which the same were sold, and the Rent Vol. 4 5,

received for the last Year the same were let prior to the Alienation.

5th, Account of Lands, &c. purchased from the Union to 22d July 1789.

Aberdeen — ist, Account of the Sums of Money levied for Land Tax, and other Taxes, for the Space of Ten Years.

2d, Account of Salaries, &c. pend to the Collector of the Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, for each of the Ten Years, for their Trouble, Risque, and Expence, in collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of aill Lands, and other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, specifying the Price and Annual Feu Duty for which the same were sold or feued out, and the Rent received for the last Year the same were let prior to the Alienation.

Stirling — 1st, Account of all Sumo levied under the Name of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, for the Space of Ten Years last past.

2d, Account of all Salaries paid to the Collectors of the Cess, &c. for each of the said Years, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of all Lands, and other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, specifying the Price for which the same were sold, and the Rent received for the last Year the same were let prior to the Alienation.

Ayr — 1st, Account of the Gross Revenue of that Burgh, for the Year 1788.

2d, Account of the Alienation of Property which have been sold, feued, or alienated by the Magistrates of that Burgh, since the Union, with the Price for which the same were sold, and the Rent received for the last Year the same were let prior to the Alienation.

Haddington — 1st, Account of all Sums of Money levied under the Name of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, for the Space of Ten Years last past.

2d, Account of all Salaries which have been paid to the Collector of the Cess, &c. for the above Period, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account erf the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of all Lands, and other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, specifying the Price for which the same were sold, and the Rent received for the last Year tire same were let at prior to the Alienation.

Montrose — 1st, Account of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, levied for the Space of Ten Years.

2d, Account of Salaries paid to the Collector for the above Period, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of all Lands which have beeQ sold, feued, or alienated, i>y the Magistrates, since the Union.

Dunbar — 1st, Account of Cess laid on by the Ma-' gistrates of that Burgh, for the Space of Ten Years preceding the Year 1789.

2d, Account of Salaries paid to the Collector, as the Expence of collecting the Cess for the above Period.

3d, Account of Poors Rate paid within Ten Years preceding 1789.

4th, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

5th, Account of all Lands and Houses which have been sold, feued, or alienated, since the Union, specifying the Rent for which the same were let prior to the Sale, and the Price they were sold for.

Lamrk — 1st, Account of the Sums levied for the Space of Ten Years on Account of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax.

2d, Account of Salaries paid to the Collector of the Cess for the above Period, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue of that Burgh, for the Year 1788.

4th, Account of all Lands, or other Heritable Property, which have been sold, feued, or alienated, by the Magistrates, since the Union, with the Prices and Rents thereof, and the Rent received for the last Year the same were let prior to the Sale.

Aberbrothock — 1st, Account of the Sums levied under the Name'of Cess, Stent, or Land Tax, for the Space of Ten Years.

2d, Account of Salaries paid to the Collector of the Cess, &c. and Servants, for the above Period, as the Expence of collecting the same.

3d, Account of the Gross Revenue, for the Year 1788.

the Harbour of Kinghorn, or Petty cur, in the said County, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House, and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

DudleyCanal Mr. Lygon reported from the Committee, to whom Navigation the Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Petition Dudley Canal Navigation was referred; That the Com-

rep0 ' mittee had examined, and found that the Standing

Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with (except that no List of the Owners and Occupiers of Lands is annexed to the Petition, the Application to Parliament being only to raise further Sums of Money, and not for the Purpose of extending or varying the Line of the said Canal); and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove, the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, was read; whereby it appeared that the said Company of Proprietors were authorized and empowered to make and maintain a Navigable Canal within and from certain Lands belonging to Thomas Talbot Foley, Esquire, in the Parish of Dudley, in the County of Worcester, to join and communicate with the Stourbridge Navigation, at a Place called Black Delpli, upon Pensnett Chace, in the Parish of winjord, in the County of Stafford. And,

Mr. Thomas Burne being examined, said, That the said Company of Proprietors have fully completed the said Canal, and the same is now navigable.

Then another Act, passed in the Twenty-fifth Year of His said Majesty’s Reign, was also read; whereby it appeared that the said Company of Proprietors were empowered to extend the said Dudley Canal from the Termination thereof in the Lands of the said Mr. Foley, to join the Birmingham and Birmingham and FazeleyCanal Navigations, at or near in

the County of Stafford, and were enabled to raise the Sum of 22,oooo/. for carrying the said Undertaking into Execution; and, if that Sum should be found insufficient, they were also enabled to raise the further, Sum of 5,000l. And,

Mr. Burne being further examined, said, That the said Company have proceeded to extend the said Dudley Canal, and have made great Progress therein, and expended upwards of 25,000l. which is nearly the Amount of the whole Sum of Money which they were authorized to raise — And he added. That it will be necessary to expend the further Sum of 10,000l. and upwards, in order effectually to complete the Extension of the said Dudley Canal, and that some further Powers are necessary for carrying the Purposes of the said Acts into Execution.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for effectually carrying into Execution Two Acts, of the Sixteenth and Twenty-fifth Years of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from the Stourbridge Navigation to the Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Navigations, in the Counties of Worcester and Stafford: And that Mr. Vox. 45.

Lygon and Mr. Foley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Lygon reported from the Committee, to whom Dudley Road the Petition of the Right honourable William Lord Petlt*0I" Viscount Dudley and Ward, and the humble Petition reporte of several Gentlemen, Merchants, Manufacturers, and others, of the Counties of Worcester, Stafford, and Salop; and also, the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined, ana found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with (oxcept that no Notices were given for the Application in the second-mentioned Petition, it not having been determined to apply for repairing the Piece of Road therein mentioned, and which is only about One Mile and a Half in Length, until it was too late to give the Notices as required by the said Standing Orders); and that the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Toble: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the first-mentioned Petition, Mr. Thomas Burne being examined, said,

That the Road leading from a Place called CaddicJis End, in the Parish of Dudley, in the County of Worcester, to a House called The New in the Parish of Patlingham,in the County of Salop, is in a ruinous Condition, in several Parts narrow, and at some Times almost impassable for Carriages — That if the said Road was properly amended and widened, and the Course or Line thereof altered and changed, in the Parishes of Dudley and Scdgeley, and iu such other Places as shall be judged necessary, so as to make the said Road shorter, and more safe and commodious, and in a more direct Line than at present, the slime would be of great Advantage to Travellers, and other Persons having Occasion to pass upon the said Road, and would also open a regular Communication with several considerable Collieries and Lime Works, and extensive Manufactories.

And to prove the Allegations of the second-mentioned Petition, Mr. Burne being further examined, said, That the Piece of Road therein mentioned, being about One Mile and a Half in Length, is in a ruinous Condition, narrow and incommodious for Travellers; and that if the 6ame was properly amended, widened, and kept in good Repair, it w’ould open a Communication with the Collieries and Lime Works in the Parishes of Dudley and Sedgeley, and also be of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for making, amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, a Road from Eve Hill,near Dudley, to the New Inn, in the Parish of Patlingham, and from the Turnpike Road at or near Shut End, in the Parish of ford, to the Turnpike Road leading from Dudley to IFolverhampton,in the Counties of Worcester, Salop, and Stafford: And that Mr. Lygon and Mr. Foley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Duncombe reported from the Committee, to Keighley whom the Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution Two Acts of Parliament, One made in the Sported. Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the other in the Eighteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing, amending, and widening the Road from Keighley, in the West Riding of the County of York, to Kirkby in Kendal, in the County of Westmorland, so far as relate to such Part of the said Road as lies within

Petition in Favourof the Birmingham and Worcester Canal Bill

Duke of Atholl's Petition referred to a Committee.

Petition to remove tke Toll Gates at Hyde Park Corner and Pimlico.

246 9° Martii. . 1T90.

the said County of York, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Acts were read: And,

Mr. William Carr being examined, said, That by the said Act of the Eighteenth of His present Majesty so much of the said Road as lies within the said County of York was made a separate District — That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution of the said Acts, and have borrowed 6,814/. on the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which still remain due — That many Parts of the Road within the said District were very steep and dangerous, and the Trustees have been under the Necessity of turning and diverting the same, in order to divide the hilly Parts thereof, which has been attended with very great Expence — That'to complete the said Road, and make the same commodious and safe for Travellers, it will be necessary to divert several other Parts thereof, and to borrow a further Sum for that Purpose, which cannot be done, and the Road kept in good Repair, unless the Tolls now payable be increased, and the-Terms of the said Act, so far as relate to the said District, be further continued, and some Alterations and Amendments made therein.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of certain Acts, made for repairing the Road from Keighley, in the West Riding of the County of York, to Kirkby in Kendal, in the County of Westmorland, so tar as relates to such Part of the said Road as lies within thl County of York: And that Mr. Duncombe and Mr. Wilberforce do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several principal Inhabitants, Merchants, and Manufacturers in the Town of Birmingham, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable' Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River

near to the City of Worcester: And praying, That the same may pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

The House was moved, That the Petition of the most Noble John Duke of Atholl, which was presented to the House upon Thursday last, and then ordered to lie upon the Table, might be again read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to General Murray, the Marquis of Graham, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow

Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of several Noblemen, and the bumble Petition of several Gentlemen, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Owners or Occupiers of Houses in Grosvenor Place, near Hyde Park Comer, in the Parish of Saint George, Hanover , in the County of Middlesex, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, that Grosvenor Place is now become Part

of the Metropolis, and is the Town Residence of the Petitioners and other Persons, many of whom are Members of one or other of the Houses of Parliament, and who, on that Account, as well as for the Purpose of transacting their Business in other Parts of the Town, are under the Necessity of passing and re-passing through the Turnpike Gates erected at Hyde Park Corner and Pimlico by the Trustees of the Kensington,

Chelsea, and Fulham Turnpikes, whereby they are not only subject to the Tolls payable there, but are also hindered and delayed by the frequent Stoppages occasioned by the immense Number of Waggons, Carts,

Stage Coaches, and other Carriages, which go the Great Western ROad, and necessarily pass through one or other of the sftid Turnpikes, and by the incessant Disputes which arise betwdbn the Turnpike Men and Travellers; and that the Petitioners have hitherto submitted to the Inconveniences aforesaid rather than trouble the House with an Application for the sole Purpose of removing their particular Grievance; but, observing that a Bill is depending for increasing the Tolls of the said Turnpikes, they judge it a proper Opportunity for representing their Case: And therefore praying the House to take the Premises into Consideration, and, by a Clause to be added to the Bill now depending before them, to enact, that the Toll Gates, now standing at Hyde Park Comer and Pimlico aforesaid, shall be taken away, and removed to a proper Distance Westward of their present respective Situations, or to give the Petitioners such other Relief as to the House shall seem meet

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Bill for more effectually repairing the Road from Hyde Park Corner to Counters Bridge, and certain other Roads, within the Parishes of Saint George Hanover Saint Margaret Westminster, Kensington, , and

Fulham, in the County of Middlesex, and for lighting, watching, and watering the same* and for several other Purposes therein mentioned, is committed.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, that they have Power to make Provision in the said Bill, pursuant to the Prayer of the said Petition.

Committee The House, according to Order, resolved itself into Trafo Act*11 a Committee of the whole House, to consider of an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for preventing certain Instruments from being required from Ships belonging to the United States of America, " and to give to His Majesty, for a limited Time, " certain Powers for the better carrying on Trade and " Commerce between the Subjects of His Majesty’s " Dominions and the Inhabitants of the said United

States;" and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to extend the Powers of an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of His present Majesty, " for giving his Majesty certain Powers for the better " carrying on Trade and Commerce between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the United States of America, to the Trade " and Commerce of this Kingdom with the British " Colonies and Plantations in America, with respect " to certain Articles therein mentioned; " and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to continue " the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade " between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and " the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the " United States of America, so far as the same relate " to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States."

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That he was directed by the Committee to make a Motion, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Report; Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the

Way* and Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re-

Meaos. ferred to consider further of Ways aind Means for raising

the Supply granted to His Majesty, the' Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Pay and Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That the Charge of the Pay and Clothing of the 8 ®* Militia, in that Part of Great Britain called England,

for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be defrayed out of the Monies arising by the Land Tax, granted for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill be brought in upon the said Resolution: And that Mr. Gilbert, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A PETITION of the Mayor, Aldermen, Capital Burgesses, and principal Inhabitants of Bridge-water, in the County of Somerset, whose Names are thereunto subscribed: And also,

A Petition of the Manufacturers and other Inhabitants of Redditch, Beoley, AUchurch, Feckenham, Cofton, Tardebig, Bradley, and the Places adjacent, whose Names are thereunto subscribed;

Were severally presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester: And praying, That the same may pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Holford and Mr. Graves:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have passed a Bill, intituled, An Act to dissolve the Marriage of Francis Thomas Rybot with Alicia Fowlei', his now Wife, and to enable him to marry again, and for other Purposes therein mentioned; to which the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the Report which was made from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Right honourable George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and the humble Petition of Reginald Pole Carew, of East Antony, in the County of Cornwall, Esquire, was referred, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Yorke took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Yorke reported from the Committep, That he was directed by the Committee to make a Motion, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Resoboed, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Bill for enlarging the Terms, and altering the Marlborough Powers, of Two Acts, made in the Sixteenth Year of Roads Bill the Reign of his late Majesty, and in the Ninth Year committed* of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Kemett, to Sheppard's Shord, and from The Hare and Hounds in Beckhampton, to the Top of Cher rill Hill,

and from the Town of Avebury to the Cross Way at Beckhampton, and from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wrought on, and from the North Side of Swindon to The Carpenters Arms in Blunsden, in the County of Wilts, and for diverting, turning, and altering Part of the said Roads; and for repairing and widening the Road on the West Side of The Three Barrows, from the Direction Post there on the new Road leading from Beckhampton to Devizes, to the Distance of One Mile from the said Direction Post Westward, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Goddard,

Sir James Tylney Long, See.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Report on Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re-ferred to consider of an Act, made in the Twenty- c *

third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for preventing- certain Instruments " from being required from Ships belonging to the " United States of America, and to give to His Majesty,

" for a limited Time, certain Powers for the better " carrying on Trade and Commerce between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the said United States; " and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the llcign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to extend " the Powers of an Act, made in the Twenty-third " Year of His present Majesty, for giving His Majesty

certain Powers for the better carrying on Trade " and Commerce between the Subjects of His Majesty’s '

Dominions and the Inhabitants of the United States " of America, to the Trade and Commerce of this " Kingdom with the British Colonies and Plantations in America, with respect to certain Articles " therein mentioned ;" and also, of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to continue the Laws " now in Force for regulating the Trade between " the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions, and the " Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United " States of America, so far as the same relate to " the Trade and Commerce carried on between this " Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States;" That he was directed by the Committee to move the House, that Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States.

And Mr. Gilbert moved the House accordingly.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States: And that Mr. Gilbert, the Marquis of Graham, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer,

Mr. Attorney General, and Mr. Solicitor General, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Cricklade

Writ.

Committee to consider of a Duty on Cocoa Nuts imported into America*

Mr. Charles Robinson reported from the Committee,

to whom the Petition of the Mayor, Jurats, and Commonalty, and other Inhabitants, of the Town and Borough of Deal, in the County of Kent, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Join Sampson being examined, said, That the Highways, Streets, and Lanes, within the said Town, are not properly repaired, paved, and cleansed, and, on Account of various Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances the same are rendered very unsafe, dangerous, and incommodious; and that it would.tend much to the Benefit, Convenience and Safety of the Inhabitants, and all Persons resorting to the said Town, if the said Highways, Streets, and Lanes were effectually repaired, paved and cleansed.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for repairing, paving, and cleansing the Highways, Streets, and Lanes within the Town and Borough of Deal, in the County of Kent, and for removing and 'preventing Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances therein: And that Mr. Charles

Robinson, and Mr. Gipps do prepare and bring in, the same.

An ingrossed Bill to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating the " Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies " and Plantations in North America, and in the West " India Islands, and the Countries belonging to the " United States of America, and between His Majesty’s " said Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The West " Indies-" and the other intituled, " And Act to allow " the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, from His Majesty’s Colonies or Plantations in The JVIndies, " into the Province of Quebec, without Payment of " Duty, under certain Conditions and Restrictions was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the one intituled, An Act for regulating " the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s " Colonies and Plantations in North America, and in the West India Islands, and the Countries belonging " to the United States of America, and between His Majesty’s said Subjects and the Foreign Islands in " The West Indies;" and the other intituled, "An Act " to allow the Importation of Rum, or other Spirits, " from His Majesty’s Colonies or Plantations in The " West Indies, into the Province of Quebec, without " Payment of Duty, under certain Conditions and " Restrictions."

Ordered, That the Marquis of Graham do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Ordered, That Mr. Speaker do issue his Warrant to the Clerk erf the Crown, to make out a new Writ for the electing of a Burgess to serve in this present Parliament for the Borough of Cricklade, in the County of Wilts, in the room of Robert Nicholas, Esquire, who, since his Election for the said Borough, hath accepted the Office of One of the Commissioners for managing the Revenues of Excise.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of imposing a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Colonies or Plantations in America, be now read,

Voi.. 45.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they bad come to a Resolution; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Committee to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled,

" An Act for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the " several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines " and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other " Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits,

" and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in " Lieu thereof; and for better regulating tire Exportation of British-made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England', and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the " Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the " Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits " for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing " the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof;

" and for the better Regulation of the making and " vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing for a " limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum " and Spirits Imported from The West Indiesand also, of an Act made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for amending and continuing, for a " limited Time, an Act, made in the last Session of " Parliament, intituled, An Act for discontinuing, for " a limited Time, the several Duties payable in " Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon " Wjprts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof; and for " better regulating the Exportation of British-ma.de " Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England-, and to continue for a limited " Time, an Act made in the Twenty-sixth Year of " the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue,

for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties " upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and granting and securing the due Payment of " other Duties in Lieu thereof; and for the better " Regulation of the making and vending British " Spirits; and for discontinuing, for a limited Time,

" certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits " imported from The West Inches; and to revive and " continue the said last mentioned Act," be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for continuing the Term of so- much of an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for rendering the Payment " of Creditors more equal and expeditious in that " Part of Great Britain called Scotland; and for " making perpetual so much of an Act, made in the " Twelfth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, as " relates to Bills and Promissory Notes," as relates to the rendering the Payment of Creditors more equal and expeditious in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland, was committed, the Amendment which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendment in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendment was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendment, be ingrossed.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for altering the Time appointed for holding the Summer Session in the Court of Session in Scotland, and for altering Whitsuntide and Lammas Terms in the Court of Exchequer in Scotland, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly.

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to -indemnify such Persons as have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, ana Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according to Law, or, having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and- for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants, and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of

their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for that Purpose: And that Mr. Rose, Mr.

Steele, and Mr. Gilbert, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Motion being made, That this House will, upon Allowance to Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee Mr- Speaker of the whole House, to consider of an Allowance to be consi* made to the Speaker of the House of Commons for the Time being, more adequate to the dignity of the said Office, and to the Expence necessarily attending the same;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer by His Majesty's Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty recommends to the Consideration of the House, the making an Allowance to the Speaker of the House of Commons for the Time being, more adequate to the Dignity of the said Office.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of an Allowance to be made to the Speaker of the House of Commons for the Time being, more adequate to the Dignity of the said Office, and to the Expence necessarily attending the same.

distinguishing each Year.

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the Proceeding* Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for the further Regulation of the Trial of Persons Cature Act. accused of certain Offences committed in the East Indies, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, might be read.

And the same was read accordingly.

And the several Lists which had been before delivered in at the Table, in pursuance of the Directions of the said Act, by Members of this House, being laid upon the Table;

The said Lists were, by the Order of Mr. Speaker, taken out of the Covers, and put together into a box, by the Clerk at the Table.

Ordered, That the said List be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the same; and report to the House upon Friday next,' the Names of every Member whose Name shall appear in Twenty or more of the said Lists:

And they are referred to Mr. Steele, Sir William Young, Mr. Call, Mr. Smith, Mr. Burges, Mr. Gilbert,

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and principal Petition re-inhabitants of the City of Worcester, and County, of the same City, was presented to the House, and read; anTliu^ng-Setting forth, That Application has been made to the ham Road8 House, by the Commissioners of the Turnpike Road Bill, leading from the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to Bromsgrove, in the County of Worcester, to enlarge the Term and Powers in the present Acts granted, with respect to such Road; and that the said Road is in many Parts exceedingly ruinous and bad, and requires to be lowered, and rendered more easy for heavy Carriages, of which great Numbers are continually passing and re-passing from the said Town of Birmingham to Worcester, and other Parts of the West of England, and the petitioners conceive, from 07 their

Ways and Means deferred.

Supply deferred.

their Knowledge of the Situation of the present Road (particularly that Part which lies within the Parish of Northfield, m Worcestershire) and from Representations which have been made to them, that it will be absolutely necessary, in order to make the said Road complete,

that the same should be formed upon a lower Level, and the present Tract, in some Parts thereof, diverted and changed: And therefore praying the House to grant such Relief ii> the Premises as to the House shall seejn meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

The other Orders-of the Day being read;

Resohxd, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

The said Account is as followeth;

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses in Parliament assembled.

An ACCOUNT of the Allowances paid at the Exchequer to the Speaker of the House of Commons foV the Time being, from the 10th Day of October 1776 to the 10th Day of October 1788; distinguishing each Year.

Memorandum:

The usual Allowance to the Speaker of the House of Commons, upon the Meeting of every new Parliament, amounts to the Sum of One thousand Pounds for his Equipage, upon which Sum the Duties of Six Pence in the Pound and One Shilling in the Pound are taken, as well as upon the above Sum of Twenty-one thousand Four hundred and Fifty-five Pounds.

Exchequer, the 11th Day of March 1790.

William Rose Htjworth.

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, ^to be perused by the Members of the House.

The House being informed that Mr. , from the

Directors of the East India Company, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

N° 1. An Account of the Annual Revenues of the East India Company in the Provinces of Bahar,

and Orissa, and from Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Mint or Coinage Duties, Post Office Collections, Benares Revenue, Oude Subsidy, Land Revenues, Customs, and the Receipts from the Sales of Salt and Opium, for Three Years, according to the latest Advices; together with the latest Estimate of the same: And also,

N° 2. An Account of the Annual Charges defrayed by the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal, Bahar, and Orissa, and in Benares and Oude; distinguishing the same under the respective Heads of Civil, Military, and Marine, the Charges of Buildings and Fortifications, of collecting the Revenues and Customs,- and the Advances and Charges on Account Vo l. 45.

of Salt and Opium, for Three Years, according to the latest Advices; together with the latest Estimate of the same: And also,

N° 3. A Comparison of the Estimated and Actual Amount of the Revenues of the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal, Bahar, and Orissa, and from Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Mint or Coinage Duties, Post Office Collections, Benares Revenue, Oude Subsidy, Land Revenues, Customs, and the Receipts from the Sales of Salt and Opium, for the Year 1788-9, and of the Charges defrayed by the said Company in the said Provinces, and m Benares and Oude; distinguishing the same under the respective Heads of Civil, Military, and Marine, the Charges of Buildings and Fortifications, of collecting the Revenues and Customs, and the Advances and Charges on Account of Salt and Opium for the said Year: And also,

N° 4. An Account of the Annual Revenues of the East India Company at the Presidency of Fort Saint George, and the Settlements subordinate thereto, and in the Carnatic and Northern Circars, under the Heads of Mint or Coinage Duties, Sea or Land Customs,

A Paper, intituled, " Return to the Order of " the Honourable House of Commons, of 19th February " 1790, requiring a Comparison of the Estimated ana " Actual Amount of the Revenues of the East India Company at the Presidency of Bombay, and the Settlements subordinate thereto, under the Heads of Land " Revenues, Customs, and Farms or Licences, for the " Year 1788-9, and of the Charges defrayed for the " same Year by the said Company in the said Presidency and Settlements; distinguishing tile same " respectively under the several Heads of Civil, Marine, Military, Buildings and Fortifications, and " collecting the Revenues and Customs:" And also,

Bombay, as far as the same can be distinguished from the Civil or other Charges of those Presidencies respectively, for Three Years, according to the latest Advices; together with the latest Estimate of the same: And also,

N® to (c). An Account of the Expences of the Island of Saint Helena, and the Factory at Canton, for Three Years, according to the latest Advices: And also,

Resources and Disbursements of the Bengal Government, from the 30th Day of April 1789 to the 1st Day of May 1790: And also,

N° 12. A Paper, intituled, " Return to the Order " of the Honourable House of Commons, of 19th " February 1790, requiring an Abstract of the Estimate " of the probable Resources and Disbursements of the " Madras Government, from 30th April 1789 to the " 1st Day of May 1790, according to the latest Advices:" And also,

N° 13. An Abstract of the Estimate of the probable Resources and Disbursements of the Bombay Government, from the 30th Day of April 1789 to the 1st Day of May 1790: And also,

N° 14. A Paper, intituled, " Return to the Order of " the Honourable House of Commons, of 19th " 1790, requiring a General Abstract of the Estimates " of the probable Resources and Disbursements of the " Presidencies of Fort William, Fort Saint George, and " Bombay, between the 30th Day of 1789 and the " 1 st Day of May 1790, according to the latest Advices:* And also,

N° 15. An Account of the Amount received at the several Presidencies of Fort Fort Saint George,

and Bombay, for Sales of Import Goods and Stores, and for Certificates on the Court of Directors, within the last Three Years, according to the latest Advices; together with the latest Estimate of the same: And also,

N° 16. Amount of the Bond and other Debts owing by the East India Company, at their several Presidencies in the East Indies, according to the latest Advices; the Rates of Interest which such Debts respectively carry, and the Annual Amount of such Interest: And also,

N° 17. A Paper, intituled, " Remarks of the Accountant General upon a Defect in the System by " which the Journal and Ledger of the Comptroller for " the Manufacture of Salt have been kept."

Together with a List of the said Accounts and Papers.

And then he withdrew.

And the said List was read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Accounts and Papers be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The said Accounts and Papers are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Sir William Cunynghame presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Linlithgow: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir Thomas Dundas presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Stirling; and for repairing the Road from Loanhead to SaintNiniain the said County of Stirling: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir Thomas Dundas presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Stirling and Dumbarton: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Wftttrbeach Sir Charles Gould reported from the Committee, to Drainage whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names pCT?td°nrC* are thereunto subscribed, being Owners and Occupiers of the several and respective ancient Commonable Messages in Waterb in the County of Cambridge, on Behalf of themselves and others, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Drainage, had not been complied with, because the Certainty that it was necessary to apply to Parliament was not known in Time, that this Certainty arose from the Opinion of an eminent Counsel on the Construction of a Clause in the present Act respecting the Regulation for stocking the said Level, which Opinion was not procured until the 28th of October last, on which Day it bears Date, but that Notice of the Intention to apply to Parliament was given by affixing the same on the Church Door of Waterbe on Sunday the 31st of January, on Sunday the 7th, and on Sunday the 14th of February last; and that all the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Application (except the Owner of One Common Right out of 119 and an Half, and he did not oppose it); and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as follow- -eth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for the effectual Draining and Preservation of Waterbeach Level, in the County of Cambridge, and Ho establish an Agreement, made between the Lord of the Manor of Waterbeach cum Denny and the Commoners within the said Manor, was read: And,

Mr. Edward Allen being examined, said, That there is a Necessity for altering the Act, in Consequence of the Opinion given by an eminent Counsel respecting the Regulation for stocking the said Level; Then,

Mr. John Hcmmington, Junior, being examined, said, That the Number of Cattle allowed by the Act to be stocked upon the said Commonable Lands is greater than the said Lands will bear — That it has been customary for a few Years last past for a Majority of the Commoners to agree to lessen the Number of Common Rights allowed by the said Act, which the Commoners have, till lately, acquiesced in; but some of them have since refused to conform thereto, and now insist upon their whole Stockage — That the Common cannot be beneficially enjoyed without the Stint being lessened, which cannot be done without the Aid of Parliament.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring tn a Bill to alter and amend an Act, made in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for the effectual Draining " and Preservation of Waterbeach Level, in the County " of Cambridge, and to establish an Agreement made " between the Lord of the Manor of Waterbeach cum " Denny and the Commoners within the said Manor:" And that Sir Charles Gould, Mr. York, General Adeane, and Mr. Gould, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition for thereunto Subscribed, was presented to the House, and additional read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners observe, by Pr°v'«on *° the Votes, that Application hath been made to the gjS aTin£ House for Leave to bring in a Bill for paving, cleans- V ing, lighting, and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages, for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts within the Borough of Truro, in the County of Cornwall; and that the Streets called Kenwyn Street, Calenick Street, and Saint Clement Street, adjoining to the said Borough, are not properly paved, cleansed, and lighted, and are subject to Nuisances, Encroachments, and Annoyances, and are not of sufficient Width: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for paving, cleansing, and lighting the said Streets.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Colonel Boscawcn, Mr. Rolle,

See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records. *

Mr. Yorke, according to Order, reported from the Report on Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re- Tamer Ferry ferred to consider of the Report which was made Report* from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Right honourable George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and the humble Petition of Reginald Pole Carew, of East Antony, in the County of Cornwall, Esquire, was referred; That he was directed by the Committee to move the House, that Leave be given to bring in a Bill for authorizing and enabling the Right bonourar ble George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and Reginald Pole Carew, Esquire, to establish and maintain a common Ferry over and across the River Tamer, between a certain Place North of Plymouth Dock, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel, in the County of Devon, and Tor-point, in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of

And Mr. Yorke moved the House accordingly.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for authorizing and enabling the Right honourable George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and Reginald Pole Carew, Esquire, to establish and maintain a common Ferry over and across the River Tamer, between a certain Place North of Plymouth Dock, in the Parish

11 °Martii. A. 1790.

of Stoke Damarel, in the County of and Tor-

point, in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall: And that Mr. Yorke, Mr. Rolle, Mr. Bastard, and Mr. Rash-leigh, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Peterborough Mr. Benyon reported from the Committee, to whom Paving Peti- the Petition of the several Persons who have there-tions reported, unto subscribed their Names, on Behalf of themselves and others, Owners and Inhabitants of Houses in the Parish of Saint John Baptist, in the City of Peterborough’, and also, the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Owners and Inhabitants of Houses in the Parish of Saint John Baptist, in the City of Peteborough, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the First-mentioned Petition, Mr. William Bowker, being examined, said, That the several Streets, Lanes, Passages, Causeways, and other Roads and public Places, within the said City, are very ill paved, and not sufficiently cleansed, lighted, and watched, and are much incommoded by Nuisances, Annoyances, and Encroachments; and that it would tend to the Safety, Accommodation, and Convenience of the Inhabitants of the said City, and of Persons resorting thereto, if the said Streets, and other public Places, were properly paved, repaired, cleansed, lighted, watched, and regulated.

To prove the Allegations of the Second-mentioned Petition, Mr. Bowker being further examined, said, That the Street within the said City, called Cowgate, is at present under the Management of the Trustees for repairing the Turnpike Road leading from ford to Peterborough, and it is necessary that the said Street should be paved, and also that the other Roads within the Township of Peterborough, and adjoining to the said City, should be included in the proposed Bill. And he added, That, in Aid of the Rates to be made upon the Inhabitants, it may be found necessary to lay a small Toll upon Horses, Cattle, and Carriages, passing to and* from the said City; and, in order to secure the Collection of such Toll, it will be proper to erect Turnpikes near the Avenues, and at a small Distance from the Limits of the said City.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the Streets, Lanes, Passages, and public Places, within the City and Township of Peterborough, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, and Obstructions therein, and for repairing the Highways within the said Township: And that Mr. Benyon and Mr. Lionel Damer do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Thomas Stanley reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Company, of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; but that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 20th of July 1789, had not been complied with, the Persons concerned not knowing or having heard of the same, they having been so recently made, and, immediately upon being informed thereof, Notice was given Three Times in The Liverpool Advertiser, in the Month of November last, and Notice was also given at the Christmas Quarter Sessions for the County of Lancaster, being the County in which the Alteration in the Line of the Canal is pro-

s

Leeds and

Liverpool

Navigation

Petition

reported.

posed to be made; and that all the Owners and Occupiers of the Lands, through which it is proposed to make the Cut, have consented to the Application, except the Trustees of a Minor, and the Occupiers of the Lands belonging to him; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as fol-

loweth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from Leeds Bridge, in the County of York, to The North Lady's Walk, in Li-

verpool, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, and from thence to the River Mersey, was read: And,

Mr. Joseph Priestly being examined, said; That he is Accountant to the Company; that the Company have, by virtue of the said Act, raised among themselves the Sum of 300,000l. and upwards, which

hath been expended in making and completing such Part of the said Cut or Canal which lies between the said Leeds Bridge and a certain other Bridge called Holm Bridge, in the said County of York’, and in making and completing such Part of the said Cut or Canal as lies between the said Port of Liverpool and the Township of Parbold, in the said County of Lancaster, and in the purchasing and improving the Navigable River Douglas, alias in the said County of Lancaster, which is now consolidated and incorporated with the said Canal Navigation by virtue of an Act, passed in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty; and in other Purposes directed by the said Acts: Then,

Mr. Robert Whitworth, Surveyor to the Company, being examined, said, That about Fifty-six Miles of the said intended Canal remain uncut, whereby the Public are deprived of the Advantages which would be obtained by finishing the said Canal — That he has surveyed the Country lying intermediate and between the completed Parts thereof; and that he apprehends great Difficulties might be avoided, or at least very much diminished, and much Expence saved, by varying a Part of the said original intended Line of the said Cut or Canal, and by making the same Navigable for Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, from or near a Place called Reediford, in the Township of Great Marsden, in the said County of Lancaster, through the Parishes and Places in the Petition mentioned, to and through a Place called Nab Wood, in the Parish of Great Harwood, in the said County of Lancaster, the said new intended Line going over a complete Tract of Coal, and by such Deviation the Necessity of making a great and very expensive Aqueduct Bridge, in the Neighbourhood of Whalley, will be avoided: — And the Witness added. That in order to complete and finish the said intermediate Parts of the said Cut or Canal, it will be necessary to borrow a considerable Sum of Money upon the Credit of the said incorporated Navigations.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool to vary the Line of the said Canal Navigation, and to raise a further Sum of Money for the Purpose of completing the said Canal Navigation: And that Mr. Thomas Stanley and Mr. Blackburn do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The Lords have agreed to

Royston and Wandesford Roads Bill.

Goudhurst Roads Bill.

Tavernspite Roads Bill.

The Lords have passed

Money's Estate Bill

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Holford and Mr. Graces:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of certain Acts of Parliament, for repairing the Roads from Royston, in the County of Hertford, to Wandesford Bridge, in the County of Huntingdon, and from the Town of Huntingdon to the Causeway at or near the West End of the Town of Somersham, in the County of Huntingdon, so far as relates to the Middle and South Divisions and separate District of the said Roads; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, of the Eighth Year of His present Majesty, for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading to and through the Town of Goudhurst, in the County of Kent', without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Term of an Act of the Eleventh Year of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, several Roads, leading from Tavernspite to the Towns of Pembroke and Tenby, and to Hubberston Haking, in the County of j

without any Amendment: And also.

The Lords have passed a Bill, intituled, An Act for vesting Part of the Freehold Estates, devised by the Will of James Money, Esquire, deceased, in Trustees, to be sold, and for laying out the Money arising thereby in the Purchase of other Hereditaments, to be settled to the same Uses ps the Estates to be sold Vol. 45.

now stand limited to; to which the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Mr. Duncombe reported from the Committee, to Leeds Water, whom the Petition of several principal Inhabitants of and Lighting the Town of Leeds, in the County of York, was rer Petltio" ferred; That the Committee had examined the Matter r®P°rted* of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and h$ read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr*

Lucas Nicholson being examined, said. That there is not at present a necessary and regular Supply of wholesome Water within the said Town, for the Use of the Inhabitants, but that a sufficient and constant Supply of good and wholesome Water may be obtained by a Regulation and Improvement of the Water Works that at present supply the Town.

Then an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of his late Majesty, intituled, "An Act for enlightening " the Streets and Lanes, and regulating the Pavements,

" in the Town of Leeds, in the County of York," was read: And,

Mr. Nicholson being further examined, said, That there are several Streets, and other Places, within and near to the said Town, to which the said Act doth not extend, and which are not properly lighted, and are subject to divers Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions; and that the Streets and Places under the said Act are subject to various other Nuisances, Encroachments, and Obstructions, which the Provisions of the said Act are not sufficient for removing and preventing — And he added, That the supplying the said Town and Neighbourhood with . a sufficient Quantity of good and wholesome Water, and the Regulation and Improvement of the Streets and Places before mentioned, will be of great Benefit and Convenience to the Inhabitants, and all Persons resorting to the said Town, and the Neighbourhood thereof.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for better supplying the Town and Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with Water; and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein: And that Mr. Duncombe and Mr. Wilberforce do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Glasgow Pe-Snuff in the City of Glasgow, was presented to the tition against House, and read; Setting forth, That towards the Tobacco Close of the last Session of Parliament, a Bill was in- c ’ traduced into the House, for the Purpose of putting Tobacco under an Excise, and the Petitioners at that Time most cordially joined the London Manafacturers in their Endeavours to prevent it from passing into a Law, and this they did from a Conviction that the End proposed could not be attained while the Duties on that Article continued so high; and that, in Consequence of the Exertions of the Manufacturers, and from the Force of the Evidence adduced at the Bar. of the House, considerable Alterations were made in many of the most exceptionable 'Clauses, which Alterations (though greatly short of the Manufacturers Wishes) tended to alleviate the Hardships which the first Draft of the Bill meant to impose upon them, and in that amended State it passed into a Law, and it then became the Duty of every good Citizen to submit to an Experiment which the Legislature had determined to adopt; and that for a Period of Twtf

3 U Months

258

11° Martii.

A. 1790.

Months 'subsequent to ltd Operation, the Petitioners were inclined to believe, that an additional Revenue would result to the Nation, and that there might be a Possibility of the fair Trader being protected under it, they, therefore, with some Degree of Cheerfulness, submitted to the great Trouble, Expence, Risque of Forfeitures, &c. to which they were subjected, in Hopes that those flattering Prospects which gave a Spring to their Industry would in the End be realized; hut it is with much Concern the Petitioners find that those Expectations have been fallacious, and that the early Ray of Hope which dawned, upon their Exertions is obscured, and they now see nothing before them but the Ruin of their Manufacture, and the Triumph of the Smuggler, whose Operations were only suspended until a thorough Knowledge of the Law had enabled him to take the most effectual Steps to evade it; and that the Petitioners, from a Sense of that Duty which they owe to themselves, to their Brethren in Trade, and to their Fellow Citizens, beg Leave, with all due Submission, but with that Freedom which they consider their Inheritance, to represent to the House the ruinous Situation of the Business in their Part of the Kingdom, and to point out the Impracticability of levying a Tax of such Magnitude, even at the Expence of the Liberty of the Subject, upon any Commodity, the intrinsic Value whereof bears such a Disproportion thereto: That it is their firm Opinion, an Excise Law is totally inapplicable to an Article which undergoes such a Variety of Alterations in the Process of Manufacture, and that no Law, consistent with the Spirit of the British Constitution, can ever be effectual in raising a Revenue on Tobacco, while the Duties continue as they are, and that, if the House do not speedily adopt Measures to defeat the Operations of the Smuggler, the Manufacture in that Part of the Kingdom will soon be nearly . annihilated: And therefore requesting the House to take the Premises into Consideration, and' the Petitioners hope that they will not only find it expedient for the Relief of the Subject to repeal the Excise Law laid upon Tobacco, but for the Benefit of the Revenue to reduce the Duties so considerably, as to render the Prosecution of illicit Trade impracticable, and thereby supersede the Necessity of an Extension . of an Excise to that Article in future.

Linlithgow, A Petition of the Manufacturers of Tobacco and and Falkirk Snuff in the Towns of Linlithgow and Falkirk, was Petition ajs0 presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, Tobacco Act. That by an Act of the last Session of Parliament, the Manufacturers of Tobacco and Snuff are subjected to the Laws of Excise, and, by the said Act, the Mysteries of their Trade, which they consider as private Property, are exposed to the Officers and to the Smugglers — That it imposes Rules and Regulations on the Manufacture which, in many Cases, cannot be conformed to, and subjects the Manufacturer to Penalties and Forfeitures which he can neither foresee nor prevent, and puts it in the Power of the Officer to ruin any Manufacturer, however honest his Transactions may be — That it subjects the Manufacturer to a new Mode of Manufacture, to the great additional Expence and Inconvenience of the Manufacturer, as well as the Risque of losing his Goods — That it occasions Delays and Interruptions quite inconsistent with the Nature of Trade, and prevents . the Manufacturer from disposing of any Part of his Goods, however much wanted, until the whole Parcel is declared finished*, which, in some Cases, cannot be done in less than Five or Six Weeks — That it puts an entire Stop to every Improvement in the Manufacture, by restricting the Manufacturer to certain Returns, although his Goods will often yield Six or Eight per Cent, more, and consequently compels him either to injure himself, and spoil his Goods, or smuggle an Article for which he has paid a high

Duty; and that the Petitioners are of Opinion, that no Excise Law will ever apply to the Manufacture of Tobacco and Snuff, as they undergo such a Variety of Alterations in the Process of Manufacture, and, they are further of Opinion, that no Law will ever be’ effectual in securing the Revenue on Tobacco, without a considerable Reduction of Duty on that Article;

And therefore praying, That the Tobacco Excise Act may be repealed, and the Duties reduced, so that the Revenue may be benefited, and the fair Trader protected and encouraged.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, ." An Act for repealing the Duties u on Tobacco and Snuflj and for granting new " Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

A Petition of the Freeholders, Commissioners of Petition Supply, Trustees on the Turnpike Roads, and He-ritors of the County of Stirling, thereto subscribing, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth,

That a Bill for disjoining the Counties of Stirling and Linlithgow, relative to the Turnpike Roads, and for maintaining and repairing the Roads in the said County of Stirling, and for imposing additional Tolls, and Loll upon Coal, to be levied within the said County, has been presented to the House; and that the Petitioners can demonstrate that the present Turnpike Funds are adequate to keep the Roads in Repair, and pay any Debts affecting the same, and they apprehend no additional Toll is necessary; and that the said' Bill contains several -other Clauses injurious to the Petitioners, and to the Public at large: And therefore praying to be heard by Counsel against such Clauses of the said Bill as are prejudicial to the Interests of the Petitioners and the Public at large.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads, in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of and for repairing the Road from Loanhead, to Saint Ninians, in the said County of Stirling, be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Stourbridge Canal Navigation, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That in pursuance of an Act, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners have made and completed a Navigable Canal from the Town of Stourbridge, with Two Collateral Cuts from the Coal Mines in the Neighbourhood thereof, to join the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal at Stourton, in the County of Stafford, and have therein expended upwards of 50,000 /. and the said Canal of the Petitioners also unites with the Dudley Canal, and by Means of the Extension of the said Dudley Cana], which is now executing, and nearly completed, a Communication will be opened between the said Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal, and the _B-mingham Canal at Tipton, and a complete Canal Navigation will be thereby made between the Town of Birmingham And the River Secern, Fifteen Mile9 nearer than the present Canal by; and that

the great Object of the Petitioners, in making the said Canal, was to supply the City of Worcester, mid g other

Petition from the Proprietors of the Stourbridge Navigation against the Birmingham and Worces-terCanalBilL

other Towns and Places on the River Severn, with Coals, from the very extensive and valuable Mines lying upon, or near to, the Line of such Canal, and which Object has been. effected with great Benefit to the Public; and that the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that a Petition hath been presented to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill to make a Navigable Canal, from or near the Town of Birmingham, to the River Secern, at Diglis, near to the City of Worcester, which, if carried into Effect, will be attended with very injurious Consequences to the Petitioners said Canal, without affording, as they apprehend, a Prospect of any real public Utility: And therefore praying to be heard, by Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate' with the River Secern, near to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, tnade in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for pulling down the Church of Saint James, at Clerkenwell, in the County of Middlesex, and for building a new Church, and making a new Church Yard or Cemetery, in the said Parish, was read: And,

Mr. James Carr being examined, said, That great Progress hath been made in the Execution of the Powers

?*ven by the said Act; but it is found that the good urposes thereof cannot be effectually answered, unless the said Act is amended, and the Powers thereof enlarged.

And Mr. Gilbert moved the House accordingly. Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of the making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from The West Indies: And that Mr. Gilbert, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The Marquis of Graham presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to continue the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of imposing a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Colonies or Plantations in America, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Two Pence per Pound Weight be charged upon all Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Colonies or Plantations in America.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill be brought in upon the said Resolution: And that Mr. Gilbert, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingroesed.

The First Resolution of the Committee, being read a Second Time, was postponed.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House ta resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State o'f the African Slave Trade;
