The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Francis took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Francis reported from the Committee, That an Agent had appeared before the said Committee on Behalf of the said Petitions, and had called a Witness, who had been, in Part, examined; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Petitions.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 12* die Martii;

Anno 36* Georgii I1I, U Regis, 1790.

Prayers.

MR. Speaker acquainted the House, That the Clerk of this House had received from Captain Williams, in pursuance of the Order of the House of Yesterday, Copies of the Letters or Orders received by the said Captain Williams from Lieutenant Colonel Hannay, or his Secretary, relative to the Execution of Rajah Mustapha Khan; together with the Original Letters from which the said Copies were taken; and that the same were now qpon the Table.

Ordered, That the said Copies and Letters do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Letters be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The said Copies and Letter^ are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Mr. Medley reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several of the Land Owners and Parishioners of the Parish of East in the County of Sussex, ou Behalf of themselves and others, was

referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition; and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and be read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it ip at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Gibbs CrauJ'urd, Esquire, being examined, said, That in the Year 1785 the Steeple of the Church of the said

03

Parish suddenly gave Way, and falling upon the Body of the said Church, entirely demolished the same, so that no Divine Worship has since been performed therein — That the Inhabitants have exerted their utmost Endeavours to re-build the said Church, but find that they cannot raise Money sufficient for that Purpose without the Aid of Parliament.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for re-building the Parish Church of East Grimtead, in the County of Sussex: And that Mr. Medley and Mr. Ford do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Colonel Boscatven reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Charles Casper Clutterbuck being examined, said, That the Streets, called Kenwyn Street, Calenick Street, and Saint Clement Street, adjoining to the Borough of Truro, in the County of Cornwall, are not properly paved, cleansed, and lighted, and are subject to Nuisances, Encroachments, and Annoyances, and are not of sufficient Width.

That if Powers were given to pave, cleanse, and light the said Streets, and to remove and prevent all Nuisances, Encroachments, and Annoyances, for the future, and also to widen the same where necessary, it would be of great Benefit to the Inhabitants thereof, and to all Persons resorting thereto.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who are appointed to prepare, and bring in, a Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages, for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts, within the Borough of Truro, and Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall, That they do make Provision in the said Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, and widening the Streets called Kenwyn Street, Calenkk Street, and Saint Clement Street, and for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances therein.

Mr. Grigby reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Communication between Slcrwmarket and Ipswich, in the County of Suffolk, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were, with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

DudleyCanal Mr. Lygon presented to the House, according to Order, Navigation a gift for effectually carrying into Execution Two Acts,

Bill present- Q£ gjxteenth an(j Tw enty-fifth Years of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from the Stourbridge N avigation to the Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Navigations, in the Counties of Worcester and Stafford: And the same was received and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Petition A Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the

from the Dudley Canal Navigation was presented to the House,

Proprietors o r *

of the Dudley an<^ read; Setting forth. That by an Act made in the Navigation Sixteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, against the the Petitioners were authorized to make a Navigable and^Vorces- Caual tVo,n certain Lands belonging to Thomas Talbot ter Canal Foley, Esquire, in the Parish of Dudley, to communicate B.ll. with the Stourbridge Navigation, which said Canal hath

been long since executed and rendered completely Navigable, and the Petitioners have expended upwards of 12,oooo /. in the said Undertaking; and that by virtue of an Act, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners were empowered to extend the said Dudley Canal from the Termination thereof, in the Lands of the said Thomas Talbot Foley, to join the Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Navigations, at or near Tipton, in the County of Stafford, in order to open a Communication with the large Tracts of Coal and other Mines lying upon or near to the Line of the said Extension, and to afford a shorter and cheaper Conveyance for Goods and Merchandize between Birmingham and Bristol, and the intermediate Places; and that the Petitioners have expended upwards of 25,000l. in carrying on the Extension of the said Dudley Canal, and the said Undertaking is in great Forwardness, and will, in a short Time, be completed; by- Means whereof a Communication will be opened between the Town of Birmingham and the River Severn, Fifteen Miles nearer than the present Navigation by Autherley; and that the principal Inducement to the Petitioners to undertake the Extension of the said Dudley Canal w as in order to open a nearer and better Communication by Water between Birmingham and Worcester, and other Places on the River Severn, for the Conveyance of Merchandize and other Articles of Commerce; and that the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that Application has been made to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill to make a Canal from or near the Town of Birmingham to the River Severn at or near Worcester, which Scheme, if carried into Effect, will be attended with great Injury to the Petitioners, and to many other Persons who have embarked their Properties in hazardous- Works under the Authority of Parliament, without affording a Prospect of Public Utility, as, when the Canal so forming by the Petitioners is united with the Birmingham Canal in pursuance of the last above stated Act, and the other Ipiprovetnents now depending are effected, a complete Communication by Water, sufficient for every Purpose of Trade and Commerce, will be opened between Birmingham and Worcester, and also between the Towns-and Places of any Importance which such proposed Canal would, if executed, communicate with or extend to, and therefore such proposed Canal cannot be in Vol. 45.

any Degree necessary for the Occasions of the Public:

And therefore praying to be heard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be th$n heard, by their Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the -said Petition.

Ordered, That the Report from the Committee, to Day ap-whom the Petition of several Noblemen, and the humble pointed for Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Traders, and ^e|)vI!tn^oin others, Inhabitants of the Counties of Herts, Essex, Committee1 Cambridge, Isle of Ely, Huntingdon, and Suffolk, on on Bishop’s Behalf ot themselves and others; and also the Petition Stortford anJ of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Traders, and other ^'^atfon l'e~ Inhabitants of the Counties of Herts, Essex, Cambridge, tjt®ons>

Mr. Thomas Pelham Reported from the Committee, j^ew Chap« to whom the Bill for continuing the Term, and enlarg- pell Road ing the Powers, of an Act made in the Tenth Year rePort* of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and eJ" keeping in Repair, the Road from New Chappell, in the County of Surrey, over Copthorn, in the County of Sussex, through Lindfield, to the Town of Ditchling, up to the Top of Ditchling Bost Hills, in the said County of Sussex, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to he true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

The Lord Eardley reported from the Committee, to cov«ntry whom the Bill for the better paving, cleansing, lighting Paving Bill and watching the City of Coventry, and the Suburbs reported, thereof, and removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein, and for widening and otherwise improving the Streets, and regulating the public Wells and Pumps, within the said City and Suburbs, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, a>nd made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were^ with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

Coventry Silk Weavers Petition reported.

*(Halldraeth, &c- Embank* ing and Drainage Bill committed.

264 12° MartH. A. 1T90

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Wilniot reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Journeymen Silk Weavers residing in the City of Coventry, and in several Towns and Places in the County of Warwick, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. Ilellsey Hewitt (a Journeyman Silk Weaver) being examined, said, That the Wages of the Journeymen Silk Weavers at Coventry have, within the last Twelve Years, been greatly reduced — That the Price of Labour for a Piece of Fourteen Pence Figure, containing Thirty-six Yards, which used to be Six Shillings, is now reduced to Five Shillings, and something lower; and that other Articles are reduced in nearly the same Proportion — That there are other Abatements frequently made by the Masters, amounting sometimes to Half the Journeymens Wages; and there have been Instances of the whole Wages for a Piece of Work being stopped, under the Pretence that the Work had not been properly done; and that such Abatements are general among the Masters, though they vary in the Degree: Then,

Mr. Charles Colton (another Journeyman SilkWeaver) being examined, said, That the Master Silk Weavers can now keep what Number of Apprentices they think proper, and that many Masters, at this Time, keep Six or Seven, and some keep more, which is a great Hardship upon the Journeymen — And the Witness added, That he has also been a Sufferer from the Abatements made by the Masters, as mentioned by the last Witness: Then,

Mr. Joseph Edwards, Mr. Robert Berry, and Mr. Cotton, being examined, said, That the Petitioners are desirous of being put under the same Regulations as are provided by an Act of the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to empower1 the Magistrates therein mentioned to settle and regulate the " Wages of Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture, within their respective Jurisdictions," for the Journeymen Silk Weavers within the Cities of London and Westminster, and Parts adjacent; and that if the Provisions of the said Act were to be extended to the City of Coventry and County of Warwick, the Witnesses apprehend it would be of great Benefit to all Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in that Neighbourhood: And,

Mr. Edwards and Mr. Isaac Simpson being examined, said, That the Regulations provided by the above-mentioned Act have been attended with great Benefit to the Journeymen, and an Advantage to the Trade, in the Districts to which the same extend.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to extend the Provisions of an Act, of the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty, relating to Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture within the Cities of London and Westminster, and other Places therein mentioned, to Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in the City and County of the City of Coventry, and County of Warwick: And that Mr. Wilmot and the Lord Eardley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Bill for more effectually embanking the Marsh called Malldraeth and Corsdda in the County of Anglesey, and draining and preserving the same, and the inclosed Low Lands contiguous thereto, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr.

Sir Charles Gould, See.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

An ingrossed Bill for making and repairing the Road from Nexcmiln Bridge, by Foodies Mill, Inverkeithing,

Aberdour, Kirkcaldy, Gallatown, and Cameron to Craill, and other Roads in the County of Fife, and for improving the Harbour of Kinghorn, or in

the said County, was read a Third Time.

The Amendment following was proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 49. 1. 11. After " upon" to insert, " or within " Five Feet of."

And the said Amendment was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for making and repairing the Road from Newmiln Bridge by Foodies Mill, Inverkeithing, Aberdour, Kirkcaldy, Gallatown, and Cameron Bridge, to and

other Roads in the County of Fife.

Ordered, That Mr. Wemyss do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of the several Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the several Gentlemen, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Owners and Occupiers of Estates in the Counties of Hertford, Essex, Cambridge, and Suffolk, and also the humble Petition of divers other Persons residing within the said County of Cambridge, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed Application is making to the House for a Bill, for extending the Navigation from London to Bishop's Stortford, in the County of Hertford, by proceeding on with that Navigation to a Place called Palmers Water, in the said County of Hertford, and from thence to the Parish of Elsenham, and through the North Parts of the County of Essex, to the Town of Saffron Walden, and from the last mentioned Place through the Counties of Cambridge and to join

the Brandon River in the last mentioned County, and for making a Cut from such extended Line, in the Parishes of Great and Little Abingdon, and Baberham, to communicate with the Town of Cambridge, and that, if any Bill should be passed for extending such Navigation, and making the said Navigable Cuts, it will be productive of great and lasting Injury to the Property of the Owners and Occupiers of Estates through which such Navigation and Cuts are to be made, without affording the Public any Advantage whatever, and be very injurious to the Trade now carried on within the said County of Cambridge: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others. Conservators of the River Cham, alias Grant, in the County of Cambridge, appointed for carrying into Execution a certain Act of Parliament passed in the First Year of the Reign of her Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, "An Act for making the River " Cham, alias Grant, in the County of Cambridge, " more Navigable from Clay-Hithc Ferry, to the " Queens -Mill, in the University and Town of " Cambridge," was also presented to the House, and

read; Taking Notice of the Application mentioned in the the last preceding Petition; and Setting forth, That if such Bill should pass into a Law, the Petitioners have Reason to apprehend the same will* be highly injurious to, if not totally destructive of, the Navigation now carried on upon the said River Cham, alias Grant, by depriving the same of the Water

necessary

A Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the severed Parishes of L Clyde, Llanfyrnach, Llarboidy, Egl a Chyrie,

glwydwen, Cilymdnllwyd, Ilandisilio, Monachlogddu,

Llangolman, Llandilo, Manclo Egre-

mont, Lawhaden, Blethinston, New Moat, Henry's Moat,

Llysy-frun, Walton East, Clarebeslon, Wiston, and

Rudbaxton, being Twenty-four Parishes in the Counties of Pembroke and Carmarthen, w as presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed a Bill is depending in the House for making a Turnpike Road from the Town of Haverfordwest, through the Village of Prendegast, and a Place called Stephens Ford, towards the Town of Cardigan, so far as a House called Morris the Bailiffs (of Comelfach) in the Parish of Castlebithe, being

an Extent of Eight Miles and a Half, and that a Toll of Six Pence will be charged on all Carts carrying Lime for Manure and other Uses, together with Dung, at a Gate to be set up at Prendegast, or some Place adjacent; and the Petitioners beg Leave to represent the very great Hardships which the Said Bill, if it should pass into a Law, will bring on them and their Posterity, by reason that the Road, leading from the Town of Haverfordwest to their respective Dwellings and Farms, branches out of the Cardigan Road at a Place called Rosswell, near Stephen's Ford, at the Distance of One Mile and a Quarter only from the Town of Haverfordwest, which they conceive to be a very trifling Consideration for a Toll of Six Pence for each Cart employed by them in Carriage of Manure and Fuel, although the Money to be collected from them at the intended Gate will amount to Three Times more than that of the Road leading from Rosswell, near Stephens Ford, towards Cardigan, for it' is notorious that the Number of Carts is in the Proportion of Three to One greater than on the Cardigan Road, which is the Thoroughfare of Six Parishes only, but that of the Petitioners the constant Thoroughfare of Twenty-four Parishes: And therefore praying, That the House will amend so much of the said Bill as may tend to subject the Petitioners to any Toll whatever, for passing from the Town of Haverfordwest, to a Place called Rosswell,. near Stephen's Ford, where the Cardigan Road branches off to the Left at Rosswell, from that frequented by the Petitioners, or add a Clause to compel the Trustees of the projected Turnpike towards Cardigan to make a Road of equal Length, leading from the Entrance of Rosswell Eastern Lane, by the Rath, Cross

Inn, and over Knockhill, to and New

Moat, towards the Village of Manclochog, in the several Parishes of Rudbaxton, Wiston, Walton East, Clarebeston, Llysyfrdn, and New Moat, and every Cart travelling over the same to be liable to a Toll of Four Vol. 45.

Pence and no more, or to grant to the Petitioners 1

such other Relief as to the House shall appear fitting:

Arid the Petitioners beg Leave to represent farther, That they are willing to prove by Evidence, and explain by Counsel, the several Allegations which they have herein made.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Report be received from the Committee, to whom the Bill for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Roads leading from the Town of Haverfordwest, to a Place called Morris the Bailiffs, and to Great Treffgarne Bridge, and to the City of Saint David's, and from the said City to the Harbour of Caerfai, in the Parish of Saint David's, in the County of Pembroke; is committed.

Committee on Militia Pay Bill.

Account, &c. of African Company presented.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, u|W)n the Bill for defraying the Charge of the Pay and Cloathing of the Militia in that Part of Great Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of Mareh One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Th'e House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

The House being informed that Mr. Meller, from the Commissioner of the Customs, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

An Account of the Number of Coast Bonds taken at the several Ports of England, during the Year 1788: And also.

An Account of the Number of Certificates of Foreign Goods that have been imported into, and entered Outwards from, the several Ports of England, during the Year 1788: And also,

An Account of the Number of Debentures that have been paid at the several Ports of England, during the Year 1788: And also,

An Account of the Number of Isle of Man Bonds taken at the several Ports of England, during the Year 1788.

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

Ordered, That the said Accounts dp lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, according to Order, Distillery Bill a Bill to continue. Two Acts, made in the Twenty- PresciHed-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in lieu thereof, and fer better regulating the Exportation of British-m&de Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upoq Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from The West Indies: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Balance of Quick Stock at the Presidencies of Fort William, Fort and Bombay,

.for the last Three Years, exhibiting a State of the East India Company’s Affairs in respect of their Debts and Assets, as they stood at Bengal, Madras, and Bombay, on the 30th of April 1787, the 30th of April 1788, and the 30th of April 1789, distinguishing each Year, according to the latest Advices.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account (according to the latest Advices) of all Bills drawn, accepted, or advised, from India, for the last Five Years, distinguishing, as far as can be collected from any Accounts received, the different Dates thereof, and Rates of Exchange, together with the Purposes, or supposed Purposes, for which drawn, and the Periods at which they respectively become due.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Value of India Goods remaining unsold in the East India Company’s Warehouses on the 1st of March 1784, and on the 1st of March 1785, distinguishing each Year.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Value of India Goods remaining unsold in the East India Company’3 Warehouses on the 1st of March 1790.

Seasons, from 1782 to 1789, inclusive, distinguishing each Year, according to the latest Advices.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty;

The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this ’ Session of Parliament, praying that the Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new 'Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir Wat kin Lewes took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir Watkin Lewes reported from the Committee, That

they had finished the Examination of the Witness who had been before examined, and had examined another Witness; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tuesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Petitions.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

A Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, Linlithgow of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth Road* hill and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Ma- com, B,tted* jesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Stirling, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir William Cunynghame, Sir Thomas Dundas, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. Tempest reported from the Committee, to whom Durham the Petition of the Mayor, Aldermen, Clergy, Citizens, £avi?g and Inhabitants of the City of Durham and From-welgate, and the Suburbs thereof, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Robert Shuttleworth, Esquire, being examined, said, That the Streets and other Places within the said City and the Suburbs thereof, are ill paved, lighted, and watched, and subject to various Encroachments, Obstructions,

Nuisances, and Annoyances — That several of the Houses and Buildings are inconveniently situated, and dangerous for the passing of Carriages and Persons on Foot, on which Account Accidents frequently happen; and that it will tend to the Advantage and Safety of the Inhabitants, and all Persons resorting to, and travelling through, -t he said City, to have Such Houses and Buildings taken down and removed, so as to make the said Streets and other Places, more convenient and safe for Carriages and Foot Passengers, and to have all Encroachments, Obstructions,

Nuisances, and Annoyances, within the said City and Suburbs, removed and prevented, and the Streets and other Places properly paved, lighted, watched, and regulated.

And he added, That it will be of great Advantage if the Markets within the said City were better regulated, and the Market Place improved.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places within the City of Durham and Borough of and the Suburbs thereof, for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs:

And that Mr. Tempest and Mr. Lambton do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Sir Thomas Dundas reported from the Committee, to Forth and whom the Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Clyde Navi-Forth and Clyde Navigation, and the Company of Proprietors of the Monkland Navigation, was referred, That reported, the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerks Table: Where the same wus read; and is as followeth;

viz.

rp

J U

30 Geo. III.

15° Marin.

269

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, several Acts, passed in the Eighth, Eleventh, Thirteenth, Twenty-fourth, and Twenty-seventh Years of the ' Reign of His present Majesty, whereby several Powers were given and granted the said Company of Pro* prietors of the Forth and Clyde Navigation to make a Navigable Cut or Canal from the Frith or River of Forth, at or near the River Carron, in the County of Stirling, to the Frith or River of Clyde, at or near a Place called Dalmuir Burnfoot in the County of barton, and also a Collateral Cut from tire same to the City of Glasgow, and for making a Navigable. Cut or Canal of Communication from the Port or Harbour of Borrowstounness, to join the said Canal at or near the Place where it will fall into the Frith of Forth, were read: And,

Mr. Robert Whitworth being examined, said, That the main Line of the Forth and Clyde Navigation is now nearly finished, and a Collateral Cut is made from the same to a Place called Hamilton Hill, within about a Mile of the City of Glasgow.

Then an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, whereby several Powers were given and granted to the said Company of Proprietors of the Monkland Navigation, to make and maintain a

Navigable Cut or Canal, and Waggon Way, from the Collieries in the Parishes of Old and New Monkland, to the City of Glasgow, was read: And,

Mr. Patrick Colquhoun being examined, said, That considerable Progress has been made in the said last mentioned Canal; and that the said Two Companies of Proprietors are desirous to have a Junction formed between the Two Canals — That it would be highly beneficial to the Public at large, if the Company of Proprietors of the Forth and Clyde Navigation were empowered to carry on their Collateral Cut from Hamilton Hill to the West End of the Monkland Canal, at Or near the Townhead of the City of Glasgow, and to purchase Lands for making a Harbour and Bason at or near a Place called Hundred Acre Hill, and were also empowered to build Houses and Warehouses for the Accommodation of Merchants and others resorting thereto, and to open Roads, Lanes, and Passages leading from the same to the City of Glasgow.

And the Witness further said, That in order to supply both Navigations with Water, and for completing the same, it is become necessary that the Monkland Canal should be extended from the Sheep Ford to the River Calder, and that the before-mentioned Acts re-

lative to both Companies should be further explained, amended, and rendered more effectual, and more ample and other Powers given to the respective Companies, to enable them to finish the Works in which they are engaged.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for forming a junction between the and Clyde Navigation and the Monkland Navigation, and for altering, enlarging, and explaining, several former Acts passed for making and maintaining the said Navigations: And that Sir Thomas , Sir Archibald

Edmonstone, and Lord Frederick Campbell, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Hungerford reported from the Committee, to Samwell’s whom the Bill to enable Thomas Sarrrwell Watson - Name Bill well, Esquire (lately called Thomas Samwell Watson) rePorteil-and his Heirs Male, to take the Surname, and use the Arms, of Samwell, pursuant to the Will of Sir Thomas Samwell, Baronet, deceased, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had directed him to report the Bill to the House, without any. ‘A Petition of Sir Thomas Godch, Baronet, was pre- Sir Thomas sented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioner observes, by the Votes, that a Petition against the hath been presented for Leave to bring in a Bill for Birmingham making a Navigable Canal from or near the Town of "'d Worces-

3 Z Bit'mingham anal

Stowmarket and Ipswich Navigation Bill passed.

Colnies and CarUord Poor Bill reported.

Rybot’s Divorce Bill committed.

270 15° Martii. A. 1790.

Birmingham to the Rivet Severn, at Digits, heat the City of Worcester; and that the Petitioner is the Owner of several valuable Water Mills, situate in and near to the Town of Birmingham, which lie below the Line of the said intended Canal, and is also the Owner of a large Landed Property in ‘and near the said Town; and that the present Supply of Water to the Petitioner’s Mills is inadequate for the necessary Use thereof, and, in case the said intended Canal should take Place, the Petitioner apprehends that the same must unavoidably intercept and take away great Part of the Resources which afford the natural Supply of Water to the said Mills, and, in consequence -thereof, the same will be greatly injured and lessened in Value; and that many very valuable and extensive Buildings have been erected upon the Petitioner's Estate in and near to the Town of Birmingham, the Value and Improvement whereof depends upon the Prosperity of the Manufactories-of the said Town, which cannot be carried on without a constant and Cheap Supply of Coals, and the Petitioner apprehends that, by Means of the intended Canal, the Coals will be sent from the Mines which lie nearest to the Town of Birmingham into distant Markets, and thereby the Supply of Coals for the Use of the said Manufactories will be rendered precarious, and the Price thereof consequently advanced, a very great Injury will result therefrom to the Petitioner’s Property: And therefore praying to be heard, by his Cdunsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioner be then heard, by his Counsel, against the said Bill, upon his Petition, if lie thinks fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Sir John Wodehouse reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for the better Relief and Employment of the Poor within the Hundreds of Colnds and Carlford, in the County of Suffolk, was eomraitted; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Report was read.

And several of the Amendments, made by the Committee to the said Bill, being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed, to by the House.

Mr. Pierrepont reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Trustees appointed by, or in pursuance of, an Act, passed in the Fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repairing, widening, and " keeping in Repair, the High Roads leading from " Alfreton, in the County of Derby, through Carter " Lane, to a certain Place, in the Town of Mansfield, " called Stodewell, and from the Bridle Gate at the

" Division of the Liberties of Blackwell and " nail, through the Town of Sutton in to

" the Mansfield and Newark Turnpike at or near " Python Hill, in the Forest of Shencood, in the " County of Nottingham," was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. William Oates, Surveyor of the Roads, being examined, said, That great Progress hath been made in the Repair of the said Roads, and a considerable Sum of Money borrowed on the Credit of the Tolls by the said Act granted, which cannot be repaid, and the said Roads completely amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be continued, and the Powers thereof amended, enlarged, and rendered more effectual.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, made in the Fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the High Roads leading from Alfreton, in the County of Derby, through Carter Lane, to a certain Place, in the Town of Mansfield, called Stochoell, and from the Bridle Gate at the Division of the Liberties of Blackicell and Hucknall, through the Town of Sutton in Ashfield, to the Mansfield and Newark Turnpike, at

or near Python Hill, in the Forest of Sherwood, in the County of Nottingham: And that Mr. Pierrepont and Lord Edward Bentinck, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Thomas Stanley presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool to vary the Line of the said Canal Navigation, and to raise a further Sum of Money for the Purpose of completing the said Canal Navigation: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Corporation and principal Inhabitants of Barnstaple, in the County of Devon, whose Names are thereunto subscribed: And also,

A Petition of the several principal Inhabitants, Merchants, and others, in the City of Bristol, and its Environs, whose Names are thereunto subscribed: and also,

A Petition of several of the Inhabitants of the City of Bath,

Were severally presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn near to the City of W;

And praying, that the same may pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions wefe severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Said Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Gilbert presented to the House, according to Edington In-Order, a Bill for draining, dividing, and inclosing certain Moors, Commons, or Waste Lands, called p Edington, otherwise Burile Moor, East Heath, West Heath, and Chyde Batch, within the Hamlet of Edington, and Parish of Moorlinch, in the County of Somerset: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

a Second Time. Nat Bill.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. committed* Gilbert, Mr. Ord, &c. And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

An ingrossed Bill for altering the Time appointed ScotcliTerm* for holding the Summer Session in the Court of Bill passed. Session in Scotland, and for altering Whitsuntide and Lammas Terms in the Court of Exchequer in Scotland, was read the 'Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for altering the Time appointed for holding the Summer Session in the Court of Session in Scotland, and for altering Whitsuntide and Lammas Terms in the Court of Exchequer in Scotland.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Dundas do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of the Merchants, and others, concerned Petition from in the Shipping Business in the City of Exeter, and Exeter, reports adjacent, was presented to the House, and read; »Pect'»gthe Setting forth, That the Petitioners always see, with of°Shi^U°n great Pleasure, any Attempts to stop the pernicious Progress of Smuggling, and the Acts passed with that View in the Twenty-fourth and Twenty-seventh of His present Majesty, in their Execution prove very detrimental to the Shipping Trade, by rendering Ships of considerable Value liable to Seizure; for Forfeitures of a trifling Amount; and that as this depends upon the Conduct of the Common Seamen, which it is impossible for the Ship Owner to controul, they are apprehensive that Branch of Business will be very much diminished, to the great Loss of Individuals, and the more material Probability of diminishing that useful Body of Men the Common Sailors: And therefore praying the House to take the Matter into their serious Consideration, and grant such Relief as they shall think its Importance deserves.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition of several Inhabitants of the Town and Petition ibr Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, was additional presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That ^^niton Application hath been made to the House, for Leave Paving, &c. to bring in a Bill for making the Passage through the Bill, said Town and Borough more safe and convenient and for paving, lighting, and otherwise improving the said Town and Borough, and for other Purposes; and that several public Roads lying within, or leading to, the said Town and Borough, are Part of certain

Turnpike

Bromham Roads Petition reported.

272

Turnpike Trusts, and might be more conveniently widened, paved, and otherwise improved, if the same were put under the sole Care and Management of the Commissioners proposed to be appointed for carrying the Purposes of the said Bill into Execution, and it would tend to the Safety and Protection of the Inhabitants of the said Town and Borough if a well regulated Nightly Watch was established therein: And

therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for discharging the respective Trustees from the Care and Management of such Parts of the said public Roads as are within or near the said Town ind Borough, and for putting the same under the sole Care and Management of the Commissioners to be appointed as aforesaid, and for establishing a proper Nightly Watch within the said Town and Borough, and for raising Money for effecting the several Purposes aforesaid, by such Ways and Means, and in suqh Manner, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Rolle, Mr. Secretary at War, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speakers Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. St. John reported from the Committee, to whom

the Petition of the several Gentlemen, Freeholders, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being severally Owners of Estates, and Inhabitants, within the several Counties of Bedford and Bucks, near the Roads thereinafter described, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April -1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had not been complied with; but that Notices were given in The Northampton Mercury Four Times, in the Months of December, January, and February last, of a Meeting to be held at Olney, on the 15 th of February, to consider of the proposed Application to Parliament for the Repair of the Road in the Petition mentioned; and that all the principal Inhabitants and Proprietors of Lands in the several Parishes through which the said Road leads have been acquainted with the Application, and are consenting thereto; and that a further Notice was given in the said Paper, on the 6th Instant, for another Meeting to be held at Olney, at both which Meetings it was unanimously agreed, that it was necessary to apply to Parliament to put the said Roads into proper Repair; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and bad directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. John Higgins being examined, said, That the Road leading from Bromham Bridge, in the Parish of Brom-ham, through Steoerton to Turoey, in the County of Bedford, and from Turvey aforesaid through the Parishes of Brayfield, Lavendon, Warrington, and Olney, in the County of Bucks to the Turnpike Road leading from Wellingborough to Olney aforesaid, and also the Road from the said Turnpike Road at or near the South End of the Town of Olney aforesaid, up Dagg Lane, to Newport Pagnell, in the said County of Bucks, are out of Repair, narrow, and incommodious, and cannot be effectually repaired, amended, and widened by the ordinary Course of Law.

A. 1790.

Ordered, That the said Report do lie upon the Table.

Ordered, That, in Consideration of the particular Circumstances mentioned in the said Report, Leave be granted, that Notices may be given, at the ensuing Easter Quarter Sessions of the Peace, to be held for the respective Counties of Bedford and Bucks, and by Advertisements in the public Newspapers published or circulated within the said Counties, before the 20th Day of April next, of the Application to Parliament for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Roads leading from Bromham Bridge, in the Parish of Bromham, in the County of Bedford, through the Parishes of Stev Turvey, Lavendon, Warrington, and Olney, to the Turnpike Road leading from Wellingborough to Olney, and frbm the said Turnpike Road at the South End of the Town of Olney, through the Parishes of Weston Underwood, Ravenstone, and Stoke 'to the Turnpike

Road leading from Northampton to Neuport Pagnell, in the County of Bucks, in such and the like Manner as are required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, of Applications intended to be made relative to Turnpike Bills.

A Bill for securing a Fund belonging to the Taun- Taunton So. ton Annuitant Society for the Benefit of Widows, ciety Bill was read a Secohd Time. committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Alexander Popham, Mr. Rolle, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Fifth Report from CommiV-tee appointed to examine Witnesses against the Abolition of the Slave Trade.

Sir William Dolben reported from the Committee, appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination of such Witnesses as shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade, and who were impowered to report die Minutes of such Exa* mination, from Time to Time, to the House; That the Committee had made a further Progress in the Matter to them referred; and had directed him to report the Minutes of the said Examination to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afi-terwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to Whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Navy Office, 15th March 1790.

An ACCOUNT of what Money has beert issued by the Treasurer of His Majesty’s Navy, in pursuance of an Act, passed in the Twenty-lirst Year of His Majesty's Reign, intituled, "An Act for continuing the " Encouragement and Reward of Persons making certain Discoveries for finding the Longitude at Sea, or " making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating " thereto:" Prepared pursuant to an Order from the Honourable House of Commons, dated the 9th March 1790.

TO WHOM, AND UPON WHAT ACCOUNT.

To Mr. William Bayly, who was employed on Board His Majesty’s Sloop The Discovery, during her last Voyage with His Majesty’s Ship Resolution round the Globe, in making Astronomical and Nautical Observations, for his Salary, at the Rate of 400l. per Annum, from the 2d March 1776, when he received his Instructions from the Commissioners of the Longitude, previous to the sailing of The Discovery, to the 24th October 1780, when she was paid off, and the Instruments with which he was intrusted returned - - - - £1,859 J4 6

To Dr. Charles Hutton, for his Labour and Trouble in computing Tables of Products, Powers, and Roots of Natural Numbers, lately published, and for furnishing the necessary Precepts, and correcting the Press -

To the Reverend Dr. Maskelyne, Astronomer Royal (by way of Imprest) to enable him to pay Persons to compute and compare Nautical Almanacks, or Astronomical Ephemeridy, for the Years 1791 and 1792 ——

To Mr. William Bayly, as a Recompence for his Trouble in reducing, compiling, and printing the Astronomical Observations made during Captain Cook’s last Voyage, and intended to be published with the Historical Account thereof -To Mr. William Richardson, Printer, being the Amount of his Bill for printing Astronomical Observations made during Captain Cook’s last Voyage, as also Nautical Almanacks, Tables, &c. -To Messrs. Wright, Gill and C*, Stationers, being the Amount of their Bill for Paper supplied by them for the Use of the Commissioners of the Longitude ——

To Mr. Robert Blair, as a Reward for having discovered a Method of adjusting Hadley’s Quadrant for the Back Observation, with the same Ease and Accuracy, and on the same Principle, as the Method now practised in the Fore Observation, with little or no additional Apparatus -

N° 8. Copy of a Letter from Earl Cornwallis to the Court of Directors, dated 7th March 1789: And also.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for defraying the Charge of the Pay and Clothing of the Militia in that Part of Great Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the 25th Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

tions, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according to Law, or, having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for that Purpose.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Birmingham, Wolverhampton, Walsall, Dudley, Stourbridge, and the Neighbourhood thereof: And also,

A Petition, of the Corporation and Inhabitants of the City of Wells: And also,

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Inhabitants of the City and Vicinity of Worcester;

Were severally presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester: And praying, That the same may pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

Dorchester , Mr. Benyonreported from the Committee, to whom reportedlU *he Bill to enlarge the Term and Powers of so much of an Act, made in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, as relates to the amending, widening, altering, clearing, and keeping in Repair, several Roads leading from the Borough of Dorchester, in the County of Dorset, was committed; that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found, the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made an Amendment thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendment, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendment was Twice read; and* upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendment, be ingrossed.

iiUingworth Mr. Gregg reported from the Committee, to whom IocImuk Bill the gin for dividing and inclosing a certain Common, reporte Moor, or Tract of Waste Ground, called Killingxoorth Moor, in the Parish of Long Benton, in the County of Northumberland, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of 1774, relative to Bills

of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietors of Lands to the Amount of 104/. a Year, who refused to give their Consent to the Bill; and that the Whole of the Lands entitled to Right of Common upon the Lands intended to be inclosed, are of the Yearly Value of 3,550/., or thereabouts; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Collingham, in the County of Nottingham, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been Vo L.

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and thfcn a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

General Murray reported from the Committee, to Duke of whom the Petition of the most Noble Duke of Atholl was referred; that the Committee had examined report«!. the Matter of the Said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, your Committee find, That by a private Act of Parliament produced to your Committee, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of King James the First, intituled,

" An Act for the assuringe and establishinge of the " Isle of Manne," after reciting, or taking Notice, that William, then Earl of Derby, and his Ancestors, had, ever since the Seventh Year of the Reign of King Henry the Fourth, held and enjoyed the Isle of Mann as their proper Inheritance, it was enacted, that the said William Earl of Derby, and the Lady Elizabeth his Wife, during their Lives, and the longer liver of them; and after their Deaths James Lord Stanley, Son add Heir Apparent of the said Earl, and the Heirs Male of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and after his Death without such Issue, Robert Stanley,

Second Son of the said Earl, and the Heirs Male of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and after his Death without such Issue, the Heirs Male of the Body of the said William Earl of Derby, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, the right Heirs of the said James Lord Stanley should and might for ever thereafter have, hold, and quietly enjoy the said Isle, against the said King James, his Heirs and Successors, and against the several Persons in the said Act particularly named, being the Widow and the Three Daughters and Co-heiresses of Ferdinando late Earl of Derby, deceased, their Husbands and Heirs; and that neither the said James Lord Stanley, nor any the Heirs Male of his Body, lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, nor the said Robert Stanley, nor any the Heirs Male of his Body; lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, nor any the Heirs Male of the Body of the said William Earl of Derby, lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, should have any Power, Authority, or Liberty to give, grant, alien, bargain, sell, convey, assure, or do away the said Isle, or any Part thereof, from his or their Issue or Issues, or other Persons by the said Act appointed to enjoy the same; but that the same should remain and continue to the said James Lord Stanley, and the Heirs Male of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the said Robert Stanley, and the Heirs Male of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the Heirs Male of the Body of the said William Earl of Derby, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the right Heirs of the said James Lord,

as before by the said Act is appointed; and that all Gifts, Grants, Alienations, Bargains, Sales, Conveyances, Assurances, and Acts, done or to be doiie or ' 4 B made.

Duke of Atholl’s Petition*

made, to the contrary, should be utterly- Void, frustrate, and of none Effect.

And to prove that on the Failure of Heirs Male of the said William Earl of Derby, James Lord Stanley, and Robert Stanley, the said Isle, on the Death of James late Earl of Derby, in the Year 1735, descended, under the said Parliamentary Entail, to the most Noble James Duke of as right Heir of the said James Lord Stanley, and that on his Decease, in 1764, the Succession thereof devolved on John Duke of Atholl, and Charlotte Dutchess of Atholl and Baroness Strange, his Wife, Daughter and only surviving Child and Heir at Iaw of the said James Duke of Atholl, an Act of Parliament of the Fifth Year of His present Majesty was produced to your Committee, intituled, "An Act for carrying into " Execution a Contract made pursuant' to the Act " of Parliament of the Twelfth Year of his late Majesty King George the First, between the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury and the Duke " and Dutchess of Atholl, the Proprietors of the Isle " of Mann, and their Trustees, for the Purchase of " the said Island and its' Dependencies, under certain Exceptions therein particularly mentioned," wherein those several Facts last mentioned are stated or recited.

And Mr. George Stuart informed your Committee, That the said John late Duke of Atholl departed this Life in the Year 1774, leaving the said Charlotte Dutchess of Atholl, his Wife, and the said present Duke of Atholl, his eldest Son and Heir at Law, him surviving; and that by virtue of a Deed of Restriction, bearing Date the 30th Day of December 1774, duly executed by the said Dutchess, for the Reasons therein recited the said now Duke of Atholl became entitled to the immediate Possession of the said Isle, and hath continued in the Possession thereof; a Copy of which said Deed, taken from the Records of the Court of Session in Scotland, and proved to be a true Copy thereof by the said George Stuart, who compared the same, was also produced to your Committee.

In further Proof of the Allegations of the said Petition, Three several Reports made to the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury; namely, a Report of the Commissioners of the Customs in England, of the 4th of January 1765; a Report of the Commissioners of Customs and Excise in Scotland, of the 24th of 1764; and a Report of the Commissioners of the Revenue in Ireland, of the 20th of October 1764, were produced to your Committee, by which it appears that great Frauds and Abuses had been practised by the running of Goods from the Isle of Mann into the Two Kingdoms, highly injurious to the Revenues thereof, the Loss thereby sustained in the Revenue of Great Britain alone being stated, in the Report of the said Commissioners of Customs and Excise for Scotland, to amount by Computation, to 350,000l. or nearly that Sum, Annually: And, in further Proof of the Existence of the said Mischiefs, His Majesty’s Orders and Proclamations in Council, of the 17th of August 1764, were produced to your Committee, whereby it was ordered, that the Commissioners of the Admiralty should station a sufficient Number of Ships and Cutters in the Harbours and Coasts of the Isle of Mam, in order to the putting a Stop thereto: And your Committee find. That by virtue of certain special Clauses contained in an Act of the Twelfth Year of King George the First, whereby the Commissioners of the Treasury were authorized to treat for the Purchase of the said Isle of Mam on the Behalf of the Crown, the said Commissioners, by their Letter of the 25th of July 1764, had made Overtures to the late Duke of Atholl for the Purchase thereof, or of such Part thereof as it should be found expedient to vest in the Crown for preventing the 01

pernicious Effects of the illicit Trade then carried oil between the said Island and the other Parts of His Majesty’s Dominions; but to which no Answer appears to have been returned by the said Duke, until the 20th of August, a few Days after issuing the said Proclamations.

The said Letter of the 26th of July, with the Duke’s Answer thereto, and the Reply of the Commissioners of the Treasury of the 12th of September following (being, as your Committee is informed, the Whole of the Correspondence on that Occasion) appearing to contain Matter deserving Attention, Your Committee have annexed a Copy thereof to their Report.

In further Support of the Allegations of the said Petition, the several Proceedings entered in the Journal of the House of the nth, 12th, 14th, 17th, and 21st of January 1765, touching the aforesaid illicit Practices, were read to your Committee from the Entries of the Journals; as was likewise the aforesaid Act, passed in the same Year, for re-vesting the said Isle of Mann in the Crown, reserving to the said late Duke and the Dutchess of Atholl, and their Heirs, their Manerial Rights and Landed Property, in the Manner stated and set forth in the said Petition; and also a Grant under the Great Seal of Ireland, dated the 2 2d Day of August, in the Fifth Year of His Majesty’s Reign, whereby, after taking Notice of the said Act of Re-vestment, and that His Majesty, having taken into His Royal Consideration the particular Situation of the Duke and Dutchess of Atholl from Rent Charges and Annuities upon their other Estates, in Consequence of Settlements made by the ldte Duke of Atholl, from the Prospect that the Revenues of the Isle of Mann would have continued to them, and on that Account that His Majesty was graciously disposed to give them a Mark of His Royal Munificence and Bounty; and His Majesty, being sensible that the Revenues and Commerce of the Kingdom of Ireland, as well as those of Great Britain, would receive great Benefit and Improvement by the said Surrender, His Majesty was graciously pleased to grant to the said Duke and Dutchess, for their Lives, and the Life of the Survivor of them, an Annuity or Yearly Allowance of 2,000l. to be issuing out of His Majesty’s Revenues at large in the said Kingdom of Ireland, in the Manner stated in the said Petition.

To shew that the said re-vesting Act was made under the Pressure of the Moment, when the Urgency of the Mischief called for an immediate and effectual Remedy, and when, from the recent Possession of th6 Petitioner’s Father and Mother, they could form no accurate Idea of the Extent or Value of the Rights and Interests which were necessary to be ceded, and that the Act was passed without any Evidence produced to prove what Rights of Property in particular were necessary to be vested in the Crown for the Security of the public Revenue (the sole Object of that Act) from future Frauds and Evasions, it was observed to your Committee, on the Part of the Petitioner, That the aforesaid Proclamations of Council were, at the-Time of making the Contract of March 1765, for the Surrender of the Island, in full Force and Effect, and that the Bill (which with some Amendments was afterwards passed into a Law) " for K the more effectual preventing the Mischiefs arising " to the Revenue and Commerce of Great Britain " and Ireland, from the illicit and clandestine Trade u to and from the Isle of Mann," was then depending in the House; and that, although the Duke and Dutchess of Atholl had been heard by their Counsel at the Bar, on the 19th of February, in Support of their Petition, complaining, " That if the said- Bill should

" pays
