" pass into a Law, they apprehended all the valuable " Rights, Privileges, and Advantages, granted to " their Ancestors under the Sanction of the Legislative Authority, so long exereised and enjoyed by " them to the Extent of their Grant, and lately* " recognized by Parliament, would be wrested and " torn from them without any Provision made for " that Recoin pence and Compensation which the " Legislature, upon a former Hearing of the Paten- tee’s Right, seemed to consider as a Debt to be " paid by the Public for the great consequential " Advantages which would result to the Community " from a Resumption, expedient perhaps to the State, ct but injurious and detrimental to the Proprietor Nevertheless the House proceeded to the P-eading the said Bill a Second Time, and on the same Day resolved that the Bill should be committed to a Committee of the whole House; and further resolved, that the House would, upon that Day Sevennight, being the 28th of February then Instant, resolve itself into a Committee upon the said Bill, in Proof whereof the said Petition, and the Resolutions thereon, were read to your Committee, from the Entries on the Journals; and in further Evidence of the said Allegations, a Letter from the said Duke and Dutchess of Atholl, addressed to the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury, of the 27th of February aforesaid, was produced and read to your Committee, whereby the said Duke and Dutchess did declare their Readiness, if it should be deemed necessary for the public Service, to part with all their Rights in the said Isle; as likewise the Evidence of Mr. Hammer sly, taken at the Bar of the House, on the 18th of May 1781, and of Sir Fletcher Norton, a Member of the House, given in his Place on the same Day, tending to prove (amongst other Things) that the Contract was considered, by the Duke and Dutchess of Atholl, as an involuntary or compulsory Act on their Parts, and that if the Duke was at Liberty, he would not take double the Consideration which had been proposed; and that it Was understood by the Duke, that an Application would be made to Parliament in the next Session to explain and set to Rights any Errors or Improprieties that might have escaped in the said re-vesting Act; and that the Committee on the said other Bill stood suspended only for a Week, to give an Opportunity for re-commencing the Negotiation with the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury for the Surrender of the Island, and within which Time it appears, by the Preamble of the said re-vesting Act, to have been accordingly concluded.

To prove the Annual Produce of the several Species of Revenue arising to the Crown within the said Island, consisting of Customs, Harbour Fund, and Herring and Salmon Fisheries, Two Accounts thereof, purporting to be the Accounts of George Watts, Receiver General of the said Island, have been produced to your Committee; by the One of which it appears that the Produce of the Revenue of Customs of the said Isle, from the Re-vestment in 1765 to the 10th of October 1789, amounts to the Sum of 70,145 /. 3 s.id.; and that by the other . of the said Accounts, that the Net Produce of Harbour Duties on Shipping and Goods, and Herring and Bay Fisheries, from the 5th of July 1771 to the 5th of July 1789, have amounted to the Sum of 7,024/. 16$. 5 which said Two Accounts your Committee have thought fit to annex to their Report, for the Information of the House.

With respect to the Complaint made by the said Petition, that in the Hurry of the Transaction of 1765, arising from the Urgency already stated, the Titles of the Petitioner’s Family appear not to have been perfectly understood, insomuch that Words of Voi. 4 5.

gveat legal Import, contained in the Act of the Se- Duke of venth or King James the First, " for the Settlement £tho!1 " and Entail of the said Island unalienably,’’ were icUUt>n‘ omitted to be inserted in the Preamble of the said Bill of 1765, and which, as the Petitioner is advised, militate against the Power of James Duke of Atholl to new model the Succession by the Deed of Trust of 1756, recited in the said Preamble, but to the Uses of which Settlement the said 70,000 /. hath been actually applied by the Trustees thereof, under the Sanction given to the new Entail by that Agreement made between the Crown and the said Trustees, and utider the Power given to the Trustees of the same Entail, by the Provisions of the said Act, for vesting Mann in the Crown: Your Committee, on comparing the Recitals of the said Act of Settlement, contained in the said Preamble, with the said Act, have found that some Inaccuracies have crept into the said Recital, and in particular, that neither the Date nor the Title of the said Act are correctly stated in the said Preamble, and that some Part of the Clause contained in the said Act, whereby any Acts or Deeds for alienating the said Isle are nullified, are omitted to be inserted in that Part of the Preamble which recites the said nullifying Clause; but whether the said Inaccuracies in the Recital of the Date and Title of the said Act, or the said Omissions, are of great legal Import, or militate with the Powers of the said James Duke of Atholl to new model the Succession to the said Isle, your Committee submit to the Judgment of the House; and for their better Information (the said Act of Succession being a private One, and not a printed Statute) your Committee have annexed an authenticated Copy thereof to their Report

Copy of a Letter, dated 25th July 1764, from the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury to the Duke of Athol, in relation to the Purchase of the Isle of Man.

My Lord,

We think proper to inform your Grace, That id pursuance of the Powers vested in us by the Twelfth of George the First, we are willing to treat with you for the Purchase of the Isle of Man, or of such Part of the Rights claimed by your Grace in the said Island as it shall be found expedient to vest in the Crown, for preventing that pernicious and illicit Trade which is at present carried on between the said Island and the other Parts of His Majesty’s Dominions, in Violation of the Laws, and to the great Diminution and Detriment of the Revenues of this Kingdom.

The House of Commons, during the last Session of Parliament, thought fit to enquire whether any, and what Steps, had been taken for this Purpose; and we have Reason to think it is expected of us that we should pursue every legal Method for the Prevention of this Evil; with, this View we have judged it necessary, First, to inform ourselves of the present extent of this illegal Commerce, of the Nature of those Rights, under Colour of which it is carried on, and of the Laws of this Country with respect to them: We are now ready to treat with your Grace, pursuant to the said Act of Parliament, and to receive from you a Proposal for that Purpose, specifying what Part of your Property and Rights in the said Island you are disposed to sell, and the Value you put upon them, that we may know whether the Terms are in all Respects such as we, who are Trustees .-for the Public, can admit; but if your Grace is qotjSfeclined to enter into a Treaty with us upon the Subject, we beg to be informed of it, that we may ifiien pursue

Duke of Athol l’« Petition.

280 16° Mar tit. . 1790.

such other Methods as we shall think our-Duty to the Public requires of us.

We are,

My Lord,

Your Grace's most humble Servants,

George,

Whitehall Treasury John,

Chambers, James Harris.

25 July 176*

Copy of a Letter, dated 20th August 1764, from the Duke of Athol to the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury, in relation to the Sale of the Isle of Man.

Athol H,20th August 1764.

My Lords,

I have received the Honour of your Lordships Letter of the 25th of July, informing me, that, in pursuance of the Act of the Twelfth of King George the First, you are willing to treat with me for the Purchase of the Isle of Man.

I am very sdiry to hear there has been so many Complaints of Smuggling from thence, which is a Practice I give no Maaner of Encouragement to, iny Revenues arising from a fair Duty, collected upon the Importation of Goods.

I have the same Ideas with regard to the Sale of the Island that the late Duke of Athol had, who always declared, that no Temptation of Gain could induce him to give up so ancient, so honourable, and so noble a Birth Right, such as no. Subject of the Crown of England now has, or ever had, which has been in our Family near Four Centuries; and that he thought nothing could be an Equivalent to One of his Rank and Circumstances for so great a Patrimony: At the same Time his Duty and Attachment to the King was such, that if it was esteemed, upon a full Consideration, an important Point for His Majesty’s Service, and for the Good of the Public, he in that Event was willing to enter into a Treaty for the Disposal of it; — and these are the only Reasons that can induce me to do the same.

The Purchase of the Isle of Man has been frequently thought of by former Administrations; but upon balancing the Advantages and Disadvantages which might arise to Government, they did not think proper to treat conclusively upon it. Sir Robert Walpole made some Proposals to the late Duke, but afterwards dropt them. Mr. Pelham once seemed very desirous to bring the Sale to a Conclusion; and the Duke of Athol gave him a true and precise State of the Nature and Revenue of this Principality, that he might be able to judge what Proposal to make; and he assured the Duke, that no Proposal should come from him which he would not adjudge, if it was left to him to settle as an Arbitrator: However the Affair, after being some Months in Agitation, was again dropt. It was resumed by the Duke of Newcastle, when he was First Lord of the Treasury; and the Duke of Athol treated with the same Confidence, being averse to sell, but always ready to submit to the King's Pleasure in any Matter which he thought for the Public Good; and having a full Reliance in the Duke of Newcastle's Honour and Justice, that as his Brother had said, so his Grace would propose no Terms which he would not award as an Arbitrator: After the Duke of Newcastle was informed, the Matter was likewise in the same Manner laid aside.

The Reason why neither Sir Robert Walpole, Mr. Pelham, nos the Duke of Newcarried it further,

was thought to be, that upon thorough Examination the Object did not appear to them of such Consequence, as it did at first; for, supposing it was in the Possession of the Government, the Proximity must still be the same; between Thirty and Forty thousand Inhabitats must still have a Right to their Constitution, Laws, Administration of Justice, and interior Trade and Commerce; and it would be in the Case of Guernsey, Jersey, Sark, and Alderney, where Imports and Exports are governed By their own Laws, as much as if they were under Feudatory Lords; and from these Islands they found that Smuggling was carried to a much greater Excess than from the Isle of Man (and I am credibly informed that is still the Case) I have heard that they have often thought in Ireland of raising a large Sum. to offer towards the Consideration, and upon fuller Consideration dropt it.

As I have been but a few Months in Possession of the Isle of Man, and never in the least turned my Thoughts towards a Sale of it, it is impossible for me, uninformed as I am at present, to fix upon what I should think an adequate Price for a Possession so very considerable both for Honour and Profit; and as I never heard of any Notion to purchase a Part only, I don’t at all understand what it is. I can therefore at present have no Proposal to make, but will always be ready to receive, with Respect, any Proposal which shall come to me from your Lordships,

I am,

My Lords,

Your Lordships most obedient and most humble Servant,

Athol.

Copy of a Letter, dated 12th of September 1764* from the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury to the Duke of Athol, in relation to the Purchase of the Isle of Man.

My Lord,

We have received your Grace’s Letter of the 20th of August, in Answer to that we wrote to you on the 25th of July, in which we informed your Grace, that in pursuance of the Powers vested in us by 12th George i"; we were willing to treat with you for the Purchase of the Isle of Man, and to receive from you a Proposal for that Purpose. Your Grace acquaints us, that, uninformed as you are at present, from the short Possession you have had of this Island, it is impossible for you to fix upon what you should think an adequate Price for it; that you cannot therefore at present make any Proposal, but that you shall always be ready to receive such as shall come to you from us.

Your Grace must be sensible, that this Objection, which you alledge against making a Proposal on your Part must operate much more strongly to prevent our making any to you; and that we, who have not even an Opportunity of informing ourselves of the Value of this Possession, cannot possibly fix upon a Price, which, as Trustees to the Public* we should think ourselves authorized to propose; but as your Grace informs us, that when the Purchase of this Island was on former Occasions under Consideration, the late Duke of Athol gave to Mr. Pelham, and the Duke of N,a true and precise State of the Nature of this Possession, and of the Revenue arising firom it, we think it proper to desire, that, if your Grace now intends to treat with us, you would in like Manner transmit to us an exact and accurate Rental of the said Revenue,

specifying

30 Geo. III.

.16° Martii.

281

specifying the several Kinds of which it consists, the Annual Amount of each, and, with respect to any Customs or Impost Duties which you may receive, the several Species of Goods on which they are levied, the Rates at which they are paid, and the Annual Amount of the Duties arising from each Species respectively. We must know the Nature as well as Value of every Branch of the Revenue of this Island before we can form any Judgment of the Price which ought to be paid for it, or can determine what Part of your Grace’s Possessions in this Island it will be necessary or expedient to purchase, in order to obtain the Benefit for which such Purchase is intended; and this is what we meant by the Proposal we made in our former Letter, of purchasing only a Part of your Grace’s Property and Rights in the said Island.

As it is highly probable that Parliament will expect to be informed in the ensuing Session what Measures have been taken for carrying their Intentions into Execution, and what has passed upon the Subject, we are the more desirous to obtain from your Grace the Information above-mentioned in the most full and accurate Manner, that the Parliament may thereby be enabled to judge what Terms it may be proper to allow; they will then take under their Consideration the Objections mentioned by your Grace, arising from the Proximity of that Island, and from its present Constitution, Laws, and Administration of Justice, as well as its interior Trade and Commerce; and as they have frequently made Laws respecting this Island, they will enact such other Laws, and make such further Provisions for preventing the illicit Trade carried on by Means thereof, as in their Wisdom and Justice they shall think proper.

We are,

My Lord,

Your Grace’s

most humble Servants,

George Grenville. John Turner.

Hunter.

North.

Whitehall Treasury Chambers,

12th Seps 1764.

Duke of Athol.

Copy of a Letter from the Duke and Dutchess of Athol, to the Commissioners of the Treasury; dated February the 27th, 1765.

London, February 27th, 1765.

My Lords,

We have already communicated to your Lordships, and by our Petition humbly laid before Parliament, our Desire to accommodate the Public, at the Expence of our private Feelings, with any Part of our Hereditary Rights in the Isle of Man, which it may be expedient to vest in the Crown for the Public Service. Your Lordships, by your Letter of the 25th of July 1764, invited us to make Proposals, and by your Letter of the 12th September following, desired us to produce such an Account of the Nature and Amount of our Revenues, as might enable you to determine what Part of our Rights and Possessions it would be expedient to purchase, and to form a Judgment of the Price which ought to be paid for them.

This has led us into a particular Consideration of Duke of these Objects; and we are now enabled to make Proposals, and to afford your Lordships the Information you desired. The inclosed Account will shew your Lordships the Nature of our Revenues arising from our Rights and Possessions in the Isle of Man, and the Amount of them. We are ready, if it should be deemed necessary for the Public Service, to part with all our Rights, held under the several Grants of the Isle of Man; but we apprehend that the Reservation of our Landed Revenue, together with the Patronage of the Bishoprick, and other Ecclesiastical Benefices in the Island, cannot interfere with the Interest of the Public: And we presume your Lordships will not have any Objection to our preserving the honourable Distinction and Service which our Ancestors have so long enjoyed, and by which they held their Rights in this Island, of presenting the Two Falcons at the Coronation.

The Legislature have formerly authorized Us to hope, and your Lordships have called upon us to propose a proper Compensation: We feel the Weight of this additional Difficulty, which may expose us to the Imputation of making an unreasonable Demand on the one Hand, and of not doing sufficient Justice to our Family on the other; but the Circumstances of the Case make it necessary, and therefore, without entering into any Discussion of the various Articles of which our Rights consist, we hope neither His Majesty nor the Parliament will think the clear Sum of 70,000l. too great a Price to be paid us in full Compensation for the absolute Surrender of the Isle, Castle, and Peele of Man, and all Rights, Jurisdictions, and Interests in or over the said Island, and all its Dependencies, holden under the several Grants thereof, or under any other Title whatsoever, reserving only our Landed Property, with all our Rights in and over the Soil, as Lords of the Manor, with all Courts Baron, Rents, Services, and other Incidents to such Courts belonging, our Wastes, Commons, and other Lands, Inland Waters, Fisheries, and Mills, and all Mines, Minerals, and Quarries, according to our present Rights therein, Felons Goods, Deodands, Waifs, Estrays, and Wrecks at. Sea; together with the Patronage of the Bishoprick, and of the other Ecclesiastical Benefices in the said Island, to which we are now entitled, to be holden of the Crown by the honourable Service above-mentioned.

But we presume to hope that our particular Situation arising from Rent Charges and Annuities upon our other Estates, in consequence of Settlements made by the late Duke of Athol, from a Prospect that the Revenues of the Isle of Man would continue to us, will, through your Lordships favourable Mediation, recommend us to His Majesty for such Mark of His Royal Munificenae, as from the Consideration of the Case shall appear to His Majesty to be reasonable.

We are,

Your Lordships

Most obedient Servants,

Athol.

C. Athol & Strange.

Vol. 45.

l)bke of Atholl's Petition.

An Acte for the assuring^ and establishinge of the Isle of Mamie.

In all bumblenes beseeche your Most Excellent Ma''", yo' loyall and faithfull Subjects, William Earle of Derbie, the Lady Elizabeth his Wife, James Lord

Stanley, Sonne and Heire Apparent of the said Earle, and Robert Stanley, Second Sonne of the said Earle:

That whereas the said Earle and his Anncesto" have, for many Ages past, ever since the Seaventh Yere of die Raigne of King Henry the Fowerth, held and en-ioyed the Isle, Castle, Peele, and Lordshipp of w,h all their Rights, Members, and Apptennes, as their owne proper Inheritance, and bene reputed and taken to be the true and vndoubted Lords and Owners of the same: And forasmuch as the said Isle and Lordship of Mann hath long continued in the Name and Bloud of the said Earle, and to the End the same may continewe still, by yo' Highnes Princely Favor and gracious Allowance, in his Name and Bloud, so longe as it shall please Almightie God, Maie it please yor Ma"*, that it may be Enacted by yor Highnes, wlh thassent of the Lords Spirituall and Temporall, and the Comdns in this p'sent Parham’ assembled, and by the Authority of the same, And be it Enacted, Or-dayned, and Established, by yo' Highnes, the Lords Spirituall and Temporall, and the Cornons in this p'sent Parham’ assembled, and by the Authoritie of the same, That yo’ said Subjects William Earle of Derbie, and the said Lady Elizabeth his Wife, for and during their Lyves, and the longer Liver of them, and after their Deathes the said Janies Lord , and the

Heires Males of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and after his Death, w’hout such Issue the saide Robert Stanley, and the Heires Males of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and after his Death, w’hout such Issue, the Heires Males of the Body of the said William Earle of Derbie, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, the right Heires of the said James Lord Stanley shall and may, for ever hereafter, Ijave, hould, and quietly enioye, freely and cleerly, against your Ma,le, yo' Heires and Successo" (for, under, and upon the Tenures, Rents, and Services hereafter menconed to be reserved) against Thomas Lord Ellesmere, Lord Channcello’ of England, the Lady Alice Countesse of Derbie, his Wife, late the Wife of Ftsrdinando late Earle of Derbie, deceased, and against Henry Earle of Huntingdon, and the Lady Elizabeth Countesse of Huntingdon his Wife, Grey Lord Chandoys, and the Lady Anne his Wife, Sir John Egerton, of Mony for their Clayme, Right, and Title to the said Isle, Castle, Peele, apd Lordship of Mam, as appeareth by their Deed thereof made, and now shewed forth in yo' Highnes Highe Court of Parliam’, And be it further Enacted by your Highnes, the Lords Spirituall and Temporal!, and the Comons in this p'sent ^liam' assembled, and by the Authoritie of the same, That neither the said James Lord Stanley, nor any the Heires Males of His Cody, lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, nor the said Robert Stanley, nor any the Heires Males of his Body, lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, nor any the Heires Males of the Body of the said William Earle of Derbie, lawfully begotten, or to be begotten, shall haue any Power, Authoritie, or Libertie, to giue, grannt, alien, bargaine, sell, convey, assure, or doe away the said Isle, Castle, Peele, and Lordship of Mamie, Messuages, Lands, Tents, Tithes, Hereditam", and other the Premisses in this Act mencioned to be enioyed as aforesaid, or any Part or jp'cell thereof, from his or their Issue or Issues, or other Persons by this Act appoynted to enjoy the same, but that the same shall remayne and contmewe to the said James Lord Stanley, and the Heires Males of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the said Robert Stanley, and to the Heires Males of his Body, lawfully begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the Heires Males of the Body of the said William Earle of Derbie, lawfullye begotten, and to be begotten; and for Default of such Issue, to the right Heires of the said James Lord Stanley, as before by this Act is appointed: And that all Gifts, Grannts, Alienacons, Bargaynes, Sales, Conveyances, Assurances, and Acts don, or to be done or made to the contrary, shalbe vtterly void, frustrate, and of none Effect: Savinge neverthelesse, that it shall and may be lawfull for them and euery of them to make such Estates of such severall Partes thereof as by the Lawes and Customes of the said Isle is vsuall, and to make such Leases and Demises of such Parts and {p'cells thereof as Tcnante in Taile by the Statute made in the Two and Thirtith Yere of the Raigne of King Henry the Eight, may lawfully doe w"in this yo' Highnes Realme of England. And be it also further Enacted by the Authoritie aforesaid, That neither this Act, nor any Thing herein conteyned, shall in any wise extepde, or be construed to avoide, frustrate, abridge, impaire, deminishe, or p'iudice the State, 07

mised. for, under, and upon such Yerely Rents, Re-servacons, Covennts, Provisoes, and Agreements as are mencioned & expressed in the said Ires Pattents against yor Ma,ie, your Heires and Successo", and all and euery other ijp’son and <^sons, and their Heires, having or clayminge any Estate, Right, Title, or Interest vnto the said demised ^misses, by force and virtue of this Act: Savinge to the Archbushopp of Yorke, and his Successo", all Metropoliticall Jurisdiction in all Points, and to all Purposes and Effects, of the Busshopprickes and Diocesse of Manne, in the said Isle of Mamie, as is geven, vnited, lymitted, and appoynted to the Province and Archbushoppricke of Yorke, accordinge to an Act of Parliam' made and provided in the Three and Thirtith Yere of the Raigne of King Henry the Eighte, late King of England: Savinge also to all and singuler <^son and ^psons. Bodies Pollitique and Corporate, their Heires and Successo", and the Heires and Successo", of every of them, and the Exeeuto", Admistrato", and Assignes of euery of them (other than yo' Highnes, your Heires and Successo", and the said Thomas Lord Ellesmere and the said Lady Alice Countesse of Derbie his Wife, and the said Henry Earle of Huntingdon and the said Elizabeth Countesse his Wife, Gray Lord Chandoys and the said Lady Anne his Wife, the said S' John Egerton and the Lady Frannces his Wife, and the Heires of the said Elizabeth, Anne, and Frannces, and the Heires of the said Ferdinando late Earle of Derbie, and the said Thomas Ireland, Esquier, his Exeeuto", Administrato", and Assignes (the Tenures, Rents, and Services reserved to yo' Ma,ie, yo' Heires and Successo", alwaies reserved) all such and every and the same Estate and Estates, Lease and Leases, Rights, Titles, Interests, Rents, Services, Tenures, Jurisdiccons, Priviledges, Liberties, Possessions, Revercons, Remaynders, Anur-ties, Pencons, Profitts, Comodities, Accons, Entries, Condicons, Claymes, and Dcmanndes wch theie or any of them now lawfully haue, or hereafter shall or may lawfully haue or clayme, of, into, out of, or for the said Isle, Castle, Peele, and Lordshipp of Manne, Manno", Messuags, Lands, Tenem", and ^misses, or of, into, out of, or for any of them, in such and the same Manner and Forme, to all Intents, Constructions, and Purposes as if this p'sent Act had never bene had or made, this Act or any Thing herein conteyned to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding; and yo' said Subjects, according to their most bounden Duties, shall and will daily pray for your Highnes longe, happie, and prosperous Raigne over vs.

George Rose,

Cler. Parliamentor.

Report of The Master of the Rolls) according to Order, reallowance to ported from the Committee of the whole House, to Mr. Speaker. wh0m it was referred to consider of an Allowance to be made to the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, more adequate to the Dignity of the said Office, ana to the Expence necessarily attending the same, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place.; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That for enabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, more effectually to support the Dignity of the said Office, and the Expence necessarily attending the same, the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury be authorized to direct from Time to Time, a Sum to be issued at the Exchequer, which, together with the Fees, and Allowances of 5 I. a Day now payable on Account of the said Office, may amount to the clear Yearly Sum of 6,000l.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, Nemine Contradicente, That a Bill be brought in upon the said Resolution: And that the Master of the Rolls, Mr. Frederick Montagu, Mr. Secretary Grenville, and Mr. Marsham, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who. are appointed to prepare, and bring in, the said Bill, That they do make Provision therein for disabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, from holding or enjoying any Office or Place of Profit, during Pleasure, under the Crown.

Money’s Estate Bill committed.

An ingrossed Bill from the Lords, intituled, An Act for vesting Part of the Freehold Estates devised Vo L. 45.

by the Will of James Money, Esquire, deceased, in Trustees, to be sold, and for laying out the Money arising thereby in the Purchase of other Hereditaments, to be settled to the same Uses as the Estates to be sold now stand limited to, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill he committed to Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Gilbert, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, Merchants, Petition and principal Inhabitants of the City of Bristol, was relating to presented to the House, and read; Setting forth,

That Application has been made to the House, for Road* Leave to bring in a Bill for widening, amending, and Bill, improving the Turnpike Road leading from the TotVn of Birmingham, in Warwickshire, to in

Worcestershire; and that the said Road is, in several Parts thereof, extremely hilly and narrow, and to be widened, and rendered more easy and convenient for Carriages, is become indispensably necessary, and the more especially as several Accidents have happened, and many Persons have been maimed and killed by Carriages being overturned: And therefore praying the House to grant such Relief in the Premises as to them shall s;em meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tomorrow Sevennight, the 24th Day of this Instant March, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

Edinburgh A Petition of certain Persons in the City of

agatngTthe burgh thereunto subscribing, Manufacturers of, and

Tobacco Act. Dealers in Snuff and Tobacco, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have no Reason to dispute that the Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting

new Duties in lieu thereof, like all others, was wisely intended for beneficial Purposes, but, if those Purposes come short of their original Intention, there must be an Error in the System, which ought to be rectified, and there can be none so materially interested in that Rectification as those who immediately feel the Hardships of the Statute; and that although the Petitioners wish at all Times not only to contribute towards the Exigencies of the State, but chearfully to comply with every Law made in that Behalf, yet the one already mentioned, and of which they now complain, is dark, inexplicable, and totally subversive of the Ends for which it was enacted, and while the Petitioners are endeavouring to obtain a Knowledge of the Law for the Regulation of their Conduct, and which after unremitted Application they have not been able to acquire, they are at all Times exposed to severe Penalties, which the utmost Circumspection upon their Part cannot avoid; and that, besides those Statutory Hardships, and probably ultimate Ruin, to which the fair Manufacturers and Dealers are exposed, they are otherwise oppressed, owing to a large Quantity of manufactured Snuff and Tobacco being already smuggled into the Country, which, so far from meeting with any proper Check, is every Day increasing to a pernicious Height, and by which the Interests of many honest and industrious Families will be totally destroyed: Such Circumstances are not Matter of private Complaint, they have been universally felt and universally reprobated, insomuch that an Application is to be made for a Repeal of the Act in Question, so far as it imposes an Excise Duty upon Tobacco and Snuff, at least for a Reduction of the Duties to a certain Amount, which Application merits the Approbation of the Petitioners, and meets with their hearty Concurrence, but, situated as they are, they can do nothing more to promote the End, than request that the House will use their best Endeavours to procure such new Enactment as may be judged beneficial for the State, and less oppressive to the Subjects: That previous to the American War, the Duty upon each Pound of Tobacco was about Five Pence, and it must be admitted, that, at that Period, none was smuggled into the Country: How soon the Duty was increased under the Customs, smuggling of Leaf Tobacco became common, and now when the Legislature, in order to remedy that Abuse, has put the Duties under the Management of Excise, the Smuggling Adventurer is, with equal Success, bringing in manufactured Tobacco and Snuff; and the Petitioners submit that a Reduction of the Duties to Nine Pence per Pound would go far to defeat those pernicious Practices, for the Object of Gain, which influences the illicit Trader, being thereby made disproportionate to his Risque, few or none would embark in such Adventures, and by this too the Duties would be rendered more effectual and permanent, and fair Traders put on a Footing to combat the sinister Practices of the Defrauders of the Revenue; and it is a Fact, that when the Duties were increased above the original Standard of about Five , Pence per Pound, Two-thirds of the Tobacco consumed in this Country was smuggled: If the Petitioners are right in this Proposition, and which they could undertake to prove, it follows as a necessary Consequence, that Government profited as much from the original Duties when no Tobacco was smuggled, as under the higher Duties which give Encouragement to Smuggling, and there can be little Doubt that, were they reduced to the Medium pointed at by the Petitioners, it would produce a certain Saving of Four Pence per Pound: These are the Sentiments of, and the only Observations which the Petitioners will make upon, the Subject, being fully convinced that, when the Law is recognized, it will be found to stand truly in Need of Alteration and Amendment: And therefore praying the House to consider the Premises, and to give the Petitioners such Relief as may be thought proper or expedient.

Ordered, That the said Petition he referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

A Petition of the Merchants, Owners of Ships, and Petition from others concerned in Maritime Commerce, residing in Plymouth re-the Town of Plymouth, was presented to th6 House, ®Pec‘intS !he and read; Setting forth. That, by several Acts for the of°Ships. '°n Suppression of Smuggling, not only the Vessels and Goods of the fraudulent Trader, but those of the fair and honest Merchant, are liable to Seizure and Confiscation, and, if those Acts make any Distinction between them, the Petitioners beg Leave to suggest, such Distinction appears to be in Favour of the Smuggler. The Act of the Twenty-fourth of His present Majesty, which seems to apply principally to Vessels hovering on the Coast, and as such indisputably Smugglers, and Objects of exemplary Punishment, has a Clause, enabling the Owner or Master, as well as those of the fair and open Trader, by giving Evidence of the Smallness of the Quantity of Goods found on Board, and other extenuating Circumstances, to assert his Innocence, and preserve his Vessel from Forfeiture; whilst the Act of the Twenty-second of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for the " further securing the Property of the Owners in such " Ships or Vessels as are liable to Forfeiture for iraporting Spirits, or other Goods, by the Misconduct " of the Master, Mate, and Seamen," and which admits the Hardship that Ship Owners labour under, and the Reasonableness of their being secured in their Property, does nothing more than give to the innocent Owners Penalties from the guilty Seamen, which the Owners find impossible to recover, from the Hazard and Difficulty a Prosecution of that Sort would involve them in; and the 59th Section of the

Act

Bill te prevent Delay iu Electious presented.

Voices to Committee on Marlborough Roads Bill.

CheadleRo&4 Bill committed.

30 Geo. III. 16° Martii. 287

Act of the Twenty-sixth of His present Majesty enacts, " That every Ship, importing any Foreign " Spirituous Liquors, British Plantation Rum and " Arrack excepted, in any Cask containing less than " One hundred Gallons, except Two Gallons for each " Seaman, with all her Stores and Furniture, be the " Burthen or Value thereof what they may, shall be " forfeited, without any Limitation or Qualification "whatsoeverand that, in consequence of those Acts, the Ship Hope, belonging to the Port of Plymouth, was seized in the River Thames, condemned and sold, owing to a fraudulent Act of the Master, in his Voyage from Hamburgh to London, with which the Owners were actually unacquainted, as appeared to the entire Satisfaction of the Commissioners of the Customs, and to the Judge who tried the Cause, by which the Owners, Men of large Families, were nearly ruined, their Loss amounting to 3,000 /., and upwards; and a large Swedish Ship called The Aurora, was also seized in the said Port, for a trifling Act of Smuggling of the Master, and the Owner in Sweden, by the Loss of his Ship and the heavy Expences attending his Endeavours to recover the same, was reduced to Poverty; and that, although Ships are not always prosecuted to Condemnation, yet the Owner is liable, from the Tenor of those Acts, to great Injury, by Delays and Expences in compounding with the Seizing Officer, &c. without having it in his Power to obtain Satisfaction from the Aggressors, Seamen in general being Men of no Property, and the Petitioners believe, that the Dread of falling under the Penalties inflicted by the aforesaid Acts hath prevented many Men of Fortune from being concerned in Shipping: And therefore praying the House to take the late Acts made for the Suppression of Smuggling into further Consideration, and fix the Punishment on the Persons actually guilty of the Fraud, in such Manner as to the House shall appear best.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Petition

16° Martii. A. 1790.

Petition from \ Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Estate* of thereunto subscribed, being Owners or Occupiers of against the Lands or Estates through or near which a Canal Na-liirmingham vigation is intended to be made from or near the

ttrCanomlu *^own Birmingham, to communicate with the River *r an , Severn,at or near Worcester, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the said intended Canal, if made, will totally destroy a large Quantity of valuable Land, and otherwise materially injure the Estates and Property through or near which the same will pass; and that a Canal Navigation from the Town of Birmingham, into the River Secern, hath been already made at a great Expence, and another is now also making to the said River, and nearly completed, by Means of the Junction of the Dudley and Birmingham Canals, which will be fully sufficient to answer every necessary and useful Purpose of Water Conveyance from the Town of Birmingham into such River; and that the Petitioners conceive the said intended Canal is calculated to answer the private Views of the Schemers thereof, without a Probability of affording to the Public any Advantage adequate to the great Injury which the Petitioners, and others, will unavoidably sustain thereby; and the Petitioners, sensible of the great Injury they must sustain in their Estates and Property, if the Scheme of making such intended Canal should be carried into Execution, do hereby declare their total Dissent thereto: And therefore praying, That the Bill for making such intended Canal may not pass into a Law, and that they may be heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the same.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester, be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

IteportWays Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the abd Means. Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Expiring Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Law. That an Act, made in the Twelfth Year of the Regin

of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for encouraging the Manufacture of Leather, by lowering the Duty payable upon the Importation of Oak " Bark, when the Price of such Bark shall exceed a " certain Rate, for a limited Time," which was to continue in Force for Five Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, which Act was by another Act, made in the Seventeenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, continued for the further Term of Five Years,* and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, and which Act, by another Act made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, was revived and continued for the further Term of Five Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, is near expiring, and fit to be continued.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Mr. Alderman Neumham, according to Order, re- Bishop’s ported from tffe Committee, to whom the Petition of Stortford and several Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the Bramdou several Gentlemen, Clergy, Traders, and others, Inha- pe*|^gn8 rt_ bitants of the Counties of Herts, Essex, Cambridge, ported.

Isle of Ely, Huntingdon, and Suffolk, on Behalf of themselves, and others; and also the Petition of the several Gentlemen, Clergy, Traders, and other Inhabitants of the Counties of Herts, Essex, Cambridge, Isle of Ely, Huntingdon, and Suffolk, on Behalf of themselves and others,' were severally referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place, and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth, viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petitions,

Mr. John Rennie being examined, said, That a Navigation is already completed from the City of London to the Town of Bishop's Stortford, in the County of Herts — That by a Survey lately taken, it appears the same may be extended, by proceeding to a Place called Palmers Water, in the said County, and from thence to the Parish of Elsenham, and through the North Parts of the County of Essex to the Town of Saffron Walden, and from the last mentioned Place through the Counties of Cambridge and Suffolk, to join the Brandon River, whereby Communication will be opened to the County of Norfolk — That a Branch may be made from such extended Line in the Parishes of Great and Little Abingdon and Baber ham, to communicate with the Town of Cambridge, and another Branch may be made by a Cut to fall into the Burwell Lode, which is already Navigable to the Cambridge River, whereby a convenient Communication will be opened with the Isle of Ely, and the Counties of Huntingdon and Bedford.

The Reverend Abraham Jobson being examined, said, That he lives at March, In the Isle of Ply, which is the Centre of the Fens — That if such Navigation, with the Branches therefrom, are made, it will be productive of great Utility and Benefit to the Inhabitants of the said Counties, and to the Public in general, by rendering the Carriage of Corn, and all Kinds of Merchandize, which pass between the Metropolis and the before-mentioned Counties, and the several Towns and Places therein, cheaper and easier than at present. —

And being asked, Whether his Place of Residence is near the Course of the intended Canal ? he said, That March is situated upon the River Nene, which will communicate with the intended Navigation.

And being asked, How far it is from the intended Canal ? he said, About 20 Miles. — And being asked,

Whether he thought himself a Judge what Effect the Canal would have upon that Part of the Country between Cambridge and Bishop's Stortford? he said. It would have a very good Effect; but is in a great Measure a Stranger to that Part of the Country.

Mr.

16° Mar til

28 9

Mr. Charles Wedge being examined, said, That he lives at Gaze ley, in Suffol, and is a Farmer; and confirmed the Evidence of the former Witness, with respect to the Utility and Benefit of the proposed Navigation. — And being asked, What particular Part he spoke to? he said, To the Country about Newmarket. — And being asked, What Distance he lived from the Line of the intended Canal? he said, Four or Five Miles. — And being asked, What particular Utility he thought the intended Navigation would be of in the District of Country he spoke to? he said, It would much reduce the Price of Carriage.

Mr. Allen Taylor being examined, said. That he lives at Wimbish; is a Farmer and Maltmaker — That many Advantages may arise from the proposed Navi-

J;ation to the Country in the Neighbourhood of

ron Walden, but particularly in the Carriage of the Produce of that Part of the Country to the River Stort. — And being asked, What was the Price of the Carriage of Malt from Saffron Walden to Bishop's Stort-ford ? he said, One Shilling per Quarter. — And being asked, AVhat it would be by the Navigation? he answered, He could not say; but had no Doubt of its being cheaper, because he found, by Experience, he could convey Goods cheaper by WTater than by Land.

Mr. Atkinson Francis Gibson being examined, said. That Jie lives at Saffron , and is a Brewer and

Maltster; that he thinks the Navigation would be of great Benefit to the Country between Saffron Walden and the Stort Navigation, and to the Sphere of Country that Saffron Walden is supplied from; and he knows it has the general Concurrence of the People of Saffron Walden, and attended your Committee, by their Desire, to state that Opinion for them.

Mr. Edward Wyburd being examined, said That he is a Miller, and lives at Tottenham High Cross — That the Navigation will be very useful to the Country between Saffron Walden and the Stort, and to Roy-don A t ill,which joins the River Lea. — And being

asked, Whether the Metropolis would receive any Advantage? he said, Certainly; a great deal. — And being asked. How it would be benefited ? he said, He at present gave Three Shillings and Sixpence per Quarter for the Carriage of Wheat by Land from Saffron Walden to Roy den Mill, which is about 22Miles; and he supposed if the Canal was made, it would cost about One Shilling and Six Pence. — And being asked, If he knew what the Tolls were to be on the proposed Canal? he said, He should suppose they would not be above Four Pence per Quarter of Wheat. — And being asked, What is the Toll, per Quarter, from Bishop’s Stortford to Roydon Alill? he said, He supposed not One Penny Halfpenny.

Mr. John Rennie being again called in, and asked, Whether he had made an Estimate? said, He had. — And being asked, How much it amounted to? he said, 170,499/. 8s. 9 {d. — And being asked, How much

Money is subscribed? he replied, He could not say, but supposed 75 or 76,000/; but that the Account was annexed to the Petition.

Motion for And a Motion being made, add the Question being Stortford Na- Put> That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for mak-vigation Bill, ing and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from Neg. the Town of Bishop’s Stortford, in the County of Hert-

ford, through the Counties of Hertford, Essex, Cambridge, and Suffolk, to join and communicate with the Brandon River, in the County of Suffolk, and also a Navigable Cut from the said intended Canal to join the Burtcell Lode, in the said County of Suffolk;

The House divided.

An Account of the Number of Ships, with their Tonnage, which have entered, in the Years 1787 and 1788, in the several British West India Islands, from Africa, with the Number of Negroes which were imported on Board the same, in each Year, and also the Negroes imported from other Countries; together with the Number of Negroes which were exported, distinguishing each Island: And also,

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Minchin reported from the Committee, That they had come to a Resolution; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Clatgov Po- Mr. M'Dowall reported from the Committee, to re' rteJ4*0" the Petition of J Campbell, Junior, Esquire,

repor ' Lord Provost, James MDowal, Esquire, James Gordon, Esquire, and James M’Jehose, Esquire, Bailies, and the other Members of the Common Council of the City of Glasgow, for themselves, and as representing the Community of the said City, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, a Member present informed your Committee, That the Corporation of Glasgow, some Years ago, purchased the Lands of Ramshorn, and others, lying

adjacent to the said City, and, the Inhabitants thereof having now greatly increased, it has become necessary to feu and fell those Lands, for the Purpose of being built upon, which renders it expedient that the Royalty of the said City, and the Jurisdiction of the said Corporation, should be extended over the said Lands — That it would also be of Benefit to the Inhabitants and Persons resorting to the said City, if certain new Streets and Avenues were opened, Footways and Pavements made, the Streets better lighted and cleansed, and the Police and Markets better regulated; and in order to carry these useful Purposes into Execution, it will be necessary to raise certain Funds.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a BiH for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgow over certain adjoining Lands; for paving, lighting, and cleansing the Streets, and for regulating the Police of the said City; and, for giving certain Power to the Magistrates of Glasgow for the Benefit of the said City« Ana that Mr. M'Dowall, Lord Frederick Campbell, and Sir James Stewart Denham, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Committee Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House on Report to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House,

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. M'Dowall took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. M'Dowall reported from the Committee, That he was directed by the Committee to make a Motion, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be now received.

The House being informed that Mr. Morton, from Accounts re-the Directors of the East India Company, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, pre- compaify sented to the House, pursuant to their Orders, presented.

N* l. An Account of the Balance of Cash which remained in the Treasury of the East India Company on the ist Day of March 1789, and of their Receipts and Payments in England, from the 1st Day of March 1789 to the 1st Day of March 1790; together with an Estimate of the Receipts and Payments from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791:

And also,

N° 2. An Account of the Sales of Goods from the East Indies, between the 1st Day of March 1789 and the 1st Day of March 1790, with the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize paid, or to be paid, thereout; together with an Estimate of the expected Sales of East India Goods, from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize, to be paid thereout: And also,

N° 3. An Account of the Sales of Goods from China, between the 1st Day of March 1789 and the 1st Day of March 1790, and foe Amount of Customs,

Freight, and Charges of Merchandize paid, or to be paid, thereout; together with an Estimate of the expected Sales of China Goods, from the 1st Day of March 1790 to the 1st Day of March 1791, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, and Charges of Merchandize, to be paid thereout: And also,

N° 4. Amount of the Bond and other Debts of the East India Company in Great Britain, as the same stood on the 1st Day of March 1790: And also,

N° 5. A Statement of the Debts of the East India Company (exclusive of the Debts transferred from India,agreeable to the Orders of the 15th September 1785 and the 31st July 1787) and a Statement of the Effects of the Company in England, and a-float Outwards, as they stood on the 1st Day of March 1790; together with an Account of the Balance of Quick Stock in China, according to the latest Advices: And also,

N° 6. An Account (according to the latest Advices) of all Bills drawn, accepted, or advised, from India, for the last Five Years; distinguishing, as far as can be collected from any Accounts received, the different Dates thereof, and Rates of Exchange, together with the Purposes, or supposed Purposes, for which drawn, and the Periods at which they respectively become due:

And also,

N° 7. An Account of the Balance of Cash which remained in the Treasury of the East India Company on the 1st of March 1784, and of their Receipts and Payments from foe 1st of March 1784 to the 1st of March 179P, distinguishing each Year: And also,

N° 8. An Account of foe Value of India Goods rerpainiqg unsold in the India Company’s Ware-

houses on the 1st of March 1784, ana oh the 1st of March 17,85, distinguishing each Year: And also,

N° 9. An Account of the Value of India Goods remaining unspld in the East India Company’s Warehouses.OF the ist of Mflrch .1790.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, according to Order; Expiring a Bill to continue the several Laws therein mentioned ^*ws relating to encouraging the Manufacture of Leather, by preeen lowering the Duty payable upon the Importation of Oak Bark, when the Price of such Bark shall exceed a certain Rate; to the prohibiting the Exportation of Tools and Utensils made Use of in the Iron and Steel Manufactures of this Kingdom, and to prevent the seducing of Artificers and Workmen, employed in those Manufactures, to go into Parts beyond the Seas; and, to the ascertaining the Strength of Spirits by s

The House was moved, That the Order, made upon Monday last, for referring the Petition of several Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, to the Consideratiorwof a Committee, might be read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Order be discharged.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and principal Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, on Behalf of themselves, and others, is referred: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

Committee Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House onlndemnity to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to indemnify such Persons as have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others, who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law', and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according to Law, or, having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for that Purpose, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee. Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for charging a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Plantations.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for appointing Commissioners to " enquire into the State and Condition of the Woods, " Forests, and Land Revenues, belonging to the Crown, " and to sell or alienate Fee-farm and other Unimproveable Rents."

Resohed, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Ways and Means deferred.

Cocoa Nuts Bill deferred.

Crown Lands Commissioners Bill deferred.

Supply deferred.

The Lords have agreed to

Tin Bill.

Polebrook Inclosure Bill presented.

Petition re-relating to Bromsgro’ve and Birmingham lload BLU.

Harby Inclo* sure Bill presented.

Ordered, That the said Account and Estimates do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Eames and Mr. Leeds:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for taking off the Duties upon unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good Hope;without any Amendment.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Sir James Langham presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and inclosing the Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of Polebrook, in the County of Northampton: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the principal Inhabitants of the Borough of Droitwich, in the County of Worcester, and the Neighbourhood thereof, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That Application has been made to the House for Powers to improve the Turnpike Road leading from the Town of Birmingham, in Warwickshire, to Bromsgrove, m Worcestershire; and that the said Road is of the greatest Consequence to the Borough of Droitwich, as it is the direct Way from the North to the West of England, through Worcester, Gloucester, and Bristol, but is, in many Parts

thereof, so narrow, hilly, and uneven, that Carriages passing along the same are in the utmost Danger, and, in many Parts thereof, Two Carriages cannot pass each other; and that that Part of the Road which lies within the Parish of Nortffeld requires to be diverted,

so as to form a straight Line, whereby the several Hills and hollow Ways, which have occasioned various Accidents to Carriages and Passengers, will be entirely avoided: And therefore praying, That the House will take the Matter into Consideration, and grant the Petitioners such Relief in the Premises as the Case shall require.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Mr. Hungerford presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open Common Fields, Pastures, and other Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Harby, in the County of Leicester: And the same was received) and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Vol. 45,

Colonel Boscawen presented to the House, accord- Truro Paving ing to Order, a Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, Bl11 Pre* and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages; for sen removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances; and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts, within the Borough of Truro, and Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall: And the same w'as received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.'

An ingrossed Bill for enlarging the Term of several Stump Cross Acts, made for repairing the Roads from Stump Cross Iload* to Newmarket Heath, and from Stump Cross aforesaid passe ’

to the End of the Town of Trumpington, next to Shelford, and from ShelfordPound to and for

making more effectual Provision for repairing the said Roads, and also One Mile of the Road between Trumpington and Cambridge, commencing at the South End of Trumpington aforesaid, and for amending the Road from Chesterford Bridge to the End of

next to Shelford, all in the County of Cambridge, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for enlarging the Term of several Acts, made for repairing the Roads from Stump Cross to Newmarket Heath, and from Stump Cross aforesaid to the End of the Town of Trumpington, next to Shelford, and from Shelford Pound to Wittlesford, and for making more effectual Provision for repairing the said Roads, and also One Mile of the Road between Trumpington and Cambridge, commencing at the South End of Trumpington aforesaid, and for amending the Road from Chesterford Bridge to the End of Wittlesford, next to Shelford, all in the County of Cambridge.

Ordered, That Mr. Yorlce do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. John Pitt reported from the Committee, to whom Blaauw’sNat. the Bill for naturalizing Willem Blaauw, was committed; Bill reported. That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had directed him to report the Bill to the House, without any Amendment: And he delivered the Bill in at the Clerk's Table.

Ordered, That the Bill be ingrossed.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Petition for Inhabitants of the City of Glasgoze, was presented to Provision in the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, That Leave has been 1 given to bring in a Bill for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgozo over certain adjoining Lands, for

paving,

308

paving, lighting, and cleansing the Streets, for regulating the Police, and for giving certain Powers to the Magistrates of Glasgow, for the Benefit of the said City; and Alledging, That the Tollbooth, or Common Gaol, of the said City, being small and incommodious, it may be necessary to purchase Houses and Areas, in order to enlarge the same: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for enlarging the said Tollbooth, and purchasing Houses and Areas for that Purpose.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Lord Frederick

Campbell, See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.
