Petition for A Petition of several Gentlemen, Freeholders, Mer-Brudford* 'n ^ants, Tradesmen, and other Inhabitants of Bradford, Waterworks *n the West Riding of the County of York, whose Bill. Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the

House, and read; Setting forth, That several Gentlemen in the Town and Neighbourhood of Bradford, about Forty-five Years ago, for the Benefit of the Inhabitants of the said Town, borrowed a Sum of Money, for conveying Water to the said Town from a Coal Drain in Horton, and such Gentlemen being all dead, their Shares have been sold to several Persons, who, the Petitioners apprehend, now wish to make great Advantage to themselves of the Waterworks; and that Part of the Inhabitants of the said Town have for several Years last past been very badly supplied with Water, and, in order that all the Inhabitants may have equal Benefit, the Petitioners apprehend that several Improvements are necessary to be made in the Works, and that the same ought to be under the Direction of Commissioners, and the Execution of the Act vested in them, with Power to borrow Money for making Improvements, and completing the Works so as to serve all the Inhabitants, and paying off, to such of the old Proprietors as are dissatisfied with their Security, their Principal Money, and that the Inhabitants ought not to be restrained from bringing other Water to the said Town, and laying Pipes in the Town for such Water, nor should any Person be obliged to pay for the present Water, who does not agree for it; and that the Proprietors give out, that they will apply to Parliament, this present Session, for an Act to authorize them to take any Sum, not exceeding 4 /. per Annum, for the Water to any Public House, and 1/. iGs. for the Water to any Private House, and, if such Act was to pass, the Petitioners apprehend that such Sums would be very oppressive on the Inhabitants of the said Town, instead of being beneficial, according to the original Institution; and that the former Owners of Land in Horton, through which the Water passes to 02

A. 1790.

the Town of Bradford (as it was for the Benefit of the Town) permitted the Gentlemen to convey the Water through their Grounds, and the present Waterworks ought to be a Security to the Proprietors for their Principal Money and Interest, but such Proprietors ought to be restrained from advancing the Water Rents any higher than will allow 7 I. per Centum Interest for their Money, such Rents to be settled by Commissioners fairly and equally upon s\ich Inhabitants as chuse to take -it: And therefore praying, That the Execution of the Act may be vested in Commissioners, and such Powers to them given for borrowing Money for the Purposes above, and completing the Works, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Bill for improving and preserving the Works made for supplying the Town of in the County of York, and Part of the Township of Horton, in the Parish of Bradford aforesaid, with Water, and for the more easy Recovery of the Rents for the said Water, be read a Second Time.

Captain Berkeley presented to the House, pursuant Ordnance to their Orders, 1>aP*r* P«-

An Account of such Charges as have been added 8CUte<*-to the Civil Establishment of the Ordnance, either by the Creation of new Places, or by additional Salaries, with the Names of the Persons, or their Deputies, so appointed, and their respective Offices, since the 1st of January 1784: And also,

A Report of such open Contracts as have been made by the Master General and Board of Ordnance, in Consequence of Advertisements in the public Prints, specifying the respective Articles so furnished since the 1st 0 1 January 1784.

And the Titles of the said Account and Report were read.

Ordered, That the said Account and Report do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Account and Report are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are petition ia thereunto subscribed, being Merchants, Manufacturers, favour of nir. and others, resident in or near the Town of Manchester, in the County of Lancaster, was presented to the House, Canal Mi and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Sevei'n, near to the City of Worcester: And praying, That the same may pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time. '

Sir Joseph Marwbey reported from the Committee, Southwark to whom the Petition of the Trustees for putting in Roads Peii-Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Twenty- *»" reportal, second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for opening " and making a new Road, from the East End of " New Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark,

" to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the said Road in Repair for " the future;" and also, another Act of Parliament, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers granted by the said Act, and for repairing several other Roads adjoining to the said Road, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had not been complied with, the Petitioners not being informed of the said Standing Orders

18° Martii.

Mr. Forbes Petition against Stirling Roads Bill

in Time to comply therewith, but that an Estimate of the Expence of making the several Pieces of new Road described in the Petition is annexed thereto; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Acts were read: And,

Mr. John Hosier being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded to put the said Acts in Execution, and have borrowed 9,000l., and upwards upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which still remains due; that the said Roads cannot be kept in Repair, and the Money repaid, unless the Terms and Powers of the said Acts are enlarged, and made more effectual — That Part of the Road leading through a Street called The in the

Parish of Bermondsey, is very narrow and incommodious, and cannot be widened without great Expence, but that a safe and commodious Road might be made to avoid the said Street, to lead from Dock-head to Lillyput Hall Bridge, being Fifty Rods in Length, or thereabouts — That it will be of much Advantage to the Public, to make a new Road to lead from the South East End of Free School Street, through Three Oak Lane, to join the said Turnpike Road at Dockhead, being Thirty Rods in Length; and also a new Road from the said Turnpike Road at the East End of MiUPond Street, through certain Grounds, to the West End of Paradise Row, in the Parish of Rotherhithe, being Eighty-eight Rods in Length. — And the Witness added, That no additional Toll is intended to be taken on the said new Roads, nor any Money borrowed for the Purpose of making the m.

Ordered, That the said Report do lie upon the Table.

Ordered, That, in consideration of the particular Circumstances mentioned in the said Report, Leave be granted, that Notices may be given, at the ensuing Easter Quarter Sessions to be held for the Counties of Surrey and Kent, and by Advertisements in the public Newspapers, published or circulated within the said Counties, before the 20th Day of April next, of the Application to Parliament for enlarging the Term, and for explaining, amending, and making more effectual, the Powers of Two several Acts, passed in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making a new Road from New Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the said Road in Repair for the future, and for making and repairing several other Roads adjoining thereto, in such and the like Manner as are required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of 1774,

of Applications intended to be made relative to Turnpike Bills.

A Petition of William Forbes, of CaUendar, Esquire, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Stirling, and for repairing the Road from Loanhead to Saint in the said County of Stirling; and Setting forth, That the Interest of the Petitioner will be materially affected and injured by several Parts of the said Bill, if passed into a Law, it being thereby proposed to grant Powers

Vo*.. 45.

to the Trustees of the Turnpike Roads, their Officers and Collectors, to take Gravel and Materials for the Roads, and to estimate Damages in an arbitrary Manner, the proper and reasonable Exemption of Tolls not being provided for, extraordinary Powers for the Suppression of Roads, and erecting Toll Bars, exclusive and final Jurisdiction given to me Trustees in their Character of Justices of Peace, and the Bill being in several other Respects injurious to the Petitioner: And therefore praying the House, That he may be heard, by himself or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect him, and to give him such Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioner be heard by himself or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon his Petition, if he thinks fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in favour of the said BUI, against the said Petition.

Mr. Frederick Montagu presented to the House, ac- Mr-Speakert cording to Order, a Bill for the better Support of the Allowance Dignity of the Speaker of the House of Commons, and for disabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, from holding any Office or Place of Profit, during Pleasure under the Crown: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the said Bill be read a Second Lime Tomorrow Morning.

The Marquis of Graham presented to the House, Repreenta-pursuant to their Address to His Majesty, h°"

A Copy of the Representation of the Lords of the Committee of Council, appointed for the Consideration respecting of all Matters relating to Trade and Foreign Planta- the Cora tions, upon the present State of the Laws for regulating Laws, pre-the Exportation and Importation of Corn; and submitting to His Majesty’s Consideration some further Provisions which are wanting to amend and improve the said Laws.

And the Title of the said Representation was read.

Ordered, That the said Representation do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Representation be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The said Representation is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Mr. Minchin, according to Order, reported from the Report n. Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re- spec ting ferred to consider of proper Bounties to be allowed, Bounties to in certain Cases, to Masters and Surgeons of Ships employed in the Conveyance of Slaves from the Coast slave Ship*, of Africa, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee;

That a Bounty of One hundred Pounds be allowed to each Master, and Fifty Pounds to each Surgeon, of every Ship employed in conveying Slaves from the Coast of Africa, upon Proof being made that not more than Two Slaves, in each Hundred that shall have been taken on Board such Ships, have died; and of Fifty Pounds to each Master, and Twenty-five Pounds to each Surgeon, where not more than Three 4 K . Slaves

310 18° Marl'd. A. 1790.

Slaves ih each Hundred have died, within a certain Period.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who are appointed to prepare, and bring in, a Bill to continue and amend an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act to continue for a limited " Time, and amend, an Act made in the last Session " of Parliament, intituled, An Act to regulate, for a " limited Time, the shipping and carrying Slaves in " British Vessels from the Coast of ," That they do make Provision in the said Bill, pursuant to the said Resolution.

Committee Ordered, That the Order of the Day for the House on American to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, Trade Bill. Upon the Bill to continue the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him x to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered\That the Report be received Tomorrow

Morning.

Strcatham Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for resuming

Workhouse the adjourned Consideration of the Report which was mittedC0, D* ma^e ^roni *he Committee, to whom the Bill for e ' providing a Workhouse for, and for the better Relief and Employment of, the Poor of the Parish of ham, in the County of Surrey, and for appointing an additional Overseer for the better Government of the Poor of the said Parish, was committed, be now read.

And the said Order was read accordingly.

And the House being informed that several other Amendments are necessary to be made to the said Bill;

Resolved, That the said Bill be re-committed.

Resolved, That the said Bill be re-committed to the Committee to whom the same was committed.

East India Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Ac-Accounts count of the Prime Cost of such Goods from India and ordered. China as have been exposed to Sale at the East India Company’s Annual Sales, from the 1st of March 1786 to the 1st of March 1790; distinguishing Quantity and Quality in the Total or Abstract.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House an Account of the East India Company’s Sales of Goods from India and China, from the 1st of March 1789 to the 1st of March 1790; distinguishing Quality and Quantity in Abstract.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of Quick Stock at the Presidencies of Fort William, Fort Saint George, and Bombay, shewing Debts and Assets on the 30th of April 1786.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Quick Stock, shewing Debts and Assets for China and Bencoolen, for Four Years; viz. for the 30th of April 1786, 1787, 1788, and 1789.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to Slave Trade resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to deferred, consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade;

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Seven-night, resolve itself into the said. Committee.

An ingrossed Bill for defraying the Charge of the Pay Mjj*1'* PaY and Cloathing of the Militia in that Part of Great Bu passed‘ Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for defraying the Charge of the Pay and Cloathing of the Militia in that Part of Great Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Indemnity Committee *f the whole House, to whom the Bill to reported, indemnify such Persons as have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others, who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according to Law, or having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for that Purpose, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Duncombe reported from the Committee, to Hallamihire whom the Petition of several of the Freemen of the Cutler* Corporation of Cutlers, in the Lordship and Liberty Petit‘f" of Hallamshire, in the West Riding of the County of rep0

York, established by an Act of the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the First, was referred;

That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act, passed in the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the First, intituled, *An Act for incorporating the Makers of Knives, and other Cutlery " Wares, in Hallamshire, in the County of York," was read: And,

Mr. Arthur Jewitt being examined, said, That the Officers of the Corporation have neglected the Rules

established

established by the said Act, after many repeated Applications to them, for redressing Grievances, which they have neglected to attend to; and that Petitions have also been presented" to them, stating the Injury to the Trade by employing various Persons, and using various Marks, not allowed by the Act

And being asked, What is the Use of marking Cutlery Wares? He said, It is to prevent Imposition, and that each Person shall be regulated by his own Work; that there is a Penalty of 40 for neglecting to mark their Wares with One regular Mark, each Person having a Mark of their own.

And being asked, Whether it would not be of great Utility if a Court was established within the Corporation for the Trial of all Offences committed respecting the Cutlery Business, before the Master Cutlers, and a Jury of Twelve Freemen, to be indifferently named ? He said, It would; for that at present they are obliged to have those Trials in the Court of King’s Bench, at a great Expence; and the Offence being only 40 s. the Attempt to recover it is not worth while.

And he added, That no greater Number of Apprentices ought to be allowed than are mentioned in the said Act.

Mr. Samuel Linley confirmed the above Evidence.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the First, intituled, "An Act for the good Order and Government " of the Makers of Knives, Sickles, Sheers, Scissors, " and other Cutlery Wares, in , in the County of York, and the Parts near adjoiningAnd that Mr. Duncombe and Mr. Wilberforce do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Committee The House resolved itself into a Committee of the on Petitions -whole House, to consider further of the several Peti-

TobaccoVct t* *ons have been presented to this House in this

’ Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir Watkin Lewes took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir JVatkin Lewes reported from the Committee, That they had examined several other Witnesses; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning," resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Petitions.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Mr. Lygon reported from the Committee, to whom Stourportand the Petition of the Company of Proprietors of the Worcester Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation was pe*JtHmn£ referred; That the Committee had examined, and ported, found that the Standing Orders of the House, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for making and maintaining a Navigable Cut or Canal from the River Severn,

" between Bewdley and Tilton Brook, in the County " of Worcester, to cross the River , at or near " Heywood Mill, in the County of Stafford, and to communicate with a Canal intended to be made " between the said River Trent and the River Mersey" was read: And,

Mr. Joseph Hodskinson, an Engineer, being examined, said, That the Navigation of the River Severn has never, in any Respect, been improved, and remains in its natural State, and is in many Places affected by Schoals, and Beds of Rock Sand, or Gravel, which in dry Seasons impede the Navivation: Then,

Mr. Samuel Danks being examined, said, That the aforesaid Company of Proprietors, with a View to improve the said Navigation, lately began to remove some Part of the said Shoals, between the Termination of the Stourport Canal and Digits, near Worcester, a Distance ot about Thirteen Miles, and therein expended a considerable Sum of Money, but were prevented from effecting their Design for want of Parliamentary Powers — And the Witness added, That the Removal of the said Obstructions would increase the general Advantages of the Canal of the said Company, and greatly tend to the public Benefit; and they are desirous, at their own Expence, and without charging the Public with any Toll or Duty whatever, to effect the Purposes aforesaid.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation to scour, cleanse, and deepen, the Bed or Channel of the River Severn, from Stourport, in the County of Worcester, to a Place called Diglis, near the City of Worcester: And that Mr. Lygon and Mr. Foley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. and

Mr. Leeds:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing the Term of so much of an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, as relates to the rendering the Payment of Creditors more equal and expeditious in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for better supplying the City of Norwich, and the Parts adjacent, with Water; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign ,of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from the Leicester and We ford Turnpike Road, in the Counties

of Leicester and Northampton, near Foston Lane, to the Turnpike Road leading from Hinckley to Ashby de la Zouch, in the said County of Leicester, and for repairing and widening Two Pieces of Road called Hunt's Lane and Wood Lane, in the Parishes of Desford and Newbold Verdon; without any Amendment.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Mr. Goddard reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for enlarging the Terms, and altering the Powers, of Two Acts, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, and in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Kennett, to Sheppard's Shord, and from the Hare and Hounds in Beckhampton to the Top of Cherrill Hill, and from the Town of Avebury to the Cross Way at Beckhampton, and from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wroughton, and from the North Side of Swindon to The Carpenters Arms in B, in the County of Wilts, and for diverting, turning, and altering Part of the said Roads, and for repairing and widening the Road on the West Side of The Three Barrows, from the Direction Post there on the new Road leading from Beckhampton to Devizes, to the Distance of One Mile from the said Direction Post Westward, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; (and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the Hoqse; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were, with several Amendments to One of them, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Sir John Wodehouse reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunder written, in Behalf of themselves, and of the Merchants, Traders, find others, concerned in the Navigation in the several Counties of,

Vol. 45.

Suffolk, Cambridge, Huntingdon, Bedford, and ton; and also, the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunder written, being Owners of Lands charged with, or chargeable to, the Repairs of the Banks or Sea Walls of the River Ouze, on the East Side of the said River, between a certain Bridge in the Parish of Denver, in the County of Norfolk, called Denver Sluice, and the Port of King's Lynn, in the said County, and on the West Side of the said River, from Salter's Load Sluice, in the Parish of Denver aforesaid, to a Place in the Parish of Tilney All Saints, in the said County, called Gool, on Be-

half of themselv'es and others, Land Owners charged and chargeable with the Repairs of the said Banks, and also of the several Merchants and Traders, whose Names are also thereunder written, on Behalf of themselves and others, navigating and using the said River, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the said Second-mentioned Petition does not come within the Standing Orders of the House relative to Navigation Bills, the Application being only for a Bill to regulate the Manner of haling with Horses on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and to make Compensation to the Bank Owners for the Damages they may thereby sustain, and that nil the Bank Owners affected by the Bill are willing and desirous that the same should pass; and that no Person appeared before the Committee in Support of the First-mentioned Petition; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Second-mentioned Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Second-mentioned Petition, Mr. Bartholomew Ramsey being examined, said. That the Banks or Sea Walls in the Petition mentioned are absolutely necessary to be kept in good Repair to preserve many Thousand Acres of valuable Land against Inundations of the said River from Tides and Floods; and also for confining the Waters of the said River to preserve a Channel for navigating Boats, Barges, Lighters, and Vessels therein — That the Banks are maintained at a great Expence to the Land Owners chargeable therewith, who are liable to heavy Fines, under the Powers of the Court of Sewers for the said County, for any Neglect in the Repairs thereof — That great Controversies and Disputes have frequently arisen between the said Land Owners and the Owners of Boats, Barges, Lighters, and Vessels, on account of haling or towing the same with Horses, or Beasts of Burthen, on the Banks of the said River — That it would greatly facilitate the Purposes of Navigation, if Leave was granted to hale Boats, Barges, Lighters, and other Vessels, with Horses, or Beasts of Burthen, on the said Banks, under certain Regulations and Restrictions, making proper Satisfaction to the said Land Owners; and the same would prevent further Suits and Controversies between the said Land Owners and Persons navigating the said River.

The House was moved, That the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th Day of 1774, and the 15 th Day of July in the last Session of Parliament, relative to Navigation Bills, might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for empowering Persons navigating Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, in the River Ouze, in the County of Norfolk, to hale or tow with Horses, or other Beasts, on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and for making Satisfaction to the Owners of the said Banks or Sea Walls; And that Sir John Wodehouse and Sir Edward Astley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

An ingrossed Bill for the better Relief and Employment of the Poor within the Hundreds of Colneis and Car ford, in the County of Suffolk, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for the better Relief and Employment of the Poor within the Hundreds of Colneis and in the County of Suffolk.

A Petition of the Freeholders of the County of Middlesex, convened by Public Advertisement by the Sheriff, to take into Consideration an Act of Parliament, which passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in " lieu thereof," was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are well apprized that the Sinews of Government must relax without the necessary Supplies, and, although they are at all Times willing and happy to contribute their Share to the Wants of the Nation, yet they cannot behold, but with the deepest Concern, a dangerous Extension of the Laws of Excise, by which considerable and respectable Bodies of their Fellow Subjects are deprived of their inherent and Constitutional Right of Trial by Jury, for a possible Increase of Revenue: And therefore praying the House, That the said Act may be repealed, or to grant them such other Relief as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco, and Snuff, and for " granting new Duties in lieu, thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Bromsgrove C*P^ Inhabitants of the City of Bath, was presented and Binning- to the House, and read; Setting forth, That a Peti-baiu Road tion has been presented to the House for Leave to BlU- bring in a Bill, for improving the Turnpike Road

leading from the Town of Birmingham, in -

shire, to Bromsgrove, in Worcestershire-, and that the said Road is, in many Parts, in a ruinous Condition, and so narrow that Two Carriages cannot pass each other without imminent Danger, and various Accidents have happened to Carriages passing along the same; and that the Hills on the said Road require, in many Parts thereof, to be avoided, in 8rder to make the Road more easy of Ascent, which would be much more convenient, safe, and commodious for Carriages, and the Public: And therefore praying, That the House will take the Matter into Consideration, and grand: the Petitioners such Relief in the Premises as the Nature of the Case may require.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

against the Tobacco Act.

Ways and Means deferred.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Cocoa Nuts The Order of the Day being read, for the House Bill deferred. tQ resoive itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for charging a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Plantations;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

The Order of the Day being read, for receiving American the Report from the Committee of the whole House, Jr.ade Ml to whom the Bill to continue the Laws now in Force de erre for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States, was conftnitted;

Ordered, That the said Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the Committee whole House, to consider further of the several Peti- on Petitions tions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for " granting new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir Watkin Lewes took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir Watkin Lewes reported from the Committee,

That they had examined several other Witnesses, and that the Agent for the Petitioners had closed his Evidence in Support of the said Petitions; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tuesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the wrhole House, to consider further of the said Petitions.

Ordered, That Mr. Jeremiah Searle do attend the said Committee upon Tuesday Morning next.

Ordered, That Mr. John Ripley do attend the said Committee at the same Time.

Ordered, That Mr. John Harding do attend the said Committee at the same Time.

Oi-dered, That Mr. Thomas Stevens do attend the said Committee at the same Time.

Ordered, That Mr. William Wilcox do attend the said Committee at the same Time.

Ordered, That Mr. John Pitt do attend the said Committee at the same Time.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock,

Luna, 22* die Martii; Anno 30° Georgii III*" Regis, 1790.

House ad- 1 ''HE House being met, the Clerk at the Table joums on ae- X acquainted the House that he had received a Deat^o/a* Letter from Mr. Speaker, who was in the Country,

near Relation desiring him to inform the House of the Death of a of the very near Relation, and therefore Mr. Speaker hoped Speaker. the House would dispense with his Attendance upon hia Duty for a Day or Two; and, if it would be attended with no Inconvenience to the Public Business, that the House would adjourn for a short Time.

Whereupon it was moved, That the House would adjourn till Wednesday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

And thereupon the Clerk (to whom those who spoke addressed themselves, according to former Practice in the Absence of the Speaker) by Direction of the House, put the Question for adjourning the House till Wednesday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

An ingrossed Bill for repairing and widening the RowdeJFord Road from Rowde Ford to Red Hill, and from Chittoe

Heath to the Town of Caine, in the county of ; Bill passed, and for repealing Three Acts, made in the Second and Twenty-fifth Years of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and in the Twenty-third Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Highways between Sheppard's Shord and Horsley Upright Gate, leading down Bagdown Hill, in the County of Wilts, and other ruinous Parts of the Highways thereunto adjacent, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for repairing and widening the Road from Rowde Ford to Red Hill, and from Chittoe Heath to the Town of Caine, in the County erf Wilts; and for repealing Three Acts, made in the Second and Twenty-fifth Years of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and in the Twenty-third Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Highways between Sheppard's Shord and Horsley Upright Gate, leading down Bagdown Hill, in the County of Wilts, and other ruinous Parts of the Highways thereunto adjacent.

Ordered, That Mr. Joshua Smith do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

And the House was accordingly adjourned till Wednesday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

Petition for Mr. M'Domtt reported from the Committee, to Provision in whom the Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, bce*$il7 P°" ^habitants of the City of Glasgoto, was referred; reported’. That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to repoit the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, a Member present informed your Committee, That the Tollbooth, or Common Gaol, of the said City is too small and incommodious, and that it will be necessary to purchase Houses and Areas in order to enlarge the same.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who are- appointed to prepare, and bring in, a Bill for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgow oyer certain adjoining Lands, for paving, lighting, and cleansing the Streets, and for regulating the Police of the said City, and for giving certain Power to the Magistrates of Glasgow for the Benefit of the said City, That they do make Provision in the said Bill for enlarging the TollbootK or Common Gaol, of the said City, and for purchasing Houses and Areas for that Purpose.

An ingrossed Bill for enlarging the Terms, and Marlborough altering the Powers, of Two Acts, made in the Six- 1

teenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, and in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Kennett, to Sheppard's Shord, and from The Hare and Hounds in Beckhamptom to the Top of Cherrill Hill, and from the Town of Avebury to the Cross Way at Beckhampton, and from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wroughton, and from the North . Side of Swindon to The Carpenter's Arms in Blunsden, in the County of Wilts, and for diverting, turning, and altering Part of the said Roads; and for repairing and widening the Road on the West Side of The Three Barrows, from the Direction Post there, on the new Road leading from Beckhampton to Devizes, to the Distance of One Mile from the said Direction Post Westward, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for enlarging the Terms, and altering the Powers, of Two Acts, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, and in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Kennett, to Sheppard's Shord, and from The Hare and Hounds in Beckhampton to the Top of Cherrill Hill, and from the Town of Avebury to the Cross Way at Beckhampton, and from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wroughton, and from the North Side of Swindon to Carpenters Arms in Blunsden, in the County of Wilts; and for diverting, turning, and altering Part of the said Roads, and for repairing and widening the Road on the West Side of the The Three Barrows, from the Direction Post there, on the new Road leading from Beckhampton to Devizes, to the Distance of One Mile from the said Direction Post Westward.

Ordered, That Mr. Goddard do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Goddard reported from the Committee, to Deverill in-whom the Bill for dividing and allotting the Open closure Bill and Commonable Lands within the Manor of rePorted-

Longbridge, Hussey Deverill, and Monkton Deverill, in the County of Wilts, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the

Bill,

30 Geo. III. 24° Martii.

3 IT

Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Owners of Lands of the Annual Value of 6i/. who had been wrote to, but returned no Answer; and that the whole Property in the Lands to be divided and allotted is of the Annual Value of 1,989/.; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be

ingrossed.

Petition re- A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and princi-lating to pal Inhabitants of the Borough of and in

and Bir-0*6 Neighbourhood thereof, was presented to the mingham House, and read; Setting forth, That Application Road Bill. has been made to the House for Powers to improve the Turnpike Road leading from Birmingham to Bromsgrove, which is now so narrow, hilly, and inconvenient for Carriages, that it is become extremely dangerous; and that, in order to make the said Road commodious, and of a proper hanging Level, it is conceived that the Course thereof, about the Middle Way between Birmingham and Bromsgrove, should be varied, and taken more in a straight Line, whereby several hollow Ways and Hills will be avoided, and the Road rendered safe for Passengers, several Accidents having happened to Persons and Carriages passing along the said Road, by Reason of such hollow Ways and narrow Parts being suffered to continue: And therefore praying the House to grant such Relief in the Premises as to them shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Cromford Mr. Mundy reported from the Committee, to whom Canal Bill the Bill to alter and amend an Act, passed in the last reported. gession Qf Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Cromford Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the . Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout* and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Duncombe reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for continuing the Term, and altering Keiehlev and enlarging the Powers, of certain Acts, made for Road Bill repairing the Road from Keighley, in the West Riding reP°rted-of the County of York, to Kirkby in Kendal, in the County of Westmorland, so far as relates to such Part of the said Road as lies within the County of York, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were, with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

A Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, to restrain taking more than One Third of the Tolls at One Toll Gate.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Petition against Bradford Waterworks Bill.

318 24° Martii. A. 1790.

A Petition of Henry Smithson, John Blayds, Samuel

Buck, Richard Cotton, John Beckett, James Kenion, William Cookson, Thomas Wade, William Smithson,

Benjamin Wade, John Dixon, John Calverley, Nicholas Smith, John Entzvisle, Joseph Fountains, and George Beaumont, Esquires, on Behalf of themselves, and of Sir

James Ibbetson, Baronet, John Edmund

Lodge, John Denison, Thomas Lloyd, Henry Scott, and John Pate Nevile, Esquires (who are absent, or resident

at a Distance from Leeds), Patrons of the Vicarage and Parish Church of Leeds, in the County of York, and of Peter Haddon, Clerk, Vicar of the said Vicarage and Parish Church, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that a Petition hath been presented from John Smyth, of Holbeck, in the said Parish of Leeds, for Leave to bring in a Bill for the purpose of having consecrated, and of vesting in him arid his Heirs for ever, the Right of Nomination or Presentation to a Chapel lately built in the Township of , in

the said Parish of Leeds, which Application is made by the said John Smyth without the Consent or Concurrence of the Petitioners, or any of them; and, that the Nomination or Presentation to all Chapels of Ease erected within the said Parish, and duly consecrated, doth, of common Right, belong to the Vicar of the Vicarage of Leeds for the Time being, and in case the said Bill should pass into a Law, the Petitioner, the said Peter Haddon, and his Successors, Vicars of the said Vicarage, will be deprived of the Right of such Nomination, and be otherwise materially injured and effected thereby, and the Right of the other Petitioners, the Patrons of the said Vicarage, will also be greatly injured: And therefore praying, That Leave may not be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, or that, if such Bill be brought in, the same may not pass into a Law; and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill’s passing into a Law, in such Manner, and at such Time, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until a Bill be brought in pursuant to the Prayer of the Petition of John Smyth, Esquire, Lord of the Manor of Wortley, in the Parish of Leeds, in the West Riding of the County of York.

A Bill for forming a Junction between the Forth and Clyde Navigation and the Monkland Navigation, and for altering, enlarging, and explaining, several former Acts passed for making and maintaining the said Navigations, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir Thomas Dundas, Sir Archibald Edmonstone, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Sir John Wodehouse presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for impowering Persons navigating Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, in the River Ouset in the County of Norfolk, to hale or tow with Horses, or other Beasts, on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and for malting Satisfaction to the Owners of the said Banks or Sea Walls: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open Common Fields, Pastures, and other Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Harby, in the County of Leicester,was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Hungerford, Mr. Sutton, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber.

A Petition of several Gentlemen, Freeholders, Merchants, Tradesmen, and other Inhabitants, of Brad-v.

ford, in the West Riding of the County of York, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That several Gentlemen in the Town and Neighbourhood of Bradford, about Forty-five Years ago, for the Benefit of the Inhabitants of the said Town, borrowed a Sum of Money for conveying Water to the said Town from a Coal Drain in Horton, and such Gentlemen being all dead, their Shares have been sold to several Persons, who, the Petitioners apprehend, now wish to make great Advantage to themselves of the Waterworks; and that Part of the Inhabitants of the said Town have, for several Years last, been very badly supplied with Water, and, in order that all the Inhabitants may have equal Benefit, the Petitioners apprehend that several Improvements are necessary to be made in the Works, and that the same ought to be under the Direction of Commissioners, and the Execution of the Act vested in them, with Power to borrow Money for making Improvements, and completing the Works, so as to serve all the Inhabitants, and paying off, to such of the old Proprietors as are dissatisfied with their Security, their Principal Money, and that the Inhabitants ought not to be restrained from bringing other Water to the said Town, and laying Pipes in the Town for such Water, nor should any Person be obliged to pay for the present Water, who does not agree for it; and that the Proprietors give out, that they will apply to Parliament, this present Sessions, for an Act to authorize them to take any Sum, not exceeding 4/. per Annum, for the Water to any Public House, and 1/. i6r. for the Water to any private House, and, if such Act was to pass, the Petitioners apprehend that such Sums would be very oppressive on the Inhabitants of the said Town, instead of being beneficial, according to the original Institution; and that the former Owners of Land in Horton, through which the Water passes to the Town of Bradford (as it was for the Benefit of the Town) permitted the Gentlemen to convey the Water through their Grounds, and the present Waterworks ought to be a Security to the Proprietors for their principal Money and Interest, but such Proprietors ought to be restrained from advancing the Water Rents any higher than will allow 7/. per Centum Interest for their Money, such Rents to be settled by Commissioners fairly and equally upon such Inhabitants as chuse to take it: And therefore praying. That the Execution of the Act may be vested in Commissioners, and such Powers to them given for borrowing Money for the Purposes above, and completing the Works, as to the House shall seem meet, and that the Petitioners may be heard by Counsel, against the present Bill, and may be allowed to examine Witnesses thereupon at the Bar of the House.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Bill for improving and preserving the Works made for supplying the Town of Bradford, in the County of York, and Part of the Township of Horton, in the Parish of Bradford aforesaid, with Water, and for the more easy Recovery of the Rents for the said Water, is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by their Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Petition A Petition of James Holmes and William

Gtrkenwell Proprietors of certain Premises in the Parish of Saint Church Bill. James at Clerkenwell,in the County of , was

presented to' the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for amending and enlarging the Powers of, and rendering more effectual, an Act made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for pulling down the " Church of Saint James at , in the County of Middlesex, and for building a new Church, and " making a new Church Yard or Cemetery, in the " said Parish, with convenient Avenues and Passages " thereto;" and Setting forth, That the said Bill contains divers Powers and Regulations, which, if carried into execution, will be highly injurious to the Interest of the Petitioners: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as affect them, and that the same may not pass as it now stands.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

A PETITION of the several Persons whose Petition Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of against themselves, and others, Master Weavers, within the S\"'’e‘'try City and County of the City of Coventry, and County 3^ eaven of Warwick, was presented to the House, and read;

Taking Notice of the Bill to extend the Provisions of an Act, made in the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty, relating to Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in the Cities of London and Westminster, and County of Middlesex, and Liberty of the Tower of London, to Persons employed in the Silk Manufacture in the City and County of the City of Coventry, and County of Warwick; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners apprehend such Extension of the Provi-.sions of the said Act to be totally unnecessary, and that the same will be attended with Consequences very prejudicial, not only to the Petitioners, and all other Master Weavers within the Limits aforesaid, but to the Silk Manufacture in general: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves and Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Honiton Paving, &c. Petitions reported.

Mr. Secretary at War reported from the Committeej to whom the Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, and principal Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, on Behalf of themselves and others; and also, the Petition of several Inhabitants of the Town and Borough of Honiton, in the County of Devon, were severally referred; That the Committee had examined the Matters of the said Petitions, and had directed him to report the same, as they appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the First-mentioned Petition, Mr. Henry Manstone Teed being examined, said, That the Great Western Road from London, and from Portsmouth to Exeter and Plymouth, and to Falmouth, and other Parts of is through the

Town of Honiton, and there are now standing in the Middle of the High Street of the said Town a large old Building, called The Shambles, and certain Dwelling Houses contiguous thereto — That the Entrance into and Passage through the said Town is very inconvenient, and the Streets thereof are badly paved, and not properly cleansed and lighted, and there are many Nuisances and Encroachments in the Streets, by which the Inhabitants ane greatly incommoded, and the Passage through the Town is greatly obstructed, and rendered dangerous to Travellers.

To prove the Allegations of the Second-mentioned Petition, Mr. Henry Manstone Teed being examined, said, That several public Roads lying within or leading tQ the said Town are part of Turnpike Trusts, which might be more conveniently widened, paved, and improved, if the same were put under the Management of the Commissioners to be appointed for paving and improving the said Town — That if a Nightly Watch was established therein, and Persons were to be restrained from covering their Houses with Thatch, it would greatly tend to the Safety and Protection of the Inhabitants of the said Town.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill, for rendering the Passage through the Town and Parish of Honiton, in the County of Devon, safe and commodious, and for paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the Streets, and other Places, and for removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein: And that Mr. Secretary at War and Air. Rolle, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Money’9 The Lord Arden reported from the Committee, to

Ported and w^om the ingrossed Bill from the Lords, intituled, An passed* -Act for vesting Part of the Freehold Estates, devised by the Will of James Money, Esquire, deceased, in Trustees, to be sold, and for laying out the Money arising thereby in the Purchase of other Hereditaments, to be settled to the same Uses as the Estates to be sold now stand limited to, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee; and that the Committee had directed him to report the Bill to the House, without any Amendment: And he delivered the Bill in at the Clerk’s Table.

And the said Bill was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass.

Ordered, That the Lord Arden do carry the Bill to the Lords; and acquaint them, that this House hath agreed to the same, without any Amendment.

Abingdon Mr. Loveden reported from the Committee, to whom Road Petition the Petition of the several Persons whose* Names are

reported. yOL 43.

thereunto subscribed, being Trustees for executing an Act, passed in the Eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from the Mayors Stone, iu Abingdon, in the County of Berks, through Cumto the ancient Horse Road at Swinford,in the said County, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with (except that the Notice required to be given at the Michaelmas Quarter Sessions was not given till the Christmas Quarter Sessions, on Account of the Illness of a near Relation of the Solicitor of the Bill, who, from the Apprehension of his Son’s Death, neglected to give the Notice at the proper Time); and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Thomas Curtis being examined, said, That for the Purpose of repairing the said Road, a considerable Sum of Money was borrowed upon the Credit of the Tolls; and that the Sum of 1,562/. 10$. now remains due, together with a large Arrear of Interest; which Debt and Interest cannot be paid off, nor the Road effectually amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be continued, and some further. Powers granted. — And the Witness added,

That it will be necessary to have an Increase of Toll.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in -the Eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from the Mayor's Slone, in Abingdon, in the County of Berks, through Cumner, to the ancient Horse Road at Swinford, in the said County: And that Mr.

Loveden, Mr. Pye, and Mr. Vansittart, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for more effectually embanking the Marsh called Malldraeth and Corsddaugau, in the County of Anglesey, and draining and preserving the same, and the inclosed low Lands contiguous thereto.

Ordered, That Sir Roger Mostyn do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

House, of the 25th of April 1774 relative to Turnpike Bills had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Mr. Theophilus Smith being examined, said, That

there is a Debt of 1,279/. due upon the said First-mentioned District of Road: And,

Admiral Leveson reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Common and Waste Grounds within the Manor of tarn, in the Parish of JVarcop, in the County of Westmorland, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of A 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and -that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietors whose Estates are assessed to the Land Tax at 21. 125. per Annum, or thereabouts; and that the whole Property of Persons having Right of Common upon the Lands intended to be inclosed, is assessed to the.Land Tax at 23/. 15. 2 or there-

abouts; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in

at the Clerks Table; Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, w>ere agreed to by the House.

A Message from the Lords by Mr. Montagu and The Lords Mr. Pepys: have agreed

Mr. Speaker, to

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Militia Pay Act for defraying the Charge of the Pay and Cloath- Blll> ing of the Militia in that Part of Great Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; without any Amendment: And also.

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Stamp Cross Act for enlarging the Term of several Acts, made for Bill, repairing the Roads from Stump to Newmarket

Heath, and from Stump Cross aforesaid to the End of the Town of TrumpingUm,next to Shelford, and from

(lately called Thomas Samwell Watson) and his Heirs Male, to take the Surname, and use the Arms, of Samwell, pursuant to the Will of Sir Thomas,

And also,

Gate, in the County of the City of Nortoich, to the Windmill in the Town of Walton, in the County of Norfolk; with some Amendments; to which Amendments the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

An ingrossed Bill to alter and amend an Act, passed Cromford in the last Session of Parliament, for making and Canal Bill maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near passeri‘ to, Cromford Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County, was read the Third Time.

Pr. 19. 1. 15. After " hereby" to insert " required."

Sir Richard Hill reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Trustees for carrying into Execution an Act, made in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repairing and widening the Road from the " End of the Turnpike Road in Shawbury, in the " County of Salop, to Drayton in Hales, in the said " County, and from thence to Newcastle under Line, " in the County of Stafford, and from aforesaid to the Turnpike Road in High Ercall, in the " said County of Salop, and from Shawbury aforesaid " to Went, in the said County, and from thence to the " Turnpike Road in Sandford, in the said County," was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the'Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Thomas Pemberton, Junior, being examined, said, That the Sum of 2,000 Lis now owing on the Credit of the Tolls within the First District comprised in the said Act, which cannot be repaid, and the Roads effectually repaired, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act are continued and enlarged.

Mr. Thomas Sparrow being examined, said, That the Sum of 1,550/. is due on the Credit of the Tolls of the Second District — That the said Act is near expiring, and the Money borrowed cannot be repaid, and the Roads amended and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Act is continued, and the Powers enlarged.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from the End of the Turnpike Road in Shawbury, in the County of Salop, to Drayton in Hales, in the said County, and from thence to Newcastle under Line, in the County of Stafford, and from Shawbury aforesaid to the Turnpike Road in High Ercall, in the said County of Salop, and from Shawbury aforesaid to Wzm, in the said County, and from thence to the Turnpike Road in Sandford, in the said County: And that Sir Richard Hill and Mr. Kynaston do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. Stephens reported from the Committee, to Ramsgate . tvhom the Petition of Richard Harvey, Clerk, Vicar 9hapel of the Church of Saint Lawrence, in the Isle of Thanet, ‘nrepor in the County of Kent, and of divers* Inhabitants of the Parish of Saint Lawrence aforesaid; was referred;

That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same* as it appeared to them, to the House; and ne read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table t Where the same was read; and is as followeth, viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr.

Jacob Sawkins being examined, said, That the Tow*ri or Vill of Ramsgate, within the Parish of Saint Lawrence, in the Isle of Thanet, is of late Years considerably increased, and likely to increase in Extent of Buildings and in Number of Inhabitants — That the Parish Church is a Mile distant from great Part of *

and is not found sufficient for the Accommodation of the Inhabitants of the said Parish, and that it would be a very great Convenience to the Inhabitants of Ramsgate to have a Place of Divine Worship within the said Town — That the Church of the said Parish of Saint Laurence is a Rectory Impropriate, within the Diocese of Canterbury, and the most Reverend* Father in God John Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, in Right of his See, is seised of the Rectory Impropriate of the said Church, and as Rector is entitled to collate to the Vicarage thereof — That the Archbishop upon the Application of the Vicar and Inhabitants of the said Town, hath approved of having a Chapel of Ease established within the said Town, for the Accommodation of the Inhabitants thereof — That John Fagg, Gentleman, being seised in Fee Simple of a certain Piece of Freehold Ground, situate within the said Town, hath lately consented to make a Donation thereof, and the present Vicar and several other Persons have, at their own Expence, caused to be built and erected on the said Piece of Ground a Building intended for a Place of Divine Worship, and to be a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the' said Parish. And the Witness added, That if the said Building was established as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the said Parish, the same would be a great Convenience to all Persons residing in, or resorting to, the said Town of Ramsgate, and of public Utility.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Laurence,in the Isle of Thanet, in the County of

Kent, as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the same Parish: And that Mr. Stephens and Mr. Brett do pre* pare, and bring in, the same.

Ordered, That Mr. Steele do make the Report from Report ‘Ways the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was re- and Mean*‘ ferred to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Mr. Steele accordingly reported from the said Committee, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed to be reported to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Exchequer That towards raising the Supply granted to His Rills. Majesty, the Sum of Three Millions Five Hundred thousand Pounds be raised by Loans or Exchequer Bills, to be charged upon the first Aids to be granted in the next Session of Parliament, and such Exchequer Bills, if not discharged, with Interest thereupon, on or before the 5th Day of April 1791, to be exchanged and received in Payment in such Manner as Exchequer Bills have usually been exchanged and received in Payment. a

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, j)».

That towards raising the Supply granted to His Majesty, the further Sum of Two Millions be raised by Loans or Exchequer Bills, to be charged upon the first Aids to be. granted in the next Session of Parliament, and such Exchequer Bills, if not discharged, with Interest thereupon, on or before the 5th Day of April 1791, to be exchanged and received in Payment in such Manner as Exchequer Bills have usually been exchanged and received in Payment.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill, or Bills, be brought in upon the said Resolutions: And that Mr. Steele, Mr. Chancellor

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, That they had heard Counsel and examined Witnesses for the said Bill, and that no Counsel or Party appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill; and that the Committee had directed him to report the Bill to the House, without any Amendment: And he delivered the Bill in at the Clerk’s Table.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir JVatkin Lewes took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

An ingrossed Bill to indemnify such Persons as Indemnity have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Bill passed. Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others, who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped, according to Law, or, having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants, and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and forgiving further Time for that Purpose, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to indemnify such Persons as have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others, who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according tq Law, or, having

Stoane presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill 'for paving, repairing, cleansing, lighting, watching, and watering Stoane Street, and certain other Streets and Places within the Parish of Saint Luke, Chelsea, in the County of Middlesex And the same was received; ami read the First Time.
