Mr. Tempest presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, within the City of Durham and Borough of Framwelgate, and the Suburbs thereof, for

removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, for widening and rendering- more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs: And the same was received and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Secretary at War presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for rendering the Passage through the Town and Parish of Honiton, in the County of Devon, safe and commodious, and for paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the Streets and other Places, and for removing and peventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir Herbert Mackworth reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Earl of Plymouth, and the humble- Petition of several Gentlemen and Freeholders of the County of Glamorgan, was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 2.5th of April, 1774, relative to Navigation Bills, had been complied with; but that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 20th of July 1789, requiring Notices to be given at the General Quarter Sessions, and also in the public Newspapers, had not been complied with, the Parties making this Application not having been apprized of the same; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and lie read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

You 45.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition Mr.

Thomas Dadford, a Surveyor and Engineer, being examined, said, That it is practicable to make a Na\i-gable Canal from Merthyr Tidvile, in the County of Glamorgan, to, or near to, the Town of Cardiff, in the said County: Then,

Mr. William Taitt being also examined, said, That the making and maintaining the said Canal will be of great Benefit to all Persons having Lands and Estates within the said County, as it will open Communications with very extensive Iron Works and Collieries, and will also be of public Utility.

Mr. Samuel Homfray confirmed the Evidence of the last mentioned Witness.

Ordered, That the said Report do lie- upon the Table.

Ordered, That, in Consideration of the particular Circumstances mentioned in the said Report, Leave be granted, that Notice may be given, at the ensuing Easter Quarter Session of the Peace to be holden for the County of Glamorgan, of the Application to Parliament for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from Merthyr Tidville to, or near to, the Town of

Cardiffm the said County, in such and the like Manner as is required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House, of the 20th of July 1789, of Applications intended to be made relative to Navigation Bills.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the Third Mr. Speaker's Reading of the Bill (now ingrossed) for the better Allowance Support of the Dignity of the Speaker of the House 1 paiSe of Commons, and for disabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, from holding any Office or Place of Profit, during Pleasure, under the Crown, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The said Bill was read the Third Time.

Resolved, Nemine Contradicente, That the Bill do pass:

And that the Title be, An Act for the better Support of the Dignity of the Speaker of the House of Commons, and for disabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, from holding any Office or Place of Profit, during Pleasure, under the Crown.

Ordered, That Mr. Frederick Montagu do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh reported Bromsgrove from the Committee, to whom the Bill to enlarge the Terms and Powers of Three several Acts, made in the BhTreposted. Thirteenth Year of the Reign of Kinj George the First, the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King George the Second, and the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Bromsgrove, in the County of Worcester, to the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the BiH, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

Add the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Account of Extraordinary Exigences of the Army, incurred and paid by the Right Honourable the Paymaster General of His Majesty’s Forces, from the 25th of December 1788 to the 24th of December 1789, both inclusive, and not provided for by Parliament, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Out Pensioners of Chelsea Hospital, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the In Pensioners of Chelsea Hospital, and of the Expences of the said Hospital, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of Pensions to be paid to the Widows of Commissioned Officers, for the Year 1790, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Estimate of the Charge of the Works and Repairs of the Military Roads and Bridges in North Britain, for the Year 1790, approved, by Lieutenant General Lord Adam Gordon, Commander ' of His Majesty’s Forces there, be referred to the said Committee.

Account respecting Relief to A merican and East Flo-ridaSufferersi

Ordered, That the Copy of the Treaty between His Majesty, and the Landgraveof Hesse Cassel, signed at Cassel, the 28th of September 1787; and Translation, which were presented to the House upon the 29th Day of November 1787, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Account, shewing the Amount of the Sums that will be necessary for the Payment of Interest, after the Rate of 3/. ios. per Centum per Annum for Six Months, of the Principal Sums remaining unpaid on the several Orders ndade out at the Receipt of the Exchequer pursuant to an Act of Parliament, of the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for giving " Relief to such Persons as have suffered in their " Rights and Properties, during the late unhappy " Dissentions in America, in consequence of their " Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the " British Government, and for making Compensation " to such Persons as have suffered in their Properties,

" in consequence of the Cession of the Province of " East Florida to the King of which will

become due on the 5th Day of April 1790, together with the Sum of 61. .5 s.per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order, and also for Six Months Interest, which will become due on the \ 01b. Day of October 1790, after the same Rate of 3/. 10$. per . Centum per Annum, on the Principal Sum then remaiming unpaid, together with 61. 5s. per Centum of the Principal Sum contained in each Order respectively, he referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to, report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning npxt, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

4 Q A Petition

26° — 29° Martil

A. 1790.

African

Company's

Petition.

A Petition of the Committee of the Cpanpany of Merchants trading to Africa, being offered to be presented to the House;

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, by His Majesty’s Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty, having been informed of the Contents of the said Petition, recommends it to the Consideration of the House.

Then the said Petition was brought up, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have laid before the House, an Account of the Money granted for the Year 177S, examined and passed by the Cursitor Baron of the Exchequer, as required by an Act of the Twenty-third of George the Second, intituled " An Act for extending and improving the Trade to " Africa," and that they have invested the Money,

granted in 1789, for the Support and Maintenance of the Forts and Settlements on the said Coast; and that the Forts, having been originally ill-constructed, and composed of the very worst Materials, were delivered to the Petitioners in a very ruinous Condition by the Royal African Company, and the Sums Annually granted by Parliament being nearly expended in the Maintenance and Pay of the several Garrisons, and in the necessary Contingent Charges thereof, leaving very little for the Purpose of Repairs, insomuch that most of them had fallen into Decay: And that the Petitioners, being sensible of the great Regard shewn by the House for the Preservation, Improvment, and Extension of the Trade to Africa, and for the Defence and Maintenance of the British Forts and Settlements on that Coast, therefore pray the House to take the Premises into Consideration, and grant such Sum as may be sufficient for the effectual support and Maintenance . of the said Forts, for such Presents as may be proper to secure the Friendship of the Natives of the Country, and likewise for the Repairs still wanted, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the

Table.

Committee Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House NutsIJiLL to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for charging a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Plantations, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they bad gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Monday Morning next.

Biggleswade The Lord Hinchingbrook reported from the Com-Koad^BUr to who the Bill to continue the Term, and reported. alter ant* enlarge the Powers, of an Act, of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Biggleswade, in the County of Bedford, through Bugden and Alconbury, to the Top of Alconbury and from Bugden to Huntingdon, and from Cross Hall to Great Stoughton Common, in the County of Huntingdon, and also the Road leading out of the aforesaid Road, at or near the Ferry House in the Parish of Tempsford, to and through Little Eyneshury,

and Saint Neot’s, to the Turnpike Road at the End of Cross Hall Lane, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second lime, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Report from Mr. Bramston reported from the Committee, who Committee were app0inted to consider of an Act, made in the last consider ° Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for better Com Act. " regulating and ascertaining the Importation and " Exportation of Corn and Grain; and also for better regulating the Exportation of Starch, and the " Importation of Rape Seed;" and to report their Opinion to the House in what Manner the Provisions of the said Act may be more effectually carried into Execution, and also, what Alterations and Amendments it may appear necessary to make in the Laws respecting the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain; bnd to whom the Copy of the Representation of the Lords of the Committee of Council appointed for the Consideration of all Matters relating to Trade and Foreign Plantations, upon the present State of the Laws for regulating the Exportation and Importation of Corn, and submitting to His Majesty’s Consideration some further Provisions which are wanting to amend and improve the said Laws, was referred; That the Committee had considered the said Act, and also the said Representation, and had come to several Resolutions; and that the Committee had agreed upon a Report, which they had directed him to make'to the House, together with the said Resolutions; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the same, together with an Appendix thereunto, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Your Committee concur with the Representation of the Lords of the Committee of Council, in the General Purport of the 1st, ad, 3d, 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, loth, and 11 th Propositions.

With respect to the 12th Proposition, Your Committee agree to the First Part thereof; viz. " That " Wheat be permitted to be exported, but without " Bounty, when the Price thereof is between 44s. and " 46*'. and all other Sorts of Com when the Price " thereof shall be in the like Proportion."

Your Committee agree also with the Representation, that the Clause in the Act of the 15th of Charles the Second, Chap. 7, which does not permit the buying Corn to sell again, and the laying it up in Gra naries, except when the several Sorts of Com are Vo l. 45.

below certain Prices therein mentioned, should be repealed.

Your Committee further agree with the Representation, That in order that the Corn Laws may be generally known and understood, the several Acts, or Parts of Acts, now subsisting relative to Corn, and which it shall be thought proper to continue, and such new Regulations as it shall be now thought fit to make; should be consolidated and formed into One Act of Parliament.

The several Propositions in the Represents tion of the Lords of the Committee of Council, before referred to, are hereunto annexed, in Appendix N* 1;

Your Committee, upon Consideration of the Whole! of the Matter referred to them, have codie to the following Resolutions;

Resolved,'1 lrat it is the Opinion of this Committee, That for the Purpose of ascertaining the Prices according to which Corn and Grain are by Law permitted to be imported and exported, and the Bounty paid, that Part of Great Britain called England bei divided into Districts, according to the Plan of an Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for better regulating and ascertaining the Iraporta tion and Exportation of Corn and Grain; and " also for better regulating the Exportation of Starch, " and the Importation of Rape Seed."

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That that Part of Great Britain called Scotland be also divided into Districts, for the like Purpose.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That whenever the Export of any Sort of Com is stopped in any One District, because the Price thereof is above the Export Price, Corn of the same Sort should not be allowed to be carried from thence! Coastwise to any other District, the Ports of which are open for the Importation thereof.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee; That the Act of the 10th of King George the Third; for Registering the Prices of Com, so far as relates to the Appointment of Inspectors, should be repealed J and that the Registry of Coro, published Weekly in The Gazette, should be- formed upon Averages taken, according to the Directions of the Act of the last Session of Parliament, from Returns made by Inspectors to be appointed in the several Districts and Inland Counties in Great Britain, in the Manner directed by" the last mentioned Act.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of One Half-penny per Last be paid on all British Corn imported Coastwise from the Ports of One District to the Ports of another District; and that a Duty of One Penny per Last be paid on all Corn imported from Foreign Countries into all the Ports of Great Britain', and that the Money arising from these Duties be made a Fund for the Payment of the Inspectors, and defraying the other Expences attending these Regulations.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Returns and Letters, sent to and from the Receiver of Com Returns to and from the several Inspectors, by the Post, be hot subject to the Payment of the Duties of Postage.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Inspectors be paid by a certain Allowance for each Return, certified to have been properly made, by the Receiver of Corn Returns.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That in case the Returns from any District shall not be completely made, the Importation and Exportation of every Sort of Corn, and the Payment of the Bounty, in that District, shall be governed by the Average Price of the rest of the Kingdom.

f *

Report on Corn Act,

29s

A. 1790.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That His Majesty be empowered, with the Advice of His Privy Council, when Parliament shall not be sitting, to prohibit generally, for a limited Time, the Exportation from this Kingdom of any Sort of Corn; and, in like Manner, to permit generally the Importation, on the Low Duties, of any Sort of Foreign Com, whenever the Average Price thereof, taken from the Returns of the whole. Kingdom, is higher than the Price at or above which Foreign Com is allowed by Law to be imported.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Collector of the Customs, at every Port in Great Britain, do transmit, Weekly, to the Receiver of Com Returns, an Account of the Quantities of the several Sorts of Com shipped in such Port to be carried Coastwise; and also, an Account of the Quantities of the several Sorts of Corn brought Coastwise into each respective Port; and that the said Receiver do transmit, to the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Customs in England, and Scotland, an Account of the Quantity of the several Sorts of Corn shipped, to be carried Coastwise from each Port, or brought Coastwise into each Port, respectively.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Expence of the Warehouses in which Foreign Com imported is to be lodged, under the joint Lock of the King and the Proprietor, and of the Officers of the Customs attending the same, be defrayed by the Public.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Foreign Com imported, and not warehoused, be not allowed again to be exported.

Resobed, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Com, so warehoused, be permitted to be taken out to be ground, by the Importer or Proprietor, under certain Conditions and Limitations.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That' it may be expedient to permit the Exportation of Wheat, but without the Allowance of Bounty, when the Price thereof is between and 46; and other

Corn, when the Prices thereof shall be in like Proportion.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the several Duties and Bounties, now payable upon the Importation and Exportation of Com, Grain, and Flour, be continued.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, in order to encourage the making of Bread and Biscuit within this Kingdom, it may be expedient that a Bounty be allowed upon the Exportation of Bread and Biscuit, in Proportion to the Bounty allowed on the Exportation of Wheat.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Bounty now allowed upon the Exportation of Flour, be equalized to the Bounty now allowed upon the Exportation of Wheat.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion-of this Committee, That the several Provisions, Rules, and Regulations, contained in any former Act or Acts of Parliament, which it shall be thought expedient to continue, for the regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, and Payment of the Bounty, together with the Regulations contained in the aforegoing Resolutions, and such others as it may be thought fit to enact, be consolidated into One Act of Parliament

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That it is expedient, that all other Provisions and Regulations, contained in any former Act or Acts of Paniament, for regulating tire Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain, and Payment of the Bounty, be repealed.

Appendix, N" 1.

EXTRACTS from the Representation of the Lords of the Committee of Council, appointed for the Consideration of all Matters relating to Trade and Foreign Plantations, upon the present State of the LaWs for regulating the Exportation and Importation of Com; and submitting to His Majesty’s Consideration some further Provisions, which are wanting to amend and improve the said Laws.

1st That England continue to be divided into Districts, according to the Plan of the Act of last Session; and that Scotland be divided into Districts in like Manner.

2d. That whenever the Export of any Sort of Corn is stopped in any one District, because the Price thereof is above the Export Price, Com of the same Sort should not be allowed to be carried from thence Coastwise to any other District, the Ports of which are -open for the Exportation thereof.

3d. That the Act of 10th III. Ch. 39, for

Registering the Prices of Corn, so far as relates to the Appointment of Inspectors, be repealed; and that the Registry of Corn, published Weekly in The Gazette*, be formed upon the Averages taken, according to the Prices returned by the Inspectors appointed under the Act of last Year."

4th. That a Duty of One Half-penny per Last be paid on all British Com imported Coastwise; and One Penny per Last on all Com imported from Foreign Countries into all the Ports of Great Britain, as is now paid in the Port of London; and that the Money arising from these Duties be made a Fund for the Payment , of the Inspectors, and defraying the other Expiences incurred by this Act; and that the Com Returns, sent by the Post, be not subject to the Payment of Postage.

5th. That the Inspectors be paid, -not by Salaries; as directed by the Act of last Year, but by a certain Allowance for each Return, certified to‘have been properly made by the Receiver of Cora Returns, according to the Act of the 10th Year of Your Majesty’s Reign, Ch. 39.

6th. That in case the Returns from any District shall not be completely made, according to the Directions of the Act, the Importation and Exportation? of every Sort of Corn in that District shall be governed by the Average Price of the rest,of the Kingdom.

7th. That a Power be lodged in Your Majesty, with the Advice of Your Privy Council, during the Prorogation of Parliament, to prohibit generally the Exportation from this Kingdom of any Sort of Corn, and, in like Manner, to permit generally the Importation on the Low Duties of any Sort of Foreign Corn, whenever the Average Price thereof, taken from the Returns of the whole Kingdom, is higher than the Price at or above which Foreign Corn is allowed by Law to-be imported, if Your Majesty, in Your Wisdom for the Public Benefit, shall so think fit.

8th. That the Collector of the Customs at every Port in Great Britain do transmit. Weekly, to the Receiver of Corn Returns an Account of the Quantity of the several Sorts of Corn shipped in such Port to be carried Coastwise; with the Name of the Ship or Vessel, the Name of the Master, and the Port or Place in Great Britain to which the Com was intended to, be carried; and also, an Account of the Quantities of the several Sorts of Com brought Coastwise into each respective Port, with the Name of the Ship or Vessel, the Name of the Master, and the Name of the Port or Place from whence it-is brought; and that the said Receiver do, at the End of every Three*

Months,

4

Months, transmit to the Commissioners of his Majesty’s Customs in England and Scotland an Account, to be formed and made up in such Manner as the said Commissioners shall approve, of the Quantity of the several Sorts of Corn shipped to be carried Coastwise from each Port, or brought Coastwise into each Port respectively.

9th. That the Warehouses in which Foreign Corn imported is to be lodged, under the joint Lock of the King and the Proprietor, according to the Statute of the 13th of Your Majesty’s Reign, Ch. 43, be provided at the Public Expence; and that the Officers of the Customs, whose Duty it is to attend those Warehouses, be paid by the Public, as is now practised with respect to the Warehousing of Tobacco.

10th. That Foreign Corn imported, and not warehoused, be not allowed again to be exported.

nth. That Com, so warehoused, be permitted to be taken out to be ground by the Importer or Proprietor, on Condition that he give Bond, not subject to any Stamp Duty, in double the Value of the said Corn, that he will export from the Port where it was warehoused, within Two Calendar Months from the Time of taking out the said Corn, a Quantity of . Flour equal to the Com so taken out, reckoning the Quantity of Wheat Meal, or other ground Com, for every Bushel of such Corn unground, according to the Proportion as it is now settled by Law; or that he will pay the Duty chargeable on the said Com, at the Time that it was taken out of the Warehouse. And that no Importer or Proprietor shall be entitled to the Receipt of any Bounty on any Com or Flour exported by him, until after he has settled his Account of the Com so taken out of the Warehouse, and discharged his Bond.

12. That Wheat be permitted to be exported, but without Bounty, when the Price thereof is between 445. and 465. and other Com, when the Prices thereof shall be in like Proportion; and that Wheat be allowed to be imported into this Kingdom, from Your Majesty’s Kingdom of Ireland only, on the Low Duties, when the Price thereof is at or above 465. and other Sorts of Corn w hen the Prices shall be in like Proportion.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Report, with the Appendix, be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will. Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the said Report.

Bill to pre- Mr. Pye, according to Order, reported from the Com-Electionls m’ttee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for the reported. further Prevention of Delay in Elections of Members to serve in Parliament, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Petition from A Petition of several Masters, Mates, and Mariners Hull respect- of Trading Ships, and others, in the Town and Port fiscation of" Kingston upon Hull, was presented to the House, Ships. and read; Setting forth. That, by an Act, passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Petitioners feel themselves in a Situation of constant Danger of forfeiting the Fruits of their Industry, by the bringing on Board of the Ships in Vol. .45.

which they sail, in Foreign Parts, sacb Goods as may not lawfully be brought to this Kingdom without being duly entered, and as this has been, and may at all Times be done, by such Seamen as will smuggle Goods on Board, without the possibility of preventing it, the Petitioners are as much exposed as the Inhabitants of all the Counties in England would be, were they made answerable for all Robberies committed during the Night: And, as the Petitioners are thus liable to be punished for the Acts of others, without being able to guard against what may be done in their Absence, therefore praying the House to relieve them from this their distressing Situation, which adds constant Anxiety to all the Labour and Hazard of their Employment, by devising such other Remedies against Smuggling as will make the Persons who commit the Crime bear their own Punishment, on Conviction, and not, as at present, the Innocent for the Guilty.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the Se- Papists cond Reading of the Bill for allowing further Time {?,er.ds.an<1.. for Inrollment of Deeds and Wills made by Papists, and for relief of Protestant Purchasers, be now- committed, read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The said Bill was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

An ingrossed Bill for making, amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, a Road from Eve Hill, near Dudley, to the New Inn in the Parish of Pattinglum, and from the Turnpike Road at or near Shut End, in the Parish of Kingswinford, to the Turnpike Road

leading from Dudley to Wolverhampton, in the Counties of Worcester, Salop, and Stwas read the Third

Time.

Resolved That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for making, amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, a Road from Eve Hill, near Dudley, to the New' Inn in the Parish of Patting ham, and from the Turnpike Road at or near Shut End, in the Parish of Kingsxoinford, to the Turnpike Road leading from Dudley to Wolverhampton, in the Counties of Wor-

Tobacco Act Resolved, That this House will, this Day, resolve deferred. itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties " in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

LordCrevea’s Ordered, That Sir Georgs Augustus William Petition burgh have Leave to make a Motion, against Co- And he moved the House accordingly; and presented yentry Pav- to the House,

A Petition of the Eight honourable William Lord

Craven.

And the said Petition was brought up, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for the better paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the City of Coventry, and the Suburbs thereof, and removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein, and for widening and otherwise improving the Streets, and regulating the public Wells and Pumps, within the said City and Suburbs; and Setting forth, That, by the said Bill, 1'hree additional Turnpikes have been laid on different Roads leading to Coventry, with considerable Duties and Tolls on Carriages and Horses, a large Proportion whereof will fall on the Owners and Occupiers of Lands in the County of Warwick, whereas the Expence of paving, lighting, and improving the City of Coventry has hitherto been paid, and ought to be paid, by the Inhabitants of the said City; and that an additional Turnpike, near the Petitioner’s Estate, with additional Tolls, was added in the Committee on the said Bill, and the Petitioner has a large property in the County of Warwick, in the Neighbourhood of the said City, but bad no Notice whatever of the said Bill, or that himself, or his Tenants, or any other Persons interested, were to be affected thereby, until after the same had passed the Committee; and, the Petitioner is informed, that the Owners of other great Estates in that Neighbourhood have had no Notice of the said Bill, and that there are many exceptionable Clauses in the Bill: And therefore praying, That he may be heard, by his Counsel or Agents, against the said Bill, or such Parts thereof as may affect him.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read the Third Time; and that the Petitioner be then heard, by his Counsel or Agents, against the said Bill, upon his Petition, if lie thinks fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

And then the House adjourned till this Morning,

Ten of the Clock.

An ingrossed Bill for charging a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Plantations, was read the Third Time.

The Amendment following was proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 3. L 5. After " paid " to insert by the " Collector of the Port or Place " in such Colony, Province, of " Plantation, where the said Duty " shall have been levied, to the " public Treasurer or Receiver " General of such Colony, Province, or Plantation respectively, " to be paid."

And the Question being put, That those Words be there inserted;

It passed in the Negative.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for charging a Duty on Foreign Cocoa Nuts imported into the British Plantations.

Account of The House being informed that Mr. Leese, from the Tobacco ma- Commissioners of Excise, attended at the Door; he London"*1 was ca"ed >n i and, at the Bar, presented to the House, presented. pursuant to their Order,

An Account of the Total Quantity of Tobacco manufactured within the Limits of the Chief Office of Excise in London, between the 10th of October 1789 and the xoth of March 1790, distinguishing the different Sorts of Tobacco and Snuff into which the same has been manufactured; specifying in what Quantities of each Sort the Credits given by Law have agreed with the Quantities manufactured, or have been greater or less than the same, and in what Proportions.

And then he withdrew.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

Ordered, That the said Account be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the " Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for. granting " new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Hie said Account is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

in the County of Surrey, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners observe; by the Votes, that a Bill is depending for Repairing and widening the Road from Parley Comer, beyond Croydon, in the County of Surrey, through to the Borough of Reigate, and fromr Godstone, by Redstone House, in the said County, through the Borough of Reigctte, to Wonham Mill Gate, and to Buckland Church, in the said County; and that a' large Sum of Money hath been borrowed on the

4T - Credit

Bradford Waterworks Bill reported.

Edinburgh Gaols Petition reported.

346 31° Martii. A. 1790.

Credit of the Tolls, arising by virtue of the said Acts, of the Twenty-eighth of George the Second, and Tenth of His present Majesty, which hath been expended in making and repairing the several Roads thereby directed to be repaired, particularly the Roads from Sutton, through the Borough of Reigate, hut some small Part of the said Roads still remains to be repaired; and that, by the said Act of the Tenth of George the First, the Trustees for putting the same into Execution are to allow to the Trustees of the before-mentioned Act the Yearly Sum of 900 L, in Lieu of any Share of Toll, to arise by virtue of the said Act of the Tenth of George the First, which Sum is to be applied to repairing the above-mentioned Roads; and that the Petitioners, and others (Creditors as aforesaid) relying on the Faith of Parliament, advanced their Monies on the Credit of the said Tolls of the Reigate Trust, which Tolls, together with the Allowance from the said other Trust, are barely sufficient to pay the Interest of the Monies borrowed, and to keep the said Roads in Repair, and, if the said Bill shall pass into a Law it must manifestly be a great Injury to the Petitioners, and others, Creditors on the said Reigate Trust: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that they may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be brought in.

Mr. Wilbeiforce reported from the Committee, to

whom the Bill for improving and preserving the Works made for supplying the Town of Bradford, in the County of York, ana Part of the Township of Horton, in the Parish of Bradford aforesaid, with Water, and for the more easy Recovery of the Rents for the said Water, was committed; and to whom the Petition of several Gentlemen, Freeholders, Merchants, Tradesmen, and other Inhabitants of Bradford in the M’est Riding of the County of York, whose Names are thereunto subscribed; and also, the Petition of several Gentlemen, Freeholders, Merchants, Tradesmen, and other Inhabitants of Bradford, in the West Riding of the County of York,whose Names are thereunto subscribed, were severally referred; That the Committee had considered the said Petitions, and had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That, the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Lord Frederick Campbell reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Lord Provost, Magistrates, and Council of the City of Edinburgh, for themselves, and on Behalf of the Community of the said City, and of the Proprietors and Inhabitants of the respective Counties of Edinburgh, Haddington, Linlithgow, Peebles, Fife, Stirling, and Clackmanon thereunto subscribing, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Tot prove the Allegations of the said Petition, John Gray, Esquire, being examined, said, That it is ne-

03

cessary to build and erect a new Prison within or adjacent to the City of Edinburgh, for confining and detaining of State and other Criminals, and also a Prison for Debtors and Persons guilty of Petty Offences, committed within the said City and County of Edinburgh — And that it is also become absolutely necessary to build and erect a Bridewell or House of Correction, within or adjacent to the City of Edinburgh, for the Punishment of idle, refractory, and profligate Persons, within the said City and County —

That a considerable Sum of Money will be necessary to be raised by Assessments, for the erecting the said Buddings, as well as for a proper Establishment, and for keeping them in proper Repair-'-That in so far as concerns the said House of Correction or Bridewell, and appointing Persons to be confined there, and transmitting them for that Purpose, it will be necessary to give additional Powers to the Sheriff,

Justices of the Peace, and Magistrates, of the said City and County.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for building and maintaining a new Gaol, Bridewell, and House of Correction, in and for the City and County of Edinburgh: And that Lord Frederick Campbell and Mr. Henry Dundas do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr. TVilberforce presented to the House, according Leeds Water to Order, a Bill for better supplying the Town and anJ1 Ligtoiif Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with M ater; and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are petition thereunto subscribed, being Gentlemen, Clergy, Free- agaiiwBd holders, and Inhabitants, of Ten Parishes, without the Parish and Limits of the Town and Borough of Deal, but within, the Custom House Limits of the Port of Deal, in the Eastern Part of the County of Kent, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for repairing, paving, and cleansing the Highways, Streets, and Lanes, within the Town and Borough of Deal, in the County of Kent, and for removing and preventing Encroachments, Obstructions, Nuisances, and Annoyances therein; qnd Setting forth, That, by the said Bill, a Duty is proposed to be laid upon all Sorts of Coals, Coke, or Cinders, which shall be imported or brought into, landed, or delivered, within the Limits of the Port of Deal, or brought into, or carried througii, the said Town and Borough of Deal, above all other Impositions and Duties payable for Coals, Coke, or Cinders, by virtue of any law now in Force; and that the Limits of the Town and Borough of Deal are coextensive with the Parish of Deal, but the Custom House Limits of the Port of Deal extend many Miles without the Limits of the Town and Borough of Deal, and the Parish of IVaimer, and Three other Parishes, abut on the Sea (as well a? the Parish of Deaf) within the Custom House limits of the Port of Deal, but are not within the Limits and Jurisdiction of the Town and Borough of; and that, for several Years past, Coals have been landed in the said Parish of JValmer, few supplying the Country adjacent to Deal, but no Coala are. landed in any of the said Nine other Parishes, and, if the said Bill should pass into a Law as it now stands, it will subject the Peti* tioners, and a great Number of other Persons, some of whom carry on very considerable Manufactories, and Annually consume great Quantities of Coals, which are not landed at, or carried through, the Town or Borough of Deal, to the Payment of a

Tax merely for the Improvement of the said Town, from which the Petitioners cannot derive any Advantage whatever, as they will not pass over, with their Coals, Coke, or Cinders, any Part of the new intended Pavement, nor will the said Parish of IVaimer, or the said Nine other Parishes, be in any ways benefited by the said Pavement, and, the Petitioners also conceive, that there are several other Clauses and Provisions in the said Bill, which, if carried into a Law, will be , very prejudicial to the Petitioners: And therefore

I praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or

! Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may be

( injurious to them, and that all Coals, Coke, and

Cinders, not landed, consumed in, or carried through, the Town and Borough of Deal, may be exempted from all Hates, Duties, or Impositions, to be laid or imposed by virtue of the said Bill, j Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the

Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

Hariiyla- Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, to closure Ml whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open reported. Common Fields, Pastures, and other Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of in the County of Leicester, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietors of 8 Oxgangs and an Half of Land, who refused to sign the Bill; and that the whole Property intended to be inclosed consists of 96 . Oxgangs and an Half; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read

throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Distillery Bill to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, deferred, upon the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-ma.de Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from The West Indies, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Accounts re* The House being informed that Mr. Morton, from

Utive to the the Directors of the East India Company, attended at Company* the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, pre-presentedL sented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

N* l. An Account of the Sales of Goods from China, between the ist of March 1785 and the 1st of March 1786, and the^ Amount of Customs, Freight, Demorage, and Charges t)f Merchandize, paid there* out: And also,

N° 2. An Account of the Sales of Goods from India, between the 1st of March 1785 and the 1st of March 1786, and the Amount of Customs, Freight, Demorage, and Charges of Merchandize, paid there* out: And also,

N° 3. An Account of the Net Value of Goods from India, remaining unsold on the 1st of March 1785, and the Net Value of Goods from India, remaining unsold on the 1st of March 1790: And also,

N° 4. An Account of the Net Value of China Goods, remaining unsold in the Warehouses of the East India Company on the 1st of March 1784, on the 1st of March 1785, and on the 1st of March 1790, distinguishing each Year; together with an Account of the Value of Tea purchased in Europe between the above Periods, and the Amount remaining unsold on the 1st of March 1785: And also,

N° 5. An Account of Stock, by Computation, of the East India Company, from the 31st of January 1789 to the 31st of January 1790: And also, -N° 6. An Account explaining the Profit and Loss of the East India Company, from the 31st of January 1781 to the 31st of January 1789, and their Accounts, now before the House, stating the Balances in 1781, 5,536,502/. to be in Favour of the Company, and the Balances in 1789, 6,719,056/. to be against the Company: And also,

N° 7. An Account of the Amount of Debts subscribed in India, between the 30th of April 1788 and the 30th of April 1789, agreeable to the Orders of 15th September 1785 and 31st July 1787.

Together with a list of the said Accounts.

Ana then he withdrew.

And the said List was read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Accounts be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Accounts be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Accounts and Papers, which were presented to the House, upon the 19th Day of February last, and the 11th Day of this Instant March, by Mr. Morton, from the Directors of the East India Company.

Mr. Loceden accordingly reported from the said Committee, the Amendments which ' the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed to be reported to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the

Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, wrere agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Ordered, That the Marquis of Graham do make the Report !Report from the Committee of the whole House, to respecting whom it was referred to consider of the Report which ComAct-was made from the Committee who were appointed to consider of an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for better regulating " and ascertaining the Importation and: Exportation " of Com and Grain; and also for better regulating " the Exportation of Starch, and the Importation of " Rape Seed," and to report their Opinion to the House in what Manner the Provisions of the said Act may be more effectually carried into Execution, and also, what Alterations and Amendments it may appear necessary to make in the Laws respecting the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain.

The Marquis of Graham accordingly reported from the said Committee, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed to be reported to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were rea?>; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That, for the Purpose of ascertaining the Prices according to which Corn and Grain are, by Law, permitted to be imported and exported, and the Bounty paid, that Part of Great Britain called England he divided into Districts, according to the Plan of an Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act " for better regulating and ascertaining the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain; and also " for better regulating the Exportation of Starch, and " the Importation of Rape Seed."

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That that Part of Great Britain called Scotland be also divided into Districts, for the like Purpose.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That whenever the Export of any Sort of Com is stopped in any One District, because the Price thereof is above the Export Price, Corn of the same Sort should not be allowed to be carried from thence Coastwise to any other District, the Ports of which are open for the Exportation thereof.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That the Act of the 10th of King George the Third, for Registering the Prices of Corn, so far as relates to the Appointment of Inspectors, should be repealed; and that the Registry of Com, published Weekly in The Gazette, should be formed upon Averages taken, according to the Directions of the Act of the last Session of Parliament, from Returns, made by Inspectors to be appointed in the several Districts and Inland Counties in Great Britain, in the Manner directed by the last mentioned Act

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of One Half-penny per Last be paid on all British Com imported Coastwise from the Ports of One District to the Ports of another District; and that a Duty of One Penny per Last be paid on all Com imported from Foreign Countries into all the Ports of Great Britain; and.that the Money arising from these Duties be made a Fund for the Payment of the Inspectors, and defraying the other Expences attending these Regulations

Resoloed, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That the Returns and Letters sent to and from the Receiver of Com Returns, to and from, the several Inspectors, by the Post, be not subject to the Payment of the Duties of Postage.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

' That

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, tion of Corn and Grain, and Payment of the Bounty,

That, in case the Returns from any District shall not be repealed.

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for repairing and widening the Road from Rowde Ford to Red Hill, and from Chit toe Heath to the Town of Caine, in the County of Wilts; and for repealing Three Acts, made in the Second and Twenty-fifth Years of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and in the Twenty-third Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Highways between Sheppard's Shord and Horsley Upright Gate, leading down Bagdown Hill, in the County of Wilts, and other

ruinous Parts of the Highways thereunto adjacent; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Terms, and altering the Powers, of Two Acts, made in the Sixteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, and in the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing tire Roads leading from Marlborough, through West Kennett, to Sheppard's Shord, and from The Hare and Hounds in Beckhamptoti, to the Top of Cherrill Hill, and from the Town of Avebury to the Cross Way at ton, and from the Turnpike Gate at Avebury to Wroughton, and from the North Side of Swindon to The Caipenlers Arms in Blunsden, in the County of

Wilts, and for diverting, turning, and altering Part of the said Roads; and for repairing and widening the Road on the West Side of The Three Barrows, from the Direction Post there on the new Road leading from Beckhampton to Devizes, to the Distance of One Mile from the said Direction Post Westward; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing the Term, and enlarging, altering, and amending, the Powers, of an Act, made in the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Road from New Chappell, in the County of Surrey, over Copthorn, in the County of Sussex, through Lindfield, to the Town of Ditchling,up to the Top of Ditch ling Bost Hills, in

the said County of Sussex; without any Amendment: And also, *

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging 02

the Powers, of certain Acts, made for repairing the Road from Keighley,in the West Riding of the County of York, to Kirkby in Kendal, in the County of West-

morland, so far as relates to such Part of the said Road as lies within the County of York; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to alter and amend an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, Bridge, in

the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Erewash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton Mill, in the said County; without any Amendment.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for raising a certain Sum of Money by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for raising a further Sum of Money by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart took the Chair of the Committee

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue several Laws therein mentioned relating to encouraging the Manufacture of Leather, by lowering the Duty payable upon the Importation of Oak Bark, when the Price of such Bark shall exceed a certain Rate; to the prohibiting the Exportation of Tools and Utensils made Use of in the Iron and Steel Manufactures of this Kingdom, and to prevent the seducing of Artificers and Workmen employed in those Manufactures, to go into Parts beyond the Seas; and, to the ascertaining the Strength of Spirits by Clarkes Hydrometer, be now' read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Tobacco Ac- Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an count* or er- Account of the Quantity of Manufactured Tobacco and Snuff, which appears by the Returns of the Officers of Excise to have been consumed in England and Scotland, from the 10th Day of October 1789 to the latest Period to which such Account can be made up.

Ordered, That there be laid before the House, an Account of the Quantity of Tobacco delivered out of His Majesty’s Warehouses in Great Britain, for Manufacture, from the 10th Day of October 1789 to the 5th Day of January 1790, and from the 5th Day of January 1790 to the latest Period to which the same can be made up.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Quantities of Tobacco delivered out of His Majesty’s Warehouses in Great Britain, for Manufacture, for Three Years, preceding the 5th Day of January 1790, distinguishing each Quarter.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Manufacturers of Tobacco or Snuff, together with the Produce of the Duties on such Licences; and also of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Dealers in Tobacco and Snuff, together with the Produce of thp Duties on such Licences.

Colonel Boscawen reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages; for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances; and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts, within the Borough of and

Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall, w'as committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Sir Charles Gould presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to alter and amend an Act, made in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for the " effectual Draining and Preservation of Waterbeach " Level, in the County of Cambridge, and to establish "an Agreement made between the Lord of the Manor of Waterbeach cum Denny and the Commoners within " the said ManorAnd the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir James Langham reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of Polebrook, in the County of Northampton, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Owners of 85 Acres of Land and One Cottage Common, who refused to sign the Bill, but do not object to the Inclosure; and that the Whole of the Lands intended to be divided and inclosed consists of 1,397 Acres and Six Cottage Commons; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the

Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were dgreed to by the House.

Ordered,'That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

An ingrossed Bill to continue an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for appointing Commissioners to enquire into the State and Condition of " the Woods, Forests, and Land Revenues, belonging to the Crown, and to sell or alienate Fee-farm " and other Unimproveable Rents," was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to continue and amend an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for appointing Commissioners to enquire into the State and Condition " of the Woods, Forests, and Land Revenues belonging to the Crown, and to sell or alienate Fee-farm " and other Unimproveable Rents."

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Common and Waste Lands, in the Liberty or Lordship of Mickleover, in the County of Derby, was committed; That the Committed had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Commitee (except the Proprietor of Lands assessed to the Land Tax at 7 s.4 d.per Annum, who could not be met with; and that the Whole of the Lands intended to be inclosed are assessed to the Land Tax at 111/. os. l\d. per Annum', and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

An ingrossed Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open Common Fields, Pastures, and bther Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Harby, in the County of Leicester, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Common Fields, Pastures, and other Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Harby, in the County of Leicester.

Ordered, That the Marquis of Worcester do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Sir William Dolben reported from the Committee, appointed for the Purpose of taking the Examination ' of such Witnesses as.shall be produced on the Part of the several Petitioners who have petitioned this House against the Abolition of the Slave Trade; and who were impowered to report the Minutes of such Examination, from Time to Time, to the House; That the Committee had made a further Progress in the Matter to them referred, and had directed trim to report the Minutes of the said Examination to thfe House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Sir William Dolben also reported from the said Committee, That they had, pursuant to the Instruction of the House of the 23d Day of February last, directing them forthwith to examine the several Persons therein mentioned, taken such Examination accordingly, the Minutes of which Examination they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report m his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

A Petition of the House of Keys, the Representatives of the People of the Isle of Mann, was presented to the House, and, in part, read.'

A Message, by Sir Francis Gentleman

Usher of the Black Rod:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords, authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission, for declaring His Royal Assent to several Acts agreed upon by both Houses, do desire the immediate Attendance of this Honourable House in the House of Peers, to hear the Commission read.

Accordingly Mr. Speaker, with the House, went up to the House of Peers.

And being returned;

Mr. Speaker reported, That the House, at the Desire of the Ix»rds authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission afore-mentioned, had been at the House of Peers, where a Commission ,undter the Great Seal was read, giving, declaring, and notifying the Royal Assent to the several Public and Private Bills therein mentioned; and also empowering His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, His Royal Highness

the Duke of York, His Royal Highness -the Duke of Clarence, His Royal Highness the Duke of Gloucester, His Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland, the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and several other Lords, to declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills; and that the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and the Duke of -Leeds,named also in the said Commission, did accordingly declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills: Which Bills are as followeth; viz.

An Act for the better Support of the Dignity of the Speaker of the House of Commons, and for disabling the Speaker of the House of Commons, for the Time being, from holding any Office or Place of Profit, during Pleasure, under the Crown:

An Act for defraying the Charge of the Pay and Clothing of the Militia in that Part of Great Britain called England, for One Year, beginning the Twenty-fifth Day of March One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety:

An Act to amend Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reigrf of His present Majesty, the one intituled, "An Act for regulating the Trade " between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Colonies and " Plantations, in North America, and in the West India " Islands, and the Countries belonging to the United " States of A)nerica, and between His Majesty’s said Subjects and the Foreign Islands in The West " Indies," and thS other intituled, "An Act to

ft allow the Importation of Rum or other Spirits, from " His Majesty’s Colonies or Plantations in The West " Indies into the Province of Quebec, without Payment of Duty, under certain Conditions and Restrictions:"

An Act to continue the Laws now in Force for regulating the Trade between the Subjects of His Majesty’s Dominions and the Inhabitants of the Territories belonging to the United States of America, so far as the same relate to the Trade and Commerce carried on between this Kingdom and the Inhabitants of the Countries belonging to the said United States:

An Act to indemnify such Persons as have omitted to qualify themselves for Offices and Employments; and to indemnify Justices of the Peace, or others, who have omitted to register or deliver in their Qualifications within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for those Purposes; and to indemnify Members and Officers in Cities, Corporations, and Borough Towns, whose Admissions have been omitted to be stamped according to Law, or, having been stamped, have been lost or mislaid, and for allowing them Time to provide Admissions duly stamped*; to give further Time to such Persons as have omitted to make and file Affidavits of the Execution of Indentures of Clerks to Attornies and Solicitors; and for indemnifying Deputy Lieutenants and Officers of the Militia, who have neglected to transmit Descriptions of their Qualifications to the Clerks of the Peace within the Time limited by Law, and for giving further Time for that Purpose:

An Act for continuing the Term of so much of an Act, made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, as relates to the rendering the Payment of Creditors more equal and expeditious in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland:

An Act for taking off the Duties upon unwrought Tin exported to any of the Countries beyond the Cape of Good Hope:

An Act for re-building the Parish Church and Tower of Saint Thomas, within the City of Bristol:

An Act for better supplying the City of Norwich, and the Parts adjacent, with Water:

An Act for making and maintaining a Navigable

Communication

Communication between Stmo and Ipswich, in the County of Suffolk:

An Act for the better Relief and Employment of the Poor within the Hundreds of and Carlford,

in the County of Suffolk:

An Act to alter and amend an Act, passed in the la9t Session of Parliament, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to,

Bridge, in the County of Derby, to join and communicate with the Ereivash Canal, at or near Langley Bridge, and also a Collateral Cut from the said intended Canal, at or near Codnor Park Mill, to or near Pinxton

An Act for continuing an Act of the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for amending the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the City of Norwich, to Block Hill, in Trcrwse, at the Angle where the Road divides to Bixley and , in the County of

An Act for continuing an Act of the Twelfth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road from Berstreet Gates, in the City of Norwich, to New Buckenham, in the County of Norfolk:

Then the Residue of the Petition of the House of Keys, the Representatives of the People of the Isle of Mann, was read; Setting forth, That a Bill has been brought into the House in Consequence of a Petition from the most Noble John Duke of , for appointing Commissioners to enquire into the Extent and Value of certain Rights, Revenues, and Possessions in the Isle of Mann, and from the general Terms of the said Bill the Petitioners are apprehensive that some Alteration is intended to be effected thereby in

of the said Duke, as far as it should be thought compatible with the Interests of His Majesty, and the Rights and Liberties of His Subjects; and that Two of the most valuable Sovereign Rights transferred to the Crown, namely, the Herring Custom, and the* Salmon Fisheries in the Bays, have been appropriated by Parliament to the Repair and Support of the Harbours in the said Isle, yet the same, with the Addition of other Funds, is so insufficient lor the Purpose, that the Harbour of Douglass, the principal Harbour in the said Isle, and which is of great Utility to Ships navigating the Irish Channel, has remained, for near Four Years past, in so ruinous a State, as to have occasioned the Wreck of several Boats and Vessels, and the Loss of many Lives, and there is a considerable Debt chargeable upon the Harbour Funds of the said Isle still remaining unpaid; and that the Petitioners submit to the Justice of the House, although the House should now be inclined to add to the very ample and liberal Compensation which has already been made to the Family of the said Duke,

the present Settlement of the Sovereignty of the said that those Rights and Privileges which have been so Isle, and they are therefore greatly surprized that a ^ong granted to the Petitioners, and the Inhabitants Matter of such Magnitude, which might so materially of ,the said Isle> would neither be consistent with the affect the Rights and Interests of near Forty thousand Faith of Parliament, nor the Dignity of the Crown, of His Majesty’s Subjects, Inhabitants of the said Isle, to resume; and that the Inhabitants of the said Isle who have experienced the many happy Effects of the have experienced such Prosperity and Blessings under present Establishment of the Island near Twenty-five die present Settlement of the said Isle, that they trust Years, should have been brought into the House the Ki.ng of Great Britain will continue their only without any previous Notice having been given to Sovereign, and that the Parliament will never

them, that such a Measure would be attempted; and reduce them again to the degraded State of being Sub-that, as no particular Object is specified by the said jects to a Subject: And therefore praying the House Bill, the Petitioners are still unacquainted with the to take the Premises into Consideration, and that they Nature and Extent of the Claims and Wishes of the may be heard» bY Counsel, or by themselves, at the Duke, nor can they form any Conjecture of the Pur- Rar *he House, against the said Bill, and that the poses of the present Bill, except that they apprehend same may not Pass into a Law.

they are similar to those of some ineffectual Bills which some Time past were brought into the House upon the same Subject; that the Reasons assigned in Support of the present Bill are, that the Act, by which the Sovereignty of the said Isle was re-vested in His Majesty, was made on the " Pressure of the Occasion," and that " sufficient Time was not given for enquiring into and ascertaining the Extent of the " Pre-eminencies and Rights of Property necessary to " be vested in the Crown, or the Amount in Value " of those Rights and Revenues which were transferred to the Crown, that, for Want of such Enquiry, " some Manerial Rights have become the Subject of " Litigation, and the Income of the Landed Estates, " and other Species of Property reserved to the Family of the said Duke, has been impaired," and the Petitioners submit to the House, that it appears, from the Correspondence upon the Subject, printed by Order of the House, that the Contract between the Crown and the Family of the said Duke was entered into after considerable Time and Deliberation; that the Petitioners know of no Litigation in which the Duke or his Family have been involved for the Re-

Ordered, That the said Petition do fie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.
