A MESSAGE from the Lords, by" Mr. Holford and Mr. Montagu:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for making, amending and keeping in Repair^ the Road from Fosbrook, in the Parish of through Dillorn, and from thence to or near to Chedleton, in the County of Stafford; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for naturalizing Willem Blaauw; without any Amendment.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

A Bill for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Laurence, in the Isle of Thanet, in the County of Kent, as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the same Parish, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Stephens, Mr. Brett, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

A Petition of the Ship Owners belonging to the Port of Sunderland, in the County of Durham, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed that the Owners of Ships belonging to the Port of Kingston upon Hull, and many other Ports, have presented a Petition to the House, stating the Hardships that Ship Owners labour under in consequence of the several Acts in Force for suppressing of Smuggling, particularly the Act of the Twenty-sixth of His preseut Majesty, which enacts, that every Ship importing any Foreign Spirituous Liquors ( British Plantation Rum and Arrack accepted) in any Cask, containing less than One hundred Gallons, except Two Gallons for each Seaman, with all her Stores and Furniture, be the Burthen and Value thereof what they may, shall be forfeited, without any Limitation or Qualification whatsoever, and praying Leave to bring in a Bill for repealing those Laws, which subject Ships employed in a fair and open Trade to Confiscation for the Misconduct of Masters and Seamen, affording to the innocent Owners of such Ships such Relief as to the House shall seem meet; and that the Petitioners have large Property in Shipping (upwards of Four hundred Sail) which are all equally liable to Forfeiture and Confiscation for the Reasons in the above-mentioned Petition referred to, and themselves liable to be reduced to a 3

State of Penury by such Forfeiture, without any Offence whatever being committed by them, or having it in their Power to obtain any Recompence from the Aggressor: And therefore praying. That the House will take the said Petitions into Consideration, and grant such Relief to the Petitioners, and other Ship Owners, as to the House shall seem necessary.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

A Bill to alter and amend an Act, made in the Waterbeach Fourteenth V ear of the Reign of his late Majesty Drainag' Bill King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for the conul,ulcdeffectual Draining and Preservation of Waterbeach " Level, in the County of Cambridge, and to establish

" an Agreement made between the Lord of the Manor of Waterbeach cum Denny and the Commoners " within the said Manor," was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Sir Charles Gould, Mr. Gould, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber.

An ingrossed Bill for dividing and inclosing the Polebrookln-Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable closure B.U Lands, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of Polebrook, passed‘

.in the County of Northampton, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, in the Parish of Polebrook, in the County of Northampton.

Ordered, That Sir James Lang ham do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

An ingrossed Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, Truro Paving and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages, for re- ^>11 passed, moving and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts, within the Borough of Truro, and Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall, was read the Third Time.

The Amendment following was proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 20. 1. 6. To leave out, " and shall also be " deemed Nuisances."

And the said Amendment was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill' was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for paving, cleansing, lighting, and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages, for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts, within the Borough of Truro, and Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall.

Ordered, That Colonel Boscawen do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

a common Ferry over and across the River Tamet', between a certain Place North of Plymouth Dock, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel,in the County of Devon, and

An ingrossed Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Common and Waste Lands, in the Liberty or Lordship of Mickleover, in the County of Derby, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Common and Waste Lands, in the Liberty or Lordship of Mickleover, in the County of Derby.

Ordered, That Lord George Augustus Henry Cavendish do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of the Owners of Ships using the Coal Trade, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and other Owners of Ships using the Coal Trade, in the Ports of Newcastle and < land, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That, by an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to regulate the Loading of Ships with Coals in the Ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, divers useful and salutary Regulations were established for ascertaining the Turn or Rotation, and directing the Manner of Loading Ships with Coals in the said Ports, which Act was to continue in Force for Seven Years, and was, by a subsequent Act, continued for the further Term of Seven Years; and that, by an Act passed in the Twenty-second Year of His present Majesty, the said first-mentioned Act was revived, and continued until the 25th Day of March 1789, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, and the further Continuance thereof will be of great public Utility; and that the Petitioners were not informed that the said Act w’ould expire with the present Session of Parliament, until the Time limited by the House for receiving Petitions for Private Bills had elapsed, and the suffering the said Act to expire will be highly prejudicial to the Ships employed in the Coal Trade, and a great Detriment to the Public: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to exhibit a Petition for Leave to bring in a Bill to continue an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to regulate the Loading " of Ships with Coals in the Ports of Newcastle and " Sunderland . Ordered, That, in Consideration of the particular Circumstances set forth in the said Petition, Leave be given to present a Petition as desired by the said Owners of Ships using the Coal Trade in the Ports of Newcastle and Sunderland.

Then a Petition of the Owners of Ships using the Coal Trade in the Port of Newcastle, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and other Ship Owners using the Coal Trade in the Ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by an Act, Vox.. 45.

passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to regulate the Loading " of Ships with Coals in the Ports of Newcastle and " Sundeiiand," divers useful and salutary Regulations were established for ascertaining the Turn or Rotation, and directing the Manner, in which Ships should be laden with Coals in the said Ports, which Act M as to continue in Force for Seven Years; and that, by an Act passed in the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, reciting the said Act of the Sixth Year of His said Majesty, and that the same had proved useful to the Coal Trade, it was enacted, that the said Act should be continued, from the Expiration thereof, for the further Term of Seven Years; and that by another Act, passed in the Twenty-second Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, reciting, that the Revival and Continuance of the said Act of the Sixth Year of His present Majesty would be of great public Utility, it was enacted, that the said Act should be revived and continued in full Force and Effect until the 25th Day of March 1789, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament; and that the further Continuance of the said Act would be of great public Utility: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill to continue an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act to regulate the Loading " of Ships with Coals in the Ports of Newcastle and " Sunderland

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Matthew While Ridley, Mr. Tempest, 8cc.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Petition A Petition of John Trafford, of in the

aSd bounty Palatine of Lancaster, Esquire, was presented

pool Naviga- *° the House, and read; taking Notice of the said tion Bill. Bill; and Setting forth, That foe Petitioner is Owner

of a Corn Mill situate upon the River Yarrow, in the Township of Croston, in the County of Lancaster, and near the Conftux of a Brook dividing the Townships of Ecclestonand Mawdesl called Sis or Sid Brook, the Streams of which River and Brook are foe Support of foe said Mill, and the Petitioner apprehends that the said Canal Navigation will be very injurious to the said Mill, or render the same totally useless to him: And therefore praying, That he may be at Liberty, by himself, or his Counsel, to be heard upon the said Bill, and be allowed to offer such Clauses, Powers, Restrictions, and Regulations, as he shall be advised, and as to the House shall appear just.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

for the Expence of confining, maintaining, and employing Conviets on foe River Thames, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Monies which have been issued to the Secretary of the Commissioners appointed in pursuance of an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act to regulate, for a limited Time, " the shipping and carrying Slaves in British Vessels " from foe Coast of Africa. ’

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Monies which have been issued to the Secretary of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of all such Persons who have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of foe Monies which have been issued to the Secretary of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of the American Loyalists, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Monies which have been issued in Consequence of the Expences incurred in carrying on the Prosecution against Warren Hastings, Esquire, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, art Account of the Monies issued to John Dally, to defray the Expences in executing an Act of last Session of Parliament for enquiring into the Emoluments of the Officers of the Customs.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the several Sums issued to Thomas Cotton,

Esquire, to pay Bills of Exchange, and other Purposes, by the Directions of the Commissioners of the Treasury, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Monies paid to Thomas and

Jeremy Pemberton, Esquires, Commissioners appointed to esquire, in America, into the Losses of American Sufferers.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of tire Money issued to the Earl of for defraying the Extraordinary Expences of His Majesty’s Mint in the Tower of London, in the Year 1788.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Expence of sending Provisions and sundry Articles to the Settlements in New South Wales.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Money issued to Henry Hughs, Esquire, for printing the Reports of the Lords of the Committee of Council concerning the present State of foe Trade to Af rica.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Monies remaining in the Exchequer, on foe 5th Day of April 1790, of the Surplusses, Excesses, or Overplus Monies, and other Revenues, of the Fund commonly called The Consolidated Fund, for the Disposition of Parliament, after satisfying the several Charges and Incumbrances thereupon.

Mr. Steele presented to the House, by His Majesty’s Account of Command, Money issued

Whitehall, Treasury Chambers, 12th April 1790.

Tho* Steele.

Ordered, That the said Account do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The House being informed that Mr. In-

spector General of the Exports and Imports of Great Britain, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

An Account of the Quantities of Tobacco delivered out of His Majesty’s Warehouses in Great Britain, for Manufacture, for Three Years preceding the 5th Day of January 1790; distinguishing each Quarter: And also.

An Account of the Quantity of Tobacco delivered out of His Majesty's Warehouses in Great Britain, for Manufacture, for Six Years, preceding the 5th Day of January 1790; distinguishing each Quarter: Ana

also.

An Account of the Duty on Tobacco, received since the passing the Act of the last Session of Parliament, to the latest Period to which the same can be made up.

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Accounts be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Accounts be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, u An Act for repealing the " Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

An ACCOUNT of the Monies which have been issued to Henry Bradley, Esquire, for the Expence of maintaining and guarding Convicts in the Harbour of Hamoaze, at Plymouth, and which have not been made good by Parliament.

The Monies which have been issued to Henry Bradley, Esquire, for the Expence of maintaining and guarding Convicts in the Harbour of Hamoaze, at Plymouth, and which have not been made good by Parliament, amount to the Sum of Six thousand Eight hundred Eighty-eight Pounds seven Shillings and Six Pence.

Exchequer, the 12th Day of April 1790.

Rolf Jennings.

Ordered, That the said Accounts do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the Three last of the said Accounts be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Petition A Petition of the Gentlemen, Clergy, Merchants,

against the and principal Inhabitants of the Town of Sheffield, in

Coders Bill* County of York, whose Names are thereto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the first, intituled, "An Act for the good Order " and Government of the Makers of Knives* Sickles,

" Sheers, Scissors, and other Cudery Wares, in Hallamshire, in the County of York, and the Parts near u adjoining;" and praying that the same may not pass into a Law.

Ditto. A Petition of the Persons whose Names are there-

unto subscribed, being Manufacturers of ’Saws, re- sident in Sheffield, and the Neighbourhood thereof, in the County of York, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That, by the Tenth Section thereof, it is proposed to be enacted, " That all Goods and Wares " whatsoever, which shall be made (within the Liberties aforesaid) of Steel only, shall be and be dee bed " to be subject, and equally, within the said proposed " Bill, and the said Act of the Twenty-first Year " of the Reign of King James the First, as if such Goods and Wares were and should be made of " Iron and Steel," and the Petitioners conceive that, if the Bill, in its present Form, was suffered to pass into a Law, it would be greatly injurious and oppressive to the Petitioners, as it would subject them, and all other Saw Makers, to the Jurisdiction of the Corporation of the Company of Cutlers in HaUtfmshire, of which they have been heretofore independent: And therefore praying the House to take their Case into Consideration, and give them such Relief therein as to the House may seem meet, and that the Petitioners may be heard by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, as well in a Committee, as at the Bar of the House, if necessary.

Ditto. A Petition of the Master, Wardens, Searchers,

Assistants, and Commonalty, of the Company of Cutlers, in Hallamshire, in the County of York, under their Common Seal, and of several of the principal Manufacturers of Cutlery Wares, residing in Sheffield, in the said County, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That by an Act, made in the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of King James the First, for the good Order and Government of the Makers of Knives, Sickles, Sheers, Scissors, and other Cutlery Wares, in the Liberty of Hallamshire aforesaid, and the Parts near adjoining, the Makers of such Cutlery Wares were ‘made a Body Corporate, and certain Persons therein named were appointed Master, Wardens, Searchers, and Assistants of the said Company, with Power Annually to elect their Successors in Office, to rule, order, and govern she said Company; and that, since she passing of the said Act, and under the Regulations thereby established, the Trade and Manufacture carried on by the said Company within the aforesaid Limits, and particularly within the last Twenty Years, have greatly flourished, and the Trade to Foreign Parts has been very much increased; and that the Petitioners are informed a Bill is depending in the House, for making several very material Alterations in the said Act, which, if passed into a Law, would, in the Opinion of the Petitioners, be very injurious to the Trade and Manufactures carried on by them within the said Liberty, and to the Public: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by their Counsel, at the Bar of the House,

03

against the said Bill, and (hat- tie same may not pqss into a Law. j

A Petition of the Persdns whose Narhefe are there- Petition unto subscribed, being Manufacturers bf Edge Tools f«ain4t *5 in Sheffield, and the Neighbourhood thereof, in the Cutlera^illL County of York, was likewise presented to the House, and read; also taking Notice at tjhe said Bill; and Setting forth; That the Petitioners hate hitherto exercised and carried on their Trpde of Edge. Tool Makers free and independent of the Corporation of the Company of Cutlers in Hallamshire, and they conceive that if the said Bill, in ifs present Form, is suffered to pass into a Law, it would be greatly injurious and oppressive to the Petitioners, as it'would subject them, and all other Edge 'Tool Makers* to the Jurisdiction of the said Company: And therefore praying the House to take their Case into Consideration, and give them such Relfef therein as to the House may seem meet, and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the Baid Bill, as well ip a Committee, as at the Bar of the House, if necessary.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and such of; the Petitioners as desire to be heard by themselves or Counsel are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to ,be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the Said Bill, against the said Petitions.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the Accounts of Five first of the Accounts-which were presented'to the House upon the 3d Day of February last, by Mr. Rose, ^s£’e panted, be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

A Bill for enlarging the Tertfi and Powers of an Shawbury Act, passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign Of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from the End of the Turnpike Road in Shaxobury, in the County of to Drtylon in Hales, in the said County* and from thence to Newcastle under Line, in the County of Stafford, and from Shawbury aforesaid, to the Turnpike Road in High Ercall, in tile said County of Salop, and from aforesaid to JVem, in the said County, and from thence to the Turnpike Road in Sandjbrd, in the said County, was read a Second Time.

Resolted, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Robert Burton, Mr. Gilbert, &c.: And they are to meet this Aftdrnoon, Tit Five of the Lfock, in The 'Speaker’S Chambeh.

A Petition of tile Proprietors anfl Occupiers of Petition Lands, Mills, and others,-in the ^Shire of Lanerk, in against the the Neighbourhood of she Jlienkl&nd Navigation, thereunto subscribing, was presented Ho tile House, Bilh*

and read; taking Notice of 'the Bill for forming a b Junction between the’ForM an H^ClydeNavigation and the Monkland Navigation, 'antUfor altering, enlarging, v' *' r Und

Petition against the Tobacco Act.

Petition against Croydon ami God-stone Roads Bill.

30Geq.HI. 12° Aprilis.

and explaining, several former Acts passed for making and maintaining the said Navigations; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners will be greatly injured by the said Bill, if the same should pass iuto a Law: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the said Bill may not pass into a Law, and that tlxe Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard,' at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, being Merchants, Manufacturers, and Traders, of the City and Liberty of Westminster, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to bear their Share of the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a Temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they me declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereofAnd therefore praying, That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this Free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for " granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Parley Comer, beyond. Croydon, in the Copaty of Surrey, through Merstham, to the Bproygh of Reigate, and from Godslone by £odstom House, in the said

County, through the Borough of Reigate to '

Mill Gate, and to Buckland Church, in the said County;

and that the Petitioners have borrowed very considerable Sums of Money on the Credit of the 'Foils granted by the said Act, ?nd are now greatly in Debt, and, in case the said Bill should pass into a Law, it will be highly prejudicial to* the Interest of the Trust under which the Petitioners act, and to the several Persons who have advanced Money on the Credit of the said Tolls: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves, their Agents, pr Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that they may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be brought in.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for foe House Committee to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, on Longitud# upon the Bill for continuing the Encouragement and u ' Reward of Persons making certain Discoveries fbtr finding the Longitude at Sea, or making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating thereto, and for adding a Commissioner to execute the several Acts for the Discovery of the Longitude at Sea, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into thp said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Stephens took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Stephens reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made an Amendment thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

A Petition of the Trustees for putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty; intituled, ‘‘ An Act for more effectually repairing the Roads leading from the Stones End in Blackman Street, in the " Borough of Southwark, in the County of Surrey, to " Highgate, in the County of Susses, and to Sutton " and Kingston, and from Vauxhall Bridge through " Stockwell to Brixton Causeway, and from Newington " to the East End of Peckham Lane, and from Camberwell Green to the Fox wider the Hill, in the County " of Surrey, and for repealing so much of several " Acts now in Force as relates to the said Roads, and " for repairing the Road from Highgate aforesaid to 11 Witchross, in the County of Sussex," was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that a Bill is ordered to be brought in for making a Turnpike Road from Vox, 43,

Manchester Mr. Bldckburne reported from the Committee, -to Poor Petition whom the Petition of the Churchwardens, Ovefseers reported. Poor, and principal Inhabitants of the Town of

Manchester, in the County of Lancaster, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the -Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk's Table: Where the same was read; and is as fulloweth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. John Bauman being examined, said, That from the present great Popnilousness of the Town of Manchester, and the daily Increase of the Poor belonging to that Township, the Workhouse now used there is found to be much too small, and in all Respects unfit lor the Accommodation of the Poor that are from Necessity sent thither. — And he added, That it is proposed to take down the present Workhouse, and to build a new one in a more convenient Situation, and that further jtegulations are wanting for the better Government of the said Poor.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for providing a new Poor House for, and for the better Relief and Government of, the Poor of the Township of Manchester, in the County of Lancaster: And that Mr. Blackburne and Mr. Thomas Stanley do prepare, and bring in, the same.

.Road and Sir James Penny man reported from the Committee,

h"8ha?.In" to whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing Part of a reported.1 certain Common or Waste Land, called Road Common, within the Manor of Road and Langham, in the Parishes of Road and North Bradley, in the Counties of Somerset and Wilts, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and tound the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Owners of Estates entitled to Right of Common on the Land to be inclosed of the Annual Value of 3411. 4 s.who had no Objection to the Inclosure, but did not chuse to sign the Bill; and also, except the Owners of Estates of the Annual Value of 189/. 15$. 6d. who refused to sign the Bill; and that the Annual Value of all the Property entitled to Right of Common on the said Land is 1,025/. 16#. or thereabouts; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That! the Bill, with the Amendments, be in grossed.

Petition A Petition of the Right honourable William Lord agaioet the Viscount Dudley and Ward, and the humble Petition Md*Wor- she several other Persons whose Names are there-ctster canal unto subscribed, Owners and Proprietors of Coal Bill. Mines lying upon, of near to, the Line of the Stourbridge and Dudley Canals, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That Two Acts having passed in the Year 1776, for making the said Dudley and Stourbridge Canals, the greait Objects of which Navi-Vol. 45.

'gations were, by communicating with the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal at Stourton, to supply the City of Worcester, and the other Towns and Places on the River Severn, as also the Counties of Worcester, Gloucester, and Hereford, with Coals from the Mines lying upon, and near to, the Line of the said Stourbridge and Dudley Canals, the Petitioners, and those under whom they claim, were induced, at a very great Risque and Hazard, to open Collieries on the Line of the said Canals, and to lay out large Sums of Money in planting and establishing the same, and by Means thereof the City Of Worcester, and the Counties of.

Worcester, Gloucester, and Her ford, have been supplied with Coals from the Petitioners Mines in very large Quantities, and in a constant and regular Manner; and that the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that a Bill is depending in the House, for making a Canal from or near the Town of Birmingham to the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester, which Canal is calculated to give a Preference in the Severn Market to the Mines on the Line of the Birmingham Canal lying nearest to the Town of Birmingham, and will operate greatly to the Injury and Prejudice of the Petitioners, without any real Advantage to the Public:

And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves, or their Agents or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition thereunto subscribed, Owners and Occupiers of Water jign,n.8t d*e Mills, and other Works, upon the several Rivers, and Wcn-Bm Brooks, Streams, and Rivulets, lying between the cester Canal Town of Birmingham and the City of Worcester, and Bill, the Neighbourhood thereof, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed an Application is making to the House, for Leave to bring in a Bill for making a new Canal Navigation from the Town of Birmingham, to communicate with the River Severn, at or near the City of Worcester; and that, below the Line of such intended Canal, there are many Mills worked by Water flowing from various Springs and Brooks arising in and above the Line of such intended Canal, at which Mills very extensive Trades and Manufactories are carried on, and large Sums of Money have been expended in planting and establishing such Works and Manufactories, and the Support and Maintenance of a large Body of Manufacturers and Labourers, their Wives and Children, depend on such Works; and that the present Supply of Water is not fully sufficient for the necessary Uses of the said Mills and Works, and, in case the said intended Canal should take place, the same must unavoidably intercept and take away great Part of the Resources of Water which now feed and support the Brooks and Streams from whence the said Mills are supplied, and thereby such Mills and Works will be very considerably injured, if not wholly ruined, and the Trade lost; and that the Petitioners apprehend no Advantage is likely to be derived to the Public from the said intended Canal adequate to the Injury which the Petitioners, and others, will unavoidably sustain thereby:

And therefore praying,-That such Bill may not pSss into a Law, and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the same.

A Petition of the principal Inhabitants of the Town Ditto, and Neighbourhood of Bromsgroce, in the County of Worcester, was likewise presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Application mentioned in the last preceding Petition: And praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or froth near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the 5 E County

" An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and " Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof: " And therefore praying. That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, and particularly

said Petitions.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

The House was moved, That the Entry in the Votes Instruction of the House, of the 5th Day of March last, of the toCoromitte* Petition of RichardBenyon, Esquire, and the Reverend church Bill

Peter Beauvoir, Rector of the Parish of Saint John,

Hackney, in the County of Middlesex (Lords of the

men of the Borough of Derby, was presented to the Manor, and Patrons of the Rectory, of Hackney afore'

said, as Trustees and Devisees in Fee under the Will of Francis John Tyssen, Esquire, deceased) and of several Owners of Lands and Estates, and principal Inhabitants within the said Parish, which Petition was then ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the Bill for taking down the Church

House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but, the Petitioners' are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Re- and Tower belonging to the Parish of Hackney, in the venue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be County of Middlesex, and for building another Church to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and Tower for the Use of the said Parish, and for

and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity enlarging the Cemetery or Church Yard thereto,

of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very is committed, might be read.

End for which they are declared to be introduced, And the same being read accordingly.;

and in this Light the Petitioners regal'd an Act, Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Compassed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, mittee, That they, have Power to make Provision in 07 . the

Longitude Mr. Stephens, according to Order, reported from the Bill reported. Committee of the/ whole House, to whom the Bill for x continuing the Encouragement and Reward of Persons

making certain Discoveries for finding the Longitude at Sea, or making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating thereto, and for adding a Commissioner to execute the several Acts for the Discovery of the Longitude at Sea, was committed, the Amendment which the Committee had made to the Bill; and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendment, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendment was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered \That the Bill, with the Amendment, be

ingrossed.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to continue the several Laws therein mentioned, relating to encouraging the Manufacture of Leather, by lowering the Duty payable upon the Importation of Oak Bark, when the Price of such Bark slia 1 exceed a certain Rate; to the prohibiting the Exportation of Tools and Utensils made Use of in the Iron and Steel Manufactures of this Kingdom, and to prevent the seducing of Artificers and Workmen, employed in those Manufactures, to go into Parts beyond the Seas; and, to the ascertaining the Strength of Spirits by Clarke's Hydrometer.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill

to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Accounts The House being informed that Mr. from

Tobacco*" the Commissioners of Excise, attended at the Door, he presented, was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

An Account of the Quantity of Manufactured Tobacco and Snuff, which appears by the Returns of the Officers of Excise to have been consumed in,

from the loth Day of October 1789 to the 17th Day of March 1790^ being the latest Period to which the same can be made up: And also,

An Account of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Manufacturers of Tobacco or Snuffy together with the Produce of the Duties on such Licences; and also, of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Dealers in Tobacco and Snuff, together with the Produce of the Duties on such Licences; And also,

An Account of the Quantity of Tobacco, Tobacco Stalks, and Snuff, of every Description, Specification, or Denomination, manufactured, unmanufactured, and in Operation, in Possession of all the Manufacturers, Cutters, and Grinders of, and Dealers in, Tobacco and Snuff) in England,at the first Time of Stock taking by the Officer after the Commencement of the Tobacco Excise Act; and also a similar Account at the last Time of Stock taking.

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Accounts be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Accounts be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of tire several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Reports, in Ordered, That the Reports, which, upon the 26th 1758 and Day of May 1758, and the nth Day of April 1759, red to Com- were ma<^e from the Committees appointed to enquire mitteeon into the original Standards of Weights and Measures Weights and in this Kingdom, be referred to the Committee who Measures. are appointed to consider the several Returns which have been, or shall be, made to the Orders of this House, of the# 5th Day of February last, respecting the different Weights and Measures now in Use in the several Cities and Market Towns throughout England and Wales, and the Town of Berwick upon Txveed.

Trade.

Committee The House, according to Order, resolved itself into on Slave a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relativfe to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir William Young took the Chair of the Committee. Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir William Young reported from the Committee, That they had heard Counsel to sum up, and observe upon, the Evidence given in Support of the Petition of the Merchants trading to Africa from the Port of Liverpool, and of the several other Petitions from the Town of Liverpool; and that he was directed by the

Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Sevennight, the 23d Day of this Instant April, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

A Petition of the several Owners of Vessels, Barge- Petition masters, Carriers, and others, Traders upon the River against the Severn, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was anTworces presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of ter Canal the Bill for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal Bill, from, or from near to, the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester; and Setting forth, That there has been already completed one Communication by Water from the Town of Birmingham to Worcester, by Means of the present Birmingham, and the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canals, which latter Canal tails into the River Severn at pourt, and another Communication is now making, and nearly finished, between those Places and the several Coal Mines on the Line of the said Birmingham Canal, by Means of the Junction of the Dudley and Birmingham Canals at Tipton; and that the Object of making such Canals was not only to convey Coals from the Mines lying on the different Lines thereof into the Severn Market, but also to connect,the several Branches of Inland Navigation with the River Severn, and thereby form a general Communication for the Conveyance of Goods and Merchandize between the Ports of Bristol, Hull, and Liverpool, and the Towns of Birmingham, Wolverhampton, and other manufacturing Towns and Places on the Line of such Canals, and the City of Worcester, and other Towns and Places on the Banks of the River Severn, and which has been accordingly effected, and the Public have been greatly benefited thereby; and that the River Severn is a free Navigation, formed by Nature, and of the greatest Importance to the Trade and Commerce of this Kingdom, but, in dry Seasons, it is often deficient in Water for navigating Vessels of heavy Burthen, and the Petitioners conceive the Project of making the said intended Canal from Birmingham to Worcester is. not founded on Principles either of Necessity or Public Utility; and that the Petitioners understand that the Supply of Water, necessary for the said proposed Canal, is to be taken out of the River Secern, the doing whereof will occasion an irreparable Injury to the Navigation of the said River, and be highly injurious to the Petitioners, and to the Public: And therefore praying. That they may. be heard, by themselves, their Agents, or Counsel, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morn- Bill respecting, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, ing Seizures upon the Bill to authorize the Commissioners of the deferred-Customs to defray Charges on Seizures out of His Majesty’s Share of Seizures in general.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

30 Gao. III.

Petition in fa\our of th Birmingham and \\ i trees* terCanalBili.

Petition against the Tobacco Act.

Ditto.

14° Apritis.

389

Merctarii, 14° die Aprilis;

Anno 30’ Georgii III'11 Regis, 1790.

Prayers.

A PETITION of the Mayor, Aldermen, Citizens, and principal Inhabitants of the City of Gloucester, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill lor making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from, or from near to, the Town of,

in the County of Warwick, to communicate with the River Severn, near to the City of Worcester: And praying that the same may pass into a Law.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the Person thereunto subscribing, being the only Manufacturer of Tobacco and Snuff in the City of Gloucester, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act of Parliament passed last Session, intituled, "An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereof," a new System is introduced, whereby the Manufactory is rendered difficult, tedious, expensive, dangerous, unprofitable, and ruinous; difficult, because the Act obliges the Manufacturer to work by a fixed Rule, which, although it may appear easy upon Theoretical Principles falsely founded, never can be practicable on the Article of Tobacco, being in its very Nature fluctuant — It is rendered tedious and expensive by the numberless Weighings, Re-weighings, taking of Stock, Notices, Declarations, and Counter-Declarations, all unnecessary, oppressive, and futile; dangerous, unprofitable, and ruinous, because the Act contains no less than Thirty-two Penalties in the Manufacturing Part, amounting to the enormous Sum of 2,390/., besides Forfeiture of Goods, the greatest Number of which the best of Judges, and the most careful honest Man, cannot avoid: That the Petitioner, notwithstanding he has paid the legal Duties on all his Tobacco, has, nevertheless, under the Operation of the said Act, incurred Penalties in his Manufactory, which no human Foresight could have avoided (without rendering the Goods unfit for Sale) to the Amount of 8,0001, and upwards, and, had it not been for a partial Suspension of the Act, must have been the total Ruin of himself and Family — It is ruinous also, because it defeats its own professed Purpose, for, instead of suppressing Smuggling, it has erected an Asylum for it in One Department, and generated a new and successful Mode in another — It is ruinous also, because it expressly prohibits a Manufacturer from selling nearly One Third of his Stock (Tobacco Stalks) because it says, he shall not send them to a Port of Importation, which, Nineteen Times out of Twenty, is his only Market, and the Petitioner has, at this Moment, a large Stock on Hand which he cannot sell, owing to the Operation of the Act in this particular Instance — It is ruinous also, because it exposes and destroys all the Manufacturers Secrets, which have been of inestimable Value to them, and have, for many Years, proved a Source of great and increasing Revenue to this Kingdom: And therefore praying, That the said Act may be repealed, and the Duties reduced, because the Petitioner conceives no other Measure can now be adopted to secure the Manufacture of Tobacco and Snuff to this Country.

A Petition of the Master, Wardens, and Commonalty of Merchant Venturers of the City of Bristol, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully convinced the Vox.. 4 3.

Laws of Excise are not only hostile to our free and happy Constitution, but that they depress the Spirit of Trade and Manufacture, on which the National Opulence depends, and although the Revenue mayderive a temporary Increase from their Exertion, yet it will most certainly, in the Event, wholly defeat the Purpose it was intended to promote; and that the Petitioners apprehend, from the Experience of the Manufacturers of Tobacco In the said City, that the Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, applying to them this System of Laws, is extremely oppressive, and subjects the fair Trader to Penalties, which, with all his Caution, he cannot avoid: And therefore praying, That the said Act may be repealed; and that the Excise Laws may not b further extended, to the Destruction of those Princip.es of Liberty which distinguish this Nation from arbitrary Governments.

A Petition of the Traders of the Borough oi Newbury Petition and Speenhamland, in the County of Berks, was also "P‘nst presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That 10 acco 1 the Petitioners are folly sensible of the Necessity of raising a ll'evenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but that the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, they will ultimately tend to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereofAnd therefore praying, That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing. Ditto, being the Traders and Inhabitants of the Town of Sheffield \was also presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they were declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, *An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff', and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereofAnd therefore praying, That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, ana particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, rjjtto. being principal Traders or Inhabitants of the Borough of Knaresborough, in the County of York, was likewise presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but; the Petitioners are convinced, however the

5 G Rigour

Answer to Address.

390 14° Aprilis. A. 1790.

Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase to the Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco " and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in Lieu " thereofAnd therefore praying, That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act " for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, " and for granting new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

to acquaint this House, that He will give Directions accordingly.

relates to the marking of Silver Wares, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Samuel Smith, Mr. Martin, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

The said Account is as followeth; vis.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Holford and Mr. Montagu:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and allotting the Open and Commonable Lands, within the Manor of Deverill Long-bridge, Hussey Deverill, and Monkton Deverill, in the County of Wilts; without any Amendment; And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for embanking the Common Salt Marsh within the Parishes of Terrington Stunt and Terrington

Saint Johns, in the County of Norfolk, and for dividing and inclosing the same, and other Commons within the said Parishes; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to enlarge the Terms and Powers of Three several Acts, made in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of King George the First, the Twenty-first Year Of the Reign of King George the Second, and the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Bromsgrove, in the County of Worcester, to the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick; without any Amendment.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

An ingrossed Bill for dividing and inclosing Part of a certain Common or Waste Land, called Road Common, within the Manor of Road and Langham, in the Parishes of Road and North Bradley, in the Counties of Somerset and Wilts, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for dividing and inclosing Part of a certain Common ’or Waste Land, called Road Common, within the Manor of Road and Langham, in the Parishes of Road and North Bradley, in the Counties of Somerset and Wilts.

Ordered, That Sir James Pennyman do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

An ingrossed Bill for continuing the Encouragement and Reward of Persons making certain Discoveries for finding the Longitude at Sea, or making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating thereto, and for adding a Commissioner to execute the several Acts for the Discovery of the Longitude at Sea, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for continuing the Encouragement and Reward of Persons making certain Discoveries for finding the Longitude at Sea, or making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating thereto, and for adding a Commissioner to execute the several Acts for the Discovery of the Longitude at Sea.

Ordered, That Mr. Stephens do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, be nowr read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Account of the Monies which have been issued to Henry Bradley, Esquire, for the Expence of maintaining and guarding Convicts in the Harbour of Hamoaze, at Plymouth, and which, have not been made good by Parliament, be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Henry Hobart also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

A Petition of Samuel Sagar, of Bradford, in the County of York, Gentleman, Proprietor of the Water Works for supplying the Town of Leeds, in the said County, with W ater, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That a Bill is depending in the House, to enable Commissioners to convey Water into the said Town of Leeds, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, whereby the Petitioner apprehends his Estate and Interest in the said Water Works will be greatly injured if the said Bill should pass into a Law: And therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, but that the Petitioner may be heard,

by his Counsel, against the passing of such Bill, and be permitted to send for such Persons and Papers, and at such Time, as to the House shall seem meet

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Report be received from the Committee, to whom the Bill for better supplying the Town and Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with Water; and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, is committed; and that the Petitioner be then heard, by his Counsel, against the said Bill, upon his Petition, if he thinks fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Committee to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, 311,1

to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Account of the Monies remaining Account of

in the Exchequer, on the 5th Day of 1790, of co^ndated the Surplusses, Excesses, or Overplus Monies, and other pun(j re_ Revenues of the Fund, commonly called The Consoli- ferred. dated Fund, for the Disposition of Parliament, after satisfying the several Charges and Incumbrances thereupon, be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Henry Hobart took, the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

The Order of the Day being read, for the Second Reading of the Bill for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgow over certain adjoining Lands, for

Vo l. 45.

paving, lightning, and cleansing, the Streets, and for regulating the Police of the said City, and for giving certain Power to the Magistrates of Glasgow for the Benefit of the said City;

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Petitions Heretors, Burgesses, Householders, or Residenters, in *8"n,t the City of Glasgow, was presented to the House, and p0^e Bill; read; taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth.

That the Petitioners are of Opinion, That it will not be for the Interest of the said City, or the Inhabitants thereof, if the said Bill should be passed into a Law:

And therefore praying to be heard by Cotinsel against the said Bill.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing,

Proprietors, Life-renters, or Tacksmen, of Houses,

Lands, and Burying Grounds, in the City of Glasgow, in Behalf of themselves, and others, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed, it is proposed by the said Bill to take from them certain Lands, Houses, Burying Grounds, or other Landed Property, in which they have an Interest, for the Purpose of opening new and widening Old Streets in the said City, and the Petitioners are surprized that such a Bill should have been brought into the House without any Application being made to them for their Consent, or any'Notice, either public or private, having been given to them by the Persons on whose Application the said Bill has been brought in; and that the Petitioners conceive they will be materially injured, if the said Bill should be passed into a Law: And therefore praying. That they may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill, and that they may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time; and the Petitioners are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

A Motion was made, and the Question being pro- Second Read-posed, That the said Bill be now read a Second Time. "8 deferred.

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Question; viz.

To leave out the Word " nowr," and at the End of the Question to add the Words " upon Tuesday " Morning next."

And the Question being put, That the Word " now’’stand Part of the Question;

It passed in the Negative.

And the Question being put, That the Words " upon Tuesday Morning next" be added at the End of the Question;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

Then the main Question, so amended, being put;

Ordered, That the said Bill be read a Second Time upon Tuesday Morning next.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

That in pursuance of Leave granted by the House, upon the 26th Day of March last, Notice hath been given, at the last Easter Quarter Sessions of the Peace holden for the said County, of Application having been made to Parliament for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from Merthyr Tidvile to, or near to, the Town of Cardiff, in the said County, in such Manner as is required to he given by the Standing Orders of the House of the 20th Day of 1789, of Applications intended to be made relative to Navigation Bills: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making and maintaining the said Canal, by such Ways ana Means, and under such. Regulations, as the House shall think proper.

Clayworth Mr. Pierrepont reported from the Committee, reorted681* *° w^om ^e Bill for dividing, allotting, inclosing, repor ‘ and regulating, certain Open Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Carrs, Commons, and Waste Grounds, within the Township and Parish of Clayworth, in the County of Nottingham, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Owners of Lands, whose Property is assessed to the Land Tax at 2/. 155. 7 per Annum, Who had not been applied to for their Consent; and also, except the Owner of Lands, whose Property is rated at 15 per Annum, who refused to sign the Bill; and that the

ot

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, petition* being Grocers and Traders, and Dealers in Tobacco, against the in the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick: Tobacco Act And also,

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, being Inhabitants of the Borough of Devizes, in the County of Wilts: And also,

A Petition of the Persons thereunto Subscribing, being the Manufacturers and Traders of the City of Canterbury: And also,

A Petition Of the Persons thereunto subscribing,

Traders and Inhabitants of the City of Chester;

Were severally presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully Sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigences of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereofAnd therefore praying, that the saihe may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to Whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled,

" An Act for repealing the Duties on " Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting ,c new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

over Henlow Bridge, to Arlesey and also the Road from Shefford Way Post to the Turnpike Road at Henlow, in the County of Bedford, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, in pursuance of Leave given by the House, upon the 30th Day of March last. Notices have been given at the last Easter Quarter Sessions of the Peace, holden for the Counties of Hertford and Bedford, that Application had been made to Parliament for Leave to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and enlarging the Powers, of the said Acts, in such and the like Manner as is required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, of Applications intended to be made relative to Turnpike Bills: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and enlarging the Powers, of the said Acts, for such Time, and in such Manuer, as the House shall think proper.

And it is referred to Mr. Mr. Whitbread,

&c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

And the Titles of the said Accounts were read.

Ordered, That the said Accounts do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

The House being informed that Mr. Irving, from Accounts re* the Commissioners of Excise in Scotland, attended at latingtoTo-the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, pre- bacc°presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders, senw '

An Account of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Manufacturers of Tobacco or Snuff, together with the Produce of the Duties on such Licences; and also, of the Number of Persons who have taken out Licences as Dealers in Tobacco and Snuff, together with the Produce of the Duties on such Licences: And also,

And then he withdrew.

And the Titles of said Accounts were read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Accounts be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Accounts be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is re-- ferred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing " the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting " new Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

The said Accounts are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Mr. Henry Hobart, according to Order, reported Report from tire Committee of the whole House, to whom it Supply, was referred to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where tire same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Two hundred Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, which has been issued to the Secretary of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of all such Persons who have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand Nine hundred Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, which has been issued to the Secretary of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of the American Loyalists.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Two thousand Nine hundred and Fifty-one Pounds One Shilling and Ten Pence, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, which has been issued in Consequence of the Expences incurred in carrying ;on the Prosecution against Warren Hastings, Esquire.:

Resolved, That it, is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, which has been issued to defray the Expences of executing an Act, of the last Session of Parliament, for enquiring into the Emoluments of the Officers of the Customs.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand Six hundred and Thirty-two Pounds Six Shillings and Three Pence Three Farthings, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, issued to Thomas Cotton, Esquire, to pay Bills of Exchange, and other Purposes, by the Direction of the Commissioners of the Treasury.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Three thousand One hundred and Sixty-two Pounds Five Shillings and Six Pence, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, paid to Thomas D and Jeremy Pembei'-

ton. Esquires, Commissioners appointed to esquire, in America, into the Losses of American Sufferers.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Thirty thousand Five hundred and Twenty Pounds Seventeen Shillings and One Penny, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, issued to the Earl of Effingham, for defraying the Extraordinary Expences of His Majesty’s Mint in the Tower of London, in the Year 1788.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Fifty-one thousand Six hundred and Thirty-eight Pounds Six Shillings and Eleven Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Expence of sending Provisions, and sundry Articles, to the Settlements in New South Wales.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Nine hundred and Ten Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum, which has been issued to Henry Hughs, Esquire, for printing the Reports of the Lords of the Committee of Council concerning the present State of the Trade to Africa.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Two hundred and Thirty-one thousand Five hundred and Seventeen Pounds Twelve Shillings and Two Pence Farthing, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the Deficiency of the Grants for the Service of the Year 1789.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Six thousand Three hundred and Seventy-six Pounds Seventeen Shillings and Six Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for detraving the Charge of the Civil Establishment of the Province of Nova Scotia, in America, from the 1st Day of January 1790 to the 1st Day of January 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, New Bruns-That a Sum, not exceeding Four thousand Four hun- wicfc* dred Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Civil Establishment of the Province of New Brunswick, in America, from the 24th Day of jMwe'1790 to the 24th Day of June 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, St. John’s That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand Eight hun- kindred and Forty Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Civil Establishment of the Island of Saint John, in America, from the 1st Day of January 1790 to the 1st Day of January 179*-

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Cape Breton. That a Sum, not exceeding Two thousand One hundred Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Civil Establishment of the Island of Cape Breton, in America, from the 24th Day of June 1790 to the 24th Day of June 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Newfouud-That a Sum, not exceeding One thousand One hun- *and* dred'and Eighty-two Pounds Ten Shillings, be granted to His Majety, for defraying the Charge of the Salaries of the Governor and Civil Officers in the Island of Newfoundland, from the 1st Day of April 1790 to the 1st Day of April 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Bahama That a Sum, not exceeding Four thousand and Eighty islands. Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of supporting the Civil Establishment of the Bahama Islands, in Addition to the Salaries now paid to the public Officers out of the Duty Fund, and other incidental Charges attending the same, from the 1st Day of January 1790 to the 1st Day of January 1791-

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Bermuda That a Sum, not exceeding Five hundred and Eighty Islands. Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Salary to the Chief Justice of the Bermuda or Somers Islands, from the 24th Day of June 1790 to the 24th Day of June 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Dominica. That a Sum, not exceeding Six hundred Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Salary to the Chief Justice of the Island of Dominica, from the 1st Day of January 1790 to the 1st Day of January 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Establish-That a Sum, not exceeding Four thousand Five hundred and Fifty-eight Pounds Seven Shillings and Eight Pence, be granted to His Majesty, for defraying the Charge of the Civil Establishment in New South Wales, from the 10th Day of October 1790 to the 10th Day of October 1791.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, African Fort*. That a Sum, not exceeding Thirteen thousand Pounds, be granted to His Majesty, to be employed in repairing, maintaining, and supporting, the British Forts and Settlements on the Coast of Africa.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.
