liowbrickhill Mr. Bernard reported from the Committee, to whom . the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open and Com-and re-common Fields, Meadows, Heath, and Waste Grounds, uitted. within the Parish of Bo and Hamlet of Fenny Stratford, in the County of Buckingham, was committed; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with, except that One of the Notices was affixed upon the Church Door of Bletchley (within which Parish the Hamlet of Fenny Stratford lies) on the 4th of October last, but that all the Parties, interested in the Inclosure within the said Hamlet, are consenting to the Bill; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietor of 8 Acres; and that the whole Property consists of 1,924 Acres; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table; ''Where the Report was read.

And the House being informed that several other Amendments are necessary to be made to the said

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Question; viz.

To leave out the Word "now," and at the End of the Question to add the Words "upon this Day Three " Months."

And the Question being put, That the Word " now" stand Part of the Question;

The House divided:

The Noes went forth.

Tellers for the Yeas,

Telle, for he Noes, *

So it passed in the Negative:

And the Question being put, That the Words " upon " this Day Three Months" be added at the End of the Question;

It was resolved in the Affirmative:

Then the main Question, so amended, being put;

Cotton End,to a Lane opposite a Farm House, called Saint Leonard's,leading into the Turnpike Road from

Saint Albans to the Town of Bedford, and the Road from the Turning out of the aforesaid Road into Hen-law Field,to Oerford Bridge, and from the Town of Henlow over Henlow Bridge, to Arksey, and also the Road from Shefford JVay Post to the Turnpike Road at Henlow, in the County of Bedford, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, arid bad directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report ia his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same wee read; and is as followeth; vis.

To prove the Allegations of the Said Petition, Mr. Daniel Tunes informed your Committee, That Notices of aa Application to Parliament for Leave to bring in a Bill for continuing the Terns and enlarging the Powers of the said Acts, were affixed on the Dears of the Sessions Houses of the Counties of Her ford and Bedford, agreeable to the Leave granted by the House upon the 30th Day of March last The House was moved, That the Report which, apon the 30th Day of March last, was made from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several Trustees for putting in Execution Two Acts of Parliament, made in the Thirtieth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty, and the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Hitchin, in the County of Hertford, through She ford, to the Turnpike Road from Saint Albans to and from She ford Way Post to the Turnpike Road at Hen-

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of certain Acts for repairing the Road from the Town of Hitchin, through Shefford, to the Turnpike Road from St. Albans to Bedford, and other Roads therein mentioned, in the Counties of Hertford and Bedford: And that Mr.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Petition being the Traders of the Borough and Town of Marl- against the borough. Wills, was presented to the House, and read; Twbacco Act* Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for " granting new Duties in lieu thereof:" And therefore praying. That the same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, and to the Subversion of the dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under this free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, be- Ditto, ing the Traders in Tobacco and Snuff of the City of Coventry, was also presented to the House, and read;

Containing the same Allegations and Prayer as the preceding Petition.

A Petition of the Mayor, Burgesses, and Com* Ditto, ntonalty, of the City of Bristol, in Common Council assembled, was also presented to' the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Petitioners are sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are willing to bear their Share of the Public Burthen, yet they cannot refrain expressing their Fears and Apprehensions at the alarming and increasing Extension of the Excise Laws, which, they are fully convinced, are inimical to the true Spirit of Trade, and injurious to the Liberty of the Subject; and that the Petitioners are satisfied, from Undoubted Information, that the System of Excise Cannot be continued in its Application to the Manufacture of Tobacco, without great Obstruction to the Manufacturer in his Operations, and a most grievous Addition of Expence in prosecuting his Business: And therefore praying, That the Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repeated, and that there be no further Adoption of the System of Excise, so hostile and injurious to those dearest Rights and Privileges which they claim under the free ana happy Constitution of this Country.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Ditto, being Traders within the Town of Bridgnorth, in the County of SiUup, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of die State, and are ready, in an equal and Contitutional Manner, to contribute their 04 Share

Petition against the Tobacco Act.

Share -to the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the County, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties in " Lieu thereof:" And therefore praying, That the same may be repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended.

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, being Inhabitants of Doncasterin the County of York, was likewise' presented to the House, and read; Set ting forth. That the Petitioners are fully sensible of the Necessity of raising a Revenue adequate to the Exigencies of the State, and are ready, in an equal and Constitutional Manner, to contribute their Share to the Public Burthen, but the Petitioners are convinced, however the Rigour of the Excise Laws may Cause a temporary Increase of Revenue, that their ultimate and certain Effect will be to diminish the Trade and Manufactures of the Country, and thereby to strike at the Root of the Prosperity of this great Commercial Nation, and defeat the very End for which they are declared to be introduced, and in this Light the Petitioners regard an Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties " in Lieu thereof:" And therefore praying, That the Same may be forthwith repealed, and that the Excise Laws may not be further extended, to the Destruction of the Trading and Manufacturing Spirit of the Country, under this free Constitution, and particularly the Right of Trial by Jury.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the > Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament,

intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties on " Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new " Duties in Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

A Petition of John Pate NeoUe, of , in the County of York, Esquire, was presented to the House,

and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for better supplying the Town and Neighbourhood of , in the County of York, with Water, and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein; and Setting forth, That the Petitioner is the Owner or Proprietor of certain ancient Water Corn and Soke Mills, at or near Leeds, called The King's Mills, and, as such is entitled to the Use of the Water in the River Aire, near Leeds, for the Purpose of working the said Mills, and is also the Owner or Proprietor of divers Lands, and other Hereditaments, at or near Leeds aforesaid; and that, if the said Bill should pass into a Law as it now stands, the same will not only greatly injure the Petitioner’s Mills, but will also be very prejudicial to his other Property at or near Leeds aforesaid: And therefore praying, That he may he heard, by himself, or his Agent, or Counsel, against such Parts of the said Bill as may affect his Property.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioner be heard, by

Vol. 45.

himself, his Agent, or Counsel^ before the said Coin-mi ttee, upon his Petition, if he thinks fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

Sir Matthew White Ridley reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Owners of Ships using the Coal Trade in the Port of Newcastle, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on behalf of themselves and other Ship Owners using the Coal Trade in the Ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, several Acts, passed in the Sixth, Thirteenth, and Twenty-second Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for regulating the loading of Ships with Coals in the Ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, were read: And,

Mr. William Ward being examined, said, That the said first-mentioned Act has proved to be of great Public Utility, and that the Continuance thereof will be of great Advantage to the Coal Trade.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue at Act, made in the Sixth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, "An Act to regulate " the loading of Ships with Coals in the Ports of " Newcastle and Sunderland:" And that Sir Matthew White Ridley, Mr. Brandling, and Mr. do pre-

pare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Owners or Occupiers of Lands, Houses, Burgages, or Tenements, within, or near unto, the City of Durham and Borough of Framwelgate, and the Suburbs thereof, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and Public Passages and Places, within the City of Durham and Borough of Framwelgate, and the Suburbs thereof, for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and Public Passages and Places, and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs; and Setting forth. That the Petitioners conceive that the said Bill is inexpedient and unnecessary, and, if passed into a Law, will be oppressive and injurious to them as Owners or Occupiers of Lands, Houses, and Tenements, within, or near to, the said City of Durham and Borough of Framwelgate: And therefore praying, That they maybe heard, by themselves or Counsel, at the Bar of the House, against the said BiH, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Report be received from the Committee, to whom the aatd Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be then beard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

A Petition of several Persons whose Names are Petitioti thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and against others, Owmers and Proprietors of Messuages, Cottages,

Lands, and Tenements, within the Manor and Township af>e of Wortley, in the Parish of Leeds, in the West Riding of the County of York, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners are informed, that John Smyth, Esquire, Lord of the said Manor of Wortley, hath presented a Petition for Leatfe to bring in a Bill for consecrating a Chapel, lately erected on a certain Green, called Wortley Green, being Parcel of the Waste of the said Manor, and also for vesting the Common or Waste Ground, called Wortley Green, in him the said John Smyth, and his Heirs, Lord of the said Manor of Wortley, for the Time being; and that the Petitioners have an indisputable Right of Common upon the said Common or Waste Ground, called Wortley Green, and they conceive that the vesting the said Common and Waste Ground in the said John Smyth and his Heirs will very materially injure and prejudice their respective Estates in the said Manor and Township, by taking away and destroying their Right of Common upon the said Common and Waste Ground: And therefore praying, That in case a Bill should be brought in, pursuant to any such Petition, that they may be heard, by their Counsel and Witnesses, to Oppose the same, or that the Petitioners may have such further Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until a Bill be brought in, pursuant to the Prayer of the Petition of John Smyth, Esquire, Lord of the Manor of Wortley, in the Parish of Leeds, in the West Riding of the County of York.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

The said Account is as followethviz.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

An ACCOUNT of Monies paid into the Exchequer, in Part of Interest on the Sum of One hundred Eighty-seven thousand Pounds, raised by Annuities, by an Act 29* Georgii Tertii Rs. for the Year ended the 5th Day of April 1790.

The Monies paid into the Exchequer, in Part of Interest upon the above Principal Sum of One hundred Eighty-seven thousand Pounds, amount to the Sum of Eight thousand and Fifty-two Pounds Six Shillings.

Exchequer, the 16th Day of April 1790.

The House being informed that Mr. Irving, Inspector General of the Exports and Imports of Great Britain, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Order,

An Account, shewing the Average Quantities of Tobacco delivered out of His Majesty’s Warehouses in Great Britain, for Home Manufacture, and the Duties paid thereon, in the several Quarters ending the 5th of January, the 5th of April, the 5th of July, and the 10th of October, for Six Years preceding the 10th of October 1789; also the Quantities delivered out of His Majesty’s W arehouses, with the Duties' of Customs and Excise paid thereon, in the Quarters ending the 5th of January and 5th'’ of April 1790.

And then he withdrew.

And the Title of the said Account was read.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Account be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the said Account be referred to the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the several Petitions which have been presented to this House in this Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for repealing the Duties " on Tobacco and Snuff, and for granting new Duties " ia Lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

The said Account is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Mr. Secretary at War reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for rendering the Passage through the Town and Parish of Honiton, in the County of Devon, safe and commodious, and for paving, cleansing, lighting, and watching the Streets and other Places, and for removing and preventing Nuisances and Annoyances therein, was committed j That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House j and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, One of them was disagreed to, and the rest were, with Amendments to several of them, agreed to by the House; and several Amendments were made, by the House, to the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

The House being informed that Mr. Morion, from the Directors of the East India Company, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Orders,

N° 1. Copy of the Minute of Sir John Macpherson, on the Establishment of the Office of Sherishtader, entered on th cBengalRevenue Consultations, 4th July 1786: And also,

N° 2. Extract from the Bengal General Letter, Secret Department of Reform and Inspection, dated 28th August 1786, transmitting the Analysis of the Finances of Bengal, by James Grant, Esquire: And also,

N° 3. Copy of the Political Survey of the Northern Circars, by James Grant, Esquire, transmitted by the Bengal Government, in the Year 1786, to the Court of Directors.

Vol. 45.

Together with a List of the said Papers.

And then he withdrew.

And the said List was read.

Ordered, That the said Papers do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Papers are preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

Resolved, That this House will, at the Rising of H°use ad-the House this Day, adjourn till Monday Morning ^owLy*. next.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Supply de-to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, ferred. to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty* be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Wayrand to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, Means de-to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the ferred-Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition thereunto subscribed, Dealers by Retail in Spirituous a8a‘n8t the Liquors, and Inhabitants of the Town and Borough Liquors Li-of Southwark, and Parts adjacent, in the County of cence Act. Surrey, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That, by an Act, made in the Twenty-seventh Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, for laying additional Duties upon Licences to be taken out by Persons dealing by Retail in Foreign Spirituous Liquors, the Petitioners are obliged to take out an additional Licence Annually, for which they pay certain Sums, according to the Rent of the Houses occupied by them (that is to say) If the Rent is under Fifteen Pounds, 21. 8 s.; if Fifteen Pounds, and under Twenty Pounds, 2/. i6«.; and so on in Proportion to the Yearly Rent of Fifty Pounds, which pays 4/. 16$. and a House of One hundred Pounds, or upwards, per Annum, pays no more, and the Petitioners are required, by the said Act, to attend Eight Times in the Year at the Chief Office of Excise in London, to pay, by Installments, the Sums directed by the said Act; and that, before the passing of the said Act, the Legislature, in Consequence of the Commercial Treaty entered into with France, reduced the Duties upon Foreign Spirituous Liquors so low, as to enable the Petitioners to purchase Brandy of the best Quality at 7 s.6 d.per Gallon, upon an Average,

but which at this Time cannot be purchased for less that 12 s.per Gallon; and that the Petitioners understood that, the better to enable them to pay for the said Licences, all Smuggled condemned Spirituous Liquors were to be destroyed, but, instead thereof, such Liquors are now sold for the Accommodation of private Persons, in as small Quantities as Two Gallons, at the Custom House and Excise Sales, to Persons who are not Dealers, and who do not take out Licences; and that the Petitioners conceive the said Act, obliging them to take out such additional Licences, was passed in Consequence of the Duties upon Foreign Spirituous Liquors being reduced, which, it was apprehended, would greatly lessen the Revenue, but, the Petitioners are informed, the Revenue on such Spirits has since considerably increased; and that the Petitioners are ready and willing to concur in contributing, in common with their Fellow Subjects,

5 K to

Petition against Durham Paving BiH.

402

to the Exigencies of the State, yet they cannot but consider themselves as partially aggrieved by the Continuance of this additional (or Six Weeks) Licence Act, it being impossible for them to charge it on the Consumer, and, as the Petitioners are the only Persons who feel the Inconvenience and Expence of finding Quarters for Soldiers, and as they, as Dealers in Foreign Wines, are, by a late Act of Parliament, prohibited from dealing in Home-made Wines (generally called Sweets) by the Sale of which many of them used to make considerable Profits, they hope that the House will take their present oppressed Situation into Consideration: And therefore praying, That the said Act, of the Twenty-seventh Year of His present Majesty, may be repealed, or such other Relief granted them as the House shall think fit, and that they may be heard by themselves or Counsel, in Support of this Petition.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to- the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider of the Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunder written, Dealers by Retail in Spirituous Liquors, and Householders, residing in the City and Liberty of

1Vest minster, and Parts adjacent; and that the Petitioners be permitted to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, in Support of their Petition, if they think fit.

A Petition of the several Persons whose- Names are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves and others, Owners and Occupiers of Messuages, Bur-« gages. Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, within the City of Durham, and the Suburbs and Neighbourhood thereof, and also, of the Merchants, Dealers, and Traders, in the Town of Sunderland near the Sea, in the said County, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, within the City of Durham and Borough of and the

Suburbs thereof, for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners conceive, that several Clauses in the said Bill, if passed into a Law, will materially injure their Estates and Interests as Owners and Occupiers of Messuages, Burgages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, within the City of Durham, and the Suburbs and Neighbourhood thereof, and also as Merchants, Dealers, and Traders, as aforesaid: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves and Counsel, before the Committee to whom the Bill is now referred, against such particular Clauses thereof as they conceive will prove materially injurious to their Estates and Interests, and that the same may not pass into a Law, and that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

A. 1790.

The other Order of the Day being read;

The House resolved itself into a Committee of the Committee whole House, to consider further of the several Peti- " tions which have been presented to this House in this Tobacco Act. Session of Parliament, praying that the Act, passed in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and for " granting new Duties in lieu thereof," may be repealed or altered.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

And then the House, having continued to sit till Three of the Clock on Saturday Morning, adjourned till Monday Morning, Ten of the Clock.

" for repairing the Road from Sunderland near the " Sea to the City of Durham, in the County of Durham,"was presented to the House, and read; Taking

Notice of the Bill for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and Public Passages and Places within the City of Durham, and Borough of Framwelgate, and the Suburbs

thereof, for removing and preventing Nuisances,

Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and Public Passages and Places, and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners ebneeive that the said Bill, if passed into a Law, will be highly injurious to the Interests of the several Persons who have advanced Money upon Mortgage or Security on the Tolls arising from the said Road, and which Money has been lent by them upon the Faith of the said Acts of Parliament: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, at the Bar of the House, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such further Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves -and against par-others, Merchants, Shopkeepers, Dealers, and Traders, g1* 1>av,nS in the Town of Sunderland near the Sea, in the County of Durham, was also presented to the House, and read; likewise taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners conceive that the said Bill, if passed into a Law, will be oppressive and injurious to them in many Respects as Merchants, Shopkeepers, Dealers, and Traders, in Sunderland aforesaid: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, at the Bar of the House, against the said Bill, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and the Petitioners are to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Petitions A Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of Dwelling «"* Houses and Premisses in the Town of Leeds, in the Md Lighting County of York: And also,

Bill. Another Petition of the Owners and Occupiers of

Dwelling Houses and Premisses in the Town of Leeds, in the County of York;

Were severally presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for better supplying the Town and Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with Water, and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners are apprehensive, if the same should pass into a Law, it will be attended with a great Annual Expence to the Petitioners, and the other Inhabitants of the said Town and Neighbourhood of and that the Petitioners are now supplied with a sufficient Quantity of Water at a moderate Expence, and apprehend that the present Water Works are very able to continue such Supply to the Town and Neighbourhood of Leeds: And therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass into a Law, and that the Petitioners may be heard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill’s passing into a Law, in such Manner, and at such Time, as to the House shall seem meet.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Report be received from the Committee, to whom the said Bill is committed; and the Petitioners are to be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petitions, if they think fit.

Ordered, That Counsel be admitted to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petitions.

A Petition of the several Gentlemen, Freeholders, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being severally Owners of Estates and Inhabitants, within the several Counties of Bedford and Bucks, near the Roads herein after described, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, in pursuance of Leave granted by the House on the Fifteenth Day of March last, Notices have been given at the last Easter Quarter Sessions of the Peace hold on for the Counties of Bedford and Bucks, and by Advertisements, in the Newspaper, called The Northampton of the

Application to Parliament for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Roads leading from Brom-ham Bridge, in the Parish of in the County of Bedford, through the Parishes of Turtey,

Bray field, Lavendon, Warrington, and to the

Turnpike Road leading from Wellingborough to Olney, and from the said Turnpike Road, at or near the South End of the Town of Olney, through the Parishes of Weston Underwood, Ravenstone, and Stoke Golding ton, to the Turnpike Road leading from the Town of Northampton to Next port Pagin the said County of Bucks, in such and the like Manner as are required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, of Applications intended to be made relative to Turnpike Bills: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for amending, widening, and keeping the said Roads in Repair, in such Manner as the House shall think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Brett, Mr. St. John,

&c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Mr. Williams reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of several of the Trustees for carrying into Execution an Act of Parliament, of the Ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from the Town of Denbigh, to the Turnpike Road between Northop and Holywell, and from Afon Wen to the Town of Mold, in the Counties of Denbigh and Flint,was referred; That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read: And,

Mr. Lewis Hughs, being examined, said, That the Trustees have proceeded in the Execution thereof, and have borrowed near 4,000l. upon the Credit of the Tolls, which still remains due — That the Roads cannot be effectually repaired, and the Money borrowed repaid, unless the Term of the said Act is further continued, and the Powers enlarged — That the said Act could be more effectually executed, if the Provisions thereof, and the Alterations necessary to be made therein, were comprized in One Act.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for more effectually amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Roads from the Town of Denbigh to the Turnpike Road between Northop and Holywell, and from Afon Wen to the Town of Mold, in the Counties of Denbigh and Flint: And that Mr. Williams and Sir Roger Mostyn do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Bill respecting Seizures deferred.

Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means

for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty. Mart is, 20° die Aprilis

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for " repealing the Duties on Tobacco and’ Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in Lieu thereof," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to explain and amend the said Act: And that Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. Edward James , the Earl of Mornington, the Lord the Lord

Apsley, Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Solicitor General, Mr. Rose, Mr. Steele, and Mr. do prepare,

and bring in, the same.

The Order of the Day being read, for receiving the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the several Accounts and Papers, which were presented to the House, upon the 19th Day of February and the 11th Day of March last, by Mr. Morton, from the Directors of the East India Company;

Ordered, That the said Report be received upon Tomorrow Sevennight, the 27th Day of this Instant April.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the Statement and Accounts, which were this Day presented to the House by Mr. Morton (from the Directors of the East India Company) be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies.

Resolved, That this House will. Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole Hoase, upon the Bill to authorize the Commissioners of the Customs to defray Charges on Seizures out of His Majesty’s Share of Seizures in general.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

MR. Bernard reported from the Committee, to Bowbrickhill whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Inclosure re-Opeti and Common Fields, Meadows, Heath, and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Bowbrickhill and Hamlet of Fenny Stratford, in the County of Buckingham, was re-committed; That the Committee had made several other Amendments to the Bill, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of several Owners and Occupiers of Petition for Houses within certain Streets and other Places within ?r?]^?ion the Parish of Saint James, and such Part of Coventry Westminster Street as lies within the Parish of Saint Martin in the Paving Bill. Fields, and Part of Princes Street, in the Parish of Saint Anne, within the Liberty of the City of Westminster, commonly called Optional Streets, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners find Application hath been made to the House, by the Commissioners for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Streets and other Places within the said City and Liberty and Parts adjacent, for Leave to bring in a Bill to enable them to enforce the Payment of the Rates authorized to be made by them within the Optional Streets in the Limits aforesaid now under their Care and Management; and that by an Act made in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the Power of paving, lighting, and cleansing the several Streets and other Places within the said Parish of Saint James (except the said Optional Streets) was taken out of the Hands of the said Commissioners, and vested in a certain Number of Committee-men to be Annually chosen by the Vestry of the said Parish, subject in some Respects to the Controul of the said Commissioners, but the said Optional Streets, and such Part of Coventry Street and Princes Street as aforesaid, have continued, and are now, under the sole Direction and Management of the said Commissioners; and that the Petitioners and the several other Inhabitants of the said Optional Streets have been, and now are, charged with higher Rates, for the several Purposes aforesaid, than the Inhabitants of the several other Streets and Places within the said Parish of Saint James are for the like Purposes, and the Petitioners apprehend that if the said Optional Streets were put under the Direction and Management of the said Committee-men, in like Manner as the said several other Streets within the said Parish of Saint James, the Works would be properly done at a much less Expence to the Inhabitants than they are now charged with; and that the Powers the said^ Committee-men are now invested with are not sufficient to enable them effectually to remove and prevent Annoyances by Projections, Encroachments, and otherwise, within the said Optional Streets, and in the other Streets and Places within the said Parish of Saint James, and it would be a great Convenience to all Persons passing along the said Streets and other Places, if such Annoyances were removed and prevented for the future: And therefore praying, That Provision may be made in the said Bill for effecting

Petition for Leave to present a Petition to amend the St. James's Burial Groiad Act

Leave given.

St. James’s Burial Ground Petition.

the several Purposes aforesaid, by such Ways and Means, and in such Manner, as the House shall think proper.

Ordered That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the Petition of the Commissioners for putting in Execution the several Acts of Parliament for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places, within the City and Liberty of , and

other Parts therein mentioned, is referred: And that they do examine the Matter of this Petition; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House.

A Petition of the Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the Rector, Churchwardens, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Trustees appointed to put in Execution an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, for providing an additional Burial Ground for the Parish of James JV ster, and erecting a Chapel adjoining thereto, and also a House for the Residence of a Clergyman to officiate in burying the Dead, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners have proceeded in the Execution of the said Act, and have caused a Burial Ground to be set out and made agreeable to the Directions thereof, but have not yet appointed any Minister, Clerk, or Sexton; and that the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that, by an Order, made in the early Part of the Session, the Time for presenting Petitions for private Bills was limited to the 5th Day of March last; and that it is very material that a Minister, Clerk, and Sexton, should be forthwith appointed to officiate in burying the Dead, but, since the making of the said Order, the Petitioners have been advised no such Appointment ought to be made until some Amendments and Alterations are made in the said Act: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to present a Petition for amending the said Act, in such Manner as the House shall think necessary and proper.

Ordered, That, in Consideration of the particular Circumstances set forth in the said Petition, Leave be given to present a Petition, as desired by the said Noblemen and Trustees.

Then a Petition of the Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the Rector, Churchwardens, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Trustees appointed to put in Execution an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, for providing an additional Burial Ground for the Parish of Saint James, Westminster, and erecting a Chapel adjoining thereto, and also a House for the Residence of a Clergyman to officiate in burying the Dead, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by the said Act, Power is given to the said Trustees to appoint, from Time to Time, Ministers and Preachers, to be licensed by the Bishop of London for the Time being, and also to appoint Clerks and Sextons of the said Chapel, and to pay all such Ministers, Clerks, and Sextons, such Sums of Money Yearly as the said Trustees shall think fit, but Doubts have been entertained whether, after such Appointments have been made, the said Trustees, or any other Person, are authorized to remove or displace any of the Ministers, or other Persons aforesaid, upon any Account whatsoever; and that some other Amendments and Alterations are found necessary to be made in the said Act, particularly for enforcing the making the Rates, and for varying the Manner of applying and disposing of any Surplus Money that may hereafter happen to be in the Hands of the said Trustees: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for making such Amendments and Alterations in the said Act as to the House shall appear necessary and proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the

A. 1T90.

Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Sir Archibald Mr.

Brett, See.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber; and have Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

from the Committee, to whom the Bill for enlarging Ga1 Bill and better regulating the Gaol for the County of War- r*Porte<L xvick, was committed; and to whom the Petition of the Proprietors of Houses and Lands within, and Inhabitants of, the Town and Borough of in

the County of Warwick, whose Hands are thereunto subscribed, on Behalf of themselves, and the other Proprietors of Houses and Lands within, and Inhabitants of, the said Town and Borough, was referred;

That the Committee had considered the said Petition, and had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Sir JohnIVodehouse reported from the Committee,

to whom the Bill for continuing and amending an Act, of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Saint Stephen’s Gate, in the County of the City of Norwich, to the Windmill in the Town of Walton, in the County of Norfolk, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee bad gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolution which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Thirty-five thousand Seven hundred and Eighty-five Pounds Fifteen Shillings and Six Pence, be granted to His Majesty, to make good the like Sum issued to Thomas Cotton, Esquire, at the Receipt of the Exchequer, out of His Majesty’s Civil List Revenues, for defraying the Expence of Allowances for the Relief and Benefit of American Civil Officers and others, who have suffered on Account of their Attachment to His Majesty’s Government.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Sir Thomas Dundas reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Stirling and Dumbarton, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, several of them were disagreed to, and the rest were agreed to by the House.

A Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, for defraying the Expence of making the Road on the South instead of the North Side of the River Blane.

You 4$.

And the said Clause was Twice read J and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Another Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, for allowing an Appeal to the Quarter Sessions, and from thence to the Court of Session.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Then several Amendments were made by the House to the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order; reported from the Report Way* Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred and Meant, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolxxd, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Money out of That, towards making good the Supply granted to His Surplus of Majesty, thei e be issued and applied the Sum of Two Millions Three hundred thousand Pounds out of the Monies that shall arise of the Surplus of the Fund, called The Consolidated Fund.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Lottery. That, towards raising the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Sum of Seven hundred and Ninety thousand Nine hundred Thirty-seven Pounds and Ten Shillings, be raised by Way of Lottery, such Lottery to consist of Fifty thousand Tickets, at Fifteen Pounds Sixteen Shillings and Four Pence Half-penny each; and that the Contributors towards the same shall, on or before the 27th Day of this Instant April, make a Deposit with the Cashiers of the Bank of England, of One Pound Sixteen Shillings and Four Pence Halfpenny, in respect of the Monies to be paid for every such Ticket, as a Security for making the future Payments to the said Cashiers on or before the Times herein after limited; that is to say: For and in respect of every such Ticket, Two Pounds on or before the 18th Day of June next; Two Pounds on or before the 30th Day of Jtdy next; Three Pounds on or before the 10th Day of September next; Two Pounds on or before the 22d Day of October next; Three Pounds on or before the 10th Day of December next; and.

Two Pounds on or before the 14th Day of January 1791; and that Tickets, as soon as the same can be prepared, shall be delivered to the Contributors so' completing their Payments: That the Sum of Five hundred thousand Pounds shall be distributed into Prizes, for the Benefit of the Proprietors of the fortunate Tickets in the said Lottery; which Prizes shall be charged upon the Aids and Supplies granted in this Session of Parliament for the Service of the Year 1790, and be paid at the Bank of England, in Money, to such Proprietors, upon Demand, on or at any Time after the 2d Day of June 1791, as soon as Certificates can be made out, without any Deduction whatsoever; and that all the Monies to be received by the said Cashiers shall be paid into the Receipt of His Majesty’s Exchequer, to be applied from Time to Time, to such Services as shall then have been voted by this House in this Session of Parliament; and that every Contributor to the said Lottery, who shall pay any of the Sums to be respectively paid by Instalments, as hereinbefore mentioned, before the Periods respectively fixed for the same, shall be allowed an Interest, by Way of Discount, after the Rate of Three Pounds per Centum per Annum, on the Sums bo respectively paid in, to be computed, from the Day of paying the same respectively, to the Periods at

5 M which

Googh

410 20° — 21° Aprilis. 1790.

which the same would be paid according to the respective Instalments herein-before mentioned.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill, or Bills, be brought in upon the said Resolutions: And that Mr. Gilbert, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr, Edward James the Earl of Mornington, the Lord Bayham, the Lord Apsley,

Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Solicitor General, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Counsel The other Order of the Day being read, for the

beard on 2d Second Reading of the Bill for extending the Royalty Reading of Qf the City of Glasgow over certain adjoining Lands, liceMh °* for paving, lighting, and cleansing the Streets, and for regulating the Police of the said City, and for giving certain Power to the Magistrates of Glasgow, for the Benefit of the said City;

Ordered, That the said Bill be now read a Second Time.

Then the Counsel for and against the Bill were called in.

And the said Bill was read a Second Time.

And the Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Heretors, Burgesses, Householders, or Resi-denters, in the City of Glasgow, and also, the Petition of John M'Caslan, Deacon Convener of the Trades in the City of Glasgow, in Name of and by Appointment of the Trades House of the said City, and of the other Persons thereunto subscribing, in Name of, and as having Power from, the incorporated Trades of the 01

said City; and also, the Petition of the Persons there-untb subscribing, Heretors, Burgesses, Householders, or Residenters in the City of; and also, the

Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, Proprietors, Life Renters, or Tacksmen, of Houses, Lands, and Burying Grounds, in the City of Glasgow, in Behalf of themselves, and others, were also read.

And One of the Counsel for the Petitioners wa» heard, and examined several Witnesses in support of the said Petitions.

And then the Counsel on both Sides were directed to withdraw.

Ordered, That the further Hearing of Counsel upon the said Bill be adjourned till Tomorrow Sevennight, the 28th Day of this Instant April.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Mercurii, 21* die Aprilis;

Anno 30* Georgii III'11 Regis, 1790.

30 Geo. III.

411

The Lords have agreed to >

Land Tax Commissioners Bill.

Bill for raising a Sum by Loans or Ex-chequerBilis.

Bill for raising a further Sum by Loans or Exchequer Bills.

Expiring Laws BUI.

Papists Leeds and Wills Inrollment Bill.

Longitude

Bill.

Malldraeth, Sec. Embanking and Drainage Bill.

Dudley Hoad Bill.

Biggleswade and Bugden Roads Bill.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Pepys and Mr. Walker:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for appointing Commissioners to put in Execution an Act of this Session of Parliament, intituled, " An *c Act for granting an Aid to His Majesty by a Land " Tax, to be raised in Great Britain, for the Service " of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety;" together with those named in Two former Acts for appointing Commissioners of the Land Tax; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for raising a certain Sum of Money by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for raising a further Sum of Money by Loans or Exchequer Bills, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to continue the several Laws therein mentioned relating to encouraging the Manufacture of Leather, by lowering the Duty payable upon the Importation of Oak Bark when the Price of such Bark shall exceed a certain Rate; to the prohibiting the Exportation of Tools and Utensils made Use of in the Iron and Steel Manufactures of this Kingdom, and to prevent the seducing of Artificers and Workmen employed in those Manufactures to go into Parts beyond the Seas; and, to the ascertaining the Strength of Spirits by Clarke's Hydrometer; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for allowing further Time for Inrollment of Deeds and Wills made by Papists, and for Relief of Protestant Purchasers; without any Amendment: And also, The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for continuing the Encouragement and Reward of Persons making certain Discoveries for finding the Longitude at Sea, or making other useful Discoveries and Improvements in Navigation, and for making Experiments relating thereto, and for adding a Commissioner to execute the several Acts for the Discovery of the Longitude at Sea; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for more effectually embanking the Marsh called Malldraeth and Corsddaugau, in the County of Anglesey, and draining and preserving the same, and the inclosed Low Lands contiguous thereto; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for making, amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, a Road from Eve Hill, near Dudley, to the New Inn, in the Parish of Pattingham, and from the Turnpike Road at or near Street End, in the Parish of Kingswinj'ord, to the Turnpike Road leading from Dudley to Wolverhampton, in the Counties of Worcester, Salop, and Stafford; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to continue the Term, and alter and enlarge the Powers, of an Act of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Biggleswade, in the County of Bedford, through Bugden and A Icon bury, to the Top of Alconbury Hill, and from Bugden to Huntingdon, and from Cross Hall to Great Stoughton Common, in the County of Huntingdon, and also the Road leading out of the aforesaid Road, at or near the Ferry House, in the Parish of Tempsford, to and through LittleBarford, Eynesbury, and Saint Neots, to

the Turnpike Road at the End of Cross Hall Lane; without any Amendment: And also,

Vol. 45.

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Edington In-Act for draining, dividing, and inclosing, certain Moors, closure Bill. Commons, or Waste Lands, called otherwise

Burtle Moor, East Heath, West heath, and Clyde Batch, within the Hamlet of Edington, and Parish of Moorlinch, in the County of Somerset; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Dormstone Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Common ^closure Fields, and other Commonable Lands, within the Parish of Dormstone, in the County of Worcester; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Harby Iu-Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Common closure B‘H< Fields, Pastures, and other Commonable Lands and Waste Grounds, within the Parish of Harby, in the County of Leicester; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for Scotch altering the Time appointed for holding the Summer Session in the Court of Session in Scotland, and for altering menu."'*" Whitsuntide and Lammas Terms in the Court of Exchequer in Scotland, with some Amendments; to which Amendments the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Lewes, &c. Act for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation Navigation of the River Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at Amendment! the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and also of a Branch of the said River, to Shortbridge, in the Parish of Fletching, in the County of Sussex, with an Amendment; to which Amendment the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to Committee resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, of Supply, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty;

Ordered, That the Account of all Sums of Money Account of which have been issued by His Majesty’s Orders, pur- Money issued suant to Addresses of the House of Commons, and addresses, which have not been made good by Parliament, be referred, referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to a Resolution; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

An ingrossed Bill to authorize the Commissioners of Bill respect-the Customs to defray Charges on Seizures out of His in8 S«izur«» Majesty's Share of Seizures in general, was read the passe Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to authorize the Commissioners of the Customs to defray Charges on Seizures out of His Majesty’s Share of Seizures in general.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

412 21 "Aprilis, . 1790:

Sir William Dolbenreported from the Committee,

to whom the Petition of the Vicar, Churchwardens,

’ and Inhabitants of the Parish of in the County of Oxford,whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr., Samuel Pcpys Cockrell, an Architect, being examined, said, That he has surveyed the Church and Tower of the said Parish, and that the same are in a very ruinous and decayed State, and it is absolutely necessary that they should be taken down and re-built — And he added, That the Expences of taking down and rebuilding the said Church and Tower will be very considerable, and cannot be raised without the Aid of Parliament.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for taking down the Church and Tower belonging to the Parish of Banbury, in the County of Oxford, and for re-building the same: And that Sir William Dolben, Mr. North, and Mr. Page, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The House was moved. That the Order made Yesterday, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, Tomorrow Morning, upon the Bill for appointing Commissioners to enquire into the Extent and Value of certain Rights, Revenues, and Possessions, in the Isle of Ma,might be read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Order be discharged.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

An ingrossed Bill for empowering Persons navigating Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, in the River Ouzc, in the County of Norfolk, to hale or tow with Horses, or other Beasts, on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and for making Satisfaction to the Owners of the said Banks or Sea Walls, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for empowering Persons navigating Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, in the River Ouze, in the County of Norfolk, to hale or tow with Horses, or other Beasts, on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and for making Satisfaction to the Owners of the said Banks or Sea Walls.

Ordered, That Sir John Wodehouse do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

The House proceeded to take into Consideration the Amendment made by the Lords to the Bill, intituled, An Act for improving, continuing, and extending the Navigation of the River Ouse, from Lewes Bridge, at the Town of Lewes, to Hammer Bridge, in the Parish of Cuckfield, and to the Extent of the said Parish of Cuckfield, and also of a Branch of the said River, to Shortbridge, in the Parish of Fletching, in the County of Sussex.

And the said Amendment was read; and is as followeth; viz.

The said Amendment being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords; and acquaint them, that this House hath agreed to the Amendment made by their Lordships.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the Attorney and Solicitor General’s Reports, in the Years 1780 and 1781, and also of the Report of the Crown Officers of the Isle of Man, which were presented to the House upon Monday last, by Mr. Rose, be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That a Committee be appointed to examine into the Expenditure of the Public Money under the Administration of the present Master General and Board of Ordnance, from the 1st of Janua 1784;

It passed in the Negative.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Friday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of made Spirits

from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Jovis, 22° die Aprilis;

Anno 30° Georgii IIP11 Regis, 1790.

r\ RDERED, That the Serjeant at Arms attend- ing this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Westminster Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this Vol. 45.

House, do j*o, with the Mace, and cleat* the Lobby, and the Speaker s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House, in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

And the Names of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by iheir Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Hall accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are Petition thereunto subscribed. Dealers by Retail in Spirituous against the Liquors, and Inhabitants of the City of London, was pre- Spirituous sented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That by j jjence Act an Act, made in the Twenty-seventh Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, for laying additional Duties upon Licences to be taken out by Persons dealing by Retail in Foreign Spirituous Liquors, the Petitioners are obliged to take out an additional Licence Annually, for which they pay certain Sums, according to the Rent of the Houses occupied by them (that is to say) if the Rent is under Fifteen Pounds, 2/. 8 s.; if Fifteen Pounds, and under Twenty Pounds, 2/. 16s.; and so on in Proportion to the Yearly Rent of Fifty Pounds, which pays 4/. 16s.; and a House of One hundred Pounds, or upwards, per Annum, pays no more, and the Peti-

tioners are required, by the said Act, to attend Eight Times in the Year at the Chief Office of Excise in London, to pay, by Instalments, the Sums directed by the said Act; and that the Petitioners understood that, the better to enable them to pay the same, all smuggled condemned Spirituous Liquors were to be destroyed, but, instead thereof such Liquors are now sold in as small Quantities as Two Gallons, for the

5 N Accommodation

Bromham ftouds Bill ordered.

Accommodation of private Persons, at the Custom House and Excise Sales, to Persons who are not Dealers, and who do not take out Licences; and that the Petitioners conceive the said Act, obliging them to take out such additional Licences, was passed in consequence of the Duties on Foreign Spirituous liquors being reduced, which, it was apprehended, greatly lessened the Revenue, but, the Petitioners are credibly informed, the Revenue on such Spirits has since considerably increased; and that the Petitioners are ready and willing to concur in contributing, in

Mr. Brett reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the several Gentlemen, Freeholders, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being severally Owners of Estates, and Inhabitants, within the several Counties of Bedford and Bucks, near the Roads thereinafter described, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Mr. William Andrews being examined, said, That, agreeable to the Leave granted by this House upon the 15th Day of March last, Notices of an Application to Parliament for Leave to bring in a Bill for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the several Roads in the Petition described, were affixed on the Doors of the Sessions Houses of the Counties of Bucks and Bedford, at the Time of the last Easier Quarter Sessions: Then,

Mr. John Higgins produced to your Committee Three several Newspapers, called The Northampton Mercury, of the 20th and 27th of March, and of the 3d of April last, wherein the like Notices were inserted.

Mr. Alderman Newham reported front the Committee, That they had heard another Counsel, and examined a Witness in Support of the said Petitions, and had closed the Evidence in Behalf of the Petitioners; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Sevennight, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Petitions.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 23° die Aprilis;

Anno 30* Georgii III® Regis, 1790.

Prayers.

East Gri list tad Church Bill reported.

MR. Medley reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for re-building the Parish Church of East Grinstead, in the County of Sussex, wa3 committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Ramsgate Chapel Bill passed.

Warwick Gaol Bill passed.

SainUatnes's Burial Ground Petition reported*

An ingrossed Bill for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Laurence, in the Isle of Thanet, in the County of Kent, as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the same Parish, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Laurence, in the Isle of Thanet, in the County of Kent, as a Chapel of Ease to the Church of the same Parish.

Ordered, That Mr. Brett do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

An ingrossed Bill for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of Wwas read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of

Ordered, That Sir George Augustus William Shuck-burgh do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Mainwaring reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Noblemen, and the humble Petition of the Rector, Churchwardens, and others, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, being Trustees appointed to put in Execution an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, for providing an additional Burial Ground for the Parish of Saint James, Westminster, and erecting a Chapel adjoining thereto, and also a House for the Residence of a Clergyman to officiate in burying the Dead, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him *to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the

Aprilis. . 1790.

Clerk’s Table: Where the Same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act was read; whereby Power is given to the said Trustees to appoint, from Time to Time, Ministers and Preachers, to be licensed by the Bishop of London for the Time being, and also to appoint Clerks and Sextons of the said Chapel, and to pay all such Ministers, Clerks, and Sextons such Sums of Money, Yearly, as the said Trustees shall think fit: Then,

Luke Ideson, Esquire, being examined, said, That Doubts have been entertained whether, after such Appointments have been made, the said Trustees, or any other Person, are authorized to remove or displace any of the Ministers or other Persons aforesaid upon any Account whatsoever. — And he added, That some other Amendments and Alterations are found necessary to be made in the said Act, particularly for enforcing the making the Rates, and for varying the Manner of applying and disposing of any Surplus Money that may hereafter happen to be in the Hands of the said Trustees.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to amend an Act of the last Session of Parliament, for providing an additional Burial Ground for the Parish of Saint James, Westminster, and erecting a Chapel adjoining thereto, and also a House for the Residence of a Clergyman to officiate in burying the Dead: And that Mr. Mainwaring and Sir Archibald Edmonstone do prepare, and bring in, the same.

An ingrossed Bill to enable the Company of Pro- Leeds and prietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool to vary the line of the said Canal Navigation, and BUI '^»sed. to raise a further Sum of Money for the Purpose of completing the said Canal Navigation, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Leeds to Liverpool to vary the Line of the said Canal Navigation, and to raise a further Sum of Money for the Purpose of completing the said Canal Navigation, and for other Purposes.

Ordered, That Mr. Thomas Stanley do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

in the said Amendment, in order to fill the Blank with the Words " One Half-penny."

And the Question being put, That the House doth agree with the Committee in the said Amendment;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

Several other of the Amendments made by the Committee to the said Bill, as far as the Amendment in Fo. 13, 1. 4, being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

The Amendment in Fo. 13, 1. 4, which was to fill the Blank with the Words " the full," being read a Second Time, it was proposed to disagree with the Committee in the said Amendment, in order to fill the Blank with the Words " One Half."

And the Question being put, That the House doth agree with the Committee in the said Amendment;

The House divided.

The Noes went forth.
