The House being informed that Mr. Monro, from the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists, attended at the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented to the House, pursuant to their Order,

A Statement of the Claims examined by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses sustained

by His Majesty’s Loyal Subjects, either by fumisliing Provisions, or other necessary Articles, for the Service of His Majesty’s Navy or Army in America, during the late War, or by having their Property used, seized, or destroyed, for carrying on the Public Service there.

And then he withdrew.

And the Tide of the said Statement was read.

A Motion was made, and the Question being pro- Address for posed, That an humble Address be presented to His Reports of Majesty, that He will be graciously pleased to order so "j?

much of the Report of the Commissioners appointed certa’in Of-to enquire into the Fees, Perquisites, and Emoluments fices. of Offices, as relates to the Victualling Office Department, to be laid before this House;

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Question; viz.

To leave out the Words " so much," and insert the Word " Copies" instead thereof; and to leave out the Word " Report," and insert the Word " Reports" instead thereof; after the Words " Emoluments of " to insert the Word "certain:" and to leave out the Words " as relates to the Victualling Office Department."

And the Question being put, That the Words

" so much" stand Part of the Question;

ft passed in the Negative.

And the Question being put, That the Word

" Copies " be inserted instead thereof;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

And the Question being put, That the Word

" Report" stand Part of the Question;

It passed in the Negative.

And the Question being put, That the Word

" Reports " be inserted instead thereof;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

And the Question being put. That the Word " certain" be inserted after the Words "Emoluments of;"

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

And the Question being put. That the Words " as " relates to the Victualling Office Department," stand Part of the Question;

It passed in the Negative.

Then the main Question, so amended, being put;

Resolved, That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, that He will be graciously pleased to order Copies of the Reports of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Fees, Perquisites, and Emoluments, of certain Offices, to be laid before this House.

Ordered,

23° Aprilis. A. 1790.

Ordered, That the said Address be presented to His Majesty by such Members of this House as are of His Majesty’s most Honourable Privy Council.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the Second Beading of the Bill to explain and amend an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act " for repealing the Duties on Tobacco and Snuff, and " for granting new Duties in lieu thereof," be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

A Petition of the Persons thereunto subscribing, being Manufacturers of Tobacco and Snuff in the Port of London, on Behalf of themselves and others, was presented to the House, and read; taking Notice of the said Bill; and Setting forth, That the Petitioners are confirmed in Opinion, that no Modification or Alteration of the said Act, while the Principle of Excise is preserved, can afford any permanent Relief to the fair Dealers, but must ultimately destroy their Manufacture, and the Revenue collected on it: And therefore praying, That, in the Bill now depending, the Survey of Excise may not be continued upon the Manufacture.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the said Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the said Bill be now read a Setond Time.

The said Bill was accordingly read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tuesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to whom the said Bill is committed.

The House was moved, That the Order made upon Monday last, for receiving upon Tuesday next the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the several Accounts and Papers which were presented to the House upon the i gth Day of February and the 11 th Day of March last, by Mr. Morton, from the Directors of the East India Company, might be read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Order be discharged.

Ordered, That the said Report be received upon Monday Sevenniglit, the 3d Day of May next.

Ordered, That Captain Wilson do attend the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Ordered, That Mr. Dalrymple do also at-

tend the said Committee.

Ordered, That Mr. Charles Wadstroom do also attend the said Committee.

Ordered, That Mr. Bowen do also attend the said Committee.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That this House be called over upon Wednesday Four Weeks, the 26th Day of May next;

It passed in the Negative.

Command, acquainted the House, That His Majesty, having been informed of the Purport of the said Bill, gives His Consent, as far as His Majesty’s Interest is concerned, that the House may do therein as they shall think fit.

The Housg, according to Order, resolved itself into Committee a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained ra<*' of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Sir William Dolben took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir William Dolben reported from the Committee,

That he was directed by the Committee to make a Motion, w'hen the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be now received.

Sir William Dolben accordingly reported from the said Committee, That he was directed by the Committee to move the House, that a Select Committee be appointed to take the Examination of the several Witnesses that have been, or shall be, ordered by the House to attend the said Committee of the whole House; and to report the Minutes of such Examination, from Time to Time, to the House.

And Sir William Dolben moved the House accordingly.

Ordered, That a Select Committee be appointed to Select Com-take the Examination of the several Witnesses that mittee ap-have been, or shall be, ordered by the House to attend l,inted 10 the said Committee of the whole House; and to report witnesses. the Minutes of such Examination, from Time to Time, to the House.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr.

Mr. Gascoyne, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Lord Penrhyn, Mr. Secretary Grenville, Mr. John Scott, Mr. Fox, Mr. Sloane, the Marquis of Graham,

Mr. Marsham, Sir William Dolben, Mr. Alderman Newnkam, the Lord Belgrave, Mr. Alderman Sarc-bridge, Mr. William Smith, Sir Grey Cooper, Sir Charles Middleton, Mr. Alderman Watson, Mr. Matthew Montagu, Mr. Beckford, Mr. Fitzpatrick, Sir Wat kin Lewes,

Mr. Martin, Mr. Cruger, Mr. Burke, Mr. Brickdale,

the Lord Muncaster, Sir William Young, Mr. Pye,

Mr. Sumner, Mr. Hawkins Browne, Mr. Dickinson,

Mr. Call, Sir William Codrington, Mr. Thomas Stanley:

And they are to meet upon Monday Morning next, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and all who come to the Committee are to have Voices.

Sir William Dolben also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the said Committee of the whole House to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon this Day Seven-night, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Bill deferred. ing next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in,

upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of BritwA-made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

Sloane Street Mr. Sloanereported from the Committee, to whom Paving Bill the Bill for paving, repairing, cleansing, lighting, watch-reported, and ing^ and watering Sloane Street, and certain other Streets re-commit- an(j piaces within the Parish of Saint Luke, Chelsea, in the County of Middlesex, was committed; That the Committee bad examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read, the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Report was read.

And the House being informed that several other Amendments are necessary to be made to the said Bill;

Resolved, That the said Bill be re-committed.

Resolved, That the said Bill be re-committed to the Committee to whom the same was committed.

Mr. Hungerford reported from the Committee, to Lutterworth whom the Bill for dividing and inclosing the Open J?«osure, . Fields and Commonable Places in the Parish of Lul- 1 repor terworih, in the County of Leicester, was committed;

That the Committee had examined, and found that the Standing Orders of the House, of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Bills of Inclosure, had been complied with; and that the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

A Petition of the Trustees for putting in Execution Petition for certain Acts of Parliament for making a free Market to prefer the Sale of Fish in the City of Westminster, was "on* respect-presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, ingWestmin-That the Petitioners observe, by the Votes, that by an sterFish Order made in the early Part of this Session, the Timfe Market, for presenting Petitions for private Bills was limited to the 5th Day of March last; and that a General Meeting of the said Trustees was holden upon the 15th Day of this Instant April (being the earliest Day a General Meeting could be had) when the State of their Affairs was taken into Consideration, and it appeared that they are possessed of a considerable Sum of Public Money, and other Property, which they conceive they are not authorized to apply for

5 P any

Le&vfe given.

Petitions from Trustees of Westminster Fish Market.

422 26° Apr ilis. 1790.

any particular Service, and they are tflso in the Receipt of certain Duties payable upon all Fishing Vessels coming from Sea up the River Thames, although the Object for which- those Duties were granted is at an End; and that the Petitioners think it their Duty to apply to the House to enable them to dispose of their said Estates and Property, for such Purposes, and in such Manner, as the House shall think fit, although the Time for receiving Petitions for private Bills is elapsed: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to present a Petition for the several Purposes aforesaid.

Ordered, That, in Consideration of the particular Circumstances set forth in the said Petition, Leave be given to present a Petition as desired by the said Trustees.

Then a Petition of the'Trustees appointed and elected by virtue of an Act, passed in the Twenty-second Year of the late King, intituled, "An Act for " making a free Market for the Sale of Fish, in the " City of Westminster, and for preventing the Forestalling and Monopolizing of Fish, and for allowing " the Sale of Fish, under the Dimensions mentioned " in a Clause contained in an Act of the First Year " of his late Majesty’s Reign, in case the same are " taken with a Hook," was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That an Act was made in the Twenty-second Year of his late Majesty, for the Establishment of a Market in Westminster for all Sorts of Fish, by virtue whereof Twenty-six Trustees were named and appointed, with full Powers to carry the said Act into Execution, and they were enabled to collect certain Duties from Fishermen and others selling Fish in the said intended Market, and were empowered to assign over the said Duties as a Security for any Monies that should be borrowed for discharging the Expence incident to the said Design, as also to appoint a Treasurer, Collectors, and other Officers, to allow them Salaries, and to remove them, if they should think fit, and, if the said Duties should yield a Surplus over and above the said Expences, the Trustees were directed to apply such Surplus in binding out poor Boys Apprentices to Fishermen, or others employed in the Sea Service, and the Commissioners of Westminster Bridge were likewise empowered, by the said Act, to grant a Piece of Ground at the Foot of the Bridge to the Trustees, for the Use of the Market, the Property of which, and of all Buildings to be erected thereon, was vested in the said Trustees, and it was also enacted, that, upon every Vacancy among the Trustees, occasioned by Death or Resignation, Seven or more of them should fill up such Vacancy, by Writing under their Hands and Seals; and that, soon after the passing of the said Act, the Commissioners of Westminster Bridge conveyed to the Trustees a Piece of Ground near Carman Raw, on -which the Market was erected and opened, to defray the Expence of which, and of the passing of the Act, the Trustees, agreeably to their Powers, borrowed the Sum of 400l., and applied it to those Purposes; and that many Difficulties arose which impeded the Execution of the said Design, insomuch that the Trustees were obliged to apply to Parliament for Assistance, and an Act passed in the Twenty-ninth Year of the late King, intituled, "An Act for explaining, amending, and rendering more effectual, an Act, made in the Twenty-second Year of His present Majesty’s " Reign, intituled, An Act for making a free Market ufor the Sale of Fish in the City of Westminster, and " for preventing the Forestalling and Monopolizing " of Fish, and for allowing the Sale of Fish under the " Dimensions mentioned in a Clause contained in an Act of the First Year of his late Majesty’s Reign, * in case the same are taken with a Hook," which enacts, that all Owners of Fishing Vessels, coming from Sea for the Supply of JJondan and Westminster with Fish, should sell off their Cargo within Eight Days after their Arrival, and the Trustees were empowered to appoint an Inspector, to take an Account of the Arrival of such Vessels, and to examine into the State of their Cargo, and for defraying the Expence of such Appointment, and otherwise, it was directed, that there should be paid to His Majesty’s Searcher at Gravesend, for the Certificate of the Entry of any such Fishing Vessel, Two Shillings, whereof the Searcher was to have Six Pence, and the remaining One Shilling and Six Pence was to be paid by the Searcher to the Trustees, or such Persons as they should appoint, and all Masters and Owners of Fishing Vessels were ordered, within Three Days of their Arrival, to report the same to the Searcher at Gravesend, but, by an Act, passed in the Thirty-third Year of the late King, it is directed, that, instead of making such Entries with the Searcher at Gravesend, they should be made with the Deputed Clerk in the Coast Office, under the Collector Outward in the Port of London, at the Custom House there, subject to the same Payment, for the same Purposes, and the Trustees were likewise empowered by the said Act of the Twenty-ninth of the late King, to mortgage and otherwise dispose of the Ground and Buildings of the said Market, for securing any further Sums of Money that might become necessary to be borrowed; and that notwithstanding all proper Means were used to carry the said Design into Execution, yet the Market was but little resorted to, insomuch that scarcely any Toll Duties were received, and the Debt contracted for its Support w-as rapidly increasing, to defray which the Trustees were finally obliged to abandon the Design, and borrow Money on a Building Lease of the Market Ground, w'hich Lease was granted to Richard Hughes for the Term of Seventy-two Years, commencing from Lady Day 1753, at a Pepper Corn Rent Yearly for the First Two Years, and at the clear Annual Rent of 6,51, for the remaining Seventy Years, and the said Trustees borrowed a Sum of 6001, upon the Security of the said Lease for the Discharge of the Debts thus contracted by the Failure of the Market; and that the Trustees continuing in the Receipt of the above stated Ground Rent, and of the Profits arising from the Entries of Fishing Vessels, were enabled, and actually did, some Time in the Year 1774, discharge the Whole of the* Principal Money, and Interest due on the Two several Loans of 400l. and 600l. before-mentioned, since which Time the said Ground Rent and Profits have been accumulating in the Hands of the Trustees, without being applied to any particular Object, and have, of late Years, been constantly and regularly invested in the Three per Cent. Consolidated Bank Annuities, for the Benefit of the Trust, and for the Increase of the Fund; and that, since the passing of the Act of the Twenty-second of the late King, all the Trustees originally named in the said Act are dead, except the Marquis of Stafford, and the present Trustees have been regularly elected agreeably to the Provisions contained in that Act; and that their Receipts and Disbursements Annually are as follows, the Interest of 4,2001. Throe per Cent. Consolidated Bank Annuities, being the Total, of the Savings invested in Government Security, 65/. per Annum, being the Ground Rent of the Market, and the Yearly Sum of 140/., being the Average Three Fourths of the Duties arising from the Entries of Fishing Vessels in the River Thames, that the Disbursements consist in 25 /. a Year for an Inspector at Gravesend, 201, a Year for a Clerk, with about 15/. Annually for the Use of a House, and otherwise; and that the Petitioners conceiving that it was their Duty, under the present subsisting Acts, to abstain from applying the remaining Profits to any new Purpose, and hoping that the Wisdom of Parliament would find out some other 01 Mode

26° Apr

423

Banbury Church Bill

presented.

Tuns tall Hoad Bill reported*

Mode of Application, have carefully, and to the best of their Ability, preserved and improved what little remained for their Management, until it is now become of some Consideration, but they are without the Means of making it beneficial to the Public: And therefore praying, That they may be relieved from the aforesaid Trust, and that the Monies now standing in the Names of Janies Thomas Parker, and

George Stubbs, Esquires, Three of the said Trustees for the Benefit of the Trust, together with the Ground Rent and Reversionary Interest in the Tenements situated in Cannon Raw, belonging to the Trustees, and also the Interest granted to them from the Entries of the Fishing Vessels in the River Thames, may be applied in Augmentation of the Fund of the Marine Society, or be disposed of in such Manner, and to such Purposes, as to the House shall seem fit and proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committees And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Brett, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

Mr. North presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for taking down the Church and Tower belonging to the Parish of Banbury, in the County of Oxford, and for re-building the same: And the same was received; and read the First Time;

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Sir Edward Littleton reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from Tunstall, in the County of Stafford, to Bosley, in the County of Chester, and from Great Chell to Shelton, in the said County of Stafford, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Ordered, That Sir Peter Parker be added to the Select Committee who are appointed to take the Examination of the several Witnesses that have been, or shall be, ordered by the House to attend the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, a Statement of the Claims examined, and Losses allowed, by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of all such Persons who have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain, up to the 11th Day of June 1789, and of the Sums which have been already granted on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Account of the Money advanced for Foreign Secret Service, which has been repaid into the Exchequer, be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chaii* of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to a Resolution; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received To-morrow-Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of Ways and Means for raising the Supply granted to His Majesty.

And the Title of the said Statement was read.

The said Statement is as followeth; viz.

To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens, and Burgesses, in Parliament assembled.

A STATEMENT of the Claims examined, and Losses allowed, by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of all such Persons who have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain, up to the 11th Day of June 1789, and of the Sums which have been already granted on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament.

Petition for A Petition of William Hamilton, Esquire, the Agent Leave to pre- of Sir William Hamilton, Knight of the most Honoura-on from'* Order of the Bath, His Majesty’s Envoy Extraor-Sirwlniam binary, resident at the Court of Naples, was presented

Hamilton. to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the said

Sir William Hamilton is possessed of certain Lands adjoining to the Creeks of Milford Haven, in the County of Pembroke, called Castle Pill and Priory Pill, on which he enjoys various Rights and Privileges, and collects Duties of Keelage; and that the said Lands

' . might be greatly improved, the present public Esta-

blishment of the Packets between Milford Haven and Ireland very essentially assisted and benefited, and the Public be materially accommodated, if the said Sir William Hamilton was enabled to make certain Improvements on his said Lands, and to erect Docks and Quays on the said Creeks, and if proper Rules and Regulations respecting Markets, and the Port Business of the said Creeks, were established; and that t the said Sir William Hamilton is desirous of obtaining an Act of Parliament for the above-mentioned Purposes, and the Petitioner hath received a Petition from him, praying for Leave to bring in a Bill accordingly; and that any Delay in the Execution of the several Purposes so proposed to be carried into Effect, will not only be prejudicial to the Interest of the said Sir William Hamilton, but productive of Inconvenience to the Public: And therefore praying, That, in Consideration of the Circumstances above stated, Leave may be given to present the Petition of the said Sir William Hamilton.

Leave given. Ordered, That in Consideration of the particular Circumstances set forth in the said Petition, Leave be given to present a Petition, as desired by the said William Hamilton, Esquire.

Sir William Then a Petition of Sir William Hamilton, Knight of Hamilton’s the most Honourable Order of the Bath, His Majesty’s Petition. Envoy Extraordinary, resident at the Court of Naples, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Creeks of Milford Haven, called Castle Pill and Prioiy Pill,remain unimproved, and, notwithstanding the Petitioner is possessed of Lands adjoining thereto, and enjoys various Rights and Privileges, and collects Duties of Keelage therein, he cannot, without the Authority of Parliament, effectually employ the same to accommodate the existing public Establishments of the Revenue and Packets, nor ensure to Mercantile Persons, or others inclined to settle on the said Lands, nor to Passengers who may resort thereto, the necessary Accommodations, and consequently cannot contribute to the beneficial Objects of Government in its late permanent Establishment of Packets from Milford to Ireland; and that, in order to facilitate the Objects of Government, it will be necessary to erect Piers, Docks, and other Buildings, on the said Lands, and also on any Part of the said Pills or Creeks within High "Water Mark, and to project the same into Mi ford Haven, and to establish and regulate a Pair and Markets; and that it will also be necessary to appoint proper and convenient Places for the more easy clearing the Packets established there, as well as for the landing and clearing all other Goods, Wares, and Merchandize, from Foreign Parts and Coastways, and to regulate the general Police of the said Pills: And therefore praying, That Leave may'be given to bring in a Bill for the Purposes aforesaid, under such Regulations and Restrictions as to the House shall seem proper and expedient.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

Vox,. 45.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Committee to resolve itself into a Committee of tjbe whole House, of Supply, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to a Resolution; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, That they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty.

Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Yeats of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low 'Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-amde Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited' Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for* Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the I Vest Indies, be now read.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Mom-ing, resolve itself into the said Committee.

The Order of the Day being read, for taking into further Consideration the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Twentieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, touching the Election for Knights of the Shire to serve in Parliament for that Part of Great Britain called England, was recommitted;

And the House being informed that some further Amendments are necessary to be made to the said BiH;

Resolved, That the said Bill be again re-committed.

Resolved, That the said Bill be again re-committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, immediately, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Bill.

The House accordingly resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Rolle took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Rolle reported from the Committee, That they had made a Progress in the Bill; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Sevennight, the 5th Day of May next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Bill.

An ingrossed Bill to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal Navigation to scour, cleanse, and deepen the Bed or Channel of the River Severn, from , in the County of Worcester, to a Place called near the

City of Worcester, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Navigation to improve the Navigation of the River Severn, from Stourport, in the County of Worcester, to a Place called Diglis, near the City of Worcester.

Ordered, That Mr. Bastard do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

The other Order of the Day being read, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for appointing Commissioners to enquire into the Extent and Value of certain Rights, Revenues, and Possessions, in the Isle of Maim;

Ordered, That the Copies of the Attorney and So- Papers licitor General’s Reports, in the Years 1780 and 1781, Ie,en'ed* on the Bill to explain and amend an Act of the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled,

" An Act for carrying into Execution a Contract made " pursuant to the Act of Parliament, of the Twelfth " of his late Majesty King George the First, between " the Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury and " the Duke and Dutchess of the Proprietors of the Isle of Man, and their Trustees, for the Purchase of the said Island, and its Dependencies,

" under certain Exceptions therein particularly named and to ascertain and establish the Jurisdiction of the Manerial Courts of the Most Noble John Duke of Atholl in the said Island, and to enable the said Duke and his Heirs to exercise and enjoy certain Powers and Remedies therein mentioned; and also, the Report of the Crown Officers of the Isle of Man on the said Bill, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Report which was made from the Committee, to whom the Petition of the Most Noble John Duke of Atholl was referred; together with the several Papers and Accounts which have been presented to this House, in this Session of Parliament, relating to the Revenues of the Isle of Man, be referred to the said Committee.

And a Motion being made, and the Question being proposed, That Mr. Speaker do now leave the Chair;

The House was moved, That the Entries in the Journal of the House, of the 6th Day of March 1765, of the Resolutions reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider what Rights of the Proprietor of the Isle of Man, under the several Grants of the said Island, it may be expedient to vest in the Crown, for the further and more effectual preventing the Mischiefs arising to the Revenue and Commerce of Great Britain and Ireland from the illicit and clandestine Trade to and from the said Island, and what Compensation it may be proper to make to the said Proprietor in respect thereof, and which were then agreed to by the House, might be read.

And the same were read accordingly.

Then the Question being put, That Mr. Speaker do now leave the Chair;

The House divided.

The Noes went forth.

AN ingrossed Bill for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from the Mayor's Stone in Abingdon, in the County of Berks, through Cumner, to the ancient Horse Road at in the said County, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from the Mayors Stone in Abingdon, in the County of Berks, through Cumner, to the ancient Horse Road at in the said

County.

Ordered, That Mr. Loveden do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Hall,

and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker’s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, 10 attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take thetti immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

And the Names of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Hall accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Leeds and Mr. Walker:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Morn-

ing next, at Ten of the Clock, in Westminster Hall.

And then the'Messengers withdrew.

The said Account i9 preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

A Petition of several of the Trustees for putting in Petition re-Execution an Act of Parliament, made in the Twenty- Southwark second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King Road Act*. George the Second, for opening and making a new Road from the East End of New Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and" for keeping the said Road in Repair for the future, and also another Act, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers of the said Act, and for repairing several other Roads adjoining to the said Road, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That, in pursuance of Leave granted by the House on the 18th Day of March last, Notices were given in the Newspapers published in the Counties of Surrey and Kent, in the Month of April Instant, of Application having been made to Parliament for an Act for enlarging the Term, and for explaining, amending, and making more effectual, the said Acts, and for making and repairing several other Roads adjoining thereto, and that Notices were also given at the Easter Quarter Sessions of the Peace holden for the said Counties of Surrey and Kent, in such and the like Manner as are required to be given by the Standing Orders of the House of the 25th of April 1774, relative to Turnpike Bills: And therefore praying, That Leave may be given to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers, of the said Acts, and for making the several new or additional Roads before described, in such Manner as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of a Committee: And that they do examine the Matter thereof; and report the same, as it shall appear to them, to the House:

And it is referred to S\v Joseph Mazobey, Lord William Russell, &c.: And they are to meet Tomorrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber; and hare Power to send for Persons, Papers, and Records.

Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerks Table: Where the same was read; arid is as followeth;

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, Martin Cole, Esquire, being examined, said, That the public Passage leading from the Market Place to the Gateway of the Minster Close, within the City of Peterborough (being Twenty-five Yards in Length, or there abouts) is yery narrow and incommodious for

Vo l. 45.

Passengers and Carriages, and it would be of Safety and Convenience to the Inhabitants of the said City, and others, if Power Afras given to take down Two Houses of small Value situate upon the Sides of the said Passage, and to make the same of a proper Width:

And a Member present informed your Committee,

That the Owners of such Two Houses have no Objection to the same being taken down.

A Message, by Sir Francis M Gentleman Royal Assent Usher of the Bluck Rod: to Bills.

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords, authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission, for declaring His Royal Assent to several Acts agreed upon by both Houses, do desire the immediate Attendance of this Honourable House in the House of Peers, to hear the Commission read.

Accordingly Mr. Speaker, with the House, went up to the House of Peers.

And being returned;

- Mr. Speaker reported, That the House, at the Desire of the Lords authorized by virtue of His Majesty’s Commission afore-mentioned, had been at tire House of Peers, where a Commission under the Great Seal was read, giving, declaring, and notifying the Royal Assent to the several Public and Private Bills therein mentioned; and also impowering His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, His Royal Highness the Duke of York, His Royal Highness the Duke of Clarence, His Royal Highness the Duke of Gloucester,

His Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland, the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and several other Lords, to declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills; and that the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and the Duke of Leeds, named also in the said Commission, did accordingly declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills: Which Bills are as followeth; viz.

Sir Joseph Mawbey reported from the Committee, Southwark to whom the Petition of several of the Trustees for Roads Bill putting in Execution an Act of Parliament, made in ortkred-the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for opening and making a new Road from the East End of New Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the said Road in Repair for the future, and also another Act, made in the Seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for enlarging the Term and Powers of the said Act, and for repairing several other Roads adjoining to the said Road, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, several printed Newspapers, called The Essex, Herts, Kent, end Middlesex Chronicle, of the 13th, 20th, and 27th of this Instant April; and also, The Diary, or Wood-fall's Register, of the 12th, 19th, and 26th of the said Instant April, were produced to your Committee, wherein Notices of an Application to Parliament, for Leave to bring in a Bill for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging thfe Powers, of the before-mentioned Acts, and for making the several new or additional Roads before described, are inserted, agreeable to the Leave granted by the House, upon the 18th Day of March last: And,

Mr. William Hosier informed your Committee, That agreeable to the said Leave of the House, the like Notice of Application had been affixed on the Door of the Sessions House for the County of Kent, at the last Easter Quarter Sessions: And,

Mr. Beriah Drew also said, That the like Notice had been affixed on the Door of the Sessions House for the County of Surry, at the said Easter Quarter Sessions.

An ingrossed Bill to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Stirling, and for repairing the Road from Loanhead to Saint in the said

County of Stirling, was read the Third Time.

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. to 1. l. To leave out " Penny," and insert " Halfpenny" instead thereof.

1.1 g. To leave out " Penny," and insert " Halfpenny" instead thereof.

And the said Amendments were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resotted, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Stirling, and for repairing the Road from Loanhead to Saint Ninians, in the said County of Stirling.

Ordered, That Sir Thomas Dundas do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of William Knox, Patentee for Life under Mewre. the Great Seal of Great Britain, of the Office of Secre- Kn°x ""1. tary of the late British Colony, now State of New Fords peti-York, and of James Ford, Patentee of the Office of °n‘ Provost Marshall of Georgia, on Behalf of themselves and other Proprietors of Patent Offices in the late British Colonies, now American States, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That Acts of Parliament having passed in the Twenty-third, Twenty-fifth, Twenty-sixth, and Twenty-seventh Years of His Majesty’s Reign, appointing Commissioners to enquire into the Losses and Services of all such Persons as had suffered in their Rights, Properties, and Professions, during the late unhappy Dissentions in America, in consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, the Petitioners delivered in to the said Commissioners Statements of the Incomes they had respectively received from the several Offices they held by Patents under the Great Seal during their own Lives, or the Lives of others, and proved the same to the Satisfaction of the said Commissioners, and expected to receive Compensation for the Life Estates therein, as legal Rights and Freehold Property within the Meaning of the said Acts, but the House having, on the 9th of June 1788, Resolved, That Allowances should be made to such Persons whose Losses of Income arose from Professions or Offices, in the Proportion of Fifty Pounds for every One hundred Pounds of such Annual Income, not exceeding Four hundred Pounds, and of Forty Pounds for every One hundred Pounds of such Income above Four hundred Pounds, where the Value did not* exceed Fifteen hundred Pounds, and where the Value exceeded Fifteen hundred Pounds, then in the Proportion of Thirty per Cent, of the Value exceeding Four hundred Pounds, the said Commissioners understanding the Word " Offices," in the said Resolution, as generally applicable to Patent Offices, as well as all others, conceived themselves restrained thereby from reporting upon the Petitioners Patent Offices as Legal Rights

RDE R ED, That the Serjeant at Arms attend- ing this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places, adjacent, and the Passages leading to Westminster Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker's Chambers, of ail Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the 6ame of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And lie went accordingly.

And being returned, be reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

Mr. Samuel Smith reported from the Committee, to Goldsmith* whom the Bill to alter so much of an Act, made in Bill reported, the Twelfth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, "An Act for the " better preventing Frauds and Abuses in Gold and " Silver Wares," and also so much of another Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for granting to " His Majesty certain Duties on all Gold and Silver " Plate imported, and also certain Duties on all Gold " and Silver Wrought Plate made in Great Britain," as relates to the marking of Silver Wares, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table:

Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, he ingrossed.

Tamer Ferry

Bill.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Graces and Mr. Leeds:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, Common Meadows and Pastures, Common and Waste Lands, in the Liberty or Lordship of Mickleover, in the County of Derby', without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing Part of a certain Common or Waste Land, called Road Common, within the Manor of Road and Langham, in the Parishes of Road and North Bradley, in the Counties of Somerset and Wilts; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for effectually carrying, into Execution Two Acts,

.of the Sixteenth and Twenty-fifth Years of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from the Stourbridge Navigation to the Birmingham and Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Navigations, in the Counties of Worcester and Stafford', without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for authorizing and enabling the Right honourable George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and Reginald Pole Carew, Esquire, to establish and maintain a common Ferry over and across the River Tamer, between a certain Place North of Plymouth Dock, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel, in the County of Devon, and -point, in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall; without any Amendment: And also.

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Common and Waste Grounds, within the Manor of Bleatarn, in the Parish

of Warcop, in the County of Westmwith some

Amendments; to which Amendments the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for paving and otherwise improving the Town of Honiton, in the County of Devon', with some Amendments; to which Amendments the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Tuesday Morning next, at Ten of the Clock, in Westminster Hall.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, Motion for That the Bill for granting to His Majesty a certain printing the Sum of Money, to be raised by a Lottery, be printed; l^Bl ‘

It passed in the Negative.

Then the Amendments made by the Committee to the said Bill being severally read a Second Time, upon the Question severally put thereupon, several of them were disagreed to, and the rest were agreed to by the House; and several Amendments were made, by the House, to the Bill.

Mr. Bramston, according to Older, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider further of the Laws relating to the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That all Meal or Flour, except Meal or Flour made of Wheat, or of Oats, be prohibited to be imported into this Kingdom.

Resoloed, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, whenever the Price of middling British Wheat hall be under Forty-eight Shillings per Quarter, there be laid upon every Hundred Weight of Wheat-meal, or Flour, imported into this Kingdom, a Duty of Six Shillings and Six Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, whenever the Price of middling British Wheat shall be at or above Forty-eight Shillings per Quarter, there be laid upon every Hundred Weight of Wheat-meal, or Flour, imported from any other Country, except Ireland, or the Province of Quebec, into this Kingdom, a Duty of One Shilling.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, whenever the Price of middling British Oats shall be at or above Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, there be laid upon every Hundred Weight of Oat-meal, imported from Ireland,or the Province of Quebec, into England,

a Duty of Two Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, whenever the Price of middling British Oats shall be under Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, there be laid upon every Hundred Weight of Oat-meal imported into England, a Duty of Five Shillings.

Resohed, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That, whenever the Price of middling British Oats shall be at or above Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, there be laid upon every Hundred Weight of Oat-meal imported from any other Country, except Ireland, or the Province of Quebec, into England, a Duty of Six Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That, whenever the Price of British Oat-meal shall exceed Sixteen Shillings per BoU, weighing One hundred and Twenty-eight Pounds Troy, in Scotland, there be laid, upon every Hundred Weight of Oat-meal, imported from Ireland, or the Provmce of Quebec into Scotland, a Duty of Two Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That, whenever the Price of British Oat-meal shall exceed Sixteen Shillings per Boll, weighing One hundred and Twenty-eight Pounds Troy, in Scotland, there be laid, upon every Hundred Weight of Oatmeal, imported from any other Country, except Ireland, or the Province of Quebec, into Scotland, a Duty of Six Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That there be granted on every Hundred Weight of Biscuit Bread exported, made of British Wheat, a Bounty of One Shilling and Sixpence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That there be granted on every Hundred Weight of Flour exported, made of British Wheat, a Bounty of One Shilling and Six Pence.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who are appointed to prepare, and bring in, a Bill pursuant to the Resolutions which, upon the 31st Day of March last, were reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the Report which was made from the Committee, who were appointed to consider of an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for better regulating and ascertaining the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain; and also " for better regulating the Exportation of Starch, and " the Importation of Rape Seedand to report their Opinion to the House in what Manner the Provisions of the said Act may be more effectually carried Into Execution, and also what Alterations and Amendments it may appear necessary to make in the Laws respecting the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain,

That they do make Provision in the said Bill, pursuant to the Resolutions now reported and agreed to by the House.

Mr. Steele presented to the House, pursuant to their Warrants Order, grautingPen-

A Copy of His Majesty’s Warrant, dated June 16th sl<\nVj° Mr* 1778, granting a Pension of 1,200l. a Year to William ^nnox Knox, Esquire; and also a Copy of His Majesty’s santedl Warrant; dated March 19th, 1782, granting a Pension of 600l. a Year to Mr. Knox, and a like Pension of 600 /. a Year to Mrs. Knox, in Lieu of the Pension of 1,2001, a Year granted to Mr. Knox in 1778.

And the Title of the Paper containing the said Copies was read.

Ordered, That the said Paper do lie upon the Table, to be perused by the Members of the House.

The said Paper is preserved amongst the other Papers of this Session.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Distillery Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Mom- Bill deferred. ing next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in th'e Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Southwark O IR Joseph Maxvbey presented to the House, accord-Roads Bill ij ing to Order, a Bill for enlarging the Term, and presented. for explaining, amending, and making more effectual, the Powers of Two several Acts, passed in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the Seventh Year of His present Majesty, for making a new Road from New Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the same, and several other Roads adjoining, in Repair, and also, for making and keeping in Repair other Roads adjacent thereto: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Westminster Mr. Henry Hobart reported from the Committee, to Fish Market whom the Petition of the Trustees appointed and Trustee* elected by virtue of an Act, passed in the Twenty-

reported. second Year of the late King, intituled, "An Act

" for making a free Market for the Sale of Fish in the City of Westminster, and for preventing the " Forestalling and Monopolizing of Fish, and for allowing the Sale of Fish, under the Dimensions mentioned in a Clause contained" in an Act of the First " Year of his late Majesty’s Reign, in case the same are " taken with a Hook," was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the said Act of the Twenty-second Year of his late Majesty

Vox.. 45.

was read; by which it appeared, That the Trustees were thereby authorized to make a free Market for the Sale of Fish in the City of Westminster', and in order to defray the Expence thereof, certain Duties in the said Act mentioned were directed to be paid by all Fishermen and other Persons bringing Fish to the said intended Market; and by the said Act the Commissioners for building Westminster Bridge were authorized to convey a certain Piece of Ground for the Sum of Five Pounds, to be made use of for the Purpose of holding such Market; and the said Piece of Ground was accordingly conveyed to the said Trustees, as appeared by a Deed of Bargain and Sale which was produced to your Committee by the Clerk to the said Trustees.

And it further appeared by the said Act, That if there should be any Surplus of the said Duties, the same should be applied Yearly in binding out Boys Apprentices to Fishermen, Masters of Ships, or some other Persons employed in the Sea Service.

And it also appeared by an Act, made in the Thirty-third Year of his late Majesty, That the Sum of Two Shillings is made payable for every Fishing Vessel arriving at The Nore, One Shilling and Six Pence of which is directed to be paid to the said Trustees, to be applied as therein is mentioned;

Then,

Mr. Thomas Drake, Clerk to the said Trustees, being examined, said, That soon after the passing of the said first-mentioned Act the Trustees caused a Fish Market to be erected upon the Piece of Ground conveyed to them for that Purpose, which Market continued for some Time, but the same could not be kept up in such Manner as to be of any Benefit to the Inhabitants of the said City; and the Trustees were therefore obliged to abandon the Design, and the said Piece of Ground whereon the Market was held hath been since let out upon a Building Lease, for a certain Term of Years, at a reserved Rent of 65 /. per Annum.

And the Witness further said, That for several Years past the Surplus Money, as it came into the Hands of the Treasury, had been placed in the public Funds, and had been accumulating.

And it appeared by the Treasurer’s Accounts, which the Witness produced, That the Trustees are now possessed of 4,200l. in the 3 per Cent. Consolidated Bank Annuities, and that their whole Annual Income amounts -at present to the Sum of 320/. or thereabouts, and their Disbursements to about 50/. per; and that

there is now in the Hands of the Treasurer the Sum of 185/. lf>J. 11 d.

Then several of the Trustees informed your Committee, That they are desirous of conveyir.g and giving up all their Estates and Property they are entitled to by virtue of the said Acts, to the Marine Society, in Augmentation of their Fund, and to be discharged from their Trust; and they beg Leave to submit to the House, whether so much of the several Acts as relates to the said Fish Market should not be repealed.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill for conveying and applying the Estates and Monies belonging to the Trustees of Westminster Fish Market, to the Marine Society, in Augmentation of their Fund, and for repealing certain Provisions in the several Acts of Parliament relating to the said Fish Market: And that Mr. Henry Hobart and Mr. Samuel Thornton do prepare, and bring in, the same.

The House proceeded to take into Consideration the Lords Amendments made by the Lords to the Bill, intituled,

Mr. Pochin accordingly reported from the saidj Committee, That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed to be reported to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Leeds Water Mr. Duncombe reported from the Committee, to and Lighting whom the Bill for better supplying the Town and Bill reporte . Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with Water, and for more effectually lighting and cleansing the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, was committed; and to whom the Petition of John Pate Nevile, of Holbeck, in the County of York, Esquire, was referred; That the Committee had considered the said Petition, and had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One.by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, One of them was disagreed to, and the rest were, - with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

A Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, to secure the Interest of Mr. Sagar in Pitt-fall Mills.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Then an Amendment was made, by the House, to the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Notice being taken that His Majesty's Interest is King’s Cott* concerned in the Bill for dividing and inclosing Tickton 8*nt toTick-Carr, or Common, in the County of York, which Bill g[j| nc ur® was, upon the 2*3d Day of this Instant April, reported from the Committee to whom the same had been committed;

Mr. Gamon reported from the Committee, who were Report from

appointed to take into Consideration an Act made in Committee the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present on Sta?e Majesty, intituled, "An Act for limiting the Number Coach p»®* ".of Persons-to be carried on the Outside of Stage 8enge " Coaches or other Carriages," and to report to the House what Measures may be deemed necessary to enforce the due Observance thereof; That the Committee had considered the said Act, and had agreed upon a Report, which they had directed him to make to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table'

Where the same was read; and is as followeth;

.Your Committee think, That it will be necessary to alter, explain, and amend the said Act, particularly with respect to the N umber of Passengers allowed to go on the Outside of Stage Coaches; and that for the better enforcing the due Observance thereof, it will be necessary to authorize the Collectors of the Tolls at every Turnpike Gate through which any Stage Coach shall pass, to demand and take, as a Toll, a certain Sum for each Passenger above the Number to be allowed, and that proper Powers shall be given for the collecting, levying, and recovering such Toll, and to prevent the same being evaded — To oblige the Owners of Stage Coaches to put the Names of the Proprietors thereon, and to Number the same — To prevent any. Passenger from driving the Coach, without the full Consent of all the other Passengers; and also to prevent the Guard of the Coach from tiring off his Arms, except for the Defence of the same. ’

Mr. Gamon also reported from the said Committee,

That he was directed by the Committee to move the House, that Leave be given to bring in a Bill to alter, explain, and amend an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled,

" An Act for limiting the Number of Persons to be " carried on the Outside of Stage Coaches or other " Carriages."

And Mr. Gamon moved the House accordingly.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to alter, explain, and amend an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for limiting the Number of " Persons to be carried on the Outside of Stage Coaches,

" or other Carriages :’’ And that Mr. Gamon, Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Pye, and Mr. Robert Burton, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

An ingrossed Bill for better supplying the Town and Letd* Water Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with and Lighting Water; and for more effectually lighting and cleansing Bypassed, the Streets and other Places within the said Town and Neighbourhood, and removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein, was read the Third Time.

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 25. L 7. After " Covert’’ to insert " where the " same shall exceed the Sum of " Twenty Pounds."

1. 24. After " Money" to insert " and also " such Sums of Money to be paid " as aforesaid as shall not exceed " Twenty Pounds."

Pr. 30. 1. 9. To leave out from " mentioned" to " or" in I. 12.

1.13. After " D.irt" to insert " or," and to leave out " or Stones."

Pr. 33-1. 36. After " Pounds" to insert " Provided " nevertheless, That no One Person ’ " shall be obliged to serve the said

" Office of Assessor more than " Once."

And the said Amendments were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for better supplying the Town and Neighbourhood of Leeds, in the County of York, with Water,

Resolved, That it appeal's to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company, in the Proviness of Bengal, Bah and > , and front Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Mint or Coin-

age Duties, Post Office Collections, Benares Revenue,

Chide Subsidy, Land Revenues, Customs, and the Receipts from the Sales of Salt and Opium,- for the Year 1789-90, are estimated by the Governor General and Council to amount to the Sum of Five Crore, Sixty Lacks, Ninety-three thousand Nine handled ana Seventy-one Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Charges to be defrayed by the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal, Bahar, and Orissa, and in Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Civil, Military, and Marine, the Charges of Buildings and Fortifications, of collecting the Revenues and Customs, and the Advances and Charges on Account of Salt and Opium, for the Year 1789-90, are estimated by the Governor General end Council to amount to the Sum of Three Crore, Sixteen Lacks, Twenty-six thousand Two hundred and Seventy Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal, Bahar, and Orissa, and from Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Mint or Coinage Duties, Post Office Collections, Benares Revenue, Oude Subsidy, Land Revenues, Customs, and the Receipts from the Sales . of Salt and Opium, amounted, on the Average of Three Years, from 1786-7 to 1788-9, both inclusive, to the Sum of Five Crore, Thirty Lacks, Fifty-seven thousand Five hundred and Eleven Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it* appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues, of the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal, Bahar, and Orissa, and from

Benares and Oude, under the same Heads, which were estimated for the Year 178S-9 at Five Crore, Forty-four Lacks, One thousand Four hundred and Eighty-one Current Rupees, amounted to Five Crore, Sixty-one Lacks, Ninety-nine thousand Nine hundred and Forty-two Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Charges defrayed by the East India Company in the Provinces of Bengal Bahar, and Orissa, and in Benares and Oude, under the Heads of Civil, Military, and Marine, the Charges of collecting the Revenues and Customs, and the Advances and Charges on Account of Salt and Opium, which were estimated for the Year 1788-9 at Two Crore, Ninety-four Lacks, Fifty-seven thousand Nine hundred and Eighteen Current Rupees, amounted to Three Crore, Eighteen Lacks, Thirty-two thousand Five hundred and Five Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company at the Presidency of Fort Saint George, and the Settlements subordinate thereto, and in the Carnatic and Northern Circars, under the Heads of Mint or Coinage Duties, Sea or Land Customs, Subsidy of the Nabob of Arcot and Rajah of Tanjore, Land Revenues, and Farms and Licences, amounted, on an Average of the Years 1786-7 and 1787-8, to the Sum of Twenty-seven Lacks, Ninety-five thousand Nine hundred and Twelve Pagodas.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company at the Presidency of Fort Saint George, and the Settlements subordinate thereto, and in the Carmlic and Northern Circars, under the Heads aforesaid, which were estimated (after allowing for the Charges of collecting the same) to amount to Thirty-one Lacks, Seven thousand Four hundred and Seventy-eight Pagodas, amounted to Thirty Lacks, Thirty-three thousand and Seventy-two Pogodas.

Vox.. 45.

Resolved, That it appears t6 this Committee; That the Charges defraydd by the East India Chtnpany at the Presidency of Fort Saint Geot'ge, and the Settlements Subordinate thereto, and in the Carnatic and Northern Circars, under the respective Heads of Civil, Military;

Buildings and Fortifications, which were estimated, for the Year 1788-9, to amount to Twenty-nine Lacks,

Eighty-seven thousand Five' hundred and Sixty-four Pagodas, amounted -to Thirty-two Lacks, Fifty-five thousand and Ninety-three Pagodas.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company at the Presidency of Bombay, and the Settlements subordinate thereto, under the Heads of Land Revenues,

Customs, and Farms and Licences, for the Year 1789-90, are estimated by the Governor and Council of Bombay at the Sum of Eleven Lacks, Ninety-one thousand Six hundred and Twenty-seven Bombay Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Charges to be defrayed by the East India Company at the Presidency of Bombay, and the Settle- . ments subordinate thereto, in the Year 1789-90, are estimated at Forty-nine Lacks, Two thousand Six hundred and Seventy-six Bombay Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Revenues of the East India Company at the Residency of Fort Marlborough and its Dependencies, arising from Customs, Farms, and Licences, amounted on an Average of Three Years, from 1785-6 to 1787-8, both inclusive, to the Sum of Eleven thousand and Twenty-four Dollars.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Total Debts owing by the East India Company in their different Settlements in the East Indies, exclusive of the Sums for which Bills have been granted, payable on the Court of Directors at Home, in pursuance of their Orders of the 15th Day of September 1785, and 31st Day of July 1787, amounted, according to the latest Accounts of the whole Debt received in England, to the Sum of Six Crore, Fifty Lacks, Thirteen thousand Eight hundred and Fifty-eight Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Total of the Debts owing by the East India Company in their different Settlements in the East Indies, bearing Interest, amounted, on the 30th Day of April 1789. to the Sum of Five Crore, Twenty-six Lacks, Six -thousand Seven hundred and Twenty-seven Current Rupees.

Resolved, That it appears to this Committee, That the Annual Amount of Interest, payable on the said Debts in India, was forty-three Lacks, Eighty-four thousand Two hundred and Sixty-three Current Rupees.

Inhabitants; of Saint Margaret's- and Saint the Evangelist, resident in Abingdon Street, are charged Three Shillings and Six Pence in the Pound, while the Streets under the Management of the Committee-men ate only charged with One Shilling and Six Pence — That if the Optional Streets within the said Parishes were put under the Management of Parochial Cora, mittees they would be better regulated, and at a less th;. To prove the Allegations of the Third-mentioned Pe. 't; tition, the said Act of the Eleventh Year of His present Majesty was read: And,

Luke Idtson, Esquire, being examined, said, That the Rates in the Optional Streets in the said. Parishes of Saint James, Saint Martin in the Fields, and Saint Anne, are from Two Shillings to Four Shillings in the Pound, and that the Parochial Rates are only One Shilling and Six Pence, out of which a considerable Saving is made towards discharging the Debt — That, if the Optional Streets within the said Parishes were put under the Management of Parochial Committees they would be better regulated, and at a less Expence than at present — That the Powers the said Committees are invested with are not sufficient to enable them to remove and prevent Nuisances, Annoyances, and Encroachments.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker’s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their'Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported. That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

And the Naples of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Thfin the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Hall accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further ,in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Thursday Morning next, at Ten of the Clock, in Westminster Hall:

And then the Messengers withdrew.
