446 5° Mani A. 1790*

the Allegations of the Gill, and found the same to be true; and that the Parties concerned had given their Consent to the Bill, to the Satisfaction of the Committee (except the Proprietor of 80 Acres, who is Abroad, and the Proprietor of 2 Acres, who could not be seen on Account of Illuess, and also the Proprietor of 2 Acres and Two Roods, who refused her Consent to the Bill; and that the Whole of the Lands intended to be inclosed consist of 2,722 Acres and One Rood; and that no Person appeared before the Committee to oppose the Bill); and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer acquainted the House, That he had a Message from His Majesty to this House, signed by His Majesty; and he presented the same to the House; and it was read by Mr. Speaker (all the Members of the House being uncovered); and is as followeth; viz.

GEORGE R.

His Majesty has received Information, that Two Vessels belonging to His Majesty’s Subjects, and navigated under the British Flag, and Two others, of which the Description is not hitherto sufficiently ascertained, have been captured at Nootka Sound, on the North Western Coast of America, by an Officer commanding Two Spanish Ships of War; that the Cargoes of the British Vessels have been seized, and that their Officers and Crews have been sent as Prisoners to a Spanish Port.

The Capture of One of these Vessels had before been notified by the Ambassador of his Catholic Majesty, by Order of his Court, who at the same Time desired that Measures might be taken for preventing His Majesty’s Subjects from frequenting those Coasts, which were alledged to have been previously occupied and frequented by the Subjects of Spain. Complaints were also made of the Fisheries carried on by His Majesty’s Subjects in the Seas adjoining to the Spanish Continent, as being contrary to the Rights of the Crown of Spain. In Consequence of this Communication, a Demand was immediately made, by His Majesty’s Order, for adequate Satisfaction, and for the Restitution of the Vessel, previous to any other Discussion.

By the Answer from the Court of Spain it appears, that this Vessel and her Crew had been set at Liberty by the Vice-Roy of Mexico; but this is represented to have been done by him on the Supposition that nothing but the Ignorance of the Rights of Spain encouraged the Individuals of other Nations to come to those Coasts for the Purpose of making Establishments, or carrying on Trade, and in Conformity to his previous Instructions, requiring him to shew all possible Regard to the British Nation.

No Satisfaction is made, or offered, and a direct Claim is asserted by the Court of Spain to the exclusive Rights of Sovereignty, Navigation, and Commerce, in the Territories, Coasts, and Seas, in that Part of the World.

His Majesty has now directed His Minister at Madrid to make a fresh Representation on this Subject, and to claim such full and adequate Satisfaction as the Nature of the Case evidently requires. And, under these Circumstances, His Majesty, having also

received Information that considerable Armaments are carrying on in the Ports of Spain, has judged it indispensably necessary to give Orders for making such Preparations as may put it in His Majesty’s Power to act with Vigour and Effect in Support of the Honour of His Crown, and the Interests of His People. And His Majesty recommends it to His faithful Commons (on whose Zeal and Public Spirit He has the most perfect Reliance) to enable Him to take such Measures, and to make such Augmentation of His Forces, as may be eventually necessary for this Purpose.

It is His Majesty’s earnest Wish, that the Justice of His Majesty’s Demands may ensure, from the Wisdom and Equity of his Catholic Majesty, the Satisfaction which is so unquestionably due; and that this Affair may be terminated in such a Manner as to prevent any Grounds of Misunderstanding in future, and to continue and confirm that Harmony and Friendship which has so happily subsisted between the Two Courts, and which His Majesty will always endeavour to maintain and improve, by all such Means as are consistent with the Dignity of His Majesty’s Crown, and the essential Interests of His Subjects.

R.

Ordered, That His Majesty’s said most Gracious Message be taken into Consideration Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That the Bill for regulating the Election of Members to serve in Parliament for that Part of Great Britain called Scotland, be printed.

The House, according to Order, resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Bill to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Twentieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, touching the Election for Knights of the Shire to serve in Parliament for that Part of Great Britain called England.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Captain Berkeley took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Captain Berkeley reported from the Committee, That they had made several other Amendments to the Bill; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received upon Friday Morning next.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Montagu and Mr. Leeds:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have passed a Bill, intituled, An Act for Sale of Part of the settled Estates of Richard Wilson, Esquire, deceased, in the County of York, and for settling other Estates, in the County of the City of York, in Lieu thereof; to which the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Tuesday Morning next, at Ten of the Clock, in Westminster Hall: And also,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will give Order for summoning John Shore, Esquire, as a Witness to be produced at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, as desired.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Petition from Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor reported from the Com-Hoosesin m*ttee, to whom the Petition of several Owners and llolborn and Occupiers of Houses within a certain Street and Place Middle Row, called Holborn and Middle Row, situate and being in reported. the United Parishes of Saint Giles in the Fields and Saint George, Bloomsbury, and in the Parish of Saint Andrew, Holborn, in the County of Middlesex, commonly called an Optional Street and Place, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is us followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, made in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to amend and render more effectual several Acts relating to paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, was read: And,

Herbert Robertson, Esquire, being examined, said, That the Inhabitants of Holborn and Middle Row have been and are now charged with much higher Rates for paving, cleansing, and lighting, than the Inhabitants of the other Streets within the same Parishes — That if the said Street and Place were put under the Management of the joint Committee-men for the United Parishes of Saint Giles in the Fields and Saint George, Bloomsbury, the Works would be better done, and at a much less Expence, than at present

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Gentlemen who are appointed to prepare, and bring in, a Bill to explain, amend, and render more effectual, several Acts, made for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places, within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, and for putting certain Streets therein mentioned, commonly called Optional Streets, under the Management of Committees, to be Annually chosen by the Parish or Precinct wherein such Streets are situate, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, bnd Encroachments in the said Streets, and other Places, and for other Purposes, That they do make Provision in the said Bill for putting a certain Street

and Plate called tiolborn and Middle Row, within die Parishes of Saint Giles in the Fields, Saint George, Bloomsbury, and Saint Andrew, Holbotn, in the County of Middlesex, under the Management of the joint Com* ihittee-men, for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Streets, and other public Passages and Places, within the said Parishes of Saint Giles in the Fields and Saint George, Bloomsbury.

The House proceeded to take the said Message into Consideration.

And the same was again read by Mr. Speaker.

Resolved, Nemine Contradicente, That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, to return His Majesty the Thanks of this House, for His most Gracious Message, acquainting this House of those Circumstances relative to the Capture of British Vessels on the North Western Coast of America, and to the Conduct of the Court of Spain on this Occasion, which have induced His Majesty to give Orders for making such Preparations as may put it in His Majesty’s Power to act with Vigour and Effect in Support of the Honour of His Majesty's Crown, and of the Interests of His People; and to assure His Majesty, that we shall readily proceed to enable His Majesty to take such Measures, and to make such Augmentation of His Majesty’s Forces, as may eventually be necessary on this Occasion.

That we trust that the Justice of His Majesty’s Demands will ensure, from the Wisdom and Equity of his Catholic Majesty, the Satisfaction which is so unquestionably due to His Majesty; and that we shall sincerely rejoice in such a Termination of the Discussions now depending, as may prevent any Grounds of Misunderstanding in future, and may continue and confirm that Harmony and Friendship which has happily subsisted between^ Great Britain and Spain; but that we, at the same Time, feel it our indispensable Duty to assure His Majesty of the Determination of His faithful Commons, to afford His Majesty the most zealous and effectual Support in such Measures as may become requisite for maintaining the Dignity of His Majesty’s Crown, and the essential Interests of His Majesty’s Dominions.

Ordered, That the said Address be presented to His Majesty by such Members of this House as are of His Majesty’s most Honourable Privy Council.

King’s Mrs-sage respecting Vessels captured by Spain considered, and Address thereupon.

A Motion was made, and the Question was pro- Motion for posed, That there be laid before this House, a State of StateofTrade the Trade carried on from Great Britain and Ireland to the North Western Coast of Noi'th America, and also America,&c. of the Southern Whale Fishery. withdrawn.

And the said Motion was, with Leave of the House, withdrawn.

Resolved, That an humble Address be presented to Address con-His Majesty, That He will be graciously pleased to cerning the give Directions, that there be laid before this House, CaPl,.ir« the Intelligence received by His Majesty’s Ministers certe,n 'Ps>

02 concerning

Motion concerning the Spanish Armament. Neg.

Mr. Newton to attend Committee on Slave Trade,

Slave Trade deferred.

African Slave Bill deferred.

concerning the Capture of the Ships mentioned in His Majesty’s Most Gracious Message.

Ordered, That the said Address be presented to His Majesty by such Members of this House as are of His Majesty's most Honourable Privy Council.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty,. that He will be graciously pleased to give Directions that there be laid before this House, the Information received concerning the Armament in the Spanish Ports, and the Dates when such Information was received;

It passed in the Negative.

Ordered, That the Reverend John Newton do attend the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

The other Orders of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tuesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House relative to the State of the African Slave Trade.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill to continue, for a Time to be limited, and amend, an Act made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act to continue, for a " limited Time, and amend, an Act made in the " last Session of Parliament, intituled, An Act to " regulate, for a limited Time, the shipping and " carrying Slaves, in British Vessels from the Coast " of Africa."

Resolved, That this House will. Tomorrow Morn- ing, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill -to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of

British-made Spirits from England to , and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported" from the West Indies.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

RATERS.

A MESSAGE by Mr. Quarme, Yeoman Usher of Royal Assent the Black Rod: to Bills.

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords, authorized by virtue of His Majesty's Commission, for declaring His Royal Assent to several Acts agreed upon by both Houses, do desire the immediate Attendance of this Honourable House in the House of PeeTs, to hear the Commission read.

Accordingly Mr. Speaker, with the House, went up to the House of Peers.

And being returned;

Mr. Speaker reported, That the House, at the Desire of the Lords authorized by virtue of His Majesty's Commission afore-mentioned, had been at the House of Peers, where a Commission under the Great Seal was read, giving, declaring, and notifying, the Royal Assent to the several Public and Private Bills therein mentioned; and also impowering His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, His Royal Highness the Duke of York, His Royal Highness the Duke of Clarence, His Royal Highness the Duke of Gloucester, His Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland, the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and several other Lords, to declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills; and that the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, and the Duke of Leeds, named also in the said Commission, did accordingly declare and notify the Royal Assent to the said Bills: Which Bills are as followeth; viz.

An Act for altering the Time appointed for holding the Summer Session in the Court of Session in Scotland, and for altering Whitsuntide and Lammas Terms in the Court of Exchequer in Scotland:

An Act for effectually carrying into Execution Two Acts, of the Sixteenth and Twenty-fifth Years of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Navigable Canal from the Stourbridge Navigation to the Birmingham, and Birmingham and Fazetey Canal Navigations, in the Counties of Worcester and Stafford:

An Act for authorizing and enabling the Right honourable George Earl of Mount Edgcumbe, and Reginald Pole Carew, Esquire, to establish and maintain a common Ferry over and across the River Tamer, between a certain Place North of Plymouth Dock, in the Parish of Stoke Damarel, in the County of Devon, and Torpoiht, in the Parish of Antony Saint Jacob, otherwise Antony in the East, in the County of Cornwall:

An Act for paving and otherwise improving the Town of Honiton, in the County of Devon:

An Act for paving, cleansing, lighting, and widening the Streets, Lanes, and Passages, for removing and preventing Encroachments, Nuisances, and Annoyances, and for regulating the Porters and Drivers of Carts within the Borough of Truro, and Part of the adjoining Parishes, in the County of Cornwall:

An Act for preserving the Works made for supplying the Town of Bradford, in the County of York, and Part of the Township of Horton, in the Parish of'

Bradford aforesaid, with Water, for the more easy Recovery of the Rents for the said Water, and to enable the Proprietors thereof to borrow Money for the improving such Wrorks:

An Act for establishing a Chapel at Ramsgate, in the Parish of Saint Lawrence, in the Isle of Thanet, in the

An Act for empowering Persons navigating Boats, Barges, and other Vessels, in the River in the County of Norfolk, to hale or tow with Horses, or other Beasts, on the Banks or Sea Walls of the said River, and for making Satisfaction to the Owners of the said Banks or Sea Walls t An Act for continuing and amending an Act, of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty, for amending and widening the Road from Saint Stephens Gate, in the County of the City of Norwich, to the Windmill in the Town of Watton, in the County of Norfolk:

An Act to continue the Term, and alter the Powers, of so much of Two Acts, made in the Twenty-fifth and and Thirty-first Years of the Reign of his late Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Linlithgow and Stirling, as relates to the Roads lying within the County of Linlithgow

A Petition of the Churchwardens and Inhabitants of Petition the Parish of Saint Mary Magdalen, Bermondsey, in the aga*1 County of Surrey, whose Names are thereunto subscribed, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for enlarging the Term, and for explaining, amending, and making more effectual the Powers, of Two several Acts, passed in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the Seventh Year of His present Majesty, for making a new Rood from New in the Parish of Saint John, Southw, to and through

the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the same, and several other Roads adjoining, in Repair, and also for making and keeping in Repair other Roads adjacent thereto; and Setting forth. That the Petitioners find themselves much aggrieved by the above-recited Act of the Seventh Year of His present Majesty: And therefore praying, That they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against such of the Clauses, Powers, and Authorities, in the said recited Act of the Seventh Year of His present Majesty contained, which any way relate to, or concern, the Petitioners, being continued in Force, and exercised and executed after the Expiration of the Term by the said Act granted, or that the Petitioners may be otherwise relieved therein, as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

Ordered, That all have Voices who come to the Committee to whom the said Bill is committed.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass i And that the Title be, An Act for the better paving, cleansing, lighting^ and watching the City of Coventry, and the Suburbs thereof, and removing and preventing. Nuisances and Annoyances therein, and for regulating the Public Wells and Pumps within the said City and Suburbs.

Ordered, That the Lord Eardtey do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

The Earl of Courlown reported to the House, That their Address of Yesterday (to return His Majesty the Thanks of this House, for His most Gracious Message, acquainting this House of the Circumstances relative to the Capture of British Vessels on the North Western Coast of America, and to the Conduct of the Court of Spain on that Occasion, which have induced His Majesty to give Orders for making such Preparations as may put it in His Majesty’s Power to aet with Vigour and Effect in Support of the Honour of His Majesty’s Crown, and of the Interests of His People) had been presonted to His Majesty; and that His Majesty had commanded him to acquaint this House, that His Majesty received, with great Satisfaction, the unanimous Assurances of their Support, which must tend to produce the most salutary Consequences in the present Conjuncture.

Mr. Baring reported from the Committee, to whom the Petition of Thomas Selby, Esquire, and Catherine his Wife, and William Commyns, Esquire, oh Behalf of themselves and of Patrick Esquire, William

Carr, Esquire, tad Henrietta his Wife, Barbara White, Widow of Nicholas White, Esquire, deceased, Charlotte Strickland, Spinster, and Sir John Lawson, Baronet^ which said Catherine Selby, William Commyns, Patrick Power, Henrietta Carr, Barbara White, and lip

Strickland, are the Heirs at Law of Sir Roger Strickland, late of Cattorick, in the County of York, Baronet,

deceased, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them* to the House; and he read the Report in his Plage; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as folloiveth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, the Probate of the Will of Mary Brathwaite, dated February 1680, was produced to your Committee, by which it appeared, That 9he devised certain Estates in Catterick, in the County of York, to her Nephew, Sir Roger Strickland, Baronet, and his Heirs Male, and irt Default of such Issue, to his Brother Robert Strickland, for Life, and then to his Heirs in Tail Male, with the ultimate Remainder to the said Sir Roger in Fee.

It also appeared to your Committee, That the said Sir Roger Strickland was attainted of High Treason in the Year 16.89, an^ thereby forfeited to the Crown all the Estates of which he was then seised in Possession or Reversion, which were accordingly seized and held until his Death, which happened in the Year 1717, without his leaving any Issue — That his Brother Robert Strickland died before him, leaving Three Sons, Roger, Mannock, and francis — That by the Settlement made on the Marriage of Roger Strickland, the eldest of the said Three Sons, dated 19th March 1725, it appeared that he had been let into Possession of the' said Estates by Reason that the Forfeiture thereof was, by the Death of the said Sir Roger Strickland without Issue, suspended, as long as there should be Issue Male of the said Robert Strickland existing — That in Consequence of Failure of Issue Male, and by virtue of

divers

Answer to Address oh King's Message.

Mr. Selby's Petition reported.

7° Mail

A. 1790.

divers Conveyances, Assurances, and Acts in Law, Thomas Selby and Catherine his Wife, in Right of the said Catherine, William Commyns, Patrick William

Carr and Henrietta his Wife, in Right of the said Henrietta, Barbara White, the Widow of and Charlotte Strickland, became entitled to, and are now in the actual Possession of the said Estates, as Tenants in Common, except a small Part which hath been purchased by Sir Henry , Baronet. —

And,

William Sheldon, Esquire, being examined, said, That Doubts have arisen whether the Reversion in the said Estates, which, by virtue of the Attainder, became vested in the Crown, has ever been barred, by Reason whereof no Person may chuse to become a Purchaser of the said Estates at a full and valuable Consideration; and that the Title to that Part purchased by Sir Henry Lawson, Father to Sir John Lawson, is of course precarious.

Ordered, That the said Report be referred to the Consideration of a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the said Report.

Petition from Tl/TR. Mainwaring reported from the Committee,

called Pentonville, was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition, an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intitule J, " An Act for pulling " down the Church of Saint James, at Clerkenwell, in Vol. 45.

Mnii. 453

" the County of Middlesex, and for building a new " Church, and making a new Church Yard or Cemetery " in the said Parish, with convenient Avenues and " Passages thereto," was read: And,

Mr. Aaron Henry Hurst being examined, informed your Committee, That the Trustees appointed by the said Act had caused the old Church to be taken down, and had begun to erect a new Church; that they had already laid out the "Sum of 8,000l. in carrying on the Work, and that a very considerable Sum more must be raised to complete the said Church, and other Works, and that a great Proportion thereof will be paid by the Inhabitants of Pentonville, although many of them will receive very little Benefit from building the said Church, owing to the great Distance of their Places of Residence from the Church. — And he added, That a commodious Chapel hath been built within the said District by private Persons, which may be purchased for the Use of the Inhabitants for a much less Sum than it would cost to build a new Chapel equally large and commodious. — And the Witness informed your Committee, That Henry Esquire,

who is Owner of a considerable Estate in Pentonville, hath offered to give an Acre of Ground to be applied to such Purpose as shall be thought most beneficial to the Parish, in case the Inhabitants shall be authorized to raise a sufficient Sum of Money to purchase the said Chapel.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Committee, to whom the Bill for amending, and enlarging the Powers of, and rendering more effectual, an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty intituled, "An Act for pulling down " the Church of Saint James, at Clerkemoell, in the " County of Middlesex, and for building a new Church, " and making a new Church Yard or Cemetery in the " said Parish, with convenient Avenues and Passages " thereto," is committed, That they have Power to make Provision in the said Bill for providing a Chapel for the Use of the Inhabitants of the District of Penion* ville, in the said Parish.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to Mr. Henry Hobart, Mr. Marsham, &c.: And they are to meet this Afternoon, at Five of the Clock, in the Speaker's Chamber.

Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to explain, amend, and render more effectual, several Acts, made for paving, cleansing and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places, within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, and for putting certain Streets, therein mentioned, commonly called Optional Streets, under the Management of Committees, to be Annually chosen by the Parish or Precinct wherein such Streets are situate, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments in the said Streets, and other Places, and for other Purposes: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

A Petition of the several Persons whose Names are thereunto subscribed, Merchants, Traders, and others, carrying on Trades and Businesses at or near Dock Head, in the County of Surrey, for and on Behalf of themselves and others, at and near the said Place, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill for enlarging the Term, and for explaining, amending, and making more effectual the Powers, of Two several Acts, passed in the Twenty-second Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, and the Seventh Year of His present Majesty, for making a new Road from Street, in the Parish of Saint John, Southwark, to and through the several Places therein mentioned, and for keeping the same, and several other Roads adjoining, in Repair, and also for making and keeping in Repair other Roads adjacent thereto; and Setting forth, That the said Bill contains certain Powers and Provisions, which, if passed into a Law, would materially affect and prejudice the Petitioners: And therefore praying, That the said Bill may not pass as it now stanCs, and that they may be heard, by themselves or Counsel, against such Parts thereof as may affect them, or that the Petitioners may have such other Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem meet.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee, to whom the said Bill is committed; and that the Petitioners be heard, by

themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do admit Counsel to be heard, at the same Time, in Favour of the said Bill, against the said Petition.

read; Complaining of their Distress, and praying Relief.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table.

The Earl of Courlawn reported the House, That Answer to their Address of Thursday last (that His Majesty would Address, be graciously pleased to give Directions, that the Intelligence received by His Majesty’s Ministers concerning the Capture of the Ships mentioned in His Majesty’s most Gracious Message, might be laid before this House) had been presented to His Majesty; and that His Majesty was pleased to say, that He would give Directions, that the Memorial delivered to His Majesty’s Secretary of State respecting the Vessels captured at Nootka, together with the Papers referred to in the said Memorial, should be laid before the House.

Henry Hobart, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of made Spirits

from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in ueu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

Ordered, That the Oader of the Day, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House upon the Bill for granting to His Majesty a certain Sum of Money, to be raised by a Lottery, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Air. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Ordered, That such a Number of Copies of the said Bill, with the Amendments, be printed, as shall be sufficient for the Use of the Members of the House.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Oi'dtred, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker’s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Members of this House in Westminster Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members

there, if an'*, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Person in the said Places or Passages.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by , their Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Hall accordingly.

Mr. Grevillereported from the Committee, to whom sir William

the Petition of Sir William Hamilton, Knight of the Hamilton’* most Honourable Order of the Bath, His Majesty's Envoy Extraordinary, resident at the Court of Naples', rei,or was referred; That the Committee had examined the Matter of the said Petition, and had directed him to report the same, as it appeared to them, to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; ’ffed afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To prove the Allegations of the said Petition,

William Hamilton, Esquire, being examined, said, That Sir William Hamilton is possessed of an Estate adjoining to Milford Haven, called Castle Pill and Priory Pill, in the Manor or Manors of Hubberstone and Pill, in the County of Pembroke.

Mr. William Davies, being examined, confirmed the Evidence of Mr. Hamilton; and added, That he collects a certain Duty called Keelage for every Vessel that enters the Creeks — That the Creeks are capable of being much improved, and want it principally on account of the Packets established between Milford and Waterford, which has brought with it an Establishment of Post Officers and Custom House Officers; and it is apprehended, that if proper Accommodations and Conveniences were provided, and the Creeks improved, and a Market established, a great Number of Persons would be induced to settle, and a considerable Trade might be carried on therefrom — That it will be necessary to erect Quays, Piers, Docks, and other Buildings, for landing and clearing Goods and Merchanize, and to make Roads of Communication with the said Pills, and such Houses and other Buildings as may be erected within the Neighbourhood thereof. — And the Witness being further examined, said, That if the Improvements, above-mentioned should take Place, it will not only considerably benefit the Estate of Sir William Hamilton, but all the others in the Neighbourhood — That it will afford Accommodation for Persons passing to and from Ireland, promote and assist the present Establishment of Packets, and be of great public Utility.

John Francis Meyrick, Esquire, being examined, said, That he is well acquainted with the Situation of the" above Estate, and of the adjacent Country; and confirmed the foregoing Evidence, with respect to the particular and general Utility of the intended Improvements.

Ordered, That Leave be. given to bring in a Bill to enable Sir William Hamilton, Knight of the most Honourable Order of the Bath, his lleirs and Assigns, to make and provide Quays, Docks, Piers, and other Erections, and to establish a Market with proper Roads and Avenues thereto, respectively, within the 02 Manor

Mr. John Stanley reported from the Select Committee, appointed to take the Examination of the several Witnesses that have been, or shall be, ordered by the House to attend the Committee of the whole House, to whom it is referred to consider further of the Circumstances of the Slave Trade, complained of in the several Petitions which have been presented to this House, relative to the State of the African Slave Trade, and to report the Minutes of such Examination from Time to Time, to the House; That the Committee had made a further Progress in the Matter to them referred, and had directed him to report the Minutes of the said Examination to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Leeds and Mr. Pepys:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Navigation to improve the Navigation of the River Severn, from Stourpoi't, in the County of Worcester, to a Place called Diglis, near the City of Worcester; without any Amendment: And also,

also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields and Commonable Places in the Parish of Lutterworth, in the County of Leicester; without any Amendment: And also,

The House being informed, that Mr. Longlands, Accounts re-Agent for the Royal Boroughs of Scotland, attended at specting the the Door; he was called in; and, at the Bar, presented KoyalBurghs to the House, pursuant to their Orders of the 2id Day p'le^ed. of July, in the last Session of Parliament,

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, an Account of the Number of Vessels, and their Tonnage, which have entered from the Southern Whale Fishery, in the Years 1785, 1786, 1787, 1788, and 1789, with the Quantity and Value of the Oil, Whale Fins, and Seal Skins, imported therein, and the Amount of the Bounties paid on the said Fishery; distinguishing each Year.

Mr. Speaker acquainted the House, that on Wednesday last, after the Third Reading of the ingrossed Bill to make perpetual an Act, made in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to enable the Lord High Treasurer, or Commissioners of the Treasury for the " Time being, to let to Farm the Duties granted by " an Act, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, on Horses let to Hire for " travelling Post, and by Time, to such Persons as n should be willing to contract for the same," an in-crossed Clause was offered to be added thereto, by Way of Ryder, requiring the Farmers of the Tax to deliver in upon Oath, every Year, an Account of their Gross Receipts; and that upon a Division of the House, on the Question being put, That the said Clause be brought up, it appeared that Forty Members were not present; whereupon the House was adjourned.

Then the Question being put, That the said Clause be brought up;

It passed in the Negative.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to continue, for a limited Time, an Act made in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act to enable " the Lord High Treasurer, or Commissioners of the " Treasury for the Time being, to let to Farm the " Duties granted by an Act, made in the Twentyfifth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, on

Horses let to Hire for travelling Post, and by " Time, to such Persons as should be willing to contract for the same."

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider further of the Supply granted to His Majesty, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That the Sum of One Million be granted to His Majesty, to enable His Majesty to take such Measures, and to make such Augmentations of His Forces by Sea and Land, as the Exigency of Affairs may require.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Sum, not exceeding Forty-nine thousand Five hundred Fifty-six Pounds Seventeen Shillings and Six Pence, be granted to His Majesty, to' give Relief to certain Merchants, and other Persons, interested in

Lands within the late Province of Georgia, which were Ceded to His Majesty by the Cherokee and Creek Indians, on the 1st Day of June 1773, for the Purpose of discharging the Debts due from those Nations to certain British Traders, which Lands, by virtue of the Treaty of Peace, were ceded to the United States of America.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Committee to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, ^m^ricau to consider of the Statement of the Claims examined, claims."^ and Losses allowed, by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists, up to the 25th of March 1790, and of the Sums which have been already granted on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the Statement of the Claims exa- Statements of mined by the Commissioners appointed to enquire American into the Losses sustained by his Majesty’s Loyal *1^ claims'*" Subjects, either by furnishing Provisions, or other referred, necessary Articles, for the Service of His Majesty’s Navy or Army in America during the late War, or by having their Property used, seized, or destroyed for carrying on the Public Service there, be referred to the said Committee.

Ordered, That the Statement of the Claims examined, and Losses allowed, by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of all such Persons who have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain, up to the 11 th Day of June 1789, and of the Sums which have been already granted on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament, be referred to the said Committee.

Then the House resolved itself into the said Committee;

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had come to several Resolutions; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

Mr. Gilbert also acquainted the House, That he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Thursday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider further of the said Statement.

MR. Baring presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill for divesting out of the Crown the Reversion in Fee of and in certain Hereditaments, heretofore the Estate of Sir Roger Strickland, Knight, deceased, in Catterick and Tunstall, in the County of York, and for vesting the same in the several Persons entitled to the said Hereditaments, and for extinguishing and destroying a certain Term of One hundred Years, for which the said Hereditaments were limited Vol. 45.

A Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, for exempting His Majesty, and His Lessee, from any Expences of carrying the Act into Execution.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Another Clause was offered to be added to the Bill, for reserving certain Rights of the Lessee of the Manor.

And the said Clause was Twice read; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

An ingrossed Bill to continue Two Acts, made In Distillery the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Bill pasted. Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-made Spirits from England to Scotland, and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, ‘ for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to continue Two Acts, made in the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, for discontinuing, for a limited Time, the several Duties payable in Scotland upon Low Wines and Spirits, and upon Worts, Wash, and other Liquors there used in the Distillation of Spirits, and for granting to His Majesty other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for better regulating the Exportation of British-made Spirits from England to Scotland,

and from Scotland to England, and to continue, for a limited Time, an Act, made in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, to discontinue, for a limited Time, the Payment of the Duties upon Low Wines and Spirits for Home Consumption, and for granting and securing the due Payment of other Duties in Lieu thereof, and for the better Regulation of the making and vending British Spirits, and for discontinuing, for a limited Time, certain Imposts and Duties upon Rum and Spirits imported from the West Indies-, and for amending the said Act, made in the Twenty-ninth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Bill for the Custody and Employment of Offenders, ordered.

Petition against the Com Regulation Bill.

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to provide for the Custody and Employment of Offenders in certain Cases, and for the Regulation and Government of the Places in which such Offenders may be confined: And that Mr. Powys, Mr. Phelips, and Sir Gilbert Elliot, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

A Petition of the Lord Provost, Magistrates, and Common Council of the City of was pre-

sented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That several of the Clauses of a Bill, lately brought into the House, for regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn and Grain, must, if passed into a Law, greatly injure the said City, and the Commercial and Manufacturing Counties connected with it, as well as establish a Precedent of the most dangerous Tendency to that Part of the United Kingdom: That more particularly the Act of the Thirteenth of His present Majesty, Chap. 43, in so far as it regulated the Importation and Exportation by the Prices in each County separately, proved a great Alleviation of the distressing Restraints imposed on that Country by former Com Laws, and One great Cause of the Establishment and rapid Improvement of their Manufactures; but the present Bill, so far as it goes to regulate the Importation and Expoi> tation by an Average of the Prices of a District, comprehending not only the Frith of Clyde, but also the greatest Part of the West Coast of* must

counteract the former Regulation, from which the most beneficial Effects have been experienced, while, at the same Time, Agriculture has in every Respect kept Pace with the general Prosperity of the Country, and the Petitioners cannot help having the most serious Apprehensions of the Consequences to the Manufactures, the Population, and the Peace and Quiet, of that very industrious Part of the Country, which must at all Times depend upon Importation for a considerable Part of their Subsistence; and that, while the Petitioners acknowledge the Propriety of subjecting all to one

and the same Law, they beg that the Extent of the District in which they are to be classed may be as much confined as possible, and they must object to the proposed separate Regulation of Oat-meal in Scotland, by which, while that Article may be imported into England whenever Oats are at or above Sixteen Shillings Sterling per Quarter, they are to be restrained from importing it till the Price of Meal exceeds Sixteen Shillings Sterling per Boll, which is equal to upwards of Nineteen Shillings per Quarter of Oats, and this proposed Regulation they thus object to, as being not only an Infringement of their Rights, as British Subjects, entitled to the Participation of equal Laws with their Fellow Subjects of England, but as a Precedent of the most dangerous Tendency to the Commerce, the Manufactures, and the Liberties, of the Country: And therefore praying the House to hear them, by themselves or Counsel, in Support of this Petition, and to afford such Relief in the Premises as to the House shall seem proper.

A Petition of the Directors of the Chamber of Commerce and Manufactures established by Royal Charter in the City of Glasgow, and representing the Trading Interest of the West of Scotland, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That the Petitioners, anxious for the Prosperity of that Part of the Country in which they reside, and solicitous for the Subsistence of its numerous Labourers and Manufacturers, cannot help being alarmed at certain Regulations proposed to be adopted into the Corn Laws, which will not only, in a very great Degree, affect the Prosperity of that Country, but which threatens the Destruction of the very extensive Manutactures established among them: That the District of the Country in which the Petitioners reside is one of the most populous and industrious in Scotland, Von. 45.

and the Manufactures thereto established have, within these few Years, increased in a high Degree, and they hope, from the' Perseverance and Assiduity of its Inhabitants, will increase ‘still further, and though the Agriculture of the Country is greatly improved, yet the Quantity of Com which is raised is so far from being sufficient for the Subsistence of its increasing Inhabitants, that they are always obliged to depend upon Importation from other Quarters; and that the Petitioners were rejoiced to find that it was proposed to make the Regulations of the Corn Trade the same over the Whole of Britain, they were convinced of the Propriety of general Laws and general Regulations for the whole Empire, and they trusted that the illiberal Distinctions in those Laws, which had so long operated to the Disadvantage of that Country, would now be at an End, they were therefore astonished to find that it was proposed not only to keep up these Distinctions, but, by the Alteration of Part of those Laws by which they are at present governed, to make the Situation of, that Country worse than it was before; and that the Grievance-which the Petitioners complain of is the very great Distinction made between their Country and England, that--though Oat-meal is allowed to be imported into England, at a Duty of Two Pence per Hundred Weight, when the Price of Oats is as high as Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, yet, by the proposed Regulations, it cannot be imported into Scotland at the same Duty, until the Price of Meal he Sixteen Shillings per Boll, which is equal to more than Nineteen Shillings per Quarter of Oats; a Distinction of such a Nature, and whereby such a Discrimination is made between one Part of the Country and another, that they trust, it is only necessary to state it to the House, to have it rectified; and that although the present Laws, which have been often and justly complained of, establish this Difference, yet, from the Average of Price for Importation being taken in each County separately, Part of the Hardship was alleviated, but the Petitioners see, with Regret, that while particular Attention has been paid to the local Situation of England, by dividing its Maritime Counties in such a Manner as that sometimes only Two, and, in One Instance, a single County, composes a District by itself, yet that a different System is intended for their Country, as it is proposed to throw the Whole of Scotland into Three Divisions, a Measure which, by uniting that Part of the Country with others less populous or more fertile, will involve its Inhabitants in Distress, and tend to the Ruin of its Manufactures, by preventing the Importation of Grain until it arrives at a Price totally incompatible with their Situation; and that the Petitioners glory in calling themselves British Subjects, and as such depend on an equal Legislation, -but, while they retain that Name, they firmly expect that they shall participate in the Advantages of every Regulation which Parliament shall judge proper for the Welfare of the Empire, and that they shall suffer no Restrictions which the other Parts of the Kingdom are freed from, and therefore rely with Confidence on the Justice of Parliament to prevent such an unequal and -oppressive Distinction, which threatens Ruin to the numerous Manufactures of the said District, and which may, if persisted in, reduce Thousands of its Inhabitants to Distress and Despair: And therefore praying the House to take these Matters under their Consideration, to hear the Petitioners, by themselves, or Counsel, in Support of their Claims, and to grant such Relief as to the House shall seem proper.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to be referred to the Consideration of the Committee to whom the Bill for regulating . the Importation and Exportation of Com, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign . Com imported, and of the Bounty on

6 B . British

12° Man.

British Com exported, is committed; and the Petitioners are to be heard, by themselves or Counsel, before the said Committee, upon their Petitions, if they think fit

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of the Statement of the Claims examined, and Losses allowed, by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of the American loyalists, up to the 2.5th of March 1790, and of the Sums which have been already granted, on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That all Persons who have suffered in their Rights and Properties during the late unhappy Dissentions .-in America, in consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government, in the Classes N# t. 2. 3. 5. 6. 7. and 9. contained in a Statement of the Claims examined by the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of the . American Loyalists, with the Amount of the Sums reported by them to be due to each Class, up to the 31st Day of March 1790, shall receive the full Amount of such Losses, as far as the same do not exceed the Sum of Ten thousand Pounds, and shall also receive, where the Amount of such Losses shall he above Ten thousand Pounds in the Whole, and not above Thirty-five thousand Pounds, Ninety per Cent, of such Part of the said Losses as shall exceed Ten thousand Pounds.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Provision be made for satisfying the Claims of the several Persons who have suffered Losses, either by furnishing Provisions, or other necessary Articles, for the Service of His Majesty’s Navy or Army in America, during the date War, or by having their Property used, seized, or destroyed, for carrying on the Public Service there, amounting in the Whole to the Sum of Sixty-six thousand One hundred and Twenty-four Pounds Fourteen Shillings and Eleven Pence.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Provision be made for satisfying the Claims of the several Persons who have suffered in their Properties in consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain, amounting to the Sum of Twenty-four thousand and Five Pounds Twelve Shillings.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That Allowances be made to such Persons as have suffered during the late uuhappy Dissentions in in consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government, whose Losses of income, arising from Offices or Professions, have been proved to the Satisfaction of the Commissioners (and who are not already adequately provided for) in the Proportion of Fifty per Cent, for every One hundred Pounds of such Annual Income not exceeding Four hundred Pounds, and of Forty per Cent, for every One hundred Pounds of such Income above Four hundred pounds.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, Agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill be brought in upon the Three first of the said Resolutions: And that Mr. ',

Mr. Chancellor ,of the Exchequer, Mr. Edward James Eliot, ;the Earl ,of Morrdngion, the Lord the Lord Apsky, Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Solicitor

06

General, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Resolved, That an humble Address be presented to Address lor His Majesty, That he will be graciously pleased to Pensions to give Directions, that Pensions be allowed to such Persons as have suffered during the late unhappy Dissen- Loyalist*, tions in America,- in consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government, whose Losses of Income, arising from Offices or Professions, have been proved to the Satisfaction of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of the American Loyalists (and who are not already adequately provided for) in the Proportion of Fifty per Cent, for every One hundred Pounds of such Annual Income, not exceeding Four hundred Pounds, and of Forty per Cent, for every One hundred Pounds of such Income above Four hundred Pounds.

Ordered, That the said Address be presented to His Majesty by such Members of this House as are of His Majesty’s jnost Honourable Privy Council.

The House was moved, That an Act, made in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for allowing the Importation and Exportation of certain Goods, Wares, and " Merchandize, in the Ports of Kingston, Savannah " la Mar, Montego Bay, and Santa Lucea in the Island " of Jamaica, in the Port of Saint George in the Island of Grenada, in the Port of Roseau in the Island of " Dominica, and in the Port of Nassau in the Island " of New Providence, one of the Bahama Islands, " under certain Regulations and Restrictions," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the said Act.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the said Committee, That they do consider of the Duties payable on the Importation of Goods and Commodities, the Growth and Production of the Countries bordering on the Province of Quebec.

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning* resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, to consider of the Importation, from any of the Provinces belonging to His Majesty in North ,of Rape

Seed, and all other Seeds used for extracting Oil* and of Rape Cakes, or Cakes made of Rape Seed, from Ireland, for the Purpose of Manure.

A Petition of John Dawson, Thomas Seaman, James Gregson, and Peter William Merchants and

Ship Owners, on Behalf of themselves and all other Merchants trading to the Coast of Africa for Slaves, was presented to the House, and read; Taking Notice of the Bill to continue, for a Time to be limited, and amend, an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act to continue, for a " limited Time, and amend, an Act made in the last " Session of Parliament, intituled, An Act to regulate, " for a limited Time, the Shipping and carrying " Slaves in British Vessels from the Coast of and Setting forth, That the said Bill, if passed into a Law, will be highly injurious to the Petitioners, and to the said Trade in general: And therefore praying, That they may be beard, by themselves or their Counsel, against the said Bill, at the Bar of the House, and that the same may not pass into a Law, or that the Petitioners may be otherwise relieved in such Manner as the House may think proper.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the Table, until the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the said Bill was committed, be taken into further Consideration; and that the Petitioners be then heard, by themselves or Counsel, against the said Bill, upon their Petition, if they think fit.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Ordered, That the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for granting to His Majesty a certain Sum of Money, to be raised by a Lottery, was committed, be received Tomorrow Morning.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Monday Morn-ing next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Bernard presented to the House, pursuant to Intelligence their Address to His Majesty, respecting
