Mr. Steele presented to the House, according to Bill for Order, a Bill for settling and securing a certain Annuity settling an for the Use of the Heirs and Descendants of William Penn, Esquire, the original Proprietor of the Province Descendants of Pensylvania,in Consideration of the meritorious Ser- presented,

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Ordered, That there be laid before this House, Copies Report* of the Reports of the Commissioners of the Customs, respecting made to the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s |flzuzts Treasury on the 8th Day of March 1781, the 11th Day orjS8sr*j| of April 1781, and the 7th Day of May 1790, respecting the Seizures of Ships and Vessels on Account of the illegal Importation of small Quantities of Spirits, and other Articles.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Report Reso-Commitlee of the whole House, to whom it was referred luhona on to consider of the Duties now payable upon Licehces lne and for retailing Wine and Sweets, and upon Licences for Liquorb*15 retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, the Resolutions Licences which the Committee had directed him to report to the Duties* House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerks Table: Where the same were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That the Duties now payable upon Licences for retailing Wine and Sweets, and upon Licences for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, do cease, determine, and be no longer paid or payable.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of Five Pounds Four Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail, Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called England, and who shall not have an Excise Licence for retailing distilled

o(j Spirituous

18° M

497

Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters, or a Licence for retailing Beer, Ale, or other Exciseable Liquors.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Four Pounds Four Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called England, and who shall take out a Licence for retailing Beer, Ale, and other Exciseable Liquors, but shall not have an Excise Licence for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, or

Strong Waters.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Two Pounds Four Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called England, and who shall also have an Excise Licence 'for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Two Pounds Four Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Bt'itish-made Wines, or Sweets, either in that Part of Great Britain called England, or in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Three Pounds Six Shillings and Eight Pence be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland, and who shall not have an Excise Licence for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters, oV a Licence for retailing Beer, Ale, or other Exciseable Liquors.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Two Pounds Thirteen Shillings and Four Pence be charged, upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland, and who shall take out a Licence for retailing Beer, Ale, or other Exciseable Liquors, but shall not have an Excise Licence for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of One Pound Six Shillings and Eight Pence be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Foreign Wine in that Part of Great Britain called Scotland, and who shall also have an Excise Licence for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Four Pounds Fourteen Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall not, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Fifteen Pounds par Annum, or upwards.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, That a Duty of Five Pounds Two Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors, or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His

Vo l. 45.

present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Report Re-Houses, at a Rent of Fifteen Pounds per Annum, of solutions on upwards, and under Twenty Pounds per Annum. s'^intuoif

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Lujuore l*i-That a Duty of Five Pounds Ten Shillings be charged' cences Du-upon every Licence which shall be granted to autho- *les-rize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Twenty Pounds per Annum, or upwards, and under Twenty-five Pounds per Annum.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of Five Pounds Eighteen Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall Reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Twenty-five Pounds per Annum, or upwards, and under Thirty Pounds per Amtim.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of Six Pounds Six Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Thirty Pounds per Annum, or upwards, and under Forty Pounds per Annum.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of Six Pounds Fourteen Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices,

Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith occupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Forty Pounds per Annum, or upwards, and under Fifty Pounds per Annum.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That a Duty of Seven Pounds Two Shillings be charged upon every Licence which shall be granted to authorize any Person to retail distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, if the Dwelling House in which such Person shall reside, or retail such distilled Spirituous Liquors or Strong Waters, at the Time of taking out such Licence, shall, together with the Offices, Courts, Yards, and Gardens, therewith oc* cupied, be rated, under the Authority of an Act, made in the Nineteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for imposing Duties on inhabited Houses, at a Rent of Fifty Pounds per Antmm, or upwards.

mittee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Sir Watkin Lewes reported from the Committee,

That they had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be now received.

And also,

A Petition of several Owners or Proprietors of Petition for Public Stage Coaches, was presented to the House, Provision in and read; Setting forth, That a Bill is ordered to be p^ngere brought into the House, to alter, explain, and amend Bill.

an

501

19° Mail

an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act " for limiting the Number of Persons to be carried " on the Outside of Stage Coaches, or other Carriages;" and that the Petitioners have paid very considerable Sums of Money, from Time to Time, and incurred many heavy Expences, on Account of Losses that have happened, and do Daily happen, in the Carriage of Money, Plate, Jewels, Goods, Wares, Merchandize, and other Effects entrusted to their Care, for a small Premium, and are liable to great and inadequate Risque, for Want of knowing the Value of Effects delivered into their Custody: And therefore praying, That a Clause may be introduced in such Bill, that all Parcels sent, or Luggage of any Passenger travelling, by any Mail Coach, Stage Coach, Diligence, or other public Carriage, carrying Persons or Parcels for Hire, for which a Receipt, expressing the Value, shall be taken from the Master, Owner, or Book Keeper of such Carriage, shall, in case of Loss, be deemed, or taken to be, the Value, and, for Want of such Receipt, that the Master or Owner of such Carriage shall not be answerable for any Loss exceeding Ten Pounds.

Ordered, That the said Petition do lie upon the

Table.

Ordered, That the said Addresses be presented to His Majesty by such Members of this House as are of His Majesty’s most Honourable Privy Council.

Prayers.

Westminster A N ingrossed Bill for conveying and applying the Fi«h Market xx Estates and Monies belonging to the Trustees of Bill passed. Westminster Fish Market to the Marine Society, in Augmentation of their Fund, and for repealing certain Provisions in the several Acts of Parliament relating to the said Fish Market, was read the Third Time.

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Rill; viz.

Pr. 2. 1. 25. To leave out " Institution," and insert " Society " instead thereof.

And the said Amendments were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for vesting the Estate and Property of the Trustees of Westminster Fish Market in the Marine Society, for the Purposes therein mentioned, and for discontinuing the Powers of the said Trustees.

Ordered, That Mr- Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Petition of the Merchants House of Greenock, Petition re* was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, *Pect'"8 t,e That by an Act, passed in the Thirteenth Year of laUon BiSl* His present Majesty, the Importation of Oat-meal into Scotland was prohibited, unless when the Price of that Article exceeded Sixteen Shillings per Boll, while the same Commodity was allowed to be imported into England when the Price of middling British Oats amounted to Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, which corresponds nearly to Thirteen Shillings and Four Pence per Boll in Scotland’, and that,

-by a Bill depending before the House, it is -proposed to continue the same Prohibition, and, as Oat-meal constitutes a very principal Part of the Food of the Poor, the Labourer, and the Manufacturer, and of those who are employed in the Fisheries of Scotland, the Petitioners submit to die House, that it would be highly oppressive and unjust to continue the Import Price of that Article more than Twenty per Cent. higher to the Inhabitants of Scotland than to their Fellow' Subjects in England, and that therefore the Importation of Oat-meal into Scotland ought to be permitted, as in England, when the Price of Oats is at Sixteen Shillings per Quarter; and that, by the aforesaid Act, the Importation and Exportation of Grain into the different Counties of Scotland was regulated by the Average Price of Grain in each County, but,

by the said Bill, it is proposed to divide Scotland into Three Districts, and to regulate the Importation and Exportation by the Average Price in each District:

That in particular the District, in which the Town of Greenock is to be comprehended, is to consist of no less than Seven whole Counties; viz. Lanark, Renfrew,

Dumbarton, Argyle, Ayr, Bute, and besides

the Western Islands, and Part of the distant Counties of Inverness, Ross, Sutherland, and Caithness; and that the Price of Grain in the plentiful County of Wigton, or in the thinly Inhabited Northern Counties (where the Corn is of an inferior Quality) ought not to regulate the Importation of Grain into the County of Renfrew, which, though of small Extent, contains, besides many large Villages, the populous Towns of Paisley,

Retfrew, Port Glasgow, and Greenock, and from the Two last mentioned Places the principal Fisheries in Scotland are. carried on, which, the Petitioners apprehend, the present Bill will materially injure, and therefore trust that the House will see the Justice of allowing the Importation of Grain into the County of Renfrew to he regulated by the Price of Corn in the County itself, or by the Average Price in Renfrew,

Lanark, Ayr, Dumbarton, Argyle, and Bute, the Counties immediately adjoining: And therefore praying the House to alter or amend the aforesaid Bill in the above Particulars, or to give the Petitioners such Relief as the House shall see just, and to allow the Petitioners to be heard, at the Bar, in Support of the Premises.

Ordered, That the said Petition be referred to the Consideration of the Committee of the whole House, to w'hom the Bill for regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign Corn imported, and of the Bounty on British Com exported, is re-committed.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending Trial of Mr. this House, do go, with the Mace, into the Lobby, Hasting*, and Places adjacent, and the Passages leading to Westminster Hall, and summon the Members there to attend their Service in the House immediately.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, do {*o, with the Mace, and clear the Lobby, and the Speaker s Chambers, of all Strangers.

And he went accordingly; and returned.

Ordered, That the Serjeant 'at Arms attending this House, do go into the Places appointed for the Mem-13 bers

bers of this House, in Westmin Hall, and clear the same of all Strangers, and summon the Members there, if any, and in the Passages leading thereto, to attend their Service in the House immediately; and, if he find any Strangers in the said Places or Passages, who refuse to go out, that he take them immediately into his Custody.

And he went accordingly.

And being returned, he reported, That there was no Pierson in the said Places or Passages.

And the Names of the Members, appointed to be Managers at the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, were called over; and they went to the Places in Westminster Hall appointed for them.

Then the House resolved itself into a Committee of the whole House, in order to be present at the said Trial.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Then the Members were called over by the Clerk, by their Counties, as usual; and they went into Westminster Halt accordingly.

And, being returned;

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

TBe Lords have agreed to

Alfreton Roads Bill.

Tunstall Road Bill.

Mr.Has tings’ Trial.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Holford and Mr Walker:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act to enlarge the Term and Powers of an Act, made in the Fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing, widening, and keeping in Repair, the High Roads leading from Alfreton, in the County of Derby, through Carter Lane, to a certain Place in the Town of Mansfield, called and from the

Bridle Gate, at tlte Division of the Liberties of Blackwell and Hucknall, through the Town of Sutton in Ashfield, to the Mansfield and Newark Turnpike at or near Python Hill, in the Forest of Sherwood, in the County of Nottingham; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of an Act, passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from Tunstall, in the County of Stafford, to Bosley, in the County of Chester, and from Or eat Chell to Shelton, in the said County of Stafford; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have commanded us to acquaint this House, That their Lordships will proceed further in the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire, on Tuesday the 1st Day of June next, at Ten of the Clock, in the Morning, in Westminster Hall.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Report on Committee of the whole House, to whom it w'as re- Statement of ferred to consider further of the Statement of the Claims examined, and Losses allowed, by the Com- a missioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists, up to the 25th of March 1790, and of the Sums which have been already granted on Account thereof, and of what remains for Consideration of Parliament, the Resolutions which the Committee had directed him to report to the House; which he read in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same were read; and is as followeth; viz

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Compensation That Compensation be made to the Claimants under to the Claim-the Will of John Earl of Granville, according lo the Statement of the Commissioners appointed to enquire vme-8 yyju, into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists, and that they be allowed the full Amount of their Losses, as far as the same shall not exceed Ten thousand Pounds, and Sixty per Cent, of such Part of the said Losses as shall exceed Ten thousand Pounds.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, Compensa-That Compensation be made to the Right honour- *j°!' *Lord able Robert Lord Fairfax, for the Loss of his Life lairax‘ Interest in certain Lands situate in the Province of Virginia, according to the Statement of the Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses of the American Loyalists, and that he be allowed the full Amount of such Loss, as far as the same shall not exceed Ten thousand Pounds, and Eighty per cent, of such Part of the said Loss as shall exceed Ten thousand Pounds.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Mr. Gilbert, according to Order, reported from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for making Allowances to Distillers of Low Wines and Spirits from Malt, Corn, or Grain, in Scotland, in respect to the Duties imposed by an Act, made in the Twenty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, was committed, the Amendments which the Committee had made to the Bill, and which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, were agreed to by the House

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That whenever the Price of middling British Barley,

Beer, or Bigg, shall be at or above Twenty-four Shillings per Quarter, there be charged an additional Duty of One Penny upon every Quarter of Barley,

Beer, or Bigg, imported into this Kingdom.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That whenever the Price of middling British Oats shall be at or above Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, there be charged an additional Duty of One Penny upon every Quarter of Oats imported into this Kingdom.

The said Resolutions being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That it be an Instruction to the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign Com imported, and of the Bounty on British Corn exported, is re-committed, That they have Power to make Provision in the said Bill pursuant to the said Resolutions.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House Commute* to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, on Yucatan upon the Bill to exempt Goods and Chattels, im- Goods Imported from the Settlement of Yucatan, in South America, and sold by Auction in Great Britain, from the Duty imposed on such Sales, and for allowing a Drawback of the Duties on Goods exported to Yucatan, be now read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Rose presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to enable His Majesty to settle a certain Annuity on the Reverend Francis Doctor of

Physic: And the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be*read a Second Time.

Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for taking into Consideration the Amendments made by the Lords to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of be now

read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

The House proceeded to take the said Amendments into Consideration.

And the said Amendments were read; and are as followeth; viz.

Pr- 19- 1- 30-1 Leave out " have been usually,

?../ "OT"

1.33. Leave out " present," and insert

" late."

Pr. 21. 1. 7. Leave out from " levied " to " And," in Line 27.'

A Motion was made, and the Question being proposed, That the said Amendments be now read a Second Time;

The Amendments following were proposed to be made to the Question; viz.

To leave out the Word " now'," and at the End of the Question to add the Words " upon this Day " Three Months."

And the Question being put, That the Word " now" stand Part of the Question;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

Then the main Question being put;

Ordered, That the said Amendments be now read a Second Time.

The First Amendment being read a Second Time;

And the Question being put, That the House do agree to the said Amendment made by the Lords;

It passed in the Negative.

The Second Amendment (which appeared to be a mere Clerical Mistake of the Reign in which the Act referred to passed) being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

The subsequent Amendment made by the Lords to the said Bill being read a Second Time;

And the Question being put, That the House do agree to the said Amendment made by the Lords;

Tt passed in the Negative.

Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to draw up Reasons to be offered to the Lords at a Conference, for disagreeing to such of the Amendments, made by their Lordships, as this House hath disagreed to.

And a Committee was appointed of Mr. Frederick Montagu, Sir George Augustus William Shuckburgh, Mr. Fox, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. Windham, the Master of the Rolls, Sir Grey Cooper, Mr. Secretary at War, Mr. Attorney General, Mr. Solicitor General, Loid Frederick Campbell, the Lord Bayham, Mr. Hussey, Mr. Comptroller of the Household, Mr. Ellis, Sir Robert Lazdey:And they are to meet To-

morrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock, in the Speaker’s Chamber.

An ingrossed Bill to explain and amend an Act, County passed in the Twentieth Year of the Reign of His Election* present Majesty, touching the Election for knights of Bl11 P88*^-the Shire to serve in Parliament for that Part of Great Britain called England, was read the Third Time.

The Amendments following were severally proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 4. 1. 7. To leave out " of the Person claiming " to vote, and."

1. 9. After " same " to insert " at the " Time of such Assessment being " made."

And the said Amendments were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Twentieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, touching the Election for Knights of the Shire to serve in Parliament for that Part of Great Britain called England.

Ordered, That Captain Berkeley do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for laying a Duty on the Importation from any of the Provinces in North America, of Rape Seed, and all other Seeds used for extracting Oil, and for allowing the Importation from the said Province, of Rape Cakes, or Cape made of Rape Seed, used for Manure, Duty-free.

The House resolved itself into the send Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had made a Progress in the Bill; and that he was directed by the Committee to move, that they may have Leave to sit again.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of die whole House, to consider further of the said Bill.

The Order of the Day being read, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for permitting the Importation of Cashew Gum, from His Majesty’s West India Islands, upon Payment of the like Duty as is paid upon the Importation of Gum Arabic, or Gum Senega;

The House resolved itself into the said Committee.

Mr. Speaker left the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert took the Chair of the Committee.

Mr. Speaker resumed the Chair.

Mr. Gilbert reported from the Committee, That they had gone through the Bill, and made an Amendment thereunto; which they had directed him to report, when the House will please to receive the same.

Ordered, That the Report be received Tomorrow Morning.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for giving Relief to such Persons as have suffered in their Rights and Properties during the late unhappy Dissentions in America, in Consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government; for making Compensation to Persons who furnished Provisions or other necessary Articles to the Army or Navy in America during the War, or whose Property was used, seized, or destroyed, for the carrying on the Public Service there; and also for making Compensation to such Persons as have suffered in their Properties in Consequence of the Cession of the Province of East Florida to the King of Spain.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert have Leave to make a Motion, it being near Seven of the Clock.

And he moved the House accordingly; and.

An ingrossed Bill for enabling His Majesty to authorize His Governor or Lieutenant Governor of such Places beyond the Seas, to which Felons, or other Offenders, may be transported, to remit the Sentences of such Offenders, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act for enabling His Majesty to authorize His Governor or Lieutenant Governor of such Places beyond the Seas, to which Felons, or other Offenders, may be transported, to remit the Sentences of such Offenders.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

Veneris, 21* die

Anno 30* Georgii III'11 Regis, 1790.

Prayers.

AN ingrossed Bill for changing the Sentence now required by Law to be passed on Women convicted of certain Crimes, and substituting another Sentence in Lieu thereof, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for discontinuing the Judgment which has been required by Law to be given against Women convicted of certain Crimes, ana substituting another Judgment in Lieu thereof.

Ordered, That Sir Benjamin Hammet do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Holford and Mr. Walker:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Road from the East End of Bromhain Bridge, in the County of Bedford, to the Turnpike Road leading from Wellingborough to Olney, in the County of Bucks, and also the Road from the said Turnpike Road, at or near the South End of the Town of Olney aforesaid, to the Turnpike Road leading from Northampton to Newport Pagnell, in the same County; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for providing a new Poor House for, and for the better Relief and Government of, the Poor of the Township of Manchester, in the County of Lancaster; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have passed a Bill, intituled, An Act for empowering the Trustees of the most Noble Henry Duke of Newcastle to lay out Part of his settled Money in the Purchase of a Leasehold Manor, Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tythes, Tenements, and Hereditaments, lying intermixed, or convenient to be enjoyed, with his settled Estates in the Counties of Nottingham and York, upon the like Trusts, and with the like Powers, as his said Estates now stand settled upon, or are subject or liable to; to which the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House.

And then the Messengers withdrew.

And the said Bill from the Lords was read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time.

Mr. Gamon presented to the House, according to Order, a Bill to alter, explain, and amend an Act, made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for limiting the " Number of Persons to be carried on the Outside of " Stage Coaches, or other CarriagesAnd the same was received; and read the First Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be read a Second Time. Ordered, That the said Bill be printed.

Ordered, That the Committee, to whom the ingrossed Bill from the Lords, intituled, An Act for exchanging the settled Estate of the Reverend John Templer, in the County of Kent, for another Estate of greater Value in the County of Devon, to be settled in Lieu thereof, is committed, have Leave to sit, notwithstanding any Adjournment of the House.

The House was moved, That the Order made upon Monday last, for the House to resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House upon Tuesday next, upon the Bill for divesting out of the Crown the Reversion in Fee of and in certain Hereditaments, heretofore the Estate of Sir Roger Strickland, Knight, deceased, in Catterick and Tunstall, in the County of York; and for vesting the same in the several Persons entitled to the said Hereditaments, and for extinguishing and destroying a certain Term of One hundred Years, for which the said Hereditaments were limited in Trust for his late Majesty King George the First, his Heirs and Successors, might be read.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That the said Order be discharged.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into the said Committee.

A Bill to enable His Majesty to settle a certain Annuity on the Reverend Francis Willis, Doctor of Physic, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

Resolved, That this House will, at the Rising of the House this Day, adjourn till Wednesday Morning next.

A Bill for repealing the Duties upon Licences for retailing Wine and Sweets, and upon Licences for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, and for granting other Duties in Lieu thereof, was read a Second Time.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed.

Resolved, That the Bill be committed to a Committee of the whole House.

Resolved, That this House will, upon Wednesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the said Bill.

His Majesty would be graciously pleased to order the Sum of One thousand Five hundred Pounds to be issued to John Wilmot, Esquire, Colonel Robert Kingston, Colonel Thomas Dundas, John Marsh, Esquire,

Jeremy Pemberton, Esquire, and Robert Mackenzie,

Esquire, respectively. Commissioners appointed to enquire into the Losses and Services of all such Persons who have suffered in their Rights, Properties, and Professions during the late unhappy Dissentions in America, in Consequence of their Loyalty to His Majesty, and Attachment to the British Government, and to assure His Majesty, that this House will make good the 6ame; and also, that His Majesty would be graciously pleased to order the Sum of Three thousand Pounds to be issued to John Anstie, Esquire, for enquiring, in the United States of America, into such Facts and Circumstances as were thought material for the better ascertaining the several Claims that were made under the Authority of an Act, made in the Twenty-fifth Year of His Majesty’s Reign, or any former Act) had been presented to His Majesty; and that His Majesty had commanded him to acquaint this House, that He will give Directions as desired by the said Addresses.

Complaint being made to the House of a Letter, Complaint contained in a printed Newspaper, intituled, " The " Diary-, or, Wood fall's Register, Tuesday, May 18, r* cot " 1790," which Letter is addressed to the Printer of the said Newspaper, and signed " John Scott," dated

Resolution

thereupon.

Debate thereon adjourned.

Bromley, May 16, 1790, ad containing Reflections on this House for prosecuting the Impeachment against Warren Hastings, Esquire, and on the Speeches and Conduct of some of the Members who are appointed as Managers on the Trial of the said Impeachment, in Breach of the Privilege of this House, and which Letter purports to be written by John Scott, Esquire, a Member of this House;

The said Paper was delivered in at the Table; and the said Letter was read.

And the said Member having, in his Place, acknowledged himself to be the Author of the said Letter, was heard.

And then he withdrew.

Resolved, That it is against the Law and Usage of Parliament, and a high Breach of the Privilege of this House, to write or publish, or cause to be written or published, any scandalous and libellous Reflection on the Honour and Justice of this House in any of the Impeachments or Prosecutions in which it is engaged.

A Motion was made, and the Question being proposed, That it appears to this House, that the said Letter, now delivered in and read, is a scandalous and libellous Paper, reflecting on the Honour and Justice of this House, and on the Conduct of the Managers appointed to manage the Impeachment, now depending, against Warren Hastings, Esquire;

And a Debate arising in the House thereupon:

Ordered, That the Debate be adjourned till Thursday Morning next.

And the said Bill was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass.

Ordered, That Mr. St. John do carry the Bill to the Lords; and acquaint them, that this House hath agreed to the same, without any Amendment.

An ingrossed Bill to exempt Goods and Chattels, imported from the Settlement of Yucatan, in South America, and sold by Auction in Great Britain, from the Duty imposed on such Sales, and for allowing a Drawback of the Duties on Goods exported to Yucatan, was read the'Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to exempt Goods and Chattels, imported from the Settlement of Yucatan, in South America, and sold by Auction in Great Britain, from the Duty imposed on such Sales, and for allowing a Drawback of the Duties on Goods exported to Yucatan.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Resolved, That the Bill do passs: And that the Title be, an Act for granting to His Majesty a certain Sum of Money out of the Consolidated Fund; for applying certain Monies therein mentioned, for the Service of the Year One thousand Seven hundred and Ninety; and for further appropriating the Supplies granted in this Session of Parliament.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Greville reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill to enable Sir William Hamilton, Knight of the most Honourable Order of the Bath, his Heirs and Assigns, to make and provide Quays, Docks, Piers, and other Erections, -and to establish a Market, with proper Roads and Avenues thereto, respectively, within the Manor or Lordship of stone and Pill, in the County of Pembroke, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put-thereupon, were, with an Amendment to One of them, agreed to by the House.

Mr. Frederick Montagu reported from the Com- Reasons for mittee, who were appointed to draw up Reasons to be disagreeing offered to the I-ords, at a Conference, for disagreeing t^II^>nr^entJ to such of the Amendments made by their Lordships to the ^ar-to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging and better wick Gaol regulating the Gaol for the County of Warwick, as Bill, agreed this House hath disagreed to; That the Committee to-had drawn up Reasons accordingly, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered it in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same Was read; and is as followeth; viz.

To the First Amendment made by your Lordships, in Press 19. Lines 30 and 31. which is to leave out the Words " have been usually or," the Commons disagree; because the restraining of the Proceeding directed by this Clause to the Provisions of the Act 12th Geo. II. (which is the Object of this Amendment) may, where the Usage has been otherwise, be attended with considerable Inconvenience and Difficulty.

To the Second Amendment made by your Lordships, ' in Press 19. Line 33. the Commons agree.

To the Third Amendment made by your Lordships, in Press 21. Line 7. the Effect of which Amendment appears to be to lay the Whole of the Expences to be incurred by this Bill on all the Persons liable to pay the County Rate, the Commons disagree; because it does not appear to them either necessary or proper, with respect to such Expences, to follow the Method prescribed by the Act of the 11 th and 12th of King William, for enabling Justices of the Peace to build and repair Gaols, unless in the common and ordinary Cases of repairing or re-building Gaols, in their ancient Form and Manner, at a moderate Expence, and where the other Regulations and Requisitions of that Act are complied with — Because also, That when any new and extensive Plan is adopted for building a Gaol, in which the Number of Cells and Apartments is to be greatly encreased, for the various Purposes of better securing or punishing of Offenders, and preserving the Health of the Prisoners confined therein, and Houses and Lands are to be purchased for the Scite of such Gaol, and other Conveniences adjoining thereto, by which a great additional Expence is to be incurred, so that the Provisions of the said Act of King William are insufficient for the Purpose of carrying such Plan into Execution, and it is therefore become necessary for the Parties to apply to Parliament for further Powers — the Commons think it proper to be attentive to the Method by which such Expence is to be defrayed; to the End that it may be imposed, not on the temporary Farmer or Occupier of the Land, but on those who have a more permanent Interest in the Subject, and are the best able to bear any extraordinary Burthen.

And as an additional Reason to induce your Lordships to waive such of your Amendments as the Commons have disagreed to, they think it right to state to your Lordships several Instances of Bills, for similar Purposes with the present, and of a recent Date, sent by the Commons to your Lordships, to which your

6 P Lordships

27° M

A. 1790:

Tenants to de-Ten ants to de-

Conference to be desired.

Selby*, &c. Instate Bill passed.

Report on Tonline Act.

Lardehip* have agreed, without any Amendment; in which Bills the Tenants of Houses or I^ands on whom Rates and Assessments were to be levied for certain public Purposes, mentioned in such Bills, were permitted to deduct the same, or some Proportion thereof, out of their Rent, which Deduction was directed to be allowed in Account by the Persons to whom such Rent was payable. '

The Instances are as follow;

8 Geo. III. Coventry Goal. Tenants to deduct Half the Rates.

8 Geo. III. Hertford Shire House.

duct the whole Rate.

9 Geo. III. Nottingham Shire Hall.

duct the whole Rate.

23 Geo. III. Salop New Shire Hall and Guildhall.

Tenants 8t full or improved Rent may deduct the whole Rate.

26 Geo. III. Salop Gaol. Tenants to deduct the whole Rate.

27 Geo. III. Stafford Gaol. Tenant to deduct the whole Rate.

29 Geo. III. Essex Shire House. Tenants to deduct Half the Rate.

For these and other Reasons, which have induced the Commons to disagree as well to the First as to the Third of your Lordships Amendments, and which other Reasons the Commons decline offering at present, the Commons hope that your Lordships will not insist on such of the Amendments proposed by your Lords!tips as the Commons have disagreed to, as the Loss of the Bill will, as the Commons apprehend, be attended with considerable public Inconvenience.

The said Reasons being severally read a Second Time, were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Conference be desired with the Lords, upon the Subject Matter of the Amendments made by their Lordships to the said Rill.

OrderedrThat Mr. Pole Carcw do go to the Lords, and desire the said Conference.

An ingrossed Bill for divesting out of the Crown the Reversion in Fee of and in certain Hereditaments, heretofore the Estate of Sir Roger Strickland, Knight, deceased, in Catterick and Tunstall, in the County of Vrn'k, and for vesting the same in the several Persons entided to the said Hereditaments, and for extinguishing and destroying a certain Term of One hundred Years, for which the said Hereditaments were limited in Trust for his late Majesty King George the FirsJ, his Heirs and Successors, was read the Third Time. '

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act for divesting out of the Crown the Reversion in Fee of and in certain Hereditaments, heretofore the Estate of Sir Roger Strickland, Knight, deceased, in Catterick and Tunstall, in the County of York, and for vesting the same in the several Persons entitled to the said Hereditaments, and for extinguishing and destroying a certain Term of One hundred Years, for which the said Hereditaments were limited in Trust ifor his late Majesty King George the First, his Heirs and Successors.

Ordered, That Mr. Gilbert do make the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom it was referred to consider of an Act made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising " a certain Sum of Money, by Way of Annuities, " to be attended with the Benefit of Survivorship, in " Classes."

Mr. Gilbert accordingly reported from the said Committee, the Resolution which the Committee had

directed to be reported to the House; which he nead in his Place; and afterwards delivered in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the same was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Resolved, That it is the Opinion of this Committee,

That such Persons as have contributed towards raising the Sum of One Million Two thousand Five hundred Pounds, under the Authority of an Act of the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for raising " a certain Sum of Money, by Way of Annuities, to " be attended with the Benefit of Survivorship, in " Classes," who shall be desirous of converting each Share of One hundred Pounds and Five Shillings, so contributed towards raising the said Sum of One Million Two thousand Five hundred Pounds, into a Jong Annuity for the same Term, with certain Annuities established by an Act, made in the First Year of His present Majesty, for the Term of Ninety-nine Years, from the 5th Day of January 1761, shall be at Liberty so to do upon giving Notice of such their Desire to the Chief Cashier of the Governor and Company of the Bank of England, at any Time before the 1st Day of September 1790.

The said Resolution being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That a Bill be brought in upon the said Resolution: And that Mr. Gilbet'i, Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. Edxoard James Eliot, the Earl of Mornington, the Lord Bayham, Mr. Attorney General,

Mr- Solicitor General, Mr. Rose, and Mr. Steele, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Mr, Pole Carew reported to the House, That he The Lords having, according to Order, been with the Lords, to desire a Conference upon the Subject Matter of the Con erenec' Amendments made by their Lordships to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enlarging and better regulating the Gaol for the County of Warwick, the Lords do agree to a Conference, and appoint the same presently, in the Painted Chamber.

Ordered, That the Committee who were appointed Managers to draw up Reasons to be offered to the Lords, at a appointed. Conference, for disagreeing to such of the Amendments made by their Lordships to the said Bill, as this House hath disagreed to, do manage the Conference.

Ordered, That Mr. Burke, Mr. Francis, Sir Joseph Maxcbey, Sir William Young, Mr. Milford, and General Burgoyne, be added to the said Managers.

And the Names of the Managers were called over; and they went to the Conference.

And being returned;

Mr. Frederick Montagu reported, That the Managers Conference had been at the Conference, and had delivered to the reported. Lords the Reasons for disagreeing to such of the Amendments, made by their Lordships to the said Bill, as this House hath disagreed to; and had left the Bill, and Amendments, with their Lordships.

A Petition of the Master, Wardens, and Com- Petition monalty, of Merchant Venturers of the City of Bristol, against the under their Common Seal, was presented to the House, and read; Setting forth. That, by a Bill depending in the House, for regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign Com imported, and on British Corn exported, there' are contained Clauses subjecting to Forfeiture any Ship or Vessel, and all her Guns,

Furniture, Ammunition, Tackle, and Apparel, in which any of the Articles mentioned in that Act shall be found, contrary to the Provisions of it: and that Penalties like those, so very excessive, and which fail not on the Offender, but on the Innocent, cannot but injure the Commerce, and ultimately the Resources and Revenue «f the Kingdom, and the 02 Petitioners

30 Geo. III.

27° M

515

Petitioners conceive, that the Purposes of the Bill may be effected with equal Certainty by Penalties more adequate to the Offence, and involving in the Punishment those only who have committed it: And therefore praying, That those Clauses in the said Bill, which the Merchant and Shipholder cannot but have the justest Reason to dread, may not pass into a Law, but that the Bill may undergo such Alteration as the House shall deem expedient.

Petition A Petition of the Merchants and Buss Owners of

against the the Borough of Rothesay, was also presented to the House, and read; Setting forth, That, by an Act, passed in the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty, the Importation of Oat-meal iuto Scotland is prohibited, unless when the Price of that Article exceeds Sixteen Shillings per Boll, while the same Article is allowed to be imported into England when the Price of Oats amounts to Sixteen Shillings per Quarter, which is nearly equal to Thirteen Shillings and Four Pence per Boll of Meal, and, by a Bill now depending in the House, the same Restriction is proposed to be continued; and that the Petitioners live in an Island, the Annual Produce of which, though indeed fruitful, is insufficient for the Maintenance of the Inhabitants of Rothesay for One-Fourth of the Year: That above a Hundred Vessels belong to the Port, most of which are employed in the British White Herring Fishery, and the Advantages derived to the Public from such a Nursery for Seamen are so well known, as to render them unnecessary to be enumerated: And, when it is considered how inadequate the Produce of the whole Island is to the Maintenance of that Place alone, what a vast Quantity of Provisions is necessary for so many Busses, and that Oat-meal, a principal Article, is only to be had at the highest Rate, which must prove highly prejudicial to the Fishing, as well as the Manufactures of Scotland in general, by raising the Wages of the Labouring Poor, it is presumed the House will be disposed to look upon the Difference between Scotland and England, in regard to the Importation of Grain, as truly impolitic and partial, and will, in future, permit the Importation of it into Scotland upon the same Terms it is allowed to be imported into England; and that by the above-mentioned Act the Importation into, and Exportation from, the different Counties is regulated by the Price of Grain in each County, whereas, by the said Bill, it is proposed to divide Scotland into different Districts, and to regulate the Importation and Exportation by the Average Price of Grain in each District; and that the District, in which the said Borough is to be comprehended, is proposed to consist of the Counties of Lanark, Dumbarton, Argyle, Ayr, Bute, JVigton, the Western Islands, and the West Coasts of the Counties of Inverness, Ross, Sutherland, and Caithness, but the Petitioners submit to the House, that the Importation of Grain to that Place, where there is so great a Demand for it, ought not to be regulated by the Prices either in the plentiful County of JVigton, or the thinly inhabited Western Islands, but by the Price in the County of Bute, or at least by the Average Price in it, and the adjoining Counties of Renfrew, Lanark, Dumbarton, Ayr, and Argyle, and, the Petitioners beg Leave also to submit, that in ca9e of any Importation when the Port is shut, that the Meal or Grain imported should be allowed to be Warehoused in joint Custody till the'--Port shall be opened: And therefore praying the House to alter or amend the aforesaid Bill in the Manner submitted by the Petitioners, or to give them such Relief as to the House shall seem just.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for regulating the Importation and Ex--Yol. 45.

portation of Cent, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign Corn imported, and of the Bounty on British Corn exported, was re-committed, be taken into further Consideration.

Th«L. Residue of the Amendments, made by the Committee to the said Bill, being severally read a Second Time, ftece, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

A Clause was offered to «be added to the Bill, for enforcing the Payment of Penalties by Admirals or Commanders at Sea, or by the Governors in the West Indies, or by the Officers of His Majesty’s Customs.

Debate on Motion respecting the Complaint against Mr. Scott, resumed.

A. 1790.

And the said Clause was Twice read, with a Blank; which being filled up, the said Clause was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Another Clause being offered to be added to the Bill, specifying the Courts where the several Penalties might be sued for and recovered;

An Amendment was proposed to be made to the said Clause, by leaving out the Words " in any Court " of Vice Admiralty in any Part of America, or in u any Island in the West Indies, wherein any such Offence shall have been committed, or wherein " any such Ship or Vessel shall, have disposed of the " Whole, or any Part of the Cargo, or."

And the Question being put, That the Words proposed to be left out stand Part of the Clause;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

And the said Clause was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House, to be made Part of the Bill.

Then several Amendments were made, by the House, to the Bill.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be ingrossed.

The Order of the Day being read, for resuming the adjourned Debate on the Motion made upon Friday last. That it appears to this House, that the Letter contained in a printed Newspaper, intituled, " The Diary; or, Wood faits , Tuesday, May

" 18, 1790," which Letter is addressed to the Printer of the said Newspaper, and signed " John Scott," dated Bromley, May 16, 1790, is a scandalous and libellous Paper, reflecting on the Honour and Justice of this House, and on the Conduct of the Managers appointed to manage the Impeachment, now depending, Against Warren Hastings, Esquire;

And the House being informed, by a Member in his Place, That John Scott, Esquire (having, since Friday last, when he was heard in his Place, had Reason to believe that what he then offered to the House had not been fully understood by several of the Members who heard him) desired that he might have Leave to explain more particularly what he had then said;

The said John Scott, Esquire, being, with Permission of the House, come into his Place, was further heard.

And being again withdrawn, the House resumed the said adjourned Debate.

And the Question being again proposed;

Resolved, That it appears to this House, That the said Letter is a scandalous and libellous Paper, reflecting on the Honour and Justice of this House, and on the Conduct of the Managers appointed to manage 'the Impeachment, now depending, against Warren Hastings, Esquire.

A Motion was made, and the Question was proposed, That John Scott, Esquire, a Member of this House, having acknowledged himself the Writer of the said Letter, is thereby guilty of a gross and scandalous Violation of his Duty as a Member of this House, and of a high Breach of the Privilege of this House.

And the said Motion was, with Leave of the House, withdrawn.

A Motion was made, and the Question being proposed, That John Scott, Esquire, a Member of this House, being, by his own Acknowledgment, the Author of the said Letter, is guilty of a Violation of his Duty as a Member of this House, and of a high Breach of the Privilege of this House;

And the previous Question being proposed. That that Question be now put;

The said Motion for the previous Question was, with Leave of the House, withdrawn.

Mr. ScoVt voted guilty of a Breach of Privily e.

Ordered to be reprimanded.

Bill for altering the Do tie* on Liquors Licences, deferred.

Resolved, That John Scott, Esquire, a Member of this House, being, by his own Acknowledgment, the Author of the said Letter, is guilty of a Violation of his Duty as a Member of this House, and of a high Breach of the Privilege of this House.

A Motion was made, and the Question being proposed, That the said John Scott, Esquire, be, for his said Offence, reprimanded at the Bar of this House, by Mr. Speaker;

An Amendment was proposed to be made to the Question, by leaving out the Words " at the Bar of " this House/’ and inserting the Words " in his " Place " instead thereof;

And the Question being put, That the Words " at " the Bar of this House" stand Part of the Question;

It passed in the Negative.

And the Question being put, That the Words " in " his Place " be inserted instead thereof;

It was resolved in the Affirmative.

Then the main Question, so amended, being put;

Ordered, That the said John Scott, Esquire, be, for his said Offence, reprimanded in his Place by Mr. Speaker.

Ordered, That the said John Scott, Esquire, do attend this House in his Place, Tomorrow Morning.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Resolved That this House will, Tomorrow Morning, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for repealing the Duties upon Licences for retailing Wine and Sweets, and upon Licences for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, and for granting other Duties in Lieu thereof.

And then the House adjourned till Tomorrow Morning, Ten of the Clock.

A Message from the Lords, by Mr. Graves and Mr. Eames:

Mr. Speaker,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for enabling His Majesty to raise the Sum of One Million, for the Uses and Purposes therein mentioned; without any Amendment: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places, within the City of Durham and Borough of Fram-welgate, and the Suburbs thereof, and Streets thereto adjoining; for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein; for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public Passages and Places; and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs; with an Amendment; to which Amendment the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have agreed to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, logs, Commons, and Waste Grounds, within the Manor and Township of Hutton Bushell, in the North Riding of the County of York; with an Amendment; to which Amendment the Lords desire the Concurrence of this House: And also,

The Lords have passed a Bill, intituled, An Act for vesting the Manor of Fisher ton Delamere, otherwise Fisherlon Delamore, and other Hereditaments, in

the County of Wilts,devised by the Will of the most Noble Charles formerly Duke of Bolton, with the Appurtenances, in Trustees, discharged of the Uses and Trusts of the said Will, for the Purpose of more effectually carrying into Execution certain Decrees or Decretal Orders of the Court of Chancery for the Vo l, 45.

A Petition of the Owners and Agents of Ships residing Petitions in or near London, convened by public Advertisement, against the

May 22d, 1790: And also, uZiBuT

Another Petition of the Owners and Agents of Ships residing in or near London, convened by public Advertisement, May 22d, 1790: And also,

A Petition of the Owners and Agents of Ships residing in or near London, convened by public Advertisement,

May 27 th, 1790;

Were severally presented to the House, and read;

Setting forth, That the Petitioners understand that a Bill, respecting the Trade in Corn, is now depending in the House, whereby Vessels, with their Guns, Furniture, Ammunition,

Tackle, and Apparel, whatever be the Value of the same (not excepting the Case of the largest East or West Indiaman) are proposed to be made liable to Confiscation for having on Board, whether for Exportation or Importation, a single Pound Weight of Biscuit, or a like Quantity of Grain. or Flour, according to the Case, contrary to the Directions of the said Bill, though the same should happen without any fraudulent Design on the Part of the Owners, and without their being, in the smallest Degree, privy thereto, or though placed on Board by some evil-minded Person or Persons maliciously, or with a View to the Profit to arise from a collusive Seizure, which Seizure may forthwith be made by any Officer of His Majesty’s Customs, no discretionary Power being vested any where to judge of the Intention of the Parties, or to lessen the Penalty where the Case merits that it should be mitigated; and that the Petitioners feel the greatest Alarm on this Occasion, which they are well persuaded will become general, should the Clauses of the said Bill, directing the said Penalties on Ships, and their Appurtenances, pass into a Law, and thereby materially affect, not only the Petitioners, but the Navigation, as well as Trade, of this Country, on which the general Welfare of the Empire so much depends, since it cannot be expected that Persons should be willing to invest their Property in Shipping, when laid under such heavy Discouragements: And therefore praying, That the Parts of the Clauses of the said Bill, which affect Ship Owners, as such, be omitted, and Penalties be substituted that shall fall upon such Persons, whatever be their Description, as shall be found Aiding and 06 abetting

Westminster Paving Bill reported.

Tontine Bill committed.

Sir Peter Burrell's, &c. Kstate Bill read.

American and h’a#t Florida Sufferers Bill passed.

abetting in the Exportation or Importation of Grain, Flour, or Biscuit, contrary to the Directions of the said Bill, which Penalties, together with the Forfeiture of such Goods, and the Fine in Triple the Value of the same in Cases of Exportation, as provided by the said Bill, the Petitioners trust will appear amply sufficient to enforce the Regulations in View in the said Clauses.

And the said Petitions were severally ordered to lie upon the Table, until the Report from the Committee of the whole House, to whom the Bill for regulating the Importation and Exportation of Corn, and the Payment of the Duty on Foreign Corn imported, and of the Bounty on British Corn exported, was re-committed, be taken into further Consideration.

Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor reported from the Committee, to whom the Bill to explain, amend, and render more effectual, several Acts, made for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places, within the City and Liberty of minster, and Parts adjacent, and for putting certain Streets therein mentioned, commonly called Optional Streets, under the Management of Committees, to be Annually chosen by the Parish or Precinct wherein such Streets are situate, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments in the said Streets, and other Places, and for other Purposes, was committed; That the Committee had examined the Allegations of the Bill, and found the same to be true; and that the Committee had gone through the Bill, and made several Amendments thereunto, which they had directed him to report to the House; and he read the Report in his Place; and afterwards delivered the Bill, with the Amendments, in at the Clerk’s Table: Where the Amendments were Once read throughout; and then a Second Time, One by One; and, upon the Question severally put thereupon, One of them was disagreed to, and the rest were agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That the Bill, with the Amendments, be iugrossed.

And the said Order being read accordingly;

Ordered, That a Committee be appointed to inspect Committee to the Lords Journals, in relation to their Proceeding on Lords Jour the Trial of Warren Hastings, Esquire; and to report naisinrela-what they find therein to the House. tion to Mr.

Ordered, That the Committee, who were appointed Hastings’ to be the Managers to make good the Articles of Impeachment against the said Wirren Hastings, Esquire, be the said Committee.

John Scott, Esquire, attending in his Place, according Mr. Scott to Order, was reprimanded by Mr. Speaker, as the reprimanded. House had directed.

Mr. Speaker spoke to him in the following Manner:

Mr. Scott,

The House have resolved that you, being the Author of a Letter, which the House have declared to be a scandalous and libellous Paper, reflecting on the Honour and Justice of this House, and on the Conduct of the Managers appointed to manage the Impeachment now depending against Warren Hastings, Esquire, are guilty of a Violation of your Duty as a Member of this IIo u?e, and of a high Breach of the Privilege of this House.

On the Nature and Magnitude of your Offence it is unnecessary for me to dwell: Whatever has a Tendency to depreciate the Honour and Justice of this House, particularly in the Exercise of its Inquisitorial

Functions,

520

28° M

A. 1700.

Functions, tends, in the same Proportion, to weaken and degrade the Energies and Dignity of the British Constitution.

The Privileges of this House have a Claim to the Respect of every Subject of this Country; as a Member of this House, it is your Duty, as it is a Part of your Trust, to support and to protect them. Had a Sense of these Obligations produced its due Influence on your Mind and Conduct, you would have avoided the Displeasure of the House, and I should have been spared the Pain of declaring to you the Result of it. The Moderation of the House is not, however, less manifest on this Occasion than their just Sense of their own Dignity, and of the Importance of their own Privileges. It is my Duty, in addressing you, to be guided by the Lenity which marks their Proceedings; and, in the Persuasion that the Judgment of the House will operate as an effectual Admonition to yourself and to others, I forbear to say more than that the House have directed, that I reprimand you for your said Offence: And, in Obedience to their Commands, I do reprimand you accordingly.

Mr. Scott's Whereupon Mr. Scott said,

Speech. *

Mr. Speaker,

I beg Leave to return you my warmest Acknowledgments for the very handsome and liberal Manner in which you have executed the Orders of the House.

I can only repeat, Sir, what I have Twice said before, that I had not the most distant Idea of violating any Privilege that the House in its Wisdom would chuse to enforce: Having diligently attended my Duty since I have been a Member, 1 have observed that Gentlemen of the first Consideration have been in the Habit of publishing to the World their Sentiments upon the most important Transactions in this House — If I have been led into an Error, it has been by taking these great Authorities for my Guide; I can only express my Concern that by so doing I have drawn upon myself the Censure of this House; and I again beg Leave, Mr. Speaker, to repeat my sincere Thanks to you for the polite and candid Manner in which that Censure has been conveyed.

Mr.Speaker’s Speech to be printed.

Motion for Address for the Date of the Answer from Sp&iu, Neg.

fell for altering the Duties on Liquors Licences, deferred.

Ordered, Nemine Contradicente, That what has been now said by Mr. Speaker, upon reprimanding the said John Scott, Esquire, be printed in the Votes of this Day.

A Motion was made, and the Question being put, That an humble Address be presented to His Majesty, that He will be graciously pleased to give Directions, that there be laid before this House, the Date of the Answer from the Court of Spain, referred to in His Majesty’s Message of the 5th Instant, and also the Date of the Receipt of the said Answer.

It passed in the Negative.

The other Order of the Day being read;

Resolved, That this House will, upon Tuesday Morning next, resolve itself into a Committee of the whole House, upon the Bill for repealing the Duties upon Licences for retailing Wine and Sweets, and upon Licences for retailing distilled Spirituous Liquors, and for granting other Duties in lieu thereof.

Bill for the The Order made this Day, for resuming the ad-Custody end joumed Consideration of the Amendment which had of CJffendert ^)een proposed to be made to the ingrossed Bill to pasted. provide for the Custody and Employment of Offenders in certain Cases, and for the Regulation and Government of the Place? in which such Offenders may be confined, after the House should have proceeded upon the Orders of the Day, being read;

The House resumed the adjourned Consideration of the said Amendment.

And the said Amendment was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

The Amendments following were also severally proposed to be made to the Bill; viz.

Pr. 3. 1. 26. After " Judges" to insert " or Justicesand after " Assize " to insert " Great Session, Oyer and " Terminer, or Gaol Deliver."

1. 33. To leave out " the," and insert " such" instead thereof.

1. 34* To leave out " of Assize," and insert " or Justices " instead thereof.

1. 39. To leave out from " committed " to " or " in 1. 40, and insert " after " the 1st Day of 1790" instead thereof.

Pr. 4. 1. 7. Before " to" to insert " or any

" Justice of the King’s Bench, " Common Pleas, or Baron of the " Exchequer, being of the Coif."

Pr. 5. 1. 1. To leave out " it shall be lawful " for."

1. 2. To leave out " Sheriff or."

1. 3. After " Offender " to insert " and is " hereby required."

I.32. After " House" to insert " for the " then Residue of the Term for " which he or she shall have been " sentenced to be transported."

Pr. 6. 1. 7. After " to " to insert " be transported, together with the Order, " or a Copy thereof, directing such " Offender to be imprisoned and " kept to."

1. 10. After " Certificate" to insert "and " Order."

1. 14. Before " to" to insert " and Order." 1. 29. After " transmit " to insert " an " attested Copy of;" and after " Certificate " to insert " and " Order."

Pr. 7. 1. 3. After " Seven " to insert "Justices." 1. io. After " Justices" to insert " or the " major Part of them."

Pr. 8. 1. 3. After " Duties" to insert " and to " such Person or Persons."

Pr. 10. 1. 13. Before " at" to insert " Great Session, Oyer and Terminer, or " Gaol Delivery."

1. 18. To leave out " of Assize," and insert " to whom such Rules and " Orders shall have been submitted."

1. 19. After " a" to insert " Certificate " or."

1. 39. After " aforesaid to insert " who " shall' subscribe such Certificate " or Declaration, as before mentioned."

Pr. 14. 1. 12. To leave out " Michaelmas."

Pr. 16. 1. 37. After " Houses" to insert " and." And the said Amendments were, upon the Question severally put thereupon, agreed to by the House; and the Bill was amended at the Table accordingly.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to provide for the Custody and Employment of Offenders in certain Cases, and for the Regulation and Government of the Places in which such Offenders may be confined.

Ordered, That Mr. Harrison do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

And then the House adjourned till Monday Morning next, Ten of the Clock.

PRAYEBS.

AN ingrossed Bill to explain, amend, and render more effectual, several Acts made for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets,. Lanes, and other Places within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, and for putting certain Streets therein mentioned, commonly called Optional Streets, under the Management of Committees to be Annually chosen by the Parish or Precinct wherein such Streets ore situate, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments in the said Streets, and other Places, and for other Purposes, was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be, An Act to alter, explain, amend, and render more effectual, several Acts made for paving, cleansing, and lighting the Squares, Streets, Lanes, and other Places, within the City and Liberty of Westminster, and Parts adjacent, and for putting certain Streets therein mentioned, commonly called Optional Streets under the Management of Parochial Committees, subject to the Control of the Commissioners appointed by, or in pursuance of, the said several Acts, and for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Obstructions, and Encroachments in the said Streets, and other Places, and for other Purposes.

Ordered, That Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

' The House proceeded to take into Consideration the Amendment made by the Lords to the Bill, intituled, An Act for dividing and inclosing the Open Fields, Ings, Colmhons, and Waste Grounds within the Manor and Township of Hutton Bushell, in the North Riding of the County of York.

And the said Amendment was read; and is as followed; viz.

Pr. 29. 1. 2. In the Interlineation leave out the Words " in Value."

And the Houste being informed that the several Parties interested in the Bill had been acquainted with the Amendment made by the Lords, and gave their Consent to the said Alteration;

The said Amendment was read a Second Time; and, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That Mr. Henry Hobart do carry the Bill to the Lords; and acquaint them, that this House hath agreed to the Amendment made by their Lordships.

An ingrossed Bill to continue, for a Time to be limited, and amend, an Act, made in the last Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act to continue, for a " limited Time, and amend, an Act made in the last " Session of Parliament, intituled, An Act to regulate, for a limited Time, the shipping and carrying Slaves, " in British Vessels, from the Coast of Africa," was read the Third Time.

Resolved, That the Bill do pass: And that the Title be. An Act to amend and continue, for a limited Time, several Acts of Parliament, for regulating the shipping and carrying Slaves, in British Vessels, from the Coast bf Africa.

Ordered, That Sir William Dolben do carry the Bill to the Lords, and desire their Concurrence.

Vol. 45.

The House proceeded to take into Consideration the Lords Amendment made by the Lords to the Bill, intituled, Amendment An Act for paving, cleansing, lighting, watching, Durham and regulating the Streets, Lanes, Ways, and public fg^ed to! Passages and Places, within the City of Durham, and Borough of Framwelgate, and the Suburbs thereof, and Streets thereto adjoining; for removing and preventing Nuisances, Annoyances, Encroachments, and Obstructions therein; for widening and rendering more commodious several of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways; and public Passages and Places; and for regulating and improving the Markets within the said City and Suburbs.

And the said Amendment was read; and is as followeth; viz.

Pr. 62. 1. 13. After " Effect" insert " and in the mean Time, and until " such Purchase, such Money " shall be placed out by the Person or Persons nominated to " receive the same, as aforesaid,

" on Behalf of such Bodies Corporate or Ecclesiastical, Corporation Aggregate or Sole,

" Feoffee or Feoffees in Trust,

" Guardian, Committee, or other " Trustee or Trustees, or from " any Feme Covert, in some " of the Public Funds, or on " Government Securities, in the " Names of Two Persons, the " one to be nominated by the " Party or Parties interested " therein, and the other by the " said Commissioners; and the " Interest arising or to be produced from such Funds of " Securities shall be paid to such " Person or Persons, or applied " for such Uses, Intents, and " Purposes respectively, as the " Rents and Profits of such " Houses, Edifices, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments,

" to be purchased as last mentioned, in case the same were " actually purchased and settled " pursuant to the Tenor and " true Meaning of this Act,

" ought to be paid and applied."

The said Amendment being read a Second Time, was, upon the Question put thereupon, agreed to by the House.

Ordered, That Mr. Michael Angelo Taylor do carry the Bill to the Lords; and acquaint them, that this House hath agreed to the Amendment made by their Lordships.

BUI to con* The House was moved, That an Act made in this Provisions of Present Session of Parliament, intituled, "An Act for Com'lndem- " indemnifying all Persons who have been concerned nity Act, " in advising or carrying into Execution certain Orders

ordered. of Council respecting the Importation and Exportation of Com and Grain, and also certain Orders " issued by the Governor General of His Majesty’s " Colonies in America, and for preventing Suits in " Consequence Gf the same, and for making further " Provisions relative thereto," might be read.

And the same being read accordingly;

Ordered, That Leave be given to bring in a Bill to continue, for a Time to be limited, certain Provisions contained in the said Act, relating to the Impo -tation and Exportation of Corn and Grain: And that Mr. Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Marquis of Graham, Mr. Comptroller of the Household, Mr. Bramstm, Mr. Hussey, Mr. Mr. Spencer

hope and Mr. Gregory, do prepare, and bring in, the same.

Committee Ordered, That the Order of the Day, for the House to SccdTt resole itself into a Committee of the whole House, to Bill.’ consider further of the Bill for laying a Duty on the Im-

portation, from any of the Provinces in NoHh of Rape Seed, and all other Seeds used for extracting Oil, and for allowing the Importation from the said Provinces of Rape Cakes, or Cakes made of Rape Seed,
